title: Bonds and Notes Up in Slow Day
description: The prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved higher in very quiet end-of-quarter trading yesterday, given a push by a drop in crude oil prices.

title: Position of Doctors On AIDS Partners
description: The American Medical Association's House of Delegates adopted the following amendment, offered by New York doctors, on how physicians should warn their patients' sexual partners if the patients are carrying the AIDS virus. It read, in part:

title: European Bank Idea Rebuffed
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said today that monetary union in the European Community would be difficult and that progress toward such integration would not necessarily involve a common European central bank.

title: Management Buyout Is Approved at Payless
description: Payless Cashways Inc.'s board of directors today approved a sweetened offer of $909 million from senior management to take the building-supplies company private in a leveraged buyout.

title: J.A.L. Orders 15 More of Boeing's 747-400's
description: Japan Air Lines has decided to buy 15 more Boeing 747's for a total of about $2 billion, a spokesman for the carrier said yesterday.

title: Reviews/Music; High-Volume Statement From Yugoslavia
description: Laibach, the Yugoslav rock band that performed last Friday and Saturday at the Kitchen, is either an ugly phenomenon or a didactic joke - and a loud one either way. Named after the word used by the German occupation forces in World War II for the Slovenian capital city of Ljubljana, Laibach arrives with songs and manifestoes espousing ''totalitarianism,'' giving up individuality to accomplish collective goals.

title: Jazz Festival; Celebrating French Jazz
description: The JVC Jazz Festival's Salute to Jazz in France at Town Hall on Wednesday was a bit like a wine tasting - it offered little sips implying larger things.

title: Rosen at Waterloo
description: The cellist Nathaniel Rosen is to be the soloist in a Waterloo Festival performance of William Schuman's ''Song of Orpheus'' tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J. (at Exit 25 on Route 80). The program, which is to be conducted by Gerard Schwarz, also includes Barber's ''Overture to the School for Scandal,'' Hanson's Symphony No. 1 (''Nordic''), Gershwin's ''American in Paris,'' and Villa-Lobos's ''Erosion - the Origin of the Amazon River.'' Tickets are $10 to $22.50. The concert is to be repeated Monday at 8:30 P.M. at the Richardson Auditorim, Princeton University, Princeton, N.J. Tickets are $22.50. Information: 307-7171.

title: Debt Sales Climb in Quarter But Stock Offerings Slump
description: Corporations continued to find the bond market a rich field for raising money in the second quarter, but investor apprehension limited their ability to find new equity capital.

title: What's Wrong With the New Law on VDT's
description: To the Editor:

title: West German Discount Rate Raised to 3%
description: In a move to stem the recent rise of the dollar, the West German central bank raised its key discount rate by half a percentage point today, to 3 percent.

title: Reviews/Music; Cerebral Solos And Standards On Saxophone
description: Anthony Braxton started his late set of alto saxophone solos at the Knitting Factory last Friday night with music that sounded like a sheaf of music crumpled and shredded -gentle melody phrases, assertive lines, trills, sputters, honks, juxtaposed every which way. Then, for the rest of the set, he put the individual pieces back together again.

title: ...But East Germans Are Intent on Staying As Is
description: Although the East German press reported fully on the keynote speech by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the Soviet party conference, East Germany's conservative leader has repeatedly made clear he has no immediate intention of importing any of the Soviet leader's program of change.

title: Most of Eastern Bloc Follows Moscow's Call for Change Intently . . .
description: The Soviet Union's closest Eastern European allies are following the Moscow party conference intently, evidently convinced that as the cards are dealt there, their own hands may be shaped in future political and economic decisions.

title: Argentina Pays Interest
description: Argentina, Latin America's third-largest debtor nation, made interest payments of around $70 million yesterday to its commercial bank creditors, it was announced yesterday.

title: Honolulu Exchange Plan
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange, which operates trading floors here and in San Francisco, said today that it had reached an agreement that it hopes will lead to the creation of another exchange in Honolulu.

title: L.I. Association Opposes Shoreham Accord
description: The Long Island Association, the Island's largest business organization, today sharply criticized New York State's agreement with the Long Island Lighting Company to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant and offered several modifications to the accord.

title: The Governors and Poor Children
description: Few states are as far from urban tumult and despair as Idaho. Yet in his State of the State speech this year, Governor Cecil Andrus stressed a problem usually associated with cities: ''We must help children at risk. We either help our children become responsible and self-sufficient, or we will pay, and pay dearly, to provide many of them with welfare or put many of them in jail.''

title: KEY RATES
Sounds Around Town
description: 3 at the Ballroom

title: Surgery for Allison
description: Bobby Allison, the race car driver who was severely injured in an accident June 19 at the Nascar Miller 500 at Long Pond, Pa., underwent surgery yesterday to install a steel rod in his fractured left leg. Allison, 50 years old, broke two bones in his lower left leg, his left ribs, his femur and suffered a concussion. His condition remained guarded after being upgraded from critical Monday. (AP)

title: Stocks Climb Broadly as Dow Gains 19.73
description: Stock prices staged a broad advance yesterday on sharply higher volume.

title: Friedman Fails In Final Appeal For a New Trial
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader who was convicted in the Parking Violations Bureau scandal in 1986, lost his final court appeal yesterday, and the judge in the case ordered him to go to prison next week.

title: On Stage
description: A Robbins Retrospective

title: DI Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $5,094,468 for debt reduction and a tax loss carryforward of $1,442,000. c-After an extraordinary gain of $15,163,591 for debt reduction.

title: MEXICANS REJECT CRITICISM FROM U.S.
description: Responding to unusually heated American protests, the Mexican Foreign Minister has declared that his Government's refusal to extradite a Puerto Rican to the United States on terrorism charges ''was in strict compliance with Mexican law'' and should not be construed as a deliberate anti-American act.

title: Former Calfed Official To Northeast Savings
description: George P. Rutland, who resigned from Calfed Inc. in May when he was passed over for the top post at the big California savings and loan institution, will head a smaller savings unit based in Connecticut.

title: REBEL ARCHBISHOP ANOINTS 4 BISHOPS
description: In a ceremony filled with cornet flourishes and angry sermons, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre brought about the first major schism in the Roman Catholic Church in more than a century today when he consecrated four bishops in defiance of the Pope's orders.

title: Strike May Make Strange TV Season
description: The television networks, which are always looking for something new and different in their program schedules, may be forced to present a fall television season that is so different it will not be recognizable.

title: Koch's Favorable Rating Falls To 36% in Poll of New Yorkers
description: With a mayoral election 16 months away, only about a third of New Yorkers now say they have a favorable opinion of Mayor Koch, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.

title: Food Lion Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 18
Jazz Festival; Mel Torme's Polished Pop
description: What is there left to say about Mel Torme, the 62-year-old pop-jazz phenomenon whose burnished baritone remains remarkably untouched by the years? The singer, who appeared with a 30-piece orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, brings a technical polish to the pop-jazz repertory that no one, save Ella Fitzgerald in her prime, has matched with such consistency. Listening to him sing ''What Are You Doing the Rest of Your Life?,'' ''The Way You Look Tonight'' and his own ''Christmas Song,'' accompanied by glowing pop-swing arrangements at Wednesday's concert, one heard the America's pop-jazz vocal tradition brought to artistic perfection.

title: Mutual Fund Sales Decline
description: Monthly mutual fund sales fell to $7.1 billion in May, compared with $9 billion in April and $13.5 billion in May 1987, the Investment Company Institute said today.

title: Review/Recital; Handling Bach With Affection
description: It's nice to come across a musician with both a heart and the technique to make its feelings clear. We seldom do. Mostly it is one or the other - as it was with the piano program by Joseph E. Fields at Weill Recital Hall on the evening of June 23.

title: Teen-Ager Convicted of Manslaughter in Fatal Fire
description: A 14-year-old who admitted setting fire to an abandoned car in Brooklyn last November, fatally burning a man inside, was acquitted of murder but convicted of the lesser charge of second-degree manslaughter by a jury that deliberated for an hour yesterday.

title: Wider Powers Backed For Nurse Practitioners
description: Specially trained nurses will be able to prescribe drugs for the first time in New York State outside of hospitals under a bill that has been passed by the State Legislature.

title: Reviews/Music; Bel Canto Opera in Cavalli's 'Calisto'
description: The Bel Canto Opera, which is still locked in a struggle with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians over collective bargaining for its occasional employees, has decided for the present to proceed with nonunion players. At the company's performance of Cavalli's ''Calisto'' Sunday afternoon at St. Bartholomew's Church, members of the Riverside Orchestra accompanied, sounding neither worse nor better than the bands assembled by this troupe in the past.

title: Isles Re-sign Smith
description: Billy Smith, a goaltender, and Mikko Makela, a right wing, agreed yesterday to contract terms with the Islanders, who also announced that Mike Bossy had been offered a personal services contract. Bossy, the club's leading career goal scorer, missed last season with a back ailment. He will be offered a player's contract if his condition improves.(AP)

title: Acquittals in Egyptian Trial
description: A criminal court today acquitted 44 police officers charged with torturung Moslem fundamentalists held in a case linked to the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat. The officers, ranging in rank up to brigadier, held posts in the Interior Ministry's Prisons Administration and the State Security Service. The case grew out of the 1982 trial of 300 Moslem fundamentalists belonging to an underground group called Holy War who were charged with trying to overthrow the Government in the wake of Mr. Sadat's assassination by Moslem extremists at a military parade in Cairo on Oct. 6, 1981.

title: Kaufman & Broad Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After losses of $512,000 and $458,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations, net of tax benefits of $400,000 and $500,000, respectively.

title: A.M.A. Urges Breach of Privacy To Warn Potential AIDS Victims
description: The American Medical Association, breaking with the centuries-old tradition of confidentiality, today strongly urged physicians to warn the sexual partners of patients found to carry the AIDS virus if there was no other way to alert them to the danger.

title: American Medical Plan Gets Support
description: M. Lee Pearce, a Miami physician who holds a 7.5 percent stake in American Medical International Inc., said he supported the request by a group of Texas investors that the board of the Beverly Hills, Calif., hospital concern form a committee to consider potential restructuring proposals. A special meeting of American Medical's board has been set for July 11 to consider the proposals from the Texas group led by the investors Richard E. Rainwater and Dort A. Cameron.

title: Conagra Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Delegates' Views: On Health, Wealth and Work
description: Discussion at the Communist Party conference has ranged over a wide variety of subjects, most not directly related to changing the political system, the ostensible focus of the meeting. Following are excerpts from some of the speeches by delegates this week, as translated by The New York Times. Yevgeny I. Chazov Minister of Health

title: 3 Are Guilty in Slaying of Grand Jury Witness
description: Three young men were convicted yesterday of the shotgun slaying of a Queens grand jury witness in a case that raised public fears about the security of witnesses.

title: Murder Defendant Is Beaten
description: A man accused of murdering two of six kidnapped women he imprisoned in a basement ''house of horrors'' was attacked by two inmates Wednesday while a jury deliberated the charges against him, officials said. The defendant, Gary Heidnik, 44 years old, suffered only bruises in the attack, which occurred in a holding cell one floor above where the jury was meeting. Mr. Heidnik is accused of luring women to his basement, where he chained them and raped them repeatedly.

title: Dry Forecast Drives Up Farm Futures
description: Soybean, grain, sugar and cotton prices rebounded yesterday as forecasters warned that the Midwest faced a new siege of hot and dry weather.

title: Tale Behind Search Warrant: Pentagon Data Believed Sold
description: Federal investigators asserted that they had overheard a Navy procurement official read bid information from contractors to a private consultant, according to Federal court documents unsealed today.

title: After 174 Years, 28 M.I.A.'s Return
description: Some were only boys when they marched to war in Canada in the summer of 1814, American greenhorns off to challenge British Redcoats steeled in battles with Napoleon.

title: Mets on Power Surge; Yanks Near Lead; Yankees 5, White Sox 3
description: Tommy John still shakes his head when he is asked how long he can continue to pitch this way. He is unsure, knowing that he has seen the end of his career before but that now, at the age of 45, he is still able to win baseball games.

title: General Public Utilities Corp reports earnings for 12mo May 31
description: The company said 1987 results are restated for the effects of a change in accounting standards concerning computation of a loss on abandonment and disallowance of plant costs.

title: Risking Double Defeat: No Arms Treaty and Bad Arms
description: ''Democracies usually do the right thing - after exhausting all the other alternatives,'' Abba Eban tells us. Nowhere is this more true than in the United States' efforts to modernize its land-based ICBM force, which after 12 long years seem still in the ''exhausting'' phase.

title: BUSH SAYS RIVALS OFFER ONLY GLOOM
description: Vice President Bush yesterday portrayed the Presidential election as a choice between two economic visions: Republican optimism and undue Democratic pessimism.

title: Wide Harassment of Women Working for U.S. Is Reported
description: A survey of Federal employees has found that more than two women in five report having been sexually harassed at work and that among all the agencies surveyed, the State Department has the worst problem.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly PALESTINIAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. COMMITTEE ON INFORMATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Wait in Gun Sales Clears Panel
description: Supporters of gun control won a victory today when the House Judiciary Committee approved an amendment to require a national seven-day waiting period in sales of pistols.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 440 money market mutual funds decreased $1.93 billion, to $264.36 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 122 institutional funds decreased $851.3 million, to $70.10 billion. Assets of the 220 general purpose funds were down $390.0 million, to $81.44 billion. The 98 broker-dealer funds decreased $689.0 million, to $112.83 billion.

title: Holiday Events Throughout the Region
description: Westchester County

title: New Image for Dukakis In a Midwestern Swing
description: Two weeks ago, the South heard from Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the crime fighter. Today, the Midwest heard from Michael S. Dukakis, the family man.

title: Advanced Institutional Mangement Software reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.P.I. Union Members Back One-Year Contract, 95 to 31
description: Members of the Wire Service Guild at United Press International voted 95 to 31 to ratify a one-year contract with the news service, the guild president, Kevin Keane, said today.

title: Iran Said to Fortify Key Strait
description: Iran has nearly completed an underground bunker that will put its Chinese-built Silkworm missiles within range of any ship passing through the Strait of Hormuz and conceal the weapons from American reconnaissance, a top American military official said today.

title: 'We Are Talking About Our Future'
description: Well, at last. Along comes a new proposal for national drug action that is clear, sensible, comprehensive, entirely doable. It is based on solid thinking about what the problems are, makes choices about priorities, sets goals and outlines organization. It could finally, finally give the country a known plan and a rational strategy for fighting narcotics.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Wednesday about a birthday celebration for Leonard Bernstein at Tanglewood in Massachusetts on Aug. 25 misstated the price range for admission tickets. It is $200 to $20.

title: Designcraft Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income and included a pre- tax gain of $1,989,000 on the sale of the company's New York City office building.

title: A Homeric Opera
description: ''The Golden Apple,'' an aopera by Jerome Moross, is to be presented by the Kurt P. Reimann Opera Studio of New York University, at the University Theater, 35 West Fourth Street, tonight at 8 o'clock. The work, which was composed in 1954, is based on sections of ''The Odyssey'' and ''The Iliad,'' but the action has been moved to Washington state, circa 1900. The Martindale, Richard Holmes and Margaret Hartmen. Robert Wallace is the conductor. The work will also be performed tomorrow evening at 8. Tickets are $12. Information: 998-5278.

title: A Suit Against Borg-Warner
description: The California Insurance Commissioner, Roxani M. Gillespie, has filed suit against the Borg-Warner Corporation seeking up to $80 million in damages as a result of the failure of Centaur Insurance, a wholly owned Borg-Warner subsidiary, to satisfy its reinsurance obligations to Mission Insurance.

title: Reviews/Music; David Murray's New Precision On Saxophone
description: The saxophonist David Murray's first set at the Knitting Factory on Sunday night could barely contain all his playing. Mr. Murray, who is a member of a generation located between the 1960's avant-gardists and today's young neo-conservatives, is changing his style, and he seems to be flaunting the fact by playing better than ever. His tone, a bit soft and wooly before, has hardened, and in places where he might have taken a holiday, not articulating every note in a run, for example, he's now become precise and meticulous.

title: About Real Estate; Homes Arising on Site of S.I. Stables
description: Three developers are creating houses on a nine-acre tract that, for as long as most Staten Island residents can remember, was the home of the Franz Reb Stables.

title: What's Wrong With the New Law on VDT's; A Source of Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: CVN Cos reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss The latest periods' figures included the full operating results of Cable Value Network. Prior to Aug. 31, 1987, when Cable Value became a wholly owned unit, results included only CVN's 50 percent interest in Cable Value. The results for the 1987 periods have been restated to the company's new fiscal reporting period. The company's annual financial reporting period was changed from a Dec. 31 calendar year to an Aug. 31 fiscal year effective Aug. 31, 1987.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Watching Party Meeting, Russians Are Wide-Eyed
description: That strange hybrid of politics and entertainment, the televised political drama, made its explosive debut here this week, bringing with it spontaneity, name calling, rapid-fire dialogue and the oddly American phenomenon of pop political stardom.

title: Iraq Says U.S. Supplied Iran With Data on Planned Raid
description: Iraq has accused the United States of supplying intelligence information to Iran that disclosed details of Baghdad's military plans to mount its successful attack on an Iranian-held oilfield last weekend.

title: Review/Dance; 'Piazza,' Grim Visions in a Garden
description: Jean-Pierre Perrault, an experimental choreographer from Montreal, brought an unusual and even unfamiliar approach to the outdoor piece that he is staging through tomorrow evening at Wave Hill, the city-owned estate on the Hudson in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Tulsa Brokerage To Be Investigated
description: The Oklahoma Securities Department will investigate the brokerage firm of Fitzgerald, DeArman & Roberts Inc., officials said. The department's administrator, Susan Bryant, said the investigation would focus on complaints about sales tactics used by the firm, which was closed Tuesday at the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: 2 S.I. Men Accused Of Sodomizing Boys In Major Abuse Case
description: Two Staten Island men surrendered yesterday to face charges of sodomizing and sexually abusing boys in what the Staten Island District Attorney described as a major investigation of child abuse in the borough.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Subscription Promoter Tries Charity
description: UP against some of the most high-powered marketing sophisticates in magazine subscription sales, M. Richard Parisi, president of Great American Magazines, is nonetheless determined to make his mark against the likes of American Family Publishers, Publishers Clearing House and Magazine Marketplace.

title: Bridge
description: Just as French toast is indignantly disclaimed by the people of France, the Chinese finesse does not come from the Orient.

title: Books of The Times
description: A Letter to Peachtree And Nine Other Stories By Benedict Keily 209 pages. David R. Godine. $17.95.

title: Tyson Wins Decision
description: Prompted by legal action brought by Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, a New York Supreme Court justice has issued a restraining order that for the time being keeps Bill Cayton, the manager Tyson recently dismissed, from collecting any of his one-third share of Tyson's purse from Monday night's victory over Michael Spinks. Tyson's earnings are expected to be about $21 million.

title: Shultz, on Latin Trip, Promises U.S. Backing
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz reaffirmed United States support for El Salvador and Honduras today as he met with leaders of the two nations to devise a common course of diplomatic action against the Nicaraguan Government.

title: South Africa Posts a Deficit
description: South Africa has recorded its first quarterly balance-of-payments deficit in four years, threatening its ability to keep up heavy foreign debt repayments and posing a dilemma for economic policy makers.

title: Article 283488 -- No Title
description: On the closing day of the fiscal year, the Koch administration, the City Council and the Board of Estimate agreed early yesterday to a $25.2 billion budget that saves 1,000 police jobs and includes a much-contested property tax increase.

title: Hooked on New York and Coming Back for More
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apache Corp., Denver, a marketer of limited partnership investments in oil and gas exploration, elected John Kocur to the new position of vice chairman. He is succeeded by Francis Merelli as president and chief operating officer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 Dismissal of four Soviet leaders, including President Andrei A. Gromyko and the editor of Pravda, was urged by a Moscow conference delegate. His demand was broadcast on the main Moscow television news show. Page A1

title: Mozart Operas
description: Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' and ''Cost Fan Tutte'' are to be performed this weekend by the opera department of the Brooklyn Conservatory at the South Street Theater, 10th Avenue at 42d Street. The performances, featuring student casts, are to be sung in English under the direction of Thomas Schilling. ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' is to be presented tonight and tomorrow at 8, and Sunday at 2 P.M. ''The Magic Flute'' is to be performed tomorrow at 2, and Sunday at 8 P.M. Tickets are $12. Information: (718) 622-3300.

title: At Least 14 People Wounded In Downtown Pretoria Blast
description: A bomb exploded in a busy shopping center in downtown Pretoria today where the air force has its headquarters, and at least 14 people were wounded, the police said.

title: Organ-Music Sampler; Organ-Music Sampler
description: Nicolas Kynaston, who served as organist at Westminster Cathedral in London between 1961 and 1971 and has worked since as a concert artist, closed Donald Joyce's venturesome Monday night organ recital series at the Church of St. John the Evangelist.

title: John Cage Is Focus Of Outdoor Concerts
description: The Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden, at the Museum of Modern Art, is for many people a kind of spiritual haven within the city: a place one can spend a few contemplative hours among the trees and reflecting pools, surrounded by works of Rodin, Moore, Picasso and Matisse, without leaving midtown. And during July and August, the museum provides a musical counterpart to its outdoor sculpture collection, in the form of its free Summergarden concerts, offered on Fridays and Saturdays at 7:30 P.M. (the sculpture garden, at 14 West 54th Street, opens at 6).

title: INSIDE
description: Inside Coca-Cola The world's best-selling soft drink is flavored with a non-narcotic extract from coca, the plant from which cocaine is derived. Page D1. U.S. 'Debtor' Status Grows The stake held by foreigners in the United States has risen sharply. The trend could eventually hurt Americans' standard of living. Page D1. Graf and Navratilova in Final Martina Navratilova beat Chris Evert and Steffi Graf defeated Pam Shriver to set up a rematch of last year's Wimbeldon final. Page B11. M.I.A.'s of the War of 1812 The remains of 28 American soldiers who died in the War of 1812 were returned from Canada in a ceremony at the border. Page A3.

title: Review/Dance; Platel Dances 'Swan Lake'
description: The Paris Opera Ballet is blessed with extraordinary dancers. That is certainly clear from the company's ''Swan Lake.'' Rudolf Nureyev's staging may be lugubrious, yet there have been memorable performances of its leading roles.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: S.M.U. Names Shumate
description: John Shumate, a former player for Digger Phelps at Notre Dame and an assistant coach under Phelps since 1986, was named yesterday head basketball coach at Southern Methodist University. He replaces Dave Bliss, who resigned to become head coach at the University of New Mexico.

title: Visa Waiver for Britons
description: In a gesture combining good will and good business, the State Department, starting today, will no longer require visitors from Britain to acquire visas before entering the United States. The program is designed to increase tourism and will be restricted to those who already have round-trip tickets, proving they intend to return to Britain within 90 days.

title: Study Links Crash Dieting to Slower Weight Loss
description: Athletes who repeatedly gain and lose weight may end up with slower metabolism, burning calories more slowly than normal, according to a new study. The findings lend support to the disputed theory that crash dieting causes slower metabolism, making it easier to gain weight and harder to diet in the future.

title: The Supreme Court; Justices to Consider Banning Death Penalty for Juveniles
description: The Supreme Court, in a dramatic epilogue to its just-concluded term, announced today that it would consider banning capital punishment for all juvenile murderers after it returns to the bench next fall.

title: Mexico Given Ban in Soccer
description: Mexico was banned from all international soccer competition today, including the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Standard Microsystems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter results included a $413,000 tax benefit.

title: Police Corruption Trial Under Way in Boston
description: At a trial in Federal District Court here today, the Government outlined its case against seven present and former Boston police detectives accused of systematically extorting money and favors from the owners of some of this city's most popular restaurants and nightclubs.

title: Economic Scene; Still Wanted: A Budget Plan
description: THE connection between a nation's internal and external deficits is clear: If a nation invests more than it saves and consumes more than it produces - as the United States has been doing - the excess must be covered by an inflow of foreign capital. The greater the internal budget deficit, the lower the rate of national savings and the greater the dependence on foreign capital.

title: 3 Convicted of Setting Fire To Home for Foster Babies
description: Three Queens homeowners were convicted yesterday evening of setting fire to an unoccupied house on their block to keep New York City from using it to shelter foster-care infants.

title: Reviews/Music; Voices Whispering and Jabbering
description: If Electric Phoenix, the British avant-garde vocal quartet, were the product of a proprietary recipe, the ingredients would include extract of King's Singers and a smidgen of Swingle, spiced liberally with essence of Monty Python. Its singers - Judith Rees, soprano; Meriel Dickinson, mezzo-soprano; Daryl Runswick, tenor, and Terry Edwards, bass -are versatile and virtuosic, and command an enormous range of vocal noises.

title: Our Towns; At Cooperstown, So Many Greats, So Little Time
description: Nine-year-old Timmy Brophy knew the Baseball Hall of Fame was going to be pretty great, but he didn't think it would be this great. ''Ma, look,'' he said. ''Babe Ruth's bowling ball!'' It was breathtaking.

title: Dynamics Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 11
Microwave Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Lord, Einstein Gets A Small Break in Court
description: Justice Herman Cahn of the New York State Supreme Court has lifted his injunction against Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners enough to let it respond to an invitation by the International Business Machines Corporation to attend a briefing meeting on July 11.

title: Baseball; Holman Shuts Out Braves
description: Brian Holman, making his second major-league appearance, pitched a five-hit shutout for his first victory as the Montreal Expos defeated Atlanta, 6-0, tonight and handed the Braves their fifth straight defeat.

title: Review/Recital; Young Violinist From China
description: Qian Zhou is a very young violinist from China who has been studying at the Peabody Institute and who last year won the Marguerite Long-Jacques Thibaud Competition in Paris. Miss Zhou's evening at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday radiated good health. There is muscle and weight to her sound and the right musical values seem to be in place.

title: Reviews/Film; Black Sheep in a Family
description: Though Diana Sullivan (Jill Clayburgh) is a successful Manhattan photojournalist, she is a dud as a single parent. Her pretty daughter, Grace (Martha Plimpton), who is 16 but looks older, snorts cocaine and is having an affair with one of her mother's former lovers. Diana feels vaguely alienated. She wishes her daughter would feel free to talk ''things'' over with her, but Grace is having too much fun.

title: Brazil Inflation Rate Up
description: Prices in Brazil shot up by 167 percent in the first half of this year, according to official figures. Inflation in June hit 19.53 percent, the biggest monthly increase since June 1987, when prices rose a record 26.06 percent. The new figures, which were released Wednesday, brought inflation since the start of the year to 167.74 percent, while prices rose 336.09 percent in the last 12 months.

title: Builders Weigh Major Project For Brooklyn
description: An 8 million-square-foot redevelopment project in downtown Brooklyn is being considered by the Campeau Corporation, the Canadian builder, and the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, the largest American builder of shopping centers, the heads of the companies said yesterday.

title: Jazz Festival; Gil Evans Tribute
description: Most big bands are modeled on machines, with gleaming, interlocking parts meshed in efficient arrangements. The Gil Evans Orchestra, until the death of its leader this year, was something else - a hive, perhaps, or a commune. Instead of a blueprinted clarity, there's a fertile murk from which solos rise while colleagues toss in dissonances and the rhythm eddies below; arrangements seem to tumble together and later dissolve, like a jam session in which the horn players just happen to come up with fully harmonized ensembles.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The Independence Day holiday will be observed on Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Fireworks: East River, 9:15 P.M., between East 23d and East 46th Streets. Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: Monday's collections will be conducted Tuesday. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedule, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on holiday schedule. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. title: ICH Offer Rejected
description: The board of the First Executive Corporation rejected an offer by the ICH Corporation to buy 6.3 million of its shares for $12 a share. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, First Executive, an insurance holding company based in Los Angeles, said its board would take no other action. The ICH offer is scheduled to expire on July 19. ICH, based in Louisville, Ky., offered in January to buy 11.2 million First Executive shares for $12 a share, but only 1.3 million were tendered.

title: Fannie Mae Offer
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, plans to announce on Wednesday the interest rate for a $500 million offering of indexed sinking-fund debentures due in 1993. The offering will be made through 25 dealers selected by Fannie Mae.

title: Graf Mows Down Shriver
description: She tied her shoelaces, dallied on the baseline between points and suddenly developed an inability to toss the ball on her serve, all attempts to slow down a runaway train named Steffi Graf. It got Pam Shriver eight more minutes and one more game on Centre Court, but left her with the same humbling feeling she had after last year's Wimbledon semifinal.

title: Review/Art; Haunting Heads From Abakanowicz
description: In a corner of a group show at the Marlborough Gallery is a cluster of eight recent sculptures by Magdalena Abakanowicz that may catch even her supporters by surprise. Her earlier sculptures in the show are more typical. ''Androgyn IV'' is a burlap torso perched on a wooden support like an idol, or like a figure awaiting execution. The other two are headless and armless standing figures, upright and a little wobbly, not unlike the sculptural figures of de Kooning.

title: Stretching the Limits of the Jury Consulting Game
description: The juror was a beauty reminiscent of the actress Jane Russell. Bruce Vaughn, a Dallas-based trial consultant, also noticed an ''unusually short distance'' separating the juror's upper lip from the base of her nose.

title: When Teen-Agers Kill
description: The Supreme Court's 5-to-3 decision spares the life of a condemned killer who, though he committed an atrocious crime, was only 15 years old when he did so. But this particular ruling still leaves the Court without a principle by which to decide who is too young to be executed.

title: Holiday Events Throughout the Region
description: Hudson Valley

title: Investor Group Buying S. Carolina Resort Island
description: Charles S. Way Jr. and his associates have bought themselves some choice real estate: a sparkling South Carolina sea island that had been in the hands of Kuwaiti investors.

title: Documents Sought From Contractors' Consultant
description: Federal investigators who searched the home of Fred Lackner, a military contracting consultant, were seeking documents concerning his ties to Stuart Berlin, a Navy procurement official, and to a variety of military electronics programs, Mr. Lackner's lawyer said today.

title: REview/Music; In a Park, Show Tunes
description: It's getting hard to tell the festivals apart without a scorecard, and sometimes they intersect. On Tuesday evening at Damrosch Park, in Lincoln Center, Martin Josman led the National Chorale in a free concert that the group's schedule listed as the opening performance of the New York Festival of American Music Theater - a run of 16 performances in New York and Westchester parks, through Aug. 5. But it was also the opening of WQXR's ''Sunset Music Concerts,'' which run weekly through July 26, and are broadcast live.

title: Japanese Buy U.S. Ski Area
description: Victoria Company Ltd., a Tokyo sporting goods retailer, said today that it had acquired the 1,500-acre Breckenridge ski area in Colorado from a Chicago partnership that includes the Denver investor Marvin Davis. No terms were disclosed, but real estate brokers estimated the purchase price to be near $65 million.

title: Ferraro's Son to Serve Jail Term in Apartment
description: John Zaccaro Jr. will begin a four-month sentence today for selling a quarter of a gram of cocaine. He has been given preliminary approval by corrections officials to serve the sentence under house arrest.

title: Blyth Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Theater; A Murder Most Foul, And Its Aftermath
description: In April 1966 French railway officials found a piece of a female human torso in a freight train. Within days other parts of the same body were found in boxcars across France. The only thing missing was the victim's head. The police, working with rail schedules, finally pinpointed a bridge under which all the trains carrying parts of the woman's body had passed. They soon arrested Claire Lannes, the wife of a retired railway employee, and charged her with the murder of her cousin, a deaf-mute named Marie-Therese, who had kept house for the Lannes family for 21 years. Mrs. Lannes readily confessed to the crime.

title: AT THE BAR
description: Alton H. Maddox Jr. and C. Vernon Mason are arguably the two lawyers New Yorkers most love to hate, largely because of their unorthodox and unsettling manner of proceeding in highly visible, racially sensitive cases.

title: Hoover Institution Chief to Resist Order to Retire
description: W. Glenn Campbell, conservative Republican, friend of Ronald Reagan and builder of the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace, relishes a good fight, and a difficult few weeks have given him an occasion for one.

title: 2d Leak on Phone Bid Is Reported
description: Officials of the General Services Administration said yesterday that secret bid information for a second Government telephone contract might have been leaked to competitors and that the agency had suspended bidding on the contract.

title: A Bit of Burton's Legacy
description: Richard Burton had a weakness for troubled clerics. From the high drama of ''Becket'' to the wonderfully trashy romance of ''The Sandpiper,'' he really knew how to wrangle with his conscience. Whether he was playing the archbishop or the adulterous minister, his eyes grew piercing, his voice projected from deep in the diaphragm.

title: How Coca-Cola Obtains Its Coca
description: For years people have speculated about the secret formula of Coca-Cola, and the ingredients its contains. The formula has been locked in a bank vault, and only a few executives can see it.

title: Swiss Ban Inside Trades
description: A new law making insider trading a criminal offense in Switzerland takes effect Friday amid a growing number of investigations by the United States Securities and Exchange Commission into Swiss links to illegal dealing.

title: City Agency Found in Contempt in Myerson Case
description: A Federal judge held the New York City Department of Investigation in contempt of court yesterday for failing to turn over investigative files to the defense in the Bess Myerson case.

title: Angolan Rebel Chief Meets Reagan
description: Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan rebel leader, met with President Reagan today and said afterward that the President had agreed with a plan he presented to bring peace and reconciliation to Angola.

title: Reviews/Music; Ysaye Quartet Performs Modern Works
description: The First New York International Festival of the Arts reserved a space on its schedule to present the winner of the Evian International String Quartet Competition, and the prize foursome duly appeared Tuesday evening in Weill Recital Hall. It is the Ysaye String Quartet from France, which is named for a magnificient Belgian violinist who, in addition to playing the solo repertory with refinement and charisma, did much to advance the cause of chamber music in France.

title: Harlem Dance Theater
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem and the Universal Symphony Orchestra, directed by Gail Hightower, are to perform Borodin's ''Polovetsian Dances,'' Stravinsky's ''Firebird Suite,'' and Alex North's ''Streetcar Named Desire'' at City Center, 131 West 55th, tonight at 8. The program will be repeated tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M., and a second program, which includes works by Copland and Tchaikovsky, will be offred on Sunday at 3 P.M.. Tickets are $15 to $40. Information: 947-5850.

title: TWO IN U.S. INQUIRY USED BY NORTHROP
description: The Northrop Corporation has employed two of the military contracting consultants linked to the Pentagon fraud and bribery investigation, a company executive said today.

title: Cane Favorite Named
description: Runnymede Lobell, who has won his last 13 races, including 6 this year, was made the 4-5 favorite among the 21 entries in the $583,790 Cane Pace for 3-year-olds at Yonkers Raceway Sunday night. The son of Nero, who is owned by the Bayama Farms and Normand Mondoux, improved his earnings this year to $705,460 with a victory at a mile in 1:54 4/5 last Saturday in the $1,043,000 final of the North America Cup at the Greenwood track in Canada.

title: New Court Setback for Carbide in Bhopal Case
description: An Indian judge has issued an injunction temporarily barring the Union Carbide Corporation from making any out-of-court settlement with individual victims of the Bhopal gas leak.

title: Isaac Molho, 83, Founded French Bookstore
description: Isaac E. Molho, the co-founder of the Librairie de France in Rockefeller Center, died of heart failure Monday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: All Sides in Nicaragua Get Plea From Bishops
description: Nicaragua's Roman Catholic bishops today called on the Sandinista Government, opposition political parties and contra leaders to renew their political discussions and reach agreements that guarantee ''an irreversible democratization and pacification of the country.''

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Holiday Bonanza at Belmont
description: The three straight days of Grade I stakes racing at Belmont Park that begin tomorrow look like a bonanza for fans of good horses, small fields and smaller odds.

title: Holiday Events Throughout the Region
description: New Jersey

title: Edward Sulzberger Is Dead at 80; President of Real Estate Concern
description: Edward Sulzberger, a patriarch of the New York real estate industry who was chairman of the board and former president of Sulzberger-Rolfe, died last night at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: Review/Theater; A Romantic Interlude
description: Bob Morris's explorations of a gay man's place in a heterosexual world are becoming wittier. ''A Circle,'' his new play, being presented at the Theater for the New City as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, twists the familiar boy-meets-girl story into a funny adventure in self-discovery.

description: The use of crash-data recorders on turbine-powered commuter airliners will greatly expand, under new rules announced by the Government yesterday.

title: Delay Sought On Mulheren
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, asked for an extension of the deadline of next Tuesday for seeking an indictment of John F. Mulheren, a takeover stock speculator who is suspected of engaging in a stock parking scheme, people close to the investigation said yesterday.

description: The year-ago period included a writeoff of $229 million related to its Vogtle Nuclear Project. The year-ago figures are also restated to reflect the merger with Savannah Electric and Power Co., effective March 3, 1988.

title: L. W. Beilenson, 89; Helped to Form Unions
description: Laurence W. Beilenson, a lawyer who helped establish the Screen Actors Guild and other Hollywood unions in the 1930's, died Monday of a stroke. He was 89 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: The Cost of Glasses, Wrongly Magnified
description: In 49 states, you can buy reading glasses without a prescription. Why not in New York? Because optometrists and opticians don't want the competition, and have successfully disguised their self-interest as medical prudence. This may be the year, however, when a majority in the Legislature is finally brought to serve the interest of the general public.

title: Mauling the Mallers at Manassas
description: More than 60,000 spectators recently gathered at Gettysburg, Pa., for a partial re-enactment of the great battles of July 1-3, 1863. That's a crowd about two-thirds the size of the Army of Northern Virginia that Robert E. Lee led into the crucial struggle of the Civil War, 125 years ago today.

title: Wyoming Finally Raises Its Drinking Age
description: Deanna Howard is a bartender at the Buck Horn Bar in this college town. But with the stroke of midnight tonight, she will not be allowed to buy a drink at the bar where she works.

description: The dollar continued to show strength yesterday, rising slightly against the yen while dipping only a bit against the West German mark.

title: RJR to Pay Fine In Boycott Case
description: The Commerce Department said it had fined RJR Nabisco Inc. $97,000 for 23 reported violations of the anti-boycott provisions of Federal law. It said RJR had settled the charges by agreeing to pay the fine. The settlement terms did not require the Atlanta-based tobacco and food products conglomerate to admit guilt. RJR was formed in 1986 from the merger of Nabisco and R. J. Reynolds.

title: Mayor Received Help In Plot, F.B.I. Charges
description: An extortion plot against a housing developer in Wayne, N.J., involved a second person besides Mayor Louis V. Messercola, an F.B.I. complaint charged yesterday.

description: Hours after the disclosure today that three White House guards had been suspended for suspected off-duty use of cocaine, the White House announced a random drug-testing program for employees of the Executive Office of the President.

description: The latest quarter's revenue included $17,017,822 in sales from Polymer's new Envirocon unit. The latest year included a gain equal to 51 cents a share from the public offering of about 26 percent of Polymer's interest in its Canadian subsidiary.

Fiddles, Fireworks And Shakespeare For the Fourth
description: THANKS to the fortuitous timing of the Declaration of Independence 212 years ago, the United States celebrates its birthday at a time when warm weather turns most people's thoughts to the great outdoors. Even in New York City, where the outdoors is all too often assumed to be a crowded intersection or a forest of tall buildings, that more gentle and natural outdoors - of parks, rivers and beaches - will be the stage on which dozens of festive dramas will be played this holiday weekend.

title: Eric T. B. Gross, Engineer, 87
description: Dr. Eric T. B. Gross, an engineer and educator, died of Parkinson's disease Monday at his home in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 87 years old.

description: Bertram Metter, the J. Walter Thompson executive who resigned under its old management, is returning to his old title of chairman of the domestic company.

description: Gold sales in the Soviet Union seem to be running at normal levels despite market rumors that Moscow has been a substantial seller in recent weeks, dealers in Europe and Asia said today.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Monday about the International Advertising Film Festival misidentified the airline client of the Leo Burnett Company whose advertising won a Gold Lion. It is United Airlines.

description: Government officials, scientists and environmentalists from 48 countries called today for immediate action to halt degradation of the earth's atmosphere and set targets for global reductions in the burning of fossil fuels.

description: The share earnings after preferred stock dividends were 6 cents a share for the latest year, compared with 9 cents a share for 1987.

description: The Mets played last night as if they were still soaring from the two-out home run that Howard Johnson launched in the ninth inning in Pittsburgh Wednesday night. The home run tied the score, and the Mets won two innings later.

description: To some, particularly among American Catholics, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre is primarily a defender of the Latin Mass and the precise question-and-answer catechisms they knew in the years before the Second Vatican Council.

description: As Meade H. Esposito pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal bribery and tax-fraud charges, his lawyer asserted that the 81-year-old former Brooklyn Democratic leader had become the victim of a Government ''vendetta'' because he has ''a name that creates media attention.''

title: The Arts Festival; Pop/Jazz; Salsa Salute Coming To Carnegia
description: When Mario Bauza went into business with his brother-in-law, he made jazz history. Mr. Bauza was a jazz trumpeter, composer and arranger, born in Cuba and flourishing in Harlem; his brother-in-law was Frank Grillo, better known as Machito, a singer and percussionist. Machito had arrived from Cuba in 1937 and sung around New York with Xavier Cugat and other bandleaders, but in 1940 he was ready for his own group. Mr. Bauza, his music director, concocted arrangements that topped Cuban dance rhythms with the most sophisticated jazz harmonies and melodies of the day, and after three months of rehearsal, Machito's Afro-Cubans unveiled music that turned New York on its ear.

title: Mildred Gillars, 87, Axis Sally During War
description: Mildred Gillars, known during World War II as Axis Sally for her propaganda broadcasts for Nazi Germany, has died. She was 87.

title: Reunion of Old Champions
description: SHE stood at the baseline, hoping for some kind of intervention, divine or otherwise, to prolong her match against her old rival. Even when she saw the linesman at the opposite end of the court extend his hand, she wanted to grasp the moment and hang out a little longer at Centre Court.

description: LEAD: June 20, 1988: Dear Diary, a historic day! The Supreme Court voted unanimously to uphold New York City's Public Law 63. Now I'm finally entitled to join any large, private all-male club. No more hanging around outside the Union League Club after work, scavenging for important business tips.

title: St. Regis Checks Out For a Year
description: He arrived in his kitchen yesterday at 6 in the morning, as usual. He oversaw breakfast and worked on his special for the day, sea bass meuniere - a simple dish, he said. The fish was lightly smoked for 15 minutes, sauteed with clarified butter and touched up with a thin layer of butter, lemon juice and parsley.

description: Memorial stones for Henry James and Henry David Thoreau will be placed in the American Poets' Corner at the cnclusion of vespers on Oct. 23 at 7 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street.

description: This was the 78th meeting in their rivalry, one that began when Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova were the child stars of women's tennis, only beginning to make their presence felt. Starting with that first meeting in 1973, they have played on clay and hard courts, indoors and on concrete, and on nine occasions they have curtsied in perfect unison in front of the Royal Box, then traded forehands on Wimbledon's grass courts.

description: The French mineral water group Source Perrier plans a substantial expansion in the United States in the next few years after several recent acquisitions, its chairman, Gustave Leven, said at the company's annual meeting at its headquarters in southeastern France.

description: In the latest quarter and year, the company had a $33 million writedown of intangible assets related to its California cooler business; it received $22 million from the sale of a jewelry division, and an additional $5 million benefit because of a reduction in foreign tax accruals.

description: A throng of cheering Cambodians lined an airport road today as Vietnam pulled its military leaders out of Cambodia, loosening its grip on the country after nearly a decade of combat.

title: Book on Greek Leader Stirs Diplomatic Dispute
description: It started out last year as a harmless sounding project: a book by American and Greek authors about the administration of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece, edited and published by Greek-Americans. But now, two months before publication, the project has created a stir involving the State Department, the Greek Embassy and others associated with it.

description: At noon yesterday, Molly C. Yard, the president of the National Organization for Women, carried to the steps of the nation's Capitol petitions bearing 100,000 signatures calling for passage of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

description: College-bound only a week ago, two Bronx youths were arraigned last night on attempted murder and other charges in what the police called a 45-minute crime spree by five prep-school classmates that ended in the death of one and possibly ruined lives for the others.

Mr. Tikoo wants to build the world's biggest luxury cruise liner in the Belfast yard, which has 4,000 workers. title: Review/Art; Paintings That Reflect Colonial Puerto Rico
description: With ''Jose Campeche and His Time,'' the Metropolitan Museum of Art focuses attention on colonial Hispanic art. Several exhibitions now traveling the country celebrate the independence and vitality of contemporary Latino painting and sculpture. Against them, the Metropolitan's somber display seems a curious addendum, devoting several galleries to the Puerto Rican painter from the late 18th and early 19th centuries who best assimilated European artistic ideals.

Terms were not announced. . . . Larry Van Eman, an assistant at Oregon State the last eight years and a coaching disciple of Ralph Miller, was appointed to the staff of Jimmy Rodgers, the new Boston Celtic coach. Rodgers was captain of the University of Iowa team in 1964-65, when Van Eman was an assistant to Miller there.

description: The American entry at this year's Henley Royal Regatta dwindled further today as both Harvard's varsity lightweights and the Union Boat Club of Boston lost second-round eliminations in the Ladies' Challenge Plate for eight-oared crews.

title: No Headline
description: GOLF Three Share Lead: Morris Hatalsky one-putted 12 times yesterday as he scrambled to a 66 and a share of the first-round lead in the $900,000 Western Open in Oak Brook, Ill. Hatalsky, who won the Kemper Open earlier this month, shared the top spot with Mark Hayes and Brian Mogg. All cut six shots off par at the Butler National Golf Club. Hatalsky missed seven greens, including four of the last five, and saved par on all seven. He and Hayes played without a bogey. A last-hole bogey cost Tom Sieckmann a share of the lead and left him alone at 67. Fulton Allem and Dan Forsman were another shot back at 68. The defending champion, D. A. Weibring, had a 70.(AP) Turner Leads in Canada: Sherri Turner took advantage of comfortable playing conditions to post a bogey-free 68 for a one-shot lead after the opening round of the L.P.G.A. du Maurier Classic in Coquitlam, British Columbia. Turner sank four birdies on the front nine, including a 21-footer on the eighth hole, then parred the last nine on the 6,361-yard Vancouver Golf Club course. The $500,000 tournament, the third of the L.P.G.A.'s four majors, is the only Canadian stop on the Tour. The winner will collect $75,000.(AP) Sunningdale Pro Wins: Darrell Kestner of Sunningdale captured the final of the the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester P.G.A. championship. He beat Nick Manlios of Mount Kisco, 1 up. Thirty-two professionals from clubs in Westchester and southern Connecticut competed for two days in the $10,000 tournament at the Knollwood Country Club in Elmsford, N.Y. YACHTING Japan, Australia Gain: Kookaburra III of Australia and Bengal III of Japan won decisive match races yesterday to advance to the final of the world 12-Meter championships in Lulea, Sweden. Kookaburra III, with Peter Gilmour as skipper, finished the round-robin semifinals with a perfect 7-0 record for 7 points after winning the fleet racing portion last week. Bengal III, New Sweden and Dennis Conner's Nordstjernan all had 5 points in the standing, but Bengal's second place in the fleet race portion of the regatta sent the Japanese-owned vessel into the final. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Victory but No Record: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union said he was happy his three-week-old world record in the pole vault was safe. ''Terrible, terrible. I'm sorry,'' he said last night, having cleared the bar at 18 feet 8 1/4 inches to win the event in a Mobil Grand Prix meet in Helsinki, Finland. He set the world record, his eighth, of 19 feet 10 1/4 inches in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia. Bubka said that the Olympic gold medal would be won at a height of about 19-8 1/4. Atanas Tarev of Bulgaria came in second by clearing 17-8 1/2 with fewer misses than Harri Palola of Finland. Bubka went on to try 19-4 1/4 and failed three times. Tatyana Samolenko won the 3,000-meter race in 8 minutes 43.48 seconds, the third-best time of the year. She is the world champion at that distance and at 1,500 meters, titles she won last year in Rome.

description: The judge in the Wedtech racketeering case ruled yesterday that if Representative Mario Biaggi takes the stand in his defense, prosecutors will be allowed to explore his conviction for accepting illegal gratuities and obstruction of justice, as well as other controversies in his past.

description: The Ford Motor Company will spend $780 million to convert a former tractor plant into a modern engine plant. The action is a departure from recent practice by the Big Three auto makers, which have been buying engines from cheaper foreign sources, primarily in Mexico and South America.

title: Review/Ballet; Pittsburgh Troupe's Balanchine
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival has made a history of presenting both the new and the familiar. Its offering this week, seen on Wednesday night at the festival's Ted Shawn Theater, was the endearingly individual and adept Pittsburgh Ballet Theater, with two recently signed lead dancers from the Beijing Central Ballet.

title: Kelso Depot Journal; Fighting for a Desert Railroad Station
description: Standing under the graceful loggia of the shuttered Union Pacific Railroad depot here, staring into the vast void that fills the desert between the lonely station and the stark Granite Mountains to the southwest, it is difficult to imagine that nearly 2,000 people lived here in World War II, mining iron ore. Now the population is down to just 26 parched souls who live in a collection of ramshackle trailers. Most of the residents are railroad workers whose main job is to keep sand from drifting over the tracks.

Where else can you have Christmas in July: pine-green walls, bright red banquettes, tinsel-draped chandeliers decorated with gleaming Christmas-tree balls; ''Russian'' waiters named Salvador and Bob decked out in festive red tunics, and stargazing and Stolichnaya in abundance?

Daniell, Ionics' chairman, Cenith offered $17 a share in cash plus $8 principal amount of newly issued subordinated debentures. Ionics' shares rose 75 cents today, to $20.125, in American Stock Exchange trading.

description: James Edgar Broyhill, founder of Broyhill Furniture Industries Inc., and father of former Senator James T. Broyhill, died today. He was 96.

description: THE patent battles are just beginning over TPA, or tissue plasminogen activator, the new genetic-engineered drug that helps dissolve blood clots in patients who have suffered a heart attack.

description: A Federal district judge in New York yesterday upheld the constitutionality of the Reagan Adminstration's regulations banning Federal aid to public health clinics that provide abortion counseling or referrals.

description: A State Supreme Court Justice, Bruce Wright, has been censured by the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct for writing letters on court stationery on behalf of a woman with whom he was acquainted, and for not disqualifying himself when legal motions involving the woman came before him.

A Civil Guard spokesman said the bodies of the chief of highway traffic, Rosa de Lima Manzano, and four men were found near the wreckage on a 4,800-foot-high peak near La Cabrera, a town 45 miles north of Madrid. The helicopter left Madrid on Thursday for Aguilar de Campoo, 160 miles north of Madrid.

description: Paul Riesman, former chairman of the anthropology department at Carlton College in Northfield, Minn., died of an aneurysm Wednesday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital, near his summer home in West Cornwall, Conn. He was 50 years old and lived in Northfield.

Lawyers for Allegheny International and Spear Leeds & Kellogg, a New York brokerage house that led the effort to gain control of the consumer products company's board, announced the settlement Thursday to Chief Bankruptcy Judge Joseph Cosetti.

title: Summer Laundry Tips
description: In warm weather, dry-cleaning bills can soar. But for some garments, laundering can save money and even time, since you don't have to rely on a cleaner's schedule. Knowing what you can wash also makes vacation packing easier. Don't rush to the suds with everything you own. Constructed garments with sewn-in shoulder pads or fused facings must be professionally cleaned; so must silk organdy, taffeta and chiffon. But many fabrics labeled ''dry clean'' can be safely washed. Summer whites - cottons, linens, silks -actually benefit; repeated dry cleaning causes yellowing. If a fabric is dyed, put a paper towel under an edge or a hem and press down with moist cotton. If no color bleeds from the garment, you may be able to wash it. Some suggestions: use a mild detergent; do not rub fabric; use plastic hangers (wooden ones may stain); never use soap, fabric softeners or chlorine bleach on synthetics. FABRIC TYPE METHOD Silk Lightweight, Hand or machine wash in cold unpatterned water Linen Unlined Hand wash in cold water Synthetics Rayon-acetate Hand wash in cold water; do not blends soak (Sources: Woolite Fashion Forum; Sweaters U.S.A. Inc.)

description: Reforms of New York City's overworked foster care system have awaited the outcome of a 15-year-old lawsuit aimed at curbing the influence of sectarian agencies. The company had notified the department in May that it would file the applications seeking its first increase in rates since 1983. The company wants to raise its electricity rates 6.4 percent, or $109.2 million a year, and its gas rates about 3.5 percent, or $6.7 million a year.

title: Results Plus
description: Baseball Japan 12, United States 10: Japan, trailing by six runs after three innings, rallied for five runs in the fourth and scored twice in each of the last two innings to beat the American college all-stars, 12-10, in the fourth game of the annual Japan-United States Collegiate Series yesterday in Mito, Japan. The victory was Japan's third against one loss in the five-game series. Andy Benes of Evansville University, the N.C.A.A. player of the year and the top pick of the San Diego Padres in the recent major league amateur draft, was tagged for four hits and five runs in three and a third innings.(AP) Rowing Syracuse Advances: Syracuse University achieved the first significant American victories at the Henley Royal Regatta yesterday, capturing its opening heat of the Grand Challenge Cup, and advancing its four-with-coxswain entry in the Prince Philip Challenge Cup. The United States began this regatta three days ago with 42 entries in the 12 events for which it is eligible, but by the end of yesterday's racing only nine entries remained in competition in Henley-on-Thames, England. In an all-American heat of the Grand Challenge Cup, Henley's premier event, Syracuse defeated U.C.L.A. in this straight knock-out, side-by-side format, which distinguishes Henley from other international regattas. Away from the start at 41 strokes to the minute, the Syracuse eight led by a half boat length a quarter-mile into the mile-and-five-sixteenths course and increased the margin to three lengths. Syracuse's varsity four with coxswain beat a boat of recent Syracuse graduates to give the Orangemen their second victory of the day in the Prince Philip Cup. Syracuse will meet Northeastern, winner over Pomfret School, in a quarterfinal today. Horse Show Illinois Rider Wins Jump-Off: Laura Gorman of Highland Park, Ill., rode Kaktus to victory in the $7,500 open jump-off yesterday at the 19th annual Lake Placid Horse Show. The 29 entries in the class struggled with the muddy conditions while trying to complete the 14-jump 477-yard course. Gorman was the only rider to complete the course without knocking down a rail. Four riders had one knock-down for four faults leaving them tied for second place: Katie Prudent of Middleburg, Va., on Special Envoy, Margie Goldstein of Miami on Salute, Linda Kossick of Somers, Conn., on Non Pariel and Louis Jacobs of East Aurora, N.Y., on Desiree. Golf Eagle for Jacobsen: Peter Jacobsen scored an eagle-3 on the way to a seven-under-par 65 yesterday that lifted him into a two-shot lead after the second round of the $900,000 Western Open in Oak Brook, Ill. Jacobsen, on the rebound from a back injury that has slowed him for four seasons, completed two trips over the Butler National Golf Club course in 135, nine under par. The eagle came on the 12th hole, when Jacobsen hit a 5-iron second shot to about eight feet and made the putt. He avoided what would have been his only bogey by sinking an eight-footer on the final hole after putting his approach in a bunker. Ed Fiori and Dan Forsman shared second at 137. Fiori had a 67 and Forsman shot a 69. (AP) Bogey-Free Round for Little: Sally Little overcame damp playing conditions yesterday to shoot a seven-under-par 65 and take a one-shot lead after two rounds of the $500,000 du Maurier Classic in Coquitlam, British Columbia. The tournament is the third of the Ladies Professional Golf Association's four majors. Little had seven birdies in a bogey-free round that left her at five-under-par 139 after 36 holes of the only L.P.G.A. stop in Canada. Laura Davies of England, Debbie Massey and first-round leader Sherri Turner were next at 140. Davies shot a 71 and Massey had a 68, while Turner matched par with a 72.(AP)
