title: Reviews/Pop; 2 Saxophonists' Idiomatic Way With a Band
description: Clarence (C) Sharpe and Billy Harper, two unjustly overlooked saxophonists, came to the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night as part of its jazz festival and performed wonderfully.

title: Company News; Cannon Sells Elstree Studios
description: Cannon Group Inc., after owning London's historic Elstree Studios for less than two years, has sold it to an unnamed buyer for an undisclosed price. The studio, where George

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions yesterday about the Pentagon procurement inquiry misidentified a company named in court documents. It is the C-Cubed Corporation, not C3 Inc.

title: A Second Assault on Hunger
description: Recently I visited a soup kitchen in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn that feeds more than 600 men, women and children every day. I saw mothers with small children, elderly men and women, and jobless young adults patiently holding out paper plates for macaroni casserole and bread. Today, though New York is booming, widespread hunger is with us once more.

title: ZIP Code: 25 and Growing
description: After a quarter century, the ZIP code is still helping to smooth the flow of nearly half the world's mail.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: Hermann Volk, Cardinal, 84
description: Hermann Cardinal Volk, the former Roman Catholic Bishop of Mainz and an advocate of ecumenism, died today after a lengthy illness, his press office said. He was 84 years old.

title: WRITERS PLAN NEW OFFER TO THE INDEPENDENTS
description: As a strike by 9,000 movie and television writers drags into its 18th week, it has become more than ever a psychological war.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Company News; G.M. Engine Plan
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would invest $80 million in a project to build a new line of engines at its plant in Tonawanda, N.Y. The Mark V engine, a V-8 that is designed for use in pickup trucks, motor homes and boats, is to be introduced in the 1991 model year. The Tonawanda plant employs 4,300 and produced 1.4 million engines in 1987.

title: Iraq Acknowledges Its Use of Gas But Says Iran Introduced It in War
description: The Iraqi Foreign Minister acknowledged today that his country had used chemical weapons in its war against Iran, but said Iran had used them first.

title: Freedom From Health Fear
description: The catastrophic health care bill that President Reagan signed yesterday offers a historic expansion of Medicare - and an equally welcome advance in political maturity.

title: Key Sections From Speech by Gorbachev on Party's Guiding Role
description: Following are key sections from the speech yesterday by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, at the Communist Party conference in Moscow, as provided in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Coca-Cola Company misstated the company's public stance, in some editions, on its use of a non-narcotic derivative of the coca plant. Coca-Cola has previously acknowledged that coca is an ingredient in its cola.

title: Company News; Morrison Knudsen Stake Purchased
description: Edward F. Heil, an Illinois investor, has purchased a 6.2 percent stake in the Morrison Knudsen Corporation and said he was considering seeking one or more seats on the board of the construction and engineering concern, based in Boise, Idaho.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health page on Thursday about screening for breast cancer gave an incorrect percentage for women over 40 who said they had a mammogram in the last year; the correct figure was 17 percent. The article also imprecisely paraphrased a Federal recommendation for women between the ages of 40 and 50; they are urged to have mammograms every one or two years. A word was omitted in a quotation from Kate Ruddon of the National Cancer Institute. She said, ''Breast cancer mortality would be reduced by 30 percent if women over 50 used mammograms.''

title: 8 Nonprofit Theaters Get Grants From Fund
description: Eight nonprofit professional theaters were awarded a total of $336,000 this week by the Fund for New American Plays to assist productions of original American plays in the coming season.

title: A DEPARTMENT OF 99 MOURNS THE LOSS OF ITS 'BROTHERS'
description: LEAD: When the roof of the Hackensack Ford building collapsed yesterday, more men in the Hackensack Fire Department died than had in the department's 117-year history.

title: Business Digest: Saturday July 2, 1988
description: The Economy

title: G.M. Extends Incentives
description: The General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet, Buick and Oldsmobile divisions today extended through Sept. 28 buyer incentive programs that were scheduled to expire on Tuesday. Many of the Chevrolet rebates will be leaner, but Buick rebates will be unchanged except for those on the LeSabre, a spokeswoman said. That model was dropped from the program. Chevrolet also dropped its double rebate on the Nova and Spectrum subcompacts.

title: YANKS FADE IN 9TH
description: Ron Guidry's night was finished in the fifth inning, when the evening was still in doubt. Later, as he sat in the Yankee clubhouse, he could not quite enjoy his accomplishment.

title: Reviews/Pop; On Piano, A Pair of Originals
description: The pianist Andrew Hill, who rarely plays in New York, stepped on stage at the Knitting Factory on Thursday night and turned in an hour and a half's worth of a perfect set.

title: Jazz Festival; McKenna's Austere Pianism
description: Even in the conservative wing of jazz, where undue ostentation is frowned upon, the pianist Dave McKenna represents an unusually staid presence. Mr. McKenna, who gave a solo performance at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday afternoon as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, is a dogged melodist who eschews fancy pyrotechnics, rarely wastes a note and, having established a tempo, holds to it with a metronomic accuracy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Standard Inc., New York, said it had completed its merger with ASI Acquisition Co., which was formed by Kelso & Co., for $78 a share.

title: Sports of The Times; The Foregone Conclusion
description: THIS was as close to a sure thing as there is in tennis. Even though Martina Navratilova and Steffi Graf had been in three tournaments this year without crossing paths, everyone knew they would finally meet on Centre Court at Wimbledon in the final. According to London bookmakers, people bet so heavily on the likelihood of this happening that there was no second choice worth mentioning.

title: Reprieve for a Famed Tower on Times Sq.
description: The slim triangular office tower at 1 Times Square Plaza that has served as a New Year's Eve beacon for most of this century is likely to remain standing, largely because city and state officials responsible for redeveloping Times Square have been unable to agree on an alternative idea for the site.

title: 2 GIRLS KILLED IN COLLAPSE OF A STOOP
description: Two young girls were crushed to death and a third was severely injured yesterday when the front stoop and the archway of an apartment building in the East Village collapsed, the police said.

title: Medicare's Nursing Home Coverage Is a Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: QUARTERLY GAINERS AND LOSERS ON NASDAQ
description: Over-the-counter common stocks traded in Nasdaq that showed the largest percentage gains and losses in the second quarter. Prices are adjusted for splits, and listings exclude stocks that began the quarter trading for less than $2 a share.

title: PRETORIA PRESENTS PLAN TO BUTTRESS SEGREGATION LAW
description: Apparently bowing to pressure from the political right wing, the South African Government today proposed legislation that would lead to stricter enforcement of residential segregation and harsher penalties for offenders.

title: Consultant Seeks Affidavit
description: Melvyn Paisley, a military consultant, went to court today in a bid to obtain the affidavit secretly filed by Government investigators to search his office for evidence in the Pentagon fraud and bribery investigation.

title: WEATHER AGAIN LIFTS CROP PRICES
description: Prices of all major farm crops rose yesterday, as commodity traders abandoned the caution they usually display before a long holiday weekend. The buying was attributed to forecasts of a hot, dry weekend in the nation's drought-ridden midsection.

title: DIPLOMATS TRY TO DECIPHER WHAT FOREIGN POLICIES DUKAKIS MIGHT FOLLOW
description: When asked what they are telling their home offices about Michael S. Dukakis, foreign diplomats are likely to say they do not interfere in America's affairs and move toward the canape tables.

title: Agriculture Secretary Says Drought Aid Is Premature
description: Although noting that the prospects are ''bleak'' for any immediate relief from the drought gripping much of the Farm Belt, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng said today that it was premature to consider Federal aid or other cash payments to assist farmers.

title: Canada to End Paper $1
description: Canada's one-dollar coin will completely replace the paper dollar bill within two years, the Government has announced. The coin was introduced last year under a plan to save taxpayers $175 million (Canadian) over 20 years because coins have a longer circulation life than paper bills. Public acceptance of the gold-colored 11-sided coin has been limited, but the Government has said that production of dollar bills will end on June 30, 1989, and that the bills will cease to be legal tender about a year later.

title: 20 Indicted in Pornography Case
description: Pornography dealers who the authorities say are responsible for mailing most sexually explict material in the country were charged today in Federal indictments with distributing obscene material through the mail.

title: 10-Minute Happy Hour Heads Down the Track
description: ''The shufflers are here,'' someone yelled out, and all the regulars at Lagoda's Saloon looked up to see the end of an era.

title: MIDRED GILLARS, 87, OF NAZI RADIO, AXIS SALLY TO AN ALLIED AUDIENCE
description: Mildred E. Gillars, nicknamed Axis Sally by American soldiers in World War II for her Nazi propaganda radio broadcasts, died of cancer of the colon last Saturday at Grant Medical Center in Columbus, Ohio. She was 87 years old and lived in Columbus.

description: For a recorded complete list of events, the number in New York is 587-1111; from outside New York State, (800) 782-4369. Tickets are available from the individual theaters. title: Bridge
description: Declarers who blunder in the play often offer the time-honored excuse: ''I had a blind spot.'' This seldom mollifies their partners.

title: Construction Spending Rose 1.1% in May After April Dip
description: Construction spending advanced 1.1 percent in May as strength in office and factory construction offset weakness in other areas.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The Independence Day holiday will be observed on Monday. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Fireworks: East River, 9:20 P.M., between East 23d and East 46th Streets. Government offices: Closed. Post Offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: Monday's collections will be conducted Tuesday. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Sunday schedule, Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North on holiday schedules. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit trains on holiday schedule, buses on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Special delivery and Express Mail delivery only. Banks: Closed. Transportation: New Haven Line on holiday schedule.

title: John Peet, a Reporter Who Defected to East
description: John Peet, a reporter who defected to East Germany in 1950 while working for Reuters, died early Wednesday in his sleep after a long illness, relatives and friends said today.

title: TIGERS FIRST ROLL A 7 AND GET 11
description: Dave Bergman drove in three of Detroit's seven second-inning runs tonight as the Tigers routed the California Angels, 11-0.

title: U.S. Stops Payments on Programs Believed Tainted in Fraud Inquiry
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci today halted payments to all contractors involved in nine military programs valued at nearly $1.7 billion because of evidence in court affidavits suggesting that competition for the contracts had been tainted by fraud.

title: Sports People; Suns Release Bailey
description: James Bailey and Jeff Cook became unrestricted free agents when the Phoenix Suns decided not to offer them contracts. Cook, 31 years old, a 6-foot-10-inch forward-center, played in 33 games last season, averaging 1.5 points and 3.2 rebounds. Bailey, also 31, averaged 4.4 points and 3.2 rebounds in 65 games. Th 6-9 forward, who played at Rutgers, has had a nine-year pro career with Seattle, the Nets, Houston, the Knicks and the Suns.(AP)

title: TAPED MEETINGS DETAIL MOB PLOT TO KILL 2 GOTTIS
description: Transcripts of what Federal authorities say were Genovese crime family murder plots against two underworld rivals, John and Gene Gotti, and a reported mob associate, Irwin Schiff, were released here today at a bail hearing for three defendants.

title: KEY RATES
Patents; Microorganisms Used As an Insecticide
description: Plant Genetics Inc. of Davis, Calif., received a patent this week on a way to use microorganisms called nemotodes as an insecticide.

title: Review/Pop; New Sound Emerging For N'Dour
description: Touring the Western world with Peter Gabriel, a British rock singer, has changed Youssou N'Dour's music.

title: Turf Trade and a Tussle: Just a Berlin Kind of Day
description: Several score West Berliners scrambled across the Berlin wall at dawn today in a brief eastward flight, adding a bizarre Berlin touch to the swap of several bits of misplaced land between the two halves of the divided city.

title: COPING: WITH BURGLAR-ALARM INSTALLATION
description: Time was when a moat and a drawbridge were the preferred home security devices. Things improved, and for a while the residents of many towns could boast that they never needed to lock their doors. That too has changed in recent years, and with more than three million burglaries reported annually in the United States, burglar alarms are becoming a staple of domestic life. Roughly 800,000 such systems were sold last year, and the million mark will probably be exceeded in 1988.

title: Tharp and Six Dancers To Join Ballet Theater
description: Twyla Tharp will join American Ballet Theater as artistic associate, a position that will make her a resident choreographer with the company. Several members of Miss Tharp's own dance troupe will join Ballet Theater in what Miss Tharp called a merger rather than a dissolution of her own troupe.

title: Crash Is Laid to Pilot Mistake
description: ''A reasonable mistake in judgment'' was the most probable cause of a collision of two Army helicopters that killed 17 soldiers during night training here in March, a report by Army investigators said today.

title: ASTROS RALLY IN 13TH TO SPLIT WITH METS
description: The Mets turned into July last night with seven hours of baseball that carried them from peak to valley and from Friday to Saturday as they split a 22-inning doubleheader with the Houston Astros.

title: Your Money; Direct Purchases Of Municipals
description: THE purest play in the municipal bond market is direct investment. Some people prefer to choose their bonds directly and structure their own portfolios, rather than relying on mutual funds or unit investment trusts. But direct investing requires sizable amounts of money and the time for active portfolio management - as well as some expertise.

title: GRILL TROUBLE: TAKE CARE
description: As many as 320,000 barbecues could be ruined this July 4 weekend because glass panels on new Sunbeam grills tend to shatter and sprinkle glass on the food below.

title: First Blacks Moving to Boston Project
description: Two black families will make history this month just by moving into a public housing project in South Boston.

title: 3 Cambodian Rebel Forces Unite Over Vietnam Talks
description: In a rare public display of unity, three Cambodian opposition forces have agreed on a common front for coming talks with the Cambodian Government and Vietnam.

title: Help for Addicts
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Iraq Uses Chemical Arms

title: Patents; Electromagnetic Gun
description: The Army has patented a portable electromagnetic rail gun. The device, which propels a bullet by applying an intense electromagnetic pulse, is similar to weapons under research for use in space against missiles. The Army said the gun could fire a bullet four times as fast as an M-16, and rip apart a steel plate.

title: Razing Rumania
description: Even as Stalinism's disastrous legacies come under attack in Moscow, the old tyrannical style flourishes in Rumania. Nicolae Ceausescu's harsh 20-year rule has turned one of Europe's traditional breadbaskets into a land of legendary deprivation. He has razed acres of ancient houses and churches in Bucharest, its once-elegant capital, to make a parade ground. Now he pushes a program to destroy half the nation's villages and move their inhabitants into new ''agro-industrial'' centers.

title: L. W. BEILENSON, UNION FOUNDER
description: Laurence W. Beilenson, a lawyer who helped establish the Screen Actors Guild and other Hollywood unions in the 1930's, died of a stroke Monday. He was 89 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Company News; Santa Fe in Switch On Property Sale
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said it would retain certain West Coast properties it had previously planned to sell as part of a corporate restructuring. The decision is expected to increase the company's real estate assets by nearly $1 billion in the next five years, Santa Fe said.

title: Alajarvi Journal; Boys of Summer in the Midnight Sun
description: It is the time of year when night in much of Finland means the sun lowers itself onto the horizon and perches there until morning, when you can read on a park bench at midnight and when this northern nation's boys of summer thrill their countrymen in contests of pesapallo, or Finnish baseball.

title: Sports People; Rams Re-sign Irvin
description: Leroy Irvin, a two-time Pro Bowl cornerback with the Los Angeles Rams, was suspended from a game last November for conduct detrimental to the team. He once cleaned out his locker in anticipation of being traded. Yesterday, he agreed to a three-year contract with the Rams worth $1.65 million.

title: Have the Brawley Lawyers Broken the Law?
description: Like agile mystery writers, Tawana Brawley's lawyers have kept prosecutors hanging in suspense over proof of their charge that white law-enforcement agents abducted and sexually abused the upstate black teen-ager last fall. But because Alton H. Maddox Jr. and C. Vernon Mason are not mystery writers but lawyers, responsible for real lives not invented ones, their tactics are highly questionable. Has their conduct violated the profession's code of ethics? Beyond that, has it violated the law?

title: Company News; CSX Reports Loss; 25% of Staff to Be Cut
description: The CSX Corporation, the large shipping, railroad and energy company, took a $778 million charge today against its second-quarter earnings to lay off nearly 25 percent of its work force, and it reported a loss of $160 million for the quarter.

title: DUKAKIS HOLDS AUDITIONS FOR NO. 2 SPOT ON TICKET
description: The political imagery seemed promising: the successful son of immigrants and the square-jawed astronaut from the Midwest, two complementary emblems of the American dream.

title: Bond and Note Prices Up a Bit in Light Day
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes inched slightly higher in very light pre-holiday trading yesterday, bolstered by an early-morning decline in oil prices and continued strength in the dollar.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Bo Jackson, the outfielder-running back who suffered a severely torn left hamstring May 31, may be activated any day by the Kansas City Royals. . . . Dan Reeves of the Denver Broncos, who coached his team to the last two Super Bowls, underwent surgery for the removal of a kidney stone Thursday in Denver. A spokesman at St. Luke's Hospital said that Reeves, 44 years old, was in excellent condition and would be released in a few days.

title: 1 Dead and 42 Hurt in Lebanon
description: One person was killed and at least 42 were wounded today when cars rigged with explosives blew up near a Syrian Army checkpoint in West Beirut and near a Syrian military camp in the Bekaa region of Lebanon, officials said.

title: QUARTERLY GAINERS AND LOSERS ON THE AMEX
description: American Stock Exchange-listed common stocks that showed the largest percentage gains and losses in the second quarter. Prices are adjusted for splits, and listings exclude stocks that began the quarter trading for less than $2 a share.

title: LENDL TRAILS BECKER AS PLAY IS HALTED
description: In true soap-opera style, Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker walked off Centre Court this evening with the outcome of their semifinal match very much in doubt. Will Lendl, No. 1 in the world but frustrated time and again in his attempt to win Wimbledon, overcome what was a two-set deficit to reach a third consecutive final? Will Becker, a two-time champion, prevail? Stay tuned.

title: Takeover Stocks Still Lead Market
description: Takeovers continued to sweep corporate America in the second quarter, producing some of the biggest gains in the stock market during the period.

title: BILL ROBERTS, EARLY REAGAN ADVISER, IS DEAD AT 63
description: Bill Roberts, a founder of political consulting and the manager of Ronald Reagan's entry into politics in 1966, died of heart failure Thursday in California after a long battle with diabetes. He was 63 years old.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Yeltsin and Ligachev
description: Following are excerpts from the remarks of Boris N. Yeltsin, the former Moscow party leader, and Yegor K. Ligachev, the head of the party Secretariat, to the special Communist Party conference yesterday in Moscow. The Yeltsin remarks were translated by Reuters; the Ligachev remarks were translated by the British Broadcasting Corporation and The New York Times. Yeltsin Remarks

title: A Bigger Splash at Niagara
description: LEAD: The incessant pounding of tons of water against the rock crest that forms the Horseshoe Falls in Niagara, N.Y., has begun to slowly carve a new shape in the waterfall. Ultimately, this natural erosion process could dramatically alter the water show that attracts millions of visitors each year.

title: Patents; A New Way to Make Drug Delivery System
description: Several small biotechnology companies are developing ways to administer drugs by encapsulating them in tiny organic spheres called liposomes. Proponents believe this approach will improve the ability of doctors to aim medications more precisely and control the speed of their release.

title: West German Begins Duties As NATO Secretary General
description: Manfred Worner of West Germany began his term as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today with a pledge to seek progress in East-West arms talks.

title: Jazz Festival; With Hampton and Marsalis, the 40's and Today
description: Lionel Hampton and Wynton Marsalis, respectively the last active band leader from the big band era of the 1940's and the currently most publicized young jazz musician, shared a JVC Jazz Festival Concert on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Both Mr. Hampton and his big band and Mr. Marsalis and his quintet played programs that offered very little in the way of surprises or freshness.

title: ROUGH-EDGED ADS SELL 'REALITY'
description: With its out-of-focus close-ups, drifting camera and grainy shots of teen-agers spraying one another with soda and sashaying between cans, the current television commercial for Sprite looks like a home movie -which is no accident.

title: Saluting Veteran of War on Poverty
description: Michael Harrington - champion of the poor, author of the influential ''The Other America,'' which helped to spur the war on poverty a quarter-century ago, co-chairman of the Democratic Socialists of America, distinguished professor of political science at Queens College - said yesterday that he considered it an honor to have been on President Nixon's ''enemies' list.''

title: Bomb Site Cleanup Is Put at Billions
description: Cleaning up the radioactive and chemical pollution caused by the manufacture of nuclear bombs will cost $40 billion to $110 billion, a report by the Department of Energy said yesterday.

title: Brazil-U.S. Pact On Securities
description: United States and Brazilian securities regulators signed a far-reaching mutual assistance pact today to cooperate in enforcing securities laws of the two countries.

title: SWEEPING POLITICAL REVISION OF SOVIET SYSTEM APPROVED IN STORMY MEETING OF PARTY
description: Delegates to a Communist Party conference today approved a major overhaul of the Soviet political system in a stormy final session that included the first openly divided votes since the early years of the Soviet state.

title: World Bank Reserve Plan
description: Recognizing that a growing number of poor countries are seriously behind on loan payments, the World Bank said today that its board was expected to increase provisions for loan losses to $500 million from the current $100 million.

title: Radiation Is Found to Slow Multiple Sclerosis
description: Researchers have nearly halted the progression of multiple sclerosis in some patients for up to four years by aiming radiation at specific sites in the body, according to a new study.

title: About New York; Hsu's Potpourri: From Fireworks To Fortunetellers
description: From time to time it is helpful, to say nothing of illuminating, to look in on Hwa-Min Hsu, attorney at law, Canal Street, Chinatown, U.S.A. You know Canal Street. That's the one where, these days, there's someone every 15 feet hollering, ''Fireworks! Fireworks! Fireworks!''

title: Review/Dance; Fokine Infuses a Program by the Harlem Troupe
description: The spirit of Michel Fokine presided over the performance that Dance Theater of Harlem offered Thursday night at the City Center as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts. One of the three works was by Fokine himself, another was a new version of a work created by him and the third might never have existed if it had not been for precedents set by this great balletic reformer.

title: 10,000 Strike At a Shipyard In Connecticut
description: Workers at the Electric Boat submarine shipyard, Connecticut's second-largest private employer, went on strike today as 10,000 machinists, electricians and tradesmen vowed to stay off the job until they receive raises.

title: Jazz Festival; A Jazz Recital With a Touch Of Semiclassical
description: The spirit of her close friend, the late Alec Wilder, seemed to infuse the pianism of Marian McPartland during her solo concert at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday afternoon. Like Mr. Wilder, Miss McPartland is a musician who does not find jazz incompatible with semiclassical instrumental music of a wistful impressionistic sort. Although she plays music that swings, these days she seems more comfortable performing songs in a more formal English parlor style of less pronounced rhythmic drive.

title: QUARTERLY GAINERS ON THE BIG BOARD
description: New York Stock Exchange-listed common stocks that showed the largest percentage gains in the second quarter. Prices are adjusted for splits, and listings exclude stocks that began the quarter trading for less than $2 a share.

title: Seven Entries for Oaks
description: Seven 3-year-old fillies, led by Goodbye Halo, have been entered in the Coaching Club American Oaks tomorrow at Belmont Park, the final leg of the New York filly triple crown series.

title: Minimizing the Damage
description: To the Editor:

title: 'DESIGNER' DOG FOODS COMPETE FOR SALES
description: Is your dog overweight? There's a new ''light'' dog food. Is he a little run-down? Maybe high-protein food would pick him up. How's his breath? A mint-flavored dog biscuit might make him better company.

title: On the Road In France
description: Nobody, least of all such star riders as Sean Kelly, Andy Hampsten and Laurent Fignon, takes the Tour de France lightly.

title: MILITARY VENDOR SAYS IT OWNS SPA
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation disclosed Friday that it purchased a health club in Ocala, Fla., little more than a year after one of its executives reportedly played a role in financially aiding a Florida Congressman who then had an interest in the spa.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Carving Out an Attitude Michael Crichton was a doctor before he became a best-selling novelist. Here he describes the evolution of a young physician's feelings as he dissects a human face. This is one of many pieces in his collection ''Travels'' (Knopf).

title: Old House in Sea Cliff Is Even Older
description: You had an interesting account of Sea Cliff's Victorian houses [ ''Sea Cliff Adjusts to Historic Listing,'' June 12 ] . But I would like to tell you what I told the Landmarks Association. It is a well-established fact that 112 Sea Cliff Avenue was built in 1884. The date of 1887 is wrong. In 1888 the tower wing was added, and of course the tower is the most conspicuous feature of the house. Anyone who wants to read of the 1887 fire in the 1884 house can look it up in a file of the old newspaper, the Sea Cliff News. MARY RISK HINE Sea Cliff

title: SEEKING THE GOLD STRUGGLES TO WIN
description: When a superior horse beats lesser rivals by an unexpectedly small margin, racetrackers often say that he won it on class alone. That was exactly how Seeking the Gold looked winning the $228,400 Dwyer Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: For M.D.'s, Ethics Can't Be Frills
description: With the publication of the anonymous article ''It's Over, Debbie,'' the Journal of the American Medical Association brought to public consciousness the issue of euthanasia and the physician's role in it.

title:
GARDENING;
Watering: How Much Is Too Much?
description: LEAD: WATERING should be the easiest of all gardening tasks to master. But that is not always the case. There can be little doubt but that over- and underwatering cause more problems for plants than any others we inflict.

title: Victoria Irwin to Wed Leland Jones Aug. 11
description: An Aug. 11 wedding is planned by Victoria Hunt Irwin, the New York City bureau chief for The Christian Science Monitor, and Leland Thomas Jones, an assistant press secretary to Mayor Koch.

title: CRAM WINS 'DREAM MILE' AT OSLO MEET
description: It was quite a day for King Olav V. He celebrated his 85th birthday, rode through town in a midday parade and played host to a lavish party tonight at the palace.

title: THE WORLD: Election Challenge; Mexicans Want Salinas - And Some Opposition
description: THERE is no doubt that Carlos Salinas de Gortari of the Institutional Revolutionary Party will win the presidential election this Wednesday in Mexico. Much harder to determine is the shape of post-election Mexico, which Mr. Salinas has promised to make more modern and democratic. Whether he will be able to guide the process of change, and do it in a way that allows his party to remain the country's dominant force, will be the central question of Mexican political life for the next six years.

title: POSTINGS: Homes in the Hamptons; Moving West to Eastport
description: Eastport is in Southhampton - the Long Island town, that is, not the village - but not quite on the South Fork. title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CHARM SCHOOL. By Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $17.95.) Nelson DeMille's new novel is a Moscow thriller, and he has mastered the mechanics of the genre, moving the plot swiftly with regular intrusions of violence, ironic twists and cynical betrayals. Mr. DeMille, whose last novel, ''Word of Honor,'' was set in Vietnam, has done his homework on Russia, accurately describing Moscow's hotels and streets and even providing dialogue with Russian obscenities translated into English, all of which suggests the assiduous note-taking (and the occasional technical mistake) of a literate tourist with a good guide. The plot begins with an American yuppie buzzing through the Russian countryside in his Pontiac Trans Am - and encountering an American pilot who was shot down over Vietnam and has been held prisoner ever since in a special training camp for spies near Moscow. Luckily, the yuppie is smart enough to call his embassy before he is murdered. The camp is the Charm School, where captured airmen are forced to train Soviet spies to be perfect Americans. To find it, a hard-nosed, cynical agent named Sam Hollis starts poking around in the woods, accompanied by the embassy's assistant press officer, Lisa Rhodes, who has just finished an affair with another of the embassy's spies. Eventually, the two get into the camp and meet the obligatory villain, Burov. They have conversations about East and West, God and morality. Some of it is convincing, some embarrassing. At one point, Sam says, ''You like spies.'' To which Lisa replies, ''I'm a spy groupie.'' When they finally get into the Charm School, which looks like a town in suburban America, she says, ''I can't believe this, Sam,'' and he agrees, ''It's a bit surreal.'' In the two years I worked in Moscow as a reporter, I met several American spies. None of them talked like that.

title: Not a Drop to Drink
description: CONSIDER A DROP IN THE ocean. This is what they're doing, on a rather grand scale, at the California Academy of Sciences, the 138-year-old museum in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park. Part of a massive new exhibit entitled Wild California that is scheduled to open Oct. 9 and intended to illustrate the diversity of habitats and ecosystems within the state, the Sea Meadow diorama will represent life forms extant in a random squirt of coastal sea water -magnified 200 times. (A model is shown at right.) ''We've got anchovy eggs, juvenile crab forms,'' says Dean C. Weldon, the exhibit production manager, ''and about 300 plantlike life forms called diatoms. There are actually thousands of species of these teeny guys. The basic message is that these microscopic plants and animals are the basis of the food chain for all the lives in the ocean.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MOMENTUM: Women in American Politics Now. By Ronna Romney and Beppie Harrison. (Crown, $18.95.) In 1973, there were 16 women in the House of Representatives. Fifteen years later, there are 23. That barely qualifies as progress, let alone the ''momentum'' of the title of this breezy, upbeat account of the current status of women in American political life. While Ronna Romney and Beppie Harrison acknowledge that the outlook is mixed, with women still facing obstacles in raising money and even in being taken seriously as candidates, they view the glass as half-full, not half-empty. For one thing, they love politics. (Ronna Romney is the Republican national committeewoman from Michigan, where her father-in-law was a governor.) ''It's almost like grown-up camp, to tell the truth,'' one Republican activist told them of life during a campaign, and a view of politics as fun and exciting, worthwhile for its own sake, shapes the book. Based on interviews with several dozen women at all levels of government, it does not rise often enough above the anecdotal level. That would be less of a failing if the women themselves emerged in sharply etched portraits, but they pass by for the most part in a blur of names and titles. The authors, who have previously written a book about marriage, pin their hopes for the future of women in politics on the 18,000 who now hold office at the state and local levels, predicting that women may eventually become ''a substantial majority in city halls and state houses.'' They offer no particular evidence of how or why this will happen, but their sincerity and enthusiasm are such that they almost make it sound plausible.

title: THE NATION: Battles Over the Years; The Feds vs. The Teamsters
description: 1957 - James R. Hoffa is elected teamsters' president despite reports of his ties to organized crime. 1962 - Hoffa is indicted by a Federal grand jury in Nashville on charges of violating Federal labor laws. Mistrial is declared because of reports of jury tampering. 1963-64 - After an investigation overseen by Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy, Hoffa is indicted on jury-tampering charges, found guilty and sentenced to eight years in prison. He is sentenced to an additional five years after his conviction on fraud and conspiracy in the handling of a union benefits fund. 1967 - With his appeals exhausted, Hoffa enters prison. Frank E. Fitzsimmons, a union vice president, assumes interim leadership of the teamsters. 1971 - Hoffa announces retirement as teamsters' president. President Nixon commutes Hoffa's sentence and Hoffa is released from prison. Fitzsimmons is elected as his successor. 1973 - Hoffa launches bid to unseat Fitzsimmons on platform calling for end to ties between teamsters and organized crime. 1975 - Hoffa suddenly disappears. 1981 - Fitzsimmons dies of cancer. Roy L. Williams, a teamsters vice president, is elected president despite pending Federal indictment on charges involving union abuses and despite widespread reports that he is linked to organized crime. 1982 - Williams is found guilty of conspiring to bribe a United States Senator and defrauding the union's Central States Pension Fund. He is sentenced to prison. 1983 - Jackie Presser elected president. 1986 - Presser is indicted on Federal embezzlement and racketeering charges involving a union local. 1988 - Presser's trial is postponed indefinitely following brain surgery. The Justice Department files a civil racketeering suit seeking to oust Presser and the 18-member executive board because of their purported ties to organized crime.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LIFE BEING THE BEST & OTHER STORIES. By Kay Boyle. Edited by Sandra Whipple Spanier. (New Directions, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $8.95.) This collection of short stories celebrates the enduring artistic discipline of Kay Boyle, who, unlike some of her better-known peers, survived the halcyon days of Paris in the 1920's. Although Ms. Boyle is not as notorious as some of the other Moderns -those intrepid expatriate writers who set out to change language, mesh literature and social context and expose the dissonance of contemporary life - she evokes these tensions with a gossamer finesse. Her characters (wise, sad children; jilted ladies; demimondaines; women on the cusp of consciousness) are each preserved in fleeting, almost prosaic moments, each fraught with weakness and passion. Ms. Boyle animates their interior lives with unsentimental grace and acute prescience (judging from her story ''Astronomer's Wife,'' for example, she clearly grasped that the personal is political long before that feminist maxim appeared). The title story -in which an alienated, dignified boy answers a hypothetical question with simple, terrible justice - provides the rest of the book with pitch and momentum. ''Life Being the Best'' gives breadth to the themes that have preoccupied Ms. Boyle throughout her career: the inviolate integrity of the human soul, the impact of external events on the most intimate of feelings, our fractured experience of love versus duty, self-respect versus hubris, social convention versus personal ethic. For 60 years, Kay Boyle's steady hand in rendering detail, authentic characterization and unequivocal moral vision has never faltered. She is still unquestionably modern.

description: Marvin Mitchelson, the lawyer who added ''palimony'' to the legal lexicon and who counseled celebrities from Bianca Jagger to Carl Sagan to Joan Collins, remains as much as ever in the public eye. But, suddenly, the spotlight has turned harsh and penetrating.

title: What Mexico's Next President Must Do
description: MEXICO will choose a new President on Wednesday. The near certain election of Carlos Salinas de Gotari will accelerate an intellectual revolution that is driving Mexico beyond its defensive, inward-looking past and toward a more receptive, internationalist future. This shift toward globalism offers a tremendous opportunity for improving Mexican-American relations.

title: James Madison Made Us Up
description: INVENTING THE PEOPLE The Rise of Popular Sovereignty in England and America. By Edmund S. Morgan. 318 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: 'I EDIT BY ARGUMENT'
description: LEAD: TILTING AT WINDMILLS An Autobiography. By Charles Peters. Illustrated. 294 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $18.95.

title: Resistance Grows on Teacher Pay
description: MANY school boards say they are finding increased taxpayer resistance to education spending this year, as budgets grow because of higher teachers' salaries.

title: Madison Avenue Lends the City a Creative Edge
description: MUCH subway-car advertising is pedantic, garish or uninteresting - if u cn rd the sml prnt at all. But sometimes an ad stands out: a child's crayon drawing aimed at incest victims, a shriveled apple symbolizing the need to conserve water.

title: RULERS IN MEXICO FACE VOTING TEST
description: The ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party has never lost a presidential election, and Carlos Salinas de Gortari is virtually certain to continue that streak next Wednesday. But for the first time, the party cannot be absolutely sure of its prospects in another election: that of the 64 senators and 500 deputies to be chosen the same day.

title: Latest Worry: The Mud Turtle
description: LEAD: THE mud turtle is a six-inch-long reptile with a large head and strong jaws, and when disturbed it gives off a foul-smelling substance called musk from glands near its hind legs. Though this creature may not be particularly appealing to the average person, environmentalists and conservation officials are concerned that it may soon join the list of endangered species in the state.

title: Ronda Pomerantz Is Married to Dr. Michael Gross
description: At the Sign of the Dove restaurant in Manhattan, Ronda Pomerantz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Pomerantz of Paramus, N.J., and Dr. Michael Lee Gross, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morton A. Gross of Great Neck, L.I., were married last night by Rabbi David Posner.

title: Set Back in Early Skirmishes, Bush Gains With New Attack
description: After several months of hearing his Presidential campaign derided for a seeming inability to forge a coherent message, Vice President Bush finds political Washington taking him seriously again. Suddenly, it seems, George Bush has seized the initiative.

title:
THE VIEW FROM:THE FLAG STORE;
Once, Patriotic Flags and Banners Flew on the Fourth of July
description: LEAD: JAMES EICH remembers the days when the Fourth of July was big business. When villages and towns and cities rented vast quantities of red, white and blue bunting from Eich of Bedford, the flag and banner business run by his father, Edward. When father and son spent simmering summer afternoons festooning public buildings with patriotic decorations, in anticipation of the big day that brass bands played under gazebos, politicians exhorted listeners to love their country and fireworks sparkled in the lavender dusk.

title: GOOD DEFENSE: THINKING, PREPARING, REACTING
description: LEAD: BRANCH Rickey, that Buckminster Fuller of baseball invention, was once reported to have told a fledgling scout that the way to watch a baseball game was to focus on a player at his position. ''Watch only one portion of the field at a time,'' the old Mahatma was supposed to have said, urging the scout to avoid the natural inclination to simply follow the flight of the ball.

title: Moratorium on Raceway Property Is Extended
description: PROMPTED by concern over the future of Roosevelt Raceway, the Hempstead Town Board has extended a moratorium until the end of September on building permits or zoning applications for the raceway land.

title: With Pen in Hand, We Hesitate
description: LOOK at little children. Crayolas in hand or fingers in paint, they happily leave their marks on the wall, on the floor and on papers that adorn our refrigerators.

title: Mexico's Radical Insider
description: It's not quite perestroika, but in Mexico, too, an entrenched party and keeper of the orthodox revolutionary flame is challenged by a new leader who urges bold democratic reform to rescue a tottering system. As in the Soviet Union, this challenge comes not from the opposition but from within the ruling party itself.

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Yankees Have Fired Billy Martin?
description: The real question is why did the Yankees rehire him? I make two pleas as a longtime Yankee fan: Let Lou Piniella take the reins so that he may use his considerable prowess to manage the team, and please do not give us Billy VI. ALAN R. STERN Brentwood, L.I.

title: Scott Edelman to Wed Debra Zarlin, Lawyer
description: Debra Jo Zarlin and Scott Alexander Edelman, who both received J.D. degrees from the Harvard Law School last month, plan to marry in September.

description: LEAD: WATERING should be the easiest of all gardening tasks to master. But that is not always the case. There can be little doubt but that over- and underwatering cause more problems for plants than any others we inflict.

title: The Race to a More Elaborate Arms Race
description: IRAN, Iraq and 46 other countries have anti-ship cruise missiles. Nineteen countries, including Argentina and India, own diesel-attack submarines. And 21 nations have naval mines, which, like the other two weapons, are capable of sinking large ships.

title: Young Calls Jackson Realist Who Won't Jeopardize Ballot
description: Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta says the Rev. Jesse Jackson is a realist and will not press to be the running mate of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis if it means the Democrats will lose in November.

title: Reunion Thoughts, and Second Thoughts
description: WHEN I received the invitation to my 25th high school reunion, I immediately sent my acceptance to the organizing committee. I was eager to attend in the hopes of seeing many of the 90 classmates I had graduated with. However, on the day of the reunion, I began to have second thoughts.

title: In a Vermont School Bus, Educated Ribs
description: BARBECUE is not the first thing that comes to mind when you think of Vermont, a state that eaters more often associate with maple syrup, cheddar cheese and apples. But barbecue it is, nonetheless, at least in the village of Putney, thanks to the efforts of a no-longer-roving migrant apple picker named Curtis Tuff and a band of local enthusiasts who gather around an old blue-painted school bus on Route 5 each time the rising cloud of smoke signifies that Mr. Tuff's barbecue grill is in operation.

title: THE ANNOTATED 'ROMAN A TEASE'
description: THE HERMIT OF 69th STREET The Working Papers of Norbert Kosky. By Jerzy Kosinski. 529 pp. New York: Seaver Books/Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: C.C.N.Y. Students Had an Advantage
description: I was highly pleased by Sherman Tufel's comment that ''any student who flunked out of C.C.N.Y. and went to another college automatically improved both colleges'' in his June 12 letter to the Long Island editor, in which he discussed hiring practices affecting graduates of state colleges. This statement echoes the sentiments that Mayor Ed Koch expressed at a dinner of the City College Alumni Association a few years ago.

description: AIRING INDEPENDENCE

description: EVER since Peter S. Kalikow bought the City and Suburban Homes buildings in 1984, tenants and community groups have been fighting his announced plans, first to replace all, and then only part of the complex with high-rise luxury apartments. The buildings cover the whole block between 78th and 79th Streets, the East River Drive and York Avenue.

WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Bond Burning
description: LEAD: With a flick of his lighter, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke symbolically paid off a big debt last Sunday.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
At Last! Independence From Barbecuing!
description: LEAD: JULY 4: flags streaming, fireworks crackling and barbecues blazing. After over 20 years of briquets and fire starters, gas grills and mesquite, marshmallows and marinades, I have come to one conclusion: People born in Brooklyn were never meant to barbecue.

description: Key Vote in Mexico

description: Insurance

title: 3 Fires Strike U.S. Laboratory For Nuclear Weapon Design
description: Three simultaneous electrical fires in a transformer and two power switches Thursday night left much of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory without power Friday.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MEMOIRS OF AN INVISIBLE MAN, by H. F. Saint. (Dell, $4.95.) Nick Halloway, a New York securities analyst, finds insider trading an easier game after a mishap in a Government-financed laboratory makes him invisible. ''The prose is so elegantly knowing, particularly the sport it makes of the Wall Street types who inadvertently help Nick out of his pickle, [ that ] 'Memoirs of an Invisible Man' sustains our interest to the end,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times last year. ORPHANS: Real and Imaginary, by Eileen Simpson. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) Eileen Simpson lost her mother when she was 11 months old and her father when she was 7. When her husband died, she was shocked into remembering her life as an orphan. The result is a book that combines reminiscence with psychoanalysis and examines orphans as they appear in history, literature and even comic strips, like Little Orphan Annie. ''There are passages of uncommon beauty in which she is for the first time able to imagine an invisible mother,'' Sheila Ballantyne said here in 1987. ''And there are others in which she fantasizes her parents to be always poised above some eternal dance floor, forever young, frozen in states of perfection.'' MISS UNDINE'S LIVING ROOM, by James Wilcox. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) Olive Mackie of James Wilcox's fictional Tula Springs, La., is afraid that the murder her 91-year-old uncle is believed to have committed will ruin her campaign to become Superintendent of Streets, Parks and Garbage. Last year, our reviewer, Rosemary Daniell, called this a novel of ''small-town Southern life as it often is, spontaneously and effortlessly funny - here magnified by Mr. Wilcox's acute ear, his selective wit. . . . Like Barbara Pym, [ he ] has created a delicious little world.'' STRAIGHT ON TILL MORNING: The Biography of Beryl Markham, by Mary S. Lovell. (St. Martin's, $10.95.) The lovers of Beryl Markham, the first woman to fly solo and nonstop across the Atlantic from England to North America, included Leopold Stokowski and Antoine de Saint-Exupery, who helped her write her celebrated memoir, ''West With the Night.'' Mary S. Lovell's biography is ''the story of a phenomenal life, told convincingly by someone fascinated by her subject,'' Diane Ackerman said here last year. MOTHER LOVE, by Candace Flynt. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) Even on her deathbed, an overbearing, alcoholic mother can't stop trying to manipulate her daughters' lives. Last year, our reviewer, Julia Markus, said this novel is ''a work of enormous beauty and psychological insight.'' THE MORMON CORPORATE EMPIRE, by John Heinerman and Anson Shupe. (Beacon, $11.95.) When the authors, a Mormon medical anthropologist and a sociologist, investigated the finances of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, they discovered an $8 billion empire working ''to reshape our society and its democratic institutions.'' ''They tell us a lot we didn't know about Mormon investments,'' our reviewer, Wallace Turner, said in 1986, and ''make a strong case that the vaunted Mormon welfare program is a myth.'' A HERO IN HIS TIME, by Arthur A. Cohen. (University of Chicago, $9.95.) For inscrutable geopolitical reasons, a minor Russian Jewish poet is dispatched to New York by the K.G.B. to read a poem written by a machine. ''Arthur Cohen has achieved here a tour de force,'' Geoffrey Wolff said in The Book Review in 1976, ''bringing the idea of poetry to life in a messy little man, no hero at all, not even much of a poet.'' The same publisher has brought out new editions of two other novels by Mr. Cohen, who died in 1986. IN THE DAYS OF SIMON STERN ($10.95) is about a blind scribe who tells the story of the Messiah, a millioniare real estate dealer born on the Lower East Side. ''Every vein of this book runs with a brilliance of Jewish insight and erudition to be found in no other novelist,'' Cynthia Ozick said here in 1973. In ACTS OF THEFT ($9.95), a sculptor who trafficks in stolen archeological treasures provides Mr. Cohen with a vehicle to write about the meaning of art, creation and the worship of graven images. THE OTHER NUREMBERG: The Untold Story of the Tokyo War Crimes Trials, by Arnold C. Brackman. (Quill, $9.95.) It was not only the Nazis who committed atrocities during World War II, Arnold Brackman reminds us in the first comprehensive account of the Japanese equivalent of the Nuremberg trials. ''This book is a necessary reminder of a dark, half-forgotten chapter of human history,'' Gaddis Smith said here last year. ''Chapters on wanton rape, torture and murder of civilians and prisoners of war are gruesome in the extreme, almost equal in sickening impact to accounts of the Nazi death camps. . . . What happened seems to have been done with grim, deliberate self-awareness.'' IN PURSUIT OF REASON: The Life of Thomas Jefferson, by Noble E. Cunningham Jr. (Ballantine, $10.95.) It is not easy condensing Thomas Jefferson's anomalous life to a single volume, Richard J. Margolis said in The Book Review last year. While he found this ''pithy and rational'' biography by ''a scrupulous scholar'' a bit one-dimensional, over all, he said, it is a success. HUNGER STRIKE: The Anorectic's Struggle as a Metaphor for Our Age, by Susie Orbach. (Avon, $4.50.) When this feminist analysis of anorexia was published last year, our reviewer, Judith Moore, said the author argues her case ''systematically, convincingly - and movingly. . . . It would be a shame for booksellers to relegate 'Hunger Strike' to the 'women's' shelves.''

description: A Federal grand jury in Pennsylvania will consider charges against the leader of an extremist group who the authorities say wanted to use counterfeit currency to set up a training camp for racist and anti-Semitic revolutionaries.

description: BACK IN RADIO days, there was a character named Baron Munchausen.

description: EUROPEAN fashion houses, including Fendi, Valentino and Genny, are providing accessories to go with their ready-to-wear. Handbags, scarves, belts, gloves and shoes are designed to add pizazz to suits, dresses and separates.

description: OFFICE condominium means never having a lease run out and never having to make a deal with a landlord. It also means independence and tax benefits for professionals and businessmen such as Jeffrey H. Nagelberg, a 43-year-old food broker who is president of Panorama Produce Sales in Mamaroneck.

title: THE REGION: Patronage and Politics; Green Tries to Get a Grip on City's Decentralized Schools
description: ALTHOUGH the new Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, has been the focus of hopes for improved New York City schools, much of the power over the schools belongs not to him but to the 288 members of community school boards. Should this 20-year-old decentralized system be changed? And if so, how?

title: BACK INTO SPACE
description: THE CREW TENSES AS SIRENS WAIL AND warning lights wink on. All but one of the space shuttle's three main engines have mysteriously failed minutes after takeoff, leaving the ship crippled dozens of miles above the choppy Atlantic. Previously, the only option would have been a potentially deadly controlled crash in the water. But now quick steps are taken. The commander and pilot jettison the huge external fuel tank and stabilize the spaceship as it plummets. Five miles up, a crew member explosively blows off the shuttle's side hatch and extends a telescoping escape pole 12 feet beyond the ship. With the craft on autopilot, the astronauts gather on the shuttle's middeck, still dressed, as they were at takeoff, in newly designed flight suits with built-in parachutes, life rafts and oxygen supplies, so they can survive the rarefied atmosphere high above the earth. At four miles up, they bail out. One by one, they hook onto the escape pole and slide down, the device guiding them away from the craft, keeping the 200-mile-per-hour headwinds from bashing them into a wing or engine pod as they fall from the doomed ship. Soon they are floating in their parachutes to a safe landing in the ocean.

title: Olympic Profile: John Moffet; Swimmer Tries to Turn His Luck
description: BUD Greenspan's film remembrance of the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, ''16 Days of Glory,'' is filled with poignant moments. None describes the fragility and frustrations of athletic success more than the scene of John Moffet on crutches.

description: The singer Betty Carter's young band opened her set at the Bottom Line on Friday night with an uptempo instrumental piece. Suddenly, Ms. Carter's voice, singing ''Everytime We Say Goodbye,'' came piping from the loudspeakers. Bouncing melodies off obbligatos played by her saxophonist, Wes Anderson, Ms. Carter, who was singing from backstage, did what she does regularly: created drama and tension.

title: David Smyth, Metaphysician
description: DAVID SMYTH was trained at the Art Institute of Chicago but he trails none of the strangeness associated with Chicago art. His paintings, on view at the Alan Brown Gallery in Hartsdale (210 East Hartsdale Avenue), contain no otherworldly grotesquerie that would link him with artists such as Jim Nutt, Ed Paschke or Ellen Lanyon, to cite a few examples. Figural elements appear here and there but they are given no more emphasis than inanimate objects -chairs, an upturned table, maps of the world and so forth.

description: Vladimir Ovchinnikov, the Soviet pianist who won the Harveys Leeds International Pianoforte Competition in 1987, made his American debut on Thursday evening at Weill Recital Hall. title: Question Of the Week; Should The Yankees Have Fired Billy Martin?

Billy Ball consists of suicide squeezes, double steals, and hit and runs just to name a few. It's a shame he had to be let go because of people second-guessing him and trying to create stories that aren't true. VINNY SAVASTANO Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

It was one of those mornings when neither mother nor daughter won. I got nothing done, and she, as she tearfully and frequently took great pains to point out, had no fun.

title: Making Jet Engines From Clay
description: The race is on to commercialize advanced ceramic materials. These lightweight materials can withstand very high temperatures making them ideal replacements for some metals in the aerospace, chemical and automobile industries. Dr. Maxine L. Savitz, director of the Garrett Ceramic Components Division of the Allied-Signal Aerospace Company, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about the state of ceramic research.

title: A Visit to the Cemetery: The Past Resonates
description: IT is an annual pilgramage that I take with my mother on the first nice day in spring. We have been doing it since 1973, when my father died, and I have always felt somewhat ambivalent about going. ''I think I want to visit Daddy,'' my mother would say to me. And dutifully we would roll across the Whitestone Bridge and exit at the Belmont Raceway and go searching among the headstones for the right one.

title: Post-Holiday Delays Expected
description: LATE-NIGHT traffic may encounter some delays this week on the New Jersey Turnpike, Holland Tunnel and George Washington Bridge as continuing repair projects are resumed after the holiday.

title: 3d Youth Is Held in Robbery
description: A Westchester youth was arrested yesterday in connection with a robbery and shooting rampage last week by five classmates from Fordham Prep Thursday. The youth, Brendan Moynihan, 16 years old, of 20 Bonmar Road in Pelham Manor, N.Y., turned himself in at the 43d Precinct station house in the Bronx, said a police spokesman, Sgt. John Venetucci. He was charged with attempted murder, attempted robbery and criminal use of a firearm.

title: The Deepest Roots Grow the Slowest
description: IT was against the general trend, yet we have bought a house in the same town that both my wife and I were raised and educated in.

title: 2 Whites Die in Blast at a Johannesburg Stadium
description: Two whites were killed and 29 other people, including two blacks and an Asian, were wounded today when a car bomb exploded as 10,000 spectators were leaving a sports stadium at the end of a major rugby match.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Ridgewood
description: LEAD: THERE is something tranquil and timeless about Ridgewood, where streets canopied with trees meander past stately old homes and deep lawns dotted with flowers and shrubs. Churches and cemeteries recall an earlier age, as does the downtown train station, the reason for the emergence of this New Jersey suburb over a century ago.

title: POSTINGS: For the Aged and Disabled; Filling a Bronx Need
description: Beth Abraham Hospital, a nursing home in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, was deluged with applicants when Scheuer Gardens opened in 1983. Now, as construction begins on Scheuer Plaza, it is braced for more of the same. A 116-unit, subsidized rental residence for the elderly and disabled, Scheuer Gardens was never meant to have a companion. But, said Michael M. Bialek, the director of real estate development for Beth Abraham, ''seeing the applications and the waiting list really hit home.''

title: Man Is Shot to Death Near Manhattan Disco
description: A 24-year-old Bronx man was shot to death outside a nightclub in Chelsea early yesterday, the police said.

title: Sports People; Bol Arrested
description: THE Maryland State Police said that Manute Bol, the 7-foot-7-inch center, was involved in a scuffle with officers yesterday after his auto was stopped in New Carrollton during the early-morning hours.

title: Jasper Johns Shows the Flag in Venice
description: THE STORY OF THE 1988 VENICE Biennale is Jasper Johns - the best known, most influential and probably the most complex American painter in the last 30 years. No one else in the 43d biennale approaches him in stature, and the show that represents him - and the United States - ''Jasper Johns: Work From 1974-1986,'' has the kind of concentration that encourages an appraisal of his achievement.

title: POSTINGS: Queens Conversion; Industrial Condos
description: For Jerry Wolkoff, a Hauppauge, L.I., developer who has made a living by luring office tenants to Suffolk County, his current project in Long Island City, Queens, represents something of a change. He and his partner, Shimon Topor, hope a $2 million conversion of a warehouse into industrial condominiums will keep manufacturers in New York City.

title: Miss McGlothlin, Executive, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Harrison McGlothlin of Sea Island, Ga., and Madison, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Anne McGlothlin to C. Evan Stewart, the son of Jenifer B. Stewart of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Charles Thorp Stewart of New York.

title: Threat of Drought Worries Officials
description: TOWNS throughout the state are asking people to cut back on water use, as the prolonged dry spell prompts the watering of withered lawns and the washing of dusty cars. Supplies are taxed, draining wells and reservoirs.

title: THE HAUNTING OF SHIRLEY JACKSON
description: LEAD: AS a writer, Shirley Jackson refused to stay put. She roamed at will among moods, genres and visions. During her life (1916-65) she investigated various states of mind -madness, horror, hilarity - fully at ease in exploring every one. Her work was brave and original, but defied simple categories; unfortunately, what the world cannot categorize, it often backs away from.

title: Turnpike to Expand Interchange 7
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Turnpike Authority is building a new toll plaza at Interchange 7 in Burlington County to accommodate a growing number of truck drivers who prefer Interstate 295, which parallels the southern half of the turnpike.

title: Summer Homework Is Applauded
description: The subject of the recent article ''Summer Homework Angers Parents'' (June 12) was about a situation I find most distressing. Apparently, some Branford parents are in an uproar about a public school principal's mandate that students grade five through eight read two books during summer vacation and then take a test on them when they return in the fall.

title: At City Hall, Flake Sows And Reaps
description: Of all the city's prominent black politicians, Representative Floyd H. Flake of Queens is considered the most friendly to Mayor Koch. And of all the city's prominent black politicians, Mr. Flake, a minister as well as a politician, probably has the most to gain from his friend at City Hall.

title: Japanese Artists Find Collectors Still Look Abroad
description: THE FLASHY YEN THAT STRUTS and strides is bringing the art of the world to these islands in headline-grabbing hauls. Impressionist paintings, contemporary works, antique porcelain and Old Masters are purchased in New York and London for corporations, galleries and private collectors in Japan.

title: ZONING EXCHANGES ASSAILED AS UNFAIR
description: The practice of trading New York City's approval of development projects for unrelated public amenities is a form of uneven taxation that distorts government and should be stopped, a report submitted to Mayor Koch and the Board of Estimate has charged.

title: Spirit of '88; America Is Ready For a Contest With A Passion for Caution
description: ''I HEAR America singing,'' declared Walt Whitman, America's poet of democracy.

title: Baseball; Gooden Repeats A Drug Denial
description: Dwight Gooden denied again yesterday that he had ever used drugs during the 1986 season or any other season, and said that he had not meant to imply any such thing while answering questions in a taped interview for an upcoming television program.

title: SAVORING BARBECUE
description: BARBECUE MEANS DIFFERENT things to different people. To someone from the Carolinas, it is shredded pork in a vinegar-based sauce. In California, it is synonymous with grilling outdoors. And according to the barbecue wizard of the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area, Robert Pearson, ''Northerners think of barbecue as a sugary, syrupy sauce that you put on ribs and chicken and that gives everything a burned taste.''

title: POSTINGS: Can III Be Far Behind?; Teleport II Takes Off
description: Not so long ago, it seemed the nearby Fresh Kills landfill would fill up quicker than Teleport I. The first speculative office building at the 100-acre Teleport Satellite Communication Center in northwestern Staten Island was only 60 percent occupied in January, a year after opening. Potential tenants were discouraged by the center's remote location between Victory Boulevard and South Avenue off the West Shore Expressway and the cost of space, $24 to $26 a square foot.

title: Making Brushes Last
description: PAINTBRUSHES and roller covers (the woolly sleeves that fit onto the roller and spread the paint) seldom receive the care they need. But even inexpensive brushes and covers will last a long time if they are used properly and cleaned thoroughly after each use, and protected when put away for long periods.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SPARE DAYS. By Marvin Barrett. (Arbor House/Morrow, $16.95.) Marvin Barrett was fighting heart disease, only to discover he had cancer. The first thing he did was go out to Baskin-Robbins and order an ice-cream cone. He was 63. Then he started a diary. The finest moments in this book, an account of his shadow-boxing match with death, will ring true for almost anyone with a potentially fatal disease.

title: A Brave Old World in Eastern Europe
description: I ONCE took a train from Warsaw to Athens, passing through every Eastern European country but East Germany, and watched with wonder as storybook towns passed my view and ancient laborers crowded my compartment. Winding through the Transylvanian Alps at dawn, we came upon horse-drawn sleighs in the snow and whole villages built of timber, the houses tall and balconied and painted in the pastel shades of butter mints.

title: In Switzerland, Mountaineering For Everyone
description: TO stand on the roof of the world is an experience that most of us believe we'll never have. To know what it's like to climb a major mountain and gain an eagle's-eye view, we have to be armchair mountaineers, relying on books or films. But a cable car line in Zermatt allows a reasonably fit person with no climbing experience to make such a climb, safely accompanied by a licensed mountain guide, and taste the thrill of true mountaineering - a brief membership in one of the world's most exclusive clubs.

title: Children's Books
description: IT'S A FREE COUNTRY! A Young Person's Guide to Politics & Elections. By Cynthia K. Samuels. Illustrated. 132 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Breaking New Ground In Thrills and Chills
description: ROLLER coasters have consistently ranked as the most popular ride in surveys of amusement park visitors. And they have come a long way since 1884 when attendants at Coney Island pushed the cars up the incline on the Switchback Gravity Pleasure Railway so that riders could zoom down at hair-raising speeds of six miles an hour.

title: Sports People; Sutton Is Disabled
description: FOR the first time in a major league career that began in 1966, Don Sutton, a 324-game winner, has been placed on the disabled list. It happened Friday night in Los Angeles, where the Dodgers assigned Sutton to the 21-day disabled list, retroactive to last Wednesday. Sutton, 43 years old, did not get a decision in his last start, a 4-3 loss to Houston Tuesday night, and complained afterward of a sore right elbow. The injury was diagnosed as a strain. He is 3-5 with a 3.70 earned run average this season.

title: Wanted, P/T, Immediate: Volunteers Please Apply
description: FROM fire departments and ambulance services to Little League baseball and city boards, the pinch for volunteers in Connecticut is becoming tighter.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: The Beriozkas in Moscow do indeed have a tempting variety of artistic items as Esther Fein said, but visitors should take with them heavy-duty capacious plastic sacks with sturdy handles or all they will bring home will be regrets over the beautiful things left behind because the flimsy paper bags supplied in the dollar shops can't make it to the airport in Moscow, and purchases made in Russia may not be shipped no matter how bulky they might be or how costly.

U.S. HAS CHANCE TO CELEBRATE SOCCER

This announcement may seem insignificant for those unfamiliar with international soccer. But for millions, actually billions, of people around the globe it is front-page news.

Joseph Gibino, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg. The bride, the daughter of Mary Bergam of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Miroslav Bergam, is an associate in the law firm of Kagan & Lubic. She will keep her name professionally. The bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Dinerman of Belle Harbor, Queens, is a partner in the law firm of Dinerman & Dinerman.

description: Jeff Robinson pitched a two-hitter, and Darrell Evans, Pat Sheridan and Dave Bergman hit home runs today as the Detroit Tigers defeated the California Angels, 6-1.

O'Rourke waged a two-day effort to head off a possible Federal environmental assessment that, he conceded, ''could stop the construction of a new terminal for two years or more.

description: JULY 4TH FETES Concerts and fireworks in celebration of the Fourth of July are being offered in communities throughout the state. They are free, unless prices are specified.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NIGHT OVER DAY OVER NIGHT. By Paul Watkins. (Knopf, $17.95.) Paul Watkins, a 23-year-old American, has written a first novel as obscure as its title. Told in the first person, it traces the declining psychic fortunes of a 17-year-old German who joins the SS in late 1944 and winds up fighting in the Battle of the Bulge. Sebastian Westland, the sullen, uncommunicative protagonist, signs on out of boredom rather than conviction. Once in uniform, he encounters not enthusiastic sadism but dispirited loutishness, an idle cruelty that soon infects new recruits. (We suspect something bad is happening to Sebastian's character when he nonchalantly stabs a pigeon in the park on his first leave home.) There is a calculated luridness, a straining for effect, both in Mr. Watkins's choice of subject and his prose: he favors off-kilter sensory effects with lots of non sequiturs and line spaces intended to resonate with deeper meanings. Mr. Watkins seems to do better when he sheds the heavy burden of thought, and the final hundred pages of the novel, when Sebastian receives his baptism by fire, include some splendid battle scenes. But, in the end, history gets short shrift in ''Night Over Day Over Night,'' despite all the fussy details about uniforms and weapons. At no point does it seem dramatically necessary for Sebastian to be in Germany in 1944. A rebel without a cause, he seems to have stumbled onto the wrong movie set.

description: FOR months, Neil Cunningham has been tracking the maze of pipelines that crisscross Nepera Inc.'s sprawling plant here, probing the thousands of fittings to measure chemicals leaking into the air in this bucolic Orange County community.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE: Berkshires
description: For some, the Berkshires are synonymous with concerts at Tanglewood. For others, it's dance at Jacob's Pillow or theater at Stockbridge, Lenox and Williamstown. But the Berkshires are also a cool summer retreat, combining scenic beauty with culture, only three hours by car from Boston or New York.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HOME FROM THE HILL. By Hilary Hook. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) Socialists of the grimmer sort have long maintained that the British Empire existed largely to provide outdoor relief for the unemployed (and perhaps unemployable) younger sons of the English upper classes. Few readers of this enjoyable little book will come away disabused of that notion.

title: The New High-Tech Battleground
description: HIGH-TECHNOLOGY battles used to be won or lost in the research laboratory, on the factory floor or in the marketplace. Now it seems they are being won or lost in the courtroom.

description: New York City judges, lawyers and court officers portrayed a judicial system permeated by bigotry and racism at hearings last week before a state commission investigating racial bias in the courts.

description: IN THE 60's, hair was a political statement. You could tell at a glance, even in the days of high school dress codes, where someone's sympathies lay simply by assessing his or her tresses.

description: The National Institutes of Health, yielding to Congressional pressure, has reversed its decision and will continue its $22 million program to develop an artificial human heart.

description: The Supreme Court has ended its 1987-88 term on a moderate but unsteady course, with hints that a more conservative majority may be emerging.

description: SOMETHING of an impasse has developed in the case of Richard Angelo, the former altar boy and Eagle Scout who was arrested seven months ago on charges of murdering patients at a hospital on Long Island by injecting them with muscle paralyzers.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: I beg to differ with the assessment of hotels in the Soviet Union. Traveling two years ago this spring, staying over in seven cities -Moscow, Leningrad, Kiev, Yalta, Tashkent, Samarkand and Bukhara - I felt spoiled by the superlative quarters providing good-size beds, spruced-up furnishings and, with one exception, clean and up-to-the-minute bathrooms. The one exception was the true water closet in Bukhara, offering toilet, wash bowl - and overhead - a showerhead. As for food, I supplemented heavy hotel fare with farmer's market carrots and cabbages and, in Soviet Asia, raisins.

title: Innocence Abroad
description: To the Editor: Sound the hurrahs for Ruth Wolff's paean to the unhurried and unregimented traveler (''Innocence Abroad,'' Travel, May 1). With the proliferation of guidebooks and ultraspecialized tours, it is a wonder that any traveler can just be left alone to savor wandering among streets, dropping in on unsuspecting shopkeepers, meandering to the point of even getting lost in quaint streets and parks, looking at sights for the sheer beauty of their ''being'' rather than of their attested place in history.

SEAN O'CASEY: A Life, by Garry O'Connor. (Atheneum, $25.) Mr. O'Connor sorts out the facts from the self-dramatizing in the life of the Irish playwright, author of ''Juno and the Paycock'' as well as several autobiographical volumes rife with nontruths. FATAL LIGHT, by Richard Currey. (Seymour Lawrence/Dutton, $16.95.) In his spare, elegant first novel, Mr. Currey evokes with precision and horror the Vietnam War and its disjunction from the outside world in short takes by his medic-narrator. TILTING AT WINDMILLS: An Autobiography, by Charles Peters. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The founder and editor of The Washington Monthly tells how insatiable curiosity and strong opinions turned a lawyer into a journalist indispensable for his magazine and for his influence on younger journalists. THE HERMIT OF 69th STREET: The Working Papers of Norbert Kosky, by Jerzy Kosinski. (Seaver/Holt, $19.95.) A clever satirical novel whose protagonist, a famous novelist and Holocaust survivor, is accused of not writing his own books; more than somewhat reminiscent of an episode in the author's own life. SPENCE + LILA, by Bobbie Ann Mason. (Harper & Row, $12.95.) Ms. Mason's ear for dialogue is as sharp as ever in this short, artful, unhurried love story about a farm couple in crisis who don't really understand what is happening to them.
