title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: In the guide to Moscow's subway system and the palatial stations, the incredibly low fare of 5 kopecks or 1/20 of a ruble retained for their use is cited. But how does one arrive at the U.S. equivalent of ''about 3 cents''? According to the official rate imposed on tourists, whereby the ruble is worth almost as much as the British pound, 5 kopecks would equal about 8 U.S. cents. According to the ruble's real value, demonstrated by black market money changers - about the same as the French franc - 5 kopecks would represent at most about a penny. One wonders if Gorbachev's program of having goods and services priced at their real cost will ever include the subway, and what the result would be. EDGAR H. LEONI New York, N.Y.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BEFORE THE FLAMES: A Quest for the History of Arab Americans. By Gregory Orfalea. (University of Texas, $22.50.) When the journalist Gregory Orfalea began this encyclopedic history of a century of Arab-American immigrants in the United States, his was a personal quest for ethnic identity. Curious to know more about his fellow Arab-Americans, as well as disturbed by the absence of a visible Arab-American community, Mr. Orfalea embarked on a series of interviews, traveling to more than 20 American cities, where he talked with Arab-Americans from all walks of life. The result is a composite portrait of three waves of mostly Syrian and Lebanese immigrants, broken up by a series of in-depth profiles of prominent Arab-Americans, among them Danny Thomas, the diplomat Philip Habib and Edward Said, the literary critic and Middle East specialist. Though Mr. Orfalea has clearly done exhaustive research, his focus is at times overwhelmed by the bulk of material he has amassed. Also, while his lyrical style works well when he is telling stories, it is less effective when he attempts an exegesis of his findings. Part of the problem, as Mr. Orfalea suggests, is the elusiveness of the Arab-American community. He repeatedly observes that most Arab-Americans shrink from identifying themselves as an ethnic entity, preferring assimilation to organizing politically for Arab or Palestinian causes, but he never successfully analyzes why this is so. Instead, he ends this book in much the same way that he begins. Arab-Americans are ''exceptionally individual'' yet ''collectively anonymous,'' he says, a paradoxical conclusion that leaves him with his central question unanswered. Who are Arab-Americans?

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: STREAK: Joe DiMaggio and the Summer of '41. By Michael Seidel. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) Baseball has its magic numbers: 2,130 (the number of consecutive games that Lou Gehrig played in over the course of 14 years), 511 (the number of career pitching victories racked up by Cy Young) and 56 (the number of consecutive games in which Joe DiMaggio hit safely in 1941). This last feat is lovingly chronicled, game by game, in ''Streak,'' a book New York Yankee fans will admire. Michael Seidel, a professor of literature at Columbia University, faithfully re-creates what life in America was like during that summer before the United States entered World War II. He has interviewed many of the men who played with and against DiMaggio that year and tells just how DiMaggio managed to keep on hitting and hitting. Part of it, of course, was luck, and DiMaggio's ran out in Cleveland on the night of July 17. With the help of some excellent fielding by a third baseman named Ken Keltner, the Cleveland Indians' pitchers Al Smith and Jim Bagby stopped the Yankee Clipper. ''Sportswriter Dave Anderson,'' Mr. Seidel writes, ''pointed out that head shots of Smith and Bagby appeared in newspapers all over the country the next day as if they had assassinated a king.'' Indeed, the author notes that even the Indians' fans were ''deeply conflicted'' during the game: when Smith walked DiMaggio, the crowd booed. And oh yes. As Mr. Seidel reminds us, there was another American League outfielder who tore the cover off the ball that summer before Pearl Harbor. For the season, Ted Williams hit .406.

description: With only five hits in two games, the San Francisco Giants needed help today. And the Pittsburgh Pirates obliged. With the bases loaded and one out in the bottom of the eighth, the Pittsburgh reliever Barry Jones threw a wild pitch that bounced high in the air, enabling two runs to score as the Giants won, 2-1.

title: Valley Stream's Future Tied to Mini-Mall Plan
description: LEAD: THE downtown shopping district in Valley Stream has fallen on hard times during the last 20 years, with a major nearby mall, Green Acres, siphoning off retail business. But a proposal to renovate a 60-year-old vacant movie theater into a three-story retail mini-mall might just turn Rockaway Avenue around, local businessmen say.

title: Creating a Christian Community on a Diverse Island
description: THE island of Long Island, a distinct geographic unit that includes Brooklyn and Queens, has traditionally been divided by political jurisdictions and widely differing social environments. Strongly ethnic and urbanized communities hug the west end of the Island, and to the east largely white, suburban neighborhoods sprawl.

title: When a Choreographer Settles Into a Formula
description: WILLIAM FORSYTHE, A MAJOR talent worth following even when he is stuck in a groove, is represented all around us this season. West Germany's Frankfurt Ballet, where he has been artistic director since 1984, has just appeared in New York City - as part of the First New York International Arts Festival - for the first time (the company made its United States debut last summer at the PepsiCo. Summerfare festival in nearby Purchase, N.Y.) with local Forsythe premieres that came on the heels of ''Behind the china dogs,'' choreographed for the New York City Ballet's American Music Festival this spring.

title: Toons and Bushers Fly High
description: MOVIE DISTRIBUTORS APPEAR to assume that, when summer arrives, the minds of their audiences go as soft as abandoned Eskimo Pies. At least, it looks that way. Schools are out. People are on vacation. Impulse theatergoing increases. Summer is a time for abbreviated, loose-fitting clothing and sloppy movies to match.

description: Q. We are building a new house that will have brick veneer on the lower half of the front wall (brick over block). I have heard that treating brick with silicone helps prevent penetration of water and the development of pressure cracks. Where can I find out about this and can I do it myself?

title: Parks That Provide Playtime for Parents, Too
description: AFTER suffering for several decades from a reputation as unsafe, unclean and unsavory, the amusement park was transformed with the opening of Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., in 1955. In the years since, the family orientation so successfully exploited by Walt Disney continues to be the driving force behind amusement park development.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: UNHEALTHFUL AIR. By Elliott Baker. (Viking, $16.95.) On one level, ''Unhealthful Air'' seems to be a defense of books and an attack on other forms of popular culture. Elliott Baker, a novelist who has also written screenplays, condemns Hollywood because its movie producers wrote off F. Scott Fitzgerald as too literary.

title: 31-Year-Old Bird Is Extraordinary
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Should The Yankees Have Fired Billy Martin?
description: Never mind the embarrassments like fighting in a topless bar in Texas and throwing handfuls of dirt at an umpire. Boys will be boys even if they are 60 years old. What really staggers the mind is that Billy Martin cannot manage any longer. Where did the inherently correct managerial decisions disappear to? The man we watched in the dugout this year was overwhelmed, gun-shy, and even timid. Dismissing him can only be viewed as face-saving for the Yankees and merciful for Billy Martin. MITCHELL RUBENSTEIN Katonah, N.Y.

title: Salmon on a Stick in the Pacific Northwest
description: In the Pacific Northwest the barbecue season doesn't have as much to do with the weather as it does with the salmon run. In early spring, Indians living near the Columbia River celebrate the first appearance of returning Chinook salmon with outdoor feasts, which are repeated, in backyards and restaurants, until the middle of fall.

title: Moscow Conference Lifts Veil On Personalities and Intrigues
description: The Communist Party conference that ended Friday has given the world an engrossing look into the heart of the party that rules the Soviet Union.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SPACE IN MOTION. By Juan Goytisolo. Translated by Helen R. Lane. (Lumen Books, Paper, $8.95.) Juan Goytisolo is a distinguished Spanish writer of novels and essays who left Spain in 1957 to escape Franco's dictatorship. He is perhaps best known here for his novels ''Count Julian'' and ''Juan the Landless.

title: Riding Merrily Along
description: RUGGLES OF RED GAP Starring Charles Laughton and Zasu Pitts (in photo), Mary Boland, Charlie Ruggles. Directed by Leo McCarey. 1935. MCA Home Video. 90 minutes. $29.95.

title: Scratches Hurt Horse Racing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Hospital Conversion Changing Islip's Face
description: LEAD: THE adaptive re-use of a major portion of the Central Islip State Hospital as a college campus by the New York Institute of Technology, begun four years ago, has drawn national attention, and is expected to be a model for the recycling of similar facilities around the country.

title: Court Figure Jailed as Perjurer
description: Jane I. Wheel, a former assistant judge who was at the center of allegations of misconduct filed against three State Supreme Court justices, has been sentenced to 45 days in jail for perjury.

title: Richard Zinman Becomes Fiance Of Miss Zambetti
description: Mr. and Mrs. Felix L. Zambetti of Riverdale, the Bronx, and West Goshen, Conn., have announced the engagment of their daughter Audrey Angela Zambetti to Richard Scott Zinman, the son of Florence T. Zinman of New York and the late Norman J. Zinman. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: Officer Is Arrested in Robbery
description: A Brooklyn police officer was arrested on robbery and kidnapping charges yesterday after an armed holdup at a bodega in East New York Friday night, the police said.

title: 2 California Cities Share Grief Over Slain Officer
description: For a few hours this week the East Palo Alto Police Department locked its doors, borrowed officers from neighboring suburbs to patrol the city's mean streets and turned out in dress blues to mourn the first local officer killed in the line of duty.

title: The Smartest Word
description: WHAT IDEA IS IT that comes to mind when you hear the noun >intelligence?

title: DATA BANK: July 3, 1988
On Latin Trip, Shultz Spoke Softly About Giving Contras Big Sticks
description: For six years, President Reagan has pressed Congress to provide more military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. But on a trip to Central America this week, Secretary of State George P. Shultz appeared reluctant to discuss American aid for the contras.

title: Barbecue From Coast to Coast
description: THE Dreamland Drive Inn Bar-B-Q, on the outskirts of Tuscaloosa, Ala., looks like a good barbecue restaurant ought to look: a smoky, clapboard building with a screen door that slaps shut, a graveled parking lot, tables with chipped Formica tops. There is just one thing on the menu at the Dreamland, and that is pork ribs, ritually served up with a couple of slabs of white bread on a paper plate.

title: Lefebvre's Followers Warned They Risk Excommunication
description: The Vatican warned adherents of Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre today that they risk excommunication if they continue to follow the traditionalist prelate's movement.

title: How High the Dollar?
description: Since last month's economic summit conference in Toronto, the dollar has risen against all major currencies. The dollar is now stronger against the West German mark and the yen, than at any time since the Oct. 19 stock market collapse. With the exception of West Germany, the central banks of the major trading nations are doing little to support their currencies against the dollar. Will the dollar's rise continue? Richard E. Witten Vice president, foreign exchange, Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Miriam I. Fredman, Clothes Merchant, 63
description: Miriam I. Fredman, the wife of Samuel Fredman, chairman of the board of trustees of the State University of New York at Purchase, died in an automobile accident Wednesday in Horsholm, Denmark, where she was attending a conference with her husband. She was 63 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Observing Tradition While Flouting It
description: ''ONE THING I HATE IS tradition,'' the opera director Tito Capobianco declared during a recent discussion in a New York City Opera rehearsal studio. Sitting at a long table filled with notebooks, empty coffee cups and a score of Verdi's ''Rigoletto,'' the production he had begun rehearsing a few days earlier, Mr. Capobianco drew on a thin cigar and elaborated. ''Tradition is like starch. It is sometimes indistinguishable from routine. And for me, routine represents the end of the arts. What I do is, I study tradition, and then destroy it.''

title: Summerfare '88: A Sampler of International Performances
description: MENTION to Christopher Hunt that the ninth Pepsico Summerfare Arts Festival, his fourth as artistic director, is being publicized as having ''the most unusual program yet,'' and he pauses. He does not disavow the claim, but he suspects that it is being misinterpreted.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article about Afghanistan in The Week in review on June 19 described American aid to Pakistan, incorrectly. Since 1981, the United States had spent or authorized more than $7 billion in aid to Pakistan. None of it has been covert.

title: Two Artistic Survivors Look Back
description: LEAD: FROM the beginning more than 40 years ago, the painter James Brooks and the sculptor Ibram Lassaw never doubted that the artistic road they had taken was revolutionary.

title: Lisa Jurries Marries
description: Lisa Hope Jurries, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman D. Jurries of Hamilton, Mich., and William Howard Waldorf, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Waldorf of Brookville, L.I., were married yesterday at the Reformed Church in Brookville. The Revs. Allan Ramirez and Roger Vander Kolk officiated. The bride, who graduated from Hope College, teaches English at Island Trees Junior High School in Levittown, L.I. The bridegroom, a graduate of Yale University, is a financial consultant at Structured Capital Designs in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: A Computer for Tin Pan Alley
description: WHAT began in 1973 as a modest project to design a computer program to teach Dartmouth College music students is turning a small high-tech company in Vermont into a major technological force in Hollywood and Tin Pan Alley.

title: The Picture Has Brightened On Pocket-Size Screens
description: AFTER THE SUMMER SOLSTICE, the woodland trails in our Berkshire neighborhood swarm with fugitives from the city. They seek the bucolic, accompanied by Walkmans to supply Mozart on the meadow or rock on the rocks.

title: GOODEN IN CONTROL FOR 11TH VICTORY
description: It took no tricks, no guile, no magic, none of the fantasy-finish stuff for the Mets to beat the Houston Astros again last night and to prove that they have survived the ''slump.'' They did it with basic muscle, and almost with no resistance.

title: Kennedy Cast Key Votes In 7 Conservative Rulings
description: The evidence so far suggests that Justice Anthony M. Kennedy may be at least marginally more conservative than Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., the pivotal centrist he replaced, on issues including criminal law, the death penalty and perhaps civil rights.

title: WHAT I LEARNED: REFLECTIONS ON MY RUN
description: MY RACE FOR the Democratic Presidential nomination took me to a close second place in Iowa, third in New Hampshire and Minnesota - and, apart from a healthy victory in my home state of Illinois, it went downhill from there.

title: Alyssa M. Bliss Plans to Marry L. S. Greenberg
description: An Aug. 6 wedding is planned by Alyssa Maria Bliss and Lawrence Scott Greenberg, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Bliss of New York, have announced. Mr. Greenberg is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Greenberg, also of New York.

description: The bad and the beautiful unite in Rudolf Nureyev's new production of ''The Nutcracker,'' which had its United States premiere with the Paris Opera Ballet on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: FISHEL'S EXAMPLE IS HIS HERITAGE TO BASEBALL
description: BOB Fishel collapsed and died on his way home from the American League office, only a few blocks away, Thursday night. In other words, he worked until the final half hour of his life, which was exactly what he always wanted.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 5 about the Midwest misidentified a home-run hitter in the 1960 World Series; he was Bill Mazeroski. The article also misidentified the losing pitcher; he was Ralph Terry.

title: The Force of Lightning Lasts for 20 Years
description: ''PERUVIAN Indians believed that a person who was struck by lightning and survived would be restored to full health if he drank vicuna blood.'' Reading this item in a newspaper recently, I thought, ''Why didn't I know about this when lightning struck our house in New Canaan 20 years ago?''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
'One Fatt Calfe'
description: LEAD: LAST Sunday afternoon, before hundreds of witnesses at the city's Davenport Park, Mayor Leonard C. Paduano of New Rochelle discharged a centuries-old obligation by presenting William Rodman Pell 2d, ''sixteenth claimant to the Lordship and Manor of Pelham,'' with ''one fatt calfe.''

title: A Vanguard Festival Seeks More in Less
description: WHEN THE PEPSICO Summerfare was first conceived back in 1980, there was no Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, no Serious Fun at Lincoln Center, and the First New York International Festival of the Arts was just a gleam in Martin Segal's eye. Now, as Summerfare prepares to open its ninth season Friday (through July 31) at the State University of New York at Purchase, its director, Christopher Hunt, is beginning to reassess the raison d'etre of the performing arts festival.

title: Lyn Ackerman Weds Theodore S. Babcock
description: The marriage of Lyn Chadbourne Ackerman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Ackerman of Sarasota, Fla., to Theodore S. Babcock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Nash Babcock of Old Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Roland Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Missiles That Are More Accurate and Popular Than Ever
description: The fastest way to move a warhead between two points is with a ballistic missile - a fact that more and more countries are beginning to exploit. Ballistic missiles propel their payloads in the same way that rockets boost satellites into orbit: Once the boost phase ends, the missile is no longer powered. The warhead separates from the booster, and the course of the warhead's flight from that point on is much like the course of an arrow that is shot into the air. Because of gains in rocket science, the missiles are gaining in accuracy.

description: NEW JERSEY'S Senators have asked the Government to study how a change in tax laws would encourage people to take mass transportation to work and leave their cars at home.

Nothing has happened since then to alter the public's summary judgment, which condemned the coin. Nonetheless, at least one company is touting the coin as a ''worthy family heirloom'' and offering it for sale in 12-piece sets for over $150 per set.

Ott of Baton Rouge, commenting in an unusual public dispute among the nation's Roman Catholic bishops over whether the church should approve disseminating information on the use of condoms to fight AIDS.

title: Headliners; On the Outs
description: Pope John Paul II has had it with Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre. The generation-long dispute between the Swiss Archbishop and the Vatican began when the Archbishop denounced the church's mid-1960's liberalizations and kept to such Roman Catholic traditions as the Latin mass. He said the church had been infiltrated by ''wolves and thieves'' and was consumed by the ''cancer of liberalism.'' Over the years, the Archbishop's traditionalists, as they are called, have grown to more than 100,000 worldwide, including more than 220 priests. The final straw came last week, when the 82-year-old primate ignored Vatican warnings and consecrated four bishops, thus creating the first schism in the Roman Catholic church since 1870. Pope John Paul II promptly excommunicated the Archbishop and the four bishops.

title: Chastened by Floods, Venice Seeks Alliance With Nature
description: EVER since marauding Franks drove this city's founders to seek an island refuge, more than 1,100 years ago, Venetians have been known for an aggressive genius at adapting nature to their demands. Now, after centuries of building canals and causeways, they are trying to undo some of the damage they have wrought.

title: Italian Essence of the East End
description: WAINSCOTT'S newest restaurant, Sapore di Mare, is seafood, Italian and very Hamptons. If a movie maker were trying to catch the essence of the East End, Sapore di Mare would be perfect for location shots. It blossoms with an airy, summer aura: white stucco walls, wood and terra-cotta tile floors, ceiling fans, leafy palms and flower-encircled screened porches.

title: Jazz Festival; For Brubeck, Old Spirit, New Faces
description: The Dave Brubeck Quartet, which appeared at the Kaufman Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y as part of the JVC Jazz Festival on Thursday evening, was not, of course, the celebrated Brubeck Quartet of the 1950's. But it was so similar in spirit, style and point of view that one almost felt time had stood still even though all the faces, aside from Mr. Brubeck's, were different.

The historian and the entertainer, patriots both, are collectors of Stars and Stripes paintings by the American Impressionist Childe Hassam (1859-1935), whose 1917 canvas of flags aflutter over Fifth Avenue hangs in the White House.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SUMMER FESTIVAL With the customary blend of the classics and pops - and something new this time out, a trio of free family concerts - Friends of the Arts opens its annual Summer Festival today on a promising note, with Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra. Conducted by Gerard Schwarz and with the ianist Lilian Kallir as soloist, the ensemble plays an all-Mozart program, including the Symphony No. 36 in C (K. 425), ''Linz,'' at 7:30 P.M. Then on Saturday at 8 P.M. the tones shifts when the Count Basie Orchestra takes over. The first free concerts, featuring Chris Holder, the folk singer-storyteller, are Friday at 1:30 and 8 P.M. Everything is at the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay. For ticket information call 922-0061. Future appearances include Judy Collins, July 16; Jean-Pierre Rampal, July 31; the Israel Philharmonic, Aug. 13, and Arlo Guthrie, Aug. 20, MUSIC, MUSIC, MUSICALS

description: Christopher Green, a playful 6-year-old from Jamaica, Queens, was about to depart for a two-week vacation at a countryside farm, and it was time for his mother to say goodbye.

title: Caroline Cooley Is a Bride
description: Caroline Rose Cooley and Harvey Loeb, lawyers in the criminal division of Westchester County Legal Aid Services in White Plains, were married last evening at the Albany Country Club by Rabbi Judith Wolkoff. The bride, who will retain her name, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Cooley of Troy, N.Y. She graduated from St. Lawrence University and the Antioch School of Law. Mr. Loeb, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Loeb of Bronxville, N.Y., graduated from the State University at Buffalo and the Vermont Law School.

title:
INVESTING;
Learning to Live With a Stronger Dollar
description: LEAD: INVESTORS in financial markets often develop obsessions with a single economic barometer, to the seeming exclusion of all others. The most recent example is the dollar.

title: 'How I'll Spend My Summer': Ten Creative Artists Fess Up
description: Do creative artists wilt or thrive under the summer sun? Here are reports from 10 of them. Garrison Keillor, humorist: New York's been very good to me this summer - in fact, it's an easy haul here compared to Minnesota, where everything's drying up. My calender is absolutely free - it's like being a kid again, with no commitments except family birthdays and the like. And of course, the week the Minnesota Twins come to play the Yankees. Now I'm just working on what I want, a book, and trying to crack a screenplay. But I am looking forward to going to Denmark at the end of the summer, with its North Atlantic climate and a cold sea that's the test of a man's real character. Malcolm Jamal-Warner, actor: I'm performing in an Off Broadway play, ''Three Ways Home'' in which I play a character very different from Theo Huxtable. This guy is a 16-year-old psycho. Lanford Wilson, playwright: What am I doing this summer? Working in the garden, watching every Mets game, and working on a play - not necessarily in that order. The Mets are first. If they do well, I do well; if they don't, I crawl under a table and sulk. The play was called ''Sympathetic Magic,'' but it's gotten away from me. I look at it now and ask, ''What are you?'' I'm hoping it will tell me by about August. John Lithgow, actor: I love doing Broadway in the summertime. After the Tonys and the so-called end of the season, the tension eases and we can rest on our laurels - and the show [ ''M. Butterfly'' ] is better than it's ever been. My performance is more focused after I can ride my bicycle to the theater or have a picnic in the park with my kids. And then there's the lovely sort of outdoorsy feel to the entire theater district. I'm happy to be working straight through to the fall, and then I'll enjoy a summer vacation. Spike Lee, film maker: In a week I start shooting a movie in Bedford-Stuyvesant Point. It's gonna be hot, but that's what I need - ''Do the Right Thing'' is about how the heat affects people. I don't have a house in the Hamptons, so the dog days is what I have to work with. But I wouldn't have it any other way. Linda Ellerbee, humorist: I've been working on a mystery novel, and for me it's the hardest writing. The only way it's going to get done is to go lock myself away, and that's just what I'll do when I turn on the answering machine in town and head to my house in the country. Then I'll go sit in the river a while. My idea of a vacation is to plant myself in one place and refuse to look a boarding pass in the eye. Bobby Short, cabaret singer: Ah, summer - it's another busy one. Some day I'll go traveling, to Russia and Scandinavia, but for now it's back to my house in France. Come to think of it, having a house like that is a little like having a wife. But it's relaxing there, unpretentious and calming - although any country house with a pool is bound to draw house guests. Most of all I'm looking forward to working on two books - but I may putter in the kitchen too. I've got a piano in the house, but a finger can afford to take off two months, I think. That way I'll be refreshed in the fall - for a couple of weeks, at any rate. Midori, violinist: Usually I go to music school, but this year I'm taking French and European history at Horace Mann. I don't mind not having a vacation, because I love to study. I like going to Horace Mann because it's so different from the Professional Children's School I go to during the season. I just finished my sophomore year, but at P.C.S. it's hard to make relationships with people: the faces are always different because they're actors and they're always going off on location. I also like Horace Mann because I don't think anybody there even knows I play the violin. It just doesn't matter. Ellen Stewart, theater director: I got the MacArthurFoundation grant some years ago and bought a ruin 10 minutes from Spoleto, Italy. I'm trying to create an artists' residence there. It seems a good way to share the award. Jackie Mason, comic: I'm going to sit in lobbies a lot, because I like air-conditioning. Since they invented lobbies with air-conditioning, a normal sensible person shouldn't go anywhere else, sweat like a pig, age before your time, and pass away just to prove you got a tan.''

title: The Artists of Summer
description: TO THOSE WHO FOLLOW CONTEMPORARY art, the large rock behind Daniel Chester French's tiny second studio in Stockbridge, Mass., may seem strangely familiar. That's because its form, transposed onto a thin aluminum skin, reappeared on 57th Street in an untitled sculpture by Robert Lobe. Mr. Lobe, who lives in New York, spent the summer of 1985 living and working at Chesterwood, French's estate, in the popular 19th-century artist's former studio. Like Mr. Lobe, many creative artists - painters, dancers, writers, sculptors, composers - spend their summers deeply immersed in the creative process. Taking advantage of residency programs in scenic, secluded locations, they are able to work without the distractions that seem part and parcel of daily life. This summer some are working away at their art in studios near the sea in Montauk, on Long Island's eastern tip; others can be found deep in the woods of New Hampshire, in the resort town of Saratoga Springs, and in Giverny, in France, in the midst of the legendary gardens of the Impressionist Claude Monet.

description: Auto Racing Elliott Wins by Inches: Bill Elliott held off Rick Wilson yesterday to win the Firecracker 400 Nascar race at Daytona International Speedway in Florida. Elliott, who started 38th in the 42-car field, did not lead until 23 laps from the end of the 400-mile, 160-lap race. Once he got his Ford Thunderbird in front, however, he kept it there, beating Wilson's Oldsmobile Cutlass by less than the length of his hood. Elliott averaged 163.302 miles per hour as he earned the winner's share of $63,500 from a purse of $549,020. To get his first Firecracker victory, Elliott came from farther back than any winner in the 30 years that the race has been run. The mark was set by Bobby Isaac, who won from 21st in 1971.(AP) Golf Little Has Two-Stroke Edge: Sally Little took another step toward her first Ladies Professional Golf Association victory since 1982 by shooting a three-under-par 69 yesterday for a two-stroke lead after three rounds of the du Maurier Classic in Coquitlam, British Columbia. Little had a 54-hole total of 208 after three trips round the 6,361-yard Vancouver Golf Club course. Sherri Turner and Laura Davies of England were tied for second at 210.(AP) Jacobsen Stretches Lead: Peter Jacobsen stretched his lead to four strokes yesterday after three rounds of the $900,000 Beatrice Western Open in Oak Brook, Ill. Jacobsen shot a three-under-par 69 over the Butler National Golf Club course. Jacobsen completed 54 holes in 204 and matched the largest third-round lead on the PGA Tour this season. Dan Forsman, Dave Eichelberger, Bill Britton and Jim Benepe, playing in his first PGA Tour event, shared second at 208.(AP) Yachting Australians Finish First: Kookaburra III of Australia, the boat that lost to Dennis Conner in the America's Cup last year, swept Bengal III of Japan yesterday to win the World 12-Meter championship in Lulea, Sweden. Peter Gilmour guided the boat to victories of 2 minutes 2 seconds and 2:27 in the best-of-three series in the Gulf of Bosnia. It was the second consecutive year that Bengal III lost in the final. Last year it lost to the New Zealand boat, Kiwi Magic, off Sardinia. Gilmour had a 7-0 record in the round-robin semifinals en route to the championship. (AP) Horse Show Pint O'Guiness Ridden to Victory: Megan Furth of San Francisco, Calif., rode Pint O'Guiness to two penalty-free rides to top a 26-horse field in the Junior Jumpoff yesterday at the 19th annual Lake Placid Horse Show. title: The Where and Ware of Hagi
description: JAPANESE connoisseurs have an old saying: ''One, Raku; two, Hagi; three, Karatsu.'' They have long ranked the most precious ceramic wares made for the tea ceremony in this order. The charms of Hagi ware's rough clay and rich, pockmarked surfaces, laced with cracks in the glaze, take on character and deeper tones with age and use. Its blushing, soft reddish and creamy white glazes, displaying the voluptuous warmth of living flesh, are often described in feminine terms. (Raku, known for the assymetrical, hand-built, low-fired tea bowls in a bold, direct and ''masculine'' style, is said to have been originated by Japan's most famous tea master, Sen no Rikyu, who died in 1591. Karatsu ware transmits a tradition, originally Korean, of freehand painting in dark-brown underglaze iron on a sandy-brown body.) Before you set out to see today's Hagi-yaki (Hagi ware) in and around this port city about 60 miles west of Hiroshima, you should first look at some Old Hagi ware (defined as pre-1770) and the Korean rice bowls that formed the base of its tradition. A good place to do this is at the Ishii Chawan Bijutsukan (Ishii Tea Bowl Museum) in the Minami Furuhagi-machi section (open from 9 to 11:30 A.M. and 1 to 5 P.M.; closed Tuesday and the month of January; admission about $2.40; telephone 2-1211). A visit there will give you an idea of Hagi ware's history and also some standards by which to evaluate the work of contemporary potters.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SHORT SEASON: And Other Stories. By Jerry Klinkowitz. (Johns Hopkins University, $16.95.) These 28 stories by Jerry Klinkowitz - who is the executive director of the Waterloo (Iowa) Indians baseball team when he isn't teaching English at the University of Northern Iowa - span a single season with the youthful, cheerful, league-leading Mason City Royals, a make-believe Class A farm club of the Kansas City Royals. The journey progresses as a series of snapshots of the players and their support staff. ''Baseball Bingo,'' for example, describes a lonely public-address announcer's yearning for the pretty girls in the stands; ''Nicknames'' introduces a sluggish infielder who is rumored to eat cats; ''The Swoon Wagon'' stars an ancient pitching coach who perpetuates the illegal art of doctoring baseballs. But like a ballgame itself, this book's most vivid stories are interspersed with dull stretches of banal play-by-play. In addition, the first six pieces are so jammed with quickly sketched characters that even the most dutiful reader can't sort them out. When the tales narrow their focus, some appealing personalities emerge. But other stories merely serve to round out the lineup. Perhaps the most irksome feature of this collection is its tolerance of unfinished business. Good stories are built around a team bus driver's dangerous fondness for drink, a teen-age ball shagger's crush on a shortstop, a pitcher's theft of a Mercedes-Benz. However, the bus driver and the teen-ager quickly vanish, and the pitcher is never held accountable for the stolen car. Over all, ''Short Season'' has the feel of a tedious extra-inning game.
