title: GUNMAN OF THE I.R.A.: A 5-YEAR WAIT
description: When Joe Doherty set up a round of beers at Clancy's Bar in Manhattan on June 28, 1983, the customers, actually F.B.I. agents, drew revolvers and placed him under arrest.

title: Radio Entrepreneur Mixes Fun and Money
description: Three rules guide Robert F. X. Sillerman's life: having fun, making money and having fun at making money.

title: U.S. SOCCER HOPING TO RISE ON LIFT FROM WORLD CUP
description: Soccer has always held a curious position on the United States' athletic landscape as a sport whose lovers invest more time and money in playing it than in watching it. Just look at the numbers: with perhaps 10 million Americans playing, coaching and refereeing, grass-roots and school programs are thriving as never before. Yet the only professional leagues currently in operation are minor regional leagues.

title: Results Plus
description: Horse Show

title: Metro Matters; College Spanish Helps Principal Reach His School
description: In Washington Heights, long a neighborhood of immigrants, virtually every student at Public School 189 is Hispanic, half the kindergarten classes are bilingual and the president of the Parent-Teacher Association, Irma Aliaga, doesn't speak English.

title: Sabotage Aimed at Computer Company Destroys Government Data
description: Information stored on personal com-puters at the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and several other Government agencies has been destroyed by a computer program designed to sabotage a private computer company in Texas.

title: In New York, the Cultural Season Is Beginning to Have No Seasons
description: Gone are the lazy summer days when the Muses fled New York City to pitch their tents at bosky summer festivals and the only sign of life at Carnegie Hall was a graduation exercise.

title: Energy Panel Nomination
description: President Reagan intends to nominate Charles Stalon, a holdover member of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, to serve additional time on the commission, the White House announced Friday.

title: Question Box
description: This column usually is confined to interesting and sometimes bizarre questions submitted by readers. This week's column, though, is confined to the interesting and sometimes preposterous answers submitted by readers in response to a question answered last month. It inspired such an unusual number and range of responses that they are worth sharing. What follows is the question, and summaries of how readers replied. QUESTION: In a nine-inning baseball game, what is the absolute minimum amount of pitches that must be thrown?

title: Reviews/Music; Yusef Lateef Celebrates Songs of Many Cultures
description: In the uncharted territory where world music and jazz converge, the line separating deep mystical expression from showy exotica is often very thin. Though Yusef Lateef, the composer and multi-instrumentalist who made a rare New York appearance at Symphony Space on Friday evening, makes music that sometimes sounds synonymous with 1950's Hollywood snake charmer's music, he usually manages to stay on a higher lyrical plane.

title: The Editorial Notebook; What's Happening at International High?
description: International High School is one of the more exclusive secondary schools in New York City. Only students who have been in the United States less than four years and who score below the 20th percentile on an English language proficiency exam are admitted.

title: Review/Television; A Refresher Course on World War I
description: History keeps repeating itself, particularly if there is a lot of it on film, as the reprise of World War I demonstrates in the premiere tonight at 9 P.M. of a new series, ''Our Century,'' on the Arts & Entertainment Network.

title: Scattered U.S. Aides Link Up by Phone On Airliner Incident
description: After a series of telephone calls that began before dawn, President Reagan decided today to remain at his Camp David retreat rather than return to the White House to deal with the shooting down of an Iranian airliner by an American warship.

title: Books of The Times; A Family Confronts the AIDS Crisis
description: At Risk By Alice Hoffman 219 pages. G.P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''After receiving further data and evaluating information available from the Persian Gulf, we believe that the cruiser U.S.S. Vincennes, while actively engaged with threatening Iranian surface units and protecting itself from what was concluded to be a hostile aircraft, shot down an Iranian airliner over the Strait of Hormuz. The U.S. Government deeply regrets this incident.'' - Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. [ 4:1. ]

title: On Your Own; Craig Virgin on Running Defensively
description: Establish eye contact with motorists so you can telegraph motorists so you can telegraph moves and they can respond accordingly.

title: Statement by Joint Chiefs' Chairman: 'U.S. Deeply Regrets This Incident' . . . but Commanders on the Scene Believed 'Their Units Were in Jeopardy'
description: Following is a transcript of the briefing conducted today by Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff: OPENING STATEMENT

title: AIDS PAROLEES GRAPPLING WITH A LIFE IN THE SHORT TERM
description: Since Gail Temple and Gary Lattanzi have been supervising parolees with AIDS, they have found themselves teaching grown men how to use condoms and sending others, who probably have only a few more months to live, back to jail.

title: Independence, From What?
description: When Richard Rovsek, a California marketing specialist, examined the little American flag his son Christian was waving at the Fourth of July parade last year, he saw red. The label said, ''Made in Hong Kong.'' Mr. Rovsek promptly composed a proposal to ban all flag imports, and sent it off to everyone he could think of, including The Times.

title: Sports World Specials; Wings Above Maine
description: If they look up into the sky and see a World War I vintage biplane droning overhead, vacationers near Rockland, Me., today may shake their heads and wonder if they have been transported back 70 years in time. Under a canvas flying helmet and pair of goggles the craggy-faced pilot of the spindly olive-green machine is Jack Gardiner, a retired airline executive. He will be making one of his regularly scheduled demonstration flights in the Owls Head Transportation Museum's replica of a 1915 Royal Air Force F.E.8 fighter plane.

title: Reviews/Music; Ozawa and the Boston For Tanglewood's 50th
description: The Tanglewood Festival has opened a busy summer with a busy weekend. Here at the end of August, a yearlong orgy of Leonard Bernstein 70th-birthday parties comes to an end. But on Friday there was an anniversary for an inanimate object as well, one as closely associated with Tanglewood as the highly animated Mr. Bernstein. It is the Shed, one of the happier matings of indoor and outdoor concert ambiance and now celebrating its 50th year. The 5,000 seats and one-and-a-half acre roof - plus all the memories held in between - were rededicated Friday night as the Serge Koussevitzy Music Shed. Seiji Ozawa and the Boston Symphony played the Beethoven Ninth Symphony and the audience joined in for ''A Mighty Fortress is Our God.''

title: Fort Howard Sees Potential New Offers
description: The Fort Howard Paper Corporation disclosed late last week that a number of unidentified parties had contacted the First Boston Corporation, the company's financial adviser, expressing interest in the company.

title: On Your Own; Liberty to Liberty by Land and Sea
description: THE rallying cry for the 200 athletes competing in today's sixth annual Liberty to Liberty Triathlon and Biathlon could be ''Bi, if by land! Tri, if by sea!''

title: Arabs Riot in Jerusalem Over Archeological Dig
description: A riot erupted in the Old City of Jerusalem this morning when Israeli authorities began excavating an ancient canal near the Western Wall and Al Aqsa Mosque, among the holiest sites for Jews and Moslems.

title: MATCHMAKERS FOR MAGAZINE INDUSTRY
description: Among the many investment banking boutiques springing up on Wall Street, few have carved out a niche like that of Veronis, Suhler & Associates. Cultivating a large network of communications industry executives, the firm has fast become one of the most visible and active marriage brokers in the magazine business.

title: Johann Baptist Gradl, German Politician, 84
description: Johann Baptist Gradl, a former minister in the West German Government who had worked for German reunification, died here Friday after a long illness, city officials said. He was 84 years old.

title: The Jazz Festival; A Tribute to Machito
description: ''Latin Jazz Jam: A Tribute to Machito,'' at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, was a dismal affair for the most part. As usual for JVC Jazz Festival concerts at Carnegie Hall, the sound system was inadequate, turning solos into noisy interludes. And as usual for these long, star-laden shows, the banal presentation managed to crush the genuinely musical moments. Making matters worse were two disingenuous masters of ceremony, whose insightful comments were on the level of ''Tito Puente's been playing for three and a half decades - that's 35 years!''

title: Washington Talk: Trade Representatives; A Difference in Societies That Can Give U.S. an Edge in Talks
description: Sermet Pasin, an international trade official from Turkey, remembers watching an American trade delegation, four young women, walking into a room in Geneva to face more than a dozen negotiators from the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry in a dispute over food import restrictions.

title: On Your Own: Fitness; You Might Climb the Walls After This Unusual Workout
description: IT'S time to celebrate the fourth-floor walk-up. It's not the apartment we're interested in, but the stairs. The typical fourth-floor walk-up should have about 50 steps, providing about 40 feet of vertical rise. Moving your body up and down the stairs is work, and work equals exercise.

title: China Nods Sagely at Soviet Changes
description: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev toured his carefully crafted landscape of economic and political change with 5,000 delegates to the Communist Party conference in Moscow last week, he trod terrain that seemed familiar to many Chinese.

title: UNDER SEIGE, BANNER MAKERS YET WAVE
description: Flag Row. Now there was a neighborhood, down around Fifth Avenue and 16th Street. It was just the kind of manufacturing district that gave New York its gritty taste. If Betsy Ross had survived the Industrial Revolution, that is where she would have found a job, in the turn-of-the-century loft buildings with stone facades and grand windows.

title: Miriam I. Fredman, Clothes Merchant, 63
description: Miriam I. Fredman, the wife of Samuel Fredman, chairman of the board of trustees of the State University of New York at Purchase, died in an automobile accident Wednesday in Horsholm, Denmark, where she was attending a conference with her husband. She was 63 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: On Your Own; Hiking Made Lighter
description: A new generation of lightweight hiking boots has turned backpacking into less of a back-breaking sport.

title: The Downing of Flight 655; Britain Regrets Jet 'Tragedy' And Backs the U.S. Account
description: Britain said today that it deeply regretted the deaths of those aboard an Iranian airliner shot down in the Persian Gulf this morning, and it endorsed Washington's explanation that American forces believed they were acting in self-defense when they fired on the jet.

title: Southland to Sell Units
description: The Southland Corporation said on Friday that it had agreed to sell its snack foods division. It said the sale will include the El-Ge Potato Chip Company of York, Pa., Keystone Pretzel Bakery of Lititz, Pa., and Pate Foods of South Beloit, Ill., but it disclosed no other terms of the agreement.

title: Reviews/Music; A Fusion of Soviet and U.S. Song
description: Few pop musicians have dedicated themselves as assiduously to promoting peace, harmony and a benign new-age consciousness than the soprano saxophonist Paul Winter. As environmentalists creating music that brings in the natural world, the seven-member Paul Winter Consort has recorded in the Grand Canyon and performed with the sounds of humpback whales. As good-will ambassadors, they have sung with well-known Soviet poets, and recently they recorded an album, ''Earthbeat,'' with a 10-member Soviet group, the Dimitri Pokrovsky Singers. The ensemble, which is involved in ecological causes, consists of folkloric preservationists dedicated to discovering and keeping alive village circle songs and chants that are hundreds of years old.

title: AS RIVER ROLLS GENTLY BY, FOES OF A BRIDGE CONVENE
description: There were banjos playing under the elms here today, where the sun-spangled waters of the Hudson River lap a sandstone shore. There were Democrats in shirt-sleeves and Republicans in white bucks, state and local politicians, nonpartisan senior citizens and children too young to vote.

title: An Officer Is Held In Robbery of Bodega
description: A Brooklyn police officer has been arrested on robbery and kidnapping charges after an armed holdup at a bodega in East New York on Friday night, the police said.

title: JACKSON CRITICIZES PARTY'S CHAIRMAN
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, miffed that he has not been consulted by the chairman of the Democratic Party on crucial decisions, plans to press Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for a ''leadership role'' in the fall Presidential campaign, Mr. Jackson's advisers said today.

title: Liberals Ready To Pursue Role In Mayor Race
description: After five years of internal dissension, a boycott at City Hall and in Albany and serious financial problems, the New York State Liberal Party is apparently unified, financially stable and prepared to play a substantial role in next year's mayoral election.

title: Markets Closed Today
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. Banks, government offices and most businesses also will be closed.

title: COMPANY-NAME CONSULTANTS BATTLE OVER POLL
description: A battle for recognition has broken out in the small world of consulting firms that help companies find new names. Two established firms that created such names as Navistar, Unisys and Primerica are defending their skills against a competitor's claims that, at least to consumers, such names are jabberwocky.

title: U.S. RIDER GETS BIG CHANCE
description: As expected, a highly regarded American rode with the PDM team as the Tour de France, the world's premier bicycle race, warmed up today in Brittany.

title: F.B.I. Search of Loral Office Said to Focus on Consultants' Role
description: Federal investigators searched the office of Fred R. Nebiker, a vice president of the Loral Corporation's Defense Systems Group, in June seeking documents concerning the company's unsuccessful effort to win a Navy contract to build a prototype blimp, according to a union leader and people close to the company.

title: Sports News Briefs; Soccer Fans Balk At Plan for Trial
description: Six of the Liverpool soccer fans accused of manslaughter in the 1985 Heysel Stadium disaster said Friday they would not return to Belgium to stand trial unless they were paid travel and accommodation costs for the three-month period.

title: Hostage to Jackson
description: Thirteen years ago, when U.S. foreign policy was paralyzed after Watergate, the Soviet Union intervened in a civil war in Africa. Cuban troops were dispatched to Angola to set up a Marxist state and to defeat the popular movement headed by the black leader Jonas Savimbi.

title: What Study of the Press And Israel Really Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Failures Seen in Safeguards on Erroneous Attacks
description: The downing of an Iranian jetliner is striking evidence of how split-second decisions in modern warfare may be based on incomplete electronic information.

title: Compare and Contrast 'Ulysses' and the Custodians of Its Text
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; From Paris, Nureyev's 'Nutcracker'
description: Rudolf Nureyev often overcomplicates matters when he restages the classics. For instance, his production of ''The Nutcracker'' contains some fussy new choreography, and he has burdened the ballet's simple story with a symbolical scheme in which Drosselmeyer, the eccentric toymaker and magician, becomes the handsome Nutcracker Prince.

title: INSIDE
description: Blimp Contract Under Study The F.B.I. and the S.E.C. are investigating the rivalry between two military contractors for a $168.9 million contract to build a blimp. Page 10. Rain at Wimbledon The men's singles final between Boris Becker and Stefan Edberg was suspended by rain in the first set. It will resume today. Page 37. Perestroika in China China has largely undergone the type of economic restructuring sought by Moscow. But openness in public debate lags behind. Page 3. Proudly Flies the Flag. . . . . .and just about everywhere, too.

title: Katowice Journal; Bad Times (and Machines) Undercut Coal Capital
description: Along the railroad tracks, where Francuska Street climbs gently, stand tenements encrusted with neo-classical flourishes that do not want to remain standing.

title: Corrections
description: An anecdote in the Metropolitan Diary column of The Living Section on May 4 about a train trip from Connecticut to New York City misstated the approach to Manhattan taken by Amtrak trains from the northeast.

title: Global Briefs
description: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States between January and May shrank by 15.5 percent from the period last year, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported. The decline, to $3.16 billion, from $3.65 billion, came as growth of Korean imports from the United States outpaced the growth of Korean exports to the United States.

title: HOLIDAY BOX
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections. SportsMonday begins on page 34, Business Day on page 29.

title: Shultz's Aim: Isolating Sandinistas?
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's visit to Central America last week appeared to be a renewed effort to isolate Nicaragua at a time when the Reagan Administration is perceived to be weakening and its policy toward the Sandinistas is seen to be in disarray, according to diplomats and government officials in the region.

title: Tax Watch; Forecasting State Revenues
description: DESPITE the widely publicized budget problems of New York, California and Massachusetts, many states seem to have accurately forecast the revenue impact of the Federal tax revision. ''Most states are either on or above target,'' said Gerald Miller, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers.

title: Outstanding Brazilian
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Writers who aim to make serious contributions to the literature of the game have a Scylla-and-Charybdis problem.

title: Traffic Threatens Economy Of Suburbs Around New York
description: Jammed rush-hour traffic, once the bane of the big city, has become a pervasive part of daily life in the suburbs around New York City.

title: Sports News Briefs; Age Limit is Set For Games Soccer
description: The ruling body of world soccer today set an age limit of 23 years for all players competing on Olympic soccer teams.

title: Review/Music; Naumburg and Tchaikovsky
description: The Naumburg Orchestra's free summer concerts have been a New York institution for 83 years, and in recent seasons the conductor Jens Nygaard has held up the tradition admirably. This year, Mr. Nygaard and his orchestra are giving two concerts in Damrosch Park, at Lincoln Center. The first, on Saturday evening, was an all-Tchaikovsky program that included the ''Capriccio Italien,'' a suite from ''Swan Lake,'' an orchestral arrangement of the Andante Cantabile (a string quartet movement) and the Piano Concerto No. 1, with William Wolfram as the soloist.

title: The Jazz Festival; Ruby Braff Recalls Lady Day
description: Ruby Braff, the diminutive, garrulous and brilliant trumpeter and cornetist, had waited 34 years for his old friend, George Wein, to let him have an evening of his own at the jazz festival that Mr. Wein started in 1954 - then the Newport Jazz Festival, now the JVC Jazz Festival. On Saturday evening at Town Hall, he got his wish, and although the program was called ''A Night for Lady Day'' - that is, Billie Holiday - it was just as much a night for Mr. Braff.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: A.T.&T. named Roger Davis corporate vice president and controller.

title: SALE OF KOPPERS CHEMICAL UNIT SEEN
description: Beazer P.L.C., which struck a deal last month to acquire the Koppers Company, is expected to announce by tomorrow that it has reached a preliminary agreement to sell the Koppers' chemical unit to a management-led group, according to people familiar with the deal.

title: On Your Own; To Run Safely, Run Wisely
description: ONE day last March I was running north on York Avenue, engrossed in conversation with a training partner, when, at a busy intersection, a car came screeching toward me. I had no time to dart away. In an instant I was sprawled out on the car's hood, in shock, lucky I had not been killed.

title: Iran Calls U.S. Action A 'Barbaric Massacre'
description: Iran reacted to the American downing of an Iranian jetliner today by accusing the United States of barbarism and by hinting strongly that it would retaliate.

title: Business People; New CBS Radio Chief Is Willing to Take Risks
description: Nancy C. Widmann, who was recently named the president of the CBS Radio division, attributes her success in the radio business to her hard work, the high quality of her staff and her willingness to take risks.

title: International Report; BIG GAINS ON FORIEGN STOCK EXCHANGES SLOW
description: With a stronger dollar, United States investors in securities denominated in most foreign currencies saw their gains moderate in the second quarter, but still enjoyed impressive appreciation for the first half of the year.

title: Man Wants to Keep Money Left by His Aunt, a Suicide
description: A man has asked a court whether he can keep $160,200 in $100 bills that his aunt wrapped as a Christmas gift and gave to him before killing herself.

title: Anne Brown Tracy Wed to Duke Roberts Ligon
description: Anne Brown Tracy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sedgwick Tracy of Point Pleasant, N.J., and Skaneateles, N.Y., was married yesterday to Duke Roberts Ligon, the son of Joan Roberts Ligon of Wewoka, Okla., and the late H .M. Ligon. The Rev. J. Edward Putnam, assisted by the Rev. Charles D. Brown, performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Skaneateles.

title: Maree Against Banning of South African Athlete
description: As the International Olympic Committee and other worldwide sports organizations are stepping up efforts to increase isolation of South Africa, Sydney Maree suggested that allowing South Africans to compete internationally would do more to chip away at the apartheid policies of his native country.

title: Harness Racing; Runnymede Lobell Is Winner
description: Runnymede Lobell, a new star in the world of harness racing, posted his 15th consecutive victory by capturing the Cane Pace, the first leg of the triple crown for 3-year-old pacers, at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

title: The Downing of Flight 655; Text of Reagan's Statement
description: Following is the text of a statement by President Reagan today at Camp David, Md., on the shooting down of an Iranian airliner over the Persian Gulf. The statement was read at the White House by the President's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater.<

title: 'Can't Anybody Here Play This Game?'
description: LEAD: It used to be that on the Fourth of July you'd see doubleheaders in the major league ballparks - and, in the parks and backyards all over the country, fathers and sons throwing the ball back and forth. But while some fathers will be traipsing off to the ballparks with their sons to watch single games, you won't see much of that other tradition vital to this country's heritage.

title: Justice Dept. Studies Overcrowding of Jails
description: Building new prisons and jails may cost less than releasing repeat offenders to relieve overcrowding, a Justice Department study said today.

title: Louisiana Takes Aim At Bawdy Bumpers
description: Bawdy bumper stickers would have to declare their coarser terms in letters only one-eighth of an inch high, under a bill passed by the Legislature and awaiting Gov. Buddy Roemer's signature.

title: National League; Jackson of Reds Puzzle for Phillies
description: Danny Jackson can't understand why he has dominated the Philadelphia Phillies this season.

title: GOING, GOING, GUANTE: YANKS LOSE IN 10
description: The telephone rang twice before Lou Piniella finally asked someone to answer it. He was clearly in no mood to do it himself, not after watching the Yankees go down in the 10th inning today. Not after seeing Dan Pasqua, a former Yankee, beat the team that traded him last November.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Friday about an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art by the Puerto Rican artist Jose Campeche misidentified the painting shown. It was ''The Wife of Governor Dufresne.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Changing a Name
description: Shortly after President Nixon visited Beijing in 1972, a small group of American companies formed the National Council for U.S.-China Trade to promote commercial relations. For years, it played host to high-level delegations and helped businesses with the Chinese bureaucracy.

title:
Business People;
President Is Selected By Southwestern Bell
description: LEAD: Edward E. Whitacre Jr., who began working for the Southwestern Bell Corporation as a repairman in a Texas town about 25 years ago, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the company.

title: Goodbye Halo Wins Oaks
description: Goodbye Halo rallied from just off the pace to score a one-and-three-quarters-length victory over Aptostar in the $284,000 Coaching ClubAmerican Oaks yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Wimbledon; Slam Is the Next Step for Graf
description: The pool of young talent includes Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, Mary Joe Fernandez of the United States and, undoubtedly, a child prodigy who has yet to make her presence felt on the women's tour. Whether anyone can challenge Steffi Graf for the No. 1 ranking in the near future is considered doubtful, with Martina Navratilova - an old-timer by comparison -still having the best chance.

title: POPE CANNONIZES WOMAN WHO FOUNDED SCHOOLS
description: Pope John Paul II yesterday canonized a woman who entered a convent against her father's will, founded the first free school west of the Mississippi and at the age of 72 helped begin a school for Potawatami Indians at what is now Sugar Creek, Kan.

title: SUSPECT IS FREED WITHOUT BAIL IN PREP SCHOOL CRIME RAMPAGE
description: A Bronx judge, citing insufficient evidence, yesterday released without bail a suspect in a robbery and shooting rampage by five prep school classmates and said he would consider dismissing all charges against the youth.

title: Leslie R. Shapiro Weds Lieut. E. K. Fippinger
description: Leslie Rose Shapiro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce L. Shapiro of Pottersville, N.J., and Lieut. Eric Kent Fippinger, U.S.M.C., a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Richard Fippinger of Manhasset, L.I., were married yesterday at the All Faiths Chapel at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md. Rabbi Larry Siegel performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Anthony Girandola, an evangelical minister.

title: Worshipers See Martyrdom in Defiance
description: After the traditional Latin mass was ended with ''Ite, missa est,'' seminarians and regular Sunday worshipers at St. Thomas Aquinas Seminary here congratulated one another on the elevation of their pastor to bishop in the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Wimbledon; Rain Postpones Men's Final
description: In much of the United States, it would come as welcome relief, but at Wimbledon, no one likes to see it rain. For the first time since 1972, the men's final was postponed. Boris Becker of West Germany and Stefan Edberg of Sweden were able to play only five games.

title: Sports World Specials; Draft Details
description: Each year, the inevitable would occur at the National Basketball Association's college draft. As evening approached and the crowd at the Felt Forum grew restless, names like Bruce Jenner, Carl Lewis and Eric Fleisher, the son of Larry Fleisher, the general counsel of the N.B.A.'s Players Association, were announced as selections in the late rounds.

title: The U.S. Navy in the Persian Gulf
description: Following is a chronology of U.S. involvement in the Persian Gulf in the last year and a half. According to the Center for Defense Information in Washington, a private group that monitors military matters, about 475 commercial vessels have been attacked in the gulf by Iranian or Iraqi forces since 1984. Nov. 1, 1986: Kuwait informs fellow members of the Gulf Cooperation Council that it will seek international protection for its ships in the Persian Gulf, which had become targets in the Iran-Iraq war. Jan. 13, 1987: The United States learns that Kuwait has an offer of protection from the Soviet Union. Kuwait asks whether its ships, if re-registered under the American flag, would receive United States Navy protection. Jan. 29: The Reagan Administration reiterates its commitment to a free flow of shipping through the gulf and says Kuwait may re-register its vessels. March 7: The United States offers to protect 11 Kuwaiti tankers. March 14: American intelligence says Iran has installed anti-ship missiles near the Strait of Hormuz. April 2: Kuwait formally accepts the American offer, applies to re-register 11 tankers and limits the Soviet role, asking only to charter three Soviet tankers. April 4: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger orders a stronger Navy presence in the gulf. May 11: Iran attacks a third Kuwait-bound tanker in eight days and warns Kuwait not to seek American or Soviet protection. May 17: The American frigate Stark is struck by two Iraqi missiles, killing 37 crew members. Iraq apologizes for ''pilot error.'' June 16: The Pentagon tells Congress that naval escorts operate under hair-trigger rules of engagement. Iran is said to be laying mines. July 1: American units reportedly find a dozen mines in gulf shipping lanes. July 24: In the first American convoy operation, one of two American-escorted Kuwaiti tankers hits a mine. Aug. 8: A United States Navy F-14 fires two missiles at an Iranian F-4 but misses. The second American-escorted convoy enters the gulf. Aug. 10: An American-owned supertanker is damaged by mines just outside the gulf. Aug. 11: More mines are discovered. Britain and France announce they will send minesweepers. Aug. 15: A tanker-tender at the entrance to the gulf is sunk by a mine. Sept. 21: An American helicopter gunship sets ablaze an Iranian vessel the Pentagon says was laying mines; 5 Iranians are reported killed and 26 captured. Oct. 8: The Pentagon says three Iranian patrol boats are sunk after firing on American helicopters. Oct. 15: An Iranian missile sets fire to an American-owned tanker in Kuwaiti waters. Oct. 16: A Kuwaiti tanker is hit by an Iranian missile. Oct. 19: American warships shell two offshore oil platforms said to serve as bases for Iranian gunboats. Dec. 12: American forces rescue 28 people from a tanker set afire by a

title: The Downing of Flight 655; Aviation Experts Assess the Incident
description: The Iranian jetliner shot down in the Persian Gulf yesterday by an American warship apparently failed to observe many of the precautions deemed necessary in a war zone, according to Western aviation experts.

title: Women Protest in Pakistan
description: About 400 women demonstrated here Saturday against the implementation of Islamic law by President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. It was the second such protest in two weeks. Many women fear that the new code will negate 1961 laws that gave them the right to file for divorce or to demand the right to register marriages and divorces. Witnesses on Saturday said many of the women were waving the flag of the leading opposition group, the Pakistan People's Party.

title: California Recycling Plan Is in Jeopardy
description: Hopes that California would show the nation how to reduce litter without imposing a deposit on beverage containers have turned into disappointment.

title: Reviews/Music; A Mesh of Rhythms Played in a Pop Format
description: ''New grooves in the making,'' Steve Coleman chanted in a jazz-funk-rap tune Saturday night at the Knitting Factory, giving a quick definition of what his band, Five Elements, is up to. Five Elements aims to mix jazz and funk without diluting either one, meshing danceable rhythms with jazzy tunes and solos, sometimes even a lyric. To add a little more challenge, the rhythms are usually in odd meters and the tunes are dissonant and asymmetrical. On the band's new album, ''Sine Die,'' each song is edited to the length of a pop tune, and the results are smart and slinky. But on stage, with longer solos, Five Elements' funk was more convincing than its jazz.

title: We Need Defense Burden Sharing
description: To the Editor:

title: Sequoyah Fuels Sale Set
description: The Kerr-Mcgee Corporation signed a definitive agreement to sell its Sequoyah Fuels Corporation subsidiary to General Atomics, a privately held high-technology company, for undisclosed terms, the companies said on Friday. The sale will be completed once regulatory approval is received. Sequoyah''s primary business is uranium conversion at its eastern Oklahoma plant. The parties announced an agreement in principle for the sale last November.

title: Sports of the Times; Anybody Seen a Boat?
description: OUR friend was a coxswain at Keble College of Oxford a few years back. We were a bit disappointed on Saturday when he did not wear his old rowing cap as he drove out to Henley. You'll see plenty of caps, he promised. He left the motorway just past Windsor Castle and maneuvered the back roads toward Henley-on-Thames, the same route he has taken on the first weekend in July since 1955. Old rowing boys do not forget the hours in the shell, the damp breeze on the river. It looks like rain, somebody said. It never rains on Saturday, our host said. Maybe a passing shower.

title: Similarities With KAL Flight Are Rejected by U.S. Admiral
description: The downing of an Iran Air passenger plane by American missiles yesterday prompted comparisons to the destruction of a South Korean airliner shot down by a Soviet fighter pilot nearly five years ago.

title: Richard S. Morse, 76, an Inventor Of Orange Juice Concentrate, Dies
description: Richard Stetson Morse, a scientist and inventor with a knack for turning inventions into commercial successes, including high-vacuum machines and frozen orange juice concentrate, died Friday of a heart attack at his summer home in Falmouth, Mass. He was 76 years old and a resident of Wellesley, Mass.

title: Aid Plan For World Bank Gains
description: With heavy lobbying by the business community, chances have suddenly improved for American participation in a $74.8 billion increase in resources of the World Bank, the biggest reservoir of funds for debt-strapped countries of the third world.

title: The Downing of Flight 655; No Policy Changes in Gulf As a Result, State Dept. Says
description: State Department officials said today that the shooting down of an Iranian passenger plane by a United States Navy warship would not lead to any fundamental change of American policy in the Persian Gulf.

title: S.E.C. Scheduled to Decide One-Share, One-Vote Rule
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is scheduled to decide this week whether corporations should be prohibited from reducing the voting rights of existing shareholders by issuing new classes of stock with different voting rights.

title: Arrival of African Bees in U.S. Will Have Impact on Agriculture
description: To the Editor:

title: The Jazz Festival; Surveying the Standards
description: The veteran pianist Gerry Wiggins, who has accompanied countless jazz and pop singers of note over the years, is one of Art Tatum's more self-effacing disciples. Mr. Wiggins, who gave the eighth and final concert in the JVC Jazz Festival's early-evening solo piano series on Friday at Weill Recital Hall, devoted most of his energy to very familiar standards. Among other tunes, his program included ''The Way You Look Tonight,'' ''Yesterdays,'' ''Don't Blame Me,'' ''Body and Soul,'' ''Mean to Me'' and ''Love For Sale.''

title: BOOK HOUSES' SUMMER TUNE: THANK GOD IT'S THURSDAY
description: NOW that it has become big business, book publishing is a far cry from what it was in the days when the summer months were often a time for rest and reflection. Still, one of publishing's concessions to the dog days of summer is a tradition known as ''summer hours.''

title: 290 REPORTED DEAD; A TRAGEDY, REAGAN SAYS; ACTION IS DEFENDED
description: A United States Navy warship in the Persian Gulf shot down an Iranian passenger plane today that the Navy said it mistook for a jet fighter, and Iran said all 290 people on board were killed.

title: Israeli Decision On Emigre Curb Splits U.S. Aides
description: A debate has erupted in the State Department over whether the United States should counter a recent decision by the Israeli Cabinet that would require most Jews who leave the Soviet Union to settle in Israel.

title: New Democracies, Old Abuses
description: LEAD: It has been an article of faith to the Reagan Administration that elections and democracy in themselves guarantee respect for human rights. Yet that faith is being betrayed in many newly emerging democracies, as I could not help but discover during a recent visit to Brazil.

title: Bank to Buy 73% of Broker
description: The National Bank of Canada, Canada's sixth-largest bank, said Saturday that it had agreed to buy 73 percent of Levesque Beaubien Inc., Quebec's largest brokerage firm, for about $100 million (Canadian) or about $82.4 million.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Staying Home
description: It is not enough that the Reagan Administration has decreed that Government officials cannot accept free lunches from journalists, lobbyists and the like.

title: Reviews/Music; 4 Saxophones And Brooklyn Philharmonic
description: Not everybody leaves town on Independence Day weekend, and not only the New York Philharmonic plays in the parks. Saturday evening, under beautiful skies and perfectly modulated temperatures, a fair-sized crowd gathered to hear the Brooklyn Philharmonic join forces with the World Saxophone Quartet for a Prospect Park concert that featured no fewer than three new pieces, two of them commissioned by the orchestra: ''The Human Factor'' by Leroy Jenkins, ''Folk Tales '88'' by Michael Richard Abrams and ''Urban Art'' by Oliver Lake.

title: Plan Calls for National Guard Action Against Marijuana Crop
description: In a marked expansion of the Federal Government's annual drug eradication efforts, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is expected to announce that National Guard troops and helicopters will be used in a program to destroy domestically grown marijuana.

title: Savoy Backed On Bar to Forte
description: Shareholders of Savoy Hotel P.L.C., a symbol of British exclusive good taste, last week backed their board's effort to block the legal campaign of Trusthouse Forte P.L.C. against the Savoy management.

title: MAYO CLINIC PRESCRIPTION: GROWTH
description: As one of the largest and richest medical centers in the world, the Mayo Clinic has been in a class by itself for much of its 81-year history.

title: Warning Is Issued on Guns
description: A group of safety advocates urged parents today to take precautions to keep pistols away from their children, especially at this time of year. The Center to Prevent Handgun Violence released a study that found that 38 percent of the unintentional shootings of children were self-inflicted or inflicted by other children. The researchers also found that an additional 41 percent of the guns used in shootings of children were owned by a friend's parents or other relatives.

title: On Your Own; Some Racing Basics for the Apprentice Skipper
description: THE small black cannon on the race committee boat thumped and more than a dozen sloops, their sails trimmed flat on starboard tack, charged across the starting line away to the first turning mark miles to windward.

title: Golf; Little Birdies No. 18 for Edge
description: Sally Little, who lost a three-stroke lead on the back nine, sank a 20-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today to beat Laura Davies by a stroke in the $500,000 du Maurier Classic.

title: Drop-In Plan for Homeless Rankling Upper East Siders
description: Not for a decade has a meeting of Community Board 8 on the Upper East Side of Manhattan been so crowded, and rarely has it been so angry.

title: Frostburg Journal; Casting the Fate of Man to the Wind
description: This was not a bad day for No. 8702, not a bad day at all, considering that while enjoying his morning reverie he had suddenly and rudely been caged, zapped and then tossed to the four winds.

title: Heidi Jensen Is Wed To Charles L. Young
description: Heidi Ann Jensen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Charles Jensen of New York and Mystic, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles L. Young, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Young of Shrewsbury, Mass. The Rev. Paul Lannan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Harvard Memorial Chapel in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Business Digest: MONDAY, JULY 4, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Sports World Specials; Who Needs Snow?
description: Ski jumping is not an event usually associated with the Fourth of July, but yesterday Lake Placid, N.Y., was the site of the first international summer freestyle aerial competition on skis. The main difference between this and the winter version was that the acrobatic leaps terminated in a 750,000-gallon pool rather than on snow.

title: Two Churches in Paris Battle Across the Lefebvre Schism
description: It was a battle for the hearts, minds and souls of thousands of traditionalist followers of Marcel Lefebvre, the dissident Archbishop who was excommunicated Thursday.

title: TV Notes
description: Lillian Gish Remembers

title: Sea-Based Missiles Should Be Banned
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Racing; Risen Star's Future in Doubt
description: Risen Star, who became racing's newest hero with a popular victory in the Preakness Stakes and an electrifying runaway in the Belmont Stakes last month, may now be retired to stud by the end of this month, his trainer said last night.

title: Marc Everett Backon Wed To Miss Kronick in Capital
description: At the Westin Hotel in Washington, Lois Gail Kronick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray W. Kronick of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday to Marc Everett Backon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Backon of New York. Rabbi Stuart Weinblatt officiated.

title: Nicole Simmons, Reporter, Is Wed
description: Nicole Sharon Simmons, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard L. Simmons of Pittsburgh, and Eric Seth Rubin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Rubin of New Rochelle, N.Y., were married yesterday at the James House in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Robert A. Rothman.

title: Review/Rock; Wire's Deadpan Songs
description: Wire started out in the late 1970's as an extremist band, playing distilled, flinty post-punk rock. Since its 1984 reunion, the band has turned to another extreme - steady-state rock that encases pop-song structures in deadpan repetitions. At the Ritz on Saturday night, Robert Gotobed dispensed unswerving, nearly uninflected rhythm patterns on a drum kit that included only a bass drum, a snare and a hi-hat cymbal. Above the beat, Graham Lewis, Colin Newman and Bruce Gilbert played layers of sustained bass notes and guitar chords that added up to active, murky drones.

title: Restaurant Madness
description: Once upon a time in New York City, people who had something left over after they paid the rent blew it on the theater. What they saw, how they liked it and how long they'd stood in line to get the tickets was what small talk was made of in those days.

title: International Report; After Optimistic Period, Peru's Troubles Return
description: Three years ago, when Peru's Government put a ceiling on the country's foreign debt payments and ordered across-the-board wage increases to stimulate domestic growth, many economists warned solemnly that it was a recipe for disaster.

title: Increasingly, Every Day Is Flag Day
description: Stephen Symonds remembers the lonely rounds of the flagpole salesman in the 1970's.

title: El Pollo Asado Co reports earnings for Year to March 27
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year loss included a $3,600,000 provision for the closing or subsidizing of various restaurants which have been or will be closed.

title: 20 Policemen in Ulster Cited in 1982 Killings
description: Twenty policemen in this British-administered province will face disciplinary action in the 1982 killings of six unarmed Roman Catholics, the police force, the Royal Ulster Constabulary, said today.

title: Reviews/Television On American Dialects, And on Getting Older
description: Marc N. Weiss, a documentary film maker, had an idea for public television. Instead of running independent documentaries on a scattershot basis, why not take advantage of the so-called summer doldrums to present a national package of strong nonfiction programming with helpful introductions and aggressive promotion.

title: Careers; New Regard For the Ideas Of Workers
description: WITH productivity so important to business, workers' ideas are now more vigorously sought by management.

title: Soviets Prepare 2 Craft For a Mission to Mars
description: THE Soviet Union, bidding for leadership in Mars exploration, plans to launch a pair of spacecraft this week and next on seven-month journeys to orbit the planet and dispatch landing vehicles to Phobos, a tiny gray moon believed to be an asteroid trapped by Martian gravity.

title: Soviet Officials in Frankfurt To Inspect Nuclear Missiles
description: A group of 19 Soviet missile specialists and officials arrived today to verify compliance with the superpowers' treaty to scrap their land-based intermediate-range nuclear missiles.

title: New Commercial Bank Names First President
description: New York is adding another commercial bank to its ranks, and Jacob Berman will be its president and chief executive.

title: Seeking Midwest Votes, Bush Stresses Positive
description: Vice President Bush sought votes in Midwest ethnic communities today, accenting upbeat themes and literally wrapping himself in a facsimile of an American flag.

title: New Techniques Enable Scientists To Study Rapid Changes in Proteins
description: USING a new particle accelerator, scientists at Cornell University have taken a snapshot of protein molecules with what amounts to a shutter speed of a billionth of a second. The scientists now hope to be able to capture changes that occur as often a million times a second as proteins perform crucial functions in the body.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph has chosen Saatchi & Saatchi Direct to handle its Reach Out America long-distance telephone program.

title: Gustave G. Rosenberg Dies at 88; Headed Higher Education Board
description: Gustave G. Rosenberg, a lawyer who was chairman of the New York City Board of Higher Education a quarter-century ago during controversies over free college tuition and control of the City University, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old. Mr. Rosenberg was a prominent trial lawyer in 1952 when he was appointed to the board, which sets policy for the City University. Five years later he was elected chairman, a nonsalaried, supposedly part-time post to which he gave full time.

title: Cannon Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-After a gain of $28,104,000 on disposal of assets. c-Net loss

title: Manor Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $5,696,000. c-After a loss on debt redemption of $2,396,000. The company noted that its year- ago fourth quarter and year's after- tax results included capital gains of about $3.6 million and $5.6 million, respectively, on property sales. As reported, current year results include net loss of $22.1 million on the sale of marketable securities, and a non-recurring provision for losses on reimbursement receivables and other non-recurring items with an after-tax effect of about $6 million.

title: L.I. Man's Body Is Found
description: The body of a 50-year-old man was found in a field in Patchogue, L.I., on Sunday, several days after he apparently wandered away from a Suffolk County nursing home, the Suffolk County Police said yesterday. The body of Frank D. Wilcox, of Patchogue, was found by a man who was looking for his dog, the police said. The county medical examiner's office determined that Mr. Wilcox died of exposure. His family told the police that he suffered from Alzheimer's disease and that, three weeks ago, he was placed in a nursing home run by the county Social Services Department.

title: Sports People; Surprise Winner
description: When Jim Benepe left Northwestern University a couple of years ago, he failed to pass the Professional Golfers Association's Qualifying School and decided he was not ready to play on the PGA Tour. Instead, he played in Asia, on the Australian tour and in Canada, winning the British Columbia Open in 1987. Early this year, he won the Victoria Open in Australia. Last week, he made his first professional start in the United States in the Western Open at Oak Brook, Ill. To enter, he needed a sponsor's exemption, which he received as a former winner of the Western amateur championship. To the surprise of everyone, the 24-year-old Benepe won his first PGA Tour event and $162,000 when Peter Jacobsen took a double bogey on the 72d hole. (AP)

title: Cenvill Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said the year-ago second quarter and 6 months results include revenue of $6,900,000 and $8,917,000, respectively, as well as net income of $4,349,000, or 30 cents a share, and $5,620,000, or 39 cents a share, from the sale of a former 80- percent owned subsidiary, Communications & Cable Inc. and certain management agreements relating to the latter company.

title: Purchasers Report June Expansion
description: An increase in production and new orders, fueled by a growth in exports, helped the economy expand in June at the largest rate since December, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report scheduled for release today.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 5, 1988: WEDNESDAY

title: To P.L.O., Base Is Not Home for Long
description: The scene has become familiar: Palestinian fighters being evacuated from one location to another. It has been repeated so many times that one radio station here advised the Palestine Liberation Organization, tongue in cheek, that it would save money by setting up its own travel agency.

title: Housing for the Poor and Poor Housing
description: ''Locked Out of the American Dream'' begins with the gloomy observation that ''the story of public housing in America is a story of high hopes and failed policies'' and ends with glimmers of promise that the nation can do better. This sober documentary, on Channel 13 tonight at 10 o'clock, recalls the way low-income neighborhoods have been bulldozed out of existence by highways, gentrification and expanding institutions. As one proponent of low-cost housing describes the process, it has been ''out with the poor, in with the pavement.'' Rents have rushed far ahead of income, and millions of Americans not classified as homeless are doubling up, making do with cramped, deteriorating quarters and paying more than they can comfortably afford.

title: Data Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the prior year figures have been restated to include the results of Compac Microelectronics Inc., which was merged with Data Technology Corp. in December 1987 on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Hanoi Is Said to Crack Down on Literary Dissent
description: Vietnam has sentenced five writers and journalists to jail terms of up to nine years, apparently as a warning that there are limits to literary dissent, according to Asia Watch, a Washington-based human rights group.

title: Corrections
description: In the Market Place column in Business Day on Friday, the price for shares of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation in 1984 was incorrect. The correct price, adjusted for a stock split earlier this year, was $19.75.

title: Merc Trading Soared in June
description: Bolstered by the rising dollar's effect on currency futures and options, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange reported record volume in June. Trading was up 31.7 percent over May volume and up 14 percent from June 1987, the exchange said.

title: Dollar's 2-Week Rally Isn't Over, Traders Say
description: Today marks the start of the third week since the dollar's rally began, and many traders and dealers cautiously predict that the United States currency will continue to rise or, at least, hold its ground.

title: Car Lynching
description: Revenge seems to help relieve the pain when police refuse to enter a locked parked car and turn off the burglar alarm that endlessly pierces the night. Such car alarms are mandated by law to shut off after 15 minutes. Too many of them don't. The police usually shrug off their responsibility to provide relief, for reasons the Department's legal adviser cannot explain. The result is inevitable: car lynching.

title: Sports People; Quisenberry Let Go
description: Dan Quisenberry was released yesterday by the Kansas City Royals, 39 months after signing a complex lifetime contract worth as much as $40 million. ''The bottom line is effectiveness,'' General Manager John Schuerholz said. ''It was purely and simply a baseball decision. His effectiveness was just not what it had been, for whatever reason.'' The relief pitcher was not available for comment. His lack of use and unhappiness had fueled speculation for almost a year that the Royals would either trade or release the right-hander, whose 238 saves rank fourth on the major league career list. ''He told me, 'Thanks for showing mercy,' '' Schuerholz said. The Royals also released the reliever Gene Garber, 40 years old, who has 218 career saves, most of them with the Atlanta Braves. Quisenberry signed his lifetime contract early in the 1985 season at the urging of the co-owner, Avron Fogelman, who put the package together and also signed the center fielder, Willie Wilson, and the first baseman, George Brett, to similar deals. The total worth of the contract has been estimated as high as $49 million, depending on the value of future real estate and commercial holdings. Quisenberry, 35 years old, is 0-1 with one save and a 3.55 earned run average. Lifetime, he has a 51-43 record with 238 saves and a 2.55 e.r.a. He set a major league record in 1983, when he saved 43 games. He was named relief pitcher of the year five times, beginning in 1980. (AP)

title: Mississippi River To Be Monitored
description: State environmental officials say they will monitor the Mississippi River more closely for salt and toxic substances as the worst drought in years continues to decrease the freshwater flow.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Two Big Saatchi Units To Merge
description: SAATCHI & SAATCHI'S William Esty Company of New York and Detroit and its Campbell-Mithun of Minneapolis and Chicago are planning to merge Oct. 1 and, on paper at least, it sounds like a marriage made in heaven.

title: 3CI Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
Punish Pretoria, But Not Lesotho
description: With the renewed state of emergency in South Africa and with Pretoria's ban earlier this year of 17 anti-apartheid organizations, the United States Congress has revived discussions of imposing sanctions against South Africa. Many Africans' faith in the United States had been restored after earlier sanctions were passed over President Reagan's veto in 1986, and the new proposals are even tougher.

title: An Asteroid's Impact
description: An asteroid about a third of a mile in diameter that crashed into the southeast Pacific Ocean about 2.3 million years ago sent so much water vapor into the atmosphere that it could conceivably have helped trigger an ice age, according to a report in the journal Science.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Congressional Appeal
description: Marking Independence Day, Representative John Conyers Jr. and 72 other members of Congress, including 11 Senators, sent a letter to President Reagan yesterday requesting that he urge South Africa to commute the death penalty in the cases of six black South Africans sentenced despite court acknowledgment of a lack of evidence. Last month a South African court granted a stay of execution for the six until July 19.

title: Talking Business; with Boyd of Airbus Industrie; Two Challenges For Jet Maker
description: Airbus Industrie has been strengthened by a spate of recent orders for its planes in its rivalry with the Boeing Company. The recent crash of one of its new A320 jetliners at an air show in France, however, has cast a shadow over its enviable safety record. Up until last week none of the 18-year-old company's planes had crashed. The company already had been troubled by the falling dollar, which made it harder for it to sell its planes in the United States. Alan S. Boyd, the chairman of Airbus Industrie of North America Inc., talked about two challenges: the air crash, and keeping up with aircraft orders.

title: China Starts New Airline
description: China's largest airline, Air China, was established last week as part of a plan to reorganize the Civil Aviation Administration of China, an agency that has been criticized for mismanagement and inefficiency. Air China will be the nation's major international carrier, operating 32 overseas routes to 31 cities in 24 countries. It will also operate 44 domestic routes among 30 cities. The airline is the third and largest to be established under the Civil Aviation Administration's decentralization plan.

title: Baseball; McGwire's Homer Wins Again for A's
description: Mark McGwire hit a home run on the first pitch of the 16th inning today, his second straight game-winning homer in the 16th inning, and Stan Javier hit a homer two outs later as the Oakland Athletics defeated the Cleveland Indians, 4-2, to win their fifth straight.

description: ''If we are attacked or hostile intent is demonstrated we will defend ourselves,'' the commander of the United States ship that shot down an Iranian airliner on Sunday said last April, before his ship left for the Persian Gulf.

title: Economics Helps Norfolk in Race With Baltimore as Key Commercial Port
description: For longer than most people in Norfolk care to remember, Baltimore was considered the premier commercial port of the Middle Atlantic states.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Why don't people who take nitroglycerin for a heart condition explode? A.Nitroglycerin, the highly explosive compound of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen and oxygen developed in the 19th century, acts on directly on the walls of the blood vessels.

title: Concord Fabrics Inc reports earnings for 13wks to May 29
description: b-After a loss of $90,000 from a cumulative effect on prior years of adopting FASB No. 96. c-Net income and includes gains on disposal of discontinued operations of $162,000 for the 13 weeks and $432,000 for the 39 weeks. The company said the year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect the exchange on May 27, 1988, one share each of Class A and Class B stock of Concord Fabrics Inc. for each share of stock previously issued of Concord Fabrics.

description: NO man is an island, Donne observed, and neither, it seems, is a sperm.

title: Sports People; Sprinter Ends Feud
description: Ben Johnson, the world record-holder in the 100 meters, and his coach have mended their differences and will soon resume training together, according to an official with the sprinter's local track club. Earl Ross, a teacher who 25 years ago founded the Optimists Track Club, said yesterday that he met with Johnson and his coach, Charlie Francis, late last week and ''we sat down and said, 'What are the problems?' and there didn't appear to be any.'' There were reports last month that Johnson and Francis had decided to split over dif-ferences concerning Johnson's recu-peration from a leg leg injury.

title: Kleer-Vu Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $3,182,000 and $2,345,000 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively. The footnotes were not reported in Friday, July 1, editions.

title: Crocodile Tears For the Teamsters
description: None of yesterday's Fourth of July tub-thumpers advocating the preservation of constitutional liberties eclipsed in fervor the anguished screams from defenders of the scandal-stained International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The cries were set off last week by the Justice Department's lawsuit charging that organized crime had infiltrated the union's leadership. The suit seeks to oust officers of that powerful union and put it under court-appointed trusteeship until new leaders can be picked in a free and fair election.

title: New Initiative to Speed AIDS Drugs is Assailed
description: A year-old program intended to speed experimental drugs to desperately ill patients has provoked a bitter debate over the right of the Federal Government to deny unproven therapies to dying patients.

title: Coca-Cola Denies Bribes to Soviets
description: Executives of the Coca-Cola Company have denied accusations that the company paid bribes to gain access to markets in the Soviet Union.Coca-Cola's chairman, Roberto C. Goizueta, distributed a memo to employees last week saying that an internal investigation uncovered no wrongdoing by Coke workers, a company spokesman, Carlton Curtis, said.

title: QUESTIONS MOUNT; Team Goes To Gulf
description: Amid a host of unanswered questions, the Pentagon today began a painstaking reconstruction of how an American warship mistakenly shot down an Iranian passenger jet over the Persian Gulf on Sunday.

description: b-Net income The company said latest quarter data includes the acquisition of Great Earth International Inc. and assets of Josu Inc., as of March 2, and reflects the company's obiligations to issue an additional 250,000 shares to shareholders of Great Earth.

description: To the Editor:

title: Prospects for Lower Rates Brighten
description: As the second half of the year begins, the prospects for lower interest rates over the next six months seem far brighter than most analysts said was possible even a month ago.

title: The Reds Give Rose a Boost
description: Pete Rose, a manager whose job has been rumored to be in jeopardy, received support from his general manager and his team last night. Only the owner was missing in her support, and, of course, Marge Schott is the only one who counts.

title: As Iran Mourns, Khomeini Calls for 'War' on U.S.
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini today called for ''a real war'' against the United States and some of its allies in the Persian Gulf following the downing on Sunday of an Iranian airliner by an American warship.

title: Bridge
description: If one had to select a ''1987 Man of the Year'' based on performance in American National Championships, it would not be an American. It would be Jaggy Shivdasani of Bombay, India, who achieved a remarkable double. In his first American appearance, in Baltimore last July, he won the Spingold Knockout Team title with a pickup foursome. Four months later, in Anaheim, Calif., he won the Reisinger Team Championship with different teammates.

title: CONFERENCE SEEMS TO GIVE GORBACHEV A STRONG MANDATE
description: The resolutions approved by last week's special Communist Party conference, published for the first time today, endorsed almost without exception the proposals by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, for political reorganization.

title: Law Firm Incomes Surging On Deals and Tax Work
description: Reaping benefits from an abundance of corporate takeovers, real estate deals and tax work, the nation's leading law firms enjoyed a healthy increase in earnings in their most recent fiscal year. Indeed, the temporary slowdown in mergers and acquisitions that followed the stock market crash had little impact on the firms.

title: Celebrations, From a Radio Day to Picnics and Yachts
description: In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, it was a day of flags and speeches, parades and picnics. There were family reunions and barbecues, with charcoal that would not burn and ants that would not go away.

title: American Standard
description: Finmeccanica Societa Finanziaria Meccanica S.p.A. said a subsidiary, Ansaldo S.p.A., had agreed to acquire the railway signaling operations of American Standard Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Finmeccanica, a unit of the state holding company Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, said in a statement that Ansaldo would acquire the Union Switch and Signal division in the United States and American Standard's Italian-based Wabco Westinghouse operations.

description: b-Net income

title: SCHOOLS FOR ARABS CLOSED BY ISRAELIS
description: Hundreds of Arab students pelted Israeli soldiers with rocks and blocked a main road here today. The Israeli Army ordered all West Bank Arab schools closed for three days, beginning Tuesday, in an effort to limit student participation in the Palestinian uprising.

title: Morrison Knudsen Investment Held
description: An Illinois businessman, Edward F. Heil, has bought 6.2 percent of the Morrison Knudsen Corporation's shares, but Wall Street analysts dismissed speculation that he might try to take over the engineering, shipbuilding and construction company.

title: Audiovox Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Mark IV Set to Buy Armtek Stock
description: Mark IV Industries Inc., which failed in a takeover bid for the RTE Corporation during the spring, has turned its sights toward the Armtek Corporation, documents filed with the Federal Trade Commission show.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't go much by what the Iranians say, ever.'' - President Reagan. [ A8:1. ]

title: 100 Vials of Blood Wash Ashore in Jersey
description: More than 100 vials containing blood washed ashore from Newark Bay and were turned over to the New Jersey Department of Health, the police said today.

title: Teachers' Union Backs Plan for Special Districts
description: The nation's largest teachers' union today overwhelmingly endorsed a call for each state to name at least one school district to be a ''learning laboratory'' where teachers could experiment and take the lead in improving schools.

title: Indepth Data Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company is a development- stage firm.

title: Saluting Liberty With Festivities And Introspection
description: It was, in a way, like two Fourths of July: the garrulous, sociable one that drew people out to thundering parades, booming musket salutes, fiddle-wailing hoedowns and picnics on small-town greens. And there was the other one that drew folks inward, to thoughts of home and of loved ones and to front-porch recollections of summers past.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Tandem Computers Picks Ogilvy & Mather

description: One of three black men attacked by a gang of whites in Howard Beach in 1986 was arrested yesterday by a New York City police officer on a warrant in the shooting of the suspect's brother in Virginia.

title: Is It a Bird or Is It a Plane? Radar May Not Know
description: Although radar can detect objects hundreds of miles away even through clouds and darkness, it cannot ordinarily discern the shapes or sizes of the objects it strikes, and in itself, it cannot usually distinguish friend from foe.

title: Yanks Rip Rangers For 13-2 Triumph
description: The Yankees put the misery of a weekend in Chicago behind them tonight. They had eight runs by the third inning, and when they had finished their work at Arlington Stadium, they had a 13-2 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: Fast Trains: Germany Expects U.S. Prize
description: Hoping to win a big United States order, West Germany is making a determined attempt to beat Japan in a high-technology race to produce the world's first high-speed magnetic levitation train. The revolutionary train uses magnets to propel it above a steel track at speeds up to 310 miles per hour.

title: Our Towns; Waging a War On the Morass Of Medicare
description: Last October, after several tests, Dr. Arthur Berken determined that his longtime patient, Helen Bennett, 72 years old, had cancer of the chest cavity. He had planned to hospitalize her for chemotherapy, but Mrs. Bennett, a widow with no family, begged him not to.

title: Whatever Welfare Is, It Isn't Hereditary
description: To the Editor:

title: Pregnant Women and Hepatitis B: New Policy Reflects Fears
description: AN important Federal recommendation last month to test all pregnant women for the hepatitis B virus reflected new evidence that many more infants are threatened by the virus than previously believed. The policy change also reflected evidence that many doctors were not being diligent enough in ordering hepatitis tests for pregnant women known to be at high risk of the liver disease.

title: Review/Dance; From Kyoto, Visions of an Experimental Universe
description: ''Pleasure Life,'' presented Sunday night by the Japanese experimentalist group Dumb Type at Performance Space 122, is a mad yet endearingly ingenuous enterprise involving miniature searchlights, four small television monitors, sleek Rube Goldberg sculptures that produce sound when they turn and ranks of shoulder-high platforms made of steel rods. The platforms fill the stage space, forming corridors through which move a mysterious woman dressed glamorously in red and four young performers in white summer clothes. And those corridors are a complete world for the five, who never venture beyond its bounds.

title: Books of The Times; A Shamus Comes Clean in a Collection of Reflections
description: Gumshoe Reflections in a Private Eye. By Josiah Thompson. 312 pages. Little, Brown. $17.95.

description: The company said its results reflect non-operating expenses of $1,341,000 after tax in fiscal 1988, compared with $1,124,100 in 1987.

title: L.I.'s Traffic Maze: The Schemes of a Savvy Commuter
description: Every morning, Lenny Grundt drives 30 miles from his home here to Garden City, where he works as a librarian. But Mr. Grundt, a commuter for 20 years, never knows what route he will take. Each morning is a new adventure in switching from highway to back road, dodging congestion.

title: Incendiary Device Explodes Under Police Van, Injuring 11

title: Trudy Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The 1987 year was comprised of 11 months and the company went public on July 14, 1987.

title: Design; Formal Elegance
description: When the evening is impeccably organized, the weather perfect, the setting beautiful, the food and wine superb, what a woman wears to a formal summer fete is immaterial. Well, almost.

title: Sports People; Carter Feels for Ryan
description: Gary Carter, who has not hit a home run since May 16, is sure that he eventually will clout the one he needs to reach 300 homers, a level that has been reached by only 58 major league players. He is also sure that Nolan Ryan, who has pitched in seven games without a victory since May 29, will soon nail down his victory No. 100 with the Houston Astros, making him only the seventh pitcher to win at least 100 games with two teams. He won 138 games for the California Angels before joining the Astros. ''It's a thing that wears you down,'' said the Mets' catcher. ''It's inevitable we'll get there.''

description: The United States today was awarded the 1994 World Cup, soccer's quadrennial international tournament, which is regarded in some countries as the world's premier sports event.

title: Zavalla Journal; 2-Way Shock as Hippie Meets Texan
description: Officers Box, McDaniel and Davis of the Texas Department of Public Safety strolled into the center of the camp at the Angelina National Forest Saturday morning, their uniforms crisp, their shoes shined, their sunglasses dark, their pistols holstered, their expressions confused.

title: Shuttle Moved to Launching Pad As NASA Celebrates a New Start
description: Amid cheers and applause, the winged spaceship Discovery was moved to the launching pad today in a star-spangled ceremony intended to boost the morale of space agency employees and to show the world that the shuttle program was back in business.

title: South Korea Company Halts Work on an Iranian Refinery
description: A South Korean contractor said today that it would stop building a gas refinery in Iran and remove all 400 of its workers there after 12 workers were killed in an Iraqi air raid.

title: Sports of The Times; Couldn't Boris Be a Yank?
description: WHILE some Yanks foraged for the hamburgers and corn on the cob that British pubs graciously provide every Fourth of July, a few Yanks clustered around a word processor that had somehow been linked with a baseball statistics bank.

description: Bob Charles shot his third straight three-under-par 69 to win the $350,000 Rancho Murieta Senior Gold Rush today by two strokes. It was his third PGA Senior Tour victoryof the year.

title: The Arts Festival; A Japanese Composer's Avant-Garde Concerns
description: When the music of Toru Takemitsu came drifting over the Pacific in the 1960's, the freshness of its language took many Westerners by surprise. Like many works composed in Europe and the United States at the time, his scores were couched in a modern idiom that used clouds of dissonance, orchestral timbres twisted in unusual ways and elements of randomness.

title: In Captain Rogers's Shoes
description: The White House's restrained expressions of regret do scant justice to the 290 victims who died at U.S. hands in the Persian Gulf Sunday. Yet while horrifying, it was nonetheless an accident. On present evidence, it's hard to see what the Navy could have done to avoid it.

description: Brazil has formally asked the International Monetary Fund for a $1.44 billion loan and presented its economic program to the fund, Government officials said Friday.

title: Critic's Notebook; Biography and the Aim of Art
description: ''Life is very nice, but it lacks form,'' Jean Anouilh once observed. ''It's the aim of art to give it some.'' It has been the aim of many recent biographies to identify the autobiographical sources lurking beneath those forms imposed by craft and imagination - an impulse with both rewards and hazards.

title: Minerals Are Linked to Sleep Difficulties
description: TRACE elements in the diet can influence the quality of sleep, according to by the United States Department of Agriculture. The research, conducted at the department's Human Nutrition Research Center in Grand Forks, N.D., revealed that women with shortages in their diets and blood of either of two essential minerals, copper and iron, were more likely to have trouble sleeping. Conversely, the more aluminum the women ingested (mainly through antacids containing aluminum) the poorer the quality of their sleep.

title: Credit-Card Tie to Nonprofit Groups
description: A few weeks ago, about 100,000 people on the Museum of American Folk Art's mailing list were asked to sign up for a Mastercard or Visa credit card in an arrangement that will benefit the museum every time the card is used. The offer came through Maryland Bank N.A., which like other banks sees the program as a way to gain accounts.

The Oakland general manager spoke with Bob Boone, then called the California general manager, who was trying to re-sign Boone. The co-owner of the Chicago White Sox sent copies of his correspondence with Jack Morris's lawyer to the commissioner and to the Detroit Tigers, who were trying to re-sign Morris.

title: Sports People; Hawks Eye Malone
description: Shortly after the Atlanta Hawks lost in seven games to the Boston Celtics in the second round of the National Basketball Association playoffs, Stan Kasten, president of the Hawks, was asked if he planned to pursue the free-agent market. He said that he would prefer to stay away from free agency, ''unless you're one player away, and this is the player who puts you over the top.'' ''We believe that the Hawks might be one player away,'' he said. ''I think we're that close. It might be the right time for the Hawks to go after a free agent.'' Now, having lost Wayne (Tree) Rollins to free agency and Scott Hastings to the Miami Heat in the expansion draft, the Hawks have only Jon Koncak at center. Reportedly, the Hawks are negotiating with Lee Fentriss, the agent for Moses Malone. Malone, 33, is an unrestricted free agent after playing for the Washington Bullets for the last two seasons. He turned down a two-year offer of $4.2 million from the Bullets.ion from the Bullets. (AP)

title: Japan Criticized on Animal Imports

There are the usual sorts of obstacles and enemies; you must be fast to dodge them, and have an itchy trigger finger besides.

Security guards at the plants in Amsterdam and Mayfield, N.Y., near Albany, said workers were given Friday off as a paid holiday. The guards said the plants, which employ about 110 people, would remain closed this week. The company's ability to make this week's payroll was questioned after a New York court issued a restraining order Wednesday, freezing Coleco bank accounts in Albany at the request of suppliers who had not been paid.

title: Olympic Invitations

In addition to Robinson, who played at Navy, and Mourning, who will play for the Olympic coach, John Thompson, at Georgetown, other centers invited to the camp were Stacey King of Oklahoma and Dwayne Schintzius of Florida. Danny Manning, who led Kansas to the N.C.A.A. championship, led a group of forwards that included Charles Smith of Pittsburgh, Sean Elliott of Arizona, Danny Ferry of Duke, J. R. Reid of North Carolina, Dan Majerle of Central Michigan and Dyron Nix of Tennessee. The remaining players are Willie Anderson of Georgia, Stacey Augmon of Nevada-Las Vegas, Vernell Coles of Virginia Tech, Jeff Grayer of Iowa State, Hersey Hawkins of Bradley, Randolph Keys of Southern Mississippi, Todd Lichti of Stanford, Mitch Richmond of Kansas State, Brian Shaw of California-Santa Barbara and Charles Smith of Georgetown.
