title: The Years in the Reagan White House
description: November 1980: Edwin Meese 3d, heralded as a crisp manager and fervent proponent of law and order, became director of President Reagan's transition team and played an important role in the selection of Cabinet officers and other top officials. January 1981: As Counselor to the President, Mr. Meese shared the White House inner circle with James A. Baker 3d and Michael K. Deaver. April 1984: Senate investigators began looking into Mr. Meese's failure to report reimbursements he received for more than 30 trips he took as White House Counselor. One day later, former President Ford suggested that Mr. Meese should resign, although Mr. Ford said he did not believe Mr. Meese had broken any laws. January 1985: The Office of Government Ethics staff concluded that Mr. Meese, then Attorney General-designate, violated conflict-of-interest rules but was overruled by the agency director. February 1985: Mr. Meese was sworn in as Attorney General. April 1985: Mr. Meese presided at meetings of the Domestic Policy Council, consisting of eight Cabinet officers who advise the President on domestic and social policy issues; Mr. Reagan created the body less than two months after Mr. Meese became Attorney General. July 1986: The final report of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography tied hard-core smut to sex crimes and included get-tough recommendations for all levels of government. November 1986: Mr. Meese announced that the United States had secretly sold weapons to Iran and that profits of $10 million to $30 million had been diverted to the Nicaraguan rebels. December 1986: Mr. Meese emerged as a leading spokesman for Mr. Reagan's conservative agenda, including attacks on pornography, crime and narcotics; he spearheaded opposition to abortion and what Reagan supporters considered overly broad Supreme Court decisions. April 1987: Mr. Meese acknowledged that he intervened on behalf of the Wedtech Corp., a defense contractor, in the company's effort to win an Army contract; he denied any wrongdoing. October 1987: Investigators looking into Mr. Meese's activities as Presidential Counselor widened their inquiry to include his actions in connection with his friend E. Robert Wallach's efforts to secure Government backing for a proposed oil pipeline from Iraq to Jordan. December 1987: A special prosecutor, James C. McKay, said he had insufficient evidence to seek criminal charges against Mr. Meese in the Wedtech case. July 5, 1988: Mr. Meese announced his resignation as Attorney General.

description: TENNIS Leconte Upset: Top-seeded Henri Leconte of France was upset by unseeded Milan Srejber of Czechoslovakia yesterday in the first round of the $270,000 Swiss Open tournament in Gstaad.

title: Freddie Mac Offers Mortgage Program
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday introduced its Multifamily Guarantor Program, whereby the corporation will buy three types of fixed-rate multifamily mortgages from lenders for a like amount of multifamily mortgage participation certificates. Included will be both conventional and Federal Housing Administration mortgages. Lenders can convert the certificates into cash or hold them as collateral in a variety of financings.

title: Anglican Leaders Seek to Avoid Deeper Split on Women in Clergy
description: The governing bodies of Anglican churches meeting on both sides of the Atlantic were struggling yesterday for ways to open religious offices to women without splintering their denominations.

title: Failure and Danger in the Gulf
description: The course of United States-Iranian relations has been distorted over the past decade by a series of bizarre and improbable events - the collapse of the Shah, the taking of American hostages, the Iran-contra affair. To that list must now be added the death of 290 individuals on board Iran Air Flight 655. The tragedy will plague relations between Iran and the United States long after the investigations are completed and the public rhetoric subsides.

title: Washington Talk: The Military
description: In the summit meeting here last December, Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev, the top military officer in the Soviet Union, told American officials that the two most important events in his life were the siege of Leningrad and the signing of the new pact banning medium- and shorter-range land-based missiles.

title: Yes, It's the Governor, And Get Him Rewrite!
description: Mario M. Cuomo - who at various times has called reporters stupid, ingrates, spoiled, incompetent, arrogant and thin-skinned - took up pen and notebook today, working as a reporter to get a taste of the job and, just perhaps, to show the Albany press corps a thing or two.

title: Allegheny to Meet With Dissident Group
description: Allegheny International Inc. has agreed to meet with dissident shareholders to explore plans to sell the company or bring in third parties for a restructuring, according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Stroh Brewery Work Switched to Hal Riney
description: Just to prove how delighted it is with the advertising it has been getting from Lowe Marschalk, the Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit has switched its account - to Hal Riney & Partners.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: Complaints that colleges exploit their student athletes are as old as big-time collegiate sports, but the practice, with high profits and alumni support, resists demands for reform. Now, Congress threatens to shame the colleges into paying attention to the education they give their athletes.

title: Trailer Truck Kills 2 At Chatham Square
description: An elderly man and woman were killed yesterday when a truck hit them as they were crossing a busy roadway in the Chinatown area, the police said.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: LETTER, written on cream-colored vellum, from our friend the partygoer:

title: Talking to Machines: Progress Is Speeded
description: Designing a computer-based system that can recognize human speech has long been a cherished goal of artificial intelligence researchers and linguists. After almost three decades of agonizingly slow progress, some researchers believe they are closing in on the ability to create machines that can recognize naturally spoken language from a variety of different speakers.

title: Columbia Gas
description: The Columbia Gas System Inc. said it was negotiating to sell a 50 percent interest in its subsidiary the Columbia LNG Corporation to the Shell Oil Company of Houston. Columbia said it and Shell were discussing a joint venture to buy liquefied natural gas and resell it at a terminal Columbia LNG owns.

title: Mulheren Grants Delay
description: Attorneys for John A. Mulheren Jr. granted a three-week extension of yesterday's deadline for prosecutors to either indict the arbitrager or dimiss charges of threatening a witness in a Federal case.

title: The Downing of Flight 655; Aegis Cruiser Protected By High-Tech Umbrella
description: The Aegis guided-missile cruiser that mistakenly shot down an Iranian commercial airliner is among the United States Navy's most modern and capable warships, even though she is far from the largest.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Federal minimum wage seems likely to be raised, and in a form that President Reagan may find impossible to veto. The minimum wage, now $3.35 an hour, is expected to be raised 30 to 40 cents in each of the next three years. [ Page A1. ] A former Unisys executive told military contractors they should raise money for Florida charities to influence decisions by Representative William V. Chappell Jr., NBC News reported tonight, citing what it said were wiretapped conversations. [ A17. ] A Pentagon report criticized the officers involved in the Army's search for an advertising agency. [ D17. ] Louisiana will offer tax-free shopping to foreign visitors under a bill approved by the Legislature and sent to the Governor. [ D1. ] The record prices paid for radio stations reflect deregulation, rising advertising revenues and continuing demand for the limited number of broadcast licenses in the largest markets. [ D16. ] THE MARKETS Major market averages climbed to their highest levels since October's crash, led by oil and industrial stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 27.03 points, to 2,158.61. [ D1. ] The Big Board will propose a rule to give individuals' trades priority over institutional trade. [ D4. ] Prices of soybean futures plunged as a rain forecast eased drought fears. But corn prices climbed. [ D13. ] Food prices have not yet increased sharply in supermarkets. [ C6. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes edged slightly lower, as participants awaited upcoming economic data. [ D12. ] The dollar drifted lower in light trading as the pound jumped. Gold rose 90 cents on the Comex, to $438.10 an ounce. [ D13. ] COMPANIES Irving's directors accepted an improved takeover offer from Banca Commerciale Italiana. Banca Commerciale agreed, under certain conditions, to sweeten its offer with warrants that would entitle holders to buy a newly issued Irving share for $65 at any time over the next seven years. Irving stockholders would receive one warrant for every four Irving shares. [ D1. ] Sun will buy Atlantic Petroleum for $513 million. Atlantic has a refinery in Philadelphia and owns 571 service stations. [ D1. ] Allegheny International will meet with dissident shareholders to explore plans to sell or restructure the company. [ D1. ] McLean filed a bankruptcy reorganization plan, hoping to settle claims against it. [ D2. ] Eastern's three major unions met with the airline's president and the chairman of Texas Air, its parent, in an attempt to improve labor relations. [ D3. ] Tropicana accused Coca-Cola of deceptive advertising for Minute Maid orange juice. [ D16. ] Columbia Pictures Entertainment is hoping to expand into a fourth, unspecified business. [ D3. ] Welbilt agreed to be acquired by its management in a buyout valued at $212.9 million. [ D3. ] INTERNATIONAL Caribbean nations agreed to remove nearly all trade barriers by Oct. 1 at a summit in Antigua. [ D2. ] TECHNOLOGY A machine that can recognize naturally spoken language from a different speakers is in the offing, some researchers say. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS How to convince a skeptical public that the eradication of poverty is a national responsibility is part of the debate over the new welfare law. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The drought is expected to depress the prices of food stocks but leave their bottom lines unscathed. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Fritz Wiessner, 88; Career as a Climber Spanned 8 Decades
description: Fritz Wiessner, a mountain climber whose active career spanned eight decades and who led difficult ascents until he was nearly 87 years old, died on Sunday from complications after a stroke at his home home in Stowe, Vt. He was 88 years old.

title: A Circuit of Festivals Showcases the Blues
description: These are busy times for Mark Naftalin, a musician and a producer of blues shows. The posters from his just-completed Marin County Blues Festival are stacked high on a living room piano bench, and the phone rings repeatedly with calls from helpers.

title: In France, the Pleasures of Eating Are More in the Talking
description: LEAD: ON vacation in France a few summers ago, my husband conducted a private sociological survey and then announced, ''There are no fat women in France.''

title: Dow, Up 27, Is Highest Since Crash
description: Led by blue-chip oils and industrial stocks, all the major market averages climbed yesterday to their highest levels since October's stock market crash.

title: Tom Hanks: From Leading Man to Movie Star
description: Josh Baskin is 13 years old. Tom Hanks is 31. Some days there's not a thimbleful of difference between them.

title: INSIDE
description: Mexican Election Today

title: Very Different Voices Finding Harmony
description: The 1.9 million-member National Education Association, the biggest teachers' group in the country, is often likened to a large cargo ship: It may take a long time to turn around but it does carry a lot of weight.

title: NMR of Ameria reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $304,952.

title: Jail Death of Texas Tycoon Symbolic of State's Decline
description: It was one of the classic stories of the Texas boom, the saga of a brilliant promoter who came to Houston almost penniless in 1979 and in eight years built a real estate empire worth an estimated $500 million.

title: MEESE SAYS HE'LL STEP DOWN, CONTENDING HE IS VINDICATED BY THE SPECIAL PROSECUTOR
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announced today that he would resign later this summer, asserting that he had been ''vindicated'' by an independent prosecutor's final report on his conduct.

title: Statement From Reagan
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's statement on the resignation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, as released by the White House today:

title: Wine Talk
description: Warren Winiarski is the owner and wine maker at Stag's Leap Wine Cellars here on the sunbaked eastern slope of the Napa Valley. The winery opened for business in 1972 and began winning international acclaim with its second vintage, 1973.

title: Review/Theater; Forming Revolutionaries, In South African 'Jika'
description: In ''Jika'' (at Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater), the making of revolutionaries in South Africa is studied with conviction but without an equivalent amount of artistry. As written and directed by Maishe Maponya, the two-man play derives its inspiration from the 1976 student uprising in South Africa.

title: OUTLOOK IS HAZY AT JUSTICE DEPT.
description: The impending departure of Edwin Meese 3d makes it quite possible that in the last six months of President Reagan's term, there will be only an Acting Attorney General. Even that depends on timely action by the Senate in confirming nominees for other high-ranking jobs at the Justice Department.

title: A Slip Of the Quill
description: Joseph Nohavicka, in his letter to The Times published June 30, raises a vexing philosophical question in defending the phrase ''between you and I'' on ground that Shakespeare used it in ''The Merchant of Venice.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jim Hart, who played quarterback for the St. Louis Cardinals for 18 years, from 1966 through 1983, was named yesterday the athletic director at his alma mater, Southern Illinois University in Carbondale, Ill., where he played from 1962 through 1965. . . . The Philadelphia Phillies extended the contract of Manager Lee Elia through the 1989 season yesterday despite the club's last-place position in the National League East. Elia took over from John Felske June 18, 1987. . . . Paul Giel, one of the greatest athletes in University of Minnesota history and the men's athletic director at the school since 1971, was dismissed yesterday. Giel was offered a job in the university's development office, heading external relations and fund-raising for university athletic programs and facilities. . . . The Quebec Nordiques have acquired a veteran goaltender, Bob Mason, from the Chicago Blackhawks yesterday in exchange for a forward, Mike Eagles. Mason, 27, had a 13-18-8 record and a 4.15 goals-against average with Chicago last season.(AP)

title: Athens Journal; Farmers Send a Message to A.T.&T.
description: In an old courtroom with green peeling paint and an old hayfield nearby, a college professor and some farmer friends are fighting with a giant telephone company over a hole in the ground.

title: Arc International reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Includes a $131,125 special gain. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Judge Schedules Start of Agent Orange Payments
description: Totally disabled Vietnam veterans who were exposed to the highly toxic herbicide Agent Orange will begin receiving payments early next year from a $240 million settlement of a suit against the chemical's makers, a Federal judge said yesterday.

title: Pentagon Faults Army Ad Placing
description: THE contracting officers involved in the Army Recruitment Command's search for an advertising agency have been faulted by the Defense Department for not investigating a conflict-of-interest complaint until after they assigned a $100 million advertising account to Young & Rubicam in January 1987, according to papers released last week by the Pentagon.

title: Prenuptial Stress Over the Contract
description: IT was to be a June wedding. The caterer was hired, the band was booked, the guests had sent in their R.S.V.P.'s. Two days before the ceremony, as the bride was having a pedicure, the bridegroom put his foot down. Sign the premarital contract, he told her, or be jilted.

title: KEY RATES
What Do They Mean by 'Black Learning Style'?
description: A small number of black educators and psychologists, believing that black children learn in distinctly different ways than do white children, have been urging schools to adapt their instructional methods to this difference.

title: Economic Scene; On Guaranteeing Child Support
description: FOR the political pros eager to untangle the welfare maze, three of the prettiest words in the English language are ''make dad pay.'' Requiring absent fathers to support their children would make a dent in the cost of supporting chronic welfare dependents, as well as saving newly separated and suddenly poor mothers from a first visit to the welfare office. That's why the new welfare law is certain to contain tough measures for tracking deadbeats and garnisheeing their wages.

title: Columbia Is Planning To Expand
description: Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., which has interests in movies, television production and movie theaters, said yesterday that it was hoping to expand into a fourth business.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Contel Corp., Atlanta, the communications concern, appointed A. W. Perigard president of its Contel ASC subsidiary.

title: Long-Term-Care Bill Wasn't Just for the Elderly; It Extended Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Sibelius Quartet Plans Agopov World Premiere
description: The Sibelius Academy Quartet of Finland will give the world premiere of Vladimir Agopov's Quartet No. 2 at P.M. tomorrow at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. Other works on the program will be Sibelius's ''Intimate Voices'' and Ravel's String Quartet in F.

title: The Downing Of Flight 655; Two Teheran Factions Are at Odds On a Response to the U.S. Downing
description: Iranian leaders have differed in the last few days on how to respond to the American downing of an Iranian airliner, with some, led by the Speaker of the Parliament, advocating a diplomatic offensive and others, led by a spiritual leader, urging attacks on American interests.

title: Statement Shows Meese Switching Investments
description: On the same day that Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announced he was resigning, he released a financial report showing he transferred many of his assets into mutual funds last year after the breakup of a partnership he had with an investment manager indicted in the Wedtech Corporation scandal.

title: Judge Strikes Down Ban on Foreign Aid To Abortion Groups
description: A Federal judge has struck down as unconstitutional the Reagan Administration policy of withholding foreign aid from private groups that perform abortions or that promote the procedure as a method of birth control.

title: Air Force Leaves, County Takes Off
description: LEAD: When the Pentagon announces the closing of a big military base, the news is universally greeted as an economic death sentence. In truth, the closing should be welcomed as a new lease on life.

title: Garden Raising Prices
description: The Knicks, who made it into the playoffs, and the Rangers, who did not, are raising ticket prices by as much as $5 per seat for next season.

title: Japanese Trade Pact Is Signed
description: Japan and the United States today signed a farm-trade agreement reached last month that would eventually dismantle Tokyo's quotas on imports of beef, oranges and orange juice. The Japanese Ambassador, Nobuo Matsunaga, and the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, exchanged letters to put the accord into effect, ending a 20-year dispute.

title: Singer Agrees to Sell Motor Products Unit
description: The Singer Company said today that it had agreed to sell its motor products division to Ryobi Ltd. of Japan for about $325 million.

title: Mr. Meese Judges Mr. Meese
description: Satisfied that he will not be indicted, Edwin Meese has decided to resign as Attorney General. Even though he hasn't seen the just-completed report of the independent counsel who investigated him for a year, Mr. Meese said yesterday that he is certain of vindication. He thus clings to the wrong standard even as he rightly declines to cling to office until the bitter end.

title: Goshen Hails 150 Years Of U.S. Harness Racing
description: A four-day celebration of the 150th anniversary of harness racing in the United States ended here on the Fourth of July in an atmosphere of mixed hope and gloom.

title: New York Public Library Deserves Federal Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: Banco Popular De Puerto Rico reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Contractor Fund Raising Called Inquiry Topic
description: During wiretapped telephone conversations, a former executive of the Unisys Corporation told military contractors they should raise money for Florida charities to influence decisions by Representative William V. Chappell Jr. of Florida, NBC News reported tonight.

title: Security Bancorp
description: Heinz C. Prechter, chairman of ASC Inc., an auto-parts supplier, has raised his stake in Security Bancorp Inc. to 5.48 percent and said he was interested in a seat on the board. . In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Prechter told the S.E.C. that he might buy additional shares but that he had no plans to wage a proxy fight for board representation. On June 23, Mr. Prechter bought 56,627 shares for $25 a share. He now holds 366,677 shares

title: Give Landmark Theaters To Nonprofit Troupes
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about this week's planned issues in the credit markets misidentified the issuer of a $290 million offering of preferred stock through Kidder, Peabody. It is the General Electric Company, not GTE Capital Corporation.

title: A Wine School Is Moving
description: THE International Wine Center, a prominent school, is moving from midtown Manhattan, and its companion operation, the Tastings Wine Bar and Restaurant, has closed because the building that housed them is to be demolished. Together, they have formed a hub of wine activities in New York City since early 1982.

title: Damon Rejects Ballantrae Bid
description: The Damon Corporation said it had rejected as inadequate an acquisition offer from Ballantrae Partners L.P. and the American Magnetics Corporation. The two companies had valued their offer at more than $30 a share, or about $265 million. But Damon said it would discuss other proposals with them.

title: Gold Circle Stores May Be Sold Soon
description: Robert H. Morosky, the former president of Allied Stores, is negotiating to buy the Gold Circle discount department store chain from Federated Department Stores, according to people in the retailing business. Gold Circle is one of the remaining Federated store divisions still to be sold by the Campeau Corporation, owners of both Federated and Allied Stores. Mr. Morosky could not be reached at his home in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Davis Water & Waste Indusries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company attributed the lower net in the latest quarter to a LIFO inventory accounting adjustment due principally to an increase in PVC pipe prices and the quantities carried in the year-end inventory. The company also said the decrease in net in the latest year is the result of lower gross profit margins due to a change in the sales product mix in the water treatment group and the LIFO inventory accounting adjustment.

title: Region's Lawmakers at Odds Over How to Combat Drugs
description: New York area Congressmen have emerged as dominant figures in the increasingly vociferous debate here over drug policy. But the legislators have also turned out to be sharply divided among themselves, a development likely to diminish the tri-state region's influence over the escalating national anti-drug campaign.

title: Reagan Urged to Press Pretoria on Executions
description: Seventy-two members of Congress urged President Reagan and other world leaders today to intervene on behalf of the ''Sharpeville Six,'' who await execution in South Africa for their part in a violent protest.

title: Vice President Leads Republican Chorus Sighing in Relief
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's announcement today that he would resign in a few weeks came as an enormous relief to Republicans, most notably to Vice President Bush.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Andrew Corp., Orlando Park, Ill., an electronics company, agreed in principle to acquire the microwave division of Solitron Devices Inc., Rivera Beach, Fla., for an undisclosed price.

title: Doctor Facing Ethics Inquiry Sues for Slander
description: One of two doctors under scrutiny for treating pregnant women with an anti-convulsion drug filed a $26 million lawsuit today, charging that a hospital medical director had slandered him by saying the practice violated ethical principles.

title: Why the U.S. Navy Is in the Gulf
description: The Vincennes' attack on the Iranian airliner left 290 civilians dead. What cause can justify the risk of so appalling an accident? It surely occasions a reexamination of the Navy's activities in the Persian Gulf and the goals of American policy.

title: Tigers Lose Game, Trammell
description: Dave Valle's two-run double keyed a three-run fourth inning, and the Seattle Mariners beat the Detroit Tigers, 5-4, last night.

title: Rye Playland, at 60, Is Facing Threats to Its Wholesome Image
description: Across Long Island Sound, a band of lights underlines the violet night sky. On the boardwalk here, a butter-soft wind carries the smell of salt and the clinking of sailboats moored on the water. This is not the Playland depicted in advertisements.

title: 9 Farm Credit Banks to Merge
description: Officials of the Farm Credit System today announced a multibillion-dollar merger that will combine nine of the system's banks for cooperatives into one lending institution.

title: JACKSON RUNS 1ST FOR THE NO. 2 SPOT
description: More delegates to the Democratic National Convention say they prefer the Rev. Jesse Jackson for Vice President than back anyone else, a survey by The New York Times shows. But a substantial number of those who do not want Mr. Jackson, and even some of those who do, say the Democratic ticket would have less chance of winning with him on it.

title: About New York; The Insolvent Find a Tradition Is Dwindling
description: It is midday at Gem Pawnbrokers, the self-proclaimed ''Money Stop'' at 608 Eighth Avenue. A man shuffles in with a duffle bag and proceeds to extract a conga drum, displaying it as if it were pure gold. He hints he might condescend to pawn it for $75. Bill Galindez, who owns the place, squints and says $35. The deal is done at $50.

title: Mitchell-Lama Housing Faces Uncertain Future
description: The future of New York State's largest and most successful program for moderate- and middle-income housing is likely to be decided over the next few weeks in the State Legislature.

title: Book Notes
description: Vice President Named

title: Shultz Says Iran Made Overtures
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that before an Iranian airliner was mistakenly shot down Sunday, Iranian officials had sent messages through third parties indicating a desire to open a direct dialogue with the United States and the United States had responded positively.

title: Letter; Geechee and Gullah
description: To The Living Section:

title: Funeral Is Held For Firefighter In Hackensack
description: After a solemn procession through quiet streets, a funeral Mass and a mournful celebration of the brotherhood of firefighters, Fire Lieut. Richard R. Reinhagen was buried here today.

title: Greater Efforts Urged In Technology Studies
description: Concerted action by the Federal Government and by schools and colleges can prevent a widely expected shortage of American scientists and engineers from becoming a ''self-fulfilling prophecy,'' a recent Government study maintains.

title: Aliens Who Are Still Illegal Find Life Is Getting Tougher
description: Since immigration officials began full enforcement of the 1986 immigration law on June 1, many aliens who did not qualify for amnesty are finding themselves pushed deeper into an illegal subclass as they seek employment in the United States.

title: Roast Beef a la Thruway
description: A RECENT newspaper article detailing the joys of engine cooking brought back a flood of memories, most of them quite hilarious.

title: AMERICAN WARSHIP MAY HAVE REACTED TO DISTANT SIGNAL
description: Navy briefers acknowledged to Congressional leaders today that the American warship that shot down a civilian jetliner may have picked up a distant identification signal used by a military plane and mistakenly concluded that the signal was emanating from the Iranian airliner shot down moments later.

title: Bartolomeu Simoes Pereira, Guinea-Bissau Minister, 40
description: Bartolomeu Simoes Pereira, the Minister of Planning of Guinea-Bissau, died in a car crash Monday. He was 40 years old.

title: Skipper's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
description: b-Net income

title: Marguerite Belleri, Singer, 64
description: Marguerite Belleri, a member of the Metropolitan Opera Chorus for 57 years, died of heart failure Saturday evening at Hempstead (L.I.) Hospital. She was 93 years old. Mrs. Belleri, born Gretl Maerkl in Traunstein, Bavaria, was engaged for the Met in 1910 when still a Munich schoolgirl. During her tenure with the company she worked with many of the great conductors and singers of the century. Her 50th anniversary in the chorus was widely reported, as was her retirement in 1967.

title: U.S. Considers Compensation In Airbus Case
description: The Reagan Administration has begun to review whether the United States should offer to pay compensation to the families of those killed when an Iran Air jetliner was shot down Sunday, Administration officials said today.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: COME summer, there is no easier way to entertain than with a steaming bowl of pasta accompanied by a succulent sauce, a large salad, some good bread, cheese and wine.

title: Nicaragua Reports 12 Killed in a Rebel Ambush
description: The Defense Ministry said today that contras killed five soldiers and seven civilians Monday in what it called the worst attack since a cease-fire was signed in March.

title: Horizon Gold Shares reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $39,188 from the early extinguishment of debt for the year. c-Includes a gain of $72,470 and $81,356 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the early extinguishment of debt, and also includes tax credits of $34,264 for the quarter and $412,264 for the year. Latest quarter and year results include minority interest of $9,325,000 and unrealized foreign exhchange losses of $741,259 related to the company's subordinated convertible debentures payable in Swiss Francs.

title: LESSONS
description: New Jersey's Education Commissioner, Saul Cooperman, likes to characterize his effort to take over the Jersey City schools as ''invasive surgery'' on a district riddled by mismanagement and possible corruption. His critics prefer phrases like ''political vendetta'' and ''abuse of power.''

title: Soviet Policy Reforms
description: The Soviets have renewed their argument for replacing the U.S.

title: TV News From the Mouths of Babes
description: At the Democratic National Convention this month in Atlanta, CBS News plans to keep its eye on a team of journalists between the ages of 8 and 13, and it won't be from some sense of pandering to kiddie viewers.

title: Cleric in Lebanon Urges Mercy for U.S. Captives
description: The spiritual leader of a pro-Iranian group believed to be associated with the kidnappers of Americans and other foreigners in Lebanon said today that the captives must not be made to suffer for the downing of an Iranian airliner by a United States warship in the Persian Gulf.

title: Chiat President For New York
description: Jay Chiat, chairman and chief executive of Chiat/Day, announced yesterday that Jane Newman had been promoted to president of the New York office.

title: Century Buys 3 Cable Units
description: The Century Communications Corporation said today that it had acquired three cable systems in the Southwest with 43,000 subscribers in two deals that totaled $106.1 million.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; After the White House
description: Thomas C. Griscom, who until last Thursday served as the White House director of communications and planning, will join the teaching staff at the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga. Effective Aug. 1, Mr. Griscom will fill the George West Chair of Excellence in Communications and Public Affairs. The job's responsibilities will be divided among teaching, public speaking and seminars on government.

title: Tax-Free Shopping Planned For Foreigners in Louisiana
description: Louisiana will offer tax-free shopping to foreign visitors under a bill approved by the Legislature and sent to Gov. Buddy Roemer. He is expected to sign the bill, to be effective Jan. 1.

title: ABC, Saying Israelis Impersonated Its Journalists, Protests to Shamir
description: ABC News sent a letter of protest to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel yesterday, saying it was deeply distressed that security forces in Israel had impersonated its news personnel to arrest a Palestinian Arab.

title: Top Guatemala Officers Solidly Behind President
description: Two months after suppressing an attempted coup, senior Guatemalan military officers appear to have solidified their alliance with President Vinicio Cerezo.

title: 2 More Are Convicted In Fire at Foster Home
description: Two more Queens homeowners were convicted of arson yesterday in a fire in an unoccupied house that the city planned to use to shelter foster-care babies.

title: Critic's Notebook
description: With its repertory of artfully choreographed images, Martha Clarke's ''Miracolo d'Amore'' at the Public Theater can be counted among the recent opera productions, films and theatrical presentations that in one way or another emulate painting. Franco Zeffirelli, George Lucas, Pina Bausch, Andrew Lloyd Webber, Robert Wilson and Peter Sellars share with Ms. Clarke this striking characteristic: They view the performing arts as a pretext for staging visual spectaculars. With unusually elaborate scenery and special effects, their productions tend to elevate the trappings of set design to the level of dialogue and song.

title: Silk, Silk, Silk International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company attributed the losses to lower than expected sales and profit margins due to increased competition and increased overhead expenses incurred to support the company's expansion program. The company completed its initial public offering on Jan. 29.

title: Excerpts From News Conference at Which Meese Announced Resignation
description: Following are excerpts of remarks made by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, as recorded by The New York Times and The Associated Press, as Mr. Meese announced his resignation in Sacramento, Calif.:

title: So Far, Drought Raises Prices at Supermarkets Only Slightly
description: ALTHOUGH economists are predicting that food prices will rise because of the drought affecting much of the farmland in the United States, consumers are not yet seeing big increases at the supermarket. And it's not yet clear that they ever will.

title: Armenians, Irate at Party Conference Results, Resume Wide Unrest
description: Widespread civil unrest began again in the southern republic of Armenia today as strikers closed the capital's airport and many industrial enterprises, in pursuit of their demand for the transfer of a disputed region in neighboring Azerbaijan.

title: Foster Injured
description: The two-time world champion high hurdler, Greg Foster, said yesterday that he would try to make the United States Olympic team despite a broken left arm that required surgery and medical opinion that the goal may be impossible. Foster, 29, broke his left forearm when he tripped on a hurdle in practice Monday at Cal Poly Pomona. ''I'm pretty optimistic,'' Foster said in a telephone interview from San Dimas Community Hospital, where he underwent surgery. ''It's painful right now. There are pins and plates holding the the bones together.'' Foster's arm was placed in a large brace rather than a cast. He said he will have to wear the device for 10 to 14 days. After that he will have to wear a lightweight brace. The Olympic track and field trials are scheduled this month, with heats for the 110-meter hurdles to be held July 22.(AP)

title: Review/Film; More Adventures of a Robot
description: ''Short Circuit 2,'' a sequel to the 1985 comedy that became a best seller as a video cassette, is about the mechanically cute robot, now named Johnny Five, and his adventures in a big unnamed city that is, in fact, Toronto. It opens today at the Criterion and other theaters.

title: Dispute Resolved
description: Ronnie Lamarque, co-owner of Risen Star, showed a $100,000 check at a news conference in New Orleans a yesterday and said it would go to the jockey, Eddie Delahoussaye, resolving his dispute with the colt's owners. Delahoussaye had complained that he had not received a 10 percent share of a $1 million bonus paid to Risen Star in recognition of the colt's performance in the Triple Crown races. A jockey's regular fee is 10 percent of his mount's winning purses, but payment of purses earned in defeat or through bonuses is usually arranged privately. ''Even though Louie and I are 100 percent right, we, Louie and I, have deducted $50,000 each from our owners' share,'' Lamarque said, referring to Risen Star's co-owner and trainer, Louie Roussel 3d.(AP)

title: Car Sales Up in Japan
description: Japanese bought a record 2.5 million vehicles in the first six months of the year, a 16.9 percent increase from a year earlier, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said today. Hisashi Kawagishi, an official with the trade group, said the increase reflected steady consumer spending and strong sales campaigns. The previous record of 2.1 million vehicles was set in January-June 1979, Mr. Kawagishi said. He said sales, excluding mini-cars and mini-trucks, included 1.8 million passenger cars, up 16 percent, and 695,723 trucks, up 19.8 percent.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: SHE was sitting cross-legged on the sidewalk one day not long ago, the woman I suspected of being the most successful panhandler in all of New York City. She was a young woman with old eyes who had taken up her station on Fifth Avenue, which may be blighted by ersatz curio shops and lost-our-lease signs but nonetheless remains an international metaphor for privilege and plenty.

description: Watching the hordes of newly sunburned tourists in Bermuda shorts wander among the groves of twisted cypress trees and Hansel and Gretel thatched cottages that give this village its distinctive look, it is difficult to imagine that an embarrassing controversy has been simmering here. But those who saw a truck parked outside a local art gallery with a sign reading ''Art Fraud Capital?'' knew something was amiss.

description: Frank Viola won his league-leading 14th game tonight, pitching a three-hitter as the Minnesota Twins defeated the Boston Red Sox, 8-1. The Twins moved within three and a half games of Oakland in the American League West.

description: Mothers have great influence in persuading children to wear automobile safety belts, while fathers often set a bad example, according to a survey of the nation's schoolchildren.

title: Review/Recital; Soviet Pianist, Busoni Winner, Makes Debut
description: A superior pianistic talent was disclosed by Lilia Zilberstein, the young Moscow-born winner of the 1987 Busoni competition, at her local debut in Weill Recital Hall Tuesday evening. The program - a part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts - was all Russian, and the style corresponded, but Miss Zilberstein moderates the harsh excesses that have been associated with Soviet piano playing in recent decades, and brings a fluid lyricism, a free swing of tempo and a sense of color to much of her playing. She wore a severe look on her face (broken by a quizzical half-smile in response to vigorous applause), but her music making was generous.

Bass Group and associated companies, primarily Wall Street firms, had violated requirements of the S.E.C. by failing to notify it that the group had jointly accumulated more than 5 percent of the publishing company's stock.

description: The Irving Bank Corporation ran into setbacks in court and at the Federal Reserve Board yesterday in its efforts to stave off a hostile takeover bid by the Bank of New York Company and to conclude a friendly agreement with Banca Commerciale Italiana.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Airlines, a subsidiary of AMR Corp., has agreed to lend its competitor Braniff Inc., which was recently acquired by BIA-COR Holdings, as much as $21 million and also agreed to buy up to $23 million of Braniff's assets.

title: 72 Tons of Marijuana Seized
description: The Coast Guard has seized a Panamanian-registered ship with more than 72 tons of marijuana, after firing on it 600 miles from shore. Officials said the converted oil-supply ship Encounter Bay, which was towed into port here today, refused orders to stop on Friday. The cutter Boutwell, with permission from the Panamanian Embassy to board her, fired 60 rounds from machine guns, then threatened cannon fire before the crew surrendered. The 18 crewmen, including three Americans, were held for a court appearance.

description: Japanese Tied to Stock Deal

title: New York Philharmonic In Free Parks Concerts
description: The New York Philharmonic is to open its summer series of free outdoor concerts in public parks with a program of Schubert, Tchaikovsky and Stravinsky on Aug. 1 on the Great Lawn of Central Park. James DePreist will conduct. The same program will be repeated that week in parks in Brooklyn and Queens and on Staten Island and Long Island.

description: Amtrak, the federally financed passenger rail system that serves both Pennsylvania Station and Grand Central Terminal, said yesterday that it would consolidate all its operations at Penn Station as early as 1990.

title: Getting the U. S. Out of the Gulf
description: Nothing will put Iran Air flight 655 back into the sky, but there is one sure way to avert another tragedy - withdrawing our naval forces from the Persian Gulf. Fortunately, Iran's declining fortunes on the battlefront with Iraq present Washington with a compelling and face-saving reason to leave.

title: Catalyst Gets Bid By Pickens's Son
description: The Catalyst Energy Corporation, an independent power producing company that owns or leases generators, said yesterday that it had received a bid of $10.75 a share from Thomas B. Pickens 3d of Dallas, the son of T. Boone Pickens.

description: A prestigious American who holds a life membership in the National Rifle Association made a suggestion recently that set off reverberations here.

description: An investment group led by the Beverly Hills investor Robert N. Goodman has raised its offer to acquire Perini Investment Properties Inc. to $21.50 a share, or $84.3 million, from its earlier $19-a-share proposal.

description: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts changed very little in the week ended yesterday, while yields of money market mutual funds continued to rise as investors moved to higher rates offered by other money market instruments.

description: A 27-year-old Queens man pleaded guilty yesterday to murdering a crime witness and gave a graphic and chilling account of how he and another man had executed her.

description: The stock market was buffeted yesterday by waves of futures-related program trading in the final minutes that left the Dow Jones industrial average down 28.45, at 2,130.16.

description: Ozzie Smith, the Wizard of Oz shortstop for the St. Louis Cardinals, stood No. 1 in the big leagues in votes last night when the final tally was made in the annual election by fans for baseball's All-Star Game.

title: St. John the Divine Gets New Resident Poet
description: The new poet in residence at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, will be Daniel Hoffman, who is also poet in residence at the University of Pennysylvania. Mr. Hoffman is chancellor of the Academy of American Poets and a former consultant in poetry to the Library of Congress.

title: Conflict-of-Interest Rules Ignored, Pentagon Aides Tell House Panel
description: Both Defense Department officials and private consultants have widely ignored some regulations intended to prevent conflicts of interest in weapons purchases, the Pentagon's inspector general testified today.

description: The General Telephone Company of Florida, a GTE Corporation subsidiary, is offering $75 million of 10 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2028 at 99.504 to yield 10.05 percent via underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.

description: NEW counter tops can transform the appearance of a kitchen or bathroom. But those that are professionally built and installed are usually expensive, and constructing counter tops from scratch seems daunting to many homeowners.

description: More than a year after a deputy refused to do so, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has issued a ''profound apology'' to James M. Beggs, former Administrator of the space agency, for the Justice Department's attempt to prosecute him on fraud charges.

description: Anti-apartheid campaigners announced plans today for an open-air concert near Soweto to celebrate Nelson Mandela's 70th birthday.

description: For the 28th time this season, Dave Johnson flashed the red-alert message to the bullpen: Send Myers. And for the 18th time, Randy Myers trotted to the mound with his heater and either won or saved a game for the Mets with his strikeout pitching.

title: SENATORS ASSERT WARSHIP CAPTAIN REACTED PROPERLY
description: Members of the Senate said after Pentagon briefings today that the captain of a Navy cruiser had acted properly in shooting down an unidentified aircraft that turned out to be a civilian Iranian airliner, even though he acted on incomplete information.

description: It's a long way from the stature of the Park Avenue address where he once lived, but Dennis B. Levine has finally returned home.

description: Airline and airport officials in Europe say they have stepped up security since an American warship shot down an Iranian airliner last Sunday, killing all 290 people aboard.

description: Helped by the deep pockets of new corporate owners and growing interest from advertisers, Spanish-language television in the United States is shedding its status as the stepchild of the broadcasting industry and maturing into a more professional and competitive business.

description: Sales of passenger vehicles rose 9.1 percent in the first half of 1988 over the comparable period last year, as domestic models increased their share of the market.

description: Announcing an important change in policy toward North Korea, President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea said today that he would allow trade, family visits and student exchanges with the North.

description: Senior State Department officials say Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, is on a roll, and they are watching to see whether his next move is a summit meeting with Deng Xiaoping of China.

description: THE scene is a penthouse on the 65th floor of Trump Tower. A man named Figaro is measuring a Castro convertible.

description: Texaco Inc.'s plan to sell Saudi Arabia a half-interest in three United States refineries and associated marketing properties can go forward without the approval of the Federal committee that reviews foreigners' purchases of American companies, a Treasury Department official said yesterday.

title: Frederick's of Hollywood reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
Review/Television; Architect at the Mainstream's Edge
description: It is not easy for a film maker to get inside the mind of any creative artist, but architects are notoriously frustrating as subjects. Either they talk too much, and fill the screen with jargon, or they talk too little, and the camera is left to do all the work by itself, roaming around mute buildings as if they were natural wonders. Despite these obstacles, the film maker Michael Blackwood has built up an admirable oeuvre of films about architects and architecture, the latest of which, ''Frank Gehry,'' will be shown on Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock.

title: Britain and Iran Settle Case
description: Britain and Iran have agreed to exchange compensation for damage to each other's embassies in incidents about eight years ago, the Foreign Office announced today. Iran will come out ahead by nearly $2 million in the deal, which Foreign Office officials and Mohammed Besti, the Iranian charge d'affaires in London, completed Tuesday after three weeks of negotiations, a Foreign Office spokesman said.

title: Oil Trader a Big Winner In Atlantic Sale to Sun
description: John Deuss, the Dutch oil trader whose attempt to corner the January market for North Sea Brent crude cost him $200 million, will more than make up for his loss with the planned sale of his Philadelphia refinery to the Sun Company.

title: Coniston Wins Round In Gillette Lawsuits
description: A Federal district judge in Boston said yesterday that the Gillette Company had violated a Securities and Exchange Commission rule by running a misleading newspaper advertisement that helped it win a proxy battle with Coniston Partners this spring.

title: To Kemp, It's Bradley
description: Michael S. Dukakis, deliberating over his choice of a running mate, has not asked Jack F. Kemp who he thinks would bring the most strength to the Democratic ticket. But at a luncheon yesterday the upstate New York Congressman, an erstwhile contender for the Republican Presidential nomination, voiced his opinion anyway.

title: Quilt Patterns of Bygone Times
description: WHEN not traversing the country in their recreational vehicle, Dorothymae and Harold Groves of Kansas City, Mo., research the history of quilts. Their efforts have yielded discovery of patterns originally published in a weekly quilt column in The Kansas City Star.

title: Fatal Fire Is Ruled Arson
description: A fire that killed five people has been ruled arson, Fire Chief Charles J. Bunyan said today. Investigators have traced the origin of the blaze to the enclosed porch of the victims' duplex, he said. Killed in the fire Monday were Jack Blose, 35 years old, his wife, Deborah, 31, and their children, Jack Jr., 12, Rachel, 5, and Lacey, 4. Chief Bunyan said the investigation was continuing.

title: United Stationers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

description: Vice President Bush promised today to name at least one Hispanic American to his Cabinet if he is elected President.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: DANIEL and Gerry Barnett hadn't expected their children to react so strongly to the family's move from Oklahoma to suburban Chicago. ''As we look back on it, we realize we missed some of the signs they were having trouble,'' said Mr. Barnett, a computer software developer for A.T.&T. ''We saw how they were behaving but, at the time, we didn't associate much of it with our moving plans.''

description: Share earnings are fully diluted. Quarters represent 12-week periods; 6 months represent a 24-week period.

Since then, enough evidence has been made public to construct an outline of the nature of the investigation, though not enough to judge the extent of the corruption.

description: Brooklyn Views, presented by the Brooklyn Historical Society, 718-624-0890.

description: Jean Way Schoonover and her sister, Barbara Way Hunter, who for two decades have run D-A-Y Public Relations (and its predecessor, Dudley-Anderson-Yutsy), have moved over to make way for John P. Margaritis, 39, to be chairman and chief executive, and Leonore C. Cooney, 45, to be president.

title: The Northeast Needs This Gas
description: The Northeast, Long Island in particular, needs more natural gas and needs it soon. Canadian gas is available, and the necessary pipeline could be built in two years. The big question is whether the sponsors will be able to overcome local opposition to the pipeline right of way and obtain the necessary consent from Federal regulators.

title: Walter Bailey, Lorraine Motel Owner, 73
description: Walter Bailey, owner of the Memphis motel where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was killed April 4, 1968, died Saturday. He was 73 years old.

title: Miles of L.I. Beaches Are Closed By a Wave of Sewage and Debris
description: More than 15 miles of ocean beach on Long Island, including Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Parks, were closed today when a mysterious wave of sewage, syringes, blood vials and infectious hospital waste washed ashore.

title: School of Fish Dies in Bronx Waters
description: Tens of thousands of small herring have died in creeks and shallow riverbeds of the northeast Bronx in the last few days, clogging the waterways and creating a rancid smell. Environmental officials said that the kill was linked to the hot weather and that similar kills were likely to occur in the western portions of Long Island Sound this summer.

description: The Economy

description: The Washington Bullets indicated yesterday that they would make no attempt to re-sign Moses Malone, the 33-year-old center who has been an All-Star 10 times.

description: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to increase its European sales by 10 percent in 1988, the president of IBM Europe, Michael Armstrong, said today at a conference here. I.B.M.

description: The men, mostly in work clothes and, by the dictates of their faith, barefoot, were rapt in prayer, bodies curled in supplication and foreheads bent to the prayer rugs on which they knelt, facing the Kaaba, the holy house in Mecca, far away from Woodside, Queens.

title: First Commercial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Irish Distillers Bid To Undergo Study
description: A takeover bid for the Irish Distillers Group P.L.C., the makers of Jameson's and Bushmills whiskies, has been referred to the Fair Trade Commission. The bid of 198.5 million Irish pounds, or about $312 million, for the maker of Ireland's top whiskies, was made last month by two British companies, the soft drink manufacturer Cantrell & Cochrane, and Gilbeys of Ireland, makers of Bailey's Original Irish Cream Liqueur.

title: T Cell Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Health; Personal Health
description: There is hope for cigarette smokers who feel increasingly victimized, misunderstood or at the mercy of their tobacco habit. Health professionals and nonsmokers are being urged to see smokers in a more sympathetic and constructive light in the wake of the Surgeon General's recent report declaring nicotine to be an addictive drug that quickly turns most users into abusers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Wahlstrom-McCrea
description: Wahlstrom & Company of Stamford, Conn., the Foote, Cone & Belding Yellow Pages specialty agency, has acquired McCrea Associates, a 27-year-old Philadelphia shop of similar bent, and has merged it into its own operation in that city. Wahlstrom also has offices in Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco.

title: Putting Son on Display as Pig Brings a Child Abuse Charge
description: A woman who dressed her 7-year-old son as a pig, tied his hands behind his back and placed him on the front porch where neighbors could view the crying child pleaded not guilty today to a child abuse charge.

title: For a Public Investment Bank
description: LEAD: The Social Security Trust Fund surplus is the product of a rare moment of bipartisan grace. Properly used in the spirit of its creation, it could play a catalytic role in stabilizing our precarious economy and in maximizing the chance that it can support essential services for the next several generations.

title: Limits to an F-14 Threat Cited by Military Aides
description: The Iranian F-14 fighter that the warship Vincennes thought it had detected in an attack pattern over the Persian Gulf on Sunday would have posed a limited threat to the ship, aerospace industry and military officials said today.

title: Reagan Vows Speed on Meese Successor
description: The White House said today that it would move quickly to nominate a successor to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d even though there is little time left in the Reagan Administration for the Senate to complete the laborious confirmation process.

title: Pakistan Sentences Five Arabs to Hang For 1986 Hijacking
description: Five Palestinians were convicted today and sentenced to be hanged for the 1986 hijacking of a New York-bound Pan American World Airways jumbo jet in which 21 people were killed and nearly 200 wounded.

title: Indicted GAF Executive Is a Student of Chess
description: In describing why he loved the game of chess so much, James T. Sherwin told a reporter last year: ''You can engage in diversionary tactics. You can try to fool your opponent into thinking you can do one thing and you're really doing something else.''

title: Intermingling of Roots From Several Nations
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival celebrated cultural intermingling Tuesday night with ''The Roots of Creole,'' a program that showed how the music and dance of several nations could mix happily together. Although such mixtures occur around the world, the festival emphasized the dances of Brazil and the Portuguese and African influences upon them.

title: AS MEXICANS VOTE, FRAUD IS ALLEGED
description: As the opposition charged vote fraud and the Government pledged that the letter of the law would be obeyed, millions of Mexicans voted today in the most important and hotly contested presidential and congressional election here in nearly half a century.

title: Yankees Stranded As Road Trip Ends
description: There were too many ways to look back and see how the night was lost. Lou Piniella merely viewed it as a collective failure.

title: Wall St. Fights Customer Plan
description: Wall Street officials have met with staff members of the Securities and Exchange Commission in an effort to derail its proposal on customer disputes.

title: Drought Evokes Fear of New Dust Bowl, but Important Differences Remain
description: Carl N. Hopkins climbed to the summit of a ridge south of his ranch near the Powder River this week and sorrowfully appraised the accumulated force of the drought that was burning the land.

title: Jackson Criticizes Bush Remarks That Praised Navy in Gulf Action
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson attacked Vice President Bush today, saying that Mr. Bush showed ''bad taste'' and was ''downright vulgar'' in praising the naval officers who shot down an Iran Air jetliner on Sunday, killing 290 people.

title: Market Place; Fund Managers Regain the Lead
description: AT the beginning of the year, some market analysts boldly stated that this would be the year that investment managers began beating the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and it appears that they were correct. After lagging behind the index for four of the last five years, the average independent investment management firm has been outpacing the once seemingly unbeatable index -and by a fairly wide margin.

title: GAF and Executive Are Indicted On Stock-Manipulation Charges
description: A Federal grand jury in Manhattan yesterday indicted the GAF Corporation, its vice chairman and two subsidiaries, charging that they manipulated the price of shares of the Union Carbide Corporation in 1986 after an unsuccessful attempt to take over the company.

title: Bodleian Opens Drive To Bring In Technology
description: The Bodleian Library at Oxford University is seeking funds for the conservation of manuscripts and the introduction of technology.

title: Sports People; Jets Sign Safety
description: The Jets have agreed to terms with the free safety Erik McMillan, a No. 3 draft pick, and a defensive tackle, Albert Goss, their No. 12 pick. The Jets have signed 6 of their 12 draft picks.

title: KEY RATES
Chinese Leaders Cite Unrest And Link It to Restructuring
description: Social unrest is unavoidable as China continues to change its economic and political structure, Prime Minister Li Peng told a meeting of senior security personnel on Tuesday.

title: Man Who Slew Burglar Faces Fine of $500 on Gun Charge
description: A 31-year-old man pleaded guilty yesterday in Supreme Court in Queens to the illegal possession of a pistol that he used to shoot two burglars, one fatally, who he found ransacking his apartment.

title: Stake in Shoney's
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company said it had bought a 5.1 percent stake in Shoney's Inc. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the New York-based broker-dealer said that the Shoney's shares had been acquired ''in connection with arbitrage and other activities in the ordinary course of the firm's business.'' Shoney's is a large restaurant chain based in Nashville. The company's shareholders have approved a $730 million recapitalization plan that includes a $20-a-share dividend.

title: Woman Burned While Sleeping In Deserted Bus
description: A woman who had been sleeping in an abandoned school bus on a desolate Bronx street was burned to death yesterday when the vehicle was set afire, the police said.

title: Sports People; Sabonis at Risk
description: The team physician of the Portland Trail Blazers has said the Soviet basketball star Arvydas Sabonis would risk a career-threatening injury if he plays in the Olympic Games this year.

title: North Sea Oil Rig Blast Kills 1 and Injures 25
description: An explosion and fire on a North Sea oil rig killed one worker and injured at least 25 others Wednesday night. Many of the injured were severely burned.

title: A Commencement

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $4.6 million relating to debt restructuring for both the quarter and 9 months, and net from discontinued operations of $2.4 million and $6.3 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2.6 million for the quarter and $4.3 million for the 9 months.

title: Baseball Is Getting a New Kind of Suds
description: As the names of laundry detergents go, ''Surf'' has a certain suggestive logic. The Lever Bothers product at once evokes the cleansing turbulence of the weekday wash waters while providing a coy counterpoint to its chief rival, Tide, the Procter & Gamble offering that has been the industry leader since it rolled in as the first synthetic detergent after World War II.

title: Board Backs Building New Military Reactor
description: An Energy Department advisory board today recommended building a nuclear reactor in South Carolina to provide raw materials for the nation's atomic weapons arsenal.

title: Since 1805, a Family Saved It All
description: HISTORIC preservationists never had it so good.

title: Big Board's Priority Plan Wins Praise
description: A proposal by the New York Stock Exchange to give priority to individual investors' orders received favorable reactions yesterday from portfolio managers and other market professionals, while their reactions to a plan to drop a post-crash reform on the Big Board were mixed.

title: Amax Selling Zinc Unit
description: The Big River Group said today that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Amax Zinc Company, a unit of Amax Inc. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Newcomers Rank High As Israeli Party Votes

title: A GARDENER'S WORLD A Touch of Gray Brings Harmony To Diverse Plants
description: AS more and more gray creeps into my hair, the same thing is happening in my garden. Goethe may have written that life's living tree is green, and all theory dead and gray, but I'm not sure he was much of a gardener.

title: Review/Music; A Night of Japanese Music With a Western Tilt

Toru Takemitsu, Japan's best-known composer, has had a long if informal association with these musicians. Tuesday night, as part of the First New York International Festival of the Arts, the group offered the first of four different programs at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, all under Mr. Takemitsu's artistic direction.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Our Tudor-style house, built in 1935, has stucco with wood trim on the outside of the second story. Casement windows are set directly into the stucco. Water is damaging the inside plaster around these windows on the south and east sides of the house. Large sections of plaster become stained, crumble and fall out. My husband has carved out these sections and replastered, and he has also recaulked around the outside of the windows, but the condition persists. The gutters are cleaned out regularly. Can you suggest a solution? A.Check the caulking around the window frames again. If it is O.K., the metal flashing above the windows could be defective or missing. In a Tudor-style stucco house, water might also seep into the walls around the wood strips that are set into the stucco. Caulking along all this trim where it meets the stucco may be required.
