description: AT a time in adland when the mere mention of client conflicts raises hackles in agency circles, a conversation with Marvin Sloves, chairman and chief executive of the 21-year-old Scali, McCabe, Sloves, offers a calming perspective.

title: F.D.I.C. Near Decision On Texas Bank Bailout
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is nearing a decision on several competing plans for a bailout of the First Republicbank Corporation, but the timing remains uncertain, a spokesman for the bank-insurance fund said today.

title: Store Roof Collapses During Storm in Texas, Killing 8
description: The roof of a downtown clothing store collapsed this afternoon in a torrential rainstorm in this border city, killing at least eight people and injuring at least 41 more.

title: Struggling Carter Makes No Apology
description: Gary Carter was accepting congratulations yesterday for making the All-Star team for the eighth straight year as the starting catcher for the National League. And he was still accepting condolences for not hitting a home run in 52 days.

title: STIFF SETBACK SEEN FOR RULING PARTY IN MEXICAN VOTING
description: The Mexican Government today failed to release all but the most fragmentary results from the presidential election Wednesday, an action immediately interpreted here as indicating that the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party and its candidate had been rejected by a larger proportion of the electorate than at any other time in the party's 59-year history.

title: Quest Biotechnology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company did not report revenue; it is in the development stage.

title: Sports People; Tests for Tired Hurst
description: One day after being driven from the game in the second inning by the Minnesota Twins, Bruce Hurst, the Boston Red Sox left-hander, said he would undergo tests for mononucleosis.

title: Bio-Logic Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
AMATEUR BOXER SHOWS KNOCKOUT STYLE
description: Since the rules are not supposed to reward a knockdown blow any more than a merely accurate punch, amateur boxing generates a style of competitor who fights without the malice aforethought that professionals have.

title: Soviet Paper Reports Strike Has Spread Through Armenia
description: A general strike over a disputed Soviet region has spread from Yerevan, the capital of Soviet Armenia, to the rest of the republic, the Government newspaper Izvestia said today.

title: To Swim or Not to Swim as Needles Wash Ashore
description: Jay Liegey, a lifeguard, found the first syringes this morning shortly after he arrived for work at Robert Moses State Park. ''It was scary, it really was,'' said Mr. Liegey, a lifeguard for 19 years. ''In all the years I've been a lifeguard, I've never seen stuff like this.''

title: Court Officer Slain; He Shot Suspect 5 Times
description: A New York State court officer was shot and killed in a shootout with a gunman who wounded another man in a dispute on a Manhattanville street corner last night, the police said. But before he died, the court officer put five bullets in the gunman.

title: Books of The Times; Political Consequences of the Islamic Viewpoint
description: The Political Language of Islam By Bernard Lewis 168 pages. The University of Chicago Press. $14.95.

title: The Law: At the Bar
description: It was the Sunday after New Year's Day in 1987, and Peter Fass had just arrived at Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Heine, Underberg, Manley, Myerson & Casey. He was still unpacking 25 years' worth of memories from his old firm, Carro, Spanbock, Kaster & Cuiffo, when the partner in the neighboring office invited him for a drink.

title: Powell Retrospective Reflects a Happy Life in Film
description: When the British Ministry of War heard in 1943 that Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger were filming ''The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp,'' based on a cartoon character that ridiculed the old, stagnant British military establishment, the Secretary of State for War phoned Winston Churchill and said, ''This must be stopped.''

title: Panel to Seek Impeachment of Judge
description: A subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee voted unanimously today to recommend the impeachment of Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings for 17 ''high crimes and misdemeanors,'' including perjuring himself to win his 1983 acquittal on charges of conspiracy to take a bribe.

title: House to Vote On Trade Bill
description: The House will vote next Wednesday on a revised bill to overhaul United States trade policy and on a related measure requiring large United States companies to give advance notice before closing a plant, House Speaker Jim Wright said today.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: 'Paris' at the Algonquin Liliane Montevecchi: ''Souvenir de Paris,'' the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street (840-6800). Liliane Montevecchi and her musical director, Joel Silberman, have skillfully adapted her recent one-woman show, ''On the Boulevard,'' into a cabaret act. The dancer and singer shares her memories of working in the chorus of the Folies-Bergeres and Parisian-inspired songs that include Cole Porter's wistful ''You Don't Know Paree'' and ''I Love Paris,'' as well as a French ''Night and Day.'' Miss Montevecchi embodies a vanishing tradition of Gallic music-hall life that one probably would be hard to find even if one went all the way to Paris. Shows are at 9:15 and 11:15 tonight and tomorrow. There is a $15 food and beverage minimum and a $20 music charge.

title: Illinois, No. 2 U.S. Corn Producer, Loses Half of Its Crop to Drought
description: Months of drought and weeks of blistering temperatures have destroyed half the corn crop in Illinois, the nation's second-largest producer of corn, state agriculture officials said today.

title: Jersey's Beach Whodunit: The Slick of Summer '87
description: When a 50-mile slick of sewage and hospital waste washed up last summer on New Jersey beaches, the state and an environmental group, Save Our Shores, threatened to sue New York City, contending the sludge was from the Fresh Kills (S.I.) Landfill.

title: Healthvest (A Trust) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mexican Vote: Turning Point in a Changing Nation
description: Even before any official returns were announced from the presidential elections here, it had become clear that for the first time in 59 years, Mexico had ceased to be a country dominated by a single all-embracing political party.

title: In a Poll, Americans Appear To Lose Sympathy for Israel
description: The number of Americans sympathetic to Israel declined from 48 percent in February to 37 percent in April in the wake of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, according to a poll released yesterday by the American Jewish Committee.

title: Market Place; Broad-Based Gain In Mutual Funds
description: MUTUAL funds in the second quarter continued their broad comeback from the 1987 year-end slide that was touched off by the October stock market crash.

title: Business People; Sterling Official Shifts To Praxis Biologics
description: Bernard C. Ouellette, president of Sterling Drug Inc.'s United States pharmaceutical business, has left to become president and chief executive of Praxis Biologics Inc., a small company that is developing vaccines.

title: 2 Iran F-14's Said to Have Passed A U.S. Ship Day Before Downing
description: The day before the cruiser Vincennes shot down an Iranian Airbus, two Iranian F-14 fighter planes came as close as seven nautical miles to another American Navy ship, prompting it to go on combat alert and to fire a warning flare, Administration officials said today.

title: Genesee Corp reports earnings for Year to April 30
House Approves Plan by G.O.P. to Limit the Cost of Welfare
description: The House of Representatives today instructed its negotiators to limit the cost of revising the welfare laws to $2.8 billion over five years after being warned by Republicans that anything higher would jeopardize the chances of an overhaul this year.

title: Leak Closes Nuclear Plant
description: The Consolidated Edison Company's Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant was taken out of service at 4 A.M. today when a leak of slightly radioactive water was discovered, a spokesman said. The spokesman, Dan Walden, said a pin-sized hole in a tube in one of four steam generators in the containment building was discovered through normal monitoring procedures. He said the leak posed no danger to the public. The plant is expected to be out of service about two weeks, he said.

title: PROPOSAL TO EASE CHURCH RIFT VOTED
description: Representatives of the Episcopal Church, meeting here, passed a measure today aimed at reducing resistance to the election and consecration of women as bishops.

title: Ringside Spending Seat
description: Department of It's All a Question of How You Look at It:

title: Sterling A. Callisen Art Historian, 89
description: Dr. Sterling A. Callisen, an art historian and former president of the Parsons School of Design, died of pneumonia last Saturday at his home in Andover, Mass. He was 89 years old.

title: Socker, Anyone?
description: The selection of the United States to host the 1994 World Cup raises the question of why Americans call the sport soccer when it's football everywhere else. A well-traveled friend explains that the name evolved when the game came over from England, which has two sports called football - rugby football and association football. To an Englishman, they are rugger and football or, sometimes in print, ''assoc. football.'' In crossing the Atlantic, ''assoc.'' came out ''soccer.''

title: Bartok String Quartets
description: The Bartok Quartet - Peter Komlos and Geza Hargitai, violinists; Geza Nemeth, violist, and Laszlo Mezo, cellist - is to perform the Third, Fourth and Sixth String Quartets by its namesake at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8. Tickets are $13 to $17.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: A Joint Jewish-Arab Peace Movement Needed; Role of Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: TAX PROPOSAL STIRS DISPUTE IN GERMANY
description: The West German Government, which is struggling to contain a soaring deficit, announced its 1989 budget today amid heated controversy over planned tax increases. There is a widespread belief among economists that the increases will largely neutralize the reductions in personal income taxes that go into effect in 1990.

title: A Joint Jewish-Arab Peace Movement Needed; Criticism and Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: Euro Disneyland Financing Gains
description: Euro Disneyland, a unit of the Walt Disney Company, said it had completed two major hurdles in the initial financing of its theme park to be built near Marne-la-Vallee, east of Paris. The park, which may turn out to be Europe's largest entertainment complex, will be built on a 5,000-acre site and is expected to open in 1992.

title: Higher Chance for Big Quake
description: A new scientific report issued today estimated that there is a 60 percent chance of a major earthquake in Southern California in the next 30 years, and a 50 percent chance of a similar quake near San Francisco.

title: Reviews/Art; Juxtapositions: From Robert to Manet to Pollock
description: Among the paintings Manet chose to exhibit in the 1873 Salon, a portrait of Berthe Morisot particularly rankled the Parisian critics. ''Le Repos'' depicts its subject reclining awkwardly on an overstuffed couch. Manet displays her left hand draped elegantly across the cushioned seat, but the other hand looks bizarre - a claw painted in loose, flat brushstrokes.

title: Share Vote Proposal Approved
description: Wrapping up an intense debate that has spanned five years, the Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to prevent public corporations from issuing new classes of stock that would diminish the voting power of their existing shareholders.

title: Silicon Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
Frank Wille, Banker, Dies at 57; Chairman of F.D.I.C. for 6 Years
description: Frank Wille, a banker who had been chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and New York Superintendent of Banks, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 57 years old.

title: 15 More Arrested in Restaurant Inspection Bribes
description: Twelve more employees of the New York City Health Department, along with three private consultants, were charged yesterday in a scheme to extort hundreds of thousands of dollars from restaurants by threatening to close them or cite them for health violations.

title: American Healthcare Management reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes gains of $2,988,000 for the latest quarter and $1,233,000 for the year-earlier period both from tax loss carryforwards.

title: Mayfair Super Markets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: Share earnings for the year-ago period are adjusted to reflect a two- for-one stock split issued in August 1987. Share earnings are Class A.

title: U.N. Agencies to Meet in Oslo On Third World Environment
description: Heads of the major international development agencies are likely to agree at a meeting here to place greater emphasis on protecting the environment to insure that economic growth becomes sustainable in the third world, the Norwegian Prime Minister said today.

title: Estate of E.S.M. Wins Suit
description: A Federal jury today awarded $22.6 million to the estate of the defunct E.S.M. Government Securities Inc., ruling against the financier Marvin L. Warner, who the firm claimed had unjustly profited from its 1985 failure.

title: Campaign Finance; How an Ecology PAC Chooses Its Candidates
description: Officers of the League of Conservation Voters' political action committee admitted that they knew very little about the environmental views of Wayne Cryts, a Missouri farmer who is running for Congress.

title: Members of Prominent Law Firm Tell of Ending Their Wedtech Ties
description: Lawyers from a prominent New York law firm, testifying in the Wedtech racketeering trial, said yesterday that they ended their representation of Wedtech in December 1986 after realizing that they had been repeatedly misled by the company's executives about its rapidly expanding legal difficulties.

title: The Media Business: Advertising; SSMC Retains Aaronson, Bartolone
description: The SSMC Inc., the old Singer Sewing Machine Company, which is starting a clothing care line, has retained Aaronson, Bartolone, Pearlman Advertising, a subsidiary of the ABP Group, as its agency.

title: General Mills Net Up 52.1%
description: General Mills Inc., the large consumer food concern, yesterday reported a 52.1 percent increase in net income for its fourth quarter, which ended May 29. The company attributed the higher earnings to productivity savings, a lower tax rate and charges last year from discontinued operations.

title: First Fidelity Acquisition
description: The First Fidelity Bancorporation said today that it would acquire Montclair Savings Bank in a transaction valued at about $80 million. Montclair, which has eight offices in New Jersey, will operate under its own name as a separate subsidiary of First Fidelity, the bank said.

title: BUSH AND HIS CHIEF IN A DEAL
description: President Reagan and Vice President Bush have agreed to disagree on some issues as Mr. Bush continues his Presidential campaign, the White House said today.

title: Soviets Launch Craft to Explore A Moon of Mars
description: The Soviet Union tonight launched an unmanned spacecraft on a 400 million-mile journey to Mars to explore the surface of Phobos, a small gray moon believed to be an asteroid, trapped by Martian gravity.

title: The Media Business; Matthews Will Leave Industry Association
description: Leonard S. Matthews, the consummate ad man who has been president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies for more than nine years, announced yesterday that he would leave the association, the most important in the industry, at year-end, when he concludes his second five-year contract.

title: CCA Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income The company said the results reflect a revised policy assigning advertising and promotional costs to quarters within the fiscal year in proportion to sales. Annual results are not affected by this change. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Jersey Recommends Measles Revaccination
description: The New Jersey Health Commissioner today recommended the revaccination of certain groups of children in Burlington and Ocean Counties because of an outbreak of measles that began in May.

title: Alitalia Ouster Sought
description: The chairman of Alitalia, Umberto Nordio, was asked to resign today by Italy's state-owned holding company, Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, a major shareholder in the airline. Last week Italian newspapers told of a dispute between the holding company's chairman, Romano Prodi, and Mr. Nordio about how the airline was being run.

title: Kennedy Gridlock: Problems Seen in Costly Solution
description: Kennedy International Airport, the region's busiest and the world's seventh-busiest by passenger volume, grinds to a state approaching paralysis most summer afternoons beginning about 4 o'clock, but not because there are too many airplanes.

title: Elscint Ltd reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $38,147,000 and $86,622,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively, for debt restructuring.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Michigan, Detroit, named Robert H. Naftaly senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Optimistic Survey for Book Industry
description: Conventional wisdom has it that fewer and fewer Americans are reading for pleasure and that those who do are reading less. Not so, according to a book industry survey.

title: BATTLING WITH CONGRESS OVER PRIORITIES ON HEART
description: In the latest flare-up of an old struggle, the National Institutes of Health, arguably the most important biomedical research institution in the world, is being forced by Congress to expand two areas of research it would rather avoid.

title: Afrikaner Church Questions South Africa's Angola Role
description: In the first sign of dissent within the Afrikaner establishment over Pretoria's military presence in Angola, the main Afrikaner church has publicly questioned South Africa's role there.

description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. American Festival Cafe

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Steve Hamilton, who played for the Minneapolis Lakers and was a major league pitcher with six teams, including the Yankees, has been appointed athletic director at Morehead State. . . . Lui Passaglia, who set a Canadian Football League record for consecutive point-after conversions in 1983 with 246, was signed as a free-agent by the Cleveland Browns. . . . Joe Niekro, whose 21-year career in the major leagues ended when he was released by Minnesota May 4, was named pitching coach of the Twins' Pacific Coast League team in Portland, Ore. (AP)

title: Bass Player
description: William Hooker on bass is to perform tonight at 9 at Lunch for Your Ears, 25 Prince Street (941-1774). Admission is free.

title: DOLLAR DRIFTS ON RUMORS; TRADE GAP FIGURE AWAITED
description: The dollar drifted again yesterday, but some currency traders said they were still confident that the two-week rally would be revived.

title: Paley Presents Model of New Broadcast Museum
description: William S. Paley, the 86-year-old founder and chairman of CBS, yesterday unveiled a model of his new $45 million Museum of Broadcasting before a gathering at the Plaza Hotel.

title: 72 Tons of Marijuana Seized
description: The Coast Guard has seized a Panamanian-registered ship with more than 72 tons of marijuana, after firing on it 600 miles from shore.

title: Cancer in People Near Atom Plants Is Studied
description: The National Cancer Institute has begun a study of cancer deaths among people living near nuclear plants.

title: Iran Sought Talks in April, U.S. Says
description: Iran apparently expressed interest in a face-to-face meeting with American officials last April, but hopes for a meeting were dashed after the United States sank six Iranian gunboats in the wake of the mining of the frigate Samuel B. Roberts, several senior Administration officials said today.

title: Rich Night at Yonkers
description: Among the outstanding horses racing Sunday night at Yonkers Raceway in an Empire City Stakes program of 15 rich harness races will be Runnymede Lobell, a 3-year-old colt whose victory in the $583,790 Cane Pace last Sunday ran his career earnings to $1,043,027.

title: Oil Weekly to Be Sold
description: The Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington-based consulting firm, has signed an agreement to buy Petroleum and Energy Intelligence Weekly Inc., according to Ed Morse, managing director of Petroleum Finance. The price was not disclosed. Petroleum and Energy Intelligence Weekly publishes Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, an authoritative industry newsletter, and Petroleum Market Intelligence, a monthly publication. Most staff members of the company being purchased resigned early last month, after a protracted dispute with Wanda Jablonski, its owner.

title: Apollo's Troubles Stun Wall St.
description: In a surprise for both Wall Street and the computer industry, Apollo Computer Inc., a maker of computer work stations, said yesterday that it expected to report a second-quarter loss of between $5 million and $8 million because of lower demand for its machines in the United States and Europe.

title: Meese's Dramatic Conservative Legacy
description: LEAD: Long after the ethical pecadilloes of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d vanish from the headlines, America will still be marching to his constitutional drummer. For this, the nation should be grateful.

title: A Chance To Lead
description: Republican and Democratic senators working on anti-drug legislation say privately that they would like the public and press to send a one-word message to the two leaders of the Senate: lead.

title: Theatrical Trickery And Sly Improvisations At Summerfare Festival
description: IN George Coates's music-theater spectacle ''Actual Sho,'' one of three events that kick off the Pepsico Summerfare arts festival in Purchase, N.Y., this evening, archetypal images are beamed from 26 slide projectors onto an elaborate system of Levolor blinds. Against an eclectic polyrhythmic score by Marc Ream, the images transform and dissolve like a grandly designed Rorschach test. The 80-minute show opens as a minister, played by Sean Kilcoyne, chokes on a wishbone and is hurled into a turbulent subconscious world of visual magic that may or may not represent death and the afterlife.

title: CAMBODIAN TALKS RAISE ASIAN HOPES
description: Senior Asian officials and Secretary of State George P. Shultz expressed cautious optimism today that a meeting between Vietnam and the four Cambodian factions, to be held in Jakarta, Indonesia, this month, would open a serious dialogue for an eventual political settlement in Cambodia.

title: A Joint Jewish-Arab Peace Movement Needed; But Not Harmless
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Off 7.47, to 2,122.69, in Listless Trading
description: The stock market closed slightly lower yesterday in listless trading, after overcoming early-morning selling. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 7.47, at 2,122.69.

title: Prague Journal; The Czechs' Fate: A Cornucopia of Useless Goods
description: Somewhere out in Czechoslovakia, amid towns and factories, are warehouses. And, Prime Minister Lubomir Strougal says, they are clogged with billions of dollars of goods nobody wants to buy.

title: How Much Does Bankruptcy Cost?
description: For Texaco, Inc., the answer could be $50 million. Texaco's bankruptcy filing was a catalogue of superlatives: the nation's third-largest oil company filed the country's biggest bankruptcy case to protect itself from the legal system's largest damage award: $10.53 billion to Pennzoil. So it may not come as a total surprise that the fee requests in the case are adding their own impressive statistics. This month Bankruptcy Judge Howard Schwartzberg is reviewing applications by 144 law, investment banking and accounting firms who have asked for $50,556,000 for tens of thousands of hours of work that they say Texaco urgently needed to get through its ordeal. With the exception of a $10 million request for 19 law firms representing individual shareholders, legal insiders expect Judge Schwartzberg to approve most of the requests without controversy. ''I'm not going to tell you that $50 million is not a lot of money,'' said Harold Jones, the Federal bankruptcy trustee who supervised the Texaco case. ''But I don't think the fees were in any way shape or form out of line.'' Following are law firms that asked for more than $1 million in fees.

description: What do you think a ''grocer-Congressman'' would look like?

title: Oil Platform Regarded as Strong by Industry Standards
description: The Occidental Petroleum oil-production platform that burst into flames in the North Sea on Wednesday night, though not designed to handle a major explosion, is an exceptionally strong structure by international oil industry standards.

title: Gold Reserve Off in Pretoria
description: South Africa's gold holdings plunged by 1 billion rand, or about $400 million, in June as Pretoria swapped bullion for hard currency to repay its foreign debts, the country's central bank said today.

title: Limited National Impact Seen If Drought Lasts Only a Year
description: A summer-long drought would inflict numerous hardships on farmers and others who depend on agriculture for a living, but the national economy as a whole will not be hurt if the drought is only a one-year phenomenon, many economists believe.

title: Grimes Ordered to Resume Testimony in Attack Trial
description: A victim of the Howard Beach racial attack who erupted emotionally on the witness stand Wednesday will have to continue testifying at the second trial in the case despite his mental and emotional problems, the judge ruled yesterday.

title: Finance Briefs; Debt
description: Ford Motor Credit Co., a unit of the Ford Motor Co., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $100 million of notes due 1991 through Bear, Stearns. Common Stock

title: Olympics; U.S. Group Keeps Link To South Africa
description: The directors of the United States Olympic Foundation, the fund-raising arm of the United States Olympic Committee, have voted against a measure that would have suspended future investments in American companies that do business in South Africa.

title: Review/Film; Moore and Minnelli in 'Arthur 2'
description: Seeing ''Arthur 2 on the Rocks'' is like meeting a once-ebullient, witty old friend who has let himself go to pieces. Arthur (Dudley Moore) still drinks too much, though now it's beginning to show. He looks vaguely unhealthy and is no longer funny.

title: On Stage
description: A Soap Musical There aren't a whole lot of new musicals scheduled for the fall season, but there'll be at least one more if everything goes according to plan. It's a fable set in a Laundromat, it's called ''Suds'' (what else?), it played seven weeks to sellout audiences at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego, and it's due here Sept. 1 to open Stage Left at Criterion Center, an Off Broadway house (fewer than 499 seats) on Broadway at 45th Street.

title: Western Steer-Mom 'n' Pop's reports earnings for Qtr to May 20
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain on the disposition of certain assets of $1,412,000.

title: Our Towns; No Time to Quit: A Nurse Battles Fears of AIDS
description: When word spread that the state planned to use 120 beds for AIDS patients at the Wanaque Convalescent Home, there was quite an ugly hoo-ha in this small town. The Mayor vowed, ''Never!'' and led pickets in circles. ''Keep AIDS Out of Wanaque!'' said signs.

title: Marquest Medical Products Inc reports earnings for Year to April 2
description: Year-ago figures are restated for an accounting change. The company said it expensed its entire receivable position owed by a former distributor which was forced into involuntary bankruptcy proceedings, for an expense of $3,628,000. The company also had a currency translation loss of $1,806,000 for the year on its Swiss franc borrowing and also expensed $873,000 of its investment in Masstron Inc. because it increased its investment in Masstron during the fourth quarter and was required to report its investment under the equity method.

title: Disposal of Hospital Waste: A Struggle Over Regulation
description: LEAD: Faced with fears about debris on the shoreline and fears about AIDS, officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have been struggling to regulate the disposal of infectious hospital waste.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A Neighborhood Haunt New York City is filled with unassuming little neighborhood haunts that rarely if ever get press attention, and they get along just fine without it.

title: Bartok's Remains Are Reburied in His Native Hungary
description: Bela Bartok Jr., left, and Peter Bartok, right, sons of the composer Bela Bartok, with an unidentified woman at a funeral ceremony yesterday in Budapest before the composer's remains were buried. Bartok, who left Hungary in 1940 and died of leukemia in New York in 1945, had been buried in Hartsdale, N.Y. His remains were exhumed at the request of his sons so he could be buried in the family tomb in his native country. (Reuters)

title: Contra Leader Says Sandinistas Yield a Key Point
description: A top contra leader said today that President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua, in a proposal that the next round of peace talks with the contras start July 28, appeared to have agreed to lead his Government's delegation.

title:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
POUGHKEEPSIE LANDSCAPE SITE PRESERVED
description: LEAD: Efforts to preserve buildings with historic significance have had wide support for many years, but only recently have historic landscapes such as gardens and parks begun to attract the same kind of attention.

title: Misadventures On the Way To Munich
description: ''Loose Connections,'' the 1983 English film that opens today at the Public Theater, is of main interest for having been directed by Richard Eyre, the director of the good, strong, politically provoking ''Ploughman's Lunch'' (1984), written by Ian McEwan.

title: All You'd Ever Want to Know About Housing in New York
description: How many New Yorkers must use more than 40 percent of their incomes to pay the rent? How many rental apartments have been converted into cooperatives and condominiums? What is the vacancy rate for apartments renting for $300 to $399?

title: Sports People; Charges Dropped
description: Rhode Island has dropped charges against a St. John's basketball player who was charged with assaulting a fan during a game against Providence last season. Jayson Williams, a 6-foot-9-inch center, was accused of throwing a metal folding chair at a Providence fan who jeered him during the game. Williams, a sophomore at the time, pleaded not guilty in April in Distict Court to a charge of assault with a dangerous weapon. The case was then moved to Superior Court because that charge is a felony.

title: Business Cards Tomorrow reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Sports People; Allison Shows Progress
description: Bobby Allison left his room at Lehigh Valley Hospital Center in Allentown, Pa., in a wheelchair yesterday for the first time since his racing accident June 19. Ed Gossage, spokesman for Allison's sponsor, Miller Racing, said Allison remained in guarded condition. Allison, 51, suffered a concussion and several broken bones in the accident in the Nascar Miller 500 at Pocono International Raceway.

title: Yachting; Gilmour Defending Liberty Cup Title
description: Peter Gilmour has gained a reputation in the last two years as the newest hotshot in sailing, a 27-year-old upstart from Western Australia who is not afraid to take on the likes of Dennis Conner.

title: Reviews/Art; The Frick Collection Shows Off a Fresh Face
description: People often think of the Frick Collection not simply as fixed and immutable, but also as a paragon among museums that came into being full grown. Hesitation and doubt can have played no part in its development, let alone anything so humdrum as a mistake. What did Henry Clay Frick ever do but get the best advice and act upon it? And what has the director of the Frick Collection to do today? Dust the pictures?

title: Company News; Goodrich Will Sell Polymer Units
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said it had signed a letter of intent to sell a majority of the business units in its Fabricated Polymers division to a company being formed by Richard J. Fasenmyer, president of the division. Terms were not disclosed. The new venture will acquire facilities in Ohio, California and Michigan and use the same brand names and trademarks of the units, the company said.

title: Company News; Drexel Said To Expect Charges
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert is stepping up its campaign to brace employees and major customers to the likelihood that it faces impending charges of securities law violations, several customers of the firm said yesterday.

title: MEESE SAYS HE MET STANDARD OF ETHICAL CONDUCT HE SET FOR HIMSELF
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d insisted today that he had worked diligently to avoid the apperance of impropriety in his tenure at the Justice Department and asserted again that an independent prosecutor's report on his conduct was a ''vindication.''

title: Sidewalk Cafes Close to Museums, Opera and Theater
description: EVEN people who hate the outdoors generally love outdoor cafes. This may seem pretty strange, but that's the way it is. They're ready to forget the debris stirred up by the tiniest breeze, the pungent scent of horses, the acrid fragrance of exhaust fumes. That's the price to be paid for the illusion of space, sunlight and fresh air, and diehard Manhattan weekenders pay it willingly. Better a flawed illusion, combined with the city's excitement, than the unflawed real thing somewhere out there.

title: Review/Art; Portraitist's Faces of Early America
description: The early-19th-century portraits by Joshua Johnson, now on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Equitable Center, come to life slowly. Johnson, one of the first known black artists in the United States, was active as a portraitist in Baltimore between 1795 and 1825, and the considerable strengths of his art emerge from behind a screen of social propriety, artistic awkwardness and pictorial convention.

title: Executive Shift at Vineyard Gazette
description: James and Sally Fulton Reston yesterday turned over management of The Vineyard Gazette on Martha's Vineyard to their son Richard and his wife, Mary Jo.

title: Yankees Stable And Not Critical
description: Fourteen games ago, the Yankees did the thing they seem to do better than anyone else: They made another managerial change, the 15th since George Steinbrenner began his reign as principal owner in 1973.

title: Music From Villages Of the Soviet Union
description: UNTIL now, an American listener would have had to traverse the length and breadth of the Soviet Union - to the borders of Mongolia, Iran, Poland and Turkey, to Siberia, the Gulf of Finland and the Black Sea -to hear the musicians appearing tomorrow at Symphony Space. For the first time in New York, 34 musicians from the villages of the Soviet Union are to perform in traditions hundreds of years old and thousands of miles apart - music that's technically demanding and emotionally wide open, and music that has rarely been carried to the outside world.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We do not and cannot accept the triumphalism of the official party.'' - Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, an opposition candidate for President of Mexico. [ A2:1. ]

title: Mel Krupin's Is Closing
description: One of the capital's most popular watering holes with the expense account, Mel Krupin's of pickles-and-onion-rolls fame, announced yesterday that it was closing as of the end of business Friday.

title: Avon Books Picks Chief
description: Carolyn Reidy, the publisher of Anchor Books, yesterday was named president and publisher of Avon Books, the mass-marketing division of the Hearst Trade Book Group. Ms. Reidy will replace Rena Wolner, who announced her retirement from book publishing. Ms. Reidy was director of subsidiary rights at William Morrow from 1983 to 1985. Last year she was named publisher of Random House's Vintage Books; she then moved to Doubleday's Anchor Books.

title: Business People; A Revamped Leaseway Will Get New Chairman
description: The Leaseway Transportation Corporation, a company that has gone through a proxy contest, a leveraged buyout and a refocusing of its business in the last few years, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Gerald C. McDonough, will retire later this month and be succeeded by Richard A. Damsel.

title: Staar Surgical reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes more than $340,000 of losses attributable to the company's equity interest in International Pharmaceutical Products Inc.

title: United Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income The company said about $280,000 in new product slotting costs, which are one-time payments made to a retail grocer for use of space that frozen products occupy in his frozen food cabinet, and $1,060,000 in adverse weather related costs had a significant negative effect on first quarter results.

title: What Films and When
description: The Michael Powell retrospective begins today at Film Forum 2. Admission is $5; $3.50 for Film Forum members. Mr. Powell will appear before the 6:40 P.M. screening of ''The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp'' today. Film Forum 2 is at 57 Watts Street; for screening times and other information, the number is 431-1590. Here is the schedule of the films. Today-Sunday ''THE LIFE AND DEATH OF COLONEL BLIMP'' (1943). Monday ''BLACKMAIL'' (1929), with ''Champagne'' (1928) and ''Lazybones'' (1935). Tuesday ''I KNOW WHERE I'M GOING'' (1945) and ''One Of Our Aircraft Is Missing'' (1942). Wednesday-Thursday ''PEEPING TOM'' (1960) and ''The Small Back Room'' (1949). July 15-16 ''BLACK NARCISSUS'' (1947) and ''A Matter of Life and Death'' (''Stairway to Heaven'') (1946). July 17 ''THE RED SHOES'' (1948). July 18 ''THE 49th PARALLEL'' (1941) and ''The Spy in Black'' (1939). July 19 ''THE THIEF OF BAGHDAD'' (1940) and ''The Elusive Pimpernel'' (1950). July 20-21 'A CANTERBURY TALE'' (1944) and ''The Wild Heart'' (''Gone to Earth'') (1950).

title: Perot's Postal Service Pact Is Suspended by the G.S.A.
description: H. Ross Perot's $500,000 consulting contract with the Postal Service was suspended yesterday by the General Services Administration because his company had refused to supply documents to the G.S.A.'s Board of Contract Appeals.

title: Credit Markets; Notes and Bonds Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed at the end of a topsy-turvy session yesterday, as market participants reacted to volatile movements in the value of the dollar and in oil prices.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Off to a Fast Start When Harry Hook looks back over his 29 years, he finds nothing that points clearly to what he has become now - a film maker with one movie, ''The Kitchen Toto,'' opening today, and another, ''Lord of the Flies,'' scheduled to go before the cameras on the island of Jamaica in August.

title: BANK BOARD DOUBLES TEXAS COST ESTIMATE
description: In an admission that it had significantly underestimated the problems in the savings and loan industry, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board today more than doubled its projection of the cost of shutting down or merging more than 100 insolvent savings and loan associations in Texas.

title: Business People; Bank Names New Officers
description: The Greater New York Savings Bank, moving to fill a vacancy caused by the death of its top executive, yesterday named Charles J. Ohlig chairman and chief executive and Gerard C. Keegan president and chief operating officer.

title: Real Benefits From Rail Profits
description: Yes, railroads gouge shippers who lack a transport alternative. An isolated coal mine in Kentucky is sure to pay a lot more than an auto parts manufacturer in Illinois that has railroads and truckers bidding for its business.

title: DUKAKIS CALLS FOR HISPANIC VOTES
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis appealed tonight to the nation's largest Hispanic American organization by mocking Vice President Bush's comments before the same audience one night earlier.

title: Soviet Art Auction Brings $3.4 Million
description: Contemporary Soviet art came out of the shadows and into the glittering world of the Western marketplace today as Sotheby's held the first international art auction in Soviet history.

title: Trash, Some of It Medical Waste, Closes Beaches on L.I. for 2d Day
description: For the second straight day, syringes, hospital waste and blood vials washed ashore on Long Island beaches today, closing more than 10 miles of shorefront on the western end of Fire Island.

title: Weis Markets Inc () reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
A Joint Jewish-Arab Peace Movement Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Gorbachev's Cultural Revolution
description: LEAD: The Communist Party conference has advanced Mikhail S. Gorbachev's cultural revolution.

title: Actors Make AIDS a Part of Their Work on Stage
description: The founding director of the theater watches from the sidelines in a wheelchair. The scenes depict prejudice, revulsion and insensitivity. And the actors, all of whom have been diagnosed as having AIDS or AIDS-related complex, sometimes are too ill to rehearse or perform.

title: Salem Journal; A Stranger, Violence, Visits a Small Town
description: In a matter of a few days this week, everyday life changed in this southern Indiana community, taking on an air of paranoia not usually associated with small-town America. Strangers are eyed warily. A paper bag lying in a street can cause panic.

title: Europe Jobless Data
description: The number of people out of work in the European Community fell by 400,000 in May, but the seasonally adjusted rate remained unchanged at 10.3 percent, according to figures released today. The statistics office said the number of jobless in the 12 member states stood at 15.5 million in May - 1.6 percent lower than in May 1987 and down 2.5 percent from April. But it said the underlying rate remained at 10.3 percent, the same as in April, after adjusting for seasonal factors and differences between national recording methods.

title: 2 EXCHANGES BACK A PLAN FOR HALTS IN THEIR TRADING
description: In an effort to reduce the chances of a market collapse like last October's, the boards of the New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange have approved a proposal under which trading in both markets could be halted before such a plunge.

title: New Reactor for Bomb Fuel In South Carolina Is Urged
description: An Energy Department advisory group has recommended that the department build a new reactor in South Carolina to produce fuel for the nation's nuclear weapons instead of converting a mothballed commercial reactor in the state of Washington.

title: INSIDE
description: Curb on New Shares The S.E.C. voted to bar public companies from issuing new classes of stock to diminish the power of existing shareholders. Page D1. Concern on Savings-Loans Federal regulators admitted that they had underestimated the cost of correcting problems in the savings and loan industry. Page D1.

title: Auctions
description: Kazuo Fujii, one of the first Japanese dealers to stock Impressionist art in the 1960's, is in the vanguard again, buying major contemporary artworks.

title: Jackson Plans Bus Trip to Atlanta Convention
description: Seated with campaign aides in the backyard of his home on Chicago's South Side last weekend, the Rev. Jesse Jackson suddenly broke into a grin. Let's plan to take a bus, he said, from Chicago to the Democratic National Convention in Atlanta.

title: The Media Business: Advertising; Management Group Acquires Arnold & Co.
description: A group of five managers of Arnold & Company, headed by Gerard T. Broderick, the president and chief executive, bought the company from its employee stock option plan.

title: The Electoral College's Cold Calculus
description: Americans have long hankered for formulas to predict elections. Some formulas work better than others. After the Roosevelt landslide of 1936, James J. Farley suggested dryly that the old cliche, ''As Maine goes, so goes the Nation,'' be updated to read, ''As Maine goes, so goes Vermont.'' Yet the inhabitants of Crook County, Oregon, have unerringly picked 26 consecutive winners, from Grover Cleveland through Ronald Reagan.

title: 165 FEARED DEAD FROM OIL RIG BLAST
description: About 165 oil workers were feared dead today after a towering oil platform off the east coast of Scotland exploded and burned in what officials said was the worst rig disaster in North Sea history.

title: Reviews/Film; A Technovillain And 2 Who Find Love in a Grave
description: There are some grotesquely stylish and scary moments in ''Phantasm II,'' the sequel to a 1979 film that Don Coscarelli made as a precocious 25-year-old. Unfortunately, these episdoes seem to take as long to arrive as the sequel did.

title: KEY RATES
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 Mexico failed to make public all but the most fragmentary results from a presidential election, which was intrepreted as indicating that the ruling party had been rejected by more voters than ever before. Page A1

title: TV Weekend; A Documentary Remembrance of Natalie Wood
description: She was a movie star, not a movie queen. That distinction is established in the opening moments of ''Starring Natalie Wood,'' when she is described as being always down to earth.

title: Washington Federal Savings & Loan Assn (DC) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes for the latest quarter a pretax loan loss provision of $235,000 compared with a similar provision of $116,000 a year ago; the latest 9 months include a pretax loan loss provision of $519,000 compared with a similar provision of $613,000 a year ago. c-Includes a pretax FSLIC secondary reserve of $1,018,000.

title: Memo To Dukakis
description: You didn't ask for my opinion on your Vice-Presidential choice, but here it is anyway. Assuming no embarrassing skeletons in any closet - a big assumption - the pluses and minuses for the eight people you're reported to be considering come out about as follows:

title: Andover Togs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BUSH TALKS SOFTLY ON TRIP TO BOSTON
description: Vice President Bush passed up repeated opportunities to attack Michael S. Dukakis in the Massachusetts Governor's own backyard today but showed no reluctance to vent his political ire on the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Sports People; Challenging the Rules
description: Even though National Collegiate Athletic Association rules have apparently disqualified Tony Mandarich of Michigan State from competition this season, Coach George Perles insisted yesterday that his lineman will play this fall.

title: HCC Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to April 2
description: b-Includes a $95,000 loss from the settlement of an EPA superfund claim and a $5,466,000 pretax charge on the restructuring of Hemetite Corp., a division of an HCC Industries subsidiary. c-Includes a $1,347,000 loss from discontinued operations. The company said its sales decreased primarily because of the sale of its transducer subsidiary in July 1987 and a 7 percent drop in hermetic sealing products shipped.

title: Review/Film; Rocks and Hard Places
description: Harry Hook's subdued and powerful first film is a coming-of-age story loaded with history. Mwangi, a 12-year-old boy of the Kikuyu tribe, is a clear metaphor for Kenya's political development. Set in 1950, at the start of the struggle that would lead to independence from British rule 13 years later, ''The Kitchen Toto'' suggests how blacks such as Mwangi were doubly oppressed - by the white colonists and by the Mau Mau, the terrorist group that forced other Kikuyus to swear allegiance to them. But the film's beauty is in its refusal to treat Mwangi as a symbol. He is first an intelligent, curious, open-natured child, who becomes the ultimate victim, crushed between two cultures.

title: Review/Operetta; Lehar's 'Merry Widow'
description: The first course in the New York City Opera's new season was dessert. An imported one with various domestic touches it was - Franz Lehar's ''Merry Widow,'' which opened a summer of opera at Lincoln Center on Wednesday night. In the politics of the performing arts, the City Opera has always negotiated between an adventurous left wing and a conservative status quo. This production leans hard to the right side of the company's constituency, with a functional, pleasant-looking, decently sung production meant more to soothe than to uplift.

title: Economic Scene; The Revolution By Gorbachev
description: THE Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, gained support for his proposals to reorganize his nation's economic and political system from last week's conference of the Communist Party. But what is striking about the resolutions adopted is the admission of the failings of the Soviet system and the painfully slow progress made thus far in overcoming them.

title: South Africa's Economic Warfare by Rail
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Senate vote on a plant-closing bill misstated the vote of Senator Bob Dole in some editions. He voted against the legislation.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Jazz With J. J. Johnson J. J. Johnson, Village Vanguard, Seventh Avenue South, near 11th Street (255-4037). J. J. Johnson's appearance at the Village Vanguard last year had the club packed not only with jazz fans, but also with trombonists, most of whom were slack-jawed in amazement. Mr. Johnson, the first be-bop trombonist, set the rules for most trombonists who followed him, not only in his unadorned, graceful swing, but in his tone and perfect intonation as well. His last engagement also showed him to be a fine small-group arranger: songs gave way to ensemble passages and modal sections, making for exciting listening. His band will feature the fine, rarely heard pianist Stanley Cowell, and a young, clear-headed tenor saxophonist, Ralph Moore. Shows tonight through Sunday are at 10, 11:30 P.M., and 1 A.M. Admission is $12, and the minimum is $6. Waldron at Sweet Basil

title: SENATE-HOUSE CONFERENCE COMMITTEE AGREES ON $299.6 BILLION MILITARY BILL
description: House and Senate negotiators today agreed on a compromise $299.6 billion military budget bill that carves out a specific role for the military in tracking drug smugglers. The measure also reverses Reagan Administration priorities on several key weapons systems, including the system to defend against attacking missiles.

title: Company News; Qantas Jet Order
description: Australia's international carrier Qantas Airways Ltd. has placed an order for three additional jetliners from the Boeing Company. ''The acquisitions, which will build the Qantas fleet to 43 aircraft, are needed to meet traffic demand,'' Jim Leslie, Qantas's chairman, said in a statement. He said the planes, two 747-400's and a 767-300ER, would lift the airline's order list to 11 new planes at a total cost of $2.06 billion. The state-owned carrier now has six 747-400's and five 767-300ER's due for delivery by the end of 1989.

title: 2 BUSES TO RUN ON NATURAL GAS IN EXPERIMENT
description: Brooklyn Union Gas yesterday introduced two buses that run on natural gas, producing very little pollution and lots of praise from city officials, including Mayor Koch, who held a white handkerchief over the exhaust pipe of one as a test.

title: MARKET REGULATION BILL INTRODUCED BY MARKEY
description: Representative Edward J. Markey, one of the key House Democrats with oversight responsibilities in the nation's securities markets, introduced his legislative proposal today to reform those markets in the wake of the October market collapse.

title: U.S. Embassy Holding Up Visas for Soviet Emigres
description: The American Embassy has temporarily stopped issuing refugee visas to Soviet citizens seeking to emigrate to the United States, preventing thousands of Armenians and dozens of Jews from moving to the West.

title: This Weekend At Summerfare
description: This weekend at the Summerfare festival: ''Actual Sho'' plays tonight at 8:30 at Theater C. Tickets are $23. ''Dubbelspoor'' plays tonight at 8:30 and tomorrow and Sunday at 7 P.M. at the Abbott Kaplan Theater. Tickets are $23. ''A Bone to Pick'' plays tonight and tomorrow at 8:30, and Sunday at 7 P.M. at the Dance Laboratory Theater. Tickets are $20.

title: A Joint Jewish-Arab Peace Movement Needed; End the Occupation
description: To the Editor:

title: NAVY WON'T ALTER ENGAGEMENT RULES
description: A senior official of the Reagan Administration said today that the rules of engagement governing American warships in the Persian Gulf, which the cruiser Vincennes was following when it shot down an Iranian civilian airliner last Sunday, would remain unchanged.

title: Results Plus
description: Cycling Dutchmen Still Dominate: Dutchmen continued to dominate the Tour de France yesterday with Jelle Nijdam taking the fifth stage and Henk Lubberding taking the overall lead. Nijdam crossed the finish line eight seconds ahead of Massimo Ghirott of Italy. Sean Kelly of Ireland, the Tour of Spain winner this year, finished third in the 91-mile leg from the northern French city of Neufchatel-en-Bray to Lievin near the Belgian border. Nijdam's time was 3 hours 14 minutes 14 seconds. Lubberding took over the leader's yellow jersey from another Dutchman, Teun Van Vliet, when Lubberding finished almost a minute ahead of Van Vliet. Two other Dutchmen, Eric Beukink and Peter Winnen, are second and third over all.(AP) Golf 7 Birdies for Mast: Dick Mast, a PGA Tour veteran was a stroke from the course record with a seven-under-par 64 for a one-shot lead in the opening round of the Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic in Williamsburg, Va. Playing on the 6,776-yard Kingsmill Golf Club, Mast rolled in seven birdie putts of between 2 and 20 feet. (AP) Inkster Leads by 3 Strokes: Juli Inkster had an eagle and four birdies in her first 10 holes and finished with a six-under-par 65 to take a three-stroke lead after the first round of the $400,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Mayflower Classic in Indianapolis. (AP) Tennis Gilbert and Perez-Roldan Upset: Mats Wilander and Andre Agassi scored easy victories, but Brad Gilbert and Guillermo Perez-Rolan, were upset in the $415,000 United States Pro Tennis Championships in Brookline, Mass. Wilander, seeded first, and Agassi, seeded second, scored straight set victories in the evening program after third-seeded Gilbert and Perez-Roldan were eliminated earlier. In other matches, fifth-seeded Aaron Krickstein defeated 12th-seeded Richey Reneberg, 7-5, 6-1; eighth-seeded Tom Muster defeated Jim Courier, 6-2, 6-2; Bruno Oresar eliminated Juan Aguilera, 6-4, 6-4, and Horacio de la Pena defeated Mark Dickson, 7-5, 4-6, 6-3. (AP) 14 Aces for Graf: Steffi Graf fired 14 aces and needed just 42 minutes to defeat Nicole Provis of Australia, 6-2, 6-3, in the Gunze World tournament in Yokohama, Japan. The match was Graf's first since winning the Wimbledon women's singles title. In another first-round singles match, Mary Joe Fernandez of the United States beat Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria, 7-6, 6-1. In the men's singles, Anders Jarryd of Sweden defeated David Pate of the United States, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) Magers Upsets Lindqvist: Gretchen Magers of the United States knocked out second-seeded Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden in straight sets yesterday for the biggest upset in the $75,000 Virginia Slims of Sweden in Bastad. Magers, a 24-year-old ranked 59th in the world, won the second-round match, 6-2, 6-3.(AP) Horse Show Furth Takes First and Second: Megan Furth of San Francisco continued her dominance of the division at the I Love New York Horse Show, taking both the first and second places in the $1,000 junior jumper competition yesterday in Lake Placid, N.Y. As the only rider among the 28 entries to post clean performances in the 13-fence, 470-yard first round, Furth competed only against herself in the jump-off second round. The 16-year-old rode Pantomime to a winning time of 34.092 seconds. Aboard Pint O'Guiness, she was second in 34.329 seconds. Gymnastics Perfect 10 for Hayden: Dan Hayden of Amherst, N.Y., scored a perfect 10 on the parallel bars to take the lead after the men's compulsory exercises in the United States Gymnastics Championships. Hayden had a combined score of 58.75 after the six compulsory events and Charles Lakes, Neuhall, Calif., was in second place with a 58.25. There are 130 men and women competing in the championships with 40 percent of their scores counting towards a spot on the 1988 United States Olympic team.

title: Attendant of Dalai Lama to Start a Sand Mandala
description: New Yorkers with an unfulfilled desire to watch the creation of a Tibetan Buddhist sand mandala may take heart: one of the Dalai Lama's personal attendants will begin one tomorrow at the Frederick H. Leonhardt People Center of the American Museum of Natural History. The design of concentric geometric forms, a 2,500-year-old Tibetan tradition, is believed to represent the home of one or more deities.

title: Threat to Kill Hostages Is Issued
description: A pro-Iranian faction believed to be holding at least some of the nine American hostages in Lebanon issued a statement today that appears to threaten the hostages with retaliation for the downing of an Iranian airliner by a United States warship.

title: River Forest Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Restaurants
description: Il Bianco Il Bianco is the gastronomic equivalent of those inane comedies that descend on movie theaters every summer: brash and action packed, dazzling with special effects yet having about as much substance as cotton candy. This animated new production is brought to you by the producers of Il Palazzo, that fleetingly faddish Italian extravaganza on West 18th Street.

title: New Hope For Victims
description: Since 1981, the poor woman who wants to end a pregnancy incurred through rape or incest has found no help in the Federal Government. That's when Congress removed the exception that allowed Federally funded abortions for those so victimized. She has, however, had a friend in Senator Lowell Weicker, the Connecticut Republican who is waging a battle to get that exception restored.

title: Review/Music; Evening of 20th-Century Music With the London Sinfonietta
description: The London Sinfonietta, now in its 20th season, showed at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening why it is in the upper echelon of the world's new-music groups. A concert of 20th-century works led by Esa-Pekka Salonen, a young Finnish conductor whose sympathy for contemporary music is obviously strong, was a marvel of ensemble synchronization and technical fluency. Each piece sounded painstakingly prepared. Mr. Salonen, resplendent in a vanilla suit, went at his work with a virtuoso's baton command, seemingly taking special pleasure in displaying his mastery of every metrical intricacy in a program rich in such complexities.

title: Hunger Legislation Would Aid Rural Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: The final deal of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, shown in the diagram, represented potential drama and some theoretical puzzlement.

title: Stolt Tankers & Terminals (Holdings) SA reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $30.5 million, or $1.41 a share, on the sale of a corporation which owned residential property in Japan. c-Net loss and includes a $2.1 million loss on the disposal of a trminal. d-Includes a $2.1 million loss on the sale of a terminal and a $4.8 million gain on the sale of land.

title: Review/Dance; Another Look at 'The Nutcracker'
description: Experience and artistic maturity do make a difference in ballet, despite the physical advantages of extreme youth. That was the message of two performances of ''The Nutcracker,'' performed by the Paris Opera Ballet on Tuesday night and Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: USG Is Offering $600 Million Issue
description: The USG Corporation, the nation's largest gypsum producer, is offering to the public a $600 million issue of senior subordinated debentures due in 2000 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Originally the corporation planned a $550 million financing.

title: Senate Blocks Reagan On Kuwait Arms Sale
description: The Senate tonight agreed by voice vote to block President Reagan's request to sell Kuwait 300 Maverick air-to-surface missiles. The action comes just days before Kuwait's ruler arrives in Washington.

title: Company News; Virgin Group Says It May Go Private
description: The management of Virgin Group P.L.C., a British music and communications concern, said it might take the company private through a management buyout of the public's 37 percent stake. Richard Branson, Virgin's chairman, said he was concerned that many of the 40,000 smaller shareholders in Virgin were losing money. He said the company's stock price had fallen from 140 pence ($2.39) to a recent range of 85 to 100. The shares shot up by 16.5 pence, to 115, on London's stock exchange on news of the possible buyout.

title: Proxy Vote Held Valid In Irving Bank Battle
description: A ballot cast by the Heine Securities Corporation for Bank of New York during its campaign to unseat the board of Irving Bank should never have been revoked, a court-appointed referee concluded yesterday.

title: Several Oil Companies Face Major Disruptions
description: The explosion in the North Sea on Wednesday night will disrupt indefinitely the source of a fifth of the crude oil produced last year by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: G.E. Profits Increase 16%
description: The General Electric Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter rose 16 percent, lifted by the strong performance of its plastics, broadcasting and financial services businesses.

title: To China, in Peace
description: It's hard to remember now, but the Peace Corps used to be a favorite propaganda target of Radio Peking and other Communist outlets. That was hardly surprising. When President Kennedy launched the Corps in 1962, he presented it as an antidote to ''Mr. Khrushchev's missionaries [ who were ] pouring forth from Moscow to advance the cause of world Communism.''

title: Danger on the North Sea
description: 1980: 123 crewmen on the accommodation platform Alexander L. Kielland died when the oil rig capsized in storms in the Norwegian Ekofisk area. December 1965: 13 men died when the Sea Gem rig collapsed and sank. 1975: Three men were killed when a pipeline ruptured on the Alexander L. Kielland. November 1965: Three people died and 11 were injured when an explosion ripped the bottom out of a drilling barge at Teesport near Middlesbrough in northeast England. 1984: Three workers were killed when they were trapped in a shaft in a fire on the production platform Brent Bravo. 1985: Two men died in an explosion in the semi-submersible rig Glomar Arctic II. 1982: One man was killed when a walkway collapsed on the Piper Alpha, the rig destroyed after an explosion yesterday. March 1987: 40 workers were winched by helicopter from two rigs during gales, and another rig drifted off the Norwegian coast with 77 men aboard. November 1981: The Transworld 58 platform was torn from its moorings and drifted for several hours in hurricane winds. Forty-four men were evacuated but another 20 remained trapped aboard the platform for several hours before being rescued. There were no casualties. July 1, 1988: An explosion occurred at British Petroleum's Sullom Voe oil terminal on the Shetland Islands. No injuries reported. July 5, 1988: Fire broke out on the North Sea Brent Alpha platform. No injuries reported. Source: Associated Press

title: Cocoa Panel Will Meet
description: A panel of industry experts has scheduled a meeting next week to try to resolve a dispute between world cocoa producers and consumers over support prices, International Cocoa Organization officials said today. The dispute over support prices has paralyzed the group's operations since March. The organization, which tries to stabilize prices by buying and selling from a buffer stock, cannot intervene in the cocoa market until the two sides agree on what price range the pact should defend. A world cocoa surplus, aggravated by rising output by nonmembers, including Malaysia and Indonesia, meant this year's purchases failed to prevent prices from falling to their lowest level in nearly six years, commodity dealers said. The panel is scheduled to meet Wednesday through Friday next week.

title: General Mills Inc reports earnings for 13wks to May 29
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $7.1 million for the quarter and $17.7 million for the year. c-After a loss of $5 million for the quarter and net of $13.7 million for the year both from discontinued operations. Prior year results have been restated to reflect discontinued specialty retailing operations separately.

title: At Teheran Funeral, 'Death to America!'
description: With tears and angry words shouted over flag-draped coffins, Iranians today continued to mourn the victims of Flight 655 at a memorial ceremony in Teheran.

title: Federal Paper Board Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 18
description: b-After an $8,217,000 charge on retirement of debt for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 15 to holders of record as of June 30.

title: Sports of the Times; Lee Weyer's Eyeglasses
description: IT started to rain that first game in Korakuen Stadium in Tokyo. Pete Rose recalled that Lee Weyer, the umpire, was going to get wet. Weyer had accompanied the Cincinnati Reds on this exhibition tour to Japan after the 1978 season, and now the Japanese umpires slipped on raincoats. They handed one to Weyer. ''Remember, Lee was 6-6 and this was before he lost some of his weight, so he was around 280,'' said Rose, now the Reds' manager. ''The raincoat they gave him was a Japanese raincoat. He put it on and it was about three times too small. The sleeves came up to about his elbows.''

title: Malaysian Founder 'Disgusted' at Successor
description: At 85 years of age, Prince Abdul Rahman, who presided 31 years ago over the founding of independent Malaysia and later called himself ''the happiest Prime Minister in the world,'' pronounced himself a disappointed man today.

title: PANEL CHAIRMAN OFFERS BANK POWERS BILL
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee produced his long-awaited bill today on providing new powers for banks, and it proved a bitter disappointment to the banking industry.

title: Digital Communications Asociates reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from a tax loss carryforward of $1,400,000.

description: FRIDAY BLOCK PARTY MUSICAL

title: Company News; Stock Offer Seen By Computerland
description: The Computerland Corporation, the nation's largest computer retail chain, is expected to file for an initial public stock offering within a week, according to financial sources and industry reports. A majority stake in Computerland was sold last year by its founder, William H. Millard, to an investment group led by E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Company. Much of the rest is held in trust pending the outcome of an appeal in a case in which an investor group, known as Micro/Vest, was awarded a 20 percent stake in Computerland as well as a huge damage payment from Mr. Millard.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's 441 money market mutual funds increased $468.8 million, to $264.84 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 122 institutional funds decreased $458.8 million, to $69.64 billion. Assets of the 220 general purpose funds were up $316.4 million, to $81.76 billion. Assets of the 99 broker-dealer funds increased $611.2 million, to $113.44 billion.

title: Sun Plans To Spin Off Oil Units
description: The Sun Company, a leading oil producer, said yesterday that it planned to spin off its domestic oil and gas exploration businesses into a separate company as part of a restructuring that will include eliminating 1,050 jobs.

title: 5 TIGER HOMERS ROUT ATHLETICS
description: Jeff Robinson and Paul Gibson combined on a four-hitter tonight, and the Detroit Tigers hit five home runs in an 8-1 victory over the slumping Oakland Athletics.

title: Networks Close Ranks Against Pact
description: Though Hollywood's striking writers overwhelmingly approved new interim contracts with independent producers Wednesday night, the three television networks have closed ranks against anyone who signs such contracts.

title: Lucas May Try To Buy Elstree
description: George Lucas, the maker of ''Star Wars'' and ''Willow,'' said today that he might buy Britain's Elstree film studios, which were recently sold to a property group.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page on Monday about corporate name changes misstated the role of Landor Associates on behalf of British Airways. Landor helped to redesign British Airways' logotype and aircraft in 1984. The name change, from B.O.A.C., was made by the company itself, in 1972, after it was formed through the merger of the British Overseas Airways Corporation and British European Airways.

title: ISRAEL WILL EXPEL MORE PALESTINIANS
description: The Israeli Government announced tonight that it would expel 10 Palestinians accused of being ''active in various terrorist organizations which played a central role in planning and implementing'' the seven-month-old Palestinian uprising.

title: Dow Falls 16.54 to Close at 2,106.15 By LAWRENCE J. DeMARIA
description: Stock prices fell yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 16.54 points to close at 2,106.15.

title: Corn and Soybeans Drop; Crude Oil Prices Also Fall
description: Corn and soybean prices fell yesterday, partly because many market participants have begun to liquidate or hedge their positions as they await a special Agriculture Department report on Tuesday on the estimated crop damage caused by the nation's worst drought since the 1930's.

title: Treasury Prices Tumble on Jobless Report
description: A report of a steep decline in the nation's unemployment rate in June sent prices of Treasury notes and bonds tumbling and yields soaring yesterday. The discount rates on Treasury bills also soared as this latest sign of economic growth heightened fears that the Federal Reserve would tighten credit to prevent a resurgence of inflation.

title: Flight On-Time Record Is Put at 80.5% in May
description: Four out of every five flights into the nation's 27 busiest airports arrived on time in May, with airports in cities in the West and South showing the best records, the Transportation Department said Thursday.

title: Palestinians, I Learned, Are Humans Too
description: LEAD: Although the news from the Middle East has been unremittingly bleak, I've found some hope to leaven my despair.

title: The Need for House Repair
description: House Republicans are forever complaining that the majority Democrats, who have reigned for three decades, act as if they owned the place. Much of that is sour grapes. But the Republican leadership now documents trends that reveal the hazards of prolonged one-party control.

title: Review/Opera; City Opera Presents An Intimate 'Boheme'
description: Compared with the Metropolitan Opera's grandiose ''La Boheme,'' the New York City Opera's production has an appealingly modest, homey quality, and one could argue that its chamber opera ambiance is the most appropriate setting for Puccini's Bohemian love story. On Thursday evening at the New York State Theater, the company offered the first performance in this season's run.

title: Reviews/Music; Sibelius Quartet, From Finland, In a New Work
description: Vladimir Agopov, a Ukrainian composer who teaches in Finland, recently delivered a new string quartet to his colleagues of the Sibelius Academy Quartet. They in turn brought the piece - Mr. Agopov's second in the genre - to listeners at the Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night.

title: Growth in Consumer Credit At a Slower Rate in May
description: Americans increased their installment borrowing at a modest annual rate of 4.6 percent in May, as growth in consumer credit slowed from the rapid expansion of earlier this year.

title: GUIDEPOST: The Long View
description: Binoculars come out in summer, for nature watching, sporting events and outdoor festivals. When shopping for a pair - through a catalogue or at a specialty store - consider not just the magnification power, but also the angle of view and the size of the front and rear glass elements. The wider the angle, the easier it is to track moving subjects. A bigger rear lens element allows for more eye movement, which can make watching a performance more comfortable. A bigger front lens element lets in more light, to help spot birds in a dim forest. Compact binoculars offer a good compromise between performance and weight. Prices typically start around $150. ACTIVITY TYPE OF BINOCULAR Theater, stage events Compact or pocket size; magnification of 7X or 8X; rear element of at least 2.5 millimeters Bird watching Standard size; 8X or 10X; front element of at least 40 millimeters; angle of view of 6.3 degrees or wider Sports, boating Standard or pocket size; 7X to 10X; water-resistant and rubber-coated for protection

title: Arizona Governor Is Cleared by Financial Inquiry
description: Gov. Rose Mofford of Arizona will not be charged in connection with gifts she gave as Secretary of State or with her financial disclosure statements, a County Attorney announced today.

title: Mets Run Into Caution Signs
description: For the Mets, the omens weren't good: The Houston Astros hadn't beaten Dwight Gooden in four years and hadn't beaten anybody in five games, so they were probably coiled and dangerous. And, sure enough, they broke both streaks tonight.

title: Bush Denies Accusation on His Campaign Travel
description: Vice President Bush, arriving today for a rally in the city where the Democrats will soon gather for their national convention, found himself recoiling from Democratic charges about who is paying some of his campaign costs.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16.

title: Budge, Graf And the Slam
description: In baseball, a grand slam is as common as a rhinestone. But in tennis or golf, a Grand Slam is a velvet pouch with four different precious jewels. As the Australian and French champion, Mats Wilander had an opportunity for a tennis Grand Slam this year. But even as Wilander advanced to the Wimbledon quarterfinals, Don Budge doubted that the sturdy Swede would win the title.

title: Arias Urges Nicaragua and Contra Leaders to Resume Peace Talks
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez called on the Nicaraguan Government and contra leaders today to hold another round of peace talks before Secretary of State George P. Shultz returns to Central America on Aug. 1.

title: Account of Brawley's Medical Condition Disputed
description: A Brooklyn newspaper, citing medical records, has concluded that Tawana Brawley was a rape victim and that she was ''near death'' when found in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., last November after a four-day disappearance.

title: Iranian Plays Down Revenge
description: The Speaker of Iran's Parliament said today that his nation would ''not push for any revenge'' against the United States for shooting down a civilian jet carrying 290 people last Sunday.

title: Ecuador Halts Bank Talks
description: Ecuador formally suspended talks with its foreign bank creditors today, bringing to a standstill an unratified $5.1 billion rescheduling accord reached in October, the Finance Minister, Eduardo Cabezas, said.

title: Television; Drug Scene Revisited In Two Documentaries
description: If ''Drugs: A Plague Upon the Land'' has a familiar ring, that may not be entirely due to the tabloid triteness of the title. The punchy ABC documentary was first broadcast in April and is being shown again tonight at 10 o'clock, as background for a new documentary, ''Drugs: Why This Plague?,'' which can be seen Monday at 8 P.M.

title: Repellent vs. Bug: Caution Is the Better Part of Valor
description: Insect repellents are standard summer equipment in beach bags and backyards. Nevertheless, they should be used with care.

title: Britain Signs Deal With Saudis, Replacing U.S. as Big Arms Supplier
description: Britain announced a major arms agreement with Saudi Arabia today, apparently involving planes, helicopters, ships and construction projects in a 10-year arrangement that will replace the United States as the Arab kingdom's main arms supplier.

title: Massachusetts Plans to Pay to Send Boston Pupils to Suburbs
description: Massachusetts lawmakers have added to the 1989 budget a $1 million plan under which the state would pay suburban public schools to accept students who live in Boston and neighboring Worcester.

title: Patsy Nasher, 59, Dies; Was Sculpture Patron
description: Patsy Nasher, who with her husband, Raymond, created one of the world's leading collections of modern sculpture, died of cancer on July 1 at the Parkland Memorial Hospital in Dallas. She was 59 years old. Mrs. Nasher, a friend of many of the artists whose work she collected, began by collecting pre-Columbian art, later becoming interested in Texas artists and 20th-century American painters and sculptors.

title: Tour de France; Climbers Show Early Power
description: The early favorites in the Tour de France began sorting themselves out today as a time trial through the Rust Belt of the French North yielded the outlines of the scramble to come.

title: Shultz, Meeting Sihanouk, Favors a Peace Force
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told Prince Norodom Sihanouk today that Washington would support an international peacekeeping force to help guarantee a settlement in Cambodia, Administration officials said today.
