description: To the Editor:

title: High-Tech Post Time: A Museum's Renewal
description: At the entrance to the newly renovated National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame here, the bell sounds over a life-size starting gate. And they're off!

title: McKay Cites Court's Order
description: James C. McKay, the independent prosecutor investigating Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, said today that a court order prohibiting any disclosure of his report on the Attorney General had been violated and that he would investigate and seek sanctions against those responsible.

title: Heinz Rehfuss, Singer And Music Teacher, 71
description: Heinz Rehfuss, a distinguished Swiss bass-baritone known for his musicianship and for his interpretation of music by such modern masters as Hindemith, Stravinsky and Frank Martin, died of cancer June 27 in Buffalo. He was 71 years old.

title: Motorist Inadvertently Shot by Police Officer
description: A police officer was hit by a car and seriously injured and a passing motorist was inadvertently shot by another officer on Route 22 in Mountainside, N.J. yesterday in a bizarre chain of events that was set off by the report of a stolen car and that included a chase of several other cars stolen in separate incidents, the authorities said.

title: Peterson Adds Sport Magazine
description: The Peterson Publishing Company, owner of such magazines as Motor Trend and Off-Road, said today that it had acquired Sport magazine from an investor group that has owned the monthly magazine for two years. No terms were disclosed.

title: Justice Cardozo's Enduring Legacy
description: Today is the 50th anniversary of the death of Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo of the United States Supreme Court, a remarkable figure who still has much to say to us about the way judges should decide cases.

description: To the Editor:

title: C. Jared Ingersoll, 94, Ex-Head Of Railways and Holding Concern
description: C. Jared Ingersoll, a former railroad executive and Philadelphia civic leader, died yesterday in his sleep in Dunwoody Village, a retirement home in New Town Square, Pa. He was 94 years old.

title: Singer Agrees to Sell Flight Simulation Unit
description: The Singer Company agreed today to sell its Link flight simulation and training systems division to CAE Industries of Canada for $550 million.

title: Lynda Clarizio, a Lawyer, and Mark Foulon Wed
description: Lynda Clarizio, an associate at the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter, and Mark Foulon, a Foreign Service officer assigned to head the political and economic section of the United States Consulate General in Jerusalem, were married yesterday at Our Lady of the Lake Roman Catholic Church in Verona, N.J. The Rev. Rocco F. Provinzano performed the ceremony.

title: When Lightning Strikes, Your Gadgets Are at Risk
description: These are the times that try men's microchips, when overloaded electrical systems fail and are restored with a surge of power, when lightning bolts hit overhead lines and send through thousands of volts.

title: Corrections
description: The ''At the Bar'' column on the Law page yesterday gave an outdated name for a firm involved in a merger. The firm, which merged with Lord, Day & Lord earlier this year, was Barrett, Smith, Simon & Armstrong.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIETS MAY PULL TROOPS OUT OF HUNGARY
description: The United States has received intelligence reports indicating that the Soviet Union may pull military units out of Hungary, a senior State Department official said today.

title: 4 Dyes Fading Under Scrutiny By U.S. Courts
description: On Friday some of the color will go out of the drug and cosmetics industries: Red No. 8, Red No. 9, Red No. 19 and Orange No. 17, to be precise.

title: Mexico Shatters a Monolith
description: A race far closer than even the opposition expected has left real doubt over who the next Mexican president will be. That in itself is a political earthquake in a country where the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has captured every presidential, senatorial and gubernatorial election since its formation in 1929.

title: RATE OF JOBLESS AT LOWEST POINT IN LAST 14 YEARS
description: With young workers finding an exceptional number of jobs, the nation's unemployment rate slid three-tenths of a point last month to 5.2 percent, the lowest since May 1974, the Labor Department announced today.

title: Rescuers Pull 6 From Store's Rubble
description: Four children and two adults were rescued this morning from the wreckage of the store where they had been entombed since Thursday in a macabre mix of concrete, steel, dirt and children's clothing that was still on hangers, price tags intact.

title: Dollar Up Strongly Vs. Mark
description: Spurred by the prospect of a stronger United States economy, the dollar surged against the West German mark yesterday, reaching its highest level in almost 10 months.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline and a subheading on Tuesday on an article about actions taken by a white F.B.I. agent, Gary W. Miller, against a black agent characterized Mr. Miller's admissions incorrectly. As the article reported, Mr. Miller acknowledged that he and his colleagues planned a campaign of ''retribution'' against the black agent, but Mr. Miller denied trying to harass him.

title: Joseph A. Brunton Jr., Boy Scout Executive, 86
description: Joseph A. Brunton Jr., chief executive of the Boy Scouts of America from 1960 to 1967, died yesterday after a long illness at St. Barnabas Village, a retirement home in Gibsonia, Pa., where he lived. He was 86 years old.

title: Employment Sets New York Record
description: LEAD: More New York State residents were employed in June than ever before, according to data released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: 'Daughter' of Westway: A New Fiasco?
description: Mayor Koch said the other day that the ''daughter of Westway has more than seven veils.'' He was probably too discreet to say that the veils are rapidly slipping off. As they reveal her blemishes, the danger increases that Westway's ''daughter'' will turn into another Westway fiasco.

title: The Arts Festival; Composers Show How To Make a Movie Sing
description: Music is an element that we often take for granted when going to the movies. An effective score blends with the action so seamlessly that we may not be fully conscious of the emotional buttons being pushed. But take away the music and what's left can look dull and aimless.

title: Jackson Considers Giving Speech Outside the Convention, Aides Say
description: Resisting pressure to cut short platform debate at the Democratic National Convention, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has said he may go outside the convention hall in Atlanta to speak if he has to, aides in his campaign said today.

title: Evert Clark, Reporter, 62
description: Evert Clark, a reporter who specialized in aviation, science and space, died Thursday after surgery for an aneurism at Montgomery General Hospital in Olney, Md. He was 62 years old.

title: GOLD MEDALIST IN 1928
description: Ray Barbuti, who won two gold medals in track for the United States in the 1928 Olympics and was for many years one of the leading officials in Eastern college football, died yesterday in Pittsfield, Mass., after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Perot Contract to Be Revised
description: The Postmaster General, Anthony Frank, said today that the Postal Service will have to modify the contract it recently awarded to H. Ross Perot.

title: Market Welcomes Sun Spinoff Plan
description: Investors and industry experts reacted favorably yesterday to the announcement by the Sun Company late Thursday that it would spin off its domestic oil and gas production.

title: 15 Officers Wounded by Inmates in Attack at Jersey Prison
description: Inmates wounded 15 corrections officers at Trenton State Prison today in what prison officials said was a planned attack. None of the officers were seriously hurt.

title: Howard Beach Defense Witnesses Say Prosecution Coached Victim
description: The defense in the Howard Beach racial-attack trial sought to show yesterday that the prosecution had improperly coached a victim so that he would later identify a defendant as one of his assailants.

title: F.B.I.'S SUSPICIONS ON PENTAGON CITED
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation suspects that three of the nation's largest military contractors gave money and gifts to Melvyn R. Paisley and his wife, Vicki, during Mr. Paisley's five and a half years as the Navy's top purchasing official, according to a search warrant made public here today.

title: Review/Pop; Leonard Cohen Reflects Darkly On the World
description: Leonard Cohen occupies a special niche in the roster of composer-performers who achieved prominence in the late 1960's. The singer, poet and guitarist, who played at the Ritz on Tuesday and moved to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, writes authentically poetic songs whose quasi-Biblical lyrics transform personal experience into the language of sacred myth. Set in an idiosyncratic musical style that partakes of American country, Middle Eastern folk and electronic pop, his songs reflect darkly on mutability and human nature while holding up for worship an idealized vision of feminine tenderness and compassion.

title: Payless Cashways Attracts Foreigner
description: Payless Cashways Inc. said a unnamed foreign company might make a proposal to acquire the company. The Kansas City, Mo., building supply concern has already accepted a $909 million leveraged buyout proposal led by a group of its senior management.

title: Plan to Allow Trading Halt Is Criticized
description: Officials from many financial exchanges throughout the country yesterday criticized a plan by the New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange under which trading could be halted in rapidly falling markets.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Armco Inc., Parsippany, N.J., said it would take a second-quarter charge of about $15 million related to those insurance operations of its Armco Financial Group that have stopped writing new business and are being liquidated.

title: School Ralph Nader Couldn't Save Is Razed
description: A not-so-little red brick schoolhouse once sat on a knoll not far from Main Street, here in the downtown section of this small city in Litchfield County. Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, learned arithmetic in its airy, high-ceiled classrooms. David Halberstam, the writer, played football on the dewy green grass behind the building.

title: Prosecutors Suggest Wedtech Lawyers Violated Ethics Code
description: In a testy confrontation, Federal prosecutors suggested yesterday that a prominent New York law firm violated professional ethics in a billing arrangement with the Wedtech Corporation.

title: Review/Dance; Foreign Imprint on Duke Festival
description: American modern dance has been the raison d'etre of the American Dance Festival for 54 years. In the 1980's, however, there has been a new development: The performances, premieres, conferences and dance classes initiated by this ever-dynamic institution have also illuminated the burst of experimental activity in dance abroad.

title: John D. Clark, 80, Rocket Fuel Developer
description: Dr. John D. Clark, a chemist who specialized in storable liquid rocket fuels, died Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital in Denville, N.J., after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Newfoundland, N.J.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Your Money; For Retirement, Start a Plan Now
description: The retirement years can be among life's most fulfilling, with opportunity for travel and leisure, for community and volunteer work or for that hobby or second career one has always dreamed of - but only if the financing is in place.

title: Bergen Brunswig
description: The founders of the Bergen Brunswig Corporation said they had revised a recapitalization plan to liquidate their holdings and temporarily ward off a potential takeover. Still to be worked out is the premium the company will pay for the founder's controlling stake and the restrictions on reselling new shares to be issued as part of the recapitalization.

title: Doubts Emerge About Plan To Aid Texas Savings Units
description: With only one of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's three completed merger deals in Texas having attracted much new cash from investors, some experts fear that the agency's slowly moving plan to close or merge more than 130 of the state's savings and loan institutions could hurt healthy institutions.

title: Taiwan President Will Also Head Party
description: In a move that could bolster Taiwan's drive toward democracy, President Lee Teng-hui won the powerful post of ruling party chairman today at a landmark convention that will test the party's commitment to further change.

title: S.E.C. Offers Margins Plan
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today sent Congress a legislative proposal that would give the Federal Reserve Board the authority to set margins, or down payment requirements, on stock index futures and index options.

title: Review/Pop; From Africa, Percussion And an All-Female Band
description: Explosive percussion and flamboyant dancing concluded the World Pop series of the First New York International Festival of the Arts on Thursday. Two groups from French-speaking West Africa, Les Amazones de Guinee and a 30-member percussion orchestra from Senegal led by Doudou N'diaye Rose, made their American debuts in a euphoric concert at the Beacon Theater.

title: Alfred Reginald Allen, 83, Dies; Former Official of the Met Opera
description: Alfred Reginald Allen, who had a long career as an assistant general manager at the Metropolitan Opera and as the executive director of operations for Lincoln Center, died last Sunday in Washington. He was 83 years old.

title: Guinness and LVMH Trade Stakes
description: The French champagne giant LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton and Guinness P.L.C. will take 10 percent stakes in each other under a complex deal whose terms were announced today.

title: When the Bubble Burst For the Mexican Rulers
description: The theme had been repeated on election day for as long as anyone could remember as both supporters and opportunists gathered Wednesday evening to celebrate the victory of the presidential candidate of Mexico's long-ruling official party.

title: San Bernardo Journal; Chileans Try an Air Force Their Way
description: In a modern industrial complex on the outskirts of Santiago, Chilean technicians are meticulously reconstructing a French-built Mirage 50 fighter plane that crashed two and a half years ago.

title: CBS Revises Fall Schedule To Counter Effects of Strike
description: CBS announced yesterday a reworked schedule for the fall that emphasizes movies, mini-series and special programming by the network's sports and entertainment divisions. The move represents CBS's strategy for filling in gaps in its schedule left by the strike of the Writers Guild of America.

title: Review/Music; Streching Vocal Limits
description: The good folks at the First New York International Festival of the Arts seem to have had trouble coming up with an alliterative marketing slogan for their concert Wednesday night at the Merkin Concert Hall. This was an imaginative grouping of three contemporary practitioners of extended vocal techniques, none well known to the general public. The confusion extended to the tickets, which had both ''Vocal Voyages'' and ''High Voltage Vocalists'' printed on them. In the end, the program settled for the three artists' names, and a decent-sized audience seemed to enjoy their wares.

title: Ex-Dukakis Aide Sentenced
description: The former top education adviser to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was sentenced today to two and a half years in prison and ordered to pay up to $80,000 to the state in restitution for the money he siphoned from a program.

title: Patents; New Devices For Summer Vacationers
description: A sampling of new patents illustrates how inventors keep thinking of new ways to play old games or to avoid familiar pests, especially in summer, when travel and outdoor activities are at their peak. Purifying Water With Ultraviolet Light

title: DANGER ON OIL RIGS DEBATED IN BRITAIN
description: Britain is engaged in a bitter debate over oil-rig safety after the explosion of a North Sea rig in which officials say 166 workers died.

title: Jackson Distances Himself From Remarks About Gore
description: As Michael S. Dukakis neared a decision on a running mate, the Rev. Jesse Jackson today distanced himself from his own campaign manager's criticism of Senator Albert Gore Jr., who has emerged as one of the top contenders for the post.

title: Electoral Panel Prolongs Delay In Mexico Tally
description: The confusion over who has won Mexico's presidential election deepened here today as the Federal Electoral Commission canceled all further scheduled meetings and said no election results would be announced until Sunday.

title: Summerpier Opens Today
description: ''Summerpier,'' a free six-part series of outdoor performances, begins at 6:30 P.M. today at Pier 16, Fulton and South Streets. Among those appearing are Carlos Barbosa-Lima and Sharon Isbin, both guitarists, and the pianist and composer Emiliam Sichkin accompanied by an ensemble. Mr. Sichkin will give the world premiere of his ''Concerto for Astronauts.'' All the concerts in the series can be heard live over WQXR-FM (96.3) and AM (1560). Spectators should bring blankets or chairs. Information: 669-9424.

title: Trump Enters Tyson's Corner
description: Donald Trump said today he would act as an adviser to Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, on business and boxing matters. The real estate developer is also aligning himself with Tyson in the dispute with Bill Cayton, Tyson's manager.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on June 29 about the birth of a child to Edwin and Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg misidentified Nancy Tuckerman. She is a spokeswoman for Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis.

title: Theodore F. Koop, 81, Former CBS Executive
description: Theodore Frederick Koop, a former vice president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, died Thursday of complications following surgery at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: 14 Marines Injured In Mortar Accident Treated in Honolulu
description: Fourteen marines who were wounded in a mortar accident that killed two other marines have been flown to Honolulu for further medical treatment, officials say.

title: Study Ties Carbonless Paper To Possible Fatal Reaction
description: Carbonless duplicating paper could cause a potentially fatal reaction in people who are sensitive to one of the chemicals in it, medical researchers said Thursday.

title: Davis Cup Rule Change
description: The International Tennis Federation has voted to adopt the tie breaker in Davis Cup competition beginning next year, following the formula used in the Grand Slam tournaments.

title: Prosecutor's Report Shedding New Light on Meese
description: Considerable new information about the involvement of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in a number of matters under investigation is included in parts of an independent Federal prosecutor's report that were obtained today.

title: Margaret Palmer, 90, Civic Leader in Jersey
description: Margaret Ochs Palmer, founder in the early 1030's of a West Orange, N.J., workshop for people with disabilities, died yesterday at Shell Point Village, a nursing home in Fort Myers, Fla., after a long illness. She was 90 years old.

title: G.S.A. Shifts Officials in Phone Case
description: Two top officials of the telecommunications division of the General Services Administration are being reassigned and a deputy administrator of the agency has been transferred, agency staff members said yesterday.

title: Navy Officials Confused On Order by Carlucci
description: A week after Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci ordered a freeze imposed on nine contracts under investigation in the Federal inquiry into Pentagon procurement fraud, Navy officials have not yet figured out how to carry out the order.

title: Mourning a Peacemaker Who Was Slain in Harlem
description: An off-duty court officer, Alphonso B. Deal, was killed in a gun battle Thursday night trying to keep peace on the block he loved.

title: Baseball; Eckersley Gets His 26th Save
description: Mark McGwire of Oakland drove in two runs with a grounder tonight and his 16th home run and Dennis Eckersley earned his 26th save as the Athletics ended a losing streak at four games with a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: About New York; Pebble Beach? No, but Clients Seem to Love It
description: The ad firm of Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey is one of Madison Avenue's hot new agencies, but the fact is the principals can't play golf. If you don't think that hurts, you should have been around recently when they were wooing a new client, an auto importer.

title: In Zaire, a World Lies Beyond Kinshasa
description: To the Editor:

title: The Boys From Babylon
description: The thermometer at the kitchen window, which is in shade, read 98 degrees at lunchtime, so we drove over to the shopping center to eat, rather than walk it.

title: May to Sell Loehmann's To an Investor Group
description: Loehmann's chain of specialty stores, one of the pioneers in discounting women's apparel, will be sold to an investor group led by Sefinco Ltd., of Spain, and the Sprout Group, a division of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

title: Bonn Tax Bill Passed
description: The West German Government's tax revision legislation was finally passed today after 18 months of often bitter debate. From 1990, taxes will be cut by 37.2 billion marks (about $20 billion) a year. But Bonn will gain 18.1 billion marks (about $10 billion) by cutting tax concessions and imposing a withholding tax on investment earnings. Chancellor Helmut Kohl has called the tax revision the ''undertaking of the century,'' offering the biggest tax cut in West Germany's 39-year history. But economists said that many of the economic benefits of the changes will be lost because the Government has decided to raise indirect taxes next year.

title: Michigan Energy
description: The Michigan Energy Resources Company said it had retained Dillon, Read & Company to assist it in evaluating its strategic alternatives, including the possible sale of company units or the entire company. Among the alternatives being considered are the sale of either the Michigan Gas Utilities Company or some cable television and broadcast properties, Michigan Energy said. It said it was also considering a recapitalization and merger or sale of the company. The company's stock gained $2.875 today, to $28.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Pretoria Plans Black Councils
description: The Government published plans today to establish black regional assemblies that would have limited powers to make laws on matters like education, welfare and local rule.

title: Fleet Cars: High Volume and Risk
description: Last year Fairway Ford sold nearly 20,000 new cars and trucks from its tiny building in this bucolic western Pennsylvania community.

title: Unemployment: The Biggest States
description: Civilian unemployment. Figures are seasonally adjusted.

title: Tipping on the Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: The Job Picture
Arafat Guerrillas Forced Out of Beirut
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, lost his last stronghold in the Beirut area today when a handful of his followers were forced out of a refugee district on the southern outskirts of the city.

title: Man Linked to Mob Is Found Slain in His Apartment on S.I.
description: A man believed to be an associate of the Gambino crime family was found dead Thursday in his apartment in Staten Island and appeared to have been murdered, the authorities said.

title: Challenges In Races For House Declining
description: After almost 18 years in office, Representative Robert A. Roe, Democrat of New Jersey, knows only too well what the summer of an election year is like: Money has to be raised, the press needs to be prodded, advertisements must be prepared, volunteers must be enlisted. Then come the speeches, the debates, the whole great free-wheeling road show that is American democracy in action.

title: Kansas Names Coach
description: Roy Williams, an assistant basketball coach at the University of North Carolina who received a strong recommendation from Coach Dean Smith of the Tar Heels, was named head coach at the University of Kansas yesterday.

title: Hackensack Chief Describes Loss Of Five Firefighters at Auto Dealer
description: In a news conference reflecting a week of emotional strains and tensions, Fire Chief Anthony A. Aiellos said today that intense flames blocked attempts to rescue five firefighters who were killed in a burning auto dealership here a week ago.

title: Dukakis Courts Prospect for Ticket
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis courted a Vice-Presidential prospect today, embraced a former rival and, in his last campaign swing before the Democratic National Convention, offered words of economic hope for the West and the Southwest.

title: Cuomo to Lead Democrats' Bid To Win Senate
description: Governor Cuomo, complaining that he has been frustrated by the Republican-controlled State Senate, says he wants to push for a Democratic takeover in this year's election.

title: Postal Agency Plans Partial Restoration Of Reduced Services
description: Window service at the nation's post offices, reduced last February to save money, will be returned to normal levels in September, Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank announced today.

title: Fed Gives 60-Day Extension To Irving Takeover Effort
description: Over the protests of the Irving Bank Corporation, the Federal Reserve Board yesterday granted the Bank of New York a 60-day extension to continue its efforts to take over Irving.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Curry Wins Title: Donald Curry captured the World Boxing Council junior-middleweight title yesterday when a bleeding and battered Gianfranco Rosi failed to answer the bell for the 10th round in San Remo, Italy. Rosi, an Italian, went to his knees seven times in the nine rounds - he was knocked down five times and slipped twice - while losing the title in his second defense. It was the second world championship for the 26-year-old Curry, who is from Fort Worth. He previously held the World Boxing Association welterweight title. The 30-year-old Rosi, who won the title from Lupe Aquino of Mexico last October, has a 43-3 record. Curry improved to 30-2, with 22 knockouts. (AP) Tennis Wilander Upset: Top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden was beaten by unseeded Horacio de la Pena yesterday at the United States Pro Championships in Brookline, Mass. Wilander, who was heavily favored to win the tournament at Longwood Cricket Club, lost by 7-6, 6-1 on the clay center court, where temperatures were estimated to be well over 100 degrees. De la Pena set the tone for the match when he broke Wilander in the third game of the first set, and held on to take the tie breaker, 7-4, in a set that lasted 57 minutes. He jumped to a 2-0 lead in the second set and, after being broken in the third game, won the next four.(AP) Teltscher Advances: Eliot Teltscher lost the first-set tie breaker, 7-4, and struggled nearly two hours before beating Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday in the first round of the Gunze World Tennis tournament in Osaka, Japan. (AP) Last American Beaten: Gretchen Magers, the only American left in the singles field, was eliminated by Isabel Cueto of West Germany yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Virginia Slims of Sweden tournament in Bastad. Cueto, seeded fifth, won by 6-3, 4-6, 7-5 to move into the semifinals against unseeded Sandra Wasserman of Belgium, who knocked out Cecilia Dahlman of Sweden, 6-2, 7-6. In the only other quarterfinal match yesterday, seventh-seeded Niege Dias of Brazil coasted to a 6-2, 6-3 victory over unseeded Laura Lapi of Italy on the slow clay.(AP) Rowing U.S. in Final: The United States eight-oared crew won its qualifying heat yesterday on the first day of racing at the annual regatta in Lucerne, Switzerland, which is serving as the world championships this year. The United States eight, last year's world champion, advanced directly to tomorrow's final against East Germany, which won the other heat. Yachting Jobson Leads in Liberty Cup: Gary Jobson, a 37-year-old sailboat champion from Annapolis, Md., captured four races in the Liberty Cup regatta yesterday to take the lead in the series with a 7-0 record. Jobson won the event in 1985 and 1986. Eight international teams are racing each day on a mile-and-a-half course in New York Harbor. At least four rounds of match racing are planned for today, with the finals scheduled for tomorrow. The standing at the end of racing yesterday was Jobson, 7-0; Pelle Petterson of Sweden, 5-1; Bertrand Pace of France, 4-3; Peter Gilmour of Australia, 3-3; Brad Butterworth of New Zealand, Tim Law of Britain and Greg Tawaststjerna of Canada, tied at 2-4, and Ryozo Tanaka of Japan, 0-6. Golf Jacobsen on Top: Peter Jacobsen shot a six-under-par 65 yesterday for a two-stroke lead after the second round of the Anheuser-Busch Classic in Williamsburg, Va. Jacobsen had seven birdies and one bogey and has a two-round total of 10-under-par 132. Jerry Pate and Tom Purtzer were two shots behind.(AP) White Grabs Lead: Donna White, seeking her first L.P.G.A. victory since 1983, shot a four-under-par 67 yesterday for a one-shot lead over Amy Alcott and Martha Nause after two rounds of the Mayflower Classic at the Country Club of Indianapolis. White had a two-round total of seven-under 135. Juli Inkster, who led after the first round, shot a 72 and was two shots behind White at 137. Sherri Turner and Terri-Jo Myers were also at 137.(AP) Track and Field Bile Beats Cram: Abdi Bile of Somalia, the world 1,500-meter champion, outsprinted Steve Cram of Britain in a 1,000-meter race last night at an I.A.A.F. grand prix meet in London. Bile's time was 2 minutes 17.75 seconds. Sebastian Coe, the two-time Olympic 1,500-meter champion, won the 800 meters in 1:46.14, pulling away from the field with a half-lap remaining. Said Aouita, aiming for the Olympic title, won the 1,500-meter run. The Olympic 5,000-meter champion cruised home in 3:56.50. Petra Felke won the javelin competition with a throw of 226 feet 4 inches, about 32 feet short of her world record.(AP) Horse Show Frenchman Rides Tall: Henri Prudent, a Frenchman who lives in Middleburg, Va., won the open jumper class yesterday in the I Love New York event in Lake Placid, N.Y. He rode The King, a Dutch-bred horse that handily outjumped 38 other entries over a 525-yard course of 15 jumps. Prudent's winning time was 38.147 seconds. Beezie Patton of Hartland, Wis., rode Elliott Ness, also a Dutch-bred, to second place in 39.398 seconds. Joe Fargis of Southampton, L.I., who won two gold medals at the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles, was third in 39.472 seconds on the gray stallion Abdullah. Fargis is a favorite for this year's Olympic team. Results of the the Lake Placid competition will help determine the American squad.

title: Coping: With Hobby Collections
description: Hobbyists take holidays too, in the summer's heat and haze. There are fewer hobby shows and fewer opportunities to buy, sell and trade. So this is a good time to put a collection in order. You will get more enjoyment from your hobby when activity resumes in the autumn, and if your collection ends up in someone else's hands, he or she will thank you.

title: Larizza Industries
description: Larizza Industries said it had provided certain information to a number of parties who might be interested in possible acquisition of the company or a portion of the company's assets. Larizza manufactures plastic products, electronic components and valve and pipe fittings. Larizza said none of the parties had made an offer and there were no negotiations under way with such parties. Stating that the information about the company was provided in connection with Morgan Stanley & Company's review of Larizza's strategic alternatives, the company said this process was in a preliminary stage and there could be no assurance that any transaction would result.

title: Review/Theater; Potpourri of Galileo, Tom Sawyer and Samurai
description: For sheer mad spectacle there is nothing quite like Hideki Noda's ''Comet Messenger - Siegfried,'' which is at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music through Sunday. God and Galileo fly around the universe on their own; Wagner's Valkyries traverse it on broomsticks; Tom Sawyer and four friends float around in a balloon; the 50-foot train on Nostradamus's white robe becomes a billowing cloud that wafts him away, and Halley's comet streaks through a starry night.

title: New Haitian Constitution
description: Haiti's military leader, Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, who last month seized power from the civilian Government of Leslie Manigat, announced today that a new constitution would soon be submitted to Haitians for approval to replace the one they approved 16 months ago. General Namphy indicated supporters of the deposed Duvalier dictatorship would be rehabilitated. Several Duvalierist figures accompanied him as he spoke.

title: Separating Facts From Hyperbole In Reports of Hospital Waste on L.I.
description: Shortly after noon on Wednesday, bathers at Lido Beach in Nassau County plucked two empty vials, syringes and other suspicious material from the surf. Almost immediately, worried lifeguards, following standing orders, ordered hundreds of bathers out of the water.

title: Reviews/Music; Takemitsu And His Space Ark
description: The closest American equivalent to Sound Space Ark, the Japanese new-music quintet, is the original lineup of Tashi. Both groups were formed in the early 1970's and brought together an odd but flexible combination of instruments, and both had a fascination with the music of the Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu. But while that first incarnation of Tashi is long defunct, Sound Space Ark has continued, with Mr. Takemitsu as artistic director.

title: USG Restructuring Backed by Holders
description: The USG Corporation's shareholders overwhelmingly approved a restructuring plan that will increase the company's debt to $3.1 billion from $800 million. The restructuring was the legacy of its costly victory in a takeover battle with Desert Partners L.P. Under the plan, shareholders of record by next Tuesday will be entitled to $37 in cash, $5 in securities and one new share of common stock for each common share they currently own.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We suggest that the United States has some additional crimes stored away for Iran, and that is why we do not push for any revenge. Wise people understand why we do not take revenge.'' - Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, Speaker of Iran's Parliament and commander of the armed forces. [ 1:3. ]

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 33.

title: Durham Corp. Tie
description: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., a Hong Kong affiliate of New Zealand's largest investment concern, has purchased a 12.7 percent stake in the Durham Corporation, an insurance and broadcasting company in Raleigh, N.C. It will seek permission from regulators to raise its stake as high as 50 percent. A separate investment group led by Financial Securities Fund L.P., a Nashville-based partnership, said it had acquired 7.1 percent of Durham. Durham has 8.4 million shares outstanding. At today's closing price of $31.25, up $2.25, the estimated value is $263 million.

title: Israelis Eye N.F.L. Game
description: Organizers hoping to promote a National Football League exhibition game here met with an aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today. Avi Pazner, the spokesman for the Prime Minister, endorsed the idea, saying it would be good for Israel's image to stage such an event.

title: Indoor Soccer Woes
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League, which lost two more franchises yesterday to reduce its membership to seven teams, will begin discussions next week to determine the future of the league, Commissioner Bill Kentling said. The Tacoma Stars and the Chicago Sting, who failed to post a $400,000 letter of credit by the deadline yesterday, joined the St. Louis Steamers and the Minnesota Strikers, who ended operations two weeks ago.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Texas Rangers have placed Larry Parrish, a designated hitter, on the irrevocable waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release, the team announced yesterday. . . . Tom Lasorda was given a contract extension through 1990 by the Los Angeles Dodgers, the club announced yesterday. . . . Peter Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner, said yesterday that the instant replay has no place in major league baseball. ''I am totally opposed to the use of any electronic or other technical device such as the instant replay in any form to replace, augment or overrule umpire decisions,'' he said in a statement that was sent to club owners and general managers. . . . Top-seeded Chris Evert withdrew yesterday from the Virginia Slims of Newport, R.I., tennis tournament next week because of a chronic foot injury.

title: More Beaches Are Shut but Cause Is in Doubt
description: Amid reports of medical waste washing ashore for a third day, 15 more miles of ocean beaches in New York City and on Long Island were closed to swimming yesterday, and it appeared likely that they would remain closed for part of the weekend.

title: North Trial Scheduled Sept. 20
description: The Federal district judge in the Iran-contra case today ordered Oliver L. North to stand trial Sept. 20 on conspiracy charges. The judge also ordered prosecutors to give the defense any secret documents showing Mr. North acted with higher authority.

title: Kentucky Aide Sues
description: A lawsuit seeking $6.9 million in compensatory damages and an unspecified amount of punitive damages was filed yesterday in Lexington, Ky., by Dwane Casey, an assistant basketball coach at the University of Kentucky, against Emery Air Freight Corporation.

title: All-Star Game; On Deck for 1989: the Designated Hitter
description: The designated hitter, the controversial element the American League adopted in 1973 and the World Series added in 1976, will become part of the All-Star Game next year.

title: Saints Sign Heyward
description: The New Orleans Saints signed first-round draft choice Craig (Ironhead) Heyward of Pitt to a three-year contract yesterday that did not include a weight clause. Terms were not disclosed. His agent, Bruce Allen, refused even to say whether it was close the league average of $1.1 million paid to first-round draft choices last year.

title: AIDS Carriers Win a Court Ruling
description: A Federal court in California has issued the most definitive ruling yet that a Federal law barring discrimination against the handicapped protects healthy carriers of the AIDS virus as well as those who have actually developed the deadly disease.

title: KEY RATES
100 Die as India Train Falls Off Bridge
description: More than 100 people were killed today when a train derailed while crossing a bridge in southern India, plunging the engine and nine cars packed with passengers into a lake.

title: In Civil War, British Labor Backed the North; A Legal Landmark
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Disappointment for Candelaria
description: In the late afternoon, before he walked to the mound to face the Kansas City Royals, John Candelaria sat in front of his dressing stall at Yankee Stadium and slowly unpacked the suitcase he had taken on the team's last trip. If he was disappointed about not being selected for next week's All-Star Game, Candelaria refused to acknowledge it.

description: William Walton Behind the Fcade By Susana Walton Illustratred. 255 pages. Oxford University Press. $22.95

title: Bridge
description: Humor is not usually an element in card play, but there is an occasional opportunity for a sly technical joke. The most famous type is the Grosvenor Gambit, a conspicuously foolish play made in the knowledge that the opponent will not be able to take advantage of the opportunity that has been offered.

title: In Civil War, British Labor Backed the North
description: To the Editor:

title: Counting Dropouts, Keeping Students
description: What proportion of students drop out of New York City high schools? According to a recent study by the Board of Education, the figure is 26.3 percent, an improvement from the 27.9 percent calculated a year ago. But by another, more sophisticated calculation that tracks students through all four years, the rate is 22.4 percent, up from 21.8.

title: Armenians in U.S. Split on Visa Issue
description: For months now Suren Bursalyan had been expecting his brother, Zareh, to emigrate from Soviet Armenia to join him in Hollywood, but the phone call from Moscow Wednesday brought bad news.

title: Florida Steel
description: The Florida Steel Corporation said that its senior management was considering a leveraged buyout that would involve cash and securities valued in the ''mid-to-high 40's'' a share. The company's shares jumped $3.625 today, to $47, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company has about 6,100,000 shares outstanding. Florida said any proposal made would be reviewed by a special committee of outside directors. The company, which makes steel construction products, earned $16.9 million on sales of $381 million for the year ended Sept. 30.

title: Maddi DeRose Is Wed To Calvin C. Groton Jr.
description: Madelyn Mary DeRose, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James DeRose of Rye, N.Y., and Calvin Cottrell Groton Jr., the son of Mr. Groton of Providence and Weekapaug, R.I., and the late Mary Jane Clark Groton, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye. The Rev. John E. Fanning performed the ceremony.

title: Seeking Out Stars of the '50's and '60's
description: LEAD: WHEN Stuart Hersh was 13 years old, he got a phone call from James Cagney. Young Stuart had wanted to interview the famous actor for his school newspaper and had managed to locate one of Mr. Cagney's friends at a home for aged show-business professionals. The friend passed along the youngster's phone number, and, lo and behold, one day the telephone rang:

title: Suffolk Deciding the Fate of Its Mounted Park Patrol
description: LEAD: TWO old horses, Peter Fox and Turk, the only animal members of Suffolk County's mounted park patrol, are in limbo while county officials decide their fate.

BUSINESS FORUM: ECONOMIC BLUEPRINT;
Living Well on the Good Land
description: LEAD: I LIVE in and have known all my life the northeastern corner of Henry County, Ky. The country here is small featured, narrowly creased and folded; it is a varied landscape whose main features are these:

title: Don't Make Museum An Elitist Club
description: Having read the June 5 article ''Museum Revamping After Years of Conflict,'' I can only hope that the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art's staff of six, who have credentials in the fine arts and were assessed by the American Association of Museums as ''well-trained, excited, caring professionals,'' will be able to function in that capacity, and not become discarded pawns in a power struggle that seems to be leaning toward making the museum an elitist club. JEREMIAH A. DRAKE Rockville Centre

title: There's a popular, finger-snapping street life to Latin.
description: THE toga's out. Latin's in modern-day khaki now. Some of it's in denim, even leather!

title: Headliners; Answering Prayers
description: When Sister Rose Philippine Duchesne worked among the Potawatomi Indians of Kansas in the 1840's, she was called ''Quah-kah-ka-num-ad,'' the woman who always prays. Last week she officially became a woman to be prayed to - Pope John Paul II canonized her as the fourth American to attain sainthood. After the French-born nun emigrated to the United States in 1818 at the age of 49 to direct the American branch of her religious order, the Society of the Sacred Heart, she oversaw the founding of a dozen schools, including the first free school west of the Mississippi. The Vatican said that prayers to Sister Duchesne, who died in 1852, had twice resulted in cures for cancer and once cured a hearing affliction, thus satisfying the church's requirement that candidates for canonization be shown to have performed three miracles.

title: R. S. Bowers Wed To Ruth Kennedy
description: At St. John's Chapel at the Groton School in Massachusetts, Ruth Hefren Kennedy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger G. Kennedy of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Robert Sloan Bowers, a son of Rebecca Sloan of New Haven and Dr. Malcolm B. Bowers of Branford, Conn. The Rev. Robert G. Trache, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Amy Scalera Has Wedding
description: The Roman Catholic Church of SS. Peter and Paul in Beaver, Pa., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Amy Marie Scalera, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Scalera of Beaver, to Donald Cameron Findlay 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Findlay Jr. of Elkhart, Ind. Msgr. Raymond T. Schultz performed the ceremony.

title: Public Art by Elyn Zimmerman in Exhibition at Wave Hill
description: LEAD: IN past summers, Wave Hill - the illustrious estate in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, which since 1960 has been a public garden and art center - has sent visitors to its exhibitions venturing across 28 acres in search of art. This year, visitors are kept indoors for what Jean Feinberg, the curator, calls a ''very didactic exhibition.

title: Michele Farrell Weds
description: Michele Anne Farrell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Farrell Jr. of Wall, N.J., and New York, was married yesterday to Michael McGuire Schwager, a son of Howard M. Schwager of South Glastonbury, Conn., and Anne Schwager of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. James Driscoll performed the ceremony at St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J.

title: NO TARGET SEEMED TOO BIG
description: THE PREDATORS' BALL The Junk-Bond Raiders and the Man Who Staked Them. By Connie Bruck. 385 pp. New York: The American Lawyer/ Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Ellen Reardon Marries Kirk Douglas Hartman
description: Ellen Francesca Reardon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Powers Reardon of Worcester, Mass., and Watch Hill, R.I., was married at the Watch Hill Chapel yesterday to Kirk Douglas Hartman, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Ray Howard Hartman of Mahwah, N.J. The Rev. George L. O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest, and the bridegroom's father, a Lutheran minister, performed the ecumenical ceremony.

title: What Does A Museum Owe an Artist?
description: The main question to ask about the Georges Braque exhibition at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is not whether it is good or bad but whether it should be taking place at all. It is something of a retrospective, with around 120 works, 90 of them paintings. Some are wonderful, and Braque's great series of gueridons, studios and billiard tables are at least represented. But there are also mediocre paintings and big gaps, and the show does little to clarify Braque's development and achievement.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Bloomington, Minn.;
A $600 Million Shopping Mall
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION will begin here next spring on one of the nation's largest shopping malls - the $600 million, 2.7 million-square-foot Mall of America. When the three-level complex opens in May 1992, visitors to its 800 stores and food outlets will discover for diversion a 300,000-square-foot enclosed amusement park.

title: Good Buildings That Make Respectful Neighbors
description: ''The street is a room by agreement,'' the great architect Louis Kahn said many years ago. In his characteristically poetic manner, Kahn was stating perhaps the most important truth about the design of cities: that there is a kind of social contract involved in the making of a well-designed city, a tacit understanding that buildings be placed so as to make a coherent whole.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
Boston Tries Gentrifying Around The Projects
description: LEAD: BUILT in the early 1950's on an undeveloped peninsula near downtown Boston, the Columbia Point housing project has been such an embarrassment to the city that one critic has called it ''a Devil's Island for the poor.''

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;
Leaving the Hamptons for the High Seas
description: LEAD: IT has become a fact of summer life: more and more people are taking to the seas rather than face the crowded beaches and rising real estate prices in most popular vacation spots.

title:
INVESTING;
The Payoff From Rebuilding America
description: LEAD: BY many standards, America is a young nation. But facets of American society are showing their age. That is especially true for the nation's infrastructure of roads, tunnels and bridges. These concrete and steel arteries are hardening - often with disastrous results.

title: The Battle of the Books
description: Nobody asks why students would want to have contemporary works taught in class. Teaching - explanation -has in the past been reserved for less accessible, noncontemporary works. Why not let students discover the world they live in by themselves? Are we teachers so desperate to direct them every step of the way? ELEONORE M. ZIMMERMANN Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Tougher Law Asked in Attacks on Indians
description: LEAD: A RASH of attacks on members of this city's Indian community has prompted a call from lawmakers for state legislation to protect racial, religious and ethnic minorities from violent crimes motivated by prejudice.

title: Metal House Becomes Case Study
description: EFFORTS to save a historic landmark have resulted in practical experience in restoration for architecture students at the New York Institute of Technology, who since the end of February have been disassembling the Aluminaire house in Huntington for its move to the school's Central Islip campus.

title: L.A. OUTLAW
description: THE CROSSKILLER By Marcel Montecino. 493 pp. New York: Arbor House. $18.95.

title: Verbatim; Uniform Standards
description: 'We did not wage that civil rights struggle merely to replace one form of judicial corruption with another. In order to be true to our principles, we must demand that all persons live up to the same high standards.' - Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan and one of the senior black members of Congress discussing his vote, as chairman of the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Criminal Justice, to recommend that Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings, a black, be impeached.

title: Detective Is Arrested in Beating of Relative
description: A New York City police detective was arrested last night in the beating of a relative in a park and driving while intoxicated, the authorities said today.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Lilco Settlement Is the Best We Can Do
description: LEAD: THE settlement agreement between Lilco and the State of New York should be ratified by the State Legislature before it recesses for the summer. The agreement permanently closes Shoreham at less expense to the ratepayer than any alternative, including a takeover, according to a thorough analysis by the staff of the Public Service

title: Special Honor For Cawley
description: IT was only last month that 36-year-old Evonne Goolagong Cawley played her first game of tennis on the clipped green lawns at the casino in Newport, R.I. She returned there yesterday, this time to be enrolled as 1988's only inductee into the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

title: Vermont Gets a Big Response To Subsidies for Dairy Farms
description: More than 85 percent of Vermont's dairy producers have applied for subsidies under the first such state program of direct payments to farmers.

title: N. D. Chapman Is Married To Mary Elizabeth Martin
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in the Georgetown section of Washington, Mary Elizabeth Martin and Nathaniel Dabney Chapman were married yesterday by the Rev. Sanford Garner, assisted by the Rev. Donald Goodness.

title: Education For Gifted Said to Lag
description: LEAD: ''IN this society, if you're really smart, you learn how to be average, because it's not considered 'neat' to be gifted.''

title: GENERATIONS OF TORMENT
description: ''In no way, can or will the Provisional Irish Republican Army ever be defeated militarily.'' - Sir James M. Glover, former general officer commanding, British Army, Northern Ireland, Feb. 21, 1988.

title: DEAD PANDA LEAVES GRIEVING MATE!
description: TRUST ME ON THIS By Donald E. Westlake. 293 pp. New York: The Mysterious Press. $16.95.

title: Iran's Stoic Voices: Firm and Self-Confident
description: ''I don't know what the future will bring,'' said Abdallah Nofeiri, a Teheran restaurant operator, a devout Moslem and strong supporter of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. ''Life is too expensive, the war has been too long. We live in Iran from day to day now.''

title: Bombs Found in Salem, Ind., Are Linked to Dynamite Theft
description: A spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said today that 13 unexploded dynamite bombs discovered in this small community earlier in the week had been traced to a theft of dynamite in another Indiana town last month.

title: From Africa Comes Inspiration
description: The all-star African pop double bill 10 days ago at the Beacon Theater, featuring Youssou N'Dour of Senegal and Salif Keita of Mali, was above all a joyous musical and commual celebration. Musical, because Mr. N'Dour and Mr. Keita have two of the finest voices around, irrespective of genre; and both of them set their singing in ebullient, triumphant, rhythmically enlivening instrumental contexts. Communal, because the sheer spectacle of the audience at the Beacon, many of them Africans arrayed in the grandest of finery and rightly seeing this concert as a kind of cultural victory, was almost as inspiring as the spectacle on stage.

title: A Secret Collection Goes Public
description: One of the finest art Deco collections formed in recent years has just come on the market. The holdings of Michael Chow, the restaurateur, have been bought by Anthony DeLorenzo, a New York dealer who specializes in 20th-century decorative arts. The sale puts on public view one of the most important collections of Art Deco ever assembled, and one that was put together in almost utter secrecy. The shimmering 1920's and 1930's tables, chairs, desks, cabinets, screens, piano, lighting fixtures, vases and cigar box, acquired by Mr. Chow over 15 years, have added a high-intensity glow to the DeLorenzo gallery (958 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street).

title: Jacqueline Sadler Wed to a Lawyer
description: Jacqueline Rose Sadler, an associate with Cole & Dietz, and Jonathan David Reichman, an associate with Kenyon & Kenyon, both New York law firms, were married last evening at a private home in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Deborah Zecher officiated. Mrs. Reichman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Sadler of Pleasantville, N.Y., graduated from Yale University and received a master's degree from the Columbia University School of International and Public Affairs and a J.D. degree from the Boston University School of Law.

title: POSTINGS: 376 Palisades Condos; Views for a Price
description: At Carlyle Towers in Cliffside Park, N.J., exposure sets expense. Apartments at the Carlyle - the latest, and possibly the last, in a line of residential towers atop the Palisades - will afford views ranging from premium (southeast toward the Statue of Liberty) to prime (northeast at the George Washington Bridge) to economy (west into the Garden State). As a result, one-bedroom apartments range in price from $165,000 to almost twice that much; the same is true of the two-bedroom units, which start at $275,000. The 376-unit project's highest prices are for the $630,000 three-bedroom apartments and the $1.1 million penthouses.

title: Repairing Clapboards
description: DESPITE the popularity of aluminum and vinyl siding and other contemporary varieties, many homes still feature traditional overlapping wood clapboards.

title: Turning a Tame Game Into a Lively One
description: WOULDN'T it be grand if there were a way to get the benefits of the Ruy Lopez without its accompanying hazards?

title: The Battle of the Books
description: As a member of this new generation (having earned my A.B. in English at Duke, I am currently studying post-philosophical thought at Harvard), I can see why the William Bennetts and the Allan Blooms so fiercely fight my generation. At stake is not only the canon of Western literary masterpieces, but the very presuppositions of Western thought.

description: A $150 MILLION golf course community, the New England Country Club, is under construction in this small town about an hour south of Boston.

title: THE NATION: Users vs. Posterity; What Is a National Park Supposed to Accomplish?
description: CONGRESS handed a tough dilemma to the stewards of America's national parks in 1916 when it created the National Park Service to ''provide for the enjoyment'' of natural and historic sites, scenery and wildlife in the parks ''by such means as will leave them unimpaired for the enjoyment of future generations.'' But perhaps never has the inherent contradiction between using the parks for recreation and preserving them for posterity been more pointed than it is this summer, as vacationers crowd into them.

title: U.N. ENVOY PUSHES AFGHAN CEASE-FIRE
description: The United Nations mediator who negotiated the Soviet troop withdrawal from Afghanistan called today for a cease-fire and creation of a temporary new ''government of peace and reconstruction'' to replace the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul by Sept. 1.

title: Dukakis Discounts Jackson as Threat
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today scoffed at signals that the Rev. Jesse Jackson might make trouble at the Democratic National Convention if the Vice-Presidential choice and platform were not to his liking.

description: Q. The ceiling in our upstairs bathroom develops ugly black stains that look like mold. We keep repainting, but the stains return. Is there a special kind of paint we can use?

description: The first New York International Festival of the Arts - a monthlong array of some 350 events - closes tomorrow. To assess the artistic accomplishments of the event, the Arts and Leisure section asked a cross-section of Times critics to evaluate both the individual performances they attended and the quality of the festival as a whole.

title: POSTINGS: Ossining Town Houses; Racing for A Discount
description: Sales were slow at Liberty Knoll, and Kathy Americo's thoughts turned to a fast race. With 70 town houses completed of her 82-unit project in Ossining, N.Y., 23 were still unsold. The last homes will be completed by the end of the year and Mrs. Americo and her husband, Salvatore, were anxious to start on a new project, 34 town houses on Lake Saratoga in upstate New York. ''Knowing that I've got to get out of Ossining and up to Saratoga,'' she said, ''we needed a vehicle to do it.'' The vehicle of choice: the bike, about 300 in a race, actually.

THE VIEW FROM THE SLATER MUSEUM;
Replicas of Greatness Teach and Delight
description: LEAD: ART students at Norwich Free Academy become so accustomed to sketching the forms created by such sculptors, Michelangelo, Verrocchio and Donatello, they don't always realize the extent of their high school's treasure trove until they go to college.

title: A Film Adaptation Of Waugh Tests the Limits Of Moving Books To the Screen
description: Evelyn Waugh's novel ''A Handful of Dust'' is the work of a man who had been deeply wounded by the failure of his first marriage: lurking at the heart of it are a cry of pain and an act of revenge. It is true that by the time Waugh's feelings reached the printed page, they had been transmuted into comedy - he was far too much of an artist to serve them up raw. But the comedy has a bitter flavor, and the underlying sense of horror surpasses anything else in his fiction.

title: POSTINGS: On Ancestral Property; 49 Homes for Putnam
description: Harold Salmon's ancestors were ''sooners'' long before anyone heard of Oklahoma and Conestoga wagons. When land now in eastern Putman County was opened to settlers in 1731 after being trapped for years in a border dispute between New York and Connecticut, the Salmon family established a 200-acre dairy farm.

description: In his June 12 essay, David W. Bates accused the Connecticut Community Colleges of not serving the poor and of being ''one of the most decrepit community college systems imaginable.'' (''The Demise of Idealism: Community College,'' Opinion page.) Mr. Bates's erroneous impressions have no basis in fact.

title: Victoria Rockefeller Is Wed
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., Victoria Stillman Rockefeller, a daughter of Mrs. John P. Fisher of Toronto and Andrew C. Rockefeller of Greenwich, was married yesterday to Peter Sandys Philip, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Van Ness Philip of Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. John W. Bishop, the rector, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Thomas P. Gariepy, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Club Must Admit Woman
description: A gun club must pay a woman $100 in damages for denying her membership application in 1980 and admit her, the Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled Tuesday. The Concord Rod and Gun Club Inc. had appealed a Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination order, affirmed by a lower court, that the woman, Donna Page, was unconstitutionally excluded from the all-male club. The club argued that it was not ''public'' under the definition of state anti-discrimination laws. The court noted that all of the 52 male applicants in 1980 and 1981 had been accepted.

title: Is the Year's Best Film on TV?
description: Philip E. Marlow, 10, sits high in a tree in the Forest of Dean, which, with its abundant, heavy foliage, looks as if it might once have sheltered Robin Hood, Will Scarlet, Friar Tuck and the others. The Forest of Dean is, instead, a kind of seed covering for West Gloucestershire's sooty, barren coal-mining villages, where lives are as bleak as the forest is rich.

title: DATA BANK: July 10, 1988

MUSIC;
'Butterfly' to Open Summer Opera Series
description: LEAD: THE Metro Lyric Opera will open its summer season on Saturday night at 8:15 with a performance of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' at the Paramount Theater for the Performing Arts.

title: Laura Austin, Actress, Weds Scott Allyn, Medical Student
description: Laura Etnier Austin, the daughter of David Etnier Austin of Southport, Conn., and the late Mary Munro Austin, was married yesterday to William Scott Allyn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Finch Allyn of Skaneateles, N.Y. The Rev. Earl Eastman, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford. He was assisted by the Rev. Edward Putnam, an Episcopal priest.

title: The Battle of the Books
description: James Atlas's article stresses canon revision as reapportionment - expansion of the tradition to include writers hitherto ignored or devalued. But equally important is the reformulation of the canon from inside. For example, feminist critics and new historicists agree that Shakespeare's work cannot be treated as esthetically autonomous or historically transcendent. Shakespeare's artistic greatness is not in question, only his use as the ultimate arbiter of experience. The result is an exciting, complicated reassessment of Shakespeare that contributes to the larger project of rewriting the Renaissance. PETER ERICKSON Williamstown, Mass.

title: Look at My Billboard, Look at Me
description: America has devised many new media for advertising, including cable television, auto bumpers, skywriters at the beach and blimps at the ballpark. Of them all, the most intriguing may be the human torso, medium for message T-shirts.

title: Virginia Family a Fresh Air Favorite
description: Rather stealthily, Alice and Lloyd Trissel stretched the rules of the Fresh Air Fund this year, but they will not get in trouble. In fact, they will probably do it again next year, and no one will say a word.

title: People's Court
description: When Joan B. Lefkowitz spent her lunch hour visiting the ShopRite Supermarket in Yonkers last month, she confronted issues a lot more serious than peanut butter.

description: ''I WENT in amused and intrigued,'' said Summerfare's artistic director, Christopher Hunt. ''I came out completely overwhelmed. I knew then that I had to bring it to Summerfare. I have rarely felt so completely sure that we must do something.''

title: STREETSCAPES: Gainsborough Studios; The Restoration of an 1881 Co-op
description: TRADITIONALLY, contractors and vendors are wary in responding to initial inquiries from co-op boards, who represent shareholders wanting to keep costs down. But an object lesson that confounds this truism is now nearing completion at the art-encrusted Gainsborough Studios at 222 Central Park South.

title: Incident at Illinois Reactor Prompts Inquiry on Dangers
description: A huge oscillation in the speed of a nuclear reaction at an atomic power plant in Illinois has prompted an inquiry into whether a whole class of nuclear plants are vulnerable to a dangerous condition that engineers had predicted was impossible.

Patrick Mooney performed the ceremony.

description: Ellis Burks's tie-breaking, bases-loaded single keyed a six-run 10th inning as the Boston Red Sox beat the Chicago White Sox, 8-2, tonight to gain a doubleheader split.

description: A $150 million golf course community, the New England Country Club, is under construction in this small, almost rural town an hour south of Boston.

title: The Battle of the Books
description: I can't help but think of one of those ''Great Books'' men, John Stuart Mill, who wrote a seminal defense of women's rights cherished by generations of feminists, and who once shrewdly noted that all parties in a dispute tend to be correct in what they affirm and wrong in what they deny. Isn't this true of the present conflict?

title: Branching Out by Giving New Kinds of Advice
description: AS American corporations try to get back to their ''core businesses,'' the consulting firms that advise them on how to slim down are diversifying.

title: Lori B. Miller, an Editor, Marries Daniel Jay Kase
description: The marriage of Lori Beth Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Miller of Manhasset, L.I., to Daniel Jay Kase, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Kase of Woodbury, L.I., took place last evening at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Daniel Fogel officiated.

title: Poland: From Independence to Communism
description: George Bernard Shaw once claimed that there were three tragic nations: the Jews, the Irish and the Poles. Of these it is the Poles whose history, passions and culture are least known by other nations. For a thousand years they have straddled a civilizational fault line where the influence of Rome gives way to Byzantium. As their once-glorious past receded and their state even disappeared for more than a century, they came to sustain themselves with elusive yearnings of salvation, heroic poetry and a pervasive sense of tragedy. The romantic pursuit of honor, the avoidance of shame, shaped an idiosyncratic culture where what mattered most was not winning, which was usually impossible anyway, but looking good and feeling righteous.

title: Arena Is Opened
description: With the snip of a ribbon, the Miami Arena, home to fledgling National Basketball Association team the Miami Heat, officially opened Friday.

title: Reviews/Music; Soviet Violinist's U.S. Debut
description: With grim determination, Dmitri Berlinsky dug into the strings from the very first notes of the Ysaye violin sonata that opened his recital at Weill Concert Hall on Thursday evening, and he hardly eased up before the concert was through. What else could a listener expect? The young Soviet musician won first prize in the Paganini Competition three years ago at the age of 16. Two seasons back he placed fourth in the Tchaikovsky contest, and last year he got another first in Montreal. Mr. Berlinsky was making his United States debut with Thursday's performance, one in the series of recitals by major competition winners sponsored by the First New York International Festival of the Arts.

title:
TV VIEW;
The Confessions of a C-Span Addict

title: Whose Good Deed?

title: TRANSIT NOTES
description: LEAD: THE roar and odor of diesel engines, long a fixture on N. J. Transit's North Jersey Coast Line, have been replaced by the relative quiet of electric locomotives, and the transformation heralds a significant improvement in the quality of service to rail commuters.

title: Between the Raindrops: An Unexpected Adventure
description: IT was threatening to rain that morning when I decided to walk into Hartsdale to go to the bank and the hardware store. I probably should have carried an umbrella, but I was feeling optimistic and decided that I would surely get back before the rain came.

title: Singapore's 'Goalkeeper' Fends Off Democracy
description: ''MY colleagues and I are well versed in theory and also in practice and we know what can work and what cannot,'' said Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, the man who almost singlehandedly has made Singapore a showcase of third-world development. What Mr. Lee believes cannot work for his small, ethnically divided country is an American-style democracy, though his critics, some of whom are in jail, disagree.

title: Sandinistas Ban March by Opposition in Managua
description: With political tension growing in Nicaragua, the Sandinista Government has refused to grant permission for a protest march organized by anti-Sandinista trade unions and supported by opposition political parties.

title: 6 Fight Their Way To Olympic Boxoffs
description: Six fighters took the first step on the road to Seoul today as they won Olympic Trials titles. Step two comes next weekend in Las Vegas, Nev., where the team will be selected for step three, the Summer Games that begin in South Korea Sept. 17.

title: Treated Wood Debated
description: LEAD: FOR more than a year, the Town of East Hampton has banned the use of chemically treated wood in the construction of docks and homes on water for environmental reasons, but a change may be under way.

title: Burmese Curfew Is Lifted
description: The authorities today lifted a dusk-to-dawn curfew imposed in Rangoon after thousands of students rioted in the streets June 21, the state radio said. A ban on public gatherings also was lifted, the broadcast said. According to the Government, six policemen and three civilians were killed in the rioting.

title: As Classroom Empties, Teacher Takes Stock
description: ''BYE, Mrs. Fisk have a nice summer.'' The lazy, hazy summer hasn't started yet, but my sophomores are busy taking exams, and I'm running back and forth to the bookroom returning American lit texts and counting ripped covers. It's that wonderful quiet time between the end of the school year and the beginning of vacation and it's a time of taking inventory both literally and figuratively.

title: Couple Hired as Sitters Held in Child's Death

title: Question Of the Week; The Draft: How Did the Knicks and Nets Do?
description: The Knicks were right to pass on Shelton Jones. He has outstanding athletic ability, but only an average, at best, outside shot.

Europeds, the creation of Peter Boynton, a Californian, offers an extensive range of cycyling and hiking tours, with an emphasis on cycling tours in the French countryside.

The movement to widen the academic canon is not just an effort by junior faculty ''to define themselves and to validate their own identities.'' It is also an attempt by students to establish a curriculum which reflects the variety of cultures in the nation and world we live in.

description: ''The Taurus: Big Sales, Big Repairs'' (June 19) prompted an unusually large response from readers. Below are some of their comments.

title: Correction
description: A chart last week about water consumption gave incorrect figures for fresh-water use in the United States. Daily residential use was 25.4 billion gallons in 1980 and 28.4 billion gallons in 1985. Daily industrial and commercial use was 51 billion gallons in 1980 and 37.9 billion gallons in 1985.

title: Glancing Back to '42 On Gentle Guadalcanal
description: THE name Guadalcanal generates feelings that still stir the American soul. Here, in 1942, United States marines were very nearly abandoned on a toehold of beach and jungle. Then, after six months of grisly fighting, they brought the Japanese onslaught to deadly and permanent halt. The story of that fighting, at places with names engraved in the American memory - Red Beach and the Tenaru River, Matanikau, Lunga Point and Bloody Ridge overlooking Henderson Field - was written by a correspondent who slogged the ridge and jungle with men of the First Marine Division. Beanpole tall with a Cornish name, Richard Tregaskis, my late husband, told the bloody tale of courage in a book entitled ''Guadalcanal Diary.''

title: Practical Traveler; Dear Tourist Bureau: Can You Help Plan a Trip?
description: IF you want free maps and information from a state travel bureau in the busy season, do not wait until the last week before vacation to ask. To find out how long it took for a response to such a request, identical letters were sent to 50 state travel organizations and the District of Columbia asking for a map, a schedule of events and sources of further information. The letters, which used a private name and return address in New York City, were mailed on May 24. By June 23, 29 places had been heard from. No inquiry was returned because of an incorrect address.

IN SHORT;
FICTION

description: LEAD: THE purple coneflower (Echinacea purpurea) is a handsome, hardy native perennial that serves many gardeners' needs. It blooms from now until frost and is at much at home in the border as in a wildflower or meadow garden.

description: HUDDLED with an elderly companion in the cluttered corner of a spacious but otherwise empty hospital room, Vanessa Salaam exuded at once reticence and strength.

title: FICTION
description: PEOPLE LIKE US. By Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) Plunging into this densely populated roman a clef by the author of ''The Two Mrs. Grenvilles'' is like coming late to a cocktail party where the socially prominent guests are already in full cry. Although the faces are familiar, there are too many to sort out; at first it's hard to catch the tune, but give it time. All those conversations add up. Threnodies about the right restaurant, decorator, broker, about what's chic and what's not, create an anthropologically fascinating picture of Manhattan's high society in the 1980's. The dialogue is funny and dead-on target, as Dominick Dunne makes it clear that Americans are not as democratic as they pretend. Instructing the millionaire social climber Elias Renthal, Lord Biedermeier details ''the little signals by which people like us recognize each other.'' While her socially accepted but ambivalent friend Gus Bailey plans murder, the attentive arriviste Ruby Renthal hones her accent and plans the ultimate society ball. Meanwhile, Justine Altemus marries beneath her, prompting the self-protective savagery of her mother, Lil, who is also busy ignoring the fact that Justine's brother is dying of AIDS. Events build to the night of the ball, one of the best and funniest social events of the literary decade. Investigated by the S.E.C., Elias has the illusion that he will be protected just because he's been admitted to Manhattan's most exclusive club. (''People like that,'' he says, ''are not about to let anything happen to me.'') But he fails to understand that he's mistaken his position. Engaging us in his characters' concerns and then pulling multiple story strands into a tight knot, Dominick Dunne demonstrates with wit and accuracy the delicate, merciless distinction between ''people like that'' and ''people like us.''

title: Truffaut Would Understand
description: It is true, at least in this one respect, that the movies are like life: beautiful women are all over the place. Beyond that - for me, anyway - the two media begin to diverge, each with its own inevitable vexations, though in the movies women are not among them. After all, they exist in two dimensions only, and that really uncomplicates everything. So at the movies I fall in love a lot, sometimes two or three times in a couple of hours (depending on the cast), which in the world would be a problem.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

title: Romance Blooms in the Park
description: When The Royal Shakespeare company brought ''Much Ado About Nothing'' to New York four years ago, the elegant British production stressed the brittle hauteur of Shakespeare's recalcitrant lovers, Benedick and Beatrice, who were played by Derek Jacobi and Sinead Cusack. In the battle of wits between the self-proclaimed eternal bachelor and the aggressively independent lady whose surface disdain masks a suspicious preoccupation with her nemesis, the emphasis was on the intellectual fireworks generated by two formidably matched antagonists rather than on the concealed passion underlying their skirmishes.

description: Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the nation's largest union, died last night at a hospital in the Cleveland suburb of Lakewood. He was 61 years old and had been suffering from brain cancer.

description: SHERWOOD ANDERSON By Kim Townsend. Illustrated. 370 pp. Boston: A Richard Todd Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.95. THE TRIUMPH OF THE EGG By Sherwood Anderson. Illustrated. 300 pp. New York: Four Walls Eight Windows. Paper, $8.95.

description: The Soviet Union has just launched another spectacular space probe to Mars, with two vehicles to land on the Martian moon Phobos. Roald Sagdeyev, director of Moscow's Institute for Space Research, is proud but not happy.

title: The Battle of the Books

But how, then, can these critics explain the fact that those who have read these books most assiduously became radical feminists and neo-Marxists? To find people who have the most conservative political views about economics, race and gender, we have to look at such groups as businessmen, factory workers and farmers, who are the least likely to have read these classics. LAWRENCE W. HYMAN Ridgewood, N.J.
