title: Headliners; Asking Questions
description: Washington is putting the pressure on to keep Mohammed Ali Hamadei from getting off. Mr. Hamadei went on trial last week in West Germany on charges of hijacking an American jet in 1985 and killing Robert Dean Stethem, a United States Navy diver who was on the plane. Present in the courtroom as co-plaintiffs were members of Mr. Stethem's family and six American servicemen. Under West German law, co-plaintiffs in effect represent the victim and may question the witnesses and appeal the judgment. Washington urged the Americans to attend the trial and retained an attorney to represent them. Some United States officials fear that Mr. Hamadei will be treated lightly by the West German court and possibly freed in exchange for a West German businessman who was taken hostage in Beirut shortly after Mr. Hamadei was arrested in 1987.

It's chiffon, cascades of the stuff, which has been flowing out of designer studios and onto some of the most elegant women around. Cast your eyes in the direction of Georgette Mosbacher (right), in an ombre-colored dress that Arnold Scaasi has masterfully draped and tucked. Judging by the style of her navy chiffon, Nan Kempner (upper right) prefers more classic lines, as does Barbara Walters (bottom right). She was recently seen in a blue-and-white design that resembled a Grecian draped dress. Not surprisingly, many chiffoneers are displaying a fondness for summery pastel colors, which make them look cool and filmy on stifling evenings. But whatever the color, these cotton-candy dresses provide a welcome respite from the very grand, and stiff, formal styles of the past decade.

title: NONFICTION
description: PERRY ELLIS. By Jonathan Moor. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $17.95.) ''Never enough!'' was a favorite maxim of Perry Ellis's, according to Jonathan Moor, whose prosaic biography of the talented sportswear designer begins by describing the memorial service that followed Ellis's death from AIDS two years ago at the age of 46. The adage can also apply to the author, who never provides enough fresh information and insights to create a satisfying portrait of his subject. He focuses instead on Ellis's business, which grew from an inexpensive sportswear line into a multimillion-dollar fashion empire. Ellis majored in business in college and had a master's degree in retailing. He never studied design and relied on his staff to translate his ideas into cloth. He was skilled, however, in dealing with the press, going so far, Mr. Moor says, as to bestow ''whole collections of clothes for a particular season, lavish foreign vacations, or even monetary 'consulting' fees'' upon ''certain key editors.'' The author, who has written for GQ and Vogue, offers few glimpses into the personal life of the genteel, Virginia-born designer. He explains why Ellis fathered a child while living with his longtime companion, Laughlin Barker, by saying, ''Perry was more attracted to men (though he would always be drawn to women and most likely wanted to lead a 'normal' life).'' How a complex, gifted, intensely private man from a well-to-do Southern family became a Seventh Avenue superstar is a fascinating story. Unfortunately, Mr. Moor never tells it.

title: NONFICTION
description: HEARTS OF LIONS: The History of American Bicycle Racing. By Peter Nye. (Norton, $19.95.) Peter Nye has written a sumptuously detailed account of American bicycle racing, emphasizing the early years when cycling was a big-money sport. Drawing principally on newspaper accounts, Mr. Nye chronicles the amazing feats of competitors such as Charles (Mile-a-Minute) Murphy, who in 1899 covered a mile in 57.8 seconds riding through the slipstream of a Long Island Rail Road locomotive. The prosperity that American cycling enjoyed through the 1920's began to diminish during the Depression. To this day the glory has not been recaptured, but the money has - at least for the few superstars who now command endorsements and contracts with teams in the United States and Europe. ''Hearts of Lions'' concludes appropriately with Greg LeMond's 1986 victory - the first by an American - in the Tour de France, the world's most prestigious bicycle race. (Last month Andy Hampsten became the first American to win the Tour of Italy, the second most important race.) LeMond's momentous achievement would seem deserving of more depth than Mr. Nye's summary gives it. Also, we get a feel for the riders but not enough of their riding, which in strength and strategy is the equal of any sport. Perhaps Mr. Nye, a competitor himself, takes that for granted. After his Tour de France triumph, LeMond was invited to the White House. It was an ironic gesture, given that he still is not well known in this country and competitive cycling is largely unrecognized by the press and the public. ''Hearts of Lions'' is welcome as a loving tribute to those athletes who race bicycles for a living. It shows they deserve better.

title: GAF Is Charged In Stock-Price Case
description: Indictments were issued against the GAF Corporation, its vice chairman and two of its subsidiaries on charges that they manipulated the price of Union Carbide stock in 1986 after GAF failed in an attempt to take over Carbide. Prosecutors contend that GAF and Jefferies & Company, a Los Angeles brokerage, agreed for Jefferies to buy large blocks of Carbide stock to inflate the price so that GAF could get a higher return from selling its 10 percent stake in Carbide. Boyd L. Jefferies, the head of Jefferies, has pleaded guilty to two felony counts, after being implicated in illegal activities by Ivan F. Boesky, who is now in prison. GAF is the first company to face charges arising from the Boesky investigation. GAF denied the charges and its attorney expressed confidence that the company and its vice chairman, James T. Sherwin, would be acquitted.

WORLD'S END, by T. Coraghessan Boyle. (Penguin, $8.95.) In his earlier books of fiction (including ''Greasy Lake'' and ''Descent of Man''), T. Coraghessan Boyle developed a reputation for black, mocking humor. In 1987, Benjamin DeMott said here that this novel about three families in the Hudson River Valley and the ghosts that haunt them is an uplifting surprise. ''Passion, need and belief breathe with striking force and freedom,'' he wrote. ''As 'World's End' interweaves, fugally, the lives of long-gone peasants, slaves, landholders and displaced Indians with those of last season's activists, wantons, rentiers and factory hands, we're conscious of recurrences and echoes'' of history. SMALL SACRIFICES: A True Story of Passion and Murder, by Ann Rule. (Signet/New American Library, $4.95.) The police were dubious when a 27-year-old mother showed up at a hospital in Springfield, Ore., in 1983 with her three wounded children and a story about a ''bushy haired stranger'' who had waved down her car. Last year, Ann Jones said here that this true-crime book is ''a page-turner, despite some shopworn characters and weary prose borrowed from cop fiction.'' SLOW HOMECOMING, by Peter Handke. Translated by Ralph Manheim. (Collier/Macmillan, $8.95.) The Austrian novelist Peter Handke is known for his fictional meditations on the uneasy relationship between language and reality. These three interrelated stories are ''the work of a totally serious major artist,'' Malcolm Bradbury said here in 1985. ''He believes in writing as an artistic and philosophical inquiry, a search into forms.'' UNDERSTANDING TOSCANINI: How He Became an American Culture-God and Helped Create a New Audience for Old Music, by Joseph Horowitz. (University of Minnesota, $12.95.) The cult of Toscanini has had a stultifying effect on American culture, Joseph Horowitz believes, leading to the mass-marketing and packaging of classical music. Last year, our reviewer, Edward W. Said, insisted that the conductor's greatness defied too schematic an analysis but said that the author's ''considerable labors to illuminate aspects of Toscanini's effect on American society are impressive.'' QUEST, by Richard Ben Sapir. (Onyx/New American Library, $4.50.) When a mysterious jewel-encrusted object shows up on the Manhattan art market, the quest for the Holy Grail begins anew. ''It took imagination backed by a great deal of solid research to put this melange together,'' Newgate Callendar said here last year. THE LIFE IT BRINGS: One Physicist's Beginnings, by Jeremy Bernstein. (Penguin, $7.95.) When this account of how the science writer Jeremy Bernstein decided to become a physicist was published last year, our reviewer, David G. Stork, said it was written ''with clarity, grace and a personal candor rare in scientific autobiographies. We feel the presence of an honest mind.'' REQUIEM FOR A DREAM, by Hubert Selby Jr. (Thunder's Mouth Press, $9.95.) For Harry Goldfarb and Tyrone C. Love, the American dream is saving enough money to buy a pound of pure heroin; Harry's mother, Sara, hopes to make her killing as a contestant on a television game show. This novel by the author of ''Last Exit to Brooklyn'' is ''extreme and often silly,'' Jerome Charyn said here in 1978, ''but it has its own magic turmoil and mad power.'' THE LEGACY OF CONQUEST: The Unbroken Past of the American West, by Patricia Nelson Limerick. (Norton, $9.95.) The American West of today is not fundamentally different from the way it was in the 19th century, the author argues. Last year, Annette Kolodny said here that the book ''offers an eminently readable historical overview, punctuated by anecdotes in which the present and the past repeatedly intertwine.'' A SIGN OF THE EIGHTIES, by Gail Parent. (Jove, $4.50.) Shelly Silver, a prosperous New York City caterer, plots to get Mickey Burke, a television writer, to marry her, but he's more interested in his secretary, Astra Rainbow Blakely. ''In this bittersweet comic novel, Gail Parent displays her knack for transforming social trends into fiction,'' Diane Cole said here in 1987. ON GLORY ROADS: A Pilgrim's Book About Pilgrimage, by Eleanor Munro. (Thames and Hudson, $10.95.) Setting out to re-enact the pilgrimages in which Hindus, Buddhists, Jews and Christians celebrate the holy islands of our material world, Eleanor Munro asks, ''Reader, will you follow me, now, as I read the scriptures by my own candle?'' ''Anyone opening this unusual book, which throws such a learned and enchanting light, will reply, why not?'' our reviewer, Ronald Blythe, replied last year. GONE TO SOLDIERS, by Marge Piercy. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Marge Piercy's best-selling novel about World War II concentrates on civilians, some of whom worked for the French underground. ''The battlefront is not all blood and guts,'' Hilma Wolitzer said here last year. ''There is also the grief of separation from family and the mitigating solace of friendship.''

title: In the Heat Of Summer, Senate Race Hits a Lull
description: FOR United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican, and his Democratic challenger, the state Attorney General, Joseph I. Lieberman, these early days of summer on the campaign trail are not filled with high political drama and heavy media exposure.

title: Sandy Sevier Simmons Marries G. P. Leonard
description: Sandy Sevier Simmons, a second vice president in real-estate finance at Chase Manhattan Bank, and Geoffrey Porter Leonard, an associate in the Manhattan law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, were married yesterday in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Franklin E. Vilas Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Wainright House.

title: Reviews/Music; Schwantner Premiere By Slatkin and Ax
description: Joseph Schwantner is one of the more prolific and more successful of the middle generation of American composers. Now in his mid-40's, he can count the Pulitzer Prize among his many honors, and requests for new works come his way with understandable frequency. His Piano Concerto, which had its world premiere on Friday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, was commissioned by the First International Festival of the Arts (with support from Chase Manhattan Bank) for Emanuel Ax and the Saint Louis Symphony.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: RIVERSIDE DRIVE. By Laura Van Wormer. (Doubleday, $18.95.) What the television program ''thirtysomething'' is to ''Dynasty,'' ''Riverside Drive'' is to the usual novel about frenzied, cynical Manhattanites. No lowlifes or high fliers here. Instead, 8 of the 10 main characters are decent, compassionate, patient and even self-sacrificing.

title: POSTINGS: Developing a Farm; Sweet Smell Of Success
description: Tice Farms (established 1808) is an aromatic survivor. Among the first family farms in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., Tice's apple orchard and roadside fruit-and-vegetable stand still set the standard. The large barn-like stand on Chestnut Ridge Road is a mini-mall of produce and trinkets. The northern Bergen County farm stayed intact as it was surrounded by wealthy suburbs such as Saddle River and Montvale, skirted by the Garden State Parkway and squeezed by office buildings along its fences.

title: Region's Flood of Federal Taxes Trickle Back
description: New Yorkers paid $14.5 billion more in taxes to the Federal Government last year than they got back in aid and programs from Washington, according to a report issued this week by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: 4 Black Companies Among Top 100
description: FOUR Connecticut companies have been ranked among the top black-owned businesses in the nation for 1988.

title: French Left's Wooing of Center Is Dealt 2 Setbacks
description: Prime Minister Michel Rocard's efforts to open up his Socialist Government to the political center faltered this week as a result of two highly embarrassing clashes with new Cabinet ministers.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
AND A BROKEN HEART FOR EVERY LIGHT
description: LEAD: The utilitarian Commissioners' Plan of 1811, which branded Manhattan with a rigid geometry of streets and avenues, is considered by many to be the city's most significant developmental milestone. But another decision may have been the more important: not to allow the purity of the imposed grid to erase the earlier footprint of a meandering Broadway, despite the irregular, ungainly, but ever-memorable (and oxymoronic) triangular squares that would one day brilliantly punctuate the grid's monotonous regularity - a kind of landmarks preservation before there were many landmarks.

title: SASSY SPANIARDS
description: Pedro del Hierro, Nacho Ruiz, Adolfo Dominguez - their names don't slide off the tongue as easily as, say, Armani or Calvin Klein. But they are some of Spain's new fashion-makers, an expanding constellation of designers who showed their collections for fall l988 in Barcelona and Madrid earlier this year. It is too soon to say which of them will emerge as world-class talents, but it seems safe to predict that a few, at least, will have an impact reaching well beyond their borders. Some, including Sybilla, who also shows in Milan, have made the breakthrough already. Her sculptural designs have been showcased by influential Manhattan stores, and her success may have helped to pave the way for others. Working in disparate styles, designers like Dominguez and del Hierro show dramatic clothes that flamboyantly allude to their country's cultural heritage. Goya-esque beauties in lace and velvet and gypsies in swirling skirts are some of the models for their looks. Others, like Trafico de Modas, espouse a more understated style. But even they occasionally offer the sort of hot, sassy looks that have helped to make Spain a stop on the international fashion circuit.

title: O'Neill House's Journey Into Blight
description: Eugene O'Neill, were he alive today, probably wouldn't be surprised that a few property-owners here want to demolish the quaint waterfront boarding house where he once lived and replace it with something likely to be a little less artful. A dockominium, perhaps.

title: Drought Calls for More Than Rain
description: AS one of the century's most severe droughts clung last week to the nation's farm belt, agriculture policy experts in Washington were coming to grips with unaccustomed choices about the nation's food supply. Since the spring's dry weather evolved into the worst drought since the Dust Bowl, the farm policy has been turned upside down.

title: A Miscellany of Figures in American Art at Silvermine
description: THE display at the Silvermine GGallery in Stamford, ''The Figure in American Art Since Mid-Century'' is open to interpretation. It is a large miscellany of paintings, prints, photographs and sculpture that can be taken as the illustration of its curator, Andrew Stasik's view, that for all the changes in the last 40 years, American art has essentially remained true to the human figure.

title: Michele Horowitz to Wed
description: The engagement of Michele Elyse Horowitz and Seth Eli Adler has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Horowitz of Forest Hills, Queens. Mr. Adler is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan L. Adler of West Brighton, S.I. The future bride, who is an assistant in the facilities-planning department of the Hearst Corporation in New York, graduated from Boston University. Mr. Adler, a computer analyst with Thomson McKinnon Securities in New York, graduated from Baruch College of the City University of New York.

title: Spanish Land-Grant System Left Its Mark on the Philippines
description: To the Editor:

title: David Atlee Phillips Dead at 65; Ex-Agent Was Advocate of C.I.A.
description: David Atlee Phillips, who spent 25 years undercover for the C.I.A. and resigned as chief of Latin American and Caribbean operations to plead the agency's case in print and on the lecture circuit, died Thursday at his home in Bethesda, Md. Mr. Phillips, who had been suffering from cancer, was 65 years old.

title: Yugoslavian Recruits
description: The University of South Carolina basketball coach, George Felton, has gone out of the country to recruit basketball players for the first time, announcing the signing of Brad Ignajatovic, a 6-foot-10-inch center and Bojan Popovic, a 6-2 guard. Both played for the Yugoslavian National Team, which won the gold medal in the World Cup Games last summer. Neither player scored more than 700 on the Scholastic Aptitute Test, part of the N.C.A.A. admission requirements. That means that neither can play on the varsity team as a freshman.(AP)

title: For Commuters, Timing Is Everything
description: ISN'T it nice having a few extra minutes to catch your train in the morning? Not a good question to ask a commuter. How could I possibly have a few extra minutes? You see. . . .

title: Pamela Freeman Planning to Wed Next September
description: The engagement of Pamela Eggert Freeman to William Hurff Christensen has been announced by Mrs. William R. Benner of Bloomfield and Fenwick, Conn., and Frederic William Freeman 5th of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Christensen of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Cutchogue, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ceiling in our upstairs bathroom develops ugly black stains that look like mold. We keep repainting, but the stains return. Is there a special kind of paint we can use?

title: U.S. Falling Short on Its Infant Health Goals
description: Most of a set of health goals the Government set in 1979 for babies and pregnant women, including a reduction in infant mortality, will not be met by the 1990 target date, Federal health officials say.

title:
GARDENING;
The Hemlock and a New Pest
description: LEAD: THE Canadian hemlock is among the most useful evergreens in the Northeast. The species itself is a graceful, fine-textured tree. When sheared, it is among the most useful plants for hedging and screen plantings. Such forms as Sargent's Weeping and Cole's Prostrate are among the most attractive of the dwarf conifers for specimen and rock garden planting.

title: Pregnant Women Increasingly Fearful of VDT's
description: Women around the country who work on video display terminals are increasingly expressing concern that their jobs may pose a threat to their ability to bear healthy babies.

title: POLITICS AS SITCOM GRIST? PAUL EDDINGTON VOTES 'YEA'
description: When the BBC first showed him the script for a new sitcom, in which he was supposed to play an inept government minister perpetually being manipulated by the canny bureaucrat who runs his department, Paul Eddington was not particularly impressed. He didn't think it would be remotely as popular as ''The Good Life,'' the television series in which he'd made his name and helped win a British audience of 24 million.

title: Welfare Reform Shouldn't Punish the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Fairness to William Buckley
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; The Draft: How Did the Knicks and Nets Do?
description: The Knicks desperately needed to fill three positions: power forward, shooting forward and backup point guard for Mark Jackson. The trade for Charles Oakley, combined with the selection of Rod Strickland, provides two of those elements.

title: CHINA'S ECONOMY GROWS AND SO DOES CORRUPTION
description: About a month ago, a doctor from the Office of Disease Inspection here visited the Huayuan Jellied Bean Curd Restaurant, wandered about and declared that the proprietor would have to pay a fine for unsanitary conditions.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE OTHER GARDEN. By Francis Wyndham. (Moyer Bell, $12.95.) In 1987 ''The Other Garden'' by Francis Wyndham won England's Whitbread Prize for the best first novel of the year. It is not difficult to see why. In just 106 pages, Mr. Wyndham conjures a lost world in the kind of prose that is almost a lost art.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The State Rent Agency; Paperwork Engulfs Housing Management
description: THERE is a doughty candor about the state's new rent commissioner, Elliot G. Sander. In February, he took over the much-criticized Office of Rent Administration, which has been struggling for four years to get on top of the job of administering the city's rent-stabilization code.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Rosebank
description: LEAD: FOR more than 60 years, Montalbano's, an Italian deli, stood at the corner of Clifton Avenue and Bay Street, epitomizing the stability of Rosebank, a blue-collar, mostly Italian neighborhood that hugs the northeastern shore of Staten Island.

title: THE FRENCH REVOLUTION: RIGHT OR WRONG?
description: History has never been easy for the French. It has, for them, probably more than for any other European people, produced a mix of exultation and anguish. Ninety-nine years ago, the French celebrated the 100th anniversary of the beginning of their great Revolution of 1789, and, by a rather extraordinary coincidence, they did so only a couple of years after inaugurating for the first time a permanently republican form of government, finishing a century-long alternation between monarchy and anarchy. The moment was full of exultation. Hope and confidence in the future prevailed. The principles of 1789, the rights of man and citizen and the concept of constitutional law, seemed finally to have been embodied in government. An Exposition Universelle was held, attracting more than 25 million paying entrants, whose centerpiece was Gustave Eiffel's extraordinary tower, in itself an awesome symbol of the belief in the perfectibility of man through reason, science and democracy.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Vivid Glimpses of the Panoply of Life Long Ago
description: LEAD: Listening to early music can be a disquietingly modern experience. From Gregorian chant through the 14th-century motet, medieval music relates in uncanny ways to contemporary music, especially Minimalism. Early music remains unconcerned with subsequent Western notions of directionality; rather than building toward a climax, or featuring bold contrasts of material, a medieval work favors an almost meditative use of stasis.

title: The Exhibition as Art Form and Blood Sport
description: Less than two weeks ago, the several institutions housed within the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris launched a multidisciplinary examination of the explosion of art, culture and commerce that followed World War II. From now until Oct. 17, when this effort draws to a close, the Pompidou is once more the scene of the kind of multimedia extravaganza for which it is best known. On the schedule is a variety of concerts, screenings, symposia and lectures devoted to the film, music, literature and philosophy that came into being in the 1950's, especially in Paris. In addition, there are four exhibitions and at least two of these - one dealing with architecture and design, the other with visual arts - seem destined to generate a healthy amount of controversy.

A Vietnam veteran turned detective checks out dubious entrepreneurs. 3 7 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is held captive. 4 1 WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Dell, $4.95.) Love and murder at a swank California health spa. 5 3 HEIRESS, by Janet Dailey. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Performing a la Mozart - Whatever That Means
description: New York City enjoys the privilege each summer of reflecting afresh on Mozart. The possibility of such reflection is omnipresent, but the annual Mostly Mozart Festival - which opens Tuesday with a concert including Frederica von Stade and Vladimir Feltsman - gives it a focus and almost always, somewhere in the program, a specific stimulus.

title: Power Failure Delays Trains at Penn Station
description: A power failure in the East River tunnel leading to Pennsylvania Station brought Long Island Rail Road service to a halt for over an hour yesterday and delayed service for several hours in the late afternoon.

title: BUKHARIN'S STATUS IN PARTY RESTORED
description: A Communist Party commission reviewing the repressions under Stalin announced today that Nikolai I. Bukharin, among the most prominent victims of Stalin's terror, was posthumously reinstated as a member of the party on June 21.

title: NEW WARS, NEW WAYS OF FIGHTING
description: TWENTIETH-CENTURY WARRIORS The Development of the Armed Forces of the Major Military Nations in the Twentieth Century. By Field Marshal Lord Carver. Maps. 468 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $24.95.

title: DOUBTS SURROUND IRAN-CONTRA CASE
description: A Federal district judge's order giving Oliver L. North broader access to secret Government documents for his defense strongly raises the possibility that he will not be tried on the main charges in the Iran-contra case.

title: Present at Stereo's Birth
description: This year is replete with audio anniversaries. The centennial of the phonograph record, as distinct from Edison's cylinder, was celebrated in May. This fall will see the fifth birthday of digital disks, and right about now - as far as anyone can fix the date - is the 30th birthday of stereo.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Windsor, Vt.; GOODYEAR SITE BOUNCES BACK
description: Richard Becken had worked 14 years as an engineer at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company plant in this southeast Vermont community of 4,000 residents when the company, which employed 300 people at a time, pulled out in April 1987. Now, one year later, Mr. Becken is back at the plant in a business of his own.

title:
GARDENING;
New Colors And Forms For Day Lilies
description: LEAD: IN the world of day lilies, there is always something new under the sun. These popular perennials are among the easiest garden flowers to hybridize, and the urge to create new flowers has gripped many growers, both amateur and professional. At last count, there were 29,960 nationally registered cultivars.

title: Correction
description: An article on June 26 about plans to build a new theater in Stamford incorrectly described the status of a closed theater on the property. The theater, at 307 Atlantic Street, has been partly torn down. The front entrance, lobby and backstage were demolished; the back of the building, including the main stage and auditorium, is still standing.

title: Israelis Raise West Bank Arabs' Hospital Fees
description: The Israeli military authorities have ordered increased fees for Government hospitals in the West Bank, prompting Palestinian doctors to assert that the move was linked to the uprising.

title: One Hurt in Amtrak Accident
description: One car of an Amtrak train derailed near here early today, injuring a passenger and delaying the Miami-to-New York run by about four hours, a spokesman for the railroad said. The accident occurred when an axle broke, the official said. The passenger's injuries were not believed to be serious, the spokesman said.

title: Nancy Rosenberg to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Steven Bruce Rosenberg of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Beth Rosenberg, to Marc Richard Tannenbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Tannenbaum of Jericho, L.I. Miss Rosenberg is the manager of an Ann Taylor store in Richmond. Her fiance is a member of the class of '89 at the Medical College of Virginia. They plan to marry in September.

title: In Massachusetts, (508) From (617) Is . . , Confusion
description: New England Telephone considers the addition of a new area code in Massachusetts a positive reflection of the state's prosperity, and besides, it was unavoidable. To many of its customers, the change is a nuisance and some of them are fighting it down to the wire.

title: Homeless Protest Ruling on Aid Cutoff
description: Corrie Fowler, a 29-year-old mother of four, spends her days and nights with her children inside one room in a welfare hotel in Newark, waiting for the one hot meal a day that uses up the daily $22.50 allowance for a family of five.

title: Anderson Wins 800th - Again
description: Lou Whitaker hit a three-run homer and Darrell Evans had a bases-empty shot as the Detroit Tigers beat the Oakland Athletics, 4-3, today in a match of divisional leaders.

title: Correction
description: A review of Michael Crichton's book ''Travels'' on June 26 misattributed a novel, ''Coma.'' Robin Cook wrote it.

title: The Battle of the Books
description: Do these cultural relativists believe that outside the Western world, which was built on the ideas in the books they would cheapen and disparage, that they would be free to sit in cozy academic nests chirping their opinions? Talk about biting the hand that feeds you! JAMES R. BRIDGELAND, JR. Cincinnati

title: Along the Vecht River By Auto or Bike or Foot
description: LESS than an hour's drive south of Amsterdam is a region that seems a microcosm of the Dutch countryside. Enfolding the River Vecht in its north-south course between Vreeland and Maarssen, the region consists of centuries-old villages, expanses of flat and watery pasture land punctuated by windmills, castles and dozens of mansions built by Amsterdam merchants as weekend retreats during the 17th and 18th centuries.

title: Question Of the Week; The Draft: How Did the Knicks and Nets Do?
description: I thought that the Nets and the Knicks both made bad draft picks. The Nets should have drafted a guard, not a big man up front. Chris Morris will probably perform well, but who's going to start alongside John Bagley? They needed someone like Hersey Hawkins or Rex Chapman to pick up the slack.

title: Pop Star in London, He Returns to Roots
description: TEN years ago, Gerard Kenny flew from Sea Cliff to San Tropez to spend a season as what he called ''a one-man, four-piece band.'' This included singing and playing the piano at La Papagallo, a big nightclub there, or, as Mr. Kenny calls it, ''the Hamptons of France.''

title: Bicycle Tours
description: To the Editor: I am writing to express my delight with the feature ''Bicycle Excursions East and West'' (Travel, April 24) and my dismay that our company was omitted.

title: Decadent Precincts
description: THE SHANGHAI GESTURE Starring Walter Huston, Ona Munson, Gene Tierney and Victor Mature (in photo). Directed by Josef von Sternberg. Produced by Arnold Pressburger. Adapted from the play by John Colton. 1941. Black and white. Mystic Fire Video, P.O. Box 30969, N.Y, N.Y. 10011. 97 minutes, $59.95. Not rated

title: Corona '88: It's Schools Now, Not Homes
description: NO ONE with spirit lives in Corona anymore, said Leo Italiano, one of the ''Fighting 69.'' Otherwise, the housing development about to be built a block from his home would have been stopped.

title: Compassion Misled
description: To the Editor:

title: The Battle of the Books
description: I still remember debating the classics up on Morningside Heights in literature-humanities and contemporary civilization classes. The one thing I remember most clearly about classroom debates at Columbia is that no one (professors included) was convinced of the worthiness of every work on the reading list. Plato was regarded as something of a fascist loon. Herodotus was a notorious fabricator. Virtually every work of English, French and German philosophy written between Hobbes and Hegel was almost completely unreadable and philosophically incoherent.

title: In Chile, a Growing 'No' Vote to Pinochet Seen
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory
description: Burma Alerts: Street Clashes And Flights

title: Like A replay of Those Old Movies

title: Corrections
description: A Travel Advisory report on June 26 about an exhibition of Chinese art misstated the university affiliation of an organizer, Dr. Robert Thorp. It is Washington University, in St. Louis, not George Washington University, which is in Washington.

title: Yonkers Faces New Court Sanctions
description: THREATS of prison sentences for city officials and a loss of authority to govern in some areas loom before the city of Yonkers for the first time this week as it faces a Federal judge in Manhattan who is seeking to force compliance with a housing-desegregation order.

title:
MUSIC;
Summer Music Festival Advances

The Rev. David Hall Teschner peformed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Augustine Kenneth Graap, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: WILDLIFE ROAMS AT TRAILSIDE IN MAINE
description: OUR first encounter with a moose, a young bull, his antlers still velvety knobs, was at dusk. Twenty feet from the trail, almost lost on the sunless floor of the spruce forest, he heard us approach, looked up and went back to his shrubs.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Diego;
Servicing Maquiladoras
description: LEAD: INDUSTRIAL development is surging in southern San Diego as manufacturers take advantage of low production costs across the border in Mexico. Sanyo, Maxell and Sony are among the major companies housed in the Otay Mesa region that have companion plants, called maquiladoras, in and near Tijuana.

title: Mexican Voters Taste Pleasures of Pluralism
description: THE loud sound emanating from Mexico last week was that of a monolith shattering. After nearly 60 years of virtually unchallenged one-party rule, the Institutional Revolutionary Party was introduced to competitive politics and immediately found the results not entirely to its liking.

title: Persisting for Peace in Angola
description: Is the bell finally tolling for the long dirty war in Angola? Can it be that South Africa will pull its troops out of Angola and end its illegal rule in Namibia? Will Cuba withdraw 50,000 troops from Angola, and will Pretoria stop arming the rebel forces of Jonas Savimbi?

title: Ex-Convict Tells Students About Ethics
description: Donna Akerson, who hopes to be a V.P. or - who knows? - maybe even a C.E.O. someday, is 6 months and 18 credits away from her M.B.A. She knows all about cost accounting and operations research, and the other day, she learned all about white-collar crime.

title: Senate Votes Change in Capital's Hiring Law
description: The Senate has voted to replace a rule requiring city employees to live in the District of Columbiawith a hiring plan that gives preference to residents of the District. The measure modified earlier House action that would have killed the residency rule.

title: Rescuing Sea Animals
description: WHEN Wookie the baby seal washed up last winter on a beach north of Atlantic City, she was in bad shape. She weighed 90 pounds, was bald and suffered from three respiratory infections.

title: Triple Crown Is Business
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: INFLATION FORECASTER: Donald Ratajczak; Finding Celebrity in the C.P.I.
description: WHAT would Michael H. Mescon, dean of Georgia State College of Business Administration, do to keep Donald Ratajczak at the school? ''His windows, his laundry, anything,'' Mr. Mescon said. Over the past decade, Mr. Ratajczak, an economist, has propelled himself and Georgia State to national prominence by becoming the best forecaster of the Consumer Price Index, the most closely watched barometer of inflation. (The Producer Price Index and the G.N.P. deflator also reflect inflationary trends.) While most leading forecasters are at high-profile institutions, Mr. Ratajczak (pronounced RAT-a-chek) works at a commuter school whose downtown Atlanta campus is a stark expanse of parking decks and concrete classroom towers.

title: Miss McKay Wed To James Meeker
description: At Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., Cynthia Berthe McKay and James Beckett Meeker were married yesterday by the Rev. Sydney A. Woodd-Cahusac, who was assisted by the Rev. Sharon H. C. Clayton.

title: Lecture on Isadora Duncan
description: Annabelle Gamson, a leading interpreter of the work of Isadora Duncan, will explore the evolution of Duncan's choreography in a lecture on July 12 at 1 P.M. at the Fieldston School, Fieldston Road, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Tickets are $5. Information and reservations: 543-5000.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Development Floods Bergen Watershed
description: LEAD: FOR decades, 2,400 acres of woods and fields framing a regional reservoir system in Bergen County had escaped the wave of development that has swept over northern New Jersey.

title: Refuting Usual Seafood Cliches
description: CLOSE your eyes. Think Clam Diggers Restaurant. What do you see: a rustic fish house, shore dinners, steamers, paper plates? Now, open your eyes and look at Shelter Island's Clam Diggers Restaurant: a bright yellow Victorian house with hanging baskets of fuchsias and outdoor dining porches. Inside, it is white lace curtains, tablecloths, cut flowers, candlelight, floral paintings, antiques, towering vases of flowering branches and strains of progressive jazz in the background.

title: DOMINATE OR ELSE
description: LEAD: THE BETRAYAL OF THE SELF The Fear of Autonomy in Men and Women. By Arno Gruen. Translated by Hildegarde and Hunter Hannum. 154 pp. New York: Grove Press. $16.95.

title: Idealism to Reality; A Matter of Morals
description: IDEALISM is often an outlook of the young. As people grow older, they allow themselves to get caught up in making a living and don't pay attention to whether what they do for a living reflects their convictions.

title: The Town That Created a Color
description: DELFT stands for blue and white pottery; in fact the whole town positively hymns the blues. Rare is the cafe or home without its casual collector's item - a blue and white vase set off by stately tulips, a fireplace framed with exquisite old tiles, an antique jar offering sanctuary to rusty keys and pencil stubs. On the central Markt Square of the town five miles from The Hague, no fewer than 10 establishments are devoted to the mission of disseminating hand-painted delft blue.

title: Paris in a Bottle
description: A MARVELOUS THING ABOUT THE great explorers, Columbus and all that lot, was not the distances they traveled or even the remarkable places they found - but the fact that they did it all without guidebooks.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE DEFECTOR. By Monika Maron. Translated by David Newton Marinelli. (Readers International, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $8.95.) In icy prose, an East German memories, meditations and hallucinatins of a woman journalist, Monika Maron, relates the fragmented who one day discovers she is unable to leave her apartment.

title:
GARDENING;
The Hemlock and a New Pest
description: LEAD: THE Canadian hemlock is among the most useful evergreens in the Northeast. The species itself is a graceful, fine-textured tree. When sheared, it is among the most useful plants for hedging and screen plantings. Such forms as Sargent's Weeping and Cole's Prostrate are among the most attractive of the dwarf conifers for specimen and rock garden planting.

title: Hundreds of Art Works Damaged By Mildew in Museum Warehouse
description: Hundreds of paintings, decorative art objects and artifacts that the New-York Historical Society is storing in a Manhattan warehouse are in such acute stages of deterioration that some may be permanently lost.

title: Review/Film; Epiphany Re-enacted, With an Italian Flavor
description: ''Cammina Cammina'' was shown as part of the 1984 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Oct. 4, 1984. The film opens today at the Thalia So-Ho, 15 Vandam Street, between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue.

title: Into the 21st Century - Supersonically
description: A GROWING number of authorities believe that the age of mass supersonic air transportation in long-haul routes may be in the offing. If they are correct, there will be major opportunities for aircraft manufacturers, airlines and travelers alike. Significant steps are being taken to make this development a reality.

title: 'Dreamgirls' Explores Life Behind Footlights
description: THE late director and choreographer Michael Bennett focused everyone's attention on the hard work and heartache of Broadway dancers in the 1975 musical blockbuster ''A Chorus Line.'' In 1981, he went backstage again to explore life behind the scenes of the music industry.

title: Mom Says Goodbye to Nursery School
description: The other evening my son and a dozen or so classmates pped up to his teacher and received an official-looking diploma, complete with ribbon. It was the annual picnic of the cooperative nursery school where Sam had spent two years of his young life and from which he was now graduating. My husband and I, bleary-eyed and reeling from the round of wholesome family activities that mark the end of every school year, looked on, slightly stunned, feeling as if we were watching a movie. Was this really happening? The moment we had waited for - was it really here?

title: Journalists Lose Court Ruling
description: California's law protecting journalists from disclosing confidential sources of information does not exempt them from giving eyewitness accounts when called on to testify, a state appeals court has ruled.

description: Six months after a black man died of extensive head injuries after being taken to a small East Texas jail, three law officers are on trial in connection with his death.

title: St. Paul's Is a Shrine For Yanks, Too
description: FOR 10 years, an embarrassing question for me, as Dean of St. Paul's Cathedral in London, has been how to welcome Americans. If you are a priest, do you mention that your most distinguished predecessor wrote lyrical and sensual love poetry? Whereas Petrarch's sonnets to his Laura put her on a pedestal, John Donne, Dean of St. Paul's from 1621 to 1631, kicked the pedestal away, caught her in his arms and put her to bed.

description: JUST what is it that puts zip into our photographs? To some minds, the magic ingredient is contrast. What's meant here by ''contrast'' is the amount of separation between bright tones and dark tones in a picture, although there are plenty of other contrasts to be found in most images.

FICTION

title: TALKING: Commissions; When Are Oral Pacts Binding?
description: CAN a real estate broker demand a commission from a seller even though the seller has not signed a listing agreement? What if the two had just had a chat and the seller casually said, ''O.K., go ahead''? Is that instruction binding? The answers to those questions are more complex than they first appear. Much will depend on the laws of the particular state in which the conversation with the broker took place, and the circumstances under which the oral pact was made.

title: Knole House: Quintessential English Style
description: IT looks as if it had always been there, a vast stone house crowned with a forest of gables and chimneys; gray and ancient, it reminds one of nothing so much as a castle in a fairy tale, a seat of power and mystery. And, in fact, that is just how Knole appeared to a little girl who lived there, and who became the writer Victoria Sackville-West; that is how, today, it remains.

title: And Now From Japan, the Hot New 'Dry' Beers
description: GIVEN the current social climate, if American marketers proposed increasing the alcohol content of a beer to spur sales, people would probably wonder what they had been drinking - and how much. After all, the trend has been toward moderation. Light beer now accounts for 25 percent of United States sales, and this year even Jack Daniel's, that supposed bastion of tradition, lowered the proof of its Tennessee whisky to 86, from 90.

title: Hotel Rates
description: To the Editor: It's about time that hotels included state and local taxes in their advertised rates. Instead of running in small print, ''Taxes not included,'' just say, ''Taxes included'' in regular print. For example, the uninitiated would be astonished at the big addition to their bill at New York hotels. I stayed at one last December, paying $95 plus taxes per night, or $109 in reality. I wasn't astonished since I'd known about the taxes beforehand. But those looking for a hotel room for less than $100 in New York or other major cities would be in for a shock when they saw the bill the next morning. A little more candor would lessen that. EUGENE W. FELDMAN Lewistown, Pa.

title: PUSHING CIGARETTES OVERSEAS
description: IT IS 10 A.M. ON A MONDAY, and the Surgeon General is already at war. C. Everett Koop is addressing a room choked with reporters at the Department of Health and Human Services. As he stands with Amish severity in his Navy uniform, jabbing his pointer at poster-sized graphs and charts, Koop looks less like a spokesman for national health than a commodore outlining his battle plans. This morning, cigarettes are the enemy.

title: Krone Rides Again
description: When she finished first at the Monmouth Park and Meadowlands meetings last year, Julie Krone became the first woman to win riding titles at United States tracks. The 24-year-old jockey, who has more victories than any other female jockey, will make history again today: She will be first woman to ride in the Queen's Plate for Canadian-bred 3-year-olds at Woodbine in Toronto.

title: The Young and the Homeless
description: IF it's difficult for young married couples, single professionals and semiskilled workers to find affordable housing on Long Island, it's even more difficult for young people who finish high school and leave family homes to live on their own. For many, there is no choice.

title: PEDANT IN LOVE
description: THE SUGAR MOTHER By Elizabeth Jolley. 210 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title:
GARDENING;
The Hemlock and a New Pest
description: LEAD: THE Canadian hemlock is among the most useful evergreens in the Northeast. The species itself is a graceful, fine-textured tree. When sheared, it is among the most useful plants for hedging and screen plantings. Such forms as Sargent's Weeping and Cole's Prostrate are among the most attractive of the dwarf conifers for specimen and rock garden planting.

title: ADAM AND CAIN IN THE MADHOUSE
description: LEAD: TWILIGHT By Elie Wiesel. Translated by Marion Wiesel. 217 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95.

title: Unification Church Renews Its Request for a Retreat Center
description: LEAD: ANDY BACUS says that he would like nothing better than one day to be able to put up guests at his home, a 120-room Tudor mansion set on 98 acres off of Route 128 in New Castle.

title: Guard Found Slain Outside an S.I. Pizzeria
description: A security guard, on overnight vigil outside a Staten Island pizzeria, was found shot to death yesterday morning outside the store, which the killer apparently had broken into before fleeing empty-handed, the police reported.

title: THE SILVER LINING IN DISASTER
description: Demographers tell us that human fecundity increases in time of war and other catastrophe. A sort of population thermostat apparently kicks in, as if nature were programmed to counteract the death count. Some cultural historians have suggested in a similarly mystical vein that artistic creativity tends to decline in relatively calm periods, but to flourish when society is convulsed. That may not square with what history testifies, for instance, about the peaceful reign of Pericles. Still, from our vantage point in A.D. 1988, the history of 20th-century music does support the notion that social convulsion can promote creativity.

title: TOUR de FRANCE; Italy's Tebaldi Wins 7th Stage
description: Valerio Tebaldi of Italy, a 23-year-old rookie pro, took the seventh stage of the Tour de France today, but Jelle Nijdam of the Netherlands held on to the overall lead.

title: Festival Report: The Highs, The Lows; DANCE: Both quality and disappointment
description: The first New York International Festival of the Arts - a monthlong array of some 350 events - closes tomorrow. To assess the artistic accomplishments of the event, the Arts and Leisure section asked a cross-section of Times critics to evaluate both the individual performances they attended and the quality of the festival as a whole.

title: DATA UPDATE: July 10, 1988
C. E. Barton Wed To Marthe Rowen
description: The marriage of Marthe Rowen, an associate at the architectural firm of Rivkin/Weisman in New York, to Craig Evan Barton, an architect with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill in New York, took place yesterday in Rocky Hill, N.J. Judge Eric Perkins of the Municipal Court of Rocky Hill performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Rowen, parents of the bride. Mr. Barton is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford E. Barton of Norwalk, Conn.

title: Agnes A. Reiss Married
description: At Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Ridgewood, N.J., Agnes Adele Reiss, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William P. Reiss of South Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to James Andrew Zachara, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis M. Zachara of Ridgewood. The Rev. Eugene P. Heyndricks performed the ceremony. The bride, an associate at the law firm of Pitney, Hardin, Kipp & Szuch in Morristown, N.J., will retain her name professio.J., will retain her name professionally. Mr. Zachara owns Jaz Glass, a glass studio in Ridgewood.

title: The Battle of the Books
description: I was struck by the portrait of Frank Lentricchia teaching ''The Waste Land'' and ''pointing out the buried allusions to Ovid and Dante, Marvell and Verlaine.'' Mr. Lentricchia's lecture is undoubtedly at its most effective when his students know Ovid and Dante firsthand and not merely as disembodied references. Many of us who teach the dreaded ''Great Books'' course are trying to provide students with some of that useful firsthand experience.

title: Prospects; Eastern's Troubled Skies
description: Since Eastern Airlines was bought by Texas Air, Eastern has been plagued by troubles, ranging from poor relations between its labor unions and management to big financial losses. Allegations regarding poor safety practices prompted an investigation of the airline by the Department of Transportation. Investigators ultimately gave Eastern a clean bill of health, but in the meantime, its passenger traffic, particularly on its popular shuttle flights, suffered. Last week Eastern's management and unions issued a joint statement on safety that may signal a new measure of labor accord. Is Eastern finally solving its problems? Clifford Winston Senior fellow, the Brookings Institution.

title: New Job for Teacher
description: WHEN a bat-wielding teen-ager attacked a Bronx schoolteacher, Gary Smith, two months ago, there was outrage over the incident and sympathy for Smith, who lost his right eye. The 39-year-old Smith, who taught at I.S. 166 in the Bronx for 16 years, is out of the hospital now.

title:
THEATER;
Brustein Confronts 'Six Characters'
description: LEAD: ''The theater is not archeology,'' wrote the Italian playwright Luigi Pirandello. ''Unwillingness to take up old works, to modernize and streamline them for fresh production, bespeaks indifference, not praiseworthy caution. The theater welcomes such modernization and has profited by it. . . .The original text remains intact for anyone who may want to reread it at home.

title: Go Ahead, Serve the Salad With the Main Dish
description: SALAD is usually served after the main course. But in the summer I sometimes like to serve salad and a fish or meat dish together. This practice is not only convenient, simplifying things when you are entertaining - it is ideal when you want to eat light.

title: Video-Terminal Law: An Overreaction
description: The Suffolk business community is overreacting [ ''Businesses Assess Impact of Law on Video Terminals,'' June 19 ] . As a business executive operating an enterprise that employs more than 100 people, I too am concerned when government mandates an increase in my costs of doing business. But the fears of many employers are unfounded.

title: President Hobart? It Might Have Been
description: IT LOOKS as if loyal citizens of the Garden State, whether Republicans or Democrats, who have been waiting for 200 years for a born-and-bred New Jerseyan to make it to the Presidency will be disappointed again.

title: Missing Couple Rescued, and 4 Are Arrested
description: A Jamaican couple kidnapped four days ago were rescued unharmed on Long Island early yesterday, and four men were arrested in the case. The New York City police said the abduction might have been drug-related.

title: A Working National Security Team
description: Finally, after seven years, President Reagan's foreign policy and defense advisers are pulling together - including in their response to last week's airliner tragedy in the Persian Gulf. That's no small accomplishment, given the history of incessant warfare among the Secretary of State, Secretary of Defense and National Security Council adviser. The next President might take a moment to consider the reasons for the current harmony.

title: 13 Caribbean Lands Accuse Justice Dept. Of Drug Interference
description: The leaders of 13 Caribbean nations have accused the United States Justice Department of interfering in the region's affairs as it clamps down on drugs, and they urged President Reagan to halt that interference.

title: U.S. Action Outpaces Policy in the Persian Gulf
description: WHAT is the United States doing in the Persian Gulf, where it now has the greatest concentration of naval firepower in one place since the Vietnam War? In the week since an American warship there shot down a civilian Iranian airliner, killing 290 people, some members of Congress and others have been asking that question about the force of 29 naval vessels and 10,000 to 15,000 naval personnel.

title: Home Safeguards
description: To the Editor: In the June 12 Practical Traveler, ''Safeguarding Your Home,'' Betsy Wade talked about engraving valuables with a Social Security number. This suggestion is valid in New York in light of the lengthy numbers on that state's driver's licences.

title: Rich Pact for Lott
description: A Pro Bowl selection at free safety for six of his seven years with San Francisco, Ronnie Lott yesterday signed a 3-year $2.5 million contract with the 49ers making him the team's highest paid defensive player.

title: Detroiters Curious About Monorail
description: BEFORE the People Mover monorail in Detroit began shuttling passengers around a 2.9-mile loop a year ago, critics feared it would be a ''horizontal elevator to nowhere.'' Instead, it has become a tourist attraction, drawing crowds that ride the computer-driven trains and look at the graffiti-free award-winning art in the stations.

title: Pentagon Fraud Curbs Are Focus of Dispute
description: Disclosures from the Justice Department's broad investigation of fraud in military procurement have provoked disputes between lawmakers and the Pentagon over the best way to change the military's purchasing system.

title: IN QUOTES
description: Even Mike Tyson gets tired of people hitting him. I'm tired of people hitting me. - H. Ross Perot, on his dispute with his former company.

title: HER BROTHER GOES BONKERS
description: MEN IN TROUBLE By Sarah Payne Stuart. 209 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: A Trio of Wild-Eyed Rebels Try Comebacks
description: When Bob Seger sang ''Rock and roll never forgets,'' he was wrong. More often than not, pioneers end coughing up the dust clouds left by their imitators. Back in the not-so-distant 1970's, Iggy Pop, Patti Smith and Pere Ubu were wild-eyed rebels, out to overhaul and shake up the rock music they saw ossifying around them. By odd coincidence, all three are now trying comebacks: Pere Ubu with a reunion album after a five-year hiatus, Ms. Smith with her first album of the 1980's and Mr. Pop with an album that intends to reclaim the Stooges' primal hard-rock. Have punks gone professional?

title: Reviews/Music; Pop With Le Jazz Hot, By Giordano and Vignola
description: The simultaneous booking of Vince Giordano's 10-piece band, the Nighthawks, and Frank Vignola's string quartet, the Hot Club of France, for a four-week engagement at Michael's Pub that began on Tuesday, suggests that the restaurant at 211 East 55th Street is offering a double bill. In a sense it is, but the quartet has been enfolded within the big band to form a large ensemble in which the groups sometimes play separately and at times are combined.

title: For Faster Car Care, New Specialized Malls
description: A NEW mall serves car owners with maintainence, engine repairs and washing and waxing.

title: Ms. Pancotti Is Engaged
description: Mrs. Robert George Pancotti of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Carolyn Ann Pancotti, to Michael Bradley Ray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Bradley Ray of Manhasset, L.I. Ms. Pancotti is the daughter also of the late Mr. Pancotti.

title: A Winning .300 Hitter From His Wheelchair
description: WHEN 11-year-old Jonathan Slifka hit a three-run home run to lead his team to its ninth straight victory in the West Hartford Youth Baseball League, he never left home plate.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Is the Coin Market Heading for a Boom?
description: LEAD: THE coin market is heating up. Investment quality coins, especially those graded Mint State-66 and above, have been surging in value. Some observers think the market may be headed for its biggest boom in history.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. $350,000 10 Byram Brook Place 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old Cape Cod; breakfast room, master bedroom, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $3,564. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $320,000 Woodland Road 6-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; 2 fireplaces, family room, cathedral ceilings, skylights, deck, 2 acres; taxes $4,084. Somers, N.Y. $297,000 Brick Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 22-year-old raised ranch; family room, fireplace, patio, pool, 2-car garage, 1.5 acres; taxes $3,998. Glastonbury, Conn. $149,000 28 Benton Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old Cape Cod; 2-car garage, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,540. Portland, Conn. $97,000 Great Hill Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 58-year-old bungalow; front and rear porches, country views; taxes $992. Rocky Hill, Conn. $239,900 36 Martin Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; ceiling fans, private setting, fireplace; taxes $2,219. OTHER AREAS Springfield, N.J. $180,000 171 Tooker Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 2 half-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; den, full basement, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,905. Smithtown, L.I. $176,000 17 Carlson Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; basement, pool, 0.5 acre, 2-car garage; taxes $3,500.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ON THE NATURE OF THINGS EROTIC. By F. Gonzalez-Crussi. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.) F. Gonzalez-Crussi's writing is obviously informed by his medical specialty. By training an anatomist, he is seemingly obsessed with the naming of parts, a will toward taxonomy and classification, a yearning to impose order where perhaps none naturally exists.

title: New Troupe Takes Up 'Fountain Pen'
description: TO the Independence Theater Company, the new professional indoor group in the great outdoors of Fort Lee Historic Park: welcome. About its philosophy of putting on out-of-the-way plays: bravo. On the occasion of its first production, ''Today I Am a Fountain Pen!'' by Israel Horovitz: better luck next time.

title: Question Of the Week; The Draft: How Did the Knicks and Nets Do?
description: Knick management says that Rod Strickland will save Mark Jackson's career. Strickland was the best player available when the Knicks picked, and may even prove to have been the best guard in the draft. Those shouting for Shelton Jones and Jerome Lane, as I naturally was, were blinded by loyalty and poor judgment. I love Jones, but, simply put, he's an untested Johnny Newman.

title: J. E. Sununu Wed To Miss Halloran In West Virginia
description: Catherine M. Halloran, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Halloran of Charleston, W.Va., was married there yesterday to John Edward Sununu, a son of Gov. and Mrs. John H. Sununu of Salem, N.H. The Rev. P. Edward Sadie performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Romantic 'Little Shop of Horrors'
description: ''LITTLE SHOP OF HORRORS'' is an ideal little musical which opened in a 98-seat, Off-Off Broadway theater. To preserve the integrity of its smallness when it was moved for a commercial run, the producers, who included the Shubert Organization, kept it in a 340 seat theater, where it prosperously ran, for five years, resisting all chances at the big Broadway stakes.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: NED SCHNURMAN knows what he should do when he returns to New York after a vacation. He should, as he put it, ''go home, unpack, go into the office the next day with presents for everybody and be a nice guy.'' He does none of those things. He times his return so that he can go directly to the office, luggage and all.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Landmark Since the Early 1800's
description: LEAD: THIS county dowager of a place has been run as Emily Shaw's Inn for 50 years but has stood as a landmark in the community since the early 1800's. Careful renovation has preserved the rustic and rather somber paneling, the old beams and age-burnished wide-plank floors; and smart money added with restraint a refreshing, modern touch here and there.

title: Steakhouse in an Art Deco Setting
description: IN a free-standing building on the Post Road in Darien once occupied by Twin Faces East, Giovanni's now holds forth. Inside, the decor suggests that nothing has changed: the same handsome Art Deco chrome light fixtures and designs, the same gray tablecloths and accouterments and tones throughout of silver and gray. A well-separated piano bar lounge is also well decorated and softly lighted.

title: Midge C. Herz, Producer, Weds
description: Midge Claire Herz, a daughter of Norma Soalt of Nyack, N.Y., and the late Walter J. Herz, and John Robbins Kosner, a son of Alice Kosner of Scottsdale, Ariz., and Edward Kosner of New York, were married last evening at the Spanish Institute in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony.

title: The American Drug Problem Takes On 2 Faces
description: FROM the headlines and the mood of politicians this year, it would seem that the outlook for America's drug problem has never been bleaker.

title: Taking Care With New York's Catch
description: WHEN you buy a fishing license from New York State, you get an unusual warning with it: The fish you catch should be eaten sparingly, if at all.

title: NAZI VICTIMS SEEK ARGENTINE JUSTICE
description: Three Polish-born survivors of World War II Nazi camps came to Argentina this week in search of justice for those they say they saw killed sadistically almost 50 years ago by the commandant.

title: In the U.S.S.R., Just Getting Food to the Table Is a Struggle
description: THE state meat store on Malaya Kolkhoznaya Ploshchad offered a typical selection the other day - baloney, salami and baloney. In the fish store a few doors down a sales clerk was pounding a block of frozen ocean perch with a sledgehammer to break off pieces for a long line of impatient customers. At the fresh produce shop next door, beets, cabbage and a mound of soggy squash were the vegetables of the day.

title: Drag Racer Tops at Land, Sea
description: When Eddie Hill finally convinced himself that racing 200 mile-per-hour drag boats would eventually prove fatal he took up a safer sport: driving 280 mile-per-hour Top Fuel dragsters.

title: On Neutral Ground
description: BRIDGE has made a notable contribution to the easing of tensions between the People's Republic of China and Taiwan. One of the earliest sporting contests in which players from the two Chinas were opposed was at the card table. They now meet regularly on neutral territory.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Muster in U.S. Pro Final: Eighth-seeded Tom Muster of Austria defeated Bruno Oresar, 7-5, 6-0, yesterday to advance to the final of the United States Pro championships. The 21-year-old Oresar struggled through a series of long games in the early stages of the 1-hour-22-minute match at Longwood Cricket Club and led, 5-2. But Muster, the only ranking player left in the field, earned his place in the final by running off 11 straight games. His opponent in the final will be 13th-seeded Lawson Duncan, who defeated Horacio de La Pena, 6-4, 6-2, just 24 hours after the unseeded Argentine had upset top-seeded Mats Wilander.(AP) Graf and Maleeva Gain: Steffi Graf advanced to the women's final of the Gunze World tournament in Osaka, Japan, by defeating Mary Joe Fernandez of the United States, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday. Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria also gained the $200,000 final by beating Etsuko Inoue of Japan, 6-3, 6-2. In the men's semifinals, Jimmy Connors defeated Anders Jarryd of Sweden, 6-2, 6-7, 7-6, and Tim Mayotte eliminated a fellow American, Elliot Teltscher, 6-0, 6-4. Despite 10 service aces in the second set, Connors lost in an 8-6 tie breaker. Connors rallied in the third set, taking a tie breaker at 8-6. (AP) Hlasek to Face Cahill: Seventh-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland and an unseeded Australian, Darren Cahill, gained the men's final of the $270,000 Swiss Open in Gstaad with quick semfinal victories. Both will be seeking their first Grand Prix title today. Cahill defeated Horst Skoff of Austria, 6-1, 6-1, in 48 minutes. Hlasek, 23 years old, downed Sergio Casal of Spain, 6-3, 6-2. (AP) Masur-Drewett Final: Wally Masur and Brad Drewett, close friends who live five minutes apart near Sydney, Australia, advanced to today's final of the Volvo Tennis-Hall of Fame Championships in Newport, R.I.

title: GENTLE ITALIANS
description: Delacroix's Algerian harems, Botticelli's pale nymphs, Degas's fragile ballerinas -they were a few of the images evoked by Milanese designers this season in collections that reflect an intensely refined romanticism.

title: Baby Heart on Hold
description: IF WE ARE TO BEGIN AT THE BEGINNING, it must be way back. In the yolk of time. The problem began with the embryo, the cells of which divide, burgeon, twist and unfold, yielding to the wash of DNA and the codes of its helix.

title: Hospital Volunteers: Short Supply
description: AS 75-year-old Doris Flynn scurried about the Intensive Care Unit at Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, carrying flowers and water, pushing patients in wheelchairs and keeping visitors informed, her duties may have seemed inconsequential amid the fluster of life-threatening crises.

title: King Hussein in Cairo
description: King Hussein of Jordan arrived here today for talks with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt on the faltering Arab-Israeli peace process and on the Iran-Iraq war.

title: Shultz Seeks Shift on Vietnam Refugees
description: In a frank admission that the decade-long strategy for dealing with Indochinese refugees no longer works, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that sending refugees back voluntarily to Vietnam must be examined as an alternative to resettling all of them in the United States and elsewhere in the West.

description: BASEBALL

description: A SERIES of studies will get under way this summer, all seeking ways to protect or enhance a necessity: water.

WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Bus Terminal Moves

The Lefrak Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING ON: Cape Cod
description: There's a Cape Cod town for every character.

description: New York City's Board of Education lacks even the most basic information necessary to recruit and place new teachers properly, a State Senate panel charged in a report issued last week.

description: The United States Government has joined Polish emigres in a major effort to help Solidarity and the Polish underground smuggle publications, printing machinery, radio equipment and video cassettes into Poland.

description: Eight members of a convoy trying to carry food and clothing to Nicaraguan civilians were arrested today in a melee with the police after they had tried to take their trucks across a bridge into Mexico.

description: THE Portuguese offer the following advice: If you plant for yourself, sow a vineyard; if you plant for your son, sow olive trees, and if you are thinking of your grandson, you should plant cork.

description: IT is possible to recycle in a big way:

title: Shelling Out For Thrill of Death
description: ONE fine morning quite recently, I occupied myself doing some neglected housework, but even while I washed the dishes, folded the laundry and swept the kitchen floor, my subconscious wrestled with weighty problems, such as which writing project I would begin now that my contemporary horror novel was finished.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the slaying of a police officer in East Palo Alto, Calif., gave an incorrect year of that city's incorporation. It was incorporated in 1983.

description: To the Editor:

title: TASTING THE WATERS
description: COOKING OUT OVER WEST LAKE from the Louwailou Restaurant across a shimmer of water embraced by tea-green hills, I bit into my first freshwater shrimp bathed in Dragon Well tea and knew why Hangzhou has been for the last six centuries China's No.1 pleasure spot.

title: Where Two Worlds Meet in China
description: SOMETIMES, as dawn's first purple splotches ooze through the folds of mist that swaddle the steep hills here, the rattle of firecrackers echoes from a not too distant treeless slope as a group of Miao people bury one of their dead. Though burials are officially banned in China in favor of cremation, the coffin-maker on the main street was busy the day before, planing and sanding long white planks in a trade that has all but disappeared from this country.

FILM;

title: Catharine Susan Shaw Weds James Gallagher
description: Catharine Susan Shaw, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Shaw of New Canaan, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to James Joseph Gallagher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Gallagher of Freehold, N.J. Acting Justice Richard Lee Price of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony at the Tavern on the Green in New York.

title: For Those Who Chase Truants, Help Is on the Way
description: By 9 A.M. most mornings, Harvey Zirofsky is on the street in Brooklyn tracking down one of the half-dozen truant high school students he sets out to find on a typical day.

title: SIBERIA TAUGHT HIM A FEW THINGS: AN 'ENEMY OF THE PEOPLE' RETURNS
description: In June 1956, the most senior representatives of the Yugoslav and Soviet Governments -Tito and Khrushchev, accompanied by their chiefs of staff - sit in one of the parlor cars of the special train that shuttles between Moscow and Kiev. There is no need for an interpreter. Since their schedule is overburdened (the meeting's purpose is to smooth out the numerous ideological differences that had accumulated during the Yugoslav ''schism''), little time remains for ancillary matters. However, taking advantage of a moment of good humor on the part of the master of the revels (Khrushchev), Tito proffers him, from across the table, as one proffers a menu to a diner, the list of dead souls. The scene is Gogolian. ''Here, this is the list of our hundred and thirteen former officials who were in the Soviet Union. What became of them?'' Khrushchev glances at the list of dead souls, then hands it to an aide. ''I will answer you in two days.'' Exactly two days later, at the point in a meeting when drinks and cigars have replaced the official conversation, Khrushchev announces suddenly, point-blank, while drumming on a piece of paper with his pudgy fingers: ''Tochno sto nyetu'' (''Exactly one hundred are no longer of this world'').

title: Margaret Meade, Executive, Wed to Dr. R. J. Hariri
description: Margaret Regina Meade and Dr. Robert Joseph Hariri were married yesterday at the Wilburton Inn in Manchester, Vt., by Archbishop Michael E. Verra of the Orthodox Catholic Church in America.

title: OPPOSITION LEADER CLAIMS PRESIDENCY IN MEXICAN VOTING
description: The principal opposition candidate in Wednesday's presidential vote here claimed tonight that he had won the election and called on Mexicans to join him in a ''popular mobilization'' to prevent the Government from stealing his victory through vote fraud.

title: THE REGION: Airport Gridlock; 'Plane City' Grows, With No End in Sight And No Room to Move
description: ''LOTS of times,'' said the veteran airline pilot, ''you push back from the gate at LaGuardia, you look out that cockpit window, and it's full - tails and wings all over. You don't go anywhere for 20 or 30 minutes because there's nowhere to move. It's Plane City. So you haven't started your engines yet, and already you're a half hour late.''

title: Keeping a Close Watch on Pool Safety
description: THE hot summer became even hotter during last month's unseasonable heat wave when a number of swimming pools and beach areas were closed by the County Health Department. According to waterfront and pool directors, the closings came swiftly and without much warning, after new regulations by the New York State Public Health Council. The new rules took effect May 1.

description: FACED with worsening labor conditions and harsh weather, blueberry growers in New Jersey say they must mechanize or be wiped out.

title: A Microcosm of the Sound in Norwalk
description: WHEN the Norwalk Maritime Center opens next Saturday, its will invite visitors to explore the marine life and heritage of Long Island Sound, once the lifeline of the city.

title: In Britain, Stompin' at the Savoy
description: LORD FORTE has come a long way. Born in the Italian mountain village of Montforte, Charles Forte emigrated as a child to Scotland, where his father ran an ice cream shop and a cafe. Through hard work and ingenuity, he rose from waiting on tables in his father's cafe to become one of Britain's most successful entrepreneurs, creating the $3 billion-a-year hotel and catering empire Trusthouse Forte P.L.C.

title: The Corporate Clamor for Help Gets Louder
description: IF there were ever a good time to be a management consultant, this might be it. As corporations reduce their size, restructure and try to cope with a rapidly changing business environment, they are increasingly asking consultants for help.

title: Competition Over Concrete
description: SINCE it turned out its first batch 13 months ago, a concrete factory that New York City helped establish has changed owners. Now city officials say the plant, at the foot of West 57th Street, is finally ready to do what they wanted it to do all along, spur competition in the construction industry.
