description: IN selecting a running mate, Barry Goldwater once explained, a Presidential nominee has one objective:

title: Soviet Artists Score Coup In Trenton
description: IN 1985, a Trenton businessman named Shelley Zeiger initiated a sister relationship between his own city and the Lenin District in Moscow. Since then, Trenton has been host to Ukrainian dancers and the Kirov and Moscow Ballets.

title: Quality Quandary
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Learning Fast
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, began a 12-year Federal prison term in Springfield, Mo., last week with the announcement that he had already learned a lesson. Having been unable to overturn his racketeering conviction, which stemmed from New York City's Parking Violations Bureau bribery scandal, he offered this advice during a WNYW-TV interview: ''If you want to stay and make money from and in the private sector, you should stay out of the political arena. If you want to go into the political arena, then you should stay out of doing business with the government.'' Mr. Friedman will have to serve at least four years.

title:
INVESTING;
Profits From Cleanliness
description: LEAD: FEAR of AIDS has increased the demand for properly sterilized medical instruments. That is why W. H. Newbold's Son & Company, a Philadelphia brokerage, likes Isomedix Inc., a small company based in Whippany, N.J.

title: Midwestern Nuclear Projects Suggest a Use for Shoreham
description: IF Shoreham is never to split an atom, can it be put to some other use?

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ceiling in our upstairs bathroom develops ugly black stains that look like mold. We keep repainting, but the stains return. Is there a special kind of paint we can use?

title: Amid Clatter, Monks Calmly Sift Sand
description: Amid all the clamor and clatter of the city, a pinpoint of pure calm - a ''gateway to bliss'' - is being created.

title: The Battle of the Books
description: Duke University Prof. Jane Tompkins wants us to read Charles Brockden Brown, a Philadelphian of the early years of the Republic. Brown's novels are filled with the rigged episodes of melodrama and the turgid prose that passed for elegance among the literary circles in America before Irving and Hawthorne arrived on the scene.

title: Pace of Building Abandonment Tumbles
description: HOUSING abandonment, once the scourge of New York City neighborhoods, has declined sharply over the last few years. Even so, city officials are preparing to assume ownership of a few thousand more parcels of real estate on which owners have fallen behind in their property taxes.

title: Building the Business Now Takes Lots of Cash
description: CONSULTING was once one of the least capital-intensive businesses. Costs were mainly salaries and rent, with a few promotional activities thrown in.

title: Sewer Line in Oxford Becomes Cause Celebre
description: LEAD: What started off as planning a sewer line across the state property has grown to include the Governor, the Department of Environmental Protection and a bridle club.

title: GORBACHEV IS DUE IN POLAND MONDAY
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrives here Monday for a six-day visit to Poland, the largest and most populous of the East European countries allied with Moscow and traditionally the most politically volatile.

title: Behind the Crash
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sauerkraut Dries Up
description: IN the 1970's, 30 percent of the sauerkraut consumed in America -more than 100 million pounds - was from Phelps, N.Y. No one there complained about the odor that hung over the village, which billed itself as the sauerkraut capital of the world.

title: Jittery Times for Pilots and Air Controllers in Gulf
description: ''Sure, I'm nervous about flying through the gulf, and I have been for a long time,'' said Capt. Harold Ewing, a commercial pilot who regularly flies Boeing 747 airliners into Dubai. ''Everybody is.'' Commercial airline pilots and air traffic controllers in the southern Persian Gulf are among the most eager to hear the conclusions of investigators looking into the downing Sunday of an Iranian airliner by a United States warship. But whatever the outcome of the inquiry, those involved in aviation over the gulf agree that the military buildup here in the last year has brought new perils to the region's busy airways. Many Navies Present

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The ceiling in our upstairs bathroom develops ugly black stains that look like mold. We keep repainting, but the stains return. Is there a special kind of paint we can use?

title: Malaysia Acts to Halt Refugee Influx
description: Malaysia, concerned about a sustained increase in the number of Vietnamese boat people arriving on its east coast, is sending its Foreign Minister, Abu Hassan Omar, to Hanoi soon to urge Vietnam to stop the refugee outflow at the source.

title: Theater Festival: The World's a Stage
description: THIS summer has been an international theater festival, not only because of the plethora of international artists performing at the first International Arts Festival in New York, but also because of adjoining festivals at the State University of New York, both Summerfare at Purchase in Westchester and Festival '88 at Stony Brook on Long Island.

title: Feminism Is an Affirmation of Humanity
description: To the Editor:

title: Martha R. C ollett Wed To Francis Mellon Jr.
description: Martha Rountree Collett and Francis Robert Mellon Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mellon of Douglaston, Queens, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Sterling Ruffin Collett Jr., in Morganton, N.C. The Rev. Parker Trevilian Williamson, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Who Are The League M.V.P.'s at This Stage?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: MINORITY STUDENTS AT SUMMER COLLEGE
description: LEAD: On a recent warm summer day, Carlos Acevedo and about a dozen other minority-group teen-agers walked out of a college English class where they had been discussing the novel ''Ragtime,'' by E. L. Doctorow. They had more classes and homework ahead of them.

title: Olympic Profile: Ed Hopson; A Quick Study Is Moving Up Fast
description: On Thursday night, in the semifinal round of the Olympic boxing trials here, Ed Hopson, a 5-foot-4-inch teen-ager from St. Louis, stepped briskly from his corner to center ring for his three-round bout against the best-known amateur featherweight in this country, 6-foot Kelcie Banks of Chicago.

title: Royal Spanish Ballet: On a New Tack
description: LEAD: The setting is a small Spanish village. A row of men, seated in chairs, stamp their feet percussively; women in white fill the stage, symbolizing the joy of a community about to celebrate a wedding. The groom, in a white suit, is vital and energetic; his bride, a sweet princess, is also in white. Into the happy scene arrives Medea, spurned and tormented wife of this groom,

title:
DANCE;
It's Dancers' Turn at Festival
description: LEAD: SOME dance companies feature lightning feet; others boast turns or jumps. The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company has arms and an exuberant kinetic style. Leading off the dance portion of the Paper Mill Playhouse's Summer Festival '88 in Millburn, the company, which dances circles around most other troupes with its combination of strikingly eloquent movement and inventive choreography, will present a program on Wednesday of three works by Mr.

title: Collectors, From the Prosaic to the Artistic
description: LEAD: THE items people collect are as diverse as the collectors. ''People and Their Collections,'' an exhibition at the Stamford Musem and Nature Center, displays 17 collections, from paper dolls to delftware.

title: Correction
description: A recording review on page 29 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies a new album by Pere Ubu. The title is ''The Tenement Year.''

title: Sports of The Times; 'Who's That Wearing Dunston's Shirt?'
description: The manager observed his shortstop and thought, ''He doesn't know how to conduct himself on a baseball field.'' The manager saw the shortstop chase foul balls ''that he had no chance for, that were 40 feet into the stands.'' At bat, the player was so undisciplined, recalled the manager, ''that he'd swing and miss so hard he'd wind up in the other team's dugout.''

title: In Its 5th Year, Festival Expands Jazz Programs
description: SUMMER MUSIC INC., a festival in its fifth season, is a success story. ''It seems hard to believe,'' said Peter Sacco, co-founder of the festival with Cynde Iverson and now music director. ''So much excitement, energy and growth in so short a time, so many friends made, and so many memorable evenings of superb music making in one of New England's most exquisite settings.''

title: In Queens, a Preview of Future Cities
description: Corona and Elmhurst seem unremarkable middle-class Queens communities. But to Roger Sanjek, an urban anthropologist, they are the future, a preview of what American cities will be like in the year 2100.

title: Our Allies Have To Do More
description: Next January, the new President will confront complicated and demanding challenges to national security policy. Although internal changes in the Soviet Union may offer new opportunities, Soviet military power continues to grow. Arms control negotiations will become more complicated. We face new threats from terrorism and other forms of unconventional warfare. Defense budgets will become even tighter.

title: The Media Business: Advertising; Creative Assignments For I.B.M. Finalists
description: The six advertising agencies that have been selected as finalists for the International Business Machines account, billing in the neighborhood of $150 million, are scheduled to receive identical creative assignments this week.

title: The Drought Adds Birds and Fish to Its Cruel Toll
description: The skeletons of 35,000 fish lay in long windrows along the receding shoreline of Browning Lake here, killed by a drought that is adding fish, birds and other wildlife to its heavy toll.

title: Karolyi Quits Olympic Job
description: Bela Karolyi, whose gym placed 5 women in the top 10 spots at the United States gymnastics championships over the weekend, has resigned as head of the United States Olympic gymnastics delegation.

title: International Report; Austria and Hungary Seek Reunion in '95 Fair
description: Vienna and Budapest, joined until 70 years ago in the Austro-Hungarian empire, are planning a six-month reunion in 1995 that they hope will bring glory to both.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; 'A Done Deal'
description: ''It's pretty much a done deal,'' said a Congressional staff member who specializes in trade matters, referring to negotiations with the Administration on a bill to put into effect the Canadian free trade agreement.

title: Review/Dance; A Visionary 'Martyre' In a U.S. Premiere
description: ''Le Martyre de Saint Sebastien,'' presented by the Paris Opera Ballet as its final premiere of the season, has come to New York in a new production by Robert Wilson.

title: The Media Business: Advertising; Financial Officers Get A Magazine
description: THE 19-year-old Warren, Gorham & Lamont, which publishes more than 300 titles for professional readers, has never created a magazine until now.

title: Anger Alters the Chemistry of Armenian Protest
description: ''Our young women greeted the soldiers with flowers when they came in a few months ago,'' a Yerevan resident, Samson Tomazyan, said today, a few minutes before he rose to address an angry crowd gathered at Moscow's Armenian cemetery. ''They won't be giving them flowers anymore.''

title: Chile General Calls Democracy's Return Inevitable
description: The commander of the Chilean Air Force, long known as a critic of President Augusto Pinochet's desire to retain power, says democracy is returning to this country whether General Pinochet wins or loses the coming plebiscite.

title: State Threat To Insurer
description: Minnesota has threatened to revoke the license of the Chubb Insurance Companies if it refuses to issue drought-insurance policies to about 1,000 farmers who paid for more than $40 million in coverage.

title: Early Jump Pays Off in Britain
description: Bobby Jones spent nearly a month in England and Scotland in preparation for the 1926 British Open, which he won after hitting a spectacular 175-yard bunker shot to the 17th green in the final round at Royal Lytham and St. Annes, a links course in Lancashire, on the west coast of England.

title: The Quiet America; Washington Silence on Mexico Vote Should Not Be Seen as Indifference
description: Mexican sensitivity to even the faintest hint of Yankee imperialism, born of more than a century of tensions between radically different neighbors, lies behind Washington's almost complete silence on the subject of Wednesday's presidential election in Mexico.

title: Reviews/Dance; On-Stage Tour of a Life
description: Danny Mydlack takes us on a tour of his distinctive art and life in ''How to Win Friends and Influence People,'' presented over the weekend at Performance Space 122. He talks of times he performed for neighbors in their living rooms, and turns the theater's small downstairs stage into a living room, complete with a small and scruffy square of rug, a television monitor, photos of himself and acquaintances and piles of familiar yet peculiar props. He even dons a lampshade for one number.

title: In Dealing With London, Riyadh Sidesteps Lengthy Tussle With the Pro-Israel Lobby
description: In signing a huge arms deal with Britain, Saudi Arabia was trying not only to meet its military needs but to avoid a series of bruising political battles with Israel's strong supporters in the United States Congress.

title: SIECKMANN CAPTURES PLAYOFF
description: Tom Sieckmann, who had not won in four years on the PGA Tour and who had missed the cut in 12 of 16 events this season, parred the second hole of a sudden death playoff with Mark Wiebe today to win the Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic.

title: Jones Beach Draws Cautious Crowd
description: At 8 A.M. there was only sand and surf and a fiery sun climbing across the sky. Six hours later the sand was obliterated by a sea of people, armed with suitcase-sized radios, bottles of baby oil and improvised cloth barricades intended to shelter them from the wind and from one another.

title: Business and the Law; GAF Case: Weak And Strong Points
description: EXPERTS who have looked at the case charging manipulation by the GAF Corporation of the price of the Union Carbide Corporation's stock say the Government's strongest proof of wrongdoing will come from the testimony of the former head of a major brokerage firm and its weakest points will be other evidence that can be interpreted in more than one way.

title: Tests on B-1 Bomber Prompt Concern About Its Capability
description: Newly conducted tests of the sophisticated electronic combat system aboard the B-1 bomber have prompted the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee to question whether the plane will ever be able to fulfill its intended mission of high-speed, low-altitude flight inside the Soviet Union, according to a Congressional official.

title: Yvonne Constant to Sing
description: Yvonne Constant, a French singer who first appeared in this country in the revue ''La Plume de Ma Tante'' and who had a featured role in the Richard Rodgers musical ''No Strings,'' will sing a program of songs in French and English on Thursday nights through July 28 at Jan Wallman's, 49 West 44th Street. Shows are at 9 and 11 P.M., with a $10 cover charge and $8 minimum.

title: Boy, 4, Drowns in Crowded Pool
description: A four-year-old boy drowned Friday afternoon in a crowded Brooklyn swimming pool while under the supervision of two other people, the police said.

title: Briefs
description: Debt First Financial Management Corp. filed $100 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2013.

title: Political Memo; Dukakis Remains on Course, Dismissing Polls and Advice >
description: Just two months ago, Vice President Bush was getting a lot of advice from well-wishers and Republican strategists on how to put some life into a flagging Presidential campaign. Now, after the polls have tightened up, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis is getting his turn to hear from the back-seat drivers.

title: Afghan Attacks Reported
description: Afghan guerrillas bombarded cities and towns across Afghanistan with rockets and artillery fire, killing or wounding 150 civilians, the Soviet press agency Tass reported today. Tass said that the raids took place over the last 48 hours and that caravans of arms for the insurgents were arriving from Pakistan. The Soviet military commander in Afghanistan said the Kremlin might rethink its schedule for withdrawing troops from the country if Pakistan kept aiding the Afghan guerrillas.

title: For Turtles, Man Is Threat
description: State wildlife officers arrested four people and confiscated more than 1,000 sea turtle eggs after staking out a beach the turtles use to bury their eggs.

title: Aid Donors Stress Environment
description: The heads of major international aid organizations pledged today to insure that the projects they finance in the third world will not harm the environment.

title: REGAL INTENTION ROMPS
description: Regal Intention, considered the second-best 3-year-old colt in Sam-Son Farm's stable, romped to a 3 1/4-length victory over stablemate Regal Classic today in 129th running of the Queen's Plate at Woodbine.

title: Plan to Split MGM/UA Is Reported
description: In his typically secretive style, Kirk Kerkorian, the reclusive entrepreneur, is again restructuring the MGM/UA Communications Company, according to an executive familiar with the transaction.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Medical International Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., a health care services company, named Wendy Simpson corporate vice president and controller and Charles R. Timpe corporate vice president and treasurer.

title: Susan Elbe Marries
description: Susan Jill Elbe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter E. Elbe of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lloyd Steven Lowy, a son of Laura F. Lowy of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Dr. Bertram A. Lowy. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony at the James House in Tarrytown, N.Y. The bride is the eastern regional manager at John Wiley & Sons, publishers in New York. The bridegroom is an associate at the New York law firm of Webster & Sheffield.

title: At Haiti's Grand Hotel, Bed, Bath, Distant Fire
description: When the army staged a coup d'etat in Haiti earlier this month, a handful of foreign reporters climbed to a creaky upper veranda of the Grand Hotel Oloffson to peer into the steamy darkness in the direction of all the shooting.

title: Pamela Dorman Wed To Stuart Krichevsky
description: Pamela Grace Dorman, a senior editor at the publishing house of Viking Penguin, and Stuart Krichevsky, a literary agent at Sterling Lord Literistic, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Estherwood mansion in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, chaplain at the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the nondenominational service.

title: FRENCH COURT BLOCKS AN ALTERED FILM
description: Opponents of film coloring were buoyed recently when a high French court blocked the first showing of a colored version of John Huston's ''Asphalt Jungle.''

title: Reviews/Dance; Reflected Perceptions
description: ''Dubbelspoor'' was a theatrical conjuring trick. It was all done with mirrors.

title: Market Place; Some Call Unocal Ready for a Buyer
description: THE oil industry seems poised for a new wave of takeovers, several analysts say. One of the companies they are wondering about is the Unocal Corporation, which is about the right size to be acquired and has just gone through a change in top management.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: U.S. Delays Medicare Payments
description: In a fiscal sleight of hand, the Federal Government has begun delaying payment of Medicare bills by 10 days as a means of stretching out payments and cutting $815 million from this year's budget deficit. On Oct. 1 the delay will be extended to 14 days on the nearly $80 billion of Medicare claims that hospitals, physicians and individuals are expected to file in the 1989 fiscal year.

title: Maxwell's Plum, a 60's Symbol, Closes
description: Maxwell's Plum, the flamboyant restaurant and singles bar that, more than any place of its kind, symbolized two social revolutions of the 1960's - sex and food - closed abruptly yesterday. Warner LeRoy, the owner of the 22-year-old establishment on First Avenue at 64th Street, likened its demise to that of an affair that had gone on too long, in the end losing its spontaneity and adventure.

title: JOBSON TAKES LIBERTY CUP
description: It was almost a clean sweep yesterday for Gary Jobson, the skipper of the United States boat in the Liberty Cup regatta.

title: Volunteer Army Helps Defeat Rash of Forest Fires in Bear Mountain Area
description: Larry Briggi was supposed to spend the day sailing off Connecticut with his girlfriend. Steven Frumkin ''would have had a barbecue like everyone else.'' Scott Cruzen expected to go fishing. Instead they were volunteers in Harriman State Park and the adjoining Bear Mountain State Park fighting some of the worst forest fires in New York State in two decades.

title: 2 Immigrants Chase a Dream and Mourn a Child
description: Pak Cheong Jaing and Mei Ying Jaing said they were ''just crazy in love with their kid,'' their landlord recalled yesterday, but they worked such long hours that they felt they had to find another family to look after him.

title: Episcopalians Remain Split on Sexual Issues
description: After months of controversy, the leadership of the Episcopal Church has shown itself unwilling to depart from traditional church teachings about sexual morality but also unwilling to rule out change in the near future.

title: Cincinnati Journal Debating the Fitness Of Enshrining Swine
description: The debate over the flying pigs boiled down to a simple issue: Do Cincinnatians lack a sense of humor?

title: Brooklyn Cabby Slain In Apparent Robbery
description: A 30-year-old gypsy-cab driver was shot dead during an apparent robbery in Brooklyn early yesterday, the police said.

title: Punch and Swagger From Little Feat
description: Little Feat's reputation kept on growing after Lowell George, its lead guitarist, singer and main songwriter, died in 1979. A reconstituted Little Feat, which included the band's survivors plus a singer, Craig Fuller, and a guitarist, Fred Tackett, appeared last Wednesday at the Ritz. The group carries the band's good name and the punch and swagger of its rhythms, but it has absolutely nothing new to offer; a handful of songs from the band's forthcoming album, due Aug. 2, sounded like the old Little Feat minus its brains. For earlier songs, Mr. Fuller tried to match George's vocals phrase for phrase.

title: International Report; Safeguards Seen From Oil Rig Blast
description: Government and industry officials said a likely result of this week's disaster on the Piper Alpha oil platform in the North Sea, in which 166 workers are presumed to be dead, is that there will be major safety-minded features in future oil rigs.

title: Review/Television; Lillian Gish Looks Back on a Century
description: You can't get off to a better start than Lillian Gish, now in her 90's and still managing to hit just the right balance between fragility and feistiness. Beginning its second season on public television, tonight at 9 on Channel 13, ''American Masters'' is presenting ''Lillian Gish: The Actor's Life for Me.'' Produced and directed by Terry Sanders, the hourlong film offers a profile of Miss Gish as ''told in her own memories, thoughts and words.'' The narrator is Eva Marie Saint. The opening moments are worrying as we watch Miss Gish board a jetliner and settle in for what looks suspiciously like a journey into tired devices. But it seems that the point of this elaborate setup is merely to illustrate the length of Miss Gish's ''journey across the 20th century.''

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis

title: Diane J. Levine Weds Lawrence F. Yermack
description: The Loeb Boathouse in Central Park was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Diane J. Levine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jason Levine of Woonsocket, R.I., to Lawrence F. Yermack, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Murray Yermack of the Bronx. Rabbi Pesach Krauss officiated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have to say what we feel, or else things will never change.'' - Micaela Cuevas, an opposition supporter in Mexican election, at demonstration yesterday. [ A6:2. ]

title: Meese Urges Action To Punish Discloser Of Report on Ethics
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that anyone who disclosed to the press details of a special prosecutor's report concerning his ethical conduct should be held in contempt of court.

title: Jackie Presser, President of the Besieged Teamsters' Union, Dies in Cleveland at 61
description: Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the nation's largest union, died late Saturday at a hospital in the Cleveland suburb of Lakewood. He was 61 years old.

title: Opportunity Knocks for Cyclist
description: The night before the Tour de France began in Brittany on July 4, Nathan Dahlberg was home in Ghent, Belgium, cooking dinner when he heard a knock at the door.

title: Ergo Propter Hoc
description: Fifteen months ago, a harangue in this space was titled ''New Teapot Dome''; I gloomily prophesied that the Wedtech scandal, then overshadowed by the Iran-contra affair, ''may turn out to be our era's top-dollar corruption.''

title: The Media Business: Advertising; N. W. Ayer's Stake
description: Since 1975, N. W. Ayer Inc. has held a minority interest in Charles Barker P.L.C., of London, and Barker has had a subsidiary called Ayer Barker. Now, Ayer plans to acquire a 25 percent position in Ayer Barker and will work toward total ownership. This will not affect its equity in Charles Barker, which is now at 12.7 percent.

title: National League; Cubs Top Padres; Maddux Wins 15th
description: Greg Maddux won his 15th game and singled in the go-ahead run today as the Chicago Cubs beat the San Diego Padres, 4-2, to snap a four-game losing streak.

title: Richard Schulze-Kossens, Hitler Adjutant
description: Richard Schulze-Kossens, an SS officer who was an adjutant to Adolf Hitler for several years, died of lung cancer on July 3, according to the West German newspaper Die Welt. He was 73 years old.

title: 2 Men Arrested In Arson Death On Bus in Bronx
description: Two Bronx men were arrested yesterday and charged in the arson fire of an abandoned schoolbus last week and in the death of a 35-year-old woman who had been sleeping inside, the police said.

title: BAUER REGAINS LEAD
description: Steve Bauer of Canada regained the overall lead in the Tour de France today while Rolf Golz of West Germany won the day's 136-mile eighth stage.

title: Bridge
description: A defender who misjudges early in the play, giving the declarer some help, should not be too quick to apologize in the post-mortem. On some rare occasions, the gods of the game will play a little joke, permitting him to prove in the post-mortem that his error was in fact a farsighted stroke of genius.

title: Global Briefs
description: Poland could start fully servicing its huge foreign debt by the end of 1991 provided exports continue to grow, the National Bank president, Wladyslaw Baka, said. Mr. Baka, appointed Poland's economic chief last month, also indicated he would follow a tight money policy to curb inflation that some economists say will exceed 60 percent by year-end. Mr. Baka said that exports had risen by more than 20 percent this year and that a continued increase could help Poland meet interest payments by 1991 and then start repaying the debt of more than $39 billion.

title: Sports World Specials; By the Book
description: Three years ago, in a stable in Metropolis, Ill., Red Clark discovered what he had been looking for.

title: American League; Weiss Leads A's Past Tigers
description: Life can be complicated for a rookie on a team loaded with sluggers. Just ask Walt Weiss.

title:
Rowing;
U.S. Finishes a Lackluster 5th
description: LEAD: The Lucerne International Rowing Regatta ended today with unfulfilled expectations for the United States eight-oared crew, which finished fifth in a six-boat final won by a previously untried West German boat., Special to the New York Times

title: Reviews/Music; New Opera By Lessing And Glass
description: ''The Making of the Representative for Planet 8,'' which had its world premiere here Friday night by the Houston Grand Opera at the Wortham Theater Center, counts as Philip Glass's latest opera. But it is really some two years old, given the difficulties of assembling an international consortium to produce it. Which may help explain the rather stale musical impression made by what is certainly a laudably ambitious effort.

title: Kuwait Signs Weapons Deal With Moscow
description: Two days after the Senate voted to block the sale of American missiles to Kuwait, the Persian Gulf sheikdom has signed an arms deal with Moscow, the official Kuwait News Agency reported.

title: Arafat Backers' Ouster From Beirut Shifts P.L.O. Tensions to South
description: Two days after the last Palestinian fighters loyal to Yasir Arafat were evicted from Beirut, tension in Lebanon has shifted to Palestinan districts near the southern port city of Sidon.

title: Business People; Pickens Son Specializes in Acquisition Offers
description: Thomas B. Pickens 3d, president of Dallas-based T. B. Pickens & Company, which is involved in mergers, acquisitions and special investment situations, seems to be following at least one of his family lines with his recent offer to buy the Catalyst Energy Corporation.

title: British Report Said to Fault U.S. on Airbus
description: A British intelligence report based on radio communications monitored in the Persian Gulf is ''severely critical'' of the United States Navy in the downing of an Iranian airliner on July 3, The Sunday Times of London reported.

title: Democrat Is Wary of Bush
description: Representative Mary Rose Oaker, vice chairman of the House Democratic Caucus, is warning her party not to become overconfident about defeating Vice President Bush in November. ''Everyone thinks he's sort of wimpy,'' the six-term Ohio Democrat said in an interview. ''I don't see him that way. He's a war hero. Wait until you see them pull all that stuff out.''

title: TV Notes
description: Vintage Woody Allen

title: CHANCES OF FED TIGHTENING GROW
description: The Federal Reserve Board may be forced to nudge up short-term interest rates again soon in order to moderate continued strength in the economy and to dampen persistent inflationary pressures, many credit market analysts contend.

title: A Modern-Day Rebel With a Historic Name
description: Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the opposition candidate who is claiming victory in the Mexican presidential election, used the moral and populist inheritance of his father, a revered former President, to run against the long-dominant political party his father helped to found.

title: WORLD BANK SETS ASIDE $500 MILLION FOR LOAN LOSSES
description: The World Bank, facing small but rising delinquencies on its loans for the first time in its history, has quietly raised provisions for loan losses to $500 million, from $100 million, according to bank officials.

title: Rangel Faults Press Coverage of Brawley Case
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, said yesterday that he believed the Tawana Brawley case would have been settled by now by the courts or by the criminal justice system if it had not been a front page story for so long.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 11, 1988: MONDAY

title: INSIDE
description: A Vision for Herald Square A plan that would route traffic on Broadway around Herald Square is being prepared by transportation officials. Page B1. MGM/UA Deal Reported At MGM/UA, a stake in MGM will be sold and United Artists will become a separate entity, according to an executive familiar with the deal. Page D1. Lightning Death in Park One man was killed and 10 people were injured in Brooklyn's Prospect Park when they were struck by lightning during a thunderstorm. Page B3. Jackie Presser Dies The president of the teamsters' union died Saturday in Lakewood, Ohio, at the age of 61. Page B5.

title: U.N. Chief Hopes Council Eases U.S.-Iran Tension
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, has begun a series of diplomatic contacts aimed at insuring that this week's Security Council debate on the downing of the Iranian airliner eases tensions between Iran and the United States and reduces the risk of terrorist reprisals, according to United Nations officials and diplomats.

title: USA TODAY PRODUCES READERS BUT NOT PROFITS
description: After nearly six years of hyperkinetic promotion by the Gannett Company, USA Today has earned itself more than five million readers and the grudging respect of competitors and many journalists.

title: MOST EXITING PLAYER, OR MOST INFURIATING?
description: EVERY once in a while, there are disparaging calls from the upper deck when Rickey Henderson walks to the plate, his ankles wrapped tightly in gauze and tape and covered by the white socks that are part of his uniform. If he hears them, he does not pay much attention. In a moment, they will be drowned out by the cheers that have welcomed Henderson since he arrived in New York more than three years ago to play baseball for the Yankees.

title: Review/Theater; A Labyrinthine Web of Suspicion in North Africa
description: Allan Havis's ''Morocco'' (at the WPA Theater) is an absorbing cat-and-mouse game in which one cannot always distinguish the cat from the mouse. Between the scenes and behind the lines, there is far more here than meets the eye.

title: Topics of The Times; What's Stale in Malaysia
description: In Malaysia, the idea of an independent judiciary is old hat, as musty a notion as freedom of the press and the rule of law - as outdated, even, as the nation's feisty 85-year-old founder, Prince Abdul Rahman.

title: A Sure Way to Cut Pentagon Waste
description: House members came close to approving an effective plan to shut some obsolete military bases last week, then shelved it and went home for the weekend. Preliminary votes showed solid support, but last-minute maneuvering by the Democratic leadership scuttled a similar plan last year. It's time, and there's plenty of reason, to let the apparent majority prevail.

title: Pakistan to Take Back Biharis in Bangladesh
description: An agreement has been reached to repatriate more than a quarter of a million Pakistanis who have been in Bangladesh for 17 years, a senior Bangladesh official said today.

title: Topics of The Times; A Soviet Marshal, Here!
description: Even one year ago, it would have been difficult to imagine the Pentagon wining and dining the Soviet Union's top military officer, let alone piping him aboard an aircraft carrier for an air show. Yet Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev was treated to precisely those events and more last week as he began a six-day visit to the United States. Such a high-ranking Soviet officer had not visited here since World War II.

title: Sports World Specials; Minding Manners
description: The United States Olympic Committee is apparently concerned with averting potential social blunders and general tactlessness by members of the press involved in the coverage of the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, this fall. So much so that the committee recently sent an advisory to editors regarding the customs and manners of the Korean people, along with helpful hints as a guide to correct behavior while covering the Games.

title: BOXER IS MAKING NAME FOR HIMSELF
description: The Cinderella story of Ed Hopson continues.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: From their glitter days of owning Studio 54 to their negotiation over who got the top bunk in the Federal penitentiary, Steve Rubell and Ian Schrager have never seemed particularly bashful.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Eating Light
description: Talk about a power lunch.

title: COLUMBUS CATCHER AWAITING MOMENT IN SPOTLIGHT AS ALL-STAR
description: Bob Geren has crouched behind home plate in more than 800 minor league games and watched dozens of teammates advance to the major leagues. Some went up after an injury or a trade. Some were called up after the rosters expanded to 40 players in September. Others, however, like Geren, were not called at all.

title: THE LATEST IN CADDIES
description: THERE is a movement within golf to get players walking again.

title: Parental Choice in Public Schools Gains
description: Betting that more variety and a bit of competition will make for better schools, a growing number of districts around the country are letting parents pick the public school their children will attend.

title: Dollar Higher Against Yen
description: The dollar began the week higher against the Japanese yen in early trading today, while stock prices eased.

title: Study Suggests a Partly Private Social Security
description: A study by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company recommended that part of the Social Security system be made private to avoid the temptation of squandering the huge surpluses accumulating in the system's trust funds.

title: Downing of Flight 655: Questions Keep Coming
description: When dawn broke in the Persian Gulf on July 3, American commanders there were armed with a valuable piece of secret information, United States military officials say. Intelligence experts had broken the coded electronic signals that Iranian F-14 planes had recently used to identify themselves.

title: The Media Business; Sales of Network Time Seen As Higher Than Expected
description: Despite the television writers' strike and the growing success of the cable networks, early signs are that the ''up front'' buying season for the three television networks will be stronger than anticipated, executives from advertising agencies and television networks say.

title: Jackson Offers His View Of His Convention Role
description: The closer the Rev. Jesse Jackson gets to the Democratic National Convention in Atlanta next week, the more he talks about it as a celebration of his campaign. Mr. Jackson speaks of the thousands of supporters who will join him there, the issues they will raise and the history they will make.

title: Peronists Choose a Governor To Oppose Alfonsin in 1989
description: Carlos Saul Menem, Governor of the northwestern province of La Rioja, has defeated the Peronist party leader, Antonio Cafiero, to become the opposition party's presidential nominee in next year's election.

title: Lightning Kills A Man in Park And Injures 10
description: A man was killed and 10 other people, including two children, were injured when they were struck by lightning in Prospect Park in Brooklyn during a thunderstorm yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Dukakis Finds the West As Pretty as a Picture
description: Michael S. Dukakis breathed the crisp mountain air this morning, strolled along a spectacular alpine lake and climbed atop rocks for a better view of snow-capped Rocky Mountain peaks.

title: FOSTER IS RELISHING LIFE AFTER BASEBALL
description: ''NOTHING but line drives, strictly line drives.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JULY 11, 1988
description: Companies

title: Asian Group Seeks to Pre-empt Khmer Rouge
description: In nearly every encounter with Asian officials during Secretary of State George P. Shultz's farewell swing through Asia, the same thorny question has come up: How do you prevent the Khmer Rouge from returning to power in Cambodia after Vietnam withdraws its troops?

title: SKUDIN BELONGS ON THE BEACH
description: JOHN SKUDIN became a lifeguard because it was the thing to do. Skudin was 16 years old and he was going to hang out on the beach anyway. Why not earn extra cash at the same time?

title: 2 Beaches Shut After Discovery Of More Waste
description: New discoveries of syringes and needles led officials to close two beaches yesterday - one on Fire Island and one on Staten Island - amid growing confusion over the sources of wastes that have turned up on the shore in the New York region in recent days.

title: SALLIE MAE PLANS $300 MILLION NOTE ISSUE
description: The schedule of new Treasury issues for this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills and tomorrow's auction of seven-year notes.

title: Crime's Link to Drugs Up Steeply in 12 Years
description: The link between drug use and crime rose sharply over a 12-year span ending in 1986, the Government reported today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; MAKERS OF COSTLY ART BOOKS BANKING ON FINE CATALOGUES
description: ART book publishers attend the same industry conventions, belong to the same publishers' association and fret about reviews and returns almost as much as publishers of novels and best-selling nonfiction do. But in important ways, art book publishers are a breed apart, and nowhere is that more apparent than in the catalogues they send to booksellers, librarians, reviewers, authors and agents.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Sandinistas Halt a Protest Rally By Using Tear Gas, Rarely Seen
description: Sandinista police used tear gas, rifle butts and truncheons to break up a spirited opposition rally here today.

title: Avoiding United States Unilateralism
description: At the time the United States Navy became involved in the Persian Gulf, circumstances seemed to dictate a unilateral approach. Washington's obsession with Moscow's intentions, the Kuwaiti request for protection of shipping addressed to both the superpowers and the repercussions of the Iran-contra affair, as well as a knee-jerk perception of the United Nations as incapable of effective conflict management or anything else, all pointed to unilateral intervention.

title: Let's Put Common Sense Into Our Libel Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Bally Selling Game Unit
description: The Bally Manufacturing Company said Friday that it had agreed in principle to sell its coin-operated amusement game manufacturing business to Williams Industries for $8 million. The sale would include Bally's pinball and video game manufacturing assets. But it would not involve Bally's Aladdin's Castle chain of amusement game arcades. The Aladdin's Castle group operates more than 300 arcades. Bally said it would expand the production of its fitness products at the factory where video and pinball games were produced.

title: Track and Field; Bubka Sets Record
description: Sergei Bubka of the Soviet Union broke his own world record in the pole vault today with a jump of 19 feet 10 1/2 inches at the Nikaia Grand Prix meet here.

title: Better Than $3.35, $4.25 or Even $5.05
description: Should the Federal minimum wage, frozen at $3.35 an hour since 1981, be raised?

title: Marilyn Shapiro, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Marilyn May Shapiro, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Tafler Shapiro of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Ralph Mark Schapira, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hans E. Schapira of New York. Rabbi Melvin Glazer performed the ceremony at the Jewish Center of Princeton.

title: Sports World Specials; Vote of Confidence
description: When Jim Abbott, the one-handed pitcher from the University of Michigan, was drafted in the first round by the California Angels earlier this month, there were those who scoffed at his chances of making a major league team.

title: Susan Schiffman Marries Christian Pestre in Jersey
description: The marriage of Susan Schiffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schiffman of New York, to Christian Pestre, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marc Pestre of Paris, took place yesterday. Judge Sylvia B. Pressler, the presiding judge of the Appellate Division of the Superior Court of New Jersey, officiated at her home in Englewood, N.J.

title: '63 F.B.I. Memo Ties Bush to Intelligence Agency
description: Vice President George Bush may have worked for the Central Intelligence Agency in 1963, more than a decade before becoming its Director, according to a magazine article that cites a recently discovered Federal Bureau of Investigation memorandum.

title: Flood Relief in Bangladesh
description: Army troops mounted a big rescue operation today after the death toll in annual floods rose to at least 121 people, forcing large-scale evacuation. At least 5 million people have been affected. An official at the Relief Ministry said soldiers were moving marooned people to safer areas but that rescue operations were difficult in the northeastern district of Sunamganj because all the roads were under deep water. There is no dry surface to land helicopters, he said, and the flooding has made the dropping of food packages nearly impossible.

title: Business People; Bridgestone Unit Gets Its First American Chief
description: The Bridgestone Corporation, the Japanese tire maker, has named an American tire executive, James P. McCann, to be president of its United States subsidiary, effective Aug. 1.

title: Vendors, at Odds With the Mayor, Face Fears of Removal
description: For the last 15 years Athanasios Mananas has stood on the same crowded corner along Manhattan's Avenue of the Americas with his vendor's cart of hot sausages and cold sodas, shish kebabs and faith.

title: Correction
description: A chart in Business Day on Thursday with an article about Spanish-language television misstated the 1987 after-tax income of Hispanic households in the nation. The correct figure is $115.6 billion.

title: Data on Hospital Mortality Rates Are Challenged
description: Three new studies challenge the validity of Federal data on mortality rates among Medicare patients at nearly 6,000 hospitals. The data were published in part to help patients assess hospitals.

title: Domingo in the Park: A Gift to New York, A Festival's Farewell
description: About four years ago, when Placido Domingo first offered to sing a free concert in Central Park as a gift to his fans in New York, the Parks Department told him it would be a lovely gesture, and that the city's security and sanitation services would cost him around $400,000. There would also, of course, be the expense of hiring an orchestra and renting a stage and a sound system, along with the crews to oversee them.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Romann & Tannenholz Gets Two Accounts
description: Romann & Tannenholz ended its week with two assignments. One sweet. One fast.

title: International Report; Duty on Japan Printers
description: The European Community announced on Friday a provisional dumping duty on Japanese daisy-wheel computer printers. The action follows the decision in late May to place a similar duty on the makers of dot matrix computer printers. The commission said a duty of 43.2 percent would be imposed on the daisy-wheel printers made by all companies except the Tokyo Electric Company and the Tokyo Juki Industrial Company, whose printers will be taxed at a lower rate of 12.4 percent.

title: Goldman, Sachs Succeeds In a Shift From Eurobonds
description: Like other big American investment firms, Goldman, Sachs & Company has found that intense competition has diminished the allure of the ''Big Bang'' of deregulation in London's stock and bond markets.

title: Boat Accident Kills 3
description: A 22-foot motorboat smashed into a concrete breakwall at the south end of Milwaukee's Lake Michigan harbor, killing all three passengers, a Coast Guard spokesman said today. The cause of the crash, which occurred about midnight Saturday, is being investigated.

title: Sears Role Seen At Texas Bank
description: Two subsidiaries of Sears, Roebuck & Company have agreed to participate in the First Republicbank Corporation's Government-assisted recapitalization plan, The Dallas Times Herald reported today.

title: Pick Wide Open in East Harlem District
description: In District 4 in New York City parents can enroll their children in any one of the district's 33 elementary school or 19 junior high school programs.

title: Singapore Journal; How to Marry Up, and Avoid the Frogs and Nerds
description: Daniel Lim is suffering from hypergamy, a widespread ailment that is causing Singapore's Government serious concern about the future of its economy, social structure and national defense.

title: Cuba Has to Do More Than Fix Up Its Prisons; Invasion by Airwaves
description: To the Editor:

title: MEXICANS PROTEST DELAY IN RESULTS OF THE ELECTIONS
description: Thousands of Mexicans gathered at vote tallying centers around the country today to protest the delay in announcing official results from the July 6 presidential election.

title: Atheist Challenges Order to Attend A.A. Meetings
description: The letter, addressed to the state office of the American Civil Liberties Union, was brief.

title: Plans to Split the Altar Split a Church
description: The Church of Notre Dame, poised on the high ramparts of Morningside Park, is one of Manhattan's spiritual sanctuaries, a tranquil Old World setting for meditation and prayer. But a fight over renovations of the church's marble-and-wood altar has divided the Roman Catholic parish and turned the spirit ugly.

title: Mets' Tumble Goes On
description: Like an actor falling on his face while making an exit, the Mets ended Act I of the season today by taking a mighty tumble: They lost their third straight game when the Houston Astros rallied for two runs in the ninth inning against Roger McDowell and Randy Myers and beat the Mets, 6-5.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-11

title: Action but No Consensus on Film Coloring
description: For the first time since motion pictures flickered into existence more than 90 years ago, a Government agency is likely to be empowered to decide which Hollywood films have artistic merit and deserve at least limited Federal protection.

title: Arab Youth Killed by Troops At Roadblock on West Bank
description: A 17-year-old Palestinian was shot dead early this morning by soldiers who opened fire on Arab protesters who had attacked them with rocks at a roadblock on the West Bank, an army spokesman said.

title: No One Called Shakespeare a Grammarian
description: To the Editor:

title: Economics of Revolution Bedevil Iran
description: A growing number of senior Iranian officials are warning that an acute economic crisis combined with the burdens of the war with Iraq are endangering the Iranian revolution.

title: YONKERS TROT GOES TO SOUTHERN NEWTON
description: On the richest night in New York State's harness racing history, Southern Newton captured the Yonkers Trot, the first leg of the triple crown for trotting.

title: Review/Music; City Opera's 'Rigoletto'
description: The production of ''Rigoletto'' that the New York City Opera introduced on Saturday evening had two bankable assets: the voices of Faith Esham and Richard Leech. Miss Esham as the virginal Gilda and Mr. Leech as her lecherous seducer, the Duke of Mantua, gave a patina of Verdian authority to a performance that otherwise dealt, at best, in promissory notes.

title: Metro Matters; By Taxing Itself, A Coalition Gives Life to a District
description: When landlords raise real-estate taxes, that's news.

title: INFIGHTING ERUPTS IN MEXICAN PARTY
description: Bitter infighting has erupted within Mexico's ruling circles over how to handle the results of last week's presidential elections, in which the official candidate's proclaimed victory is being strongly challenged.

title: New York City Police Dept. Has Never Used Dumdum Bullets
description: To the Editor:

title: Business People; Ex-Im Bank Position Expected for Arizonan
description: Richard C. Houseworth, a second-generation banker who worked to open Arizona to interstate banking, is expected to be nominated today by President Reagan to fill the balance of a four-year term as a director of the Export-Import Bank.

title: Books of The Times; Images of Protest in a Social History
description: The Sisterhood The True Story of the Women Who Changed the World By Marcia Cohen Illustrated. 445 pages. Simon & Schuster.

title: Guide to Avoid Broaching
description: DURING a New York Yacht Club regatta in Newport, R.I. in May, a fleet of racing boats encountered a cruise ship barreling along at about 15 knots. The ship kept bearing down, appearing not to change course. The sailboats had to move fast to get out of the way. And since they were all flying spinnakers, it was no easy task. Several boats broached in a mass of quivering rigs and thrashing sails.

title: Cuba Has to Do More Than Fix Up Its Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: PALACES OF THE MIND
description: MAYBE it was the only palace built on the site of a city dump. I mean, can you name another? Not long ago, someone showed me a scorecard from a White Sox game in 1938 and on it was the logo ''Comiskey Park: Baseball Palace of the World.''

title: The Curse of Campaign Fund Raising
description: Campaigns have always cost money but never the breathtaking $25 million it now takes to win the Presidential nomination of either party. Fund raising always mattered, but never was it so demanding, ceaseless and pivotal as it is today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Ranking among the leaders in home runs, batting average and runs batted in, Dave Winfield of the Yankees is making a bid to become the first major leaguer in years to win baseball's triple crown. Who did it last and who came closest since?

title: WALL ST. RETHINKS ITS GLOBAL PLANS
description: A year ago, the big London offices of Wall Street's leading investment banks seemed dedicated to slugging it out in the hotly competitive markets for international stocks and bonds.

title: MAGAZINES FIND VIDEO AN ATTRACTIVE MEDIUM
description: An increasing number of magazines, seeking wider audiences and new sources of income, are spotlighting themselves with television programming through home video cassettes, cable TV and broadcast television.

title: Racial Memo Costs Store Manager Her Job
description: A department store has apologized and dismissed a manager over a memorandum that told employees to turn away black customers who tried to return linen. Civil rights groups remained outraged over the incident.

title: Yanks Need Heroes; Royals Win At Stadium
description: When the Yankees resume the season on Thursday, they will send the hitting of Rickey Henderson, Don Mattingly and Dave Winfield and the relief pitching of Dave Righetti against recent history. The way the Yankees have played in the past few weeks, recent history may be favored to win.

title: Global Food Deficits Seen
description: The North American drought endangers world cereal stocks and could cause food shortages in the Third World, the Food and Agriculture Organization said in a report to be released Monday.

title: Fall Literary Readings Planned by 92d Street Y
description: Readings by three Nobel Prize-winning authors - Saul Bellow, Joseph Brodsky and Isaac Bashevis Singer - will mark the opening in October of the 50th-anniversary season of the Poetry Center at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; As Schumer Questions Farm Policy, He Earns Rural Critics of His Own
description: Charles E. Schumer is a city slicker and the first to admit it. The Democrat from Brooklyn, where a tree may grow but precious little wheat, barley or sorghum does, is an old hand on issues like banking, finance and the plight of the homeless.

title: Cuba Has to Do More Than Fix Up Its Prisons; Helsinki Pact Flouted
description: To the Editor:

title: Hitting in Brett's Footsteps
description: THE swing, as effortless in appearance as it is familiar, is the result of dozens of early springtime afternoons at Terry Park in Fort Myers, Fla. Day after day, through childhood and adolescence, Mike Greenwell headed for the snug wooden place where older citizens would pass the time watching the Kansas City Royals prepare for the baseball season, and Greenwell's idol would pass near enough for a close annual inspection.

title: Traffic Past Herald Square To Be Shifted
description: New York City transportation officials are planning to reroute traffic from Broadway at Herald Square by the early 1990's, a move, they say, that will be the most extensive reorganization of Manhattan's clogged traffic grid in decades.

title: 2 Dance Companies To Perform at Beacon
description: The West Side Cultural Center will present performances by the Pilobolus Dance Theater next Monday and the Miami City Ballet on July 22 at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 75th Street.

title: The World Bank's Growing Irrelevance
description: As even its traditional supporters recognize, the World Bank is slipping into obsolescence.

title: BIG INVESTORS FEAR EXCHANGES' PLAN
description: The automatic trading halts proposed by officials of the New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on Thursday are being opposed by some of the market's biggest and most influential investors.

title: Arms Inquiry Adds 2 Israeli Concerns
description: In a move that signals a widening of the military procurement inquiry, the Federal Bureau of Investigation is seeking evidence that two Israeli-controlled companies that bid on Pentagon contracts had business ties to Melvyn R. Paisley, a former Navy official and a central figure in the affair.

title: Four-Party Talks on Angola Resume Today in New York
description: Officials from the United States, South Africa, Angola and Cuba will meet in New York on Monday to try to reach agreement on a Cuban troop withdrawal from Angola and black majority rule in South-West Africa.

title: Outdoors: The Dance of the Tarpon
description: STILL hopeful after two fruitless mornings casting into the Homosassa Bay's shallow waters, I tossed a dark red, feathered jig three feet from a telltale swirl and retrieved it routinely with a swift, jerky action. The lure suddenly slammed to a halt, dead.

title: Why Awad Expulsion Resembles a U.S. Case
description: To the Editor:

title: R. R. Van Anda, Architect, And Bonnie Akers Are Wed
description: The marriage of Bonnie Louisa Akers to Richard Rankine Van Anda took place yesterday in St. Helena, Calif. The Rev. Diane K. Hooge, an American Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Meadowood resort.

title: Fitness; Ideal Weight Is Just an Elbow Away
description: NEARLY everyone would like to lose a little weight. Nearly everyone is on a diet, is contemplating beginning a diet or just fell off a diet. Some people even exercise and diet at the same time, a modern form of masochism. To say that Americans are a bit obsessed with weight is to state the obvious.

title: South Africa's Strategy on Angola Falls Short, Enhancing Cubans' Role
description: South Africa's military strategy in Angola appears to have backfired, placing the Pretoria Government in an uncomfortable bargaining position in the latest round of talks on the Angolan conflict. And the South Africans are finding their image of invincibilty in southern Africa challenged by the Cuban forces allied with the Angolan Government.

title: Hasbro in Accord For Coleco Lines
description: Hasbro Inc. said it had reached an agreement with Coleco Industries to buy part of Coleco's indoor and outdoor children's furniture and ride-on toy product lines for $21 million. Two manufacturing plants in Amsterdam, N.Y., that were recently closed are also included, the company said.

title: Memory-Resident Utilities: Built-In Convenience
description: MEMORY-RESIDENT utilities are programs that you can load into your computer's built-in memory and forget about until you need them.

title: Carpenter Sues Leona Helmsley Over a Job
description: Lawyers for a carpenter who built elaborate television cabinets for Leona and Harry Helmsley's Greenwich, Conn., estate in 1985 filed a $250,000 civil lawsuit against Mrs. Helmsley in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday, charging breach of contract.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Absolut's Budget Said To Be Record
description: ABSOLUT, Sweden's best-known entry into the United States vodka market, will have an ad budget of about $18 million for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

title: Anthony Holland Is Dead at 60; Actor, Ill With AIDS, Is a Suicide
description: Anthony Holland, an actor who was known best for his comic performances in theater, film and television, committed suicide early Sunday morning in his apartment in Manhattan, his cousin, Jessica Holland, said.

title: Curbing Street Vendors
description: Everyone wants to do business at New York's busiest corners: missionaries and card sharps, break dancers and book salesmen - and, as always, vendors. Many peddle merchandise but none serve so basic a need as the food vendors. In this age of budget gourmetry, they have gone from hot dogs and peanuts to falafel, shish kebab, egg rolls and deluxe ice cream. Yet not even the need for a quick lunch in crowded midtown justifies the congestion when the food vendors all swarm to the busiest intersections, snarling movement and dirtying the streets.

title: Women Rabbis
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Players Lose in Court
description: The National Football League Players Association's request for unrestricted free agency for 280 of its members was denied yesterday by Judge David Doty in United States District Court in Minneapolis.

title: International Research & Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mexican Political Foes Block Bridge to El Paso
description: In the cool darkness after midnight this morning, the great arched bridge here that is usually one of the busiest crossing points along the long border with the United States looked like a jumbled campground.

title: Our Towns; Everyone Duck: It's Novice Day On the Fairways
description: Thursday is novice day at Orchard Hills public golf course. ''You're on your own now,'' the cashier, John Rogers, says after taking the golfers' money. ''Wear a helmet and goggles.''

title: Pentagon Resumes Paying Suppliers; Lack of Data Cited
description: The Pentagon today restored all contract payments that were blocked 10 days ago by Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci after several military programs were named in a broad inquiry into possible bribery and fraud in weapons procurement.

title: GRI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Gorbachev Seeks Europe Arms Talks
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, arrived here today and proposed a meeting of European leaders to achieve movement on reducing conventional arms.

title: Behind the Slap to PRI: The Pocketbook Ballot
description: The unparalleled opposition showing in the elections last week is being interpreted here as an indictment of Government policies that brought Mexico six years of economic stagnation.

title: Children Hunter Is Charged With Sex Crime
description: A self-styled bounty hunter of abducted children, who has traveled the country quizzing parents and police departments about missing-child cases, is in a county jail charged with attempted abduction and sexual abuse of young boys.

title: Exaggeration Seen in Report of Columbus Avenue's Demise
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article Sunday on Michael S. Dukakis's campaign for the Presidency gave an incorrect result for the baseball game Friday night between the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Los Angeles Dodgers. The Pirates won, 4 to 3.

title: On Horse Racing; Beating the Odds (by Just a Nose) at Japan's Racetracks
description: Baedeker, the trusted world-travel guide, offers some forbidding advice to a horseplayer visiting Japan: ''Betting is under state control and offers poor odds. In particular the system is so complicated that it is virtually impossible for foreigners to participate.''

title: Jackson Camp Lacked Votes, Not Conviction
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani And Ruder Dispute Bill
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the United States Attorney for Manhattan disagreed today over whether laws should be passed permitting the Government to pay rewards, or bounties, to people who alert Federal prosecutors to insider trading and other securities fraud.

title: S.E.C. Bid For Change
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission sent to Congress today the final and most controversial portion of its legislative recommendations for changes in the financial markets.

title: Yes: Drug Tests for (Some) Officials
description: Does the Federal Government have the right ''to seize at random the bodily fluids of hundreds of thousands of its employees and search those fluids by urinalysis for evidence of drug abuse?'' That's what the American Civil Liberties Union and other critics of the Reagan Administration's random drug testing program are asking.

title: Mets, in First Place, A Puzzle to Johnson
description: Depending on how you look at it, the Mets either won the first half of the season by three and a half games and achieved success or they failed to win it big and jeopardized success.

title: Genetics Institute reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The latest 6-month results included a $5,732,000 gain on the sale of equity investment.

title: Yeutter Warns Korea on Beef
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today that South Korea must open up its beef market soon or face the possibility of trade retaliation.

title: Transplant Patient Dies
description: Clinton House, who survived 14 months with a donated heart and lungs he received after donating his own healthy heart in the nation's first domino donor transplant, died today, Johns Hopkins Hospital said.

title: Fab Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a $1,800,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Mexican Ruling Party Candidate Leading in First Official Returns
description: Carlos Salinas de Gortari of the ruling party took a commanding lead today as the first official returns from Mexico's presidential election were announced, five days after the Federal Electoral Commission initially said they would be made public.

title: A Modern Party Machine
description: The decisions by delegates to next week's Democratic National Convention will be forwarded to the chair and the American public by an electronic voting system that is said to be the fastest and most sophisticated ever used at a Presidential nomination convention.

title: An Ode to the Danube
description: Among the projects of the last, extraordinarily fertile decade of Leos Janacek's life was an attempted symphony on the subject of the Danube River. He set it aside without ever considering the work finished, but after his death in 1928 it was found that the sketches represented self-contained, continuous music.

title: Review/Opera; 'Die Zauberflote,' With No American Accent
description: When the New York City Opera's German-language production of ''Die Zauberflote'' appeared last season, it raised some questions. Why, for example, should a Central European work so dependent on the spoken word and so amenable to translation be entrusted to Americans forced to operate in a tongue other than their own?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Potter Advances: Third-seeded Barbara Potter of Woodbury, Conn., defeated unseeded Betsy Nagelsen of Kapalua Bay, Hawaii, 7-6, 7-5, yesterday in the first round of the $200,000 Virginia Slims of Newport tournament in Rhode Island. Three other seeded players advanced to the second round. No. 4 Ros Fairbank of San Diego beat Anne Smith of San Antonio, 6-4, 6-2. No. 5 Robin White of San Jose, Calif., eliminated Pilar Vasquez of Key Biscayne, Fla., 6-3, 6-3. No. 6 Gigi Fernandez of Puerto Rico beat Anna Maria Fernandez of Torrance, Calif., 6-2, 6-3.(AP) Arena Football Knights Lose Again: Keith Tinsley, signed to a contract last week, scored three touchdowns, two on catches of 38 and 14 yards and another on a 6-yard interception return as the Pittsburgh Gladiators routed the New York Knights, 44-28, last night at Madison Square Garden. Tinsley finished with eight catches for 105 yards in his debut with the Gladiators (6-5), who have already clinched a playoff spot. The Knights, who once trailed by 35-2, are 2-9 for the season and finished without a victory in six home games. (AP) Horse Racing Crusader Sword Wins: Crusader Sword, ridden by Pat Day, slipped through along the rail entering the stretch and romped to a four-length victory yesterday in the $33,000 Native Royalty Purse for three-year-olds and up at Belmont Park. Crusader Sword went one and one-sixteenth miles over a fast track in 1:43 1/5 to record his first victory in four starts this year. The Virginia-bred 3-year-old colt by Damascus earned $19,800 for Rokeby Stable and returned $3 for $2 to win.

title: Court Lets Baby M's Mother Write Book About the Child
description: Mary Beth Whitehead Gould received court approval yesterday to write about her daughter Melissa in a book on the bitter Baby M surrogacy fight.

title: An Insider's Guide Offers 'Ins' Advice on Hiring
description: ''The Federal Government is like the Pony Express, changing the riders, but not the horses,'' said Mark A. Abramson, executive director of the Center for Excellence in Government.

title: CPC International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a special gain of $176 million for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Review/Music; An All-Day Immersion in New British Works
description: The London Sinfonietta, which is celebrating its 20th anniversary this season, has built its reputation on the strength of its affinity for contemporary music from around the world.

title: Damaged Wildlife Shows Pollution Still Plagues Great Lakes
description: LEAD: FEDERAL and state regulators have shut the spigot on much of the muncipal sewage and industrial effluent that once flowed into the Great Lakes, but subtler sources of pollution continue to plague the lakes, recent studies show.

title: Sports of The Times; Trump: Promoter Or Adviser?
description: MORE than a year ago, Donald Trump was basking on the dais at the Grand Hyatt Hotel during the announcement of the Spinks-Cooney fight in the Atlantic City Convention Center only a roll of the dice away from his Trump Plaza casino-hotel. When the speeches ended, Trump was approached by someone who knew the zillionaire during one of his few financial flops -the demise of the United States Football League.

title: Chess
description: Lev Polugayevsky started badly but finished strongly to win the Sweden International Chess Tournament held May 9-21 in Haninge, a suburb of Stockholm. The 53-year-old Soviet grandmaster, a former world championship candidate, topped an almost-all-grandmaster field with an 8-3 score.

title: Roadway Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 18
Heinz Crop Losses
description: The H.J. Heinz Company said it expected to lose much of its Midwestern tomato and cucumber crops to the drought, despite recent scattered showers in growing regions. The food processor said it expected to harvest about 60 percent of its cucumber crop and 75 percent of its tomatoes in Ohio, Michigan and Indiana.

title: Passenger Traffic Down at Eastern
description: Eastern Airlines Inc. has reported a 15.7 percent decline in passenger traffic in June and said it reflected its continued ''downsizing.'' Revenue passenger miles, the number of miles flown by paying passengers, fell 18.6 percent for the first six months of 1988, compared with the first half of 1987.

title: Festival Latino to Present Plays, Films, Music and TV
description: The annual summer event for New Yorkers who feel at home in Spanish, the Festival Latino in New York, will open on Aug. 3, with plays, films, music and television programs running through Aug. 27.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the old days, you had to look out for broken bottles. Now it's needles and syringes. People need to use caution.'' - Dr. Stephen C. Joseph, New York City health commissioner, on beach pollution. [ B4:4. ]

title: Sale at Beecham For $91.5 Million
description: The Beecham Group P.L.C., the British pharmaceuticals company, said it had agreed to sell its American cosmetic business, which makes the Jovan and Vitabath brands, for $:53.8 million, or about $91.5 million. Its Chicago unit, Beecham Cosmetics Inc., is being purchased by a group organized by its management.

title: A Fair and Practical Plant-Closings Bill
description: The House is scheduled to vote this week on the controversial plant-closings bill, which would require businesses to give 60 days' notice when planning large layoffs or a complete shutdown. The Senate passed it by a surprisingly large 72-to-23 margin, but the bill needs veto-proof House approval, too. It is an overdue act of social justice.

title: U.S. and Soviets to Seek Ways To Avoid Fighting by Mistake
description: Top Soviet and American military officials announced plans today to set up a working group to consider ways to avoid unintended military confrontation.

title: Cocaine Addiction Isn't Forever

description: To the Editor:
