title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Algorex Corp., Hauppauge, L.I., which is engaged in design automation, computer-aided design systems and printed circuit boards, announced that Dr. Robert M. Brill had resigned as president, chief executive and a director to pursue other opportunities. Its chairman, Sheldon O. Newman, will assume Mr. Brill's duties.

title: U.S. Oil Rigs Increase
description: The number of rotary rigs working in the United States rose by 5 rigs, to 926, for the week ended last Friday, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. A year earlier, there were 891 working rigs, the company said. The count of rigs working offshore rose by 2, to 130, while the number of rigs working in shallow inland waters was unchanged at 28, Baker Hughes said. The rig count reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not the number producing oil.

title: Microscope Innovation
description: The ability of a microscope to reveal fine detail in a sample illuminated by ordinary light is ultimately limited by the wavelength of the light itself. If an object is smaller than a single wave of the light striking it, no lens, however powerful, can form an image of the object.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Della Femina Obtains Farrar, Straus Account
description: From coast to coast yesterday came announcements of account assignments. In New York, Della Femina, Sherman, the entertainment advertising subsidiary of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS, has become agency for Farrar, Straus & Giroux, the book publisher, whose budget should be around $1 million. Formerly the company was served by Sussman & Sugar, a subsidiary of the Omnicom Group.

title: Commerce Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hal Riney Is Selected For Fuji Photo Account
description: Hal Riney & Partners has hit the jackpot again.

title: Elsa Mott Ives Philanthropist, 83
description: Elsa Mott Ives, a philanthropist and the daughter of a founder of General Motors Corporation, died yesterday at King Edward Hospital in Hamilton, Bermuda. She was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan and Southampton, Bermuda.

title: What's In a Name? Often Confusion
description: PICTURE the scene: A team of doctors has just identified a strange and apparently new form of arthritis that showed up in Lyme, Conn., and they want to name it appropriately. They decide to call it ''Lyme arthritis,'' and thereby unwittingly manage to insure a certain measure of confusion about that disease for years. The disease will actually occur in many parts of the world, but some people will continue to assume it is a problem only in Connecticut because of its name.

title: Patterns
description: The storm crows of Seventh Avenue have come up with many explanations for the gloom and doom at the retail level in women's apparel, but one Wall Street analyst says they have missed the point.

title: Postal Service Loses Appeal on Perot
description: An appeals board of the General Services Administration yesterday denied the United States Postal Service's request for reinstatement of its contract with the Texas entrepreneur H. Ross Perot.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Books of The Times; In Defense of the Virtues of Solitude
description: Solitude A Return to the Self By Anthony Storr 216 pages. The Free Press. $17.95.

title: Paychex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective November 1987.

title: Pullman Holdings Increases Offer
description: The Pullman Company said that Pullman Holdings Inc. had increased the amount it would pay for all of the Pullman Company's stock to $7.75 a share in cash and debt securities, from $7.50 a share. Under the agreement, Pullman Holdings would pay $232.5 million in cash for 30 million common shares.

title: Market Place; Dollar Rise Brings Investors Home
description: IN recent years, the smart money was playing a falling dollar by investing in overseas securities. With dollars invested in securities denominated in rising currencies, global mutual funds were among the best-performing investments.

title: Timing Is Everything
description: So you want to hold a news conference, and you want a big turnout. What should you do? Well, assuming that timing is everything, schedule it for a Wednesday. That's what most people do. And make it at 10 A.M. By that time, the reasoning goes, most reporters are awake, but not yet hankering for lunch.

title: It's Not Just the Calories, It's Their Source
description: FAT calories appear to count more to the human body than do calories from carbohydrates, according to careful analysis of the diets and body fat content of 155 sedentary obese men.

title: Reagan Said to Pick Thornburgh To Succeed Meese at Justice Dept.
description: The White House has selected former Gov. Dick Thornburgh of Pennsylvania to succeed Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General, a White House official said today. President Reagan is expected to offer the job to Mr. Thornburgh in a White House meeting on Tuesday, the official said.

title: A Capital Conference
description: American and Soviet academicians convened in Alexandria, Va., last week to discuss political and economic developments in Eastern Europe. The keynote speaker, Zbigniew Brzezinski, called it ''a reflection of what is taking place in the Soviet Union - glasnost.''

title: Steps to Avoid Physical Strains of Computer Use
description: USING a computer can be a pain in the neck, the back, the arms, the wrists, the shoulders, the knees, the eyes and virtually every other part of the body. It doesn't have to be that way.

title: Sports People; Heat Hires Piston Aide
description: Ron Rothstein, a Detroit Pistons assistant coach, will be head coach for the Miami Heat of the National Basketball Association, the club said yesterday. Jodi Grossman, a spokeswoman for the club, said Rothstein would meet the news media today. Rothstein spent two years as the defensive specialist on the Pistons' staff. He was an assistant for three years with the Atlanta Hawks and a scout over five seasons for first the Hawks, then the Knicks. He began his coaching career at New Rochelle High School and Eastchester High School in Westchester County.(AP)

title: Peoples Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Commenting on second quarter earnings, the company said it indicates an improvement in core performance and did not include nonrecurring income such as that from the sale of indirect loans which added $785,000 to noninterest income during the second quarter of last year.

title: Glaucoma and Cataract: Closing In on Causes
description: EMPLOYING new techniques to grow thin layers of cells from the human eye in the laboratory, researchers believe they are closer to understanding why people develop glaucoma and cataracts.

Savings Units' Deposits Fall

title: U.S. COMPENSATION WILL BE PROVIDED IN AIRBUS DOWNING
description: President Reagan has decided that the United States will pay compensation to the families of the 290 passengers killed when an Iranian jetliner was shot down by an American warship, the White House announced today.

title: Convoy Member Is Arrested
description: A member of a peace group was arrested for the second time in three days today when trucks laden with food and medical supplies bound for Nicaragua tried to cross a bridge into Mexico, the officials said.

title: Isomedix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Details Given On Splitting MGM/UA
description: The MGM/UA Communications Company yesterday announced the details of a complicated reorganization plan through which the company would be divided into two entities: United Artists and MGM.

title: Mississippi River Journal; Slow Times on a Shallow Waterway
description: The sounds were gentle: shallow water lapping the brown mud below and red-winged blackbirds trilling away in the bushes nearby. Huck Finn and Jim were no doubt holed up on their raft along the banks of the river over on the Illinois side.

title: By Design; Boxer Shorts Meet the Sun
description: For years women have borrowed T-shirts, sweaters and jeans from their male friends and relatives. Now it is men's underwear they are appropriating. Boxer shorts - also having a big revival with men - have found new popularity as street wear for women.

title: Designatronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Share earnings and shares oustanding are adjusted to give retroactive effect to a 5 percent stock dividend declared in Sept. 1987 and 1986.

title: British Company Seeks Payless Data
description: The Ward White Group P.L.C. said that it had requested information from Payless Cashways Inc. and that it might make a takeover bid for the American home-improvement store chain. ''We were just requesting information as a fact-finding operation, that's all,'' said Philip Horwath, Ward White's secretary.

title: Beijing Journal To Fail Is Human, to Get Into a University Divine
description: A bell rang. Then, like coal rumbling down a tin chute, the slap of sandals and scuffle of sneakers grew to a low roar and the school's doors banged open, spewing out a torrent of teen-agers with faces furrowed in worry.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Robertson Rejoins Young & Rubicam
description: Michael R. Robertson is rejoining Young & Rubicam, New York, as executive vice president and a creative director, succeeding Louis DiJoseph, 58, who will be in charge of improving the company's creative product in Europe.

title: Northwest Cuts Fares
description: Northwest Airlines, a subsidiary of NWA Inc., today cut its lowest discount fares in more than 500 markets, with reductions ranging from $6 to $150 for round-trip tickets. Northwest also said adult passengers who begin their trips in Louisville, Ky.; Buffalo, and the Wisconsin cities of Green Bay and Madison would be eligible for children's excursion fares on tickets bought in July for travel during off-peak periods.

title: King Athelstan's Justice
description: About 10 centuries ago, the Anglo-Saxon King Athelstan -an advanced law-giver for his time - sent word to an archbishop that ''it seemed too cruel to him that a man should be killed so young [ at age 12 ] , or for so small an offence. . . . He said then that it seemed to him and to those with whom he had discussed it, that no man younger than fifteen should be killed unless he tried to defend himself or fled.''

title: Nancy Friday Weds Norman Pearlstine
description: Nancy Colbert Friday, the writer, and Norman Pearlstine, the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, were married last night at the Rainbow Room in New York. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard, a minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, performed the ceremony.

title: Stocks Modestly Higher in Slow Trading
description: Investors shrugged off a flow of positive news yesterday and the stock market closed modestly higher. It was the third-slowest trading day of the year, with 123.3 million shares changing hands, down from 136.1 million on Friday.

title: Western Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Affected by an additional tax expense of $340,000 as a result of the 1987 Puerto Rico tax reform package and also by a reduction in the gain on sale of securities of $321,000.

title: Error at Rocket Plant May Delay Shuttle Flight
description: DAMAGE to a test rocket in Utah, caused by a worker's mistake over the weekend, may force a new delay in the resumption of space shuttle flights, space agency officials said yesterday.

title: Texas System of Picking Judges Challenged
description: The method of electing Texas district judges was challenged today in a Federal lawsuit that charges that the at-large system makes it more difficult for Mexican-Americans and blacks to be elected.

title: Advanced Micro Devices Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mets to Sign McClure
description: The Mets will sign the left-hander Bob McClure today to replace the right-hander Rick Aguilera, who will undergo surgery tomorrow and be placed on the disabled list, Jay Horwitz, the Mets' spokesman, said last night.

description: To the Editor:

title: No Democracy? Blame Poverty.
description: ''It is obviously illusory to think of the full enjoyment of rights and liberties in the context of absolute poverty in which nearly 70 percent of the population in the country is vegetating.'' So said Gen. Henri Namphy last week as he ripped up Haiti's 1987 Constitution, the last tangible vestige of his country's recent bid for democratic change.

title: Sports People; Nilan Signs
description: The Rangers have re-signed the right wing Chris Nilan. Nilan, 30, was acquired from the Montreal Canadiens in January in exchange for draft considerations. He had 7 goals and 5 assists in 50 games with the Canadiens. After joining the Rangers, he had 3 goals and 5 assists in 22 games. Terms of the new contract were not disclosed.(AP)

title: Joint Chiefs Split on Next Gulf Commander
description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff have reportedly split over whether an Army general or a Navy admiral should be the next commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf and the Middle East.

title: Snags in Proxy Fights: Errors in the Tally
description: Millions of dollars are at stake. The management of corporations hangs in the balance. Sophisticated Wall Street firms and banks get involved. But when it comes down to the final vote in a proxy fight, what seems like the simplest task - counting the ballots - often gets fouled up.

title: Sports People; 8-1 Favorites
description: The British bookies have made Sandy Lyle of Scotland and Seve Ballesteros of Spain betting favorites for the British Open, which starts Thursday at Royal Lytham-St. Annes in Lytham, England. Lyle and Ballesteros were made 8-1 choices, and American golfers were put down as longshots. ''Maybe they know something I don't,'' said Lyle, winner of the Masters earlier this year and the leading money-winner on the PGA Tour. Lyle did have a more serious observation. ''The course looks to me to be one of the toughest we've ever played in the Open,'' he said. The course, on the west coast of England, has always been tough for Americans. Bobby Jones won here in 1926. But in the six British Opens played at this site since then, no American has won.(AP)

title: Britain Opens Inquiry Into Oil Rig Blast
description: As relatives of some of the victims charged that safety warnings had been ignored, the British Government today began an investigation of the North Sea oil-rig explosion that left 166 workers dead.

title: North Korea Rejects Overtures From Seoul
description: North Korea today rejected a South Korean proposal to end the animosity between the two countries, saying the plan served only to make the division permanent.

description: The Control Data Corporation has told its employees that it plans to make its computer disk drive group a wholly owned subsidiary.

description: Vice President Bush vowed today to make the expansion of domestic and foreign markets for farm products his top agriculture priority if he is elected President.

title: Love-Bead Alert: The Hippie Look Flowers Again
description: Jeans have holes again. Love beads are back. Short and tight is in. Tie-dyed shirts and hosiery are selling. It is not quite the dawning of a new age of Aquarius, but hippie fashions are making a comeback in the twilight of the 1980's. For example, at Bentley's, a dance club for fashion victims with a sense of humor, they are bringing back everything but free love.

title: Poll Finds Public Is Wary Of Both Bush and Dukakis
description: With four months to go until the Presidential election, the public is taking a harder look at both Vice President Bush and Michael S. Dukakis, and is not enchanted with either man, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: William R. Hamcke, Banker, 63
description: William R. Hamcke, former senior executive vice president and chief financial officer of Irving Trust Company, died of a heart attack Saturday at Stamford Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: Europe Votes on Disclosure
description: The European Community agreed today to establish disclosure requirements for stock purchases to deter hostile corporate takeovers within the 12-nation economic bloc.

title: Coffee Curbs Predicted
description: London coffee dealers predicted today that the International Coffee Organization would soon cut coffee producers' export quotas because of low prices, removing 1.5 million 60-kilo bags of coffee from the total of 54.5 million bags that members may now export. But forecasts of cold weather in Brazil, lifting prices today, may postpone the quota cut. London robusta coffee futures rose by $:21, or $35, to $:1,118, or $1,890, a metric ton.

title: Advanced Micro Net Soars
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. said its net income for the second quarter rose sharply from a year earlier. Earnings in the quarter totaled $23.5 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $2.8 million, or 4 cents a share. Revenue rose 22.8 percent, to $308.1 million, from $250.8 million.

description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $64,491,000, or 67 cents a share, from the February 1988 sale of the company's book publishing subsidiary. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $29,364,000, or 30 cents a share, from the sale of the company's interest in South China Morning Post, Ltd.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Leo Burnett Buys Stake
description: Leo Burnett International has acquired a minority position Nordskar & Thorkildsen of Oslo, Norway's 10th largest agency, which is expected to bill $14 million this year. Pepsi-Cola is one of its clients.

title: Printmaking for the Love of It
description: You'd never get Bob Blackburn, an artist, master printer and modest man, to admit that he had made ''a significant contribution to the cultural life of New York State.'' Yet that is the official reason he and the nonprofit Printmaking Workshop he founded 40 years ago were recently given a Governor's Art Award by the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: Review/Television; Poland's Struggle to Be
description: Watching ''The Struggles for Poland,'' the absorbing new public broadcasting series on that unlucky nation's efforts to find independence, you may wonder how anybody ever came up with the notion of a Polish joke.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Convenes With Pride But Is Concerned About Election
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which has suffered its moments of self-doubt in recent years, is meeting this week in an atmosphere of pride in recent accomplishments.

title: Gene is Used to 'Brand' Engineered Creatures
description: A TEXAS research group has patented a genetic ''branding iron'' for indelibly marking strains of laboratory animals to foil would-be mouse rustlers, flynappers and other genetic claim jumpers.

description: b-Includes a $135,000 gain from discontinued operations. The company said pretax income in the latest 9 months included other income of $657,000, which consisted of a $737,000 gain on sale of one of its product line, offset by settlement of litigation, in the third quarter.

title: For Day-Care Centers, School Doors Close
description: In six weeks, the staff at the Basic Trust Infant-Toddler Center will pack up the highchairs, the blocks, the goldfish, the cribs and the cots and move out of Public School 166 in Manhattan to new quarters five blocks away.

title: Off-Duty Jail Guard Hurt in Queens Racial Attack
description: An off-duty black correction officer was beaten Sunday with a steel pipe in a racial attack, when a group of white men tried to force him and his friends to leave a Queens beach, the authorities said.

title: Robert Ferro, 46, Dies; Wrote Books on Family
description: Robert Ferro, a writer, died of AIDS yesterday at his father's home in Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dr. Anthony L. Davidson, Surgeon, 43
description: Dr. Anthony Lewis Davidson, a surgeon, researcher and educator, died of colon cancer Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 43 years old.

description: Donald Trump yesterday declared himself an undisputed friend of the undisputed heavyweight champion.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Why do roosters crow? A.Experts who have studied roosters say they crow for a number of reasons, but mainly to maintain a certain dominance.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Up Modestly
description: Interest rates at the weekly auction of Treasury bills rose modestly yesterday, and now stand at the highest level since the middle of last October,when rising interest rates were one factor blamed for the sharp drop in stock prices.

title: Bridge
description: Take a few pairs of adjectives: superb and exasperating; attractive and misleading; well-designed and badly planned. All these apply to ''Teach Me to Play. A First Bridge Book,'' by Jude Goodwin and Don Ellison (available for $12.45, including postage, from Barclay Bridge Supplies, 8 Bush Avenue, Port Chester, N.Y. 10573). This is for children between ages 8 and 14.

description: * Alan Neadle was promoted to executive vice president at Princeton Partners.

title: Review/Dance; Explosions Of Sounds And Steps
description: Choreographers like to work with Harry de Wit. And it is easy to see why. The Dutch composer's music certainly doesn't take a back seat to the dancing, providing an easily complementary aural backdrop. Instead, he collaborates with an aggressiveness and sense of invention that lend extra energy to the dance. Or so it seemed in ''A Bone to Pick,'' a recent, 70-minute work by Mr. de Wit and Laurie Booth that was performed on Sunday afternoon at the Dance Laboratory at the State University College at Purchase, N.Y., as part of the Pepsico Summerfare festival.

title: Sihanouk Resigns as Head of Rebel Coalition
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk announced his resignation today as head of the guerrilla coalition fighting Cambodia's Vietnamese-backed Government. He said he would go into exile in France.

description: Amid heavy police security, two black families moved quietly into an all-white public housing development in South Boston today.

description: Apollo Computer Inc. said today that it had slightly exceeded its forecast for its unit volume shipments in the second quarter, even though the computer work station maker will report a loss for the period.

description: Six days after medical debris began turning up on New York area beaches, city and state officials were still unable yesterday to say where the material came from, what infections, if any, it might cause and how great a risk to public health it posed.

description: The company said on a pro-forma basis, it had net of $1,233,000, or 25 cents a share, on revenue of $25,483,000 for the year-ago quarter. The company terminated its S corporation tax status last August.

The fee was indluded in the accord for the Richmond-based company. In January, Robins agreed to be acquired by the American Home Products Corporation for a value of about $700 million.

description: Should New York stiffen its penalties for hate crimes? Should there be a permanent special state prosecutor for such crimes? description: Ten weeks after the nation's corn crop was sown, heat and drought are disrupting the plants at the crucial, delicate stage when they develop flowers, achieve pollination and form kernels.

description: LEAD: Last February, I lectured at a West Coast university on relations between Jews and blacks. The lecture was one I'd given at many schools over the past four years, and I had always respected the blacks in attendance as they struggled to come to terms with me, a black and a Jew, a combination that must've made me seem like a sociological mutant to them.

description: Donald L. Sturm, the chairman of Kiewit Continental Inc., settled charges today that he had helped a friend in an insider trading scheme involving the stock of Aviation Group Inc.

description: A key index of semiconductor industry sales remained at a high level in June, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today.

title: Review/Television; The Constitution: That's the Way It Is
description: How well does television cover the news? Figuring out how broadcasters have dealt with the Reagan era will alone be enough to keep expert analysts in business for years. Now, at 9 o'clock tonight on Channel 13, we are given an opportunity to see how television might have covered the ratification of the Constitution 200 years ago. The mind wobbles. Nevertheless, ''An Empire of Reason'' has recruited Walter Cronkite, John Chancellor, Robert McNeil, Phil Donahue and William F. Buckley Jr., among others, to look terribly serious and informed as they report on and interview actors playing everybody from Alexander Hamilton (Francois Giroday) to Melancthon Smith (Roberts Blossom.) Be grateful for modest efforts. After the national hoopla that greeted the Independence Bicentennial and the Statue of Liberty's 100th birthday, the public might well wonder what happened to the bicentennial of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights. The Reagan-appointed Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution, with Warren Burger as chairman, is becoming embroiled in allegations ranging from puzzling timidity to right-wing biases. Let it be said, with some relief, that ''An Empire of Reason,'' being presented by WNET and the New York Bar Association, received funds from the New York State Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution. This no doubt accounts for the presence of Governor Cuomo as a bit player.

title: Discount Retailer To Close 35 Stores

The affected stores are in West Virginia, Virginia, Indiana, Kentucky, Maryland, Ohio and Pennsylvania, the company said. About 700 to 1,000 jobs will be eliminated. A Federal bankruptcy judge last week gave Heck's permission to close 40 stores.

description: As courts and local governments begin to unlock the doors of all-male clubs to women, the Y.W.C.A. is resisting rising pressure to open jobs and membership to men.

title: Fruitless Search for Missing Girl Prompts Talk of Vigilante Action
description: Hundreds of residents of this coastal town have helped search a beach where a missing teen-ager's bicycle was found hidden in the brush. But her body has not been found after nearly a month, and some residents are talking about taking the law into their own hands.

title: Sports People; Robinson Collapses
description: The Baltimore Orioles' manager, Frank Robinson, was recuperating at home yesterday after collapsing at Baltimore-Washington International Airport, according to a team spokesman. Robinson, 52, was waiting for a flight to Cincinnati, where he was to attend the All Star Game, when he fell to the floor. He was with his wife, Barbara, and his daughter, Nichelle. The manager was taken home. Rick Vaughn, the Orioles' spokesman, said Robinson was expected to be able to manage the team Thursday night when it plays a doubleheader against the Minnesota Twins. Robinson, who has been bothered by a slipped disk since early in the season, aggravated the injury Sunday night after the Orioles had defeated the Texas Rangers, 2-1, at Memorial Stadium. He took painkillers early yesterday morning and apparently had a bad reaction, Vaughn said.(AP)

Zimmer chastised Dunston for missing three hit-and-run signs in the fifth inning of the game, which the Cubs won, 4-2. When the shortstop challenged Zimmer to fight, Andre Dawson stepped in and pulled the two apart, The Chicago Sun-Times reported yesterday. After being forced out at second base by the pitcher Greg Maddux in the fifth inning, Dunston was still getting up from his slide when Maddux ran into him, taking second on an error by the first baseman Keith Moreland. Zimmer spoke sharply to Dunston when he returned to the dugout, and the player reacted.. Dunston was replaced by Angel Salazar in the sixth inning. Neither Zimmer nor Dunston would comment on the incident.(AP)

In Cincinnati for the All-Star Game break, the St. Louis general manager, Dal Maxvill, said in a statement that Quisenberry would join the Cardinals for their home game Thursday against the San Diego Padres. Quisenberry, 35 years old, will join a team that has lost six consecutive games and 22 of its last 28. Cardinal relief pitchers have blown their last six save opportunities. Cardinal Manager Whitey Herzog was Quisenberry's first manager in the major leagues, in 1979 with the Royals. Quisenberry has 238 career saves and is tied with Sparky Lyle for fourth on the career list. He has a 51-43 record with a 2.55 earned run average. This season, he was 0-1 with the Royals with one save and a 3.55 e.r.a. Quisenberry was released by the Royals on July 4.(AP)

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Shriver Gains: Playing her first tournament since losing in the semifinals at Wimbledon, top-seeded Pam Shriver advanced yesterday to the second round of the Virginia Slims of Newport tournament. Shriver, ranked No. 4 in the world, defeated Terry Phelps of Larchmont, N.Y., 7-5, 6-1. Two other seeded players also advanced, but No. 8 Wendy Turnbull was upset. No. 2, Lori McNeil of Houston, defeated Michelle Jaggard of Australia, 6-3, 6-4. Seventh-seeded Gretchen Magers of San Antonio beat Katrina Adams of Chicago, 6-3, 6-2. Wendy White of Fort Worth eliminated Turnbull, 6-2, 6-4.(AP) 2 Favorites Lose in Sweden: Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden, the second-seeded player, and Menno Oosting of the Netherlands, seeded No. 4, were upset in the second round of the Swedish Open yesterday by unseeded players. Francesco Cancellotti of Italy eliminated Gustafsson, 7-6, 6-1, and Karel Novacek of Czechoslovakia scored a 6-1, 6-2 triumph over Oosting. (AP) Mecir Advances: Top-seeded Miroslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia eliminated Thierry Tulasne of France, 6-3, 2-6, 6-2, in the second round of the Nabisco Grand Prix tournament in Stuttgart, West Germany. In another second-round match, ninth-seeded Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina defeated Damir Keretic of West Germany, 5-7, 6-3, 7-5.(AP) Horvath Is Upset: Kathy Horvath, the defending champion and the seventh seeded-player in the Belgian Open, was upset by Silvia La Fratta of Italy, 7-5, 5-7, 6-4, in their first-round match in Brussels. Other favorites won as expected. Second-seeded Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria defeated Laura Golarsa of Italy, 6-1, 6-0; fourth-seeded Arantxa Sanchez of Spain beat Silke Meier of West Germany, 6-0, 6-1; and fifth-seeded Isabel Cueto of West Germany downed Maria Strandlund of Sweden, 6-2, 6-3.(AP) Golf Rosenzweig-Ruggiero Duo Wins: Sam Rosenzweig, who returned to competition a few months ago after a four-year layoff because of surgery for a herniated disk, and Frank Ruggiero of Rockland Valley combined for a 29-30-59 to win the Met Golf Association/Met Life Met Team Championship at Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. Tom Montagna and Wally Chapman of Suburban (30,30-60) and Bob Russano and Bob Finnelli of Beaver Brook (32,28-60) tied for second place.

title: Shultz and Aquino Call Agreement Near On Philippine Bases
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and President Corazon C. Aquino said today that they were confident that Washington and Manila would conclude an interim agreement for two American military bases in the Philippines by the end of the month.

description: WHILE many Soviet citizens stand in interminable queues to buy meat, Arthur Stepanyan and his wife, Olga, don't bother. They eat almost no meat at all and serve it to their children only once or twice a week. They don't think meat is healthful.

description: A lawyer testified yesterday that an officer of the Wedtech Corporation urged him to devise a way for company executives to sell their stock to Wedtech's Hispanic co-founder, allowing the company to defraud the Small Business Administration by appearing to be minority-controlled.

title: U.S. Not Monitoring Air Traffic Control In the Persian Gulf
description: American warships in the Persian Gulf do not routinely monitor civilian air traffic control channels and have not been ordered to do so since the American downing of an Iranian airliner last week, Navy officers said today.

title: Illinois Legislature Moves to Give Parents Control of the Chicago Schools
description: The Illinois Legislature, responding to criticism of Chicago public schools as the nation's worst, has passed a bill to completely restructure the system and shift power for running the schools largely to parents.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Polaroid will sell conventional film, challenging Kodak and Fuji in the $7 billion world market. The change reflects the declining popularity of the instant photography market. [ Page D1. ] Coleco filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors under Chapter 11. The filing by the maker of Cabbage Patch dolls was accompanied by a management shakeup. [ D1. ] Citibank will triple the minimum balance required to avoid fees on checking accounts. That could raise the cost of checking for more than 40 percent of Citibank's customers. [ D3. ] Merrill Lynch's quarterly profits fell 35.8 percent, reflecting the sluggish brokerage business. [ D4. ] Intel's net nearly tripled, spurred by the popularity of its latest microprocessor. [ D4. ] Braniff will buy 12 small jets and build a hub in Kansas City, Mo., the airline's new management said. [ D2. ] Anacomp will acquire Xidex, a microfilm manufacturer, for $10 a share in cash, or about $415 million. [ D4. ] Cullum supermarkets received a buyout offer of $360.8 million in cash. [ D4. ] Coca-Cola agreed to change the wording on packaging of its new Minute Maid Premium Choice orange juice. [ D20. ] Washington Post staff members withheld their bylines in a protest marking two years of working without a contract. [ D20. ] THE ECONOMY The drought will cut the corn harvest to 5.2 billion bushels, 2.1 billion bushels less than expected when the crop was planted, the Agriculture Department said. [ D1. ] Prices of farm crops rebounded before the report was released. [ D6. ] Federal and private spending on biotechnology research and development exceeded $4.5 billion last year, the Government said. The spending and industry sales of more than $1 billion puts the U.S. well ahead in the biotechnology race. [ D1. ] A Taiwan businessman accused of insider trading tried to shift millions of dollars to Hong Kong illegally and maintained contacts with several Wall Street analysts, the S.E.C. asserted. [ D1. ] The Government will equip the nation's 52,000 pharmacies with computer terminals to enable them to keep track of the medications and drug expenditures of Medicare patients. [ A1. ] Legislators contended that the S.E.C. caved in to industry pressure concerning reforms of its arbitration processes. [ D15. ] Harvard Business School will require students to study ethics in a three-week course at the start of the fall semester. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL The new capital guidelines for banks will have a broad impact on banks, their borrowers and the economy. Many large American and Japanese banks are expected to slow their lending. [ D1. ] MARKETS Stock prices sagged in moderate trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 18.67 points, to close at 2,092.64, and has now pulled back by more than 65 points since last Tuesday, when it reached its highest level since October's market collapse. [ D10. ] Treasury note and bond prices fell as investors stayed on the sidelines in advance of today's Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman. [ D18. ] The dollar slipped as profit taking pushed it lower against most major currencies. On the Comex, gold rose $2.40, to $437. [ D17. ] Crude oil prices weakened further in volatile New York trading, but unleaded gasoline strengthened. [ D17. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A close look at the U.S. trade deficit suggests that foreign policymakers will have to be more accommodating than the optimists would like to believe. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Basic industries may give investors a pleasant surprise if the last-minute earnings estimates are right. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: Review/Dance; Cunningham's Patterns of Stillness
description: It is likely that the performances by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, on an outdoor stage at Battery Park City in the early evening on Saturday and Sunday, will prove to have been one of the highlights of the First New York International Festival of the Arts. Mr. Cunningham believes in making dances that can fit into a variety of spaces. But the company rarely performs out of doors in New York City. And so this preview of ''Five Stone Wind,'' seen on Saturday, was in itself a special event.

title: Drug Cheaters Are Growing Smarter
description: Beneath the glitter and glory of the 1988 Olympic Games, there continues an inglorious cat-and-mouse game pitting athletes who use banned substances against officials determined to catch them cheating.

title: Cullum Gets Buyout Offer
description: The Cullum Companies, the dominant supermarket chain in North Texas, said today that a group including its top management and a private investment fund headed by Morgan Stanley & Company had offered to buy Cullum for $360.8 million in cash.

title: Bridge
description: In general, a partnership that finds a satisfactory major-suit fit has no reason to look further. But it is also true, and obvious, that 9 trumps are better than 8, and 10 are better than 9.

description: In addition to being a writer for People magazine, Fred A. Bernstein is involved with an organization called The Princeton Review, which tutors students for the Scholastic Aptitude Test. It was at that organization that he realized there was a paucity of advertising media to reach such people.

description: For Britain, the huge arms sale to Saudi Arabia announced last week represents both a strategic and an economic coup for the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, bolstering Britain's influence in the Persian Gulf and guaranteeing jobs at home.

description: The Royal Spanish National Ballet does not have great dancers but proficient ones. No matter. The company's New York debut Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House was greeted with wave after wave of delirious applause.

title: Research Tax Credit
description: The Reagan Administration favors a permanent tax credit for research and experimentation, Dennis Ross, Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary, told a Senate finance subcommittee today. The current 20 percent tax credit for research expires at the end of 1988. The House Ways and Means Committee approved a two-year extension but the Senate panel is considering a permanent extension.

title: For Iranians, Redress Without Strings
description: President Reagan has decided to pay compensation to families of those who died in the Iranian airliner mistakenly shot down by the U.S.S. Vincennes. That's plainly the right decision. But it prompts a tough question: Should compensation be linked to other goals, like return of the American hostages held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon, or an end to the Iran-Iraq war?

title: Corn Harvest Will Fall 29%, Report Says
description: The Agriculture Department, in a long-awaited report, estimated today that the drought would cut the nation's corn harvest to 5.2 billion bushels, 2.1 billion less than was expected when the crop was planted.

title: Yukon Pacific
description: The CSX Corporation said it had raised its stake in the Yukon Pacific Corporation of Anchorage to 54 percent, becoming Yukon's largest shareholder. CSX already owned about 30 percent of the stock in Yukon Pacific, which has been actively lobbying for the construction of the Trans-Alaska Gas System, an 800-mile pipeline that would export natural gas from the state's North Slope to Pacific Rim countries. CSX, which is based in Richmond, also operates in the transportation, technology and properties businesses.

title: Sports People; Ciccarelli on Defense
description: On trial in Toronto's provincial court on charges of assault during an incident which occurred in a National Hockey League game in January, Dino Ciccarelli of the Minnesota North Stars, pleading not guilty, testified Monday that he was acting in self defense and that the play in question was ''part of the game.'' He said he had ''definitely no intention'' of injuring Luke Richardson, a defenseman for the Toronto Maple Leafs. ''His stick was up clearly before mine was and I was reacting,'' Ciccarelli told Judge Sidney Harris, who has reserved judgment until Aug. 24. Richardson was not injured, but Ciccarelli was ejected and later given a 10-day suspension. He testified that he struck Richardson on the side of the helmet after Richardson had cross-checked him in the second period of the game. (AP)

title: Sports People; Ready to Resign
description: After an investigation that revealed improper personal use of gifts and services, Neale Stoner, the athletic director at the University of Illinois since 1979, is expected to resign within two days, according to Morton Weir, the school's chancellor. Weir said that Stoner had used athletic association employees to perform personal work and would step down as soon as details of an agreement are reached. ''This past week, Neale Stoner and I have spent many hours reviewing all that has happened in the past month or so and both of us have reluctantly concluded that these events have made it impossible for him to continue to be effective as director of athletics,'' said Weir. He added that the school's investigation revealed that over a five-year period, athletic association employees performed about $904 of work on Stoner's home, yard and family cars. The university began an investigation this spring after employees charged that they had been ordered to do Stoner's chores.(AP)

title: Boxing Notebook; Cayton Is Shocked By Trump's Move
description: On June 27, when Mike Tyson fought Michael Spinks in Atlantic City, there was a pre-bout celebrity party at Trump Plaza that Bill Cayton attended with his family.

title: DEBATE ON AIRBUS POSTPONED AT U.N.
description: A Security Council debate on the American downing of an Iranian passenger plane was postponed today as diplomats said Iran was having difficulty lining up support for a resolution condemning the United States.

title: Citing Race, Jersey Bars Student-Shift Plan
description: New Jersey's Education Commissioner today prohibited Englewood Cliffs from removing its students from a predominantly minority-group high school in Englewood, ruling that a withdrawal would have a ''significant negative impact'' on racial balance and educational quality.

title: Alfred Harvey Wheeler, Teacher, 83
description: Alfred Harvey Wheeler, a social studies teacher in the New York City public school system for 42 years, died yesterday at his home in Huntington, L.I., after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

description: When a team of New England college football All-Stars embarks on a 17-day goodwill mission to England today, the purposes of the four-game trip will be to teach basic football skills, to provide some exposure to Europeans and perhaps to give John Miller a taste of victory.

description: No one thinks of Michael S. Dukakis as a big risk-taker. But his choice of Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas as a running mate represents a series of gambles that the Massachusetts Governor's admirers see as bold and his detractors see as dangerous.

title: A Food Pantry Where the Poor Help the Poor
description: SOMETIMES, the rich feed the poor. They contribute to charities, or they volunteer in soup kitchens. But often, the poor feed the poor.

description: Most staff members of The Washington Post withheld their bylines and credits from the newspaper yesterday and planned to do the same today in a protest marking the second anniversary of the expiration of their union's contract with the newspaper.

title: Why the Rush on Nuclear Waste?
description: LEAD: The Energy Department is hell-bent on opening an underground disposal facility for radioactive waste in New Mexico that may be technically flawed. Unless Congress stops the department, at a minimum the public health and safety of New Mexicans and perhaps Texans may be jeopardized.

description: Ken Flach and Robert Seguso, the Wimbledon doubles champions, and John McEnroe and Andre Agassi will make up the United States Davis Cup squad that will face Argentina July 22-24.

title: Sports People; 3 Jet Rookies Unsigned
description: With rookies scheduled to report by Friday night, it became nine down and three to go for the Jets yesterday when they signed three more of their 12 draft choices. Signing were James Hasty, a cornerback from Washington State, who was the Jets' second pick of the third round; Mike Withycombe of Fresno State, a tackle and the fifth-round pick, and John Galvin of Boston College, a linebacker and the 11th-round choice. Only three draftees remain unsigned, including the top choice. Dave Cadigan, an of-fensive tackle from Southern Cal. (AP)

title: Bentsen to Run Two Races
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, selected by Michael S. Dukakis to be his running mate, will continue his bid for a fourth term in the Senate, a dual campaign made legal in Texas in 1959 to let Lyndon B. Johnson run two races. If Mr. Bentsen wins both races this year, his Senate seat would become vacant in January. Gov. Bill Clements of Texas, a Republican, would then appoint a replacement to serve until a special election.

title: Mudslide Kills 35 in China
description: A mudslide killed 35 workers at a power station in southwestern China, where flooding after heavy rains had already claimed 76 lives, the official New China News Agency reported today. The slide also injured 10 workers when it swept through an electric generating plant in Sichuan on Sunday evening, the agency reported.

title: Merrill Lynch Profits Fall 35.8% in Quarter
description: Reflecting the slowdown in its brokerage business, Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that its profits fell 35.8 percent in the second quarter.

title: Aaron Solomon, 80, a Manhattan Lawyer
description: Aaron Solomon, a New York lawyer who specialized in labor relations, died of a heart attack yesterday at New York University Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title:
At the Nation's Table;
Kahului, Hawaii
description: LEAD: MAUI BAGEL, a small bakery and delicatessen in a converted sailboard shop, is the only bagel bakery on Maui. Two miles from the Kahului Airport, the shop is on the road to everywhere: Lahaina, Kihei, the Haleakala crater and far-flung Hana. Travelers from around the world stop in on their way up, down and around the Valley

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column on July 6 incorrectly described the findings of a Pentagon investigation into the Army Recruiting Command's decision to give an advertising contract to the Young & Rubicam agency. The Pentagon criticized the contracting officers for delaying an investigation of a complaint by N. W. Ayer, a rival agency, until after they had awarded the contract. The Pentagon did not criticize Col. Robert L. Phillips, the retired chief of staff of the Army Recruiting Command, who had been retained as an adviser by a consultant to Young & Rubicam.

title: Down and Out in Hollywood: That's Life
description: Most people who live in Los Angeles, and certainly visitors to the city, probably have no real sense that there's a major strike going on here and that a group of writers has brought the entire show-business industry to its knees. They may have read or heard about the strike in passing, or seen a few scattered picketers, but in a sprawling city like this one, a strike is almost invisible to the untrained eye.

description: The latest battle in the orange juice wars ended yesterday when the Coca-Cola Company, which had begun promoting its new Minute Maid Premium Choice orange juice as ''straight from the orange,'' agreed to drop those words from its packaging.

title: Review/Television; Exploring the Frontiers of Medicine
description: There once was the commercial, you may remember, in which a soap-opera actor proceeded to hawk a pharmaceutical product. ''I am not a doctor,'' he said, ''but I play one on television.'' The exploitation was so blatant that most viewers hooted. Tonight at 10 o'clock on NBC, ''Modern Medical Breakthroughs'' is a touch more subtle. Gregory Harrison, the host, does not say that he played a doctor on television, but there's no doubt that most of his fans still identify him closely with ''Trapper John, M.D.'' That series is clearly the prime qualification Mr. Harrison can muster for this misguided project.

title: The Silver Lining in Mexico's Election
description: The problem with holding competitive elections in which the outcome is predetermined is that credibility and legitimacy suffer dearly. That is the moral of last week's elections in Mexico, and that is one of the burdens that Mexico's next president will carry into office.

title: Coney I. Thriller Becomes Landmark
description: The most twisted, hair-raising and scream-inducing landmark in New York City was created yesterday when the Cyclone roller coaster at Coney Island was given official status by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Senate Votes to Elevate V. A. to Cabinet Status
description: The Senate voted today to elevate the Veterans Administration to the Department of Veterans Affairs, making it the 14th Cabinet department in the Federal Government.

title: New Chairman At Gas Utility
description: Richard D. Farman will become the chairman and chief executive of the Southern California Gas Company, the nation's largest gas utility, effective Jan. 1, 1989.

title: Bank Capital Rule Expected To Slow the Pace of Lending
description: The new capital guidelines approved Monday by the world's leading central bankers may not read like a best seller, but they will surely have a far-reaching effect on banks, their borrowers and the economy at large.

title: U.S. Retaliates, Ousting 8 Nicaraguans
description: PresidentReagan said today that he was expelling Nicaragua's Ambassador and seven other Nicaraguan diplomats in retaliation for the expulsion of eight American diplomats from Managua.

title: Sports People; Houston Investigated
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has formally notified officials at the University of Houston by letter of its investigation into allegations of recruiting violations and charges that coaches frequently gave cash to football players. The school has until Oct. 17 to respond to the letter. The allegations center on the Cougar football program from 1978 to 1984 when Bill Yeoman was head coach. Yeoman, who resigned after the 1986 season, said of the letter: ''I'm immediately reminded that someone else has indicated that they'll take care of all revenge, and they'll take care of the judgment. So I think it would be vastly better for me to keep my mouth shut.'' The former coach admitted last year that he gave money to players who were broke or whose families needed money.(AP)

title: Afghan Guerrilla Campaign Sputters
description: Soviet and Afghan attacks on positions captured by Afghan insurgents have recently stalled and in some areas reversed the guerrilla campaign to topple the Kabul Government, Western diplomats said today.

title: Justice Dept. Aide Quits
description: Charles J. Cooper, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel, is joining the Washington office of the law firm McGuire, Woods, Battle & Boothe, it was announced Monday.

title: 11 Guardian Angels Arrested in a Dispute With 2 Officers
description: In the latest skirmish in a simmering feud between the Guardian Angels and the New York City police, 11 Guardian Angels were arrested early yesterday after they surrounded two plainclothes officers in a Manhattan park. The police said the officers were in the park to investigate complaints that the civilian patrol group was harassing homeless people.

title: A Janitor's Nail Hits The Lottery on the Head
description: A janitor who has worked in the same East Harlem apartment building for 23 years claimed a New York State lottery jackpot of $22 million yesterday, making him the second richest individual lottery winner in the state.

description: Opposition parties appeared today to be stepping back from threats to take to the streets to press their allegations of vote rigging in the most contentious Mexican presidential race in recent times.

title: Closed Beaches and Wandering Barge: Two Chapters in the Same Story

Officials have reported slicks of trash, hundreds of yards wide and several miles long, floating in the waters around New York.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Gore Wins an Exception
description: Tucked away in the fine print of the military legislation that House and Senate negotiators agreed to last week is a curious sentence dealing with military procurement of microwave ovens.

title: Reviews/Film; Bunraku Puppets in Natural Settings
description: ''The Love Suicides at Sonezaki'' (1981), opening today at Film Forum 1, is an adaptation of Monzaemon Chikamatsu's 18th-century bunraku puppet drama, filmed not in a bunraku theater but in realistic settings that are at odds with this most highly stylized theatrical form.

title: Two Dukakis Decisions
description: In sweltering Faneuil Hall yesterday, Michael Dukakis announced what he called his first Presidential-caliber decision, his choice of Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas to run with him. It's a shrewd, audacious decision, likely to advance the Democrats' chances.

title: Testing of Blood For AIDS Virus
description: The AIDS-related tests used on blood samples from beach debris detect antibodies to the AIDS virus, substances the body produces in response to the virus. Their presence in a specimen would not necessarily mean that live, infectious viruses were still present. That could only be determined by attempting to grow the virus from the sample, which takes weeks and is unreliable.

title: U.S. Equestrian Finalists
description: The United States Equestrian team has announced its list of 16 riders eligible for selection to the Olympic show-jumping team. They must compete in the final trial, which will be held at the Hampton Classic Horse Show July 28-31 in Bridgehampton, L.I.

title: New York and Firefighters Agree on Tentative Contract
description: New York City and the firefighters' union tentatively agreed yesterday on a three-year contract that would provide annual 6 percent pay increases, maintaining the traditional economic parity with police officers, but require each firefighter to work 54 more hours a year.

title: Family-Owned Bigelow Sees Peril in Tea Merger
description: R. C. Bigelow Inc. is a family affair. Ruth C. Bigelow founded the tea company during the Depression in her kitchen on 50th Street near Second Avenue in Manhattan. Now her son, David C. Bigelow; his wife, Eunice, and their daughters, Lori and Cindi, run their modern-day company from its headquarters in Norwalk, Conn.

title:
At the Nation's Table;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: PANO KARATASSOS, one of Atlanta's most respected restaurateurs, will serve food to many of the visitors at the Democratic National Convention, which opens here on Monday. But the one visitor he is really looking forward to seeing is his cousin, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, the likely Democratic presidential nominee.

title: Merrill Lynch & Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

This was partially offset by after-tax gains of $76.2 million related to the sale of a portion of the leasing business and $48.3 million related to the sale of master limited partnership units of residential area estate operations.

title: Park Electrochemical Corp reports earnings for Sales
description: The company said its tax rate in the latest quarter was 37 percent, up from 30 percent in the year-ago first quarter.

title: Fresh Air at Justice
description: Dick Thornburgh's arrival as head of the Justice Department will be as welcome as Edwin Meese's departure. The regret is that the nation couldn't have had an attorney general of Mr. Thornburgh's caliber all along.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: FROM Lillian Lowenherz of Sunnyside, Queens, comes news of her friend who has a circulatory problem and whose doctor advised her to walk two miles - 40 blocks - every day. The friend (who shall be nameless) has been following the recommendation religiously for some months. During the hot, humid days of July, however, the daily routine proves to be something of a problem.

title: Beijing Criticizes Rating by Moody's
description: China complained yesterday that Moody's Investors Service assigned too low a rating when the nation issued its first international bonds last October.

title: Yanks Reply to Owner
description: As their All-Star teammates were chatting, taking batting practice and posing for pictures, the three representatives of the Yankees were forced to conduct a too-familiar ritual.

title: Rules on Waste Still in Works
description: A year after two state agencies were ordered to adopt new regulations to reduce the unsafe disposal of infectious waste, many of the regulations are not in place, and officials of the agencies said they were working on them.

title: Marietta to Buy Gould Division
description: As part of the continuing divestiture of its military businesses, Gould Inc. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Ocean Systems division to the Martin Marietta Corporation, a major military contractor. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The division, which makes underseas surveillance systems for use against submarines, posted revenues of about $100 million in 1987. The unit employs about 1,300 people in its Glen Burnie, Md., operations.

title: Quipp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotations of the Day
description: ''The Massachusetts and the Texas axis was good for the country and good for the Democratic Party in 1960 and it's going to be a real winner in November of '88.'' - Senator Lloyd Bentsen, on his selection as the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate. [ A1:6. ]

title: Jackson, 'Too Mature to Be Angry,' Icily Offers No Embrace for Ticket
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who just the previous night said he would accept the Vice-Presidential nomination if offered it, greeted the selection of Senator Lloyd Bentsen today with an icy refusal to either embrace or condemn the prospective Democratic ticket.

description: Crum & Forster Inc., an insurance company owned by the Xerox Corporation, said yesterday that Sidney F. Wentz had elected to take early retirement and was being succeeded as chief executive by Robert J. Vairo.

title: Reviews/Music; A Rossini Comic Opera, Reassembled, in Newport
description: In a remarkable feat of musicological detective work, the noted scholar Philip Gossett succeeded a few years ago in reconstructing from disparate manuscripts virtually the entire comic opera written by Rossini in 1825 for the coronation of Charles X of France, ''Il Viaggio a Reims.''

title: Citicorp Unit Helps Market Louisiana Revenue Bonds
description: A $982 million bond issue to refinance Louisiana's budget deficit was offered yesterday through underwriters headed by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

description: The 1987 results are restated to reflect the acquisition of Suncook Bank.

description: The Soviet Union today ruled out a quick withdrawal of its forces from other Eastern European countries.

title: Donald Blaisdell, 88, City College Professor
description: Donald C. Blaisdell, a former professor of political science at City College of the City University of New York, died of pneumonia Saturday at the Lorien Nursing Home in Columbia, Md. He was 88 years old and lived in Skaggsville, Md.

description: Citibank, the nation's largest bank, will triple, to $3,000, the average minimum monthly balance it requires for customers to avoid fees for checking accounts and the use of automatic teller machines.

title: Braniff Buying Fokker Jets, Planning Kansas City Hub
description: In its first important rebuilding steps, Braniff Inc. announced yesterday that it was buying 12 Fokker 100 jets and would build a major hub at Kansas City, Mo.

description: WHEN strip shopping centers first appeared on the suburban landscape in the 1950's and 1960's, they typically were no-frills structures consisting of little more than long flat-roofed buildings with little visual appeal.

title: Sharpeville Journal; Black and Poor, Her Daughter Faces the Gallows
description: As Julia Ramashamola sees it, the almost unbearable agony of being the mother of a woman facing execution for a political crime is made even worse because she is black.

title: Societe Generale's First U.S. Offering
description: Societe Generale's New York branch made its first debt offering in the United States yesterday through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

description: To the Editor:

title: Kidder Data Link With First Boston
description: The First Boston Corporation said it would give one of its competitors, Kidder, Peabody & Company, access to its computer system, a move that will help cover the system's cost and help pay for its future development. First Boston developed its advanced global trading and clearance system in 1985. It will allow the companies to do 24-hour trading, introduce new products more quickly and major costs. Kidder, Peabody is responsible for developing retail capabilities for the system.

title: Second Spacecraft Launched by Soviets Toward Mars Moon
description: The second of two Soviet spacecraft bound for Mars was launched from the space center at Baikonur today. It and the craft launched Thursday represent the first missions to Mars since the American Viking probes arrived in 1976.

title: Sports of The Times; Winfield's Answer
description: SURELY suffering from writer's cramp for autographing so many copies of his best-selling autobiography, Dave Winfield set only one All-Star Game record with a fourth-inning double, tied only one other record and scored the winning run last night in the American League's 2-1 victory.

title: Boeing Test on Plane Feature Is Focus of Accident Hearing
description: Two months before a Boeing 737 jetliner was ripped open on a flight in Hawaii in April, the manufacturer told the Government that special tests had verified the effectiveness of a design feature to prevent explosive decompression. Other experts had warned that this design might be inadequate.

title: Market Place; Basic Industries' Outlook Brighter
description: IF the last-minute revision of earnings estimates by securities analysts is any indication, companies in basic industries like steel, aluminum, forest products, chemicals, paper and packaging may be giving investors a pleasant surprise in coming weeks. And the same goes for New York City banks, according to Benjamin Zacks, executive vice president of Zacks Investment Research, a Chicago-based firm that tracks earnings estimates at more than 100 brokerage firms.

title: Workers for 911 Protest Suspension of Dispatcher
description: Chanting ''We want respect'' and ''We don't want to be scapegoats,'' dozens of 911 operators and dispatchers spent their lunch hours and breaks demonstrating in front of Police Headquarters in Lower Manhattan yesterday, protesting what they said was generally poor treatment from the Police Department.

title: New Procedure Clears a Vessel Totally Blocked
description: Balloon angioplasty, the medical procedure in which a tiny balloon is inflated inside a blood vessel to clear a blockage, is growing in popularity among doctors as an alternative to coronary bypass surgery. A thin tube, or catheter, is inserted into a blood vessel and the balloon inflated so that it pushes the blockage, called plaque, back against the vessel walls.

title: American Passage: A Niche Marketer
description: Among the things that American Passage, a Chicago advertising company, has been doing is representing military and college newspapers to national advertisers. It has also been selling ad space on college newspaper racks.

title: Dow, Off 18.67, Has Lost 65 Points in a Week
description: Stock prices sagged yesterday, continuing their recent downward trend.

title: Tour de France; Cyclists Go Easy, Preparing for Alps
description: A trio of well-known sprinters, led by Jean-Paul van Poppel of the Netherlands, led the 10th stage of the Tour de France today, while Steve Bauer of Canada retained the overall lead.

description: Dozens of severely deteriorated and damaged paintings that the New-York Historical Society is storing in a Manhattan warehouse are not owned by the society but are part of a collection on long-term loan from the New York Public Library.

description: Six Israeli policemen were wounded slightly this morning when dozens of Arabs attacked them in a crowded courthouse, the police said. Two of the officers were stabbed. Four Arabs were arrested.

description: Whom the gods would madden, they first make writers. This leads inevitably to a requirement for typewriter ribbons. Cat's-paw that I am to these Olympian sadists, I had bought three typewriter ribbons scarcely 10 minutes before the Monday mail arrived with news that they would have to be amortized.

title: Caterpillar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 22
description: For the latest quarter, on a pre-tax basis, profit improved $86 million, to 8.3 percent of sales and revenues compared with 6.3 percent in the same quarter last year. However, this improvement was largely offset by a $59 million increase in income tax expense between the two periods. Inventories increased $204 million during the second quarter to support higher sales, and from the acquisition of Carter Machinery Company, Inc. In the second quarter, the company adopted new Statement of Financial Accounting Standards 94 which had no effect on consolidated profit, net assets, ownership, or the financial strength of the company. The most significant changes occurred in receivables from customers and others, long-term receivables, and total debt, which increased $216 million, $757 million, and $855 million, respectively.

title: Greece Issues Photos of Suspects in Ship Siege
description: Greece said today that it had obtained the photographs of four suspects in the terrorist attack aboard an excursion ship in the Saronic Gulf on Monday and that it had identified two of them. The Government said it did not know the whereabouts of the attackers.

title: Albany Gains Tentative Pact On the Budget

description: Riding a wave of popularity for its latest microprocessor, the Intel Corporation reported today that its net income nearly tripled in the second quarter from a year earlier.

description: David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, came under sharp attack today by House members who complained that the agency had given in to industry pressure concerning reforms of its arbitration process.

title: Allegheny Deal Set
description: Allegheny International Inc. said it intends to sell its semiconductor equipment business to Silicon Valley Group Inc. for undisclosed terms. The parties signed a letter of intent and will try to negotiate a definitive agreement and win the approval of both boards, Government regulators and the Federal bankruptcy judge overseeing Allegheny International's Chapter 11 reorganization. The unit, Thermco Systems Inc., employs about 450 people in Orange, Cerritos and Hayward, Calif., making equipment used in the manufacture of semiconductors. Thermco also has small offices in West Germany, England and Hong Kong. Silicon Valley Group, based in San Jose, Calif., makes production equipment for the semiconductor industry.

title: Washington Talk: International Relations; The Roots and the Rudiments of Compensation to Foreigners
description: When the White House announced Monday that the United States would compensate the families of the 290 people who died on Iran Air Flight 655, only the circumstances were new. The practice in which one country makes amends for misfortune visited on another country's citizens has deep roots in modern diplomacy and international law.

title: 2 Die as Train Hits Their Van in Intersection
description: Two people were killed this morning when a N.J. Transit commuter train collided with their van as it crossed an intersection in this northern New Jersey suburb, the authorities said.

title: Despite Serious Wrist Injury, Vanbiesbrouck Stays Upbeat
description: Every day the baby can do something new. It isn't always dramatic, often amounting simply to an added subtlety in a smile or a firmness in a grip. For John Vanbiesbrouck, whose first child was born on June 18, these have been days of wonder for him and his wife, Rosalinde. They have also brought wonderfully useful lessons for him.

description: A group of Southern California Protestant ministers threatened today to urge a boycott of businesses owned by MCA if Universal Pictures releases Martin Scorsese's new film, ''The Last Temptation of Christ.''

title: Legislature in Armenian Enclave Votes to Secede From Azerbaijan
description: In a brash symbolic move likely to worsen a five-month territorial dispute, the ruling legislature of a predominantly Armenian enclave voted today to secede from Azerbaijan, the republic that has ruled the enclave for 64 years.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE firm, rich flesh of fresh tuna is well suited to barbecuing and broiling, and the quick recipe here makes a delicious main course that can be prepared slightly ahead of time and held if you are entertaining.

title: Beaches on Brooklyn and S.I. Close as Sewage Hits Harbor
description: All the municipal beaches on Staten Island and in Brooklyn were closed yesterday when sewage gushed into New York Harbor after a power failure at a sewage-treatment plant, adding new concerns for beachgoers and health officials already alarmed by recent deposits of medical waste on the local shoreline.

title: The Jacket Finds A Place in the Sun: In Hand or on Arm
description: EXHAUSTED glances at those Fahrenheit/Celsius digital thermometers scattered around town aren't the only way to know for certain that the temperature has soared. The most consistent indicator, perhaps, is the way men are dressed on their way to and from the office. Jackets are the first item to be shed. The jacket-over-the-shoulder look seems to be the favorite; it may also be the most macho (especially if the other hand is used to tote a gym bag or attache case). The more serious-looking gentlemen seem to prefer their jackets carried over the arm, with somewhat less derring-do, but equally effective in beating the heat. Most serious of all are the die-hards who, regardless of heat and polyester blends, refrain from removing their jackets (double-breasted, yet). Nor do they loosen or lower their neckties, a bit of relaxation that, along with open shirt collars, is another sure sign that humidity is high. Ties bestow a business touch to those sweltering fellows who go jacketless and wear short-sleeved shirts. It has been said that the shorter a man's shirt sleeves, the less likely he is to be high up the corporate ladder. But it's too hot to think about that.

title: Nassau County's 1986 Chardonnay
description: The origins of the Long Island wine industry date to 1816 or thereabouts when a certain William Prince grew a grape called the Blue Isabella in the country village of Flushing in what is now Queens. The spending, coupled with industry sales that for the first time exceeded $1 billion last year, puts the United States well ahead in the international biotechnology race, industry experts said.

description: Almost everybody, it seems, is jamming messages into ideological bottles and tossing them into the political seas hoping that they will be read by the next President and his aides.

description: Claire Shulman, Borough President of Queens, is asking the Board of Estimate to reconsider its earlier approval of the 42d Street redevelopment project. She argues that the project has changed significantly since it received the original go-ahead. In particular, she objects to the fact that the project's proposed merchandise mart will be occupied mainly by manufacturers and sellers of furniture and fixtures used in interior decorating.

description: More than a thousand New York City food vendors, chanting anti-Koch slogans, marched on City Hall yesterday to protest the Mayor's ban on food vendors in congested areas of Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Cut
description: Japan said today that its trade surplus narrowed in June to an unadjusted $5.93 billion from $6.60 billion a year earlier.

description: The Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms has proposed wider restrictions on the use of foreign geographical names on American wine labels and in advertising.

title: Cherokee Group
description: The Cherokee Group, which last month rejected a $12.50-a-share bid by management to take the company private, said it had received a sweetened $13-a-share offer, or about $161 million, apparently from the same group. James P. Argyropolous, chairman and chief executive of Cherokee, a women's clothing and shoe company based in Sunland, Calif., said the investor group was interested in friendly deal. Under the new takeover bid, the buyout would include an equity interest for Mr. Argyropolous as well as three top Cherokee officers. Cherokee stock rose 25 cents, to $12, in over-the-counter trading today.

This time, held to six hits in the 59th All-Star Game, the American League avoided another embarrassment by turning to the player with the most humbling statistics on the team.

description: A Federal judge indicated yesterday that he intended to create a special commission with the power to carry out his court-ordered housing desegregation plan in Yonkers, bypassing a recalcitrant City Council that has refused to put his order into effect.

description: Anacomp Inc. today signed a letter of intent to acquire the Xidex Corporation, a microfilm manufacturer in Santa Clara, Calif., for $10 a share in cash, or about $415 million.

title: Asset Move Attempted, S.E.C. Says
description: An investor from Taiwan accused of insider trading illegally tried to transfer several million dollars to Hong Kong last week, the Securities and Exchange Commission asserted yesterday.

title: Mother's Cooking Inspires 2-Star Chef In French Heartland
description: MICHEL BRAS is a good example of how far a chef can go on home cooking. The restaurant bearing his name in Laguiole was awarded two Michelin stars in 1987, but unlike most of the 87 other two-star chefs in France, Mr. Bras never apprenticed with a famous chef. His mentor is his mother. From the time he was a teen-ager, the tall, wiry, professorial-looking Mr. Bras, who is now 42 years old, has worked in the kitchen of Lou Mazuc, the inn his parents, Angele and Marcel, have owned since 1954 in Laguiole, in the Massif Central, the French heartland, about two hours' drive north of Toulouse. (The name of the family is pronounced BRAHSS, and that of the town is generally pronounced La-ghee-OLE, but in the region, it's La-YOLE.) Mr. Bras's professional training consisted of attending a vocational school, the Centre d'Apprentissage, in nearby Rodez three days a week for three years.

title: Head of Jesup & Lamont Wants It to Stay Small

LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I REMEMBER being homesick, although I'd rather not. It is one of those things you can't forget if you've experienced it, like sky diving or falling in love with the best-looking boy in the senior class when you are a freshman with bad skin and posture. Except that being homesick is more horrible than either of these, and more resonant, too: that sense that if you were only in one specific ordinary place the nausea would disappear, and the misery, and the palpable sense of unhappiness and disaffection that keeps you only inches from tears except, of course, when you are actually crying. (It makes me feel unspeakably safe, being able to write this without actually feeling it.) I have been thinking, reluctantly, of the times when I've been homesick because each morning I send a child off to day camp who is wrestling unsuccessfully with his first bout of it. He does not yet have the word, although it is mentioned in the book in which Big Bird goes off to the beach to visit Granny and feels so terrible he cannot eat his birdseed pancakes. Instead he says, ''I miss you so much'' and he cries. This is how he describes it: missing Mom, and crying.
