description: TENNIS Shriver Advances: Pam Shriver, the No. 1 seeded player and the two-time defending champion, beat the qualifier Kim Steinmetz of St. Louis, 6-2, 6-3 yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the Virginia Slims of Newport tournament.(AP) Agassi Wins: Andre Agassi of the United States defeated Ricki Osterthun of West Germany, 6-3, 7-5, yesterday in a second-round match of a Grand Prix tournament in Stuttgart, West Germany. The victory by the second-seeded Agassi over the 24-year-old Osterthun removed the last West German from the tournament. In other second-round matches, third-seeded Brad Gilbert beat Darren Cahill of Australia, 6-4, 7-6; Jonas Svensson of Sweden defeated Mansour Barahmi of Iran, 6-3, 3-6, 6-0, and Kent Carlsson of Sweden eliminated Shozo Matsuoka of Japan, 7-6, 6-4. (AP) Duncan Upset: Nicklas Kulti, a 17-year-old Swedish junior, upset Lawson Duncan of the United States, who was seeded sixth, in straight sets at the Swedish Open in Bastad yesterday. Kulti, who is ranked 398th in the world, won the second-round match, 6-3, 7-5, on a slow clay court. Duncan, from Asheville, N.C., was a finalist last Sunday in the United States Pro Championships at Longwood, outside Boston, and received a first-round bye here like the other seeded players. Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, the top-seeded player, rallied to defeat a countryman, Ulf Stenlund, 4-6, 6-2, 6-3, in another second-round match. Karel Novacek, an unseeded Czechoslovak, became the first man to reach the quarterfinals by beating Thierry Champion of France, 6-1, 6-4, in the only third-round match. Third-seeded Jan Gunnarsson of Sweden advanced to the third round with a 6-3, 7-6 victory over Jean Fleurian of France.(AP) Garrison Advances: Top-seeded Zina Garrison won her second-round match in the Belgian Open in Brussels yesterday, and second-seeded Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria was upset. Garrison advanced to the quarterfinals with a 7-5, 6-4 victory over Celine Cohen of Switzerland, and Angeliki Kanellopoulou of Greece defeated Maleeva, 1-6, 6-4, 6-3.(AP) HORSE RACING Seattle Meteor Stays Unbeaten: Buckland Farm's Seattle Meteor remained undefeated after two starts when she raced to a one-length victory in the $89,400 Astoria Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Belmont Park yesterday. Seaquay, the favorite in the field of eight, finished fast to be runner-up. Seattle Meteor, a daughter of Seattle Slew from the Northern Dancer mare Northern Meteor, came from off the pace carrying 112 pounds under Randy Romero to cover 5 1/2 furlongs on the fast track in 1:05 3/5. She earned $53,640 and paid $8.60 for $2 to win. GOLF Texans Leading: Jerry Hudgins and J. P. Sale of Deerwood, Tex., shot a five-under-par 32,34-66 yesterday for the first-round lead in the 36-hole qualifying for the John G. Anderson Memorial Tournament on the East course of the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Competition will be on the West course today to determine the 15 teams that will join Randy Sonnier and Bob McKinney of Houston, the defending champions, for medal play tomorrow and Saturday.

NEW WORRIES ON SEXUALLY TRANSMITTED DISEASE
description: Some major forms of venereal disease, such as syphilis and chlamidia, have increased dramatically in recent years, but other diseases, once extremely rare, are also on the rise. Among them are chancroid, granuloma inguinale and lymphogranuloma venerium. The estimates of annual new infections are from the Federal Centers for Disease Control. DISEASE: Chlamydia; More than 4 million new infections Symptoms: Urinary tract, rectal or vaginal infections; can cause pelvic inflammatory disease in women, leading to infertility. Can be asymptomatic. Treatment: Long-term tetracycline regimen DISEASE: Gonorrhea; 1.8 million Symptoms: Irritation, discharge, painful urination. Can promote pelvic inflammatory disease in women. Treatment: Penicillin or other antibiotics DISEASE: Cytomegalovirus; More than 1 million Symptoms: Usually none, except in people with impaired immune systems or in newborns, who may suffer retardation or death. Treatment: None approved in U.S. DISEASE: Genital warts; 1 million Symptoms: Warts, sometimes painful, on genital organs or rectum. Treatment: Surgical, chemical or cryogenic removal DISEASE: Genital herpes; Up to 500,000 Symptoms: Often asymptomatic. Can cause genital blisters and malaise. Can cause blindness, hearing problems and death in newborns. Treatment: Acyclovir, in capsule or ointment form, can suppress symptoms. DISEASE: Hepatitis B; 200,000 Symptoms: Can be asymptomatic. Virus can cause short-term liver inflammation or chronic diseases including cirrhosis and liver cancer. Treatment: None. Vaccine can prevent infection. DISEASE: Syphilis; 85,000 Symptoms: Can produce sores but is frequently asymptomatic. Can damage heart, nervous system, brain and other organs. Can cause stillbirth or birth defects. Treatment: Highly responsive to antibiotics DISEASE: Chancroid; Up to 10,000 Symptoms: Genital ulcers; often painful, enlarged lymph nodes in the groin. Treatment: Antibiotics DISEASE: Lymphogranuloma venerium; More than 1,000 Symptoms: Enlarged lymph nodes in the groin, genital or rectal infection, pain, fever and inflammation. Treatment: Tetracycline DISEASE: Granuloma inguinale; Up to 100 Symptoms: Genital or rectal ulcers. More common in warmer climates. Treatment: Antibiotics

title: Q&A
description: Q. I live in an aging, rundown apartment house and constantly struggle to keep the sinks, tubs and toilet bowls clean. The toilet bowl seems to have a permanent ring around it at the water line. Scrubbing with most household cleansers does not seem to help. Are there any suggestions you can offer? A. One cleanser that often works well on such stains is a product called Zud. It is sold in supermarkets, hardware stores and some plumbing supply outlets. If this fails, you can probably remove the stains with a solution of muriatic acid (sold in hardware stores). Wearing rubber gloves, mix the acid with four parts water in a glass or plastic bowl. Scoop most of the water out of the toilet bowl, then scrub with the solution. Let soak for about five minutes, then flush. Q. When our house was built 12 years ago, old bricks were used instead of new ones to provide a rustic look. But many of these bricks absorb too much moisture, so that winter freezing and thawing causes the face of some bricks to crack and fall off. Can these bricks be repaired, and can they be sealed to prevent further damage? A. When bricks flake off in the manner you describe, the most common cause is moisture getting in through defective or missing mortar, not through the bricks themselves. So the first cure is usually a tuck pointing job - raking out the defective mortar and replacing it with fresh mortar.

Au Grenier Cafe Diner's Journal (June 6, 1986), 2867 Broadway, at 111th Street (666-3052) - Hot weather wilts appetites but sparks thoughts of refreshing salads artfully composed and lightly dressed. Au Grenier, an informal walk-up bistro with a second-story view of the Columbia University neighborhood, provides a good selection of salads at lunch. Other choices are salade nicoise made with fresh tuna; a salad of marinated chicken, grilled and served cold on watercress, and a blend of artichoke heart, broccoli and red pepper. Salads are $3 to $7. Lunch hours are 11 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Friday and 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Sunday for brunch; dinner, 6 to 10:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday, to 9:30 P.M. Sunday. Gotham Bar and Grill

title: Report on Meese Due Monday
description: An independent prosecutor's final report on the conduct of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is scheduled to be made public here Monday.

title: Are Today's 'Dreamers' Tomorrow's Doctors?
description: Mary Anne Gallagher, assistant director of nursing at the Beth Israel Medical Center, with sixth-grade students from Public School 17 in Brooklyn. The youngsters visited the maternity ward as part of the school's ''I Have a Dream'' class. The career program enabled students with an interest in health care to tour the hospital and meet the staff. From left were Shakira Maldonado; Melody Camacho; Rene Conde Jr., rear; Angel Rameres, and Theresa Massey. (NYT/Peter Freed)

title: Hibernia Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Koch Plan Would Speed Welfare Hotels' Closing
description: The Koch administration is preparing a plan to set aside more than a thousand additional apartments a year for homeless families, to accelerate plans to close down the city's welfare hotels, city officials and advocates for the homeless say.

title: Candelaria Wins 10th
description: The same team that trudged quietly into the All-Star Game break -and then spent its time absorbing the verbal assault of George Steinbrenner - made something of a charge into the season's second half last night. When they were done, the Yankees spoke of the need to forget their past and keep moving ahead.

title: Kaydon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Agent Indicted in Arrest of Pedestrian
description: An agent for the Secret Service was indicted yesterday on charges that he made an unwaranted arrest of a Manhattan pedestrian who crossed paths with the motorcade of a Presidential candidate last spring.

title: Markets Appear Reassured by Greenspan's Remarks
description: The financial markets' calm reaction to Alan Greenspan's assessment of the economy implies that the man who wields immense power over interest rates will not shock the markets with a suffocating tightening of credit to stop inflation.

title: Mets Score on Error in 11th
description: The Mets, mired in a confusing slump, watched a rare offensive burst dwindle to nothing before they recovered tonight to beat the Braves, 9-8, in 11 innings in front of 11,805 at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium.

title: Afghan Capital Bombarded
description: Afghan rebels fired more than 20 missiles at the capital city of Kabul today, killing 20 people and wounding 34, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported. The one-sentence report gave no other details of the attack.

title: NBD Bancorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago net earnings were reduced by a second-quarter special $54 million provision for possible credit losses on Latin American loans. The charge reduced after-tax income by $32,400,000, or 69 cents a share.

title: Some Khmer Rouge Will 'Retire,' Shultz Is Told by Chinese Official
description: China's Foreign Minister told Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that some senior members of the Communist Khmer Rouge had indicated that they would ''retire,'' a senior State Department official said.

title: Outdoor Sculptures Reflect Struggles Of Life in the City
description: SOMETHING has happened to outdoor sculpture in New York. There have always been works of substance, but they seemed isolated and often marginal, with little relation to issues about which most sculptors were concerned. Each year, however, the outdoor season has become more of a forum in which large sculptural ideas and themes are developed and debated. Indeed, it may be on sidewalks, waterfronts and grass that the lifeblood of sculpture in New York pounds on.

title: Hawkeye Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $7,446,000 from the elimination of debt.

title: National Parks Should Remove Some Hotels
description: To the Editor:

title: Vendors Agree to Limited Lottery
description: After rejecting similar proposals for months, New York City food vendors agreed yesterday to a limited lottery for midtown Manhattan locations, a move urged by a councilwoman trying to break the standoff between the vendors and Mayor Koch.

title: Agency Moves to Revive Embryo Studies
description: The Health and Human Services Department announced today that it would re-establish an ethics committee to rule on applications for funds for fertility research involving embryos. The move is a first step in ending what amounted to a de facto ban on federally sponsored research on ''test tube'' babies.

title: Security Pacific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and includes $558 million of additional provision for developing country debt for the second quarter. The company said that excluding the provision, its year-ago second quarter net would have been $116.1 million, or $1.03 a share, and its year-ago 6-month net would have been $232.6 million, or $2.09 a share. Year-ago second quarter is restated to include, on a pooling-of-interests basis, the Aug. 31, 1987 acquisition of Rainier Bancorp and the retroactive adoption of a change in accounting for nonrefundable fees and costs associated with originating or acquiring loans and initial direct costs of leases. The company also said its developing country debt declined by about $600 million in the latest quarter to a level of less than 2 percent of total assets. It said the provision for credit losses declined to $79.3 million in the latest quarter from $102.7 million a year earlier after exluding the special provision. For the first 6 months of 1988, the provision totaled $157.9 million, down from $202.1 million in the year-ago period excluding the special provision.

title: Singer in Agreements To Sell 2 More Units
description: The Singer Company, which has announced the sale of three subsidiaries in the last week, said yesterday that it had reached agreements to sell two more units.

title: KEY RATES
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alberta Energy Co., Edmonton, Alberta, said preliminary results of its offer for shares of Chieftain Development Co. had disclosed that the company now holds about 95 percent of Chieftain's common shares.

title: The Law; Legal Hired Gun: Have Computer, Will Detect
description: When a California manufacturer of mobile homes found itself facing 13 lawsuits alleging unhealthy formaldehyde levels, the company's lawyers unleashed a new and powerful weapon in the legal arsenal: a private investigator with a computer.

title: Forecast Drives Up Crop Futures
description: Forecasts of a return of hot, dry weather to the nation's Farm Belt this weekend again catapulted most prices of soybeans and corn to their daily permissible limits on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Baseball; Pirates Drop Giants 4 Back
description: Brian Fisher pitched five and a third shutout innings in relief of the injured John Smiley, and Darnell Coles and Andy Van Slyke each drove in four runs as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the San Francisco Giants, 9-2, tonight.

title: Probation Ordered for Man Who Set Fire to Yale Shanties
description: A Yale alumnus who burned an anti-apartheid shantytown on the university's campus last month was granted special probation today after apologizing for setting the fire.

title: MCI Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $28 million from previously negotiated antitrust settlements, and a pre-tax charge of $8 million related to the expected sale of certain maintenance facilities. Results for the quarte also reflect a decrease in access charges effective January 1 and an average 3.5 percent price decrease on interstate traffic, effective March 1. c-Includes a pre-tax non-recurring gain of $12 million, while net income for the December 1987 quarter included pre-tax non-recurring gains of $22 million and an after-tax non-recurring charge of $14 million.

title: Debt Securities Prices Are Steady
description: Prices of debt securities were little changed yesterday, but the credit markets remained unsettled about rising commodity prices and the possibility that the Federal Reserve will eventually push short-term rates higher.

title: Armenians Stage Strike Over Disputed Region
description: Armenians stayed away from work by the thousands today and rallied to press for the transfer to their republic of a mountain enclave that has been part of neighboring Azerbaijan since 1923.

title: Texas Gas Notes
description: The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation, a unit of the CSX Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 1/4 percent debentures due in 1992 at a price of 99.95, to yield 9.264 percent, through Goldman, Sachs & Company. Underwriters said the issue was noncallable and priced to yield about 63-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. The notes are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by S.&P.

title: Ford Motor Credit Begins Note and Warrant Offering
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $100 million of four-year notes and $4.75 million of currency exchange warrants in separate transactions through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Tyner and Blythe

title: Lawyer in Lee Insider Case Assails S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission misrepresented a conversation its investigators had with the lawyer for the investor from Taiwan accused of insider trading, the lawyer asserted in an affidavit filed this week.

title: Senators Doctors Kennedy and Hatch
description: Last May, the National Heart Institute had the courage to do what a bureaucracy seldom does: It pulled the plug on a failed program, the effort to develop a permanently implantable artificial heart. Over 24 years, this Dracula of a project has leeched $240 million from the taxpayers. But no sooner was the stake driven through the monster's heart than the Senate ordered it revived.

title: Intergraph Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
How the Media Slight Pinochet
description: LEAD: The journalistic drumbeat from Chile has, for some time, signaled that freedom and democracy are on the rocks and that prospects for change are slim. It is alleged that the responsibility for this sad state of affairs lies with that country's ever-present pariah, Gen. Augusto Pinochet. In fact - hard though this may be for liberal critics to accept - General Pinochet and the military regime have moved dramatically to expand economic liberty and are moving Chile on schedule, under the

title: Newborn Baby Left on Jet; Mother Is Charged
description: A New York City woman gave birth in an airliner restroom Wednesday and left her newborn daughter in a mass of blood-soaked towels, the authorities said.

title: New Scorsese Film Shown to Religious Leaders
description: In an effort to defuse criticism by evangelical Protestants of Martin Scorsese's latest film, ''The Last Temptation of Christ,'' Universal Pictures screened it for a group of religious leaders in New York City on Tuesday.

title: Gannett Net Up 8.7% in 2d Quarter
description: The Gannett Company yesterday reported net income for the second quarter of $97.5 million, or 60 cents a share, up 8.7 percent from $89.7 million, or 56 cents a share, in the quarter a year ago.

title: Japan on U.S. Trade
description: Japan said today that its trade figures with the United States had improved strikingly in the last six months, and it predicted that the trend would continue for the rest of the year. Over all, the trade surplus with the United States was down 14.9 percent during the period from January through June, compared with the period last year, according to statistics from the Foreign Ministry.

title: Sewage-Dumping Agencies Draw Threats of Stiff Fines
description: The Environmental Protection Agency yesterday called for fines of $1.25 million against nine sewerage authorities in New York and New Jersey, charging they improperly dumped sludge in the ocean.

title: Winston Furniture Co, Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
Volleyball Team Basks in Anonymity
description: When they travel to Japan, they provoke a response akin to the Beatlemania of the 1960's. When they compete in South America, their prowess is so feared that they are spat upon by the legions of fans who come to watch them. Only in the United States, not a volleyball hotbed despite being the sport's birthplace, does the Olympic men's volleyball squad, the defending gold medalist, go about its business virtually unnoticed.

title: Last of Playboy Clubs In U.S. to Shut Down
description: The last Playboy Club in the United States will close at the end of July, formally ending the era of buxom waitresses with bunny tails.

title: Second Setback In B.A.T. Case
description: The Oregon insurance commissioner handed B.A.T. Industries its second defeat in as many months by rejecting the British conglomerate's $4.5 billion hostile bid for Farmers Group Inc., the nation's seventh-largest insurer.

title: Rangers Sign Center
description: In an effort to strengthen themselves on face-offs, the Rangers yesterday signed Doug Wickenheiser, a free-agent center who has played with three teams since being the first player selected by the Montreal Canadiens in the 1980 entry draft.

title: For Artists, the Choice of Colors Can Be Fateful
description: To the Editor:

title: Atom Laser Had Early Fans Besides Teller, Study Finds
description: Edward Teller, the physicist credited with helping prompt the ''Star Wars'' program, was in most cases no more optimistic than his colleagues in hailing its X-ray laser, the General Accounting Office reported yesterday.

title: Prime Rate Up 1/2 Point, To 9 1/2%
description: In response to the recent rise in interest rates, major American banks, led by the Chase Manhattan Corporation, raised their prime lending rate yesterday to 9 1/2 percent from 9 percent. Other banking companies that quickly followed Chase included Citicorp, First Chicago, Chemical and J. P. Morgan.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: New Nemesis for Bond

title: Sports of The Times; A Phone Call In the Night
description: QUITE early one morning, or was it quite late one night, the phone rang and I answered it from a deep dream of peace.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the Assembly session in Albany misidentified the Assemblyman with James R. Tallon Jr., the majority leader. He was Frank J. Barbaro.

description: Year-ago figures are restated to report results of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. and T.C.C. Beverages Ltd. under the equity method of accounting.

title: Goodrich, B F Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that during the second quarter it adopted FAS No. 96 retroactive to Jan. 1. While the move had no significant impact on total net income either in 1988 or 1987, the new standard requires that tax-loss carryforward benefits be reflected as part of continuing operations rather than as extraordinary items. The second quarter and first-half net income was enhanced by $13.4 million, or 53 cents a share, and $24.3 million, or 96 cents a share, respectively. In the 1987 periods, net income benefited by $10.5 million, or 45 cents a share, from tax-loss carryforwards.

title: Glatfelter, P H Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest second quarter and 6-month includes net sales of $57,091,000 and $110,310,000, respectively, and net income of $4,707,000 for the quarter and $8,074,000 for the 6 months from the Ecusta division, acquired May 7, 1987. Year-ago quarter and 6-month include $31,384,000 in sales and $2,530,000 in income from the Ecusta division.

title: JACKSON SUGGESTS CARTER MIGHT HEAL RIFT WITH DUKAKIS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson took his smoldering dispute with Michael S. Dukakis in a new and striking direction today by saying someone else, former President Jimmy Carter, was needed to mediate it.

title: Military and Civilian Design Not the Same
description: To the Editor:

title: JMB Realty Trust Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a 9 cents a share gain for disposition of investment property for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Big Board's Curb Called Ineffective
description: The New York Stock Exchange's curb on computerized program trading failed to moderate prices on the first two days in which it was used, according to two Government studies released today.

title: Review/Music; Journey Into the Surreal
description: ''Actual Sho,'' an 80-minute music-theater extravaganza conceived, written and directed by George Coates, a San Francisco-based multimedia artist, might be described as a psychedelic rock show for grown-ups.

title: AC&R/DHB Receives Sterling Auto Account
description: It is hardly a surprise, but now it is official. Austin Rover Cars of North America has designated AC&R/DHB & Bess Advertising to handle its $20 million account to promote the Sterling 825S and 825SL luxury sedans.

title: Reagan, After Tour of Parched Farms, Prods Congress on Drought Relief
description: After touring corn and soybean fields parched and stunted by weeks of searing heat, President Reagan urged today that Congress swiftly pass drought relief legislation being developed by the House and Senate Agriculture Committees.

title: Zenith Stock Falls On Report of Bids
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation's stock fell $2.25 a share, to $25.75, on the New York Stock Exchange today after a newspaper reported that it had rejected four foreign offers for its consumer electronics business. Analysts said investors pulled out for fear that Zenith would be unable to sell the unit - the last United States television manufacturer - at a reasonable price.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Major banks raised their prime lending rate to 9 1/2 percent, from 9 percent, confirming the recent trend toward higher rates. The second increase in the prime this year brought it to its highest level since March 1986. The increase may affect consumer spending but is unlikely to be a major drag on the economy. [ Page D1. ] Bank holding companies must raise billions more in new capital than their overseas counterparts, according to the F.D.I.C.'s internal calculations. The new requirements, part of an international accord, have caused growing concern that U.S. banks will be at a competitive disadvantage. [ D1. ] The S.E.C. and the lawyer for an investor from Taiwan disagree about what the lawyer told investigators. [ D4. ] Retail sales rose a moderate 0.5 percent in June, as hot, dry weather spurred brisk sales. [ D2. ] COMPANIES The Bass Group won a crucial court ruling against Macmillan. The ruling prevents Macmillan's restructuring and allows the Bass Group to proceed with a $73-a-share tender offer. [ D1. ] Eastern Airlines and its machinists appear deadlocked in their contract talks, raising the possibility of a strike. [ D4. ] MCI will buy back 47 million shares owned by I.B.M. for $667 million. I.B.M. will buy $400 million of MCI preferred stock. [ D3. ] Chemical, Bank of New York and Security Pacific posted stronger second-quarter earnings. In 1987, the banks made special loss provisions to cushion their exposure to third world debt. [ D3. ] Mastercard's president and chief executive resigned, in a move that surprised the credit card industry. Russell E. Hogg said he wanted to pursue a smaller entrepreneurial venture. [ D3. ] Singer will sell its electronics systems division, which makes military products, to Plessey, of Britain, for $310 million. [ D3. ] Time Inc. and Warner Communications may merge their cable operations. [ D13. ] Gabelli Group confirmed that it is in settlement talks with the S.E.C. over possible violations of disclosure rules during its 1987 takeover attempt of Di Giorgio. [ D2. ] Oregon's insurance commissioner rejected B.A.T.'s takeover of Farmers Group, the nation's seventh-largest insurer. [ D3. ] MARKETS Forecasts of hot, dry weather catapulted soybeans and corn prices to their daily permissible limits on the Chicago Board of Trade. The demand for post-harvest contracts left large pools of unsatisfied orders at the close. [ D1. ] A curb on computerized program trading had little effect, according to two Government studies of volatile trading. [ D1. ] Stock prices moved higher after the increase in the prime rate by a half percentage point. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 9.25 points, to close at 2,113.62. [ D4. ] Prices of debt securities were little changed, but the markets remained unsettled about rising commodity prices and the possibility that the Fed will push short-term rates higher. [ D10. ] The dollar rose to an 11-month high against the mark and generally defied the cautious position usually taken the day before the release of major economic data. [ D11. ] INTERNATIONAL The last snags in legislation to enact the free trade agreement with Canada were removed by the House Ways and Means and Senate Finance Committees. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis circle warily around the critical economic issue: how to eliminate the huge budget deficits. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Stores that sell every item for the same price are beginning to take hold in the discounting. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: News Summary

Page A1 Nicaragua has confiscated the nation's largest private business, the San Antonio sugar plantation, a symbol of capitalism for nearly a century. Officials asserted that its production was declining. A1 Iran failed to win support in the United Nations Security Council for a resolution condemning the American downing of an Iranian airliner. Vice President Bush said the main problem was Iran's refusal to halt its war with Iraq. A1 Iran was also rebuffed by the International Civil Aviation Organization, which deplored the use of weapons against civilian aircraft but did not mention the United States. The rejected nominee for the Federal Appeals Court for the Ninth Circuit is Bernard H. Siegan, a conservative law professor. title: Soviet Jew Reports Exit Visa
description: A 50-year-old Jewish mathematician who has sought for nine years to leave the Soviet Union said Wednesday that he had been granted an exit visa and that he would fly to the United States on the private jet of Dr. Armand N. Hammer, the industrialist. The mathematician, Veniamin Charny, who had been denied emigration on the basis that he had access to space technology, said he planned to join his daughter, Anna Charny-Blank, 28, in Brookline, Mass. She emigrated last September.

Why Not Run Twice in Texas?
description: Thanks to Lyndon Johnson, Texas law allows Lloyd Bentsen to run for re-election as a Senator at the same time he's running for Vice President. This leeway was written into the state's election code in 1959 for then-Senator Johnson, who had his eye on the 1960 Presidential nomination. While it smacks of opportunism, it actually makes good sense. But it also raises a disturbing new question.

title: Our Towns; For an L.I. Man, The Rough Road To a Group Home
description: Yesterday, Saul Maluth, a union printer, took the day to fetch his son Lee from Pilgrim State Psychiatric Hospital. ''A big day?'' said Mr. Maluth as he drove the '76 Ford up to Building 42. ''Oh, it's just sensational. This is the longest Lee's been in. He's been pretty far down and he's come pretty far up.''

title: Water Diversion Rejected
description: The Army Corps of Engineers has rejected requests from Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois and other officials for increased diversion of water from the Great Lakes into the drought-parched Mississippi River, an Army official said today.

title: Capital Plan Feared as a Burden on Banks
description: Bank holding companies in the United States must raise billions more in new capital than their overseas counterparts under a Federal Reserve plan to increase capital requirements, according to calculations by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Stephen Reichard, 39; Started an AIDS Fund
description: Stephen Reichard, an arts marketing consultant who helped to conceive and lead a major fund-raising campaign for AIDS research in the New York art world, died of cardiac arrest resulting from AIDS on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 39 years old.

title: Racial Motive Investigated In Death of Kingston Woman
description: The slaying of a 19-year-old woman whose body was found Tuesday morning near abandoned railroad tracks in Kingston, N.Y., may have been racially motivated, officials said yesterday.

title: Gabelli Holds S.E.C. Talks
description: Gabelli Group Inc. and various subsidiaries confirmed yesterday that they are in settlement talks with the Securities and Exchange Commission over possible violations made in their 1987 takeover attempt of the Di Giorgio Corporation.

title: Fire Laid to Drug Rivalry Kills 4
description: A firebombing attributed to a rivalry among drug dealers gutted an apartment house today, killing four residents and injuring six other people, the authorities and neighbors said.

description: Demonstrating organizational strength, Philip F. Foglia yesterday filed nominating petitions with 31,667 signatures, considerably more than four other aspirants for the Democratic nomination for Bronx District Attorney - the most hotly contested primary in New York City this September.

Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's 443 money market mutual funds increased $1.39 billion, to $266.33 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 100 broker-dealer funds increased $725.2 million, to $114.17 billion.

title: Neighbor Found Guilty Of Murdering a Girl, 9
description: A 23-year-old Brooklyn man was convicted yesterday of murdering a 9-year-old girl who lived in his apartment building and then covering her body with plaster of Paris and hiding it in the basement.

title: Shulman Retracts Request on Times Sq. Plan
description: Queens Borough President Claire Shulman withdrew yesterday a request that the Board of Estimate reconsider its approval of a multimillion dollar Times Square development she believed might financially threaten an existing project in Queens.

title: Pretoria Willing to Discuss Atom Ban
description: South Africa has told Britain, the Soviet Union and the United States that it is prepared to discuss renouncing nuclear weapons and opening all its atomic establishments to international inspection, diplomats and officials here say.

title: Hungary Reform Plan
description: Hungary's ruling Communist Party approved plans today for radical political and economic reforms and slashed the number of top jobs needing party approval. A Central Committee meeting agreed overwhelmingly to work out details of a tough economic recovery plan for 1989 that would give free rein to market forces and but would be liable to increase unemployment.

title: TERRORIST SUSPECT IS JAILED IN GREECE
description: A Palestinian sought by the United States on charges of involvement in two midair bomb attacks was sentenced today to seven months' imprisonment on charges of entering Greece with a forged Syrian passport.

title: Macmillan Restructuring Is Blocked by an Injunction
description: The Robert M. Bass Group won a crucial court ruling yesterday against Macmillan Inc. that will prevent the publishing and information company's planned restructuring into two separate companies.

title: Cubs-Expos Trade
description: In a trade of outfielders, Dave Martinez was sent by the Chicago Cubs to the Montreal Expos yesterday for Mitch Webster. ''It was the fact Martinez never learned how to read pitchers and could not steal bases that led us to this decision,'' the Cubs' manager, Don Zimmer, said. ''We want to take advantage of Webster's switch-hitting ability and we think he can steal more bases than Martinez.''

title: Albany Strains To Settle Issues Stalling Session
description: Straining to close the legislative session by Sunday, lawmakers in both houses exchanged a flurry of potential compromise bills today but failed to resolve most of the major outstanding issues.

description: The company said the lower earnings were attributable to the company's share repurchase program which had been funded through internal cash flow and additional debt which reduced the growth in investment income and increased interest expense by $3.2 million after-tax for the 6-month period. The company also attributed lower earnings to its claims experience in its medicare supplement business which were higher than expected during 1988, resulting in an after-tax reduction in earnings for the second quarter of approximately $5.3 million, or 10 cents a share, and last year's results included nonrecurring, after-tax gains from the sale of subsidiaries in the first quarter of $2.7 million.

About Real Estate; Utility's Land Sales Plan Stirs Connecticut Region
description: A pastoral 134-acre wooded site in Easton, Conn., has become the first of an estimated 2,000 acres of excess land that the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company intends to sell over the next decade or so. The Easton site, in the city's southeastern corner, will be developed with high-priced custom homes on three-acre lots.

description: The GAF Corporation and its vice chairman, James T. Sherwin, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of criminal stock manipulation in connection with the sale of a block of the Union Carbide Corporation stock in 1986.

description: Tom Coulter has been named to replace Ken Adams as coach of the United States Olympic boxing team. Adams was suspended for six months June 11 by a committee of the United States Amateur Boxing Federation, and his appeal was turned down yesterday in Las Vegas, Nev., by a national review board.

title: 5 of 6 Humanitas TV Prizes Awarded to ABC Programs
description: ''God Bless the Child,'' an ABC television movie about a homeless mother and daughter, and episodes of ''Frank's Place'' and ''Thirtysomething'' were awarded the Humanitas Prize today for the 1987-88 television season.

description: The dollar rose yesterday, hitting an 11-month high against the West German mark and generally defying the usual cautious position taken the day before the release of major economic data.

description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said that the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Denver had ruled as adequate a major portion of its reorganization plan. The court approved the company's disclosure statement on Wednesday, which details the proposed reorganization, how it would be executed and the company's future business prospects.

description: Overheated and underinformed Westchester County residents are threatening to strike a helping hand that would begin to remedy homelessness in the suburbs.

Pentagon's Budget Approved
description: Congress today approved the final version of Pentagon budget legislation that cuts $800 million, or more than 16 percent, from the amount allowed for President Reagan's program for a defense against attacking missiles.

title: Patti Page Looks Back On 40 Years
description: How odd it seems in retrospect that Patti Page, a singer who has always exemplified wholesome pop-country conservatism, should have been a key figure in the evolution of pop-music technology. Forty years ago, Miss Page - who opened her first New York engagement in 19 years at the Ballroom on Tuesday -became the first pop singer to have her voice overdubbed to sound like a duet or a group.

title: Flightsafety International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are not adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a 50 percent dividend, payable on Aug. 5 to shareholders of record July 15.

title: Review/Art; An Exhibition of Old Master Prints
description: The season's most debonair skeleton can be seen in the 27th annual exhibition of Old Master prints at the Associated American Artists gallery. Not even Fred Astaire himself could stand more nonchalantly, with legs elegantly crossed, head resting on the long thin fingers of the left hand, and a human skull held lightly in the long thin fingers of the right hand. What better hot-weather wear, we think, than our own bones, intact, with nothing whatever on them?

title: Howard Beach Man, 19, Cleared
description: A white teen-ager was found not guilty yesterday of attempted murder and other charges stemming from the racial attack by a group of young whites on three black men in Howard Beach, Queens, 18 months ago.

title: New York Opens 4 Beaches, but Jersey Shuts 4
description: Four New York City beaches were reopened yesterday as the danger from a sewage overflow was deemed to have passed, but four New Jersey beaches have been closed because of high fecal bacteria counts.

title: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes investment tax credits of $500,000 for the latest 6-months and $2.3 million for the year-earlier period. Results in 1988 include the company's Nekoosa packaging division which was acquired last September for $1.15 billion.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; For Voters, a Clear Choice of Styles and Futures
description: Carlos Saul Menem cooked up gnocchi for 7,000 people during his primary campaign, and he promises to govern Argentina as an updated version of Juan D. Peron.

title: SPLIT IS REPORTED OVER ABM ACCORD
description: Disagreeing with the civilian leadership of the Pentagon, the Joint Chiefs of Staff are resisting a move that would allow the United States to suspend some of its obligations under the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, Administration officials say.

title: AIDS Survey Shows Course Of Infection
description: Giving the clearest picture yet of current infection with the AIDS virus and thus the epidemic's likely future course, the State Health Department today released data on 141,000 anonymous tests for AIDS antibodies showing drastic contrasts by race, age, sex, residence and drug abuse.

title: Review/Film; The Police, Terrorists And a Captive Audience
description: ''Die Hard,'' the movie that gambles a $5 million salary on Bruce Willis, has to be the most excessive film around. It piles every known element of the action genre onto the flimsy story of a New York cop who rescues hostages from a Los Angeles office tower on Christmas Eve. Partly an interracial buddy movie, partly the sentimental tale of a ruptured marriage, the film is largely a special-effects carnival full of machine-gun fire, roaring helicopters and an exploding tank. It also has a villain fresh from the Royal Shakespeare Company, a thug from the Bolshoi Ballet and a hero who carries with him the smirks and wisecracks that helped make ''Moonlighting'' a television hit. The strange thing is, it works: ''Die Hard'' is exceedingly stupid, but escapist fun.

title: Corrections
description: The Letters column in The Living Section Wednesday gave an incorrect identification for the writer of a letter about hot dogs. He is Michael F. Jacobson.

title: Gain Reported in Hepatitis Treatment
description: An experimental treatment for hepatitis B infection has apparently rid some patients of the virus and stopped the virus from reproducing itself in others, according to a report published today.

title: McGirt-Davis Bout
description: In what its promoters call the last scheduled 15-round championship fight in the United States, James (Buddy) McGirt will make the first defense of the International Boxing Federation junior welterweight crown that took him six years to attain July 31 at the Felt Forum. His opponent will be Howard Davis Jr., the 1976 Olympic lightweight champion who has been unable to lay claim to a professional title in a dozen years.

title: Steinbrenner Mends Fences
description: George Steinbrenner stepped forward to make amends with his three All-Star performers yesterday, meeting separately and privately with Don Mattingly, Dave Winfield and Rickey Henderson. But there were no assurances from any of them that relations have improved.

title: Healthy Kids Magazine Will Publish 3 Editions
description: The American Baby Group is taking on a very big project for the American Academy of Pediatrics. And that is to publish a magazine three times a year called Healthy Kids, which will be distributed by pediatricians to parents. It is expected eventually to have a circulation of 13.5 million.

title: Bridge

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the Sandinistas begin to open up the political process, the United States Embassy begins to promote insurrection, distortion and chaos. On the other hand, if the Sandinistas close down the political space, then the Administration will use that to promote military aid to the contras.'' Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa. [ A6:6. ]

description: Like upwardly mobile immigrants, Huberts restaurant has followed each surge of its success with a move to a better neighborhood. Karen Hubert and her chef and husband, Len Allison, started in 1976 with a Victorian-style nook in Boerum Hill in Brooklyn. In 1981, they crossed the East River and settled on East 22d Street, near Gramercy Park, where their ingenuous charm and ecumenical cooking continued to win followers. Five months ago, they reached the summit: a Park Avenue address.

description: The White House said today that President Reagan supported a proposal in Congress to provide additional aid, including weapons and ammunition, to rebels who have been trying to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

title: Raymond Goldsmith, Noted Economist, Dies at 83
description: Raymond W. Goldsmith, an economist who for several decades was a leading authority on national income and wealth, died of heart failure Tuesday at the Whitney Center, a retirement community in Hamden, Conn. He was 83 years old and had lived for many years in New Haven.

title: Two Bills on Drought Relief Advance in Congress
description: Relief for drought-stricken farmers moved a big step closer to reality today as both the House and Senate Agriculture Committees approved separate legislation aimed at putting payments in farmers' hands by September.

title: Pfister Survives Rocky Finish
description: E. J. Pfister, who turned professional three weeks ago after winning the national collegiate championship, survived three bogeys on the last five holes today to win the Michelob New York State Open championship.

title: A Break in the Angola Stalemate
description: This week's secret talks in New York on Angola have produced tentative agreement on what Chester Crocker, the U.S. mediator, called the ''essential elements of a political settlement in southwestern Africa.'' This is far from a final agreement. But if one can eventually be struck, it would be a major diplomatic triumph, ending South Africa's illegal rule in Namibia and removing Cuba's 45,000 troops from war-battered Angola.

Economic Scene; Candidates Wary On Budget Deficit
description: IN their race for the White House, Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis continue to circle warily around the nation's most critical economic issue: how to eliminate the huge Federal budget deficits, which have increased the national debt in the last eight years to $2.5 trillion from $1 trillion. Those budget deficits have been the underlying cause of the chronic deficits in the balance of payments of the United States, its growing dependence on foreign capital and its vulnerability to a withdrawal of that foreign support.

But the audience at the Central Park ''Much Ado About Nothing'' seems to be rooting for the couple's fusion harder than usual, extending its applause to the dull early exposition required to bring the merry warriors into harmony.

title: Masco Plans Operations Shift
description: Masco Industries said it would transfer operations with annual sales of about $250 million, representing about 15 percent of its revenues, to a new company that it expects to form late in the fall. John C. Nicolls Jr., the treasurer of Masco, said his company would exchange its military, gas cylinder, fastener and heat-treating operations for about half of the equity in the new company, which is to be called the Trimas Corporation. The remaining ownership is to go to the Masco Corporation for about $70 million in cash, and a portion of that is to be distributed to Masco Corporation's shareholders as a dividend.

title: Carlyle-Oakite
description: Carlyle Investors Partnership V, L.P., a Washington-based investment firm, has offered to acquire Oakite Products Inc. for $44 a share in cash. Oakite, a chemical concern based in Berkeley Heights, N.J., has 1.64 million shares outstanding, giving the proposal an estimated value of $72 million. Carlyle made its offer in a letter Thursday to the Oakite board. The letter, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, set out a number of conditions on the offer, including the negotiation of a friendly agreement between the two parties and the availability of adequate financing.

title: Dollar Up Sharply on Trade Data

title: Wiktor Weintraub, 80, Slavic Studies Scholar
description: Dr. Wiktor Weintraub, an educator and author who specialized in Slavic studies, died of cancer on Thursday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 80 years old. Dr. Weintraub held the Alfred Jurzykowski Chair of Slavic Studies at Harvard University from 1971 until his retirement in 1978. He was a prolific writer in Polish and English, with more than 400 books, articles and essays. His most recent book was ''The Poet and the Prophet,'' published in 1982.

title: Suzuki Sales Move
description: The American Suzuki Motor Corporation said today that it was trying to reverse last month's 70 percent slump in sales of the company's Samurai sports-utility vehicle by giving dealers $2,000 for each unit they sell. A spokeswoman for Suzuki, the United States unit of Suzuki Motor of Japan, said dealers might use the money, which is available from today through Sept. 2, for advertising, special promotions or price discounts. If all of it were passed directly to the consumer, the vehicle's $8,495 base price would drop by about 25 percent, to slightly less than the $6,550 introductory price set in November 1985.

Now, with recess only days away, there is a chance that vital elements of that agenda may be deferred by the Senate. Progress has been made in some areas, but little or none in others. School reform is too vital to the city's future for such a laid-back approach.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Agassi Advances: Andre Agassi of the United States defeated Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 7-5, 6-1, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the $350,000 Nabisco Grand Prix tournament in Stuttgart, West Germany. Agassi, seeded second, will play sixth-seeded Henri Leconte of France, who defeated Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 6-3, 6-4. In the other semifinal match, ninth-seeded Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Ecuador meets 11th-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador. Perez-Roldan defeated Thomas Muster of Austria, 6-2, 7-5. Muster had upset top-seeeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia on Thursday. Gomez defeated fourth-seeded Yannick Noah of France, 6-3, 6-3. (AP) Garrison Upset: Isabel Cueto of West Germany upset top-seeded Zina Garrison of the United States, 6-4, 7-5, yesterday to reach the semifinals of the $75,000 Belgium championships as persistent rain and wind sent the tournament indoors in Brussels. The fifth-seeded Cueto will play Aranxta Sanchez of Spain. Sanchez, seeded fourth, beat Mercedes Paz of Argentina, No. 8, 6-2, 6-2. Sanchez has not lost a set.(AP) Golf Pulling Away: Colleen Walker pulled five strokes ahead of her nearest challenger yesterday in the $300,000 L.P.G.A. Boston Five Classic.

title: GUIDEPOST: Melting Point
description: High temperatures take their toll on the contents of handbags, beach bags and weekend totes. Medications, cosmetics and other items will deteriorate if they are repeatedly left in a hot car or in the sun, because heat accelerates natural spoilage. Most medications will not lose their potency for quite a while, but the coating on capsules can become gluey. Latex condoms may eventually deteriorate, and creams and lotions will run and separate. Photographic film may yield poor prints, and batteries may weaken. Aerosol cans explode in extreme heat; manufacturers warn against leaving them in car trunks. ITEM TEMPERATURE EFFECT Film Above 80 degrees Pictures may have reddish tint; develop as soon as possible Medications Above 90 degrees Capsules and pill coatings may melt Batteries Above 100 degrees Energy may diminish Aerosol cans Above 130 degrees May explode (Sources: Eastman Kodak Company, Parke-Davis, Carter-Wallace Inc. title: Trying for an Unsettled Tactical Brouhaha
description: THERE are players who are spoiled, who are not content to have brought about a winning position but also seem to expect the opponent to lose according to their preconceived plan. When the opponent refuses to just sit there and be mated, these players often lose their concentration - and soon after, the game.

title: Headliners; At Odds
description: The executive board of the teamsters' union picked William J. McCarthy as their new president last week, but it is uncertain how long Mr. McCarthy will stay in the driver's seat. The new head of the 1.7-million-member union defeated Weldon Mathis, the hand-picked successor to Jackie Presser, who died last weekend, in an election marked by rare - for the teamsters - open debate.

title: Tick-Borne Diseases Rear Their Ugly Heads
description: LEAD: WHILE reports of the incidence of Lyme disease continue to rise steadily throughout Long Island, other tick-borne diseases are either declining or remaining constant, according to public-health experts.

title: Encouraging News On Trade, Inflation
description: Encouraging economic reports sent the dollar soaring. The U.S. trade deficit rose slightly in May, to $10.93 billion. Although higher than the revised $10.3 billion of April, it was the second-smallest imbalance in almost three years. Imports rose 3.4 percent, to $37.6 billion, while exports also increased 2.3 percent, to $26.6 billion. In another report, wholesale prices rose in June by only four-tenths of 1 percent - especially good news since raw food prices jumped by the steepest rate in more than 2 1/2 years. The food increases were offset by lower energy prices.

title: The Dukakis-Bentsen Ticket Has An Opinion for Anyone in the Party
description: IN the next few weeks, Lloyd Bentsen will have to vote in the Senate on President Reagan's request for new military assistance to the Nicaraguan contras.

title: THE DEMOCRATS IN ATLANTA: Political Memo; On the Republican Side: Gone Fishing
description: Sometimes Presidential candidates just can't seem to win.

title: Horchata
description: To the Editor: One of my best memories of Madrid on a trip in 1971 was the thirst-quenching taste of horchata. A friend and I used to go almost daily to the little stand in the main park for a glass. Since I didn't speak Spanish, I thought it was made from coconut milk, but as the article by Penelope Casas (Travel, May 1) explained, it is made from an obscure African root.

title: In Edmonton, Hockey Great Meets Match
description: Most Canadians tend to think of themselves as more restrained than Americans, less given to hoopla and razzmatazz.

title: Americana's Finest: Rich Pickings
description: Enthusiasts continue to pay extraordinary prices for exceptional examples of Americana. Last month a historical clock, a rare silver service, a Windsor chair, a cigar-store Indian, several firemen's hats and three major pieces of lighting and furniture designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, John Henry Belter and Gustav Stickley brought prices that took everybody by surprise.

title: Barbara Kalland Weds
description: The marriage of Barbara H. Kalland, the daughter of David J. Hobens of Tenafly, N.J., and the late Ronnie Hobens, to Fred W. Feldt, the son of George Anne Feldt of Hicksville, L.I., and Fred H. Feldt of New York, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's father and stepmother, Gisele Hobens. Richard S. Arilotta, a Councilman in Tenafly and the Acting Mayor, performed the ceremony. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce. The bridegroom is an actor and an owner of Starwrite Express Word Processing in New York.

title: 'Rosencrantz and Guildenstern'
description: THE pairing of ''Hamlet'' and ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead'' could turn out to be inspired, or just plain insipid. The proof is in the performance, not the programming.

title: Enduring Brass of Florence
description: A DOORKNOB is a doorknob is a doorknob, as Gertrude Stein would have put it - or is it? In Florence, doorknobs are made in every shape and size and style, from blackened 14th-century handles to grandiose gargoyle door knockers on 16th-century palaces, to Empire lyres and laurel crowns, to the bows and furbelows of the Liberty style.

title: Correction
description: An article about the PBS documentary series ''The Struggles for Poland'' on the Television page last Sunday gave an erroneous figure for the production cost. It was $3.25 million.

title: Where Hospital Waste on Our Beaches Comes From
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH INDICTING MARCOS
description: The Justice Department is reviewing a draft of a proposed racketeering indictment of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former President of the Philippines, but has not made a final decision on whether to bring criminal charges, according to department officials.

title: CONFESSIONS OF A DADAIST HOUSEWIFE
description: THE HEAT DEATH OF THE UNIVERSE And Other Stories. By Pamela Zoline. 204 pp. Kingston, N.Y.: McPherson & Company. Cloth, $20. Paper, $10.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: EMILE ZOLA: A Biography. By Alan Schom. (Holt, $19.95.) Emile Zola, the founder and chief exponent of the French school of naturalism, wrote novels that were frank and often brutal depictions of 19th-century French society and were repeatedly condemned as immoral and obscene. An active journalist throughout his life, Zola fearlessly attacked political, religious and social ills.

title: BRAVO BEETHOVEN, BACH AND HANDEL
description: Although Harry Clark and Sanda Schuldmann have titled their summer series ''Beethoven Bravo!'', Bach, Handel and Schubert are also on the programs. There is even one, aptly dubbed ''Ludwig Goes Fishing,'' where Beethoven gets the day off.

title: Judge Bars U.S. From Isolating Prisoners for Political Beliefs
description: Two women who were held in an isolation unit at a Kentucky prison because of their radical political beliefs were ordered Friday by a Federal district judge to be transferred into regular cells.

title: EIGHT LUMINARIES SHOW OFF THE TOWN
description: Henry Aaron retired as a major-league baseball player in 1976 after hitting 755 home runs, more than anyone else in the history of the game. Now 54 yeras old, he maintains ties to the Atlanta Braves by serving as director of player development, a job that allows enough time at home to give him and his wife, Billye, the chance to sample restaurants all over the Atlanta area.

title:
INVESTING;
Surprising Strength of Mutual Funds
description: LEAD: THE strong performance of stock mutual funds has surprised many experts since the market crashed in October. And offerings of new mutual funds of all varieties have also been remarkably robust.

title: Notebook; Whatever It's Called, Forkball or Split-Fingered, It's Screwy
description: Ron Darling says he throws a split-fingered fastball; Mel Stottlemyre, the Mets' pitching coach, says the pitch is a forkball.

title: Today's Schedule
description: All times are eastern daylight. 5:45 P.M.: Michael S. Dukakis arrives from Washington with Senator Lloyd Bentsen, his choice for a running mate. 7:00 P.M.: Parties for state delegations begin. 8:00 P.M.: Reception sponsored by Paul G. Kirk Jr., Democratic National chairman. Television Coverage NBC: ''Sunday Today'': Interview with Kitty Dukakis, wife of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, expected Democratic Presidential nominee; profile of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Mr. Dukakis's main challenger; Reuven Frank, former NBC president, reflects on previous Democratic conventions. 9 A.M. CBS ''Face the Nation'': The Democratic Convention: Will it be unified? With Mr. Jackson. 10:30 A.M. NBC: ''Meet The Press'': The Democratic Convention. Paul Kirk Jr., Democratic national chairman; Susan Estrich, campaign manager for Mr. Dukakis, Ron Brown, convention manager for Mr. Jackson. 10:30 A.M. ABC: ''This Week With David Brinkley'': The Democratic National Convention. Former President Jimmy Carter; former Vice President Walter F. Mondale; Robert Strauss, former Democratic national chairman. 1:30 P.M. ABC: ''Business World'': Mr. Dukakis discusses his economic agenda and the Democrats' relationship with big business. 2:30 P.M. C-SPAN: Preview of the convention, 6:30 P.M.

title: MAINSTREAM JAZZ IS ALIVE AND WELL IN TWO SERIES
description: In the days when Be-bop was the new thing in jazz, people who liked traditional jazz used to be called moldy figs. There's probably another derogatory name now for people who like be-bop, cool, New Orleans or any other mainstream jazz, but if so, it would have to apply to a lot of people. For, to judge by the number and amount of record sales of older jazz, there are plenty of lovers of mainstream jazz out there.

title: Lost Yacht of Italian Scientist to Be Recreated
description: The inventor of the wireless telegraph, Guglielmo Marconi, so adored his research ship that he named a daughter after her - Elettra -instead of the other way around. But the ship, which the scientist used as home and laboratory, was destroyed in World War II, and a piece of Mr. Marconi's history was lost with it.

title: Claryss Hartman To Wed in August
description: Claryss Nan Hartman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Hartman of Cherry Hills Village, Colo., and Thomas Crawford Jamieson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jamieson Jr. of Princeton, N.J., plan to marry Aug. 27, the future bride's parents have announced.

title: Keir Dullea Stars In Westport Show
description: ''An actor's constant companion is fear,'' says Keir Dullea in his new two-person show, which is a sampler of theater pieces, personal and professional reminiscences and a retrospective of his acting career.

title: Ballesteros's Clubs Are in New Hands
description: A 40-year-old Englishman from Yorkshire, Ian Wright, is carrying the big bag for Seve Ballesteros in the British Open this week. The Spaniard recently stopped using any of his three brothers as a caddie.

title: Steel and Glass Amid Greenery In La Villette
description: LIKE a phoenix from the ashes, the hottest new attraction in Paris has risen on the site of the Fifth Republic's greatest financial scandal. Where the city's stockyards and abattoirs stood in the 19th century, the de Gaulle government squandered a fortune to build new slaughterhouse facilities that were obsolete before the 1960's, when they were started.

title: CELEBRATING 300 YEARS
description: When the H.M.S. Rose sails into New Rochelle Harbor at 6 P.M. Friday it will mark the beginning of a week-long waterfront festival celebrating New Rochelle's tricentennial. The 180-foot, three-mast frigate, with 24 cannons, will dock at Hudson Park, where the first Huguenot settlers from La Rochelle, France, landed in 1688.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: IN THE LAKE OF THE MOON. By David L. Lindsey. (Atheneum, $17.95.) Stuart Haydon, the homicide detective who has starred in three of David L. Lindsey's previous thrillers, can afford to sidestep a long-offered promotion. Descended from a line of wealthy Houston brahmins, he appears to perform his work as a public service - and an expiation for unspecified feelings of class guilt.

title: And So the Wagon Rolled West
description: LEAD: SHOULD the family take a trip from Connecticut to California in a seven-year-old station wagon?

title: Reviews/Music; Vivaldi and Telemann as They Heard It
description: If one didn't pay close attention, the new Mostly Mozart season's Thursday evening concert went amiably by. The large friendly audience seemed to like it, though one wonders if its thunderous applause was not as much for Avery Fisher Hall's virtuosic air-conditioners as for the music itself. The latter was by Vivaldi and Telemann, played by Christopher Hogwood and a small band of local musicians known as Music on Original Instruments. John Gibbons had given a brief harpsichord recital an hour earlier.

description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Aliens Rush to Farmhands' Amnesty
description: With more than four months to run, the Federal program to bestow legal status on alien farm workers in the United States has already drawn 675,000 applicants, nearly double the number officials originally estimated would be eligible.

title: PERUVIAN GUERRILLAS EMERGE AS AN URBAN POLITICAL FORCE
description: Long dismissed as an isolated band of violent fanatics, the Shining Path guerrillas of Peru have spread out from their Andean mountain haven and are emerging as a growing urban political force.

title: No Ban on Latin Mass
description: To the Editor:

title: Australian Plays: The Moment For Export?
description: Audiences at this year's Pepsico Summerfare festival might do well to check their program notes before the metaphorical curtain goes up in Purchase, N.Y., this week on the Sydney Theater Company's two festival offerings - Ray Lawler's 1955 classic, ''Summer of the Seventeenth Doll'' and Michael Gow's 1987 hit, ''Away.''

title: David McK. Key, 88, A Former Ambassador
description: David McKendree Key Sr., a retired Foreign Service officer who served as Ambassador to Burma and Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, died Friday of cancer at his home in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: THE PRO ATHLETE: HERO OR HARD HAT?
description: The judge has spoken. There will be no immediate free agency for some 300 National Football League players, but the cheers or sighs of relief from 28 owners and their commissioner ought not to be too loud. Judge David Doty all but promised the players' union that they would win their antitrust suit if it comes to trial.
