title: A SUPERIOR VIEW IN NEW PRESTON
description: Boulders Inn on a hillside overlooking Lake Waramaug at New Preston has long commanded a superior view. In fact, for years the viewwas the sturdy fieldstone inn's star attraction.

title: George C. Anders to Marry Elizabeth Corcoran, Editor
description: Elizabeth Anne Corcoran, an editor of Scientific American magazine in New York, and George Charles Anders, a senior special writer at The Wall Street Journal, plan to marry Aug. 27.

title: Tulane Picks Clark
description: The basketball program at Tulane University, dropped in 1985 after a point-shaving scandal, is scheduled to be resumed in time for the 1989-90 season, and yesterday the school named Perry Clark as the new coach. The 36-year-old Clark, currently an assistant to Coach Bobby Cremins at Georgia Tech, will become the first black head coach in any sport at Tulane. Clark is respected nationally for his recruiting and defensive coaching.(AP)

title: Optimism on Allison
description: Doctors have told Bobby Allison's family that the stock-car driver should completely recover from injuries suffered in a June 19 crash, his brother-in-law, Donnie Johnson, said. ''It wouldn't surprise me if he sat down in one this year; I'm not saying to compete, but maybe to practice or start a race and then park it,'' Johnson told The Birmingham News. Allison was seriously injured in a crash on the first lap of the Miller 400 Nascar at the Pocono Raceway. He remains hospitalized in guarded condition in Allentown, Pa., where he is being treated for a broken leg, broken ribs, a broken shoulder and a concussion. (AP)

title: A Debate on Hospital's Name
description: LEAD: What's in a name? Apparently quite a bit of controversy, some members of the County Board of Legislators are discovering.

title: Jacqueline Meyer, Lawyer, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Meyer of Beechhurst, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Meyer, to Martin I. Gold, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Gold of Oceanside, L.I. A December wedding is planned.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: ZOYA. By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The heroine of Danielle Steel's 23d novel is a plucky, good-natured girl, a cousin of the doomed Russian Czar, whom she refers to as ''Uncle Nicky.'' Zoya and her grandmother are the only family survivors of the Russian Revolution. They flee to Paris, where Zoya, a budding ballerina, dances on the same stage as Nijinsky in a production of ''Petrouchka.

title: Adelaide Pearson To Wed Sept. 3
description: Adelaide Douglas Pearson and Greg Ted Hulbert are planning to be married Sept. 3, the parents of the bride-to-be, Lawrence Pearson of Easton, Conn., and Mrs. Joseph R. Hallett of Hampton, Conn., have announced. Mr. Hulbert is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Ted Hulbert of Rockaway, Ore.

title: Borg Has No Regrets
description: Retirement has been kind to Bjorn Borg of Sweden. At age 32, his life as the tennis king of the 1970's is a distant memory. ''I retired when I was 26,'' he said yesterday at the International Tennis Hall of Fame in Newport, R.I. ''If I had any regrets, I think I would have been back to tennis a long time ago.''

title: Democrats, After Lean Years, Are Optimistic as They Gather
description: The Democrats who open their national convention here Monday have been chastened by defeat, tempered by four years of searing internal debate and buoyed by the hope that their long period in opposition is about to end.

title: Ellen Lander Plans to Wed John Brodsky in September
description: Ellen Gail Lander and John Bernard Brodsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Brodksy of Princeton, N.J., plan to marry Sept. 25, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lander of Lake Grove, L.I., have announced.

title:
GARDENING;
Caring For Plants Exposed to Stress
description: LEAD: It is not uncommon for an apparently healthy plant to die without warning. A tree that appeared to be healthy and vigorous in spring may be dead by mid-summer. It may have died so suddenly that its leaves remain in place all dried and scorched.

title: U.S. to Process Some Soviet Visa Applicants
description: The United States Embassy said today that it would resume processing the visa applications of some Soviet citizens whose efforts to gain refugee status in America have been temporarily thwarted by a lack of State Department funds.

title: Paris Hotel Fire Kills 5
description: A fire in a tourist hotel in central Paris overnight killed five people, the police said today. The dead were two Belgians, a Swede, a Japanese and the French manager of the Saint Vincent de Paul hotel, near the Gare du Nord railroad station, they said. At least two people were seriously injured and 19 others suffered slight injuries, the police said.

title: Correction
description: A caption on page 17 in Television today incorrectly identifies the actors pictured. They are Christopher Connelly and Jodie Foster, who starred in the ABC-TV series ''Paper Moon,'' based on the 1973 film of the same name. The original film is to be broadcast today at noon and Friday at 2 P.M. on the Showtime cable channel.

title: Baseball: National League; Pirates Coast to 8th in Row
description: Mike LaValliere's two-run double and Doug Drabek's two-run triple highlighted a six-run third inning as the Pittsburgh Pirates routed the San Francisco Giants, 10-1, tonight for their eighth straight victory.

title: High Tech to the Rescue
description: In these days of high-tech-whoopee, one of the neater little tricks has no moving parts, no microchips, no plug-in jacks, no power source. But it can start your car when there's no other way.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: A RUTGERS UNIVERSITY professor who has developed new methods of treating hazardous waste at Superfund sites will be honored next month by the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.

title: Tornadoes Cut Wide Paths In Cities Along the Missouri
description: National Guardsmen sealed off a large part of the city to protect against looting today as crews cleared trees and other debris strewn by tornadoes that swept through entire blocks.

title: RECAST IN STONE
description: JUAN MONTOYA WAS LOOKING FOR LAND when he happened on this 1939 stone house. Set amid 110 wooded acres in the Hudson Valley, the dilapidated structure was simply a building waiting to be renovated. And renovate he did, but over time. ''I left the property alone for a year in order to understand the terrain during each season,'' says the interior designer. ''I wanted to be sure exactly how to correctly approach the building in relation to the landscape.'' His cautious attitude was for a good reason. Surrounding the granite house are stands of oak and chestnut trees, and there is also a natural lake on the property.

title: Two New Efforts To Counsel Youths
description: LEAD: County teen-agers between the ages of 14 and 18 who are struggling with alcohol, drug or emotional problems have two new sources of assistance.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The front of my wood-burning fireplace is made of off-white color bricks. From constant use, some of the bricks under the mantle have blackened. I would like to restore the chalky off-white appearance that the bricks originally had. How can I do this?

title: Hans Holbein: A Great Poet Of Equanimity
description: Some exhibitions are born great and could hardly be improved upon. One of them is the exhibition of drawings by Hans Holbein the younger that can be seen at the Kunstmuseum in Basel through Sept. 4. What makes it unique is that for the first and quite probably the only time the two great surviving collections of portrait drawings by Holbein have been brought together under one roof. As a result, a momentous episode in human affairs is amply commemorated, and we realize as never before to what an extent we still see one another as Holbein saw our ancestors. As a lesson in human awareness, this show could not be bettered.

title: TESTIFYING TO TORTURE
description: Ines Murillo's story of torture in a prison in Honduras was known in 1983. She was interviewed by members of a delegation representing the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, Americas Watch and the Washington Office on Latin America. Few in authority or the news media had much to say then. Five years and who knows how much suffering later, the Reagan Administration is on its way out, power is shifting and the political climate has changed. Now The New York Times presents the case with its overtones of shock and moral outrage. WILLIAM COTTY Professor of Political Science Northwestern University Evanston, Ill.

title: In a Small Space, Boundless Creativity
description: USUALLY, closets are not a source of designers' inspiration. But Anne Harris saw the possiblities. At Keewaydin, the decorator show house open until Aug. 7 in Southampton, L.I., the Manhattan artist turned a walk-in closet into a witty, personal environment.

title: 200,000 in Mexican Capital Protest Vote Count
description: Responding to an opposition summons to ''defend the popular will,'' more than 200,000 people marched on the National Palace here today to support their charge of widespread vote fraud in last week's presidential election.

title: Removal of Cape Cod Shacks Is Considered
description: The National Park Service says it may remove rustic cottages it owns on the windswept dunes of outer Cape Cod between Provincetown and Truro.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Bootstraps Housing for Stamford's Needy
description: NEIGHBORHOOD Housing Services of Stamford, a private, nonprofit corporation, is extending its development activities on West Main Street to include new construction.

title: Edna L. Foley-Lyons Weds J. A. Vasquez Jr.
description: Edna Linn Foley-Lyons and Joseph A. Vasquez Jr. were married yesterday at St. Stephen Martyr Roman Catholic Church in Washington by the Rev. Francis J. Bober.

title: THE REGION: On the Sidewalks; Koch Clears the Pushcarts Out of the Way of the Crowds
description: WHEN Mayor Koch swept hundreds of food vendors from New York City's most congested streets last week, some New Yorkers were puzzled. Why, they asked, with the city making so little headway against drugs and homelessness, would the Mayor dispatch police officers to battle hot-dog stands on Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn street corners?

title: In Managua, No More Accommodation
description: MUCH of the painstaking progress made toward peace in Nicaragua seemed to slip away last week as tension between the Sandinista Government and its critics dramatically increased. The Government cracked down on the political opposition and United States diplomats and confiscated the nation's largest private business.

title: PRESTO, HE'S A SUCCESS
description: RUSH TO NOWHERE By Howard Lewis Russell. 287 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $17.95.

title: Who Are The League M.V.P.'s at This Stage?
description: Where would the Tigers be without Luis Salazar? He has played solidly in seven positions (except pitcher and catcher). He can bat anywhere in the lineup against righties and lefties. He has been a clutch hitter (.303, 44 runs, 11 homers and 46 r.b.i. in only 267 times at bat. JAIME VARGAS New York

title: Grand Slam And Then Some
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bargaining to Keep Pol Pot Away From Phnom Penh
description: WHEN Secretary of State George P. Shultz paid his annual call on Southeast Asia this month, the region's message to Washington was clear: Don't let the Khmer Rouge go back to Cambodia. The plea seemed urgent because on July 25 in Jakarta, Communist and non-Communist Southeast Asians will meet to start on the tentative, treacherous road to a negotiated Cambodian peace.

title: NONFICTION
description: COGS IN THE WHEEL: The Formation of Soviet Man. By Mikhail Heller. (Knopf, $22.95.) Mikhail Heller, a Soviet emigre and author who has lived in Paris since 1969, has produced a textbook for the school of thought that depicts the Soviet Union as a great machine. Chapter by didactic chapter, he lays out the ideology and methods whereby, in his view, the Soviet citizen is denatured, beguiled, infantilized and frightened into becoming little more than a willing cog. ''Homo sovieticus,'' a new type of human being, is here, or almost here. Mr. Heller scoffs at those in the West who say that the Soviet Communists' vaunted engineering of souls has never been that consistent or that successful, and that the trend since Stalin's time has been away from the Great Leader's totalitarian utopia. The book was originally published in Paris in a French translation three years ago (this edition is anonymously translated from the French), before the rise of glasnost and perestroika, and the author supplies a new introduction dismissing these phenomena as variations on an old theme. Yet every week brings new headlines from the Soviet Union that seem to undercut his argument that essentially nothing has changed. All the same, Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms would not be having such hard going if it weren't for the Orwellian elements wedded to the Soviet system from its beginnings, and Mr. Heller's morose examination of this debasement of Soviet life provides valuable insight into what, to a large extent, the Soviet Union still is.

title: Sharon Iverson Is Married To Colas Huisman in Iowa
description: Sharon Iverson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Iverson of Des Moines, and Colas Huisman, a son of Gisele Thiriez and Denis Huisman, both of Paris, were married yesterday at the Embassy Club in Des Moines by the Rev. David Carllson, a Lutheran minister.

title: Officials Are Criticized Over Attack on Indian
description: LEAD: WHILE state and county officials have been working with the Indian community in Jersey City to ease tensions arising from attacks on Indians, the father of a victim criticized the judicial system for what he said was leniency shown to three of the youths accused of killing his son.

title: Commuter Calls It Quits
description: LAST year I lost my job at a major corporation in Manhattan. I had been commuting there daily from New Jersey for over 15 years. The company gave me a decent severance package, and I immediately did what any reasonable person would under the circumstances: I put in for a refund on my unused bus tickets, and I set my alarm clock ahead one hour.

title: Delay in Shuttle Launching Looms Over Leak in Engine
description: Engineers at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida intensified their search yesterday for a fuel leak in a space shuttle engine after 40 frustrating hours, increasing concern that the shuttle Discovery will have to be rolled away from the launching pad and its next flight will be delayed for months.

title: Dean S. Brown Is Wed To Janet Lynn Howard
description: At St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Weston, Mass., Janet Lynn Howard, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Howard of Weston, was married yesterday to Dean Stewart Brown, the son of Mrs. Marvin Novak of Norwell, Mass. The Rev. John M. Scott, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. David Van Dusen.

title:
FOCUS: Denver;
Convention Center Coming
description: LEAD: SITE preparation has started here for a new convention center, the centerpiece of this city's efforts to strengthen its national competitive position in the city-as-host business.

title: Who Are The League M.V.P.'s at This Stage?
description: The Pirates' Andy Van Slyke is the best overall outfielder in baseball, possibly the best center fielder of the last 10-15 years, and the second best player in the National League. That's why he finishes second. The best player in the N.L. is Darryl Strawberry. Without him, the Mets would be looking up in the standings.

title: New Polish Work Lures Eli Wallach
description: LEAD: ELI WALLACH takes to the stage of the new Cultural Center of Southampton Tuesday to appear in a reading of a world premiere. How he got there is a tale well told, even by the standards of show business.

title: Out of Chaos, Alternative Orders
description: WITH the Agenda software it introduced last week, the Lotus Development Corporation is trying to define a category of software - personal information managers - that has emerged recently. Agenda is not the first personal information manager, and it certainly will not be the last. But because it comes from Lotus, whose 1-2-3 program defined spreadsheets, Agenda has the burden of explaining just what a personal information manager is.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: New Bedford, Mass.;
Star Store's Metamorphosis
description: LEAD: THE conversion of a department store into a first-class hotel has given a long-awaited lift to revitalization in the downtown commercial district in New Bedford, once the nation's whaling capital.

title: VISUAL ANECDOTES AND DRAMAS FROM A MASTER OF INNOVATION
description: Richard Redgrave (1804-1888) was one of the many painters represented in ''Hard Times,'' the survey of Victorian social realism that was recently staged at the Yale Center for British Art. But he was not the one who most deserved closer inspection. All the same, that is what he gets in the center's current show, ''Richard Redgrave R.A.,'' and evidently it is because he was not just an artist but a curator, educator, designer and, with his brother, Samuel, the author of ''A Century of British Painters.''

title: Julie Kalberer and James G. Turino, Architects, Married in Rhode Island
description: The marriage of Julie Lawton Kalberer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kalberer of Providence and Wakefield, R.I., to James Gerard Turino took place yesterday at the Peacedale (R.I.) Congregational Church. The Rev. Dr. Ernest Gordon performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Turino of Alpine, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Armenians Ask End to Strike
description: A regional official said speakers at a rally in Yerevan, the Armenian capital, called today for an end to a two-week-long general strike. The strike is to demand that Azerbaijan, a Soviet republic that borders on Armenia, give up control of Nagorno-Karabakh, an Armenian-dominated enclave inside Azerbaijan.

title: EVENTS FOR MANDELA ARE BANNED
description: The police today banned all events marking Nelson Mandela's 70th birthday and set up roadblocks around Pollsmoor Prison in Cape Town, where the black leader is confined.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
For a Summer Bracer in Tokyo, It's Eels to Go
description: LEAD: RESTING warmly on its bed of white rice inside a red lacquered box, the amber-glazed flesh is unctuously tender. An aromatic fragrance blends with that of the slightly sweet soy sauce glaze soaking into the top layer of rice. What is this delicious morsel, prized as a stamina-giving dish perfect for combating the summer blahs?

title: How Matters Stand at Session End
description: When the New York State Legislature broke off its session early this morning, many major issues remained unresolved, but a number of other matters had been addressed. Matters Pending

title: Arms Scandal: More Than a Matter of Greed
description: DURING the last Pentagon procurement scandal, in the mid-1980's, Karl G. Harr, then head of a lobby for arms makers, pointed to a fundamental contradiction of the arms industry. ''It is free enterprise that must serve two masters,'' he said, ''the Government customer and the corporate stockholder.''

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A WOMAN'S PRISON JOURNAL: Germany, 1944. By Luise Rinser. Translated by Michael Hulse. (Schocken, $15.95.) In 1944 the young German writer Luise Rinser was denounced by a friend and arrested for high treason. ''A Woman's Prison Journal'' - finally available in America after being the first book of its kind published in postwar Germany, in 1946 - is the secret diary she kept during her two months in a women's prison, awaiting an almost certain death penalty.

title: Tenant Managers
description: To the Editor:

title: Popular Featherweight Loses
description: Ed Hopson, the 5-foot-4-inch dervish featherweight from St. Louis, finally was beaten.

title: ANNALS OF THE BESIEGED
description: THE POLISH WAY A Thousand-Year History of the Poles and Their Culture. By Adam Zamoyski. Illustrated. 422 pp. New York: Franklin Watts. $24.95.

title: Lobs, Volleys and Smashing Whites
description: GOING to the net for a good cause, tennis players in Southampton, L.I., showed that they had the white stuff. Against the towering hedges of the village's estate area, classic tennis clothes in pristine white were the winners in the recent pro-celebrity benefit at Ilyse Wilpon's rented oceanside home. The event raised $450,000 for Ms. Wilpon's favorite charity, United Cerebral Palsy.

title: At 17 State Street, High Tech Passes Into the Vernacular
description: There is no airplane on the roof of the new office tower at 17 State Street in lower Manhattan, and there are no neon tubes in the lobby, or gigantic clocks, funny benches or umbrellas out front. Why, at first glance one might almost think that this sleek, thin skyscraper could have been put up by just any builder, and not by Melvyn Kaufman, the man who has made a virtual mission out of making the New York skyscraper entertaining. Over the years Mr. Kaufman and his brother, Robert, his partner in the William Kaufman Organization, have managed to put a Sopwith Camel atop their building at 77 Water Street, use a corrugated metal tube with neon as an entrance to 129 John Street, and put a tiny hillscape of undulating brick in front of 747 Third Avenue. Disneyland, more than architecture with a capital A, has been the inspiration.

title: Captivating Country Cousin
description: MANHATTAN is invading Long Island. This time it's more than the summer migration to the Hamptons. New York restaurateurs have found Long Island to be fertile ground. In the last year or two, Italian restaurants have led the parade of transplants: Sempre Vivolo in Hauppauge, Cirella's in Melville, Wainscott's Sapore di Mare and Villa Gattopardo in the village of Roslyn.

title: A COACH'S REWARD COMES FROM PLAYERS
description: When I do it in the fall, for the high school, my salary works out to about minimum wage. When I did it this spring, for the local soccer association, I got paid for the first time in 13 years, though far less than I could have earned at my real job as a writer.

title: Zap Me the Pepper, Please
description: SUNNY ROGERS shrieked with delight as, in one swift movement, Yothin Rojpattanadit, a waiter, swiftly zapped freshly ground pepper on her chicken dish with an object that looked like a prop in a ''Star Wars'' movie. At the same moment, with a similar weaponlike object, he sprinkled ground Parmesan cheese on the macaroni of an amazed Jeannette Watson.

title: Is It Time to Lose Sleep Again Over Inflation?
description: WITH the economy growing without interruption since 1982, unemployment down to just a bit over 5 percent and the country gripped by severe drought, people are starting to worry about inflation again.

title: Thirsty Plants Need Some Help
description: THE land in the Northeast is not as parched as farms in the Midwest and Southeast. Normal rainfall in this region, so far, is down by about 25 percent.

title: Protection for Drought-Plagued Habitats
description: The drought that has ravaged waterfowl nesting areas in Canada and the United States has produced habitat conditions described by some biologists as the worst they have ever seen. Responding to this, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service has already announced plans for more restrictive regulations during the 1988-1989 hunting seasons.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Potter Upsets Shriver: Third-seeded Barbara Potter upset top-seeded Pam Shriver, 7-6, 7-6, yesterday in the semifinals of the $200,000 Virginia Slims of Newport, R.I. Potter of Woodbury, Conn., ranked No. 16 in the world, faces second-seeded Lori McNeil of Houston in the final today. McNeil, ranked No. 9, defeated fourth-seeded Ros Fairbank of San Diego, 3-6, 7-5, 6-3. (AP) No Swedes in Final: Marcelo Filippini of Uruguay overcame a slow start to defeat Paolo Cane of Italy, 2-6, 6-2, 6-4, and Francesco Cancellotti of Italy eliminated the last Swede to reach the final of the $245,000 Swedish Open in Bastad. Cancellotti breezed past Christian Bergstrom, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) Sanchez Advances in Belgium: Fourth-seeded Arantxa Sanchez of Spain and third-seeded Raffaella Reggi of Italy won their semifinal matches in the women's $75,000 Belgian Open in Brussels. Sanchez, 16 years old, defeated fifth-seeded Isabel Cueto of West Germany, 6-0, 6-4, and Reggi beat unseeded Angeliki Kanellopoulou of Greece, 6-2, 6-2.(AP) Golf Walker Has 4-Stroke Lead: Colleen Walker lost her five-stroke lead on the first eight holes, but gained four in the final three to finish the third round of the Ladies Professional Golf Association Boston Five Classic four shots ahead of Jan Stephenson. Walker, who shot a 2-under-par 70, had a three-day total of 205. Stephenson had a 69 for a 209 going into today's final round. (AP) McCallister Matches Mark: Blaine McCallister, a seven-year pro seeking his first PGA Tour victory, followed his second-round 62 with a 63 to match a Tour scoring mark and take a four-stroke lead after three rounds of the $600,000 Hardee's Golf Classic in Coal Valley, Ill. McCallister's 62-63-125 total for the middle two rounds matched the best consecutive two-round total in PGA Tour history, equaling Ron Streck's total in the last two rounds of the 1978 Texas Open. McCallister finished three rounds at 17-under 193.(AP) Spencer and Tedesco Win: Steve Spencer and Larry Tedesco of Furman, Ga., defeated Bob Lewis and Bob Fairchild of Canterbury, Ohio, 1-up on the 20th hole for the championship of the John G. Anderson Memorial Tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club, Mamaroneck, N.Y. Smith Leads Seniors: Ben Smith shot a 5-under-par 67 to take a four-shot lead after two rounds of the Senior PGA Tour $350,000 Showdown Classic in Jeremy Ranch, Utah. Smith, a 54-year-old former auto mechanic, played the front nine in 30. (AP) Track and Field O'Mara Surprises Cram: Frank O'Mara, the Irishman who accidentally dented Sebastian Coe's Olympic hopes earlier this week, provided a nasty shock for another leading British middle-distance runner, Steve Cram, at the International Amateur Athletic Federation Kodak Classic in Gateshead, England. Just four days after causing Coe a leg injury by accidentally tripping him in a race in Dublin, the world indoor 3,000 meters champion narrowly beat Cram over two miles with a time of 8 minutes 17.78 seconds.(AP) Cycling Longo Extends Lead: Jeannie Longo of France extended her lead in the women's Tour de France by taking a short individual time trial. Longo, the defending champion, won the 19-mile fifth stage round Blagnac. Maria Canins of Italy was next, 21 seconds behind. (AP) Swimming World Record in Backstroke: Igor Polyansky of the Soviet Union broke his world record in the 100-meter backstroke yesterday, covering the distance in 55 seconds, Tass, the official news agency, reported. Polyansky, from the Siberian city of Novosibirsk, set the record at the Soviet championships in Moscow. His time was .16 seconds less than the record he set in a meet against East Germany last March in Tallinn.(AP) Horse Racing Forty Niner Sets Record: Forty Niner, in his first race since finishing seventh May 21 in the Preakness, set a track record in the mile at Monmouth Park in a $30,000 allowance race. Forty Niner, trained by Woody Stephens, won by seven lengths over Slew City Slew in the race, a prep for the $500,000 Haskell Invitational July 30. He paid $2.60 on $2 to win. Julie Krone rode Forty Niner, second-place finisher in the Kentucky Derby, to a time of 1:33 4/5, knocking four-fifths of a second off the record shared by Nahodah in 1957 and Rumptious in 1984.(AP) Boxing Brown Keeps Title: Simon Brown of Jamaica retained his International Boxing Federation welterweight title last night by knocking down Mexico's Jorge Vaca six times at Kingston, Jamaica, before the referee stopped the fight in the third round. Brown improved his record to 27-1, including 21 knockouts. The loss dropped Vaca to 43-7-1.(AP)

title: Berwick
description: To the Editor: Anne Wilson's article notes that Lindisfarne Castle is ''16th-century'' without further comment. Although this date, and its impressive location, may be sufficient reasons for some to seek it out, architecturally minded travelers might like to know that it was extensively rebuilt by Sir Edwin Luytens in 1903. According to David Dunster's ''Edwin Luytens'' (Architectural Monographs 6, New York, Rizzoli), ''he added a pantiled roof covering three new bedrooms beneath and remodeled elements such as windows and the tower at the west end. His primary achievement is the alternating sequence of internal and external spaces experienced by the visitor as he moves up between ramps, ramparts, staircases and rooms that appear to be hewn from rock.'' Since the castle is not a large structure when compared to others in the region, the greater part of what the visitor will see is Luytens's work. JOHN P. RASH New York, N.Y.

title: Waste Dumpers Turning to West Africa
description: In this African delta port, where children run barefoot through oil palm plantations and men pilot dugout canoes through mangrove swamps, the arrival of a ship from Europe has often meant disruption.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Rehabilitation Spurts in Hudson County
description: LEAD: SINCE the middle of the decade the shortage of affordable housing, combined with a shrinking supply of buildable land and a renewed interest in urban areas, has spurred rehabilitation projects in Hudson County and elsewhere.

title: The Genteel Feasts and Manners of the Victorians in Norwalk
description: LEAD: The art of dining in the Victorian era was rank with do's and don'ts in contrast to today's more casual, eclectic style, and there was a measure of charm to it, as shown in a new exhibit at the Lockwood-Mathews Museum in Norwalk called ''Savory Suppers and Fashionable Feasts: Dining in Victorian America.

title: Americans Are in the Fast Lane
description: In 1896, Thomas Burke of Boston won the 100-meter dash in the first of the modern Olympic Games, and not much has changed since then.

title: CRYPTO-INTELLECTUAL NEUROTICS AND OTHERS
description: NOT A FREE SHOW By Helen Schulman. 165 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Tampopo Starring Tsutomu Yamazaki, Nobuko Miyamoto, Koji Yakusho, Ken Watanabe, Rikiya Yasuoka, Kinzo Sakura, Mampei Ikeuchi. Directed by Juzo Itami. 1987. Republic Pictures Home Video. 112 minutes. $79.95. In Japanese with English subtitles. Not rated.

title: Conversations Probe American Culture
description: THE conversation faltered at the word ''mingled.''

title: BONN CELLIST TO PLAY AT BENEFIT
description: When the Mark Brent Dolinksy Memorial Foundation helped finance the Westchester Conservatory's ''Arts in Education Initiative'' last year, it was just the latest addition to a long list of donations to organizations and projects assisting Westchester adolescents.

title: A Floating Pool For New Yorkers?
description: PICTURE this on a steamy summer day: a breezy recreation center, with a refreshing 10-lane swimming pool and open-air cafe, floating serenely on the New York waterfront.

title: POLICE SAY BLACK IS VICTIM OF BIAS
description: In what the police described as a racially motivated incident, a black New York City sanitation worker was hospitalized yesterday after he was attacked by a group of white men on a street corner in the Belmont section of the Bronx.

title: Hi-Fi Show Ear-Catchers
description: My colleague John Rockwell was actually writing about something else, but what he said aptly describes the state of audio: ''Most of almost anything is not very interesting. Some of it is downright meretricious; much of it is mediocre or second-rate. Occasionally something first-rate comes along.''

title: Christa Ludwig Sings Schubert's 'Winterreise'
description: A cautiously worded paragraph of justification in the program notes for Deutsche Grammophon's new ''Winterreise'' recording (423 366-2) reminds us that in recent decades it has been considered unusual or inappropriate for a female singer to perform this work. Christa Ludwig is not the first woman to record Schubert's great cycle in the postwar era, but she is certainly the most celebrated, and hers is the first to be issued on a major label. For most of the four decades spanned by her career, the general view has been that women should sing lieder whose ''ich'' is either indeterminable or feminine.

title: Olympics Will Be Safe, Shultz Is Told
description: The Soviet Union and China have assured the United States that they will use their influence with North Korea to help make the 1988 Olympics in Seoul free of terrorism, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today.

title: When the State of the Refrigerator Mirrors the State of One's Life
description: I'VE always had the feeling that if I could store my leftovers neatly, the rest of my life would fall into place. A person who has an organized refrigerator has life by the tail.

title: Suzanne Stroble Plans To Wed Douglas Sitter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Coon of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Coon's daughter Suzanne Louise Stroble to Douglas Richard Sitter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Richard Sitter of Bronxville. An Oct. 1 wedding is planned. Miss Stroble, a daughter also of Charles R. Stroble of Greenwich, Conn., graduated from the University of Richmond and was presented at the Westchester Cotillion in 1982. She is an assistant press secretary to Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia. Her father is the president of Stroble & Associates, a human-resource consulting firm in Greenwich.

title: Close Match in Olympic Trials
description: Commanding leads by skippers in seven of the eight Olympic yachting classes turned the last day of United States trial racing into a formality for the crews involved.

title: Toxic Waste Uprooting Elderly From Trailer Park
description: Guy Reynolds had planned to stay put for the rest of his life. At the age of 82, he spends most of his time caring for his handicapped wife, Dorothy. He likes his life in his blue mobile home in this Connecticut River Valley town.

title: Greek Cruise Ships: 'Easy Targets' for Terrorists?
description: The Greek captain of this ferry and a 21-year-old American passenger agree on one thing: Excursion ships like this one in the Aegean seem highly vulnerable to terrorist attacks.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Where the Dead Drew Throngs

title: DOG SHOW FINDS NEW AUDIENCE
description: LEAD: The tiny, wire-haired Border Terrier named Charity runs over to the phone, picks up the receiver and starts barking. She is merely repeating an act she learned during her heyday as a television actress, but her audience is enthralled.

title: Decisions After the Vote
description: Short of some startling event, the prospects are that foreign policy won't be a significant issue in the campaign. Major foreign governments, the Soviet Union as well as allies, are unusually relaxed this year as they anticipate a new U.S. administration. Despite Republican emphasis on Michael Dukakis's lack of foreign policy experience, the impression is that main policy lines have been set and won't change drastically whoever wins.

title: Atlanta Up Close; An Institution Inherited
description: RED geraniums and blue delphiniums stand bright against yellow and orange marigolds in a clash of colors and fragrances that characterizes the summertime Southern garden. There is the heady sweetness of magnolia and gardenia blossoms, black-eyed Susans, daisies, day lilies and azalea hedges. Slate walkways wind through clipped spreads of ivy, with dogwoods, maples, oaks and pines towering over in a leafy mesh.

title: Hers; Child's Play, Women's Sway
description: WHEN I HEARD A bunch of women were having a jacks tournament last summer on Martha's Vineyard, I didn't hesitate: I invited myself and my best friend, Wendy. Jacks! The very word was like a bell that tolled me back to childhood summers, to hour after hour (when time was not money) spent on the small concrete porches of our cabins at camp doing ''Cherry in the Basket,'' ''Flying Dutchman'' and ''Over the Fence.''

title: Heavy Rain Forces A Rare Suspension
description: The third round of the 117th British Open was wiped out today by a steady rain that flooded a number of greens at the Royal Lytham St. Annes links. Then the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews, which conducts this tournament, the oldest in the sport, promptly set about causing considerable confusion about the next two rounds.

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Ben Bova;
'Science Fiction Leapfrogs The Tough Stuff'
description: LEAD: In a few months, the space shuttle is to roar into orbit, after being grounded two and a half years. But in its imagination, the country has never left space. In fact, for more than 60 years, Americans have ventured off the earth through science fiction.

title: HUSBANDS AT BAY
description: LEAD: ONLY CHILDREN By Rafael Yglesias. 523 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: Treat the Causes, Not the Symptoms
description: FRUSTRATION with our current welfare system runs deep. Conservatives see it as a narcotic, encouraging illegitimacy and dependency. Liberals complain that welfare benefits are too small and that the system isolates, stigmatizes, even humiliates recipients. Americans generally oppose its expansion. Some of the disdain for welfare comes from misunderstanding. Only one-quarter of those who ever use welfare actually do so for 10 or more years, although long-term users are a much larger fraction of those found on the rolls at any point; short-term users move off quickly and long-term users tend to accumulate. Virtually every highly regarded study has found that welfare plays only a minor role in out-of-wedlock births. And just slightly more than 1 percent of the gross national product is spent by all levels of government on cash, food or housing assistance for persons who are neither aged nor disabled.

title:
The View From: The Port Chester Station;
Commuters in a Daily Race To Secure a Parking Spot

title: New & Noteworthy
description: AFTER THE GARDEN, by Doris Jean Austin. (Plume/ New American Library, $7.95.) A rich black girl from Jersey City falls in love with a boy from the wrong side of the tracks. Last year, our reviewer, Robert G. O'Meally, praised the author of this ''eloquent first novel'' for her ''startling command of nuances of black vernacular speech and of human feeling [ and ] her very unfirst-novel-like control of technique.'' BECOMING A DOCTOR: A Journey of Initiation in Medical School, by Melvin Konner. (Penguin, $7.95.) When he was 33 years old, the anthropologist Melvin Konner decided to go to medical school, where he found the stressful, rigorous training reminiscent of that experienced by healers in a Kalahari tribe. ''The confidence to heal comes in part through the pain,'' he wrote.

title: Sullivan Is on Pole Despite Problems
description: Danny Sullivan ran into a mechanical problem when his engine went cold today, but he held onto the pole position for the CART Toronto Molson-Indy race Sunday as a strong effort by Mario Andretti fell just short.

title: Cute. Who's Her Agent?
description: WHEN PLANS FOR A NEW STAGE version of Vincente Minnelli's 1944 movie musical ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' were hatched, some of the people who now want to be in it couldn't yet speak, much less sing. It's been four years since the producer Louis Burke got together with Hugh Martin and Ralph Blane, composers of the original score (which includes ''The Trolley Song'' and ''Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas''). At long last, there's a new book by three-time Tony winner, the late Hugh Wheeler (he died last year); there are 10 new songs by Martin and Blane; there's an opening scheduled at the Kiel Opera House in St. Louis in early December, and there's a talent search under way. Open auditions have been held in six cities for two teen-age roles - Esther, famously originated by Judy Garland, and her young swain, the boy next door - as well as for the role of Esther's unbearably cute little sister, Tootie. ''We've seen maybe 250 Tooties,'' including those shown above, in New York, says Burke, who will direct. Finalists will be chosen by early next month.

title: Audrey Hochberg On Refuse Policy
description: The County Government, which should be encouraging recycling and working to hold down refuse disposal taxes, is doing just the opposite. This results from its failure to enforce the terms of its waste disposal contracts with the local municipalities, and the county's disregard for sound fiscal practices in its dealings with the private carters. These policies harm taxpayers and the environment.

title: As the Soviets Go to Mars, the U.S. Wants to Know Why
description: AS part of the most complex interplanetary endeavor yet attempted by the Soviet Union, two probes have soared into space in the last two weeks to explore Mars and its moon Phobos. While enthusiasts of detente were heralding the launchings as a prelude to a possible Soviet-American manned visit to the planet by 2010, some critics in the Reagan Administration were worried about military implications. For more than a year, officials of the two countries have argued over whether the Soviet mission, which will sample the surface of Phobos using one of the most powerful lasers yet flown in space, can also be viewed as a test of antimissile space weaponry.

title: On Language; Coiners' Corner
description: THE GREATEST thrill a man can experience, Winston Churchill was reported to have said, is to be shot at and missed. (If that quotation cannot be found in his works, I have taken a shot at the source and missed.) For a writer, the big thrill is to coin a word or phrase that fills a linguistic void and becomes part of the history of the era. The widespread adoption of Churchill's blockbuster phrase >Iron Curtain must have been profoundly satisfying to him as a historian as well as a statesman; never mind that earlier uses of the phrase were found. In the same way, the ghost of Teddy Roosevelt must smile when a modern pol denounces his >lunatic fringe.

title: POSTINGS: Along Kill van Kull; Harbor Rentals
description: Richmond Terrace was supposed to be the spine of a construction boom on Staten Island's northwest coast. The shoreline drive's harbor views and proximity to the Staten Island ferry were expected to be a magnet for workers in lower Manhattan just starting out. But when Harbour View opened in May at 388 Richmond Terrace, four-fifths of a mile from the St. George ferry terminal, it stood out as the first new construction at the head of the Kill van Kull in over a decade.

FRANCES PATIKY STEIN

title: NONFICTION
description: ANATOMY OF A SCIENTIFIC DISCOVERY. By Jeff Goldberg. (Bantam, $17.95.) People packing for summer holiday might well consider tucking into their kits Jeff Goldberg's story of the search for endorphins, the body's own opiates, producers of everything from the runner's high and the anesthetic effect of acupuncture to (maybe someday) ''the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow: the nonaddictive painkiller.'' Mr. Goldberg, co-author of ''Flowers in the Blood: The Story of Opium,'' provides just enough heft to keep the summer reading list respectable, and what with the passions of scientific privacy, some test tube nitty-gritty, the mystery of the brain, little guys versus big guys and millions of dollars at stake, the book moves right along. In the end, the little guys - an unlikely team of John Hughes, a cockney who went to Yale, and Hans Kosterlitz, a cranky and quite solid German Jewish refugee, working out of a derelict university laboratory in Aberdeen, Scotland, an oil boom town - are the winners. Among the losers are Avram Goldstein, an exquisitely intelligent research and grants master at Stanford's superb labs, and crack groups from Johns Hopkins, among other universities, and Eli Lilly, among other pharmaceutical companies. Sort of winners, that is. The men from Aberdeen beat out the competition in discovering morphinelike chemicals in the brain and, in 1975, announcing they had. No one, including them, has since been able to figure out how to turn endorphins into the ''bee without a sting.'' The sequel is eagerly awaited.

title: Atlanta Up Close; A Journey Into Black History
description: REMNANTS of the history of blacks in the South are largely hidden, apart from the well-documented heritage trails in main cities. Atlanta, for example, is fairly well preserved: There is Auburn Avenue, a two-mile strip that Fortune magazine once called ''the richest Negro street in the world.'' There is the childhood home of Martin Luther King Jr., the church where he preached and his tomb. There are the schools, including Morehouse and Spelman, that form the Atlanta University Center, the largest private consortium of black institutions of higher education.

Not having a car, I was advised to take the train to Berwick in England, where I could get a bus to Duns in Scotland.

title: FICTION
description: AMBUSH AT OSIRAK. By Herbert Crowder. (Presidio, $18.95.) Basically, ''Ambush at Osirak'' is about hardware, the kind of hardware that kills - offensive weapons with cute names like Sidewinder and good-neighbor names like SAM. Herbert Crowder sets this novel of political intrigue and suspense in the Middle East. Iran is at war with Iraq. Iraq is at war with Israel. Israel is at war with just about every neighboring Arab country and, at times, even itself. Osirak, just outside Baghdad, is the site of a nuclear plant, the ''atomic weapons arsenal for the forces of Islam in their sworn campaign to purge Israel from the face of the earth.'' Years earlier, Israel had devastated Osirak in a pre-emptive air strike, putting the Iraqi end of the arms race on hold. Now, with Russian aid, Iraq is back in the game and Israel plans an encore. This time, however, Iraq is ready. Dropped into this scenario is David Llewellyn, handpicked by the President of the United States to be the No. 2 man in the American Embassy in Jerusalem. There's a mole loose and Llewellyn is to ferret it out, thus saving the world from a nuclear holocaust. There's more, of course, including attempts by both the Russians and the Americans to topple Israel's government, and even a little romance between Llewellyn and a stunning Israeli spy. But most of all there's that hardware. In fact, the most successful parts of this first novel are those in which Mr. Crowder, a former missile radar engineer, shares his technical knowledge of weaponry. Unfortunately, although he writes smoothly and with a certain flair for detail, his plot and characters never seem as interesting as all those planes and missiles.

title: DISPATCHES FROM THE RUBBLE
description: ''How did you find Lebanon?'' Kahlil Gibran wrote to a friend. ''Did you find it as lovely as your imagination and yearning had made it out to be, or did you find it a barren land of complacency?'' Lebanon has always been a land of contradiction, the crossroads of fact and fantasy. Beirut is the biggest contradiction of all: for some, it's tennis at the St. George Hotel in a past of prosperity; for others, it's a widening gyre of gunmen and anarchy. In BEIRUT: City of Regrets (Norton, Cloth, $34.95; Paper, $19.95), Eli Reed and Fouad Ajami present a portrait of the city in photographs and words. Mr. Reed, a photographer for Magnum, arrived in Beirut in the fall of 1983 and spent four and a half months taking pictures of a dying city. In one photo, refugee children from Sabra and Shatila stand above the rubble of a house; by a bullet-chipped cinderblock wall is a cage of parakeets, feathers blue like the sky and yellow like the ruins. The photos can be dramatic and touching, but they are overshadowed by Mr. Ajami's account of the decline and fall of Beirut. Mr. Ajami, a Middle East specialist and author of ''The Vanished Imam,'' acknowledges his debt to the Oxford historian Albert Hourani. But he repays it with a colorful, thoughtful appraisal of some of the thousand and one tales about Lebanon, such as ''the city's great myth - that it was a place where Islam and Christianity met and fashioned a society of compromise.'' In addition to drawing on Gibran, Mark Twain and many others who have written of Lebanon, Mr. Ajami weaves in the Beirut he saw by streetcar while growing up in the 50's. In the end, he lets the Syrian-born poet Nizzar Qabbani write the city's epitaph: ''Nothing remains of old Beirut except the scent of it that blows from old notebooks.''

These are to be found either at plain independent places or at what are called ''limited service'' chains, such as Days Inn, Motel 6, Comfort Inn, Travelodge and Econo Lodge, which the publication Hotel and Motel Management says are the five largest in this category.

title: The Yucatan
description: To the Editor: In reference to the letter by Prof. Evon Z. Vogt Jr. (Travel, April 24), which recently came to my attention: The tendency to refer in English to the Yucatan is perfectly normal and correct. Just as we say the Ukraine, the Bronx, the Yukon, we say the Yucatan. Spanish usage has no bearing on it. The writer implies that North American usage is somehow ignorant or disrespectful of the local form. In fact, different languages have different rules. The French are not mistaken in calling Mexico Le Mexique, in accordance with French rules for use of the article with names of countries, although, in Spanish, the country is called Mejico, with no article. More such examples could be quoted, but the point is that usage in the local language does not set down rules for usage in foreign languages. PAUL GLASSER Department of Linguistics Columbia University New York, N.Y.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Fantasy Golf ''WHOAA, there's another natural element,'' said 14-year-old Jeff Sharman, as he and his golfing buddies stepped around one of their golf course's unusual ''hazards'': a recent fertilizer deposit left by Casey, the club's mixed-breed mascot.

title: Reviews/Music; Al Grey, Trombonist, And Quintet
description: Al Grey, the trombonist who was one of the great latter-day stars of the Count Basie Band, has been leading a quintet that is focused on two jazz generations, at Carlos I, 432 Avenue of the Americas, below 10th Street. The group - which ends its engagement today - includes Mr. Grey's son, Mike, also a trombonist, and the guitarist Joe Cohn, the son of the late tenor saxophonist Al Cohn.

title: Business Fears Behind Long Island Arms Inquiry

The checks, and several others later mailed, totaled $14,000 and were from business people and others who wanted to see military spending on Long Island increased.

title: Elderly Become Tennis Novices
description: When Howard Weiss of Norwalk showed up for an instructional tennis program at Scalzi Park in Stamford recently, he brought along an abundance of enthusiasm but not the proper equipment.

title: Atlanta Up Close; An Inside Look at the City
description: ATLANTA has a streak of self-promotion that seems ingrained in the civic character, the understandable result, perhaps, of the city's growth in two decades from a sleepy Southern town to a bustling commercial center.

title: Review/Concert; Victor Borge's Melange Of Relics and Inspiration
description: Victor Borge, at 79, remains the Heifetz of the malapropism; he doesn't do badly with the piano, either, and he controls an audience with impressive virtuosity. On Friday evening, at the second of his seven Carnegie Hall shows, the audience was a ticklish one that at first seemed to find Mr. Borge's presence alone sufficient reason to giggle, and for a while he played along happily with the crowd's mood. But eventually, he had the audience listening attentively - and without so much as a chuckle - to his straightforward renderings of several sugary Romantic showpieces.

title: Pina Bausch Adds Humor To Her Palette
description: The second half of ''Victor,'' a dance-theater piece by Pina Bausch, begins with a woman making exactly the same arm-rotating gestures that William Forsythe uses in ''Steptext.'' These are taken from the exercises and movement ''models'' developed by the German modern-dance pioneer, Rudolf von Laban. Thus, what looks mysterious is not as meaningless or as secretly coded as it appears.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about military contractors incorrectly described the Pentagon's actions against a company linked to the investigation of procurement fraud. The Pentagon suspended a single unit of Varian Associates Inc., the Continental Electronics Division, from future military contracting work.

title: Geoffrey Bruun, 89, Historian and Teacher
description: Geoffrey Bruun, a historian and biographer who taught at New York University from 1927 until 1941, died of a kidney ailment on Wednesday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 89 years old.

title: Will the Stealth Bomber Work?
description: SOME TIME around election day this November, America's putative wonder weapon for the 21st century - the Northrop Corporation's B-2 ''Stealth bomber'' - will lumber into the air for the first time. As the boomerang-shaped machine climbs away from its birthplace at Palmdale, Calif., for a 25-mile flight to Edwards Air Force Base, a cluster of generals, industrial leaders and politicians will be on hand, their fingers tightly crossed.

description: My husband and I and another couple had the pleasure of seeing ''Fools'' at Studio Theater in Lindenhurst.

title: Headliners; At Fault
description: Federal District Judge Hubert I. Teitelbaum was in no mood to have some woman lawyer calling herself ''Ms.'' in his Pittsburgh courtroom and further offending his sense of propriety by refusing to use her husband's name. He ordered the lawyer, Barbara Wolvovitz, to call herself Mrs. Lobel - her husband is Jules Lobel, a law professor - and threatened to jail her. ''Do what I tell you or you're going to sleep in the county jail tonight,'' he said. But a judge can change his mind, particularly when it is brought to his attention that the law is not on his side - Judge Teitelbaum had said, incorrectly, that a married woman in Pennsylvania needed court permission to go by her maiden name. So last week he apologized. ''I recognize your right to be addressed in any manner in which you see fit,'' he said. ''I was wrong.''

description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee completed her remarkable assault on another world record today in the heptathlon, finishing with 7,215 points at the United States track and field Olympic trials to become the first athlete to break 7,200 points, for her third world record in two years.

title: 2d Bus Lane Is Not the Answer
description: ALTHOUGH trans-Hudson transportation congestion is worsening at an increasing rate, it seems that the only corrective steps being considered amount to little more than Band-Aids. Moreover, the few practical solutions that have been presented are ''too little and too late.''

title: 'IF YOUR BOOKS ARE FUNNY, PLEASE TELL ME WHERE'
description: LEAD: One of the letters I regularly receive in my large daily post is something I have come to call the Wissenschaft letter. It comes with a foreign stamp and can be from a university in Germany, France, Italy, Spain, Denmark or Greece - any one of the European countries where they study contemporary literature in a decidedly energetic and theoretical sort of way.

title: Kimberly L. Dahl Is Wed To Richard Norman Hoag
description: At the Park Congregational Church in Norwich, Conn., Kimberly Louise Dahl, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thure William Dahl Jr. of Norwich, was married yesterday to Richard Norman Hoag, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Norman Hoag of Winnetka, Ill. The Rev. H. Donald Smith performed the ceremony.

title: LET SINGAPORE BE SINGAPORE
description: Ian Buruma sees Singapore as a ''city of homeowners . . . a city without slums, where women can safely walk the streets at night, in many ways an ideal society,'' but suggests that the absence of Western-style democracy makes Singapore a ''city of fear'' (''Singapore,'' June 12). Having years of exposure to Singapore (and a professional relationship with its Development Bank), we have a different perspective. We say, let Singapore be Singapore. Singapore's critics should consider that the balance that has been struck by the Lee Government, although not democratic in the American sense, may be correct for fledgling Singapore, in its third decade of independence.

title:
GARDENING;
Caring For Plants Exposed to Stress
description: LEAD: It is not uncommon for an apparently healthy plant to die without warning. A tree that appeared to be healthy and vigorous in spring may be dead by mid-summer. It may have died so suddenly that its leaves remain in place all dried and scorched.

title: Cynthia Gowen, Arts Consultant, Engaged to Wed
description: Cynthia Hood Gowen's engagement to William Michael Crawford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll E. Crawford of Wayzata, Minn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George W. Gowen of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The couple plan to marry Sept. 10.

title: Beach Waste Raises New Fears
description: TWELVE years after Long Island's last major bout with garbage washing onto South Shore beaches, residents once again watched with concern as medical waste and other debris scattered along 25 miles of oceanfront, closing numerous beaches to swimming and raising public fears of a rapidly degrading marine environment.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: What Great Big Eyes Art Has While writers generally tend to magnify things, Paul West goes them one better and turns one of his characters into ''a walking microscope.'' This is from ''Those Pearls His Eyes'' in ''The Universe, and Other Fictions'' (Overlook).

title: Autumn Wedding For Ms. Sandler
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Sandler of East Norriton, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lauren Beth Sandler to Samuel David Zurier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin L. Zurier of Providence, R.I. The couple plan to marry Sept. 25.

title: Man Arrested in June Killing That Led to 911 Suspension
description: A 26-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday for the June 21 murder of his ex-girlfriend, the police said. The murder drew wide attention because a 911 dispatcher apparently delayed at least 20 minutes before sending a car to the scene, and the victim was shot while she was making a second desperate call to police. The dispatcher was suspended. William Elliot, of 238-15 148th Drive in Rosedale, Queens was arrested yesterday without incident yesterday near the corner of 112th Street and Northern Boulevard in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: In Its Most Symbolic City, the South Gets a Chance to Show How It's Risen
description: The last time a major political party came to the Deep South for its convention was in 1860. The Democrats met that year in Charleston, S.C., wrangled furiously over the slavery question, cast 57 deadlocked ballots, adjourned and went home without nominating anyone.

title: Beach Buggies Upsetting East End
description: LEAD: ON THE East End, the persistent issue of the rights of year-round local residents versus the rights of part- time residents and tourists escalates during the summer. An issue that has brought the conflict into sharp focus is an attempt by the Town of East Hampton to restrict the use of vehicles on its beaches.

description: They are mostly commerce, but at least partly entertain ment, and the combination is making auctions more popular than ever.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Orioles' manager, Frank Robinson, underwent back surgery yesterday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. Dr. Donald Long, who removed a disk, said that the surgery went ''very well'' and that he expected a prompt and thorough recovery. Robinson is expected to remain hospitalized for three or four days. He will be out of uniform a minimum of two weeks, the club said. . . . Bone chips from the right elbow of Von Hayes, the Phillies' first baseman, will be removed tomorrow in an operation at Methodist Hospital in Philadelphia. The 29-year-old Hayes is expected to be out until the middle of September.(AP)

description: The University of Alabama's star tailback, Bobby Humphrey, suffered a broken jaw early yesterday in an attack at a Tuscaloosa, Ala., area nightspot that left another Crimson Tide player slightly injured, Coach Bill Curry said.

title: 'Tintypes': A Cheer For the Melting Pot
description: THE United States may be getting battered in the daily headlines, out at Studio Theater the bruised flag is being proudly honored in a rousing revival of ''Tintypes.'' In this intimate musical by Mary Kyte, Mel Marvin and Gary Pearle, we are once again infused with the spirit of adventure of the great wave of immigration that took place around the turn of the century. If these immigrants arrived in New York and discovered that the streets were not paved with gold, they merely shrugged and determined to do some repaving.

title: The Hovnanians Add New Twists To a Tale Of Success in Jersey
description: SOMETIME this summer, K. Hovnanian Enterprises will complete its 30,000th home someplace along the East Coast between New Hampshire and Florida. Like nearly all the others that have brought the Hovnanian company success as a home builder, it will be a town-house condominium in a growing outer suburb. And it will probably be purchased sight unseen by someone who is buying a home for the first time.

title: Charles W. Lubin, 84, Sara Lee's Founder
description: Charles W. Lubin, founder of the Kitchens of Sara Lee, died Friday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, apparently after suffering a heart attack while driving. He was 84 years old. A Chicago native, Mr. Lubin was apprenticed to a baker at the age of 14 in Decatur, Ill. In 1949, he named his first special cheesecake for his 8-year-old daughter, Sara Lee. He created the rich dessert in one of three small Chicago bakeries he had bought with his brother-in-law for $1,500 in 1935.

title: THE REGION: On the Streets; Unlocking the Gridlock for Those Who Must Drive
description: IN a city increasingly composed of rich and poor, New York's streets often seem like one of the last bastions of democracy, equalizing all in immobility and gridlock. But with many of the city's arteries clogged most of the time, and with Federal air-quality standards looming that could mandate sharply reduced automobile emissions by the early 1990's, traffic officials are being forced to consider alternatives that could strike at the very heart of the cherished tradition of driving one's own car even in midtown Manhattan. The questions are not easy. Can enough motorists be persuaded to make the change to mass transit to keep the system from congealing around those who must drive? And indeed, who gets to decide who must drive, and whose need is less urgent?

title: What We Need Is Fewer People

Service aboard the Pendolino, a red and cream, all-first-class train built by Fiat, started in May between Rome and Milan, the country's two largest cities, offering nonstop travel in about four hours twice a day.

title: The Bunny Hops into History

It was a commercial formula suited to the times. By 1972, a million keyholders had joined 22 clubs. At the end of this month, the last of Hugh Hefner's U.S. hutches (in Lansing, Mich.) will close.

title: A Retailing Resurrection?
description: American women, in general, have held off buying new clothes for more than a year, producing the longest dry spell for women's apparel in more than four years. Because sales of women's and girls' clothes represent about 60 percent of all clothing sales, this has severely affected the nation's retail sales. What will sales look like this fall? Russell Stravitz Executive vice president, Bloomingdale's.

title: 'Nuclear Blackmail'? No, Best Deal
description: TWO weeks ago, Irving Like, a trustee of the Long Island Power Authority, criticized the State and Long Island Lighting Company Shoreham agreement, calling it ''nuclear blackmail.'' Mr. Like went on to criticize the negotiating process, contending that somehow Vincent Tese, the state's chief negotiator, prevented myself and L.I.P.A.'s chairman, William Mack, from successfully completing a Lilco takeover. Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: Did Mozart Order a Side of Fries?
description: Sometimes I wonder if I am, all unaware, living in one of those reverse-image universes that science-fiction writers assure us exist out there. You know, the world in which large dogs and cats keep cute people as pets or the one where everyone dies at birth and then grows inexorably younger unto eternity. In the world that I inhabit, for instance, it is not necessary to persuade anyone that Mozart is a profound composer. No thoughtful being in what I thought was the only world has believed otherwise for many generations.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Cincinnati Is Host For the Convention
description: LEAD: THE 97th anniversary convention of the American Numismatic Association will open Wednesday at the Convention Center in Cincinnati, Ohio. More than 15,000 visitors are expected to attend the show, which continues through next Sunday.

title: Long Absent, Glen Tetley Returns
description: When the National Ballet of Canada opens its weeklong season tomorrow evening at the Metropolitan Opera, its program will include the much-anticipated New York premiere of Glen Tetley's hourlong ballet ''La Ronde,'' based on the play by Arthur Schnitzler and set to a score by Erich Wolfgang Korngold. (The company, with guest artists Natalia Makarova and Fernando Bujones, will also perform John Cranko's ''Onegin'' and the New York premiere of Robert Desrosier's ''Blue Snake.'') The story of ''La Ronde'' is perhaps best remembered from the acclaimed 1950 French film by Max Ophuls, in which love is a merry-go-round of sexual encounters by couples from various stations in life who recklessly meet, part, then move on to someone else. In its balletic incarnation, ''La Ronde'' is Mr. Tetley's hommage to the Vienna of the 1920's at its most deviously cynical and sensually explicit.

title: FICTION
description: MEMORY OF DEPARTURE. By Abdulrazak Gurnah. (Grove, $15.95.) The mingled anger and longing of an expatriate seeking to come to terms with his homeland inform every page of this fierce, vivid first novel by Abdulrazak Gurnah, a Tanzanian-born writer who now teaches at the University of Kent in England. Set in a bitterly poor, unnamed East African state ruled by a totalitarian regime that is both brutal and hopelessly disorganized, ''Memory of Departure'' is a compelling study of one man's struggle to find a purpose for his life and a haunting portrait of a traditional society collapsing under the weight of poverty and rapid change. Hassan Omar and his family are black Moslems in a country in which religion has ceased to have any importance. His father, a minor civil servant frustrated by his powerlessness, can communicate with his children only by varying the pitch of verbal and physical abuse he hurls at them. After a confrontation with thugs recruited by the regime, Hassan is sent off to a wealthy relative in Kenya. But the community he discovers there is equally ruthless. Devoid even of socialist rhetoric, it has been given over to the relentless pursuit of money and the unthinking embrace of all things Western. Here, Hassan begins to uncover his own values, to invent himself, after falling in love. The affair, and Hassan's eventual fate, are rendered in a poignant and convincing fashion, conveying a young man's bittersweet and quite believable truce with unavoidable circumstances. What lingers in the imagination, though, is Mr. Gurnah's singular portrait of a world spinning out of control: of crushing poverty; sour, hopeless lives; rapacious governments; age-old cultures giving way - and behind it all, the specter of chaos always threatening.

title: Considering the New Alternatives
description: You may have noticed, this weekend, an unfamiliar subculture wandering around midtown Manhattan and the city's rock clubs. Those people with high-concept haircuts and plastic rectangles dangling from their shirts have arrived for New Music Seminar 9, the quasi-convention of the ''alternative'' music business. With panel discussions and exhibitions at the Marriott Marquis, showcase concerts all over town and enough networking to boggle a neurophysiologist, the New Music Seminar has evolved from a cabal of disaffected music-business people to a hotel-filling annual institution with a $295 registration fee. It has been courted in recent years by major record companies that want to stay up to date, yet it still attracts fringe elements, eager beginners and even a rebel or two.

title: As Ever, Democrats Would Prefer a Contest
description: HUBERT H. HUMPHREY never tired of proclaiming Democratic dedication to ''the politics of joy.'' Fellow Democrats of various stripes have long insisted that, win or lose, love feast or fistfight, they have a lot more fun nominating their Presidential candidates than do the Republicans. More noise, more disorder, more gleeful fratricide. Truth to tell, however, the Democrats have not had much political fun at a national convention in a quarter-century or more. There was plenty of ugly action at the 1968 brawl in Chicago and some clever manipulation in Miami in 1972, but both the resulting nominees, Hubert H. Humphrey and George McGovern, went down to defeat, and their conventions have had to share the blame.

title: FICTION
description: ZENO WAS HERE. By Jan Mark. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) When John McEvoy, a schoolteacher and family man, discovers he is the basis for a character in a book by a long-forgotten acquaintance, his peace of mind begins to crumble - especially because he's been depicted as an arrogant, thoughtless rogue who had once been responsible for the death of a mutual friend. McEvoy, previously unaware that he had such an unsavory reputation, becomes obsessed with the way he appears to the world, pestering his friends for their opinions of him, evaluating his actions and their consequences over and over again. He starts to wonder, for example, if he is to blame for the creepy, compulsive behavior of his thoroughly awful wife. The more he doubts himself, the more he identifies with the character in the book, and the more he begins to believe he is living out the role (as yet unwritten) that must be that character's destiny. While he's trying to sort this out, he has a most unlikely affair with a wildly eccentric poet named Ruth Prochak, for whose fate he also believes he (or the book's character) is responsible. Jan Mark's engaging premise in her first novel for adults (she has published several books for children in England) is filled with brain-teasing ambiguities and multilayered plot developments. Unfortunately they are not satisfyingly explored. The characters are relentlessly quirky, in some cases merely grab bags of idiosyncrasies rather than fully rendered personalities. At one point, McEvoy's confidante, Geneva, claims she is ''writing a book about a man who's writing a book, but the more he writes, the further he is from finishing it.'' While it's clear the man Geneva is writing about is none other than McEvoy, it's not until she gives away the working title that the reader realizes how elaborate this hall of mirrors actually is.

title: NONFICTION
description: TEMPERED ZEAL: A Columbia Law Professor's Year on the Streets With the New York City Police. By H. Richard Uviller. (Contemporary, $19.95.) This book is a shrewd appraisal of how police officers handle criminal procedure: searches and seizures, arrests, lineups and interrogations. H. Richard Uviller, a onetime prosecutor who now teaches law at Columbia University, spent a sabbatical back on the front line of the criminal justice system - the crime-ridden Ninth Precinct in lower Manhattan. Since the Supreme Court over the past few decades ''had been unabashedly engaging in lawmaking as instruction'' in police practices, he wondered: ''Were the cops awake and responsive at the other end of the pipeline?'' Riding along with members of the precinct's robbery investigation unit, Mr. Uviller sought the answer to this question. Not surprisingly, many officers mistakenly feel the Court has meant to discourage all searches and seizures. They also think they should be able to talk freely with suspects in the squad car, saving Miranda warnings for precinct-house interrogations. But the author found, ultimately, that the rules are working, though police officers can play a very tough game: ''Their notorious efforts to alter the facts to fit the rules are evidence of both the fact that the cops grasp the essence of the Court's message and that they reject its wisdom.'' Mr. Uviller uses anecdotes to show how the law is played out in practice and effectively illustrates street life. (In one telling scene, three teen-age suspects leaf through a book of mug shots as if it were a high school yearbook.) There are no polemics here - only a sober, sympathetic look at modern-day police work.

To my fevered, innocent eye, the Bois was the perfect embodiment of the dream picture I had painted in my mind of France. Here was Manet's ''Dejeuner sur l'Herbe,'' luncheon on the grass. Here were Renoir and Degas and Seurat, sun streaming through the trees and dappling the lawns and gardens with shadow and light.
