title: Team Readies for '88 Trials
description: Hours before most teen-agers roll out of bed during their summer vacations, 17-year-old Janel Jorgensen of Ridgefield is up and on the go at 6 A.M. Monday through Saturday. For her, however, even that is sleeping late, since she gets up at 4:40 A.M. during the school year to train at the Wilton Y.M.C.A. before school.

title: On the Waterfront: Films Afloat
description: The struggle to devise new ways to entertain New Yorkers continues. During a season in which dancers have performed in a swimming pool and theater audiences have had a chandelier crash toward their heads, it was probably to be expected that movie theaters would be found floating on city waterways. Certainly, it is rather refreshing to have something other than medical wastes washing up on New York shores this summer.

title: Guidry and Heat Melt White Sox
description: The hot, heavy air finally wore down Ron Guidry. He worked five innings yesterday at the Stadium, and then he reluctantly gave in to the climbing temperature: 87 degrees when the afternoon began, 96 by the time help arrived from the bullpen.

title: Iraqis Say They Plan To Give Up All Land Captured Inside Iran
description: The Iraqi Government announced tonight that it would withdraw from the Iranian city of Dehloran as part of a plan to refrain from holding any Iranian territory.

title: Philip Sills, 68, Maker of Women's Clothing
description: Philip Sills, a Russian-born immigrant who manufactured women's sportswear and collected contemporary American art ranging from cartoons to circus posters, died of lung cancer in his Manhattan apartment Saturday. He was 68 years old.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis

title: New York Visitors: Japanese Take Over
description: Tiffany's is ready. All its salespeople have been instructed in basic Japanese, including counting. The Fifth Avenue jeweler has laid in a trove of medium-sized, 18-karat-gold Elsa Peretti heart necklaces, which, at $350 apiece, are the single most popular item among Japanese customers.

title: A Services Trade Plan For GATT
description: Australia plans to propose a set of principles Monday to establish free global trade in services, including banking, insurance and transport.

title: Treasury Offering Only Bills This Week
description: The schedule of new Treasury issues for this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * China and the Soviet Union increased trade by nearly a third in the first half of this year, compared with the corresponding period last year. The Xinhua News Agency said China sold the Soviets $670 million worth of goods and imported $627 million worth from January to June in the largely barter trade. It said the two-way trade was up 32 percent from the first half of 1987. Xinhua said the Soviets largely buy agricultural products and raw materials from China, including corn, soybeans and meat. Mechanical products, from refrigerators to locomotives, make up 30 percent of China's purchases from the Soviet Union, with the rest of the purchases consisting of timber, steel, fertilizer and raw materials.

title: Jersey Grapples With High Cost Of Insuring Cars
description: Even as the State Legislature has struggled unsuccessfully to reduce automobile insurance rates, New Jersey motorists have been battered by a succession of increases in the premiums they must pay.

title: Lester V. Chandler, Economist, Dies at 82
description: Lester V. Chandler, an economist, author and adviser to the Federal Government during World War II, died of leukemia Saturday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 82 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Answer to Nursing Shortage Is More Nurses; Patients Would Suffer
description: To the Editor:

title: Weather Forecasters Enjoy Boom
description: When the commodities market took a sudden plunge on June 28, Charlie Notis described it as one of his most gratifying moments. No, Mr. Notis is not a speculator who beat the markets for a pocketful of trading profits.He is a meteorologist.

title: Today's Schedule
description: All times are eastern daylight. 6:24 P.M.Call to order by Paul G. Kirk Jr., party chairman. 6:46 P.M. Reports on rules and credentials by Democratic officials. 9:08 P.M. National Anthem lead by Garrison Keillor. 9:24 P.M. Keynote address by Ann Richards. 10:08 P.M. Remarks by Mr. Kirk. 10:34 P.M. Address by former President Jimmy Carter Television Coverage CBS ''CBS This Morning'': Michael and Kitty Dukakis, 7:35 A.M. NBC ''Today'': Michael Dukakis, 7:07 A.M.; Michael and Kitty Dukakis, 7:15 A.M. CNN ''Democratic National Convention'': Live coverage, from the Omni Coliseum in Atlanta, beginning at 4 P.M. C-SPAN ''Election '88: Delegates' Roundtable'': Interviews and discussion with Democratic National Convention delegates, 4 P.M., followed by live convention coverage. ABC, CBS, NBC ''Democratic National Convention'': Live coverage from the Omni Coliseum in Atlanta, 2 hours, from 9 P.M. CBN ''700 Club'': Democratic National Convention coverage, 1 hour, from 9 P.M.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Cargill, Wilson Wins Charter Medical Ads
description: The Charter Medical Corporation of Macon, Ga., plans to run multimedia advertising in the markets where it operates its 87 psychiatric and substance-abuse hospitals. The company is publicly held and has revenues of more than $1 billion.

title: Egypt Depositors Protest
description: More than 1,000 depositors demonstrated today outside the offices of an Egyptian Islamic investment company, protesting a law that has temporarily frozen their funds. Depositors said they had been unable to draw on their funds at el-Rayan Investment Company since the Government passed a law last month regulating such firms. El-Rayan is one of half a dozen Islamic firms, estimated to control more than $2 billion in deposits, which operate risk-sharing enterprises in which depositors take a percentage of profits or losses. They do not pay fixed interest, which is banned by Islam. The Government passed a law on June 9 requiring the companies to go public, issue investment deeds to depositors and submit to strict scrutiny by state regulators.

title: Mobil Project In Nigeria
description: Mobil Producing (Nigeria) Ltd. plans to bring a large Nigerian condensate field into production, the company's managing director said.

title: Aliza S. Rubin, 74, Nursery School Founder
description: Aliza Sass Rubin, who founded the West Side Jewish Community Nursery School 10 years ago and directed it until her retirement last year, died early yesterday at her daughter's home in Connecticut, following a brief illness. She was 74 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 18, 1988: MONDAY

title: Outdoors: Slick Salmon
description: ''MY plan for tomorrow after you and I take our early morning shot at the big river is that you drive to Two Brook,'' said my host Joseph Cullman 3d. ''You'll have it all to yourself.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9 Refugees have flooded into Malawi from Mozambique. In the last 20 months, more than 600,000 Mozambicans fleeing civil war have crowded into Malawi, a poor nation that cannot feed its own people. Page A1

title: Baker's Identity Crisis
description: Howard H. Baker Jr. will make his maiden speech on the lecture circuit tomorrow in Asheville, N.C., and one of the stories he plans to tell is about his first visit to the White House as the newly minted majority leader of the United States Senate.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation, parent of the Chemical Bank, has named Joseph G. Sponholz chief financial officer of the bank and the parent, which is the nation's fourth-largest banking company.

title: Review/Rock; Heavy Metal From Sweden
description: Yngwie Malmsteen, the 24-year-old Swedish heavy-metal guitarist, started his show from offstage at the Beacon Theater on Friday night.

title: After Years of Soviet Chill, West Germans Warm to Gorbachev
description: Across Western Europe, the vaunted ''new thinking'' of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, is stirring sympathy and softening perceptions of a Soviet military threat. But perhaps nowhere is popular enthusiasm for Mr. Gorbachev as strong as in West Germany.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hathaway to TBWA
description: TBWA Advertising has been assigned the C. F. Hathaway Shirt Company by Warnaco Men's Apparel, Warnaco's president, Robert R. Lindley said. He said no budget had been set. Warnaco's seven-year relationship with Eric Mower & Associates has ended, Mr. Lindley added.

title: Tensions Within OPEC Heighten Oil Price War
description: A widely anticipated collapse of production restraint within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has combined with political discord to clear the way for what many oil industry officials describe as a free fall in oil prices.

title: Coke Earnings Increase 13.8%
description: The Coca-Cola Company has reported that its second-quarter profit rose 13.8 percent, to $303.1 million, reflecting brisk domestic and overseas soft-drink sales.

title: 'Acquaintance' Is Charged In Kingston Woman's Death
description: A man from Kingston, N.Y. was arrested early yesterday and charged with the murder of a black teen-ager who was found strangled last week with the letters ''KKK'' carved into her body, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Jackson Seeks Unusual Role In Campaign
description: The kind of ''partnership and shared responsibility'' that the Rev. Jesse Jackson is seeking for himself and his followers in the fall campaign exceeds what any loser in a Presidential nominating race has ever sought or been granted.

title: Griffith Joyner Keeps Going
description: Florence Griffith Joyner is for real.

title: Rebuffed, Governor to Take His Shoreham Plan to L.I.
description: With Governor Cuomo unable to win support in the State Legislature for his plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the battle now moves onto the plain of public relations as the Governor and his opponents take their cases to the people of Long Island.

title: Long-Term Dangers in Dollar Rise
description: The continuing rally in the dollar has had short-term benefits, including making imports cheaper and reducing the prospect of higher inflation. But it also hides real long-term dangers, including a slowdown in economic growth and a widening, rather than narrowing, United States trade deficit, according to three new economic studies.

title: SHUTTLE ENGINEERS LOCATE FUEL LEAK
description: After more than two days of toil, engineers at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida yesterday pinpointed the source of a leak in a small, hard-to-reach space shuttle fuel tank and struggled to find a way to fix it.

title: Body Washes Ashore on L.I.; Thought to Be Missing Boy
description: What was believed to be the body of one of two 16-year-old boys who were last seen last Monday paddling a surfboard on Long Island Sound, was found on a beach in Orient, L.I., yesterday, the police said.

title: Horse Racing; 10-1 Shot Captures Prioress
description: Fara's Team, who had the poorest winning percentage in a field of eight 3-year-old filly sprinters, rallied from just off the pace to lead a parade of long shots home in the $87,000 Prioress Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Sewage Pollution Reported Common in New York
description: The release of raw, or untreated, waste from New York City sewage-treatment plants is almost an everyday occurrence, a nonprofit lobbying group says.

title: Youth Will Be Served In Jets' Plans for 1988
description: LEAD: The other day, prior to the opening of training camp, the Jets ran their 1987 highlight film for some guests at their Hofstra training camp. The closest this Walt Disney version of ''Towering Inferno'' came to reality was to describe last season as ''a roller coaster ride.''

title: Lawyers Say Robins Plan Has Approval of Creditors
description: The A. H. Robins Company's bankruptcy reorganization plan appears to have been approved by all the groups asked to vote on it, lawyers involved in the case say. The plan would create a trust fund valued at $2.47 billion to compensate women injured by Robins's Dalkon Shield birth control device, pay off all other creditors in full and allow Robins to merge with the American Home Products Corporation.

title: Hide That Agenda
description: This is the first Democratic Convention dedicated to benumbing all controversy. The strategy at this confabulation of concealment is to hide the changes that the election of its nominees would bring. Here are a few of the questions being evaded: 1. Why does Jesse Jackson refuse to make clear what his constituency requires in return for its enthusiastic support?

title: Study Finds Less Bias Against Asian Workers
description: Based on an analysis of income levels, discrimination against Asians has declined dramatically since the 1960's and does not appear to be widespread in the American labor market, according to a study by the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: Ex-Meese Aides Balk at Testifying About Quitting
description: There are growing indications that Congress will never learn the full story behind the abrupt resignations last March of two senior Justice Department officials.

title: For Farmers: Relief, Not Perversity
description: With election-year politics speeding a drought relief bill through Congress, this week's Democratic Convention break comes at a good time. Thousands of farmers and livestock breeders need and deserve help, but not a free dip into the Treasury.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMEV Holdings Inc., the United States arm of N.V. AMEV, a Netherlands-based multinational financial services company, elected as a director Robert J. Blendon, the chairman of the department of health policy and management at the Harvard School of Public Health.

title: David McK. Key, 88, A Former Ambassador
description: David McKendree Key Sr., a retired Foreign Service officer who was Ambassador to Burma and Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs, died of cancer Friday at his home in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: New Product Plans at G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to devote a larger part of its capital spending to developing new products and will share more of those costs with high-technology suppliers, the company's president, Robert C. Stempel, said today.

title: Reviews/Music; Relief From the Heat Via Mozart and Respighi
description: In the midst of this nasty weather, Mostly Mozart's Friday concert did its best to soothe us. There was the most sweetly singing of Mozart's piano concertos, the 23d (K. 488), then his familiar teen-age hit the ''Exultate, Jubilate.'' We were also stroked (lightly) with ''The Birds'' by Respighi and a bit more firmly by the Brahms Serenade in A. Gerard Schwarz conducted; Bella Davidovich was the pianist and Hei-Kyung Hong the soprano. The place as usual was Avery Fisher Hall.

title: CAN CROSS-TRAINING IMPROVE YOUR FITNESS?
description: THE triathlete has taken on mythic proportions. He has become a superhuman who can run, swim and cycle in an orgy of exertion that would have left even the toughest warrior of ancient Sparta prostrate in the dust. A national sports magazine recently featured Dave Scott, winner of the Ironman triathalon in Hawaii, and asked if he might not be the world's greatest athlete.

title: Cuomo Sees Risk in Arrest Of Brawley
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that several factors - the public safety, the independence of the police and Constitutional protections such as the First Amendment -had outweighed the state's desire to arrest Tawana Brawley's mother, Glenda, for contempt of court when she left a Brooklyn church Saturday.

title: FOR NOVICE HOCKEY, DREAMS COME TRUE IN JULY
description: THE players arrive minutes before the face-off, lugging hockey equipment and looking awkward on a steamy summer evening in New York City.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Housing Hope in the Bronx
description: The vacant lots on Andrews Avenue in the Bronx are littered with collapsed baby carriages and crushed bottles. Yet hope survives on Andrews Avenue under the auspices of a city initiative called POMP - Private Ownership Management Program. POMP is as vigorous as the tree that grows in an Andrews Avenue courtyard.

title: The Media's Blind Spot: Themselves
description: Anyone who pays attention to the news saw a great deal of the following during the last year: the fate of the family farmer, the Robert Chambers murder case, the crackdown on Noriega, the plight of little Jessica McClure, who fell down a well in Texas.

title: Giants Hope Image Reflects a Winner
description: It unfolded in Chicago on that memorable Monday night last September when the Giants were battered and embarrassed by the Bears, 34-19. That night was when the Giants began looking in the mirror - a mirror that did not lie.

title: Hard-Line Folly on Nicaragua
description: Those thirsting for renewed confrontation between Washington and Managua have got their wish. The extremists on both sides are regaining the upper hand. And while it seems too late to hope that the Reagan Administration would begin serious negotiations, it's far too early in the present turbulence to consider renewing military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Judith Silverman Weds
description: Judith Ann Silverman and Matthew Sloan Fenton were married yesterday at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens, by Rabbi Michael Ehrlich. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Silverman of Glendale, Queens, is a nursery-school teacher at Public School 127 in Elmhurst, Queens. Mr. Fenton, a son of Malcolm Fenton of New York and Lois Sloan Fenton of Mamaroneck, N.Y., is in the apprenticeship program of the Directors Guild of America.

title: Castro Urges Sugar Gain
description: President Fidel Castro wants Cuba to increase its revenue with a bigger sugar harvest next year, according to the official daily newspaper Granma. At a Communist Party meeting on Friday, it said, he called for an increase to 8 million metric tons, from this year's estimated 7.3 million tons.

title: Howard Newman Weds Dr. Razavi
description: Dr. Maryam Razavi and Howard H. Newman were married yesterday at the bride's home in Manhattan. Rabbi David B. Kudan officiated.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * George Miller is joining Calvillo, Shevack & Partners as executive vice president and creative director.

title: LEBANON RADICALS RESUME ATTACKS
description: After a lull lasting three months, Lebanese Shiite Moslem guerrillas backed by Iran have resumed large-scale attacks on Israeli troops and their Christian allies in southern Lebanon.

title: Long-distance Tribute to Jim Fixx
description: Thanks to the long-distance determination of runners in North-east Scotland, Jim Fixx, the author and running guru, was memorialized Saturday in Hardwick, Vt., where he collapsed and died four years ago after a training run.

title: Newport Party Recalls City's Sumptuous Past
description: The Newport Preservation Society's annual dinner dance was held Saturday night and the prominent and the not-so-prominent gathered once again to drink a toast to the sameness of it all, The scene was, as always, The Breakers, the mansion that is the crowning attraction of this idyllic resort community. .

title: China Warns On Price Abuse
description: China's Prime Minister Li Peng warned that abuses of the country's price reform program could threaten social stability, the Government's news agency said today.

title: Nigeria to Ban Cigarette Advertising
description: Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, plans to prohibit cigarette advertising by the end of this year.

title: A COOL ADVANTAGE TO TENNIS
description: The idea started out simply enough. Nancy Abt, a recreational tennis player in Sarasota, Fla., suggested to a friend that she wear a scarf stuffed with ice cubes around her neck to cut down on overheating during a match.

title: PRICE HOLDS TWO-STROKE LEAD
description: Three of the world's best golfers - Nick Faldo of England, Seve Ballesteros of Spain and the Scot, Sandy Lyle - are within three shots of South Africa's Nick Price going into Monday's final round of the 117th British Open.

title: Panhandling Woman Charged in Beating of Boy, 3
description: A 3-year-old boy was severely beaten on a sidewalk in the Flatiron District at 3 A.M. yesterday, and a woman who was baby-sitting the boy has been arrested on a charge of assaulting him when he refused to continue to help her panhandle, the police said.

title: Program Helps the Disabled Farmer
description: On the wall of Bill Field's office there is a poster that reads, ''Together we will Break New Ground,'' with a photograph of a farmer and his small son walking down a path, the boy holding the hook on his father's prosthetic arm.

title: Chile's Debt-Swap Plan Cuts Loans by $4 Billion
description: While recurring foreign debt crises continue to plague most of Latin America, Chile has made inroads in its debt through the most aggressive buyback program in the region.

title: 10 Lifters Picked for Seoul
description: Mario Martinez, a silver medalist at the 1984 Olympic Games, heads a squad of 10 weight lifters that will represent the United States at the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul.

title: Philadelphia Journal; Reunion of Clan Marks A Heritage of 300 Years
description: There has almost never been a Philadelphia without a Rittenhouse. The name calls forth images of old money and low-key gentility.

title: A Sad Chapter Ends
description: The long-running debate over whether and how to compensate the Japanese-Americans who were interned in relocation camps in World War II is about to come to an end. A House-Senate conference committee has reached agreement on a new bill, and President Reagan, who was earlier urged by the Justice Department to veto the measure, is now reported as all but certain to sign it.

title: Sports World Specials; Football, Italian Style
description: When the phone rang on a June day in 1984, Sam Rutigliano figured he knew the caller's business. He was the head coach of the Cleveland Browns then, and training camp was creeping ever so close. The season never ends in the National Football League.

title: Chubb Denies It Reneged
description: The Chubb Corporation denies that it reneged on a drought insurance offer, despite its decision to provide coverage to only about 10 percent of the Midwest farmers who applied.

title: Blackmun Has Sharp Opinions Of Colleagues
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun singled out colleagues on the United States Supreme Court by name for personal criticism in a speech in which he expressed concern about bloc voting by President Reagan's judicial appointees.

title: Johannesburg Journal; Mandela, 70, Captivates Even Those Who Jail Him
description: After more than quarter of a century behind prison bars, Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela, a legend in his own lifetime, is sometimes portrayed as holding the Pretoria Government captive.

title: Man Asserts AIDS Illness Was Revealed
description: A man with AIDS-related complex has filed a formal complaint that his medical confidentiality was violated by the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and the city Human Rights Commission.

title: INSIDE
description: Shultz Criticizes Seoul The Secretary of State assailed South Korea's tendency to close its markets while expecting open markets in the United States. Page A3. Mandela Turns 70 Nelson Mandela, turning 70 today after more than 25 years in prison, is sometimes portrayed as holding South Africa itself prisoner. Page A4.

title: Books of The Times; Pilgrim's Regress In Dallas, Late '63
description: Libra By Don DeLillo. 456 pages. Viking. $19.95.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ketchum Details Plans For Dutch Venture
description: Ketchum Communications, an advertising agency based in Pittsburgh with $600 million in billings, has disclosed further information on its previously announced plans to set up a joint venture based in the Netherlands called Brunning & Ketchum International with the Brunning Group, a publicly held British communications company, which unlike Ketchum, has no overseas operations.

title: South St. Seaport Ignoring Its Museum Role
description: To the Editor:

title: The Democrats Gamble on Tinkering and Sleaze
description: This is an ideal city for the Democratic Presidential nominating convention. It is a symbol of the changing world, full of promise and problems, with its slums and skyscrapers broiling in the Southern sun.

title: Charles J. Meyers, Law School Dean, 62
description: Charles J. Meyers, a former dean of the Stanford University Law School, died yesterday at his home in Denver. He was 62 years old and had been suffering from throat cancer.

title: In Nicaragua, I Am a Camera
description: LEAD: I traveled to Nicaragua recently to get the feel of the place and, I hoped, to interview a Representative from my state on human rights matters. Instead I got the vertiginous feel of what it's like to be at the center of an international incident. I was one of several Americans who attended a by-now infamous anti-Sandinista rally the Sunday before last.

title: Brain Death Proposal In Jersey Is Dangerous
description: To the Editor:

title: Sprinter's Form Overtakes Her Fashion
description: As good a runner as she is, Delorez Florence Griffith Joyner has been better known through the years for her sense of fashion.

title: Review/Theater; Options for a Murder
description: Arthur Jamison is a highly successful criminal lawyer who would like to get rid of his wife. Permanently.

title: Competition Grows in Paperback Business
description: Sales of mass-market paperback books have been flat for three years, unsold paperbacks are being returned in record numbers and the outlook for the next several years is equally bleak. In theory, then, mass-market publishers should be cutting back on the number of books they publish, and other publishing houses should be thankful they are not in such a cutthroat end of the business.

title: 'At Risk' Author Discusses Fears About AIDS
description: If Alice Hoffman had set out to write a calculated, commercial novel, she could not have done better than ''At Risk,'' the story of an 11-year-old girl, from a perfectly average middle-class family, who has AIDS. ''I never once thought, 'Oh, AIDS is this hot topic; I'm going to write a novel about it and make a lot of money.' '' Ms. Hoffman said on a recent visit to New York. ''I don't write books for that,'' she said with a laugh. ''I write screenplays for that.''

title: Laura Gardner Is Wed To Mitchell B. Briskin
description: The marriage of Laura Gardner to Mitchell Bruce Briskin took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederic J. Gardner, in West Falmouth, Mass. Katherine Norton, a justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Ex-Sailor, a Suspected Spy, Granted Asylum by Soviets
description: A former Navy enlisted man who is the subject of an espionage investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been granted political asylum in the Soviet Union, the Soviet press reported today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How long ago was the spitball made illegal in the major leagues?

title: Answer to Nursing Shortage Is More Nurses
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: American League; Angels' 4-Run 8th Topples Tigers
description: Brian Downing snapped a scoreless tie with a two-run single with two outs in the eighth inning, and Terry Clark pitched a five-hitter for eight innings as the California Angels defeated the Detroit Tigers, 4-0, today.

title: Foreign Police Training Leads to Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: TWELVE WEEKS TO A BETTER BIATHLON
description: WHAT kind of preparation does it take to race in a biathlon? Ned Northrop, a 45-year-old management consultant from Arden, N.Y., runs 4-8 miles one day, and then bikes 20-25 miles the next on a rotating schedule. Every other week, from April through September, he competes in at least one scheduled event. Since he also enters local triathlons, he looks at biathlons as ''a way of being able to start the season early and keep it going late.''

title: Medical Waste Shuts Jacob Riis Park Beach
description: The beach at Jacob Riis Park in Queens was closed to swimming yesterday after park rangers discovered some discarded syringes that they believe had washed up on shore with the morning tide.

title: Reviews/Music; Rappers at Irving Plaza
description: It wasn't until four acts into Street Rap Explosion at Irving Plaza on Saturday night that the crowd stopped booing. A few weak-kneed, cloddish English rappers and an obvious and shrill, self-proclaimed female version of the rap group Public Enemy had the crowd in a nicely belligerent mood.

title: Iroquois Bid for Portec
description: Iroquois Brands Ltd. said Friday that it had offered to acquire Portec Inc. in a stock swap under which one Iroquois common share would be exchanged for five Portec common shares. Iroquois, a holding company based in Greenwich, Conn., , said the offer would be subject to the refinancing of a bank loan on which Portec defaulted and on a satisfactory agreement with Portec's management. Iroquois also said the deal would require approval of both companies' shareholders. Portect, based in Oak Brook, Ill., makes construction and materials-handling equipment. Portec stock gained 25 cents on the New York Stock Exchange Friday, to close at $5.625.

title: 600,000 Mozambique Refugees Tax an Already Desperate Malawi
description: More than 600,000 Mozambicans, fleeing the cruelty of war, have crowded into this tiny country over the last 20 months. Hundreds more come across the border each day, with no end in sight.

title: Linda Weinstein, Editor, Weds Michael C. Barnas
description: Linda Jane Weinstein, a national editor at The Associated Press in New York, and Michael Carl Barnas, a lawyer for the General Electric Company in Schenectady, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Swan Club in Roslyn Harbor, L.I. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Marketing Service Firm For Senior Executives
description: Harry Clark, 52 years old, a former executive vice president of J. Walter Thompson, has joined with Peter T. Smith, 46 years old, who went from client to agency to client, to start Smith Clark Associates in Princeton, N.J., to provide ''senior managers with innovative marketing and communications services.''

title: Sports World Specials; Financial Incentive
description: Thomas McCants spent May 15 to June 29 in Sweden, Czechoslovakia, Switzerland, France and West Germany. Obviously, he did it because he had money.

title: Music in Full Bloom At Union Square Park
description: Free music and colorful flowers will be featured at the Second Union Square Park Full Bloom Festival, beginning today in the park, which is situated between 14th and 17th Streets, from Park Avenue South to Broadway. The annual festival, sponsored by the 14th Street-Union Square Local Development Corporation, will run through July 29 and will include performances of jazz, country, rhythm-and-blues, new-wave and African-Caribbean music. All concerts begin at noon; on the program today is the Inner Circle All Stars Jazz Quartet.

title: The Advertising Slogan in Decline
description: They don't write them like that anymore.

title: Sports of the Times; A Whole Lot Of Quacking
description: THE strangest element in the strange case of Mike Tyson vs. Bill Cayton just might be Kevin Rooney, Tyson's trainer.

title: Review/Jazz; A Precocious Saxophonist
description: Listening to the 18-year-old alto saxophonist Christopher Hollyday play is a bit like hearing a baby speak in a grown man's voice. Mr. Hollyday, who ended an engaement at the Village Vanguard last night, has learned the tricky be-bop vocabulary of Charlie Parker, Cannonball Adderley and Jackie McLean - a vocabulary created from intellectual and emotional maturity under social duress.

title: Giants Receiving Warm Welcome
description: IN this peaceful Morris County hamlet, where there exists no main street or central business district, the event of the summer usually occurs in late August, when packed Volkswagens return students to Fairleigh Dickinson and Drew, the two local colleges.

title: Long Balls, Bit of Anger Spur Mets
description: For those eager to witness a real floor fight, they will have to wait until later this week and move a mile or so downtown. The Mets and the Braves emptied their benches in the seventh inning this afternoon, but once they converged near the mound, they milled more than they mauled and exchanged more yawns than they did hostilities.

title: Morton Kline, 85, Dies; Lawyer and Developer
description: Morton Kline, a New York City lawyer and real-estate developer, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Reporter's Notebook; With Rather and Cronkite, That's the Way It Is
description: If the Michael and Lloyd show is expected to be staid television fare, then the Walter and Dan show is considered, in the nervous phrase of a CBS News executive, ''a 40-ton bundle of dynamite.''

title: Inflation Fear Casts Pall on Bond Market
description: Fears of a resurgence of inflation cast a pall over the credit market last week, and investor confidence in fixed-income securities is expected to be further undermined in the foreseeable future.

title: Before They Get Down to Business, Atlanta's Visitors Go Out and Party
description: For weeks, Larry Cochran cut deals, traded votes, bartered favors and today, at last, here he was, an Arkansas delegate to the Democratic National Convention, standing in the sun-splashed lobby of a north side Atlanta hotel and sipping champagne and orange juice.

title: Metro Matters; A History Maker Recalls the Door That She Opened
description: Since 1948, only two New York-bred candidates have been nominated for the national ticket by either major party.

title: TV Notes
description: 'Funny People' Debut

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Planning Can Reverse Suburban Traffic Crush
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Road Back: Alvarado Vitalizing a School District
description: After the scandal that forced him to resign as Chancellor of New York City's public schools, many of Anthony Alvarado's friends and colleagues advised him to find another line of work or even leave town.

title: Tour de France; Giving a Ride Nobody Wants
description: Driving in the Pyrenees early this afternoon, Philippe Pietrowski heard on the Tour de France's radio frequency that two riders had fallen far behind. ''I think we have customers,'' he said.

title: U.S.-Canadian Trade Outpacing the Treaty
description: Canada, with the world's second-largest area, and the United States, with the world's largest free-market economy, are fast forging a colossal continental economy of nearly 260 million consumers. And they are doing this quietly, almost without noticing it themselves.

title: Calculation Mixes With Compassion
description: After President Reagan decided that compensation should be paid to the families of those killed when an American warship downed an Iranian jetliner in the Persian Gulf, the White House described it as a purely humanitarian gesture.

title: Boxing; Hopson Fails to Make Team
description: Ed Hopson, a 5-foot-4-inch perpetual motion fighter from St. Louis, lost his place on the United States Olympic team when he was beaten by Kelcie Banks of Chicago in an unpopular decision on the last day of the Olympic boxoffs at Caesars Palace.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The coffee is only for drinking, not for tasting. It's not coffee, it's only black water.'' - Thierry Ponchon, a French tourist in New York City. [ B2:3. ]

title: Hot and Cold, Then and Now
description: Once, summer in New York City was the season for staying outdoors. People who had fire escapes perched on the landings; people who didn't lounged in the parks. At night, strollers moved slowly along streets still hot from the sun, staring somnolently into shop windows. It was the era of the tangled sheet, the lukewarm shower and the long pause in front of the open refrigerator door.

title: SHULTZ DENOUNCES KOREANS ON TRADE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz sharply criticized South Korea today for what he decribed as its unfair foreign trade practices. He acknowledged that his remarks might add fuel to growing anti-American sentiments here.

title: Runner Who Fell Wins an Appeal
description: Essie Washington, who fell and eventually finished fifth in a women's 800-meter semifinal today at the United States Olympic trials, won an appeal and was advanced to the final.

title: Summons in Bhopal Case
description: A Bhopal magistrate has issued a fourth summons for the former chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, Warren M. Anderson, to appear in court on criminal charges stemming from the 1984 gas disaster at a company plant in Bhopal.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council Meets at 3:30 P.M. on Iranian complaint against United States General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10:30 A.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE ON THE INDIAN OCEAN - 3 P.M.

title: DUKAKIS ASSERTS CONTROL AND ASKS DEMOCRATIC UNITY
description: Michael S. Dukakis arrived here today for the Democratic National Convention that is to nominate him for President on Wednesday, pledging to seek unity but insisting that he, not the Rev. Jesse Jackson, must be in charge.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Mark Cross Items And a New Theme Line
description: The venerable Mark Cross, supplier of leather goods for the well-to-do, is getting a new print ad campaign from Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, with the theme line ''No wonder Americans have such style. They have Mark Cross.'' To accompany this uplifting line, the agency has come up with black-and-white photographs against which new products, in color, will stand out. The new product line comprises items whose designs have been taken from company files and updated. Mark Cross was founded in 1845. The ads, as two-page spreads or full pages, will first appear in the August issues of Vogue, Elle, GQ, Town & Country, Vanity Fair, Accessories magazine and the Fashions of the Times and Men's Fashions sections of The New York Times Magazine.

title: May Stores Talks of Sale Of Mall Stake
description: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that it was holding discussions with several parties to sell 50 percent of its interest in 28 shopping centers across the country.

title: Reviews/Music; Roger Norrington and the Bostonians
description: Roger Norrington, best known in this country as the currently most admired exponent of the original-instruments movement, is a 54-year-old English conductor with wide experience in the full range of modern performance, very much including modern symphony orchestras. Thus his debut Saturday night with the Boston Symphony at Tanglewood was of interest beyond the occasion of great music very well performed: it showed how one period-performance specialist chose to adapt to the exigencies of contemporary mainstream concert life.

title: Soviets Print the Works of a Dissident Poet
description: A popular weekly printed poetry by the writer Yuli M. Daniel today, becoming the first Soviet publication in more than 20 years to publish the verse of a man who was jailed in one of the most celebrated trials of Soviet intellectuals in decades.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Regulatory Expert Head Of Texas Savings Unit
description: LEAD: The United Savings Association of Texas, the state's largest savings and loan institution, has elected Lawrence Connell, a Washington lawyer and expert in savings industry regulation, to be its president and chief executive officer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * South Street Seaport to Siegel & Gale.

title: Market Place; Wall St. Wonders About Icahn Plan
description: THE nation's most prominent corporate raider, Carl C. Icahn, may be keeping a low profile these days but Wall Street has a watchful eye on him, nevertheless.

title: Yes, He'll Be There, As Delegate Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo will make his first appearance at the Democratic National Convention here Monday at a meeting of the 293-member New York delegation.

title: Jane L. Penziner Weds Daniel George Dausch
description: Jane Laura Penziner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Lawrence Penziner of White Plains, and Daniel George Dausch, a son of George Edward Dausch of Easthampton, Mass., and Kathryn Dausch of Fairfield, Conn., were married yesterday at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Walter Lawton, the leader of the Westchester Ethical Cultural Humanist Society, officiated.

title: Gallant Elephant, 82, Is Dead in Sri Lanka
description: White flags flew today over Kandy, the old Buddhist capital, as the nation mourned Raja, the elephant who was called the country's ''most venerated moving monument.''

title: Herbert Simins, 59, Ex-Public Works Chief
description: Herbert J. Simins, a former Commissioner of Public Works for New York City, died of cancer yesterday at Queens Hospital Center. He was 59 years old and lived in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Review/Theater; Big Money, Morality And a Banker's Rise
description: As editorial pages and television talk shows boil over with timely debate prompted by the Democratic National Convention, New York audiences are handed yet another example of the contrastingly low estate of political debate in the American theater. Keith Reddin's ''Big Time: Scenes From a Service Economy'' spreads the news that money corrupts, and that big money corrupts absolutely. The message is brought to us by the American Theater Exchange, A.T.&T.: Onstage, and the First New York International Festival of the Arts, which together have airlifted this 70-minute production from Cambridge's American Repertory Theater to the Joyce.

title: Palestinian Shot Dead By a Soldier in Israel
description: An Israeli soldier shot and killed a Palestinian who was reportedly trying to grab his rifle in the Israeli town of Petah Tiqva today, the police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; AIDS Test Center Drive Set to Begin
description: A former Long Island high school principal is prepared to spend $600,000 in New York in the fourth quarter alone to promote a privately owned AIDS-detection center primarily for people outside the high-risk groups.

title: National Gallery of Art Elects Deputy Director
description: Roger Mandle, director of the Toledo Museum of Art in Ohio, was elected deputy director of the National Gallery of Art today.

title: In the New Soviet Psyche, A Place Is Made for Freud
description: Sigmund Freud, long scorned by Soviet doctors as a quack and by Communist ideologists as a heretic, is now being hailed as a visionary as a small band of psychiatrists here tries to give a society in turmoil new ways to understand itself.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; The None-Too-Gentle Art Of the 'Bankruptcy Boys'
description: ''We don't like to cause pain,'' Jay Goldsmith insisted. It's just that in the game he plays of trying to turn bankrupt companies into money, pain comes with the territory.

title: Dukakis, Before Heading South, Tidies Up a Budget Mess at Home
description: Ending months of budgetary turmoil that threatened to become an issue in his Presidential bid, Michael S. Dukakis signed legislation today balancing Massachusetts's 1988 budget and authorizing an $11.6 billion 1989 budget three weeks into the new fiscal year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Judge Comments On Lord, Einstein
description: Justice Herman Cahn of New York State Supreme Court moved last week to clarify a temporary restraining order against Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners taking any more employees or clients of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein. The move was aimed at allowing Lord, Einstein to participate in the competition for the I.B.M. account, which is rumored to bill more than $100 million.

title: Faded Funland: Fears and Hopes
description: The rusting rides and peeling concession stands have been spruced up. Once again crowds march along the ancient boardwalk to the thumping cadences of rap music and stroll in the amusement park to the strained voices of carnival barkers. It's summertime. Coney Island is vibrant again. Attendance is strong. And, after so many years of false starts and roller-coaster hopes, city officials and developers are moving along with new plans to reverse the de cline of this ''working man's paradise' by the sea.

title: Bridge
description: At the midpoint of the Big Apple Regional Knockout Team final yesterday at the New York Penta Hotel, Kathie Wei and her team led Dale Beers of Voorhees, N.J., and his squad by 20 imps. Thirty-two deals remained to be played. The winners of events completed Friday and Saturday: Senior Pairs, Dorothy Robinson, West Orange, N.J., and Michael Kassay, Huntington, L.I.; Men's Pairs, Jim Linhart, Ridgefield, N.J., and Charles Reich, Manhattan; Women's Pairs, Rozanne Pollack, Englewood, N.J., and Stasha Cohen, Glen Ridge, N.J.; Flight A Pairs, Jim Krekorian, Manhattan, and Larry Griffey, Jacksonville, Fla., and Flight B Pairs, Elias and Cynthia Schneider, of East Brunswick, N.J.

title: Review/Television; A Look at Huston and Ellington
description: The two-part documentary ''A Duke Called Ellington'' - beginning on Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock - is being presented by public television's ''American Masters'' series as a ''musical portrait.'' The label reflects both the strengths and weaknesses of the production. There is plenty of wonderful Ellington music, with an orchestra featuring some of the century's greatest jazz musicians. But the man himself remains something of a mystery. Without the orchestra, he is almost invisible. But maybe Edward Kennedy Ellington, who died at age 75 in 1974, wanted it that way.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press; Newspapers Seek to Widen Their Antitrust Exemption
description: EUGENE CERVI, a crusading weekly newspaper publisher from Denver, made himself very unpopular in publishing circles in the late 1960's by railing against the newspaper industry's efforts to win Federal exemption from antitrust laws. He did not care much for railroads, mining companies or big banks, either, but he held a special place in his spleen for big-city newspapers, including his two hometown competitors.

title: David Baker, 60, Dies; Pianist and Composer
description: David Baker, a pianist and composer of Broadway musical scores, died of lung cancer Saturday at his weekend home on Fire Island, according to a friend and associate, Sylvia Fine Kaye. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: National League; Pirate Winning Streak Hits 9
description: Barry Bonds hit a tie-breaking, two-run pinch homer in the eighth inning as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the San Francisco Giants, 5-4, today to extend their winning streak to nine games.

title: Texas Oil Spill Kills Wildlife
description: A spill of more than 600,000 gallons of crude oil in the harbor has killed a small number of crabs, birds and other wildlife, state officials said. Volunteers sounded a propane cannon and air horns Saturday to scare birds away from an oily marsh. The spill occurred Wednesday when a tanker carrying oil from Scotland rammed a dock near the marsh.

title: Man Shot Dead in Queens
description: A 22-year-old man was shot to death last night during a dispute with a gang of Korean youths outside a bowling alley in Elmhurst, Queens, the police said. The victim, Veerakit Chisitichai, was from Thailand and was thought to have been studying in New York. The police said Mr. Chisitichai, of 42-19 Ketchum Street in Elmhurst, argued with the youths inside the Ace Bowling Alley, 82-02 45th Avenue. The dispute spilled onto the street and Mr. Chisitichai was shot in the chest about 6:25 P.M. He was pronounced dead at Elmhurst General Hospital. The youths fled, and no weapon was recovered, the police said.

title: Sports World Specials; Matchless Future?
description: The words ''match race,'' immediately evoke a sense of sadness in the minds of people in the horse racing world.

title: How NBC Union Lost Olympics
description: When NBC goes to Seoul, South Korea, this summer to televise the Summer Olympics, 488 of the 1,100 people in its entourage will be technicians - camera operators and video crews. But of those, none will be American employees who belong to the biggest union at the network, the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians.

title: Seymour C. Lechter, Executive, 66
description: Seymour C. Lechter, a former executive in the apparel industry, died of cancer yesterday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Art; Eclectic Show of Soviet Paintings at Hirshhorn
description: ''Russian and Soviet Painting 1900-1930,'' which includes 93 canvases representing an almost dizzying array of styles, explores the art of a country in the midst of political upheaval. The question is, which upheaval?

title: Eli Wallach in Reading
description: ''Karpilewski, or What Is to Be Done With Him,'' a play by Kobi Weitzner, is to be read by the actor Eli Wallach tomorrow at the Veteran's Memorial Hall, Pond Lane, Southampton, L.I. The reading is sponsored by the Polish Theater Institute and the Cultural Center of Southampton. ''Karpilewski'' is a comedy about a struggling poet who dies and is given a second chance at life and his career. Admission is free. Information: (516) 283-0247.

title: HOLYFIELD ON ROAD TO TYSON
description: For Evander Holyfield, the undisputed cruiserweight champion who made his debut as a heavyweight here Saturday night, James (Quick) Tillis turned out to be nothing but a workout.

title: 4 G.I.'s Wounded in Honduras
description: Four American soldiers were wounded early today when attackers opened fire and threw grenades at them as they left a discotheque in the northern Honduran city of San Pedro Sula, the police said.

title: Olympic Trials; The Old Guard Runs at Front
description: On another glorious day for American track and field, Edwin Moses, Florence Griffith Joyner and Mary Decker Slaney struck a blow for the older generation, leading their events in qualifying for places on the Olympic team.

title: Israelis Hear About Bribery In Latin America Adoptions
description: She is just one among hundreds of Israelis to adopt Brazilian-born infants, and she insists that her son's papers are all in order.

title: Sandinistas' Rationale; They Say Crackdown Against Opposition Was Necessary to Derail Lethal Campaign
description: As of a week ago, the contra guerrilla movement appeared to be in disarray. Congress was not disposed to provide it with new aid, and the Administration was reduced to seeking diplomatic backing from Guatemala, Costa Rica and other Latin American countries that have made clear they will not provide it.

title: A Skilled Politician and Speaker: Dorothy Ann Willis Richards
description: Ann Richards, who will deliver the keynote address at the Democratic National Convention Monday, has a theory about humor.

title: Tax Watch; Deadline on Fiscal Vs. Calendar Year
description: FOR many professionals and small businesses, a crucial tax deadline is only eight days away.

title: Triad Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Metro Datelines; Prosecutors to Retry Wood-Chipper Case
description: State prosecutors said yesterday that they would retry Richard Crafts, an airline pilot, on a charge of murdering his wife.

title: Nissan U.S. Output
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation expects to manufacture a second automobile at the Smyrna, Tenn., plant that builds its Sentra subcompact car and a light pickup truck, Nissan's president, Kazutoshi Hagiwara, said Sunday. Increased production in the United States would give Nissan relief from currency fluctuations that make cars and parts shipped from Japan more expensive.

title: Giant Oil Rig in Atlantic Planned by Canadians
description: In a development that Prime Minister Brian Mulroney compared to the building of Canada's transcontinental railway in the 1880's, the Canadian Government and a consortium of five oil companies led by Mobil Oil Canada Ltd. announced today that they would build and operate a huge oil-drilling platform in an iceberg-prone area of the Atlantic Ocean off Newfoundland.

title: SouthTrust Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Comissioner Is Critical Of Report on Pollution
description: The New York City Environmental Protection Commissioner yesterday dismissed a lobbying group's report on waste-water treatment as ''simplistic'' and ''misleading.''

title: Commercial Credit Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $53.6 million for the quarter and $52.8 million for the 6 months. The company said the year-ago loss was due to an additional $53 million in reserves which was recorded against LDC loans and it then began accounting for them as discontinued operations.

title: Florida Steel Gets Offer
description: The Florida Steel Corporation said today that a management-led investor group had offered to acquire it in a bid that values the company at about $285 million.

title: Apple Reports a Sharp Gain; Net Rises at Lotus and NCR
description: Apple Computer Inc. maintained its momentum in the most recent quarter, reporting a 71 percent gain in net income and a 56 percent rise in revenues from the comparable quarter a year earlier.

title: The Democrats in Atlanta; Local TV Filling Hall and Airwaves
description: Far above, floating in their anchor booths in the convention sky, the important network stars were interviewing important people about important political matters.

title: Champion International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes pre-tax gains of $92.4 million and $50.4 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, relating to the sale of the company's investments in Stone Container Corp. and U.S. Plywood Corp. Year-ago results were reclassified to reflect accounting changes.

title: On Horse Racing; Tom Fool a Sight For Sore Traveler
description: An American returning from 10 days in the Far East is supposed to give himself two or three days to recover, keeping the windows shuttered to ease the disorienting effects of jet lag and culture shock.

title: United Technologies Net Up
description: The United Technologies Corporation, which makes high-technology products, said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 23 percent, in part because of strong contributions from its Otis elevator and automotive units.

title: Dennison Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $9,802,000 on the sale of Hygeia Sciences Inc. common stock and an after-tax loss of $7,123,000 on the sale of two wholly owned subsidiaries.

title: Vermont American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: Following are excerpts from Edwin Meese 3d's rebuttal to the independent prosecutor's report: INTRODUCTION

title: I.R.S. Bills ARCO for $1.1 Billion
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that the Internal Revenue Service had billed it for more than $1.1 billion in back taxes and interest in a dispute over how the company valued oil that it produced in Alaska from 1980 to 1983.

title: Jail Term for Ex-Hotel Manager
description: The former manager of the Holland Hotel - a midtown welfare hotel that has become a symbol of the plight of the homeless in New York City - was sentenced yesterday to 20 days in jail and fined $1,000 for failing to improve security at the decaying hotel.

title: Vipont Pharmaceutical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary item from the use of a tax credit of $437,200 and $1,025,400 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes an extraordinary item from the use of a tax credit of $291,300 and $673,100 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Jackson's Real Campaign
description: Jesse Jackson will not go away. He is not going away during the convention and has no plans at all to go to the back of the bus when it ends. He intends to be right there in American politics, more and more prominently, for years and years.

title: Chess
description: Ian Rogers captured first prize in the Second Tata Steel Alekhine International Tournament in Calcutta, India, in April. Rogers, 28 years old and the only grandmaster in Australia's history, scored 9 1/2-3 1/2 in the 14-player invitational round-robin event.

title: Union Files Suit On Bid That Failed
description: A union representing employees of the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation said it had filed a $30 million lawsuit against the Wickes Companies over lost jobs and benefits that resulted from Wickes's failed 1986 takeover attempt.

title: Prime Computer Adds to Series 50
description: Prime Computer Inc. announced a midrange superminicomputer intended for use in offices and a more powerful machine for use in computer rooms. It said the two new members of its series 50 family of computers, the midrange 4450 and the high-end 6150, would be available immediately. Superminicomputers, very fast and powerful computers one step below mainframes, are most commonly used in specialized scientific or engineering applications.

title: Westlaw And Lexis Near Truce
description: The bitter legal dispute between Lexis and Westlaw, the two-largest computerized research services for lawyers, appeared on the verge of ending yesterday when a public relations firm representing Lexis sent out a news release announcing a settlement.

title: Oil Price Rises Sharply; Outlook Called Unclear
description: The price of oil jumped sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on the expectation that an end to Persian Gulf hostilities would enhance the ability of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to limit its output and raise prices.

title: Williams Tries to Survive
description: Terry Williams once again found himself clawing for survival, this time on the opening day of the Jets' training camp today at Hofstra.

title: GTE to Sell Telecom More of Sprint
description: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell most of its 50 percent stake in the U S Sprint Communications Corporation to United Telecommunications Inc., its business partner in the troubled long-distance venture, for more than $600 million.

title: Error by Mets Sends Reds to 2-1 Victory
description: It was with no joy but a lot of candor that Mookie Wilson said he thought there was still something genuinely amazing about the Mets. That they are still in first place, he said with a with a sigh as heavy as many of the bats for the Mets, is what he finds bittersweetly beyond belief.

title: Books of The Times; A Labyrinth of Intrigue in the Teutoburg Forest
description: A New Kind of War By Anthony Price 248 pages. The Mysterious Press. $17.95.

title: LEWIS WINS, BUT BY A FRACTION
description: Carl Lewis made the United States Olympic team tonight in his second event by winning a marvelous long jump battle from Larry Myricks. Joetta Clark, Joe Clark's 25-year-old daughter, made it, too, though a nasty fall at the finish almost cost her a berth. Diane Dixon of Brooklyn, a gold medalist in 1984, made the team again.

title: Careers; Drought Seen As Threat to Manager Jobs
description: THE drought may damage a number of industries, threatening the jobs of middle-level managers in the Midwest, according to James Challenger, president of Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., a Chicago outplacement concern.

title: New Technologies Aim to Make Toxic Wastes Permanently Harmless
description: LEAD: HAZARDOUS waste laws, lawsuits against toxic dumpers and popular demands that toxic wastes be destroyed rather than merely buried are stimulating development of a host of new technologies that render toxic wastes permanently harmless.

title: Plexus Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; When Wright's Away
description: The Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, is out of town this week, serving as chairman of a Democratic gathering in Atlanta.

title: Metro Datelines; Dental Data Identify Body Found in Sound
description: A body found in the Long Island Sound was identified yesterday as that of Daniel Monaco, one of two boys who disappeared while surfing on July 11, the Suffolk County Medical Examiner said.

title: Bond May Have Raised Bell Stake Above 25%
description: Alan Bond, the billionaire entrepreneur who is seeking control of Bell Group Ltd., may now have more than 25 percent of the company, which is part of the diminishing holdings of the corporate raider Robert Holmes a Court.

title: Lambert Net Rises 13.3%
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that its net income rose 13.3 percent on a sales gain of 12.5 percent for the three months ended June 30.

title: 2 Flee as a Fire Erupts In Los Angeles Tower
description: A smoky fire erupted tonight at the downtown Union Bank building, burning above the 30th floor of the 38-story tower before it was extinguished by about 75 firefighters.

title: Reich & Tang LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
With Bentsen, the Democrats Look West, Not South
description: LEAD: Virtually all the experts are saying that Senator Lloyd Bensten's selection as the Vice Presidential candidate signals the beginning of a classic Southern strategy by the Democrats. I think not.

title: Metro Datelines; U.S. Is Refining Bomb Suspect Case
description: The Federal Government is seeking a new indictment against Yu Kikumura, the 35-year-old Japanese man arrested in New Jersey on April 12 with three powerful homemade bombs in his car, his lawyer, Ronald L. Kuby, said yesterday.

title: District of Columbia; The Tug of the Leash From Those on the Hill
description: It has been 13 years since Congress authorized home rule for the District of Columbia, giving its 620,000 residents the right to elect their own mayor and city council.

title: Texaco Says It Won 58.6% of Proxy Vote
description: Texaco Inc. won its proxy fight with Carl C. Icahn last month by a vote of 58.6 percent to 41.4 percent, according to the preliminary report of the company counting the ballots.

title: Suffolk Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Macmillan Presses Fight to Stop Bass
description: Macmillan Inc. is pressing ahead with its legal battle against the Robert M. Bass Group, which yesterday began a sweetened tender offer of $75 a share, or $1.94 billion, for the publishing company.

title: Warner Posts Record Net; Overseas Sales Key Factor
description: Steven J. Ross, chairman of Warner Communications Inc., said yesterday that demand for the company's movies and records had increased sharply outside the United States, lifting the company's second-quarter earnings by 22.3 percent.

title: Patterns
description: Business on Seventh Avenue has always been byzantine, but with a revolution in retailing going on, it's even more confusing now. In the currently evolving relationship between retailer and manufacturer, a tension-filled romance at best, the key phrase these days is ''real estate.''

title: Rivera Quits Bronx District Attorney Race
description: The campaign for district attorney in the Bronx, already marked by bitter infighting and the withdrawal of the incumbent under pressure, took another surprising turn yesterday with the unexpected withdrawal of one of the leading candidates.

title: BERMUDEZ ELECTED A CONTRA DIRECTOR
description: The military leader of the Nicaraguan rebels, Col. Enrique Bermudez, was elected to the contra political directorate today in a nearly unanimous vote.

title: The Democrats in Atlanta; The Platform, Short on Commitment, Is Merely a Shadow of Oratory Past
description: The platform the delegates to the Democratic National Convention will adopt Tuesday night will enumerate the broad principles on which party members agree but, as befits the campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, will contain few commitments.

title: Judge Ready To Approve Robins Plan
description: A Federal district judge indicated last night that he expected to approve the A. H. Robins Company's bankruptcy reorganization plan.

title: Great Lakes Chemical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lotus Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
L.I. Water Shows Radioactive Trace
description: Radioactive material from the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island has entered the drinking water of nearby homes, though not at dangerous levels, according to a draft report by the United States Department of Energy.

title: Archer Daniels Midland Co reports earnings for Year to June 30
Sports People; Royals Scuffle
description: George Brett and Willie Wilson scuffled in the rear of the Royals' team plane Sunday after Kansas City's fourth consecutive loss to the Boston Red Sox.

title: Crop Futures Fall on News Of Rainfall
description: Prices of corn and soybeans plunged yesterday after large areas of the parched Farm Belt received unexpected soaking rainfall over the weekend. With meteorologists predicting more rain for today and tomorrow, corn and soybeans were bid down the maximum levels allowed from the opening bell at the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Dangerous to Humans
description: To the Editor:

title: Norwest Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and the second quarter loss included a charge of $204 million for international loans.

title: WPP Group Begins Revival of Byoir Agency
description: Britain's WPP Group, owner of Hill & Knowlton, one of the world's largest public relations firms, is bringing back the venerable Carl Byoir & Associates to be its second international public relations network.

title: American Electric Power Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The McKay Report: An Ambiguous Conclusion to a 14-Month Investigation; PROSECUTOR FINDS MEESE IN THE CLEAR IN MAJOR SCANDALS
description: An independent prosecutor said today that Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d had probably broken the law in managing his personal finances, but he essentially exonerated Mr. Meese of wrongdoing in two major government scandals.

title: United Technologies Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that in the latest second quarter it sold its share of Telefunken Electronic GMBH, a West German semiconductor joint venture, resulting in a pretax gain of $41.4 million.

title: Rochester Telephone Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an accounting change gain of 50 percent.

title: Sports People; Butkus Replaces Snyder
description: Dick Butkus, the Hall of Fame linebacker, will replace Jimmy (The Greek) Snyder on CBS's ''NFL Today,'' sources said yesterday.

FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Nash Finch Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 18
Sports People; Tennis Tournament
description: Arthur Ashe and Althea Gibson announced plans yesterday for the Arthur Ashe-Althea Gibson Tennis Classic, to be held at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens, July 25-31. The tournament, which is in its 10th year, was named in honor of the two former tennis stars last year. It will attract almost 900 players from around the country who will compete for prizes and scholarships. The tournament is sponsored by the Black Tennis and Sports Foundation and the Kinney Shoe Corporation.

title: Topics of The Times; The Out-of-Towners
description: They're at Rockefeller Center, their cameras fixed on Prometheus. At the Empire State Building. title: Who's Who in the Meese Inquiry
description: Edwin Meese 3d 57 ... Resigned as Attorney General after three years in office ... Had been investigated by two independent prosecutors about the propriety of his personal finances, the awarding of a Government contract for the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor, and a plan to construct an Iraqi oil pipeline close to Israel, but was not been charged with breaking the law ... Political longevity rested on his relationship of more than 20 years with Ronald Reagan, beginning when Mr. Reagan was Governor of California ... Conservative Republican, lawyer and former law professor at the University of San Diego School of Law ... Fourth-generation Californian. E. Robert Wallach 57 ... San Francisco personal-injury lawyer and law-school friend of Mr. Meese who helped the Attorney General reorganize the Justice Department ... Indicted on Federal racketeering charges involving the Wedtech Corporation ... Also respresented a Swiss financier, Bruce Rappaport, who stood to profit from a proposal to build a $1 billion oil pipeline from Iraq to the Jordanian port of Aqaba ... Wrote a memorandum in 1985 to Mr. Meese suggesting payments to the Israeli Labor Party in connection with the proposed pipeline project. Mr. Wallach's $150,000 unusually high returns on Mr. Meese's investment. The pipeline was never built. W. Franklyn Chinn 46 ... Was a colleague of Mr. Wallach and Mr. Meese's former financial adviser. Mr. Meese, at Mr. Wallach's suggestion, turned most of his investments, about $55,000, over to Mr. Chinn in 1985. Mr. Chinn generated about $35,000 in profits for Mr. Meese from the investment pool before Mr. Meese ended the investment arrangement last year ... Also advised Wedtech and was charged with racketeering involving the corporation ... Came to the United States in 1945 from Shanghai as a war refugee.

That assessment appears to have prompted Iran's announcement today that it would abide by a United Nations call for a cease-fire with Iraq, these experts said.

title: Basis for an End to Persian Gulf Fighting: Security Council Resolution 598
description: Security Council Resolution 598, which Iran said today it had accepted, was adopted on July 20, 1987, as part of diplomatic efforts to end the war between Iran and Iraq. Here is the text of the resolution. THE SECURITY COUNCIL, REAFFIRMING its Resolution 582 (1986),

title: Vast Persistent Air Pattern Spreading Heat Wave
description: Almost the entire country, from California to Cape Cod, is roasting in scorching heat because of an unusual set of meteorological conditions brought on by the spread of a vast vortex of high-pressure air. This has expanded from the Middle West, where it has persisted for a sweltering month, all across the northern United States.

title: Addictions and Mr. Reagan
description: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop recently declared that nicotine is as addictive as heroin. So you'd think that when Michael Dukakis, faced with a revenue shortfall in Massachusetts, raised the tax on cigarettes, Ronald Reagan would have praised him for his antidrug initiative.

title: A Glimpse of Peace in the Gulf
description: A little shy of its eighth full year and one million dead, the dangerous and brutal war between Iran and Iraq may be nearing its close. Iran has at last accepted the United Nations resolution calling for a cease-fire. If diplomats can now give substance to this glimpse of peace, there will be a long list of beneficiaries, from the war-weary people of Iran and Iraq to the gulf states whose sovereignty and commerce the war threatened and to Western nations dependent on the region's oil.

title: Topics of The Times; Turkish Censors, and Censure

Still, there are laws that ban serious discussion of Turkey's treatment of its ethnic minorities, like the Armenians or the Kurds. Censorship forbids publicizing ''racialist'' statements or offending Turkish nationalism.

title: Greece Says U.S. Issued Alert on Terrorism

Mid America, a maker of auto replacement parts, based in Fort Smith, Ark., said GKN would make a tender offer for all Mid America common shares at $8.50 each, valuing the company at about $15.7 million. Mid America stock rose 62.5 cents today, to $8.25, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: PC Makers' Campaign in Schools

title: Bayer Unit Offers To Acquire Matrix

Matrix, which manufactures cameras for medical diagnostic equipment, including CAT scanners. has 13.1 million shares outstanding, but Agfa already controls 1.42 million, or 11 percent. Matrix's shares rose $2.125, to $9.375, on the American Stock Exchange, where the stock's gain of 29.3 percent was the second largest of the day.

title: John R. May, Fund Raiser, 79

He was 79 years old and lived in San Rafael, Calif, When Mr. May was appointed the first director of the San Francisco Foundation in 1948, the philanthropy had assets of less than $1 million. By the time he retired, it had $50 million in assets and was dispensing its grants to more than 300 organizations in the San Francisco area.

title: Solving a Quality Control Problem
description: Trying to find the cause of defects in the paint on an mini-van hood, engineers identified seven possible causes. In a traditional approach, bottom, extensive experiments in which each possibility is investigated one by one would be conducted, involving as many as 500 different hoods. Using the Taguchi method, top, a brainstorming session is followed by a few experiments with about 40 hoods in which several factors are changed simultaneously, their selection based on statistical techniques. TAGUCHI METHOD Brainstorming and a few bold experiments seek to quickly find the problem. Production problem: Blemishes appear in paint on finished hood. ... Brainstorming session: Identify factors that could be responsible. ... Employ Taguchi Statisical Sampling Methods: A handful of experiments are designed in which many of the possible causes are varied, based on statistical techniques. ... Experimental Production Runs: Eight sets of five hoods each are produced, varying several of the possible causes at once. ... Confirm Results: The experiments are evaluated and a changed production run made to confirm the findings. TRADITIONAL METHOD Possible causes are studied one by one while holding the other factors constant. Production problem: Blemishes appear in paint on finished hood. ... Perform Experiment: Change one factor and hold the others constant in a production run involving 70 oods. ... Measure Results: If problem is not solved, design new experiment with another 70 hoods, varying different factor while olding others constant. ... Repeat Experiments: Each of the possible causes must be studied in separate production runs of 70 hoods until the culprit is found.

title: Inquiry on Manley
description: Dexter Manley, the Washington Redskins defensive end, is being investigated for suspected drug abuse and could face disciplinary action this season by the National Football League, according to a published report. Unidentified sources said the investigation stemmed from Manley's positive result for a ''minor'' substance in a recent test, The Washington Post has reported. Manley's attorney, Bob Woolf, confirmed that the player is under investigation, and he said that he and Manley were cooperating with officials. Manley, 30 years old, was treated for alcohol abuse in March 1987 at the Hazelden Foundation in Minnesota. where the player said he was treated for alcohol abuse. Manley and Woolf had met with Commissioner Pete Rozelle to talk about Manley's suspected involvement with drugs and alcohol, the newspaper said. Rozelle put his concerns in writing, and the league then gave Manley guidelines regarding his conduct, and included periodic drug tests, according to the report. A meeting with league officials is scheduled within the next week. ''Our goal is to correct Dexter's problem and to keep him in football,'' Woolf said.(AP)

description: TENNIS Teltscher Upset: Sixth-seeded Eliot Teltscher was upset by Danie Visser of South Africa, 4-6, 7-5, 6-2, yesterday at the $232,050 D.C. Tennis Classic in Washington. Jorge Lozano and Christo Van Rensburg, seeded players who had been having problems on Monday night when rain interrupted play, rallied for victory yesterday. Lozano, the 15th-seeded player, had trailed, 1-2, in the second set after losing the first, 4-6, when rain caused play to be suspended. But the 25-year-old Mexican came back strong yesterday for a 4-6, 6-4, 6-3 decision over Scott Davis of Largo, Fla. Ninth-seeded Van Rensburg, down a break in the second set when play resumed yesterday, defeated Jeff Tarango, 6-4, 6-4.(AP) Hanika Advances: Top-seeded Sylvia Hanika of West Germany posted an easy second-round victory in a $100,000 women's tournament at Aix-en-Provence, France, yesterday. Hanika, ranked 15th in the world, defeated Alexia Dechaume of France, 6-2, 6-1. Today, the other top-seeded players, Raffaella Reggi and Sandra Cecchini of Italy and Arantxa Sanchez of Spain, will play their second-round matches. All were in tournament finals over the weekend and earned an extra day of rest for their opening matches after a first-round bye. (AP)

title: Chevrier Traded
description: Alain Chevrier, who started last season as the No. 1 goaltender for the Devils, will be starting this one with the Winnipeg Jets. In a trade yesterday, the Devils sent Chevrier and their 1989 seventh-round draft choice to Winnipeg for Steve Rooney, a left wing, and a fourth-round draft pick in 1989. The trade should give Chevrier more playing time, because he had fallen behind Sean Burke and Bob Sauve in the goalie numbers game with the Devils. Last season, Chevrier, 27 years old, appeared in 45 games, had one shutout in an 18-19-3 won-lost-tied record and allowed an average of 3.77 goals. He did not play in the Devils' playoff run to the Stanley Cup semifinals. Rooney, 26, scored 7 goals and 6 assists in 56 games last season. He accumulated 217 minutes in the penalty box, and gives the Devils an aggressive wing, as well as adding depth to the forward position. . . . The Rangers have signed Mark Tinordi, a 22-year-old defenseman who split last season between the parent club and their Colorado affiliate International Hockey League. The new deal restructures the cap from $900,000, which every club was required to spend, to a $775,000 minimun and an $875,000 maximum. It runs through 1991-92. (AP)
