title: 10 Die in Mexico Prison Riot
description: A riot broke out today in the penitentiary of the central Mexican state of Michoacan, and officials said that at least 10 people were dead and 15 injured before it was brought under control. A preliminary report by the state government described the violence at the prison, in Morelia, the state capital, as ''an attempt at a mass breakout.'' Details of the riot were not immediately available, according to local officials and journalists.

title: Former Mayor Leaves Prison
description: Former Mayor Mike Roark of Charleston, W.Va., walked out of Federal prison today after serving five months for cocaine possession. The 42-year-old former prosecutor was whisked past news cameras at the Federal Correctional Institute shortly before 8 A.M. He pleaded guilty Nov. 17 to six counts of cocaine possession and resigned as mayor Nov. 24, seven months after election to a second four-year term. In January, he was sentenced to 179 days in prison and fined $5,000, and he entered prison on Feb. 12.

title: AMR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY
description: THE ECONOMY Telephone companies would be free to offer cable television in their service areas, under a recommendation to Congress approved by the Federal Communications Commission. But Congressional aides said the proposal faces an uphill battle. [ Page A1. ] COMPANIES U.S. regulators accepted a bid for two banking companies by a Minnesota investor. Carl R. Pohlad will put $200 million into a transaction that will merge Texas American of Fort Worth and National Bancshares of San Antonio. [ D1. ] An offer to buy Polaroid was made by Roy E. Disney, who disclosed that his Shamrock Holdings group already held 8 percent of the photography company and was willing to pay $2.3 billion, or $40 a share, for the rest. Polaroid is expected to resist the offer. [ D1. ] Gencorp has reached a regulatory settlement that clears the way for it to sell a Los Angeles television station and a Memphis radio station for about $217.5 million. The accord may be a model to settle disputes dating back to 1965. [ D1. ] An Indian tribe in Maine is selling a cement company for an undisclosed price that is estimated to be more than three times what the tribe paid for the company five years ago. [ D1. ] Pratt & Whitney plans to cut more than 1,000 salaried jobs at its main operations plant in East Hartford, Conn. [ D1. ] Bankers Trust had a strong second quarter, earning $174.1 million, in contrast to a $554 million loss in last year's quarter. First Interstate had quarterly profits of $97.2 million. [ D5. ] A.T.&T.'s profits dipped slightly in the second quarter, to $594 million. GTE's earnings were $299 million, but when special items were excluded the figure was almost the same as last year's $223 million. [ D4. ] Earnings doubled at Dow Chemical in the second quarter, but GAF and Hercules reported lower profits. [ D4. ] G.M.'s two publicly traded subsidiaries posted earnings gains, but G.M.A.C., the financing unit, had a decline. [ D6. ] Airbus has won a contract worth about $1.8 billion (Canadian) to supply 34 airliners to Air Canada. [ D2. ] Eastern Airlines is considering laying off 4,000 workers, about 12 percent of its work force, The Miami Herald reported. [ D2. ] Calmat has tentatively agreed to sell its cement business for at least $310 million to Japan's largest cement maker. [ D4. ] MARKETS A stockbroker at Gruntal & Company was indicted on charges of insider trading and perjury stemming from the 1986 takeover of Waldbaum by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company. Robert Chestman was accused of using non-public information to generate $250,00 in illegal trading profits. [ D1. ] Grain and soybean markets came under renewed pressure as the July futures contracts expired and the Midwest continued to receive much-needed rainfall. [ D16. ] The dollar rebounded in quiet, but nervous trading. Gold fell $1.70, to $444.80 an ounce. [ D16. ] Stocks reversed two days of declines. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 13.34 points, to 2,110.60. [ D8. ] The credit markets were sluggish as traders awaited new economic statistics. [ D15. ] A new financial instrument is being proposed by the American Stock Exchange based on the Standard & Poor's 500 index. [ D7. ] INTERNATIONAL The U.S.-Canada free-trade accord will be blocked in Canada's Senate until voters have passed judgment on the accord, the Liberal Party, which has a majority in the Senate, said. [ A3. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The fight for Macmillan has produced an unusual twist: a judge has depicted management, rather than the corporate raider, as the greedy and devious party. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] BankAmerica shares have gained 96 percent so far this year, but some enthusiastic analysts say there is more to come. A few analysts are more cautious. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Life in the 30's
description: THE worst job I ever had was as a waitress at a rest stop on the New Jersey Turnpike the summer I was 18. Everyone who passed through the place wanted their food NOW, and many of them seemed to think that tipping was a nice idea in theory but not in practice. The pace was manic, and I had to wear a hairnet and white oxfords. Most of the time I arrived at work crying, and drove home crying. The only good thing I can say about the experience is that it left me with the most profound respect for people who wait tables and with a pronounced tendency to overtip.

Dukakis: the man from Plains, Ga., ran against Washington and what he saw as its sins - ran, it sometimes seemed, against government itself -while the man from Brookline, Mass., is running with the support of senators, members of Congress and other worthies, sought the counsel of the Georgetown sages whom Mr. Carter ignored, and seems impatient to start playing inside baseball. title: Iran-Iraq War: Eight Brutal Years
description: 1980 Sept. 7: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq cancels 1975 treaty with Iran and claims sovereignty over the Shatt al Arab, the waterway that forms part of the southern border between the countries. Iran rejects the claim. Minor border clashes follow. Sept. 22: Iraqi forces invade Iran. By the end of October the Iraqis occupy a strip of Iranian territory 6 to 25 miles wide. 1981 May: Iran begins a counteroffensive, forcing Iraqi forces back on the central and northern fronts. October: Iran starts drive on the Iraqi-held port of Khorramshahr. 1982 March 29: President Hussein proposes an Iraqi withdrawal to international borders. Iran ignores his offer and sets its conditions for negotiations: Iraqi withdrawal from Iranian territory, the overthrow of Mr. Hussein and payment of reparations. May 24: Iranians take Khorramshahr. 1984 Feb. 22: Iran mounts an offensive, entering Iraq by the end of the month and taking part of the Majnoon oilfields, north of Basra. An attempted advance on Basra is thwarted by Iraq. March 27: Iraq begins air attacks on oil tankers serving Iran. May: Iran retaliates by attacking Kuwaiti and Saudi tankers. 1985 March 11: Iran starts new offensive against Basra and crosses the Tigris River, but is driven back. Iran fires missiles at Baghdad in retaliation for Iraqi air raids on Iranian civilian targets. September: Iran seizes more territory around Majnoon. 1986 Feb. 9: Iranian forces cross the Shatt al Arab south of Basra. By Feb. 16, they occupy 300 square miles of the Fao peninsula. Dec. 24: Iran mounts offensive in southern Iraq. 1987 Jan. 6: President Hussein calls for peace. Jan. 9: Iran mounts drive against Basra, reaching outskirts. April 23: Iran increases attacks on neutral shipping. Kuwait appeals to big powers to protect free navigation in the gulf. May 17: Iraqi missile attack on the Navy frigate Stark kills 37 Americans. July 20: U.N. Security Council adopts resolution calling for end to war. July 24: Mine damages supertanker Bridgeton in first U.S. Navy convoy for Kuwaiti ships. Oct. 16: Iranian missile hits the Kuwaiti tanker Sea Isle City. Oct. 19: U.S. forces attack two Iranian oil platforms. 1988 March 16: Iran takes Halabja, in northern mountains; Iran says Iraq used chemical weapons. March 21: Up to 54 die in Iraqi air strike on Iranian supertankers. April 18: In retaliation for mining of the Samuel B. Roberts, a Navy ship, U.S. forces destroy two Iranian oil platforms and sink or damage six Iranian naval vessels. Iraqi forces recapture Fao peninsula. June 26: Iraqis retake Majnoon oilfields. July 3: Navy cruiser Vincennes downs Iranian jet, killing 290. July 11: Iraqis recapture Halabja. July 18: Iran says it will accept a U.N. resolution calling for an immediate cease-fire. July 20: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini personally endorses a cease-fire. Source: Associated Press

title: Reviews/Film; Obsessed By Allende's Overthrow
description: Jorge Duran's ''Color of Destiny,'' the Brazilian film opening today at the Public Theater, has the sincerity of the work of a young director looking for a way to come to terms with a subject that haunts him: the overthrow of Salvador Allende Gossens' Marxist Government in Chile in 1973. Like Mr. Duran, the film's hero, Paulo (Guilherme Fontes), is a Chilean who has been living in exile in Rio de Janeiro since the coup. Paulo, now a teen-ager who expresses himself through his paintings, remembers those events only through vintage newsreels and through nightmares in which he dreams about his older brother, killed by the military government that succeeded Allende's.

title: Review/Film; Caught in a Psychological Pas de Trois
description: The mannered style of ''Pascali's Island'' perfectly suits its tale of political and emotional intrigue hiding behind a crumbling facade of stability. On a Greek island in 1908, in the fading years of the Ottoman Empire, Greek rebels, Turkish spies and foreign mercenaries mingle in shady hotel bars and winding streets overlooking the sea. Basil Pascali (Ben Kingsley) has been sending unanswered espionage reports to the sultan for 20 years. Anthony Bowles (Charles Dance) is a British archeologist whose purpose in visiting the island is mysterious and suspect. And Lydia Neuman (Helen Mirren) is a bohemian-looking Viennese painter, a woman of a certain age who attracts the two men.

title: Economic Scene; Democrats Seek Big Issue for 1988
description: WHAT is the main economic issue on which the Democrats will fight the 1988 Presidential campaign? He made his own life the symbol of the issue - and of hope that others could follow his example in making it. ''I was born in the slum,'' he said. ''But the slum was not born in me. Reviews/Film; A Story of A Man and His Boredom
description: A 30-year-old single man who works at a copy center and lives in a boxy house in suburban New Jersey can't be blamed for saying, as the main character in ''Home Remedy'' does, ''Life is boring and then you die.'' When Richie attempts to overcome boredom by learning to love it, his attitude is more suspect. He locks himself in the house, reads ''Understanding the Kaballah,'' plays the harmonica and captures it all on videotape. A film about this moribund antihero is bound to run into a classic problem: How does a story about boredom avoid becoming a boring story?

description: The Texas Rangers signed Jim Sundberg in a deal that will pay the catcher $30,000 to play this season for his original team in the majors. Sundberg broke in with the Rangers in 1974. Sundberg, a six-time Gold Glove winner, was released by the Chicago Cubs last Friday. . . . Jerry Butler, the third-leading receiver in Buffalo Bills' history, was waived at his request after failing a team physical. Butler missed last season after suffering a broken leg in a 1986 game. . . . The Green Bay Packers signed Alton Alexis and Teddy Wilson, wide receivers. Alexis made 84 catches for the Jacksonville Bulls of the United States Football League in 1985, when they were coached by Lindy Infante, the Packers' new coach.(AP)

title: PANEL WILL HEAR 2 EX-MEESE AIDES

title: Stages Fill The Great Outdoors
description: Music changes when it moves outside. It leaves behind the claustrophobia of New York real estate, breathes fresher air, expands to fill wide open spaces; as stages sprout at parks, boats, beaches and piers, the music trades ceiling for sky, concert-hall formality for party spirit. This weekend, from the center of New York City to the far periphery, music with pedigrees from Memphis to Puerto Rico to Java can be heard under the open sky.

title: Reviews/Film; The World of the Circus According to Pee-wee

There are few halfhearted responses to the wildly successful comedian who always plays ''himself'' - that is, a fictional character who behaves like a child in a skinny gray suit, whose lipstick and eyeliner can seem eerily androgynous to adults and clownish to kids.

title: Reviews/Art; A Russian Artist Pulverizes Styles of the West
description: As everyone knows by now, the Russians are coming, and the American art scene, ever on the lookout for new ''product,'' is adjusting its sights accordingly. How, in the cultural sense, is this relatively unknown art to be seen? As a contrast to the official Social Realism that has, until recently, prevailed in the Soviet Union, or in comparison with Western developments of the same period? These are questions that Western critics will be grappling with in the months to come as more and more New York dealers introduce Russian art. In the meantime, viewers can do some grappling of their own at the Phyllis Kind Gallery, where the Russian artist Yuri Dyshlenko is having his first exhibition outside his own country.

description: International 2-5 Iraq began an offensive against Iran, and at the same time, the two countries said they would send their Foreign Ministers to the United Nations next week to negotiate an end to the Persian Gulf war. Page 1 A report of protests in Mecca was broadcast by the Teheran radio, which said that hundreds of pilgrims demonstrated in the Saudi Arabian city and that some of them were attacked by the police. 5 Jews in Israel born in Arab countries will outnumber voters of Western origin in coming national elections. The major parties are racing to include Sephardim among their parliamentary candidates. 1 Eight Soviet officials were barred from entering the United States to inspect missile sites under the new arms control treaty because they are spies, American officials said. 1 Nationalism in Lithuania has surged in recent weeks, making it a major force in the Soviet republic's political life. The Lithuanian movement is challenging Moscow's dominant role in the republic's affairs. 3 Stability is challenged in Bombay as the richest and poorest residents strain its resources. Some blame its problems on people who have come looking for work. Others see a coming economic breakdown. 4 National 6-10, 28 Eastern Airlines will lay off 4,000 employees and announced sharp cuts in flights from its hub in Kansas City, Mo., and the suspension of service to 14 cities, in the troubled airline's latest action to reduce its size. 1 Dallas dropped a mass transit plan involving a 93-mile rail system after voters turned down a proposal to borrow $1 billion. The vote reflects a national debate over similar plans in other cities. 1 The Consumer Price Index rose in June by three-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in May and less than the increases in March and April, the Government said, allaying some fears about a resurgence of inflation. 1 A Federal prosecutor's assertion that a travel agent linked to Libya may have helped plot the assassination of a ''high government official'' is supported by little evidence, Justice Department officials said. 6 A campaign to save the rattlesnake is being waged by a computer executive in Texas. He concedes that it is difficul to get people to care about rattlesnakes, which are usually more popular dead than alive. 6 A verdict against two newspapers was returned by a Minnesota jury, which found that The Minneapolis Star Tribune and The St. Paul Pioneer Press Dispatch broke agreements with a source by identifying him. 6 A grand jury indicted the driver of a pickup truck that crashed into a church bus in May on 27 counts of murder, rejecting charges that could have brought the death penalty. Larry Mahoney pleaded not guilty. 6 Research on Alzheimer's disease suggests that some cases of the disorder may be caused by infection with an unidentified, slow-acting virus. The researchers said their conclusions were tentative. 10 Repairs on the space shuttle Discovery may not have to be made in the vehicle's assembly building, space agency officials said. Even so, the launching was expected to be postponed two or three weeks. 28 House panel investigates maker of AIDS drug 6 Top Navy officer doubts role in war on drugs 10 Politics 8-9 Michael Dukakis set out to battle Vice President Bush, after meeting this morning with supporters of Jesse Jackson, telling them their support was crucial. 1 Governor Dukakis stopped in Texas on the first official trip of the general election campaign. The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert Morgenthau, said no charges would be brought against John Santucci. 29 A Congressional race on Long Island is expected to produce a fight. The Republican challenger, Ed Romaine, is trying to defeat the Democratic incumbent, George J. Hochbrueckner, in the heavily Republican First District. 29 The historic Hill Cumorah Pageant, a Mormon play in Palmyra, N.Y., that celebrates the beginning of the faith, has been rescripted to rid it of archaic language and add special effects, including a flying Jesus. 29 Summer theater in Stratford, Conn., will begin again next year. But school officials said they would consider hand-held detectors. 30 City Hall is peaceful, even quiet, with Mayor Koch in Ireland. title: GUIDEPOST: Keeping Bills at Bay
description: Letting bills sit during an extended vacation is risky. Some creditors now impose penalties after 30 days, especially if there is a history of erratic payments. Figure out what bills you'll miss by taking a list of billing-cycle dates for your regular payments; you might also include your account numbers and the addresses and customer-service telephone numbers of the creditors. Ways to take care of bills while on vacation range from simply having a neighbor forward them to you, to using bill-paying services that some banks offer. If you come home to a pile of bills, don't push them aside. METHOD WHAT TO DO Prepayment Call creditors and arrange to pay either your outstanding balance or an average monthly charge. Payment by phone or computer A few banks will pay authorized bills for customers when they call; others offer similar services via portable computers. Third-party payment Provide a relative or friend with signed checks and access to your bills, but make sure to avoid overdrafts. (Source: Consumer Credit Institute of the American Financial Services Association)

title: NONFICTION
description: BIFURCATED POLITICS: Evolution and Reform in the National Party Convention. By Byron E. Shafer. (Russell Sage Foundation/Harvard University, $27.50.) This is a profound study of the transformation of national party conventions from meetings where Presidential candidates were actually selected (that last happened in 1952) to political theme parks where all kinds of causes, including the Presidential election, compete for a hearing. Byron E. Shafer, a professor of American government at Oxford University, examines how the nationalization of politics has moved the real choice of a nominee out of the convention and into the primaries, and how the convention has become only an insurance policy against political disaster - a ''nominator of last resort.'' He uses the convention as a window on politics in general, showing how it has come to stress communicating with ''organizable publics'' rather than creating ''continuing coalitions among major political actors.''

title: Amy Henrich Has Wedding
description: The wedding of Amy Louise Henrich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Henrich of Huntington, L.I., to Theodore Brooks Lynn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore R. Lynn of Hamden, Conn., took place yesterday at the Old Presbyterian Church in Huntington. The Rev. Dr. Stanert L. Dransfield performed the ceremony.

title: Sarah Patterson to Wed
description: The engagement of Sarah Louise Patterson to Robert Rafael Beltran, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Rafael Beltran of Riverdale, the Bronx, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Patterson Jr. of Darien, Conn. Ms. Patterson, who graduated from Williams College, is a television producer at Young & Rubicam in New York, where her fiance, a graduate of Columbia College, is an account executive. They plan to marry in October.

title: New Hunter President's Goal: Students Pursuing Doctorates
description: If the newly appointed president of Hunter College has his way, Hunter will become a national model for encouraging minority students to pursue doctoral degrees and become university professors.

title:
TELEVISION;
Queen Isabella, Please Speak Into the Microphone
description: LEAD: A group of Medieval horsemen clatter through narrow, cobblestoned streets, scattering pigs and chickens in their path. Followed by giggling urchins, they rein up in front of a church where Pope Innocent IV is waiting to receive his emissary. Carpini, the messenger, has just returned from a two-year sojourn to the Court of the Great Khan.

title: James Dearden: Life After 'Fatal Attraction'
description: For 20 years, Basil Pascali has meticulously recorded his observations of the mundane activities on a sun-drenched Aegean island and sent them to the Sultan in Constantinople. But as World War I approaches and the end of Turkish rule on the Greek island looms, this man of inaction is tortured by questions. Who has been reading his reports? Why have they never been answered? And above all, what has this life of perpetual letter-writing signified?

title: DALLAS, ECHOING DOWN THE DECADES
description: LIBRA By Don DeLillo. 456 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Young Pirates Bring Out That Old Fan Spirit
description: The most telling sound to come from the confluence of the Ohio, Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers on Friday night was not the succession of roars produced by the big crowd at Three Rivers Stadium. It was a sound that had more to do with the respect the Pittsburgh Pirates have earned than a celebration of what they have achieved.

title: Disney Group Puts Polaroid Into Play
description: Polaroid is in play. After months of speculation that the photography company was a takeover target, Roy Disney announced that his Shamrock Holdings held 8 percent of Polaroid's stock and was willing to buy the rest for $2.3 billion, or $40 a share. Polaroid had been selling for about $30 a share in February before the first takeover rumors began. Polaroid did not take an official stand on the offer, but it is widely expected to resist the bid. Earlier this month it made a number of corporate changes, including putting 10 million new shares into the supposedly friendly hands of an employee stock plan. Mr. Disney, the nephew of Walt Disney, is challenging those changes in court.

title: Years of Isolation Produced Intensely Poor Nation
description: In his 26 years of unchallenged rule in Burma, U Ne Win, whose name means ''Brilliant as the Sun,'' has preserved the facade of Burmese independence while turning a country with extraordinary economic potential into one of the poorest nations in Asia.

title: Across America by Rail; An alternative to crowded planes
description: Equipment

title:
DINING OUT;
A Charming Setting in Bay Head
description: LEAD: THE BLUFFS hotel and restaurant in Bay Head is so charming that I would be tempted to recommend it even if the food were inedible.

title: County Cultural Groups Entice City Audiences
description: POLLY GUERIN had thought the place was ''very far away.'' Joanne Ebersbach had had ''no idea'' where the hamlet was. So when those and 40 other Manhattan residents got off the train at Katonah for Caramoor's opening concert on June 25, they were pleasantly surprised. ''We got here in no time,'' Ms. Guerin said of the 64-minute trip from Grand Central Terminal. ''It was so easy I think I'll do it again,'' said Barbara Heckman, another rider.

title: America the Possible
description: ''It's reached a point in this country where Rosa Parks is a heroine to everyone.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Big Step for Housing
description: LEAD: IT was only a milelong walk through a portion of Port Chester and Rye, but to the 100 Westchester residents who took it earlier this month, it was a potentially significant step toward providing housing for the county's needy.

title:
GARDENING;
Controlling Pests Without Pesticides
description: LEAD: CONCERN has been building over the use of chemical pesticides in and around the garden, even those relatively safe materials available over the counter.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cary, N.C.;
Europe Comes To Piedmont
description: LEAD: PLANS for a gigantic European-style supermarket were announced last month in this once quiet bedroom community adjacent to Raleigh, the state's capital.

title: Bagpipes And Kilts Recall Proud Heritage
description: IT is parade season, and the pipes are calling. From glen to glen, from village to town, the exotic sound of the bagpipe lends a sense of enchantment to familiar streets.

title: THE NATION: Cultivating Votes; Drought Aid: Just Another Entitlement?
description: Rain and cooler temperatures blessed the Middle West and South last week, giving hundreds of thousands of farmers hope that their withered crops might recover from the worst drought in half a century. But the moisture did nothing to deter members of the House and Senate Agriculture Committees, who are eager to approve a drought relief bill this week that would be the most generous farm disaster legislation ever considered.

title: 20 More Willa Cather Letters Given to Vermont Collection
description: The year was 1905. Willa Cather had just finished an unflattering depiction of a woman with a disfiguring scar on her face, a character based on Evelyn Osbourne, an acquaintance. Seeking comment, Miss Cather had sent to the story to Dorothy Canfield Fisher, her colleague and confidante. Mrs. Fisher was horrified.

title: BURMA: At a Glance
description: Economy

title: Make Money. Have Fun. Be Ethical.
description: LATELY I've done a lot of thinking about ethics in business. This might be because my job is very competitive. I'm in charge of getting new clients for my firm, a medium-sized advertising agency with a reputation for memorable commercials. Trying to win an advertising account in a contest with other agencies has to be one of the most intense forms of business competition. Every pitch is a battle of ideas and personalities. I face ethical situations every day that would tempt a saint. And I am unhappy with the level of ethics in the business world in general today, not because I have all the answers, but because I don't see many people even thinking about the questions.

title: Sports of The Times; The Man With the Ring
description: When youngsters are brought to the detention shelter in the Bronx, they have other things on their mind than the large ornate ring on the left hand of one of the house parents.

title: FIRST LADY OF THE HIGHWAYS
description: LADY BIRD JOHNSON AND THE ENVIRONMENT By Lewis L. Gould. Illustrated. 312 pp. Lawrence: University Press of Kansas. $29.95.

title: Newspaper in New Case Over Naming Source
description: The 600,000 subscribers to The Minneapolis Star Tribune will find no Sunday magazine in their newspapers this morning because of a conflict over the identification of news sources.

title: Are We Getting Value For Education Dollars?
description: Recently you printed some most interesting letters about the social problem of educating the handicapped.

title: Pruett Ready for Big Chance
description: Branch Rickey, the bushy-browed sage of baseball, often said that luck is the residue of design.

title: Atlantic City Airport: Ready to Soar
description: A RECENT newspaper article warned of a pending national crisis that could jeopardize our economy and change our life styles: gridlock at airports.

title: Peruvians Combating Red Tape
description: With Peru caught in its worst economic crisis in decades, the line separating rich and poor here is growing sharper than ever.

title: ADVICE FROM AN ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: REAL MAN TELLS ALL Confessions of an Eligible Bachelor. By Peter Nelson. 168 pp. New York: Penguin. Paper, $6.95.

title: Nurse Gets $65,000 For a Pulled Ponytail
description: A nurse who says she suffered pain and distress after a doctor yanked her ponytail has been awarded $65,000 in an out-of-court settlement.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS DEMOCRATS CLOAK THEIR TRUE COLORS
description: In his first response to the Democratic National Convention, President Reagan today accused his political rivals of making ''personal attacks'' against Republicans and trying to conceal from the voters what he portrayed as the Democrats' true liberal colors.

title: DiMaggio Released
description: Looking as fit as a Hall of Fame center fielder should, Joe DiMaggio was discharged yesterday from the Miami Beach hospital where he underwent surgery 10 days earlier. ''His prognosis is excellent; the reason he recovered so well is that he's in excellent physical condition,'' said Dr. Manuel Sivina, a vascular surgeon. ''He did extremely well, no complications.''

title: Question Of the Week; What Should Righetti's Role Be?
description: Dave Righetti now needs space, where an occasional gopher ball isn't the end, where there's time to erase a deficit and a victory is solid and good (not the upside-down reliever's kind). For the sake of our sanity, return the man to the regular rotation. He has paid his dues.

title: Bronx Woman's Goal: Revive a Block
description: Hetty Fox says she believes a father is like half the universe. If that is true, then she must be the other half for more than 70 children on Lyman Place, a block in the South Bronx.

title:
Fare of the Country;
Tapas for Spain's Happy Hour
description: LEAD: TAPAS, a finger food served in convivial taverns, personify the diverse tastes of Spain's cooking. They are also part of the fiber of Spanish life. As the Spanish food writer Juan Carlos Alonso said, ''Eating tapas is a complex game in which all your senses intervene.''

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Maplewood $348,000 44 Clinton Street 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 46-year-old colonial; deck, living room, fireplace, sun porch; taxes $5,362. Millburn $220,000 40 Southern Slope Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; 1-car garage, eat-in kitchen, full basement; taxes $2,811. Short Hills $283,507 68 Crescent Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; c/a, den; taxes $4,403. South Orange $290,000 364 Charlton Avenue 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; screened porch, 3 fireplaces, den; taxes $4,641. Tewksbury Township $229,000 4 Felmley Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, porch, brick fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $2,800. title: Into the Mouths of Babes
description: IT IS WELL WITHIN THE REACH of most white-collar criminals to assume an air of irreproachable virtue, especially when they're about to be sentenced. But there was something unusually compelling about the bearing of Niels L. Hoyvald and John F. Lavery as they stood before Judge Thomas C. Platt of the United States District Court in Brooklyn last month - especially in light of what they were being sentenced for. As president and vice president of the Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation, Hoyvald and Lavery had sold millions of bottles of ''apple juice'' that they knew to contain little or no apple juice at all - only sugars, water, flavoring and coloring. The consumers of this bogus product were babies.

title: Foundation Officials Sued by Ex-Employee
description: LEAD: A FORMER assistant to the president of the Waterloo Foundation for the Arts in Stanhope has filed a lawsuit against the foundation and its co-founders, Percival H. E. Leach and Louis Gualandi.

title: F.D.A. Will Allow AIDS Patients To Import Unapproved Medicines
description: The head of the Food and Drug Administration told an AIDS conference in Boston today that the agency would allow Americans to import unapproved drugs from abroad in small quantities for their personal use.

title: New York No-Smoking Law: Echoing Society's 'No More!'
description: New Yorkers are adjusting to the city's new anti-smoking law with little argument or incident because it follows a profound social change that has transformed the way people live and work.

title: Lisa Hearst and T. P. Espy Engaged to Wed in October
description: Patricia T. Ruggieri of New York and John Randolph Hearst Jr. of Bridgehampton, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Lisa Tenney Hearst to Thomas Pierson Espy, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James J. Espy of Cincinnati. An October wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;
Indonesian Fare in Mamaroneck
description: LEAD: DURING these dog days, cool outdoor spots are hard to find. But beyond the narrow blue and white dining room, Luke's back patio seems always to catch a breeze. Since our review last year, the owners, Linda and Luke Teurlinckx, have revised and literally spiced up their Dutch-Indonesian rotisserie menu with the addition of a number of

title: The Busiest Time to Keep Plants Growing
description: GROOM petunias, geraniums, snapdragons and salvias by cutting off or snapping off old flowers to prevent seed pods and prolong bloom; if there is time, remove faded roses and day lilies. Sow ripe columbine seed promptly where it is to grow. Prune hedges to keep them in line, especially if they block street and drive views or hinder foot traffic. The Rains Came

title: HALF IS BETTER THAN NONE
description: THE TOPIC OF TODAY'S SERMON is half-bottles - with an explanation. You think it's cut and dried? Either you like them or you don't? Shows how much you know.

title: On the Perils Of Automatic Rewind
description: LIKE the monster in Mary Shelley's novel ''Frankenstein,'' automation can sometimes run amok. We're left behind, watching helplessly as the motorized innards of our cameras take on wills of their own.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: In PRELUDE TO FOUNDATION (Doubleday, $18.95) Isaac Asimov continues to tie together his three best-known science fiction series - those dealing with robots, the Galactic Empire and the First and Second Foundations. Mr. Asimov, who is 68 years old, seems to have no trouble recapturing the style and mood of s.f. classics he wrote nearly half a century ago.

title: Repertorio Espanol Goes on With el Espectaculo
description: Repertorio Espanol is 20 years old this summer, a milestone the company is too busy to observe and one that is unlikely to seize the attention of New York's mainstream theater world. Repertorio, which remains adamantly Castilian in tongue, tone and tune, is one of the more venerable professional repertory groups in the nation, and offers a profusion of plays, dance and musicals that would, in its native land, be at center stage in the cultural scene.

title: Question Of the Week; What Should Righetti's Role Be?
description: Dave Righetti could break the record book in many categories if he became a starting pitcher again, but I know he would go crazy waiting every fifth day to pitch. He is one of the best relief pitchers in the game. As long as he is happy putting out the fire, I am for the relief role. HOLLY S. HOAK New Canaan, Conn.

title: Painting Plants for the Sake of Science
description: LEAD: ITS simple stylized form has made botanical art appealing to decorators, but its roots go deeper - to scientific documentation.

title: Wacky Comedy in Debut
description: AS he tumbles out of the mouth of an M-G-M lion to a crescendo of lights and action, Charley Bacon roars, ''I don't want any more drama in my life.'' And, in Arthur Giron's wacky comedy, ''Charley Bacon and His Family,'' at the John Drew Theater, drama, excitement, beauty and just plain entertainment are what Charley unsuccessfully tries to suppress.

title: GUIDES FOR THE BAREFOOT INVESTOR
description: HIGH STEPPERS, FALLEN ANGELS, AND LOLLIPOPS Wall Street Slang. By Kathleen Odean. 212 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $17.95. ABZs OF MONEY & FINANCE By Susan Lee. 219 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $16.95.

title:
About Men;
A Budding Artist
description: LEAD: I LOVE TO WATCH MEN cut dahlias,'' Mayumi told me during a break in our ikebana lessons. ''They go about it in a completely different way. I think I could fall in love with a man by the way he cuts dahlias.''

title: New School Aid for the Homeless
description: THE State Legislature has now provided financial support for a regulation issued two months ago by the Board of Regents that gave homeless parents the right to choose where their children attend school.

title: Turning Lear Into a Matriarch
description: WHAT has been happening to Lear since she stopped over in New Brunswick?

title: POSTINGS: At Languishing Teaneck Retail Center; And Now, Offices
description: At Glenpointe in Teaneck, N.J., Alfred Sanzari built 160 town houses and has sold all but five. He built 567,000 square feet of office space in two seven-story towers and has leased 95 percent of it.

title: Robert Cox Wed To Nancy Jones
description: The marriage of Nancy Lynn Jones, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Franklin Jones of Somers, Conn., to Robert Howard Cox took place yesterday at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. David Uhl performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bert George Cox of Rye.

title: DEBUNKING THE MYTH OF DECLINE
description: Daniel Patrick Moynihan's article ''Debunking the Myth of Decline'' (June 19), reminds us, usefully, that the Federal budget and trade-balance deficits are, in large measure, the consequences of bad policy, which can be corrected.

Garden City $308,400 131 Chestnut Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 45-year-old colonial; fireplace, dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. title: Ordinary People
description: The reporter had just been talking to Madeleine Albright, foreign affairs adviser to Gov. Michael Dukakis. Then, in the Atlanta hotel corridor, he encountered Susan Estrich, the Dukakis campaign manager. A few steps farther down the white-tiled floor, he saw Robin Toner of The Times, who has been covering the Governor's campaign.

title: Correction
description: The Bridge column in the Pastimes page July 17th had an incorrect bidding with South bidding double. The final double was by East and not by South.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. When we decided to close our house for the winter while we were away, we got conflicting advice. One school of thought recommended leaving the heat on at a low setting because otherwise the woodwork, furniture and even the latex paint could be damaged by cold and dampness inside the house. The other school of thought said that dmage, if any, would be negligible, and the worst would be offset by the savings in fuel bills. What do yo think we should do next winter?

title: Wetlands Dispute
description: A dispute over the size of an affected wetlands area has delayed indefinitely a public hearing to consider the environmental effects of a 94-unit residential project proposed for Yorktown.

title: Francis Ford Coppola: Promises to Keep
description: OUTSIDE, NEW YORK City is sweltering in a heat wave. In an apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, an 11-year-old girl mixes a strawberry daiquiri in a blender, pours a glass for her mother, then sips from her own tall glass of foamy pink fluid.

title: Q and A
description: Consolidators

title: Robert S. Bridges Jr. Wed To Kelly L. Miller in Ohio
description: Kelly Lynn Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Miller of Toledo, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Robert Shaw Bridges Jr., a son of Beryl C. Bridges of Montclair, N.J., and Mr. Bridges of London. The Rev. Walter Sobol performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: POSTINGS: At a Farm on the Hudson; A Budding Crop of 450 Houses
description: Farm-to-town-house conversions along the Hudson River in upstate New York have become as common as factory-to-loft conversions along Hudson Street in Soho. Most recently, Otto and Henry Frank decided it was time to retire and sell the Frank Brothers Farm just east of downtown Poughkeepsie on Route 44. John A. Maione, a New Jersey builder, took one look at the 165-acre tract and, he said later, decided ''I have never seen a property to equal this property, and I've been at it for 22 years.'' Upon final town approvals for his 450-unit project, which he expects next month, Mr. Maione will close on the former vegetable farm and begin construction.

title: An Easygoing Bistro With Big Apple Roots
description: MANHATTAN clones in the Hamptons are commonplace. The frame storefront on Main Street in Bridgehampton that housed the Stage Deli last year is now the home of Mel's Restaurant and Bar.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CHECKER AND THE DERAILLEURS. By Lionel Shriver. Illustrated by the author. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) Now that Jackie Collins has published a cardboard fictionalization of rock 'n' roll in ''Rock Star,'' a younger, hipper writer has produced a novel that has all the adolescent energy and raw appeal of an early David Bowie bootleg.

title: THE ORDERLY RISE OF A NEW KIND OF DEMOCRAT
description: On one side stood Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the courtly embodiment of the Democratic Party's conservative wing. On the other, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the impassioned voice of the party's left. In the middle was Michael Stanley Dukakis, the nominee of the Democratic National Convention, and he was smiling. It was exactly where he wanted to be.

title: Caroline Erisman Plans to Be Wed To J. J. Silberstein
description: Caroline Kent Erisman and John J. Silberstein, who are lawyers, are planning to marry Sept. 10. The parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Otis William Erisman of Gladwyne, Pa., have announced the engagement.

title: GARDENING MEANS WAR
description: We experienced the woodchuck invasion last summer and we had a fence. Nothing deterred them. Wildlife experts advised us to set humane traps, then drive to some distant, wooded area and release them. Somehow, transporting woodchucks in the back of my new car appealed to me less than giving up my garden-fresh produce.

title: Headliners; Sounding Familiar
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist John Hersey last week ended a literary brouhaha he helped create. He did that by publicly apologizing for liberally using, without attribution, another writer's material in a magazine article he had written. Mr. Hersey's article, an essay about the critic and writer James Agee, appeared recently in The New Yorker, and borrowed heavily from Laurence Bergreen's biography of Mr. Agee - though Mr. Bergreen received no credit in the article. ''I'm very sorry if I've offended Mr. Bergreen. I should have given him some direct credit,'' said Mr. Hersey. ''That I will now do.'' Mr. Bergreen's lawyer has asked The New Yorker to publish a corrective statement, and the magazine has indicated that one may appear in Monday's edition.

title: The Grandmaster Draws a Blank
description: WHEN a grandmaster heads straight into a variation that has long been known to be defective and doesn't produce any sort of innovation, bad or good, one may well wonder what was going on.

title: MISERABLE AT THE FEAST OF LIFE
description: THE ANTIPEOPLE By Sony Labou Tansi. Translated by J. A. Underwood. 170 pp. New York: Marion Boyars/Kampmann & Company. $18.95.

title: Wedtech's Challenge: 'Monsoon' of Evidence
description: During more than four months at trial, the prosecutors of the Wedtech racketeering case have faced a constant, nettlesome problem: how to create a compelling story line out of what one lawyer called ''a monsoon of evidence'' that is by turns either obscure or circumstantial, to convict seven seemingly disparate defendants of conspiracy and extortion.

title: With Friends
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest Betsy Wade's ''Tips for Trips With Friends'' (Practical Traveler, May 1) because of our own experience with a couple whom we met on a trip to Madrid in 1971 and with whom we have traveled ever since.

title: Review/Theater; Guilt and Secret Pain In Australian Drama
description: A couple of decades ago there was a great deal of talk about the domino theory. Under the circumstances of the time, the theory went that if Vietnam fell to the Communists, the rest of Southeast Asia would collapse, country by country, in rapid succession. The double-six in this particular set of dominos was Australia.

title: Democrats, Upbeat After Atlanta, Emerge With Ambitious Strategy
description: The Democrats emerged from their national convention this week united in support of their ticket and upbeat in their assessment that the gathering in Atlanta improved Michael S. Dukakis's chances in November.

title: Avoiding a Sunburn With Pills and Patches
description: TOO busy to pack sun lotion? You could wear a pliable plastic bracelet that snaps open to dispense an ounce of waterproof suntan oil. Called Handy Tan - and available in four colors at some convenience stores and health food outlets - the item can be strapped onto the wrist or ankle or worn in the hair.

title: Giants Sign Carthon
description: The Giants reached terms yesterday with Maurice Carthon, one of the six veterans missing from camp, but they lost a versatile defensive back for the season when Herb Welch suffered ligament damage in his left knee during a training camp drill in Florham Park, N.J.

title: One Convention Rite Lives On
description: The nominee may be cool and cerebral, the results predetermined, the event carefully packaged for television and unity the word of the hour. But the roll call at the Democratic Convention was as folksy and unpredictable as ever.

title: U.S. SEES NO BAR TO ARMS IN ANGOLA
description: American officials say the new Angola peace plan does not prevent the United States from continuing to send weapons and ammunition to Angolan guerrillas fighting against the Soviet-backed Government in Luanda.

title: Correction
description: A chart on third world missile deployment in The Week in Review on July 3 was incorrectly labeled. The headline should have said that the chart listed only ''nuclear capable'' missiles (defined as those with a range of greater than 190 miles and a payload of greater than 1,100 pounds), and the footnote should have said that countries listed with question marks were reported to be seeking the missiles indicated, not that they already had them.

title: Dodgers Top Pirates on Five-Hitter
description: Tim Leary finally believes in himself, and he's making believers of the rest of the National League as well.

title: Students Befriend Nature on the Cape
description: The tiny box turtle, barely two inches long, was cleverly hidden deep among the dried leaves in the Massachusetts Audubon Society's Wellfleet Bay Wildlife Sanctuary.

title: Telephone Service Lagging
description: LEAD: A GROWING number of rural residents are having telephone problems while the telephone company tries to catch up with the phenomenal boom in new housing that has hit the state over the last three years.

title:
FASHION;
COUTURE'S CACHET
description: LEAD: For the fall-winter couture collections that start in Paris today with Christian Lacroix, designers have the ultimate luxury of second-guessing a season. All have already presented earlier versions of the same season in their ready-to-wear lines, shown here in March, and, in most cases, already arriving in American stores.

title: Here's to Your Health, but Not All the Details
description: THE 80's is the decade of medical show and tell. I'm sick of it.

title: After 46 Years, Archie Remains Fresh-Faced Kid Next Door
description: LEAD: IF Michael Silberkleit's teen-ager ever grows up and gets a job, then Mr. Silberkleit may well be out of business.

title: NONFICTION
description: AT THE HEART OF THE WHITE ROSE: Letters and Diaries of Hans and Sophie Scholl. Edited by Inge Jens. Translated by J. Maxwell Brownjohn. (Harper & Row, $21.95.) The anti-Nazi group known as the White Rose consisted of a small circle of students and a teacher at the University of Munich who in May 1942, when Hitler was still triumphant in the war, secretly began to distribute leaflets denouncing the Nazi regime. Led by Hans Scholl, a medical student and military conscript, along with his sister, Sophie, the White Rose constituted one of the very few anti-Nazi enclaves operating in Germany. (The Scholls and their co-conspirators were beheaded in 1943 after brother and sister were spotted dropping fliers over a school balustrade.) These excerpts from their diaries and letters, edited by the German journalist Inge Jens and capably translated by J. Maxwell Brownjohn, are almost entirely without reference to the group's operations, since any entry might one day have been confiscated. But if this collection lacks drama, it does offer a remarkable record of daily life in Hitler's Germany in all its surreally mundane particulars. We see the Scholls attending concerts, talking of nature and Goethe, even as they risk death. Hans's diaries of German campaigns into Russia and Poland are especially stirring, documenting his tormented compassion for Hitler's victims. What this book makes clear is that the White Rose had no coherent political strategy or much chance of victory. The Scholls' resistance was that of European spiritual humanism at its most sublime - and desperate.

title: How to Sleep in an Austrian Bed
description: LEAD: WELL, you don't just throw open the covers, jump in and abandon yourself to the embrace of Morpheus. Wooing sleep in an Austrian bed requires patience, dexterity and a nodding acquaintance with thermodynamics. The secret is selective exposure, a strategy that will be elucidated in due course.

title: Aiding Caregivers of the Elderly
description: LEAD: FIRST, Kevin Dolan's 78-year-old father had a near-fatal heart attack last July, a few months after he and his wife, Mr. Dolan's stepmother, moved to Delray Beach, Fla. He also has acute emphysema.

title: State Power Agency Contemplates Larger Role in Wake of Shoreham
description: LEAD: A DREAM of public power on Long Island quite unlike what backers of the Long Island Power Authority had in mind has taken root in the second largest public power authority in the country.

title: Behind the Wheel: Anatomy of a Crash
description: Auto racing is a much safer sport today than it was 18 years ago when I started driving at a small track near Birmingham, Ala. The Winston Cup stock-car circuit, where I race these days, has a particularly good safety record. And although I had the misfortune of being hurt fairly badly in Charlotte, N.C., last fall, when I get into my Valvoline Pontiac before the start of a race these days , I don't think about the chances of getting hurt again.

title: Always Out of Step In the Fashion Parade
description: I KNOW when I get to heaven and I'm tying on golden slippers, adjusting my robe and wings, preparing to dance down that golden street, I'll look up and see that everyone else in the robe room is putting on sweats and Reeboks. When it comes to fashion, I'm always out of step.

description: THE LONG-DISTANCE RUNNER An Autobiography. By Michael Harrington. 260 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: The Right To Protect Our Own Backyards
description: SUDDENLY everyone is worrying about Nimbys - the ''not-in-my-backyard'' reactions of neighbors and communities when they find out that someone is planning a development that threatens the way they live.

title: Across Lake Michigan On a Deck Chair
description: LAKE travel, the utterly civil and once-popular mode of transportation, probably seems out of pace with America of the late 20th century, gone the way of homemade ice cream and cornet bands and Pullman berths.

title: FICTION
description: LOOSE CONNECTIONS. By Sybil Claiborne. (Academy Chicago, $16.95.) The connections in Sybil Claiborne's first collection of short stories are loose indeed. Many of the characters have only a tenuous grip on reality; still others inhabit a collapsing world in which a malevolent government, god or military-industrial complex is systematically destroying the populace. In ''The Gulag Computer: Dead Souls in the Terminal,'' a man dies and discovers that he and other deceased men and women have been transmuted into computer chips that will be forced to put together the words of a trashy novel. The circle of elderly friends in ''Last Year at Pittsburgh'' may or may not be imagining a horrible war that has devastated America. The narrator of the title story couples with a C.I.A. man who's selling tiny radios that fit into bodily crevices and monitor conversations. Although one can admire - and sometimes be amused by - Ms. Claiborne's powers of invention, these nightmarish visions seldom disturb or provoke. The development of her characters' personalities is largely missing, and any emotional resonance is lost in the midst of her rambling and often self-consciously jokey prose. Only a few of the 16 stories elicit a real chill. Tellingly, the most successful one, ''Rubble,'' has the most conventional narrative structure. In it, a woman discovers that her eccentric aunt, long considered the destructive member of the family, may have been more victim than victimizer. By concentrating here on substance rather than style, Ms. Claiborne finally makes a connection with the reader's emotions.

title: Foster Fails in Bid for Olympics
description: Roger Kingdom, Tonie Campbell and Arthur Blake, the three favorites, made the United States Olympic team today in the 110-meter hurdles. The best human-interest stories revolved around Greg Foster, Al Joyner and Renaldo Nehemiah, who did not.

title: Headliners; Pronouncing Sentence
description: Perhaps the only consolation that the Colombian drug kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas could find at his sentencing in Florida last week was that the judge did not quite throw the book at him. Prosecutors had asked Federal District Judge Howell W. Melton to sentence Mr. Lehder to life in prison without parole, plus 150 years, following his May conviction for smuggling 3.3 tons of cocaine into the country. Only a minor point of law prevented the prosecution from total success. Mr. Lehder, who is 38 years old, received life plus 135 years. He was also fined $350,000. Prosecutors believe he was responsible for 80 percent of the Colombian cocaine reaching the United States, much of it shipped through the Bahamas. Judge Melton called the sentence ''a signal to society that it will do everything it can to rid itself of this cancer.''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Gallery 'Creatures'

title: CONSUMER RATES
Across America by Rail; Eastward From Seattle on the Empire Builder
description: THE train skimmed past the freshly mowed hayfields of western Washington in the long shadows and golden light of late afternoon. A narrow dirt road curved in from the countryside to parallel the tracks, and I leaned on the windowsill in my private compartment to watch a man in a pickup driving alongside the train, idly scanning the windows. When he got to mine, I lifted my wine glass in a toast. He grinned and tipped his cowboy hat, then gunned off down the road.

title: Tests of a Potential Drug for AIDS Beginning After Months of Delay
description: After months of controversy, the Federal Government is beginning human trials of a potential AIDS drug, dextran sulfate, which is already being used by thousands of desperate patients who purchased it abroad or from covert suppliers.

title: Let the Electoral College Die Like the Dinosaur; House Decided in 1824
description: To the Editor:

title: Mabou Mines Offers a Female 'Lear'
description: WHAT has been happening to Lear since she stopped over in New Brunswick?

title: Power Struggle
description: YOU MIGHT SEE IT AS EITHER A dark day or the coming of the light; night baseball is dawning at Wrigley Field. On Aug. 8, at 7:05 P.M. C.D.T., when the Chicago Cubs take to their venerable home diamond to face the Philadelphia Phillies, baseball's most famous anachronism will be history. Night games at Wrigley, which was built in 1914 (the Cubs moved in two years later), were made possible last February when a City Council vote cleared the way for the installation of lights. On the one hand, The Tribune Company, which owns the Cubs, anticipates increased attendance and access to prime-time television revenue. On the other hand, purists wail: another tradition lost to filthy lucre. Somewhere in the middle sits Don Zminda, whose interest is scholarly.

title: Travel Trap
description: To the Editor:

title: Rides Go On, but He's Getting Off
description: THE Casino Pier is one of the major boardwalk attractions here that Kenneth Wynne Jr. and his family built in the last 40 years with quarters and Kewpie dolls, as well as plenty of charm and tenacity.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HOLIDAY WATERCOLORS The New Britain Youth Museum has added a series of art exhibits to its schedule, beginning with a display of Tasha Tudor's original illustrations for ''A Time to Keep,'' for which she also wrote the text. Her watercolors depict the holiday celebrations of a single New England family during one year. They can be seen until Sept. 6. Future exhibits will continue to focus on artists who have created works especially for children.

title: Maine Dogcatcher In a Tender Trap
description: FOR Rick Caron, a dogcatcher in central Maine, the job boiled down to this: Who was catching whom?

title: 'SILENCE IS ESSENTIAL'
description: THE SHOOTING GALLERY By Yuko Tsushima. Translated and compiled by Geraldine Harcourt. 138 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Paper, $7.95.

title: New York Arsenal Celebrates Role As Only 'Big Gun' Producer in U.S.
description: In an age of atomic bombs and intercontinental ballistic missiles, old-fashioned cannon still pour out of the Watervliet Arsenal, which this month is celebrating its 175th anniversary of producing arms for the United States Army.

title: Marie Oh Weds John Huber
description: At Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Potomac, Md., Marie Jae-hwa Oh, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Kie-chiang Oh of Potomac, was married yesterday to John Robert Huber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edmund Huber of Atherton, Calif. The Rev. Leo R. Huber, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: An Exponent Of Order And Control
description: Name the greatest prodigy in the history of music. Mozart? Mendelssohn? Korngold? Wrong. He was Charles Camille Saint-Saens, who was composing at the age of 3 1/2. If you find this hard to believe, go to the Conservatoire in Paris where the manuscript is on display. The child was playing the standard repertory with mature violinists before he was 7. When he made his debut at 12, he volunteered to play as an encore any of the 32 Beethoven sonatas. Now that's real style.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Office Condos Gain as Rental Alternative
description: LEAD: A GROWING number of small service businesses looking for alternatives to leasing office space or buying a free-standing building have brought on a spurt in commercial condominium projects throughout the state.

title: Barbecue
description: To the Editor: At last it happened to me. I ate at a restaurant just before reading about it in the Travel section. Dreamland Bar-B-Q ribs are a treat well worth the drive from anywhere to Tuscaloosa. If one were to compile the Top-Twenty Hole-in-the-Wall Restaurants, Dreamland Bar-B-Q Drive Inn should certainly be on the list.

title: RULING RAISES FEAR OF RESEARCH CURBS
description: The revival of a lawsuit over whether a patient retains rights to his blood and tissue has rekindled fears among scientists that legal constraints could hamper medical research.

title: With Friends
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade could have added one more caveat. That is, try to travel with friends you already know well. That way you will already know some of their likes, dislikes, prejudices and idiosyncrasies.

title: Navy Is Studying Bias in Promotions
description: The Navy has begun an intensive inquiry to find out why its recruiting and promotion of black and Hispanic personnel as officers and senior non-commissioned officers lags behind that of whites and of minority officers in the other services.

title: Jennifer L. Proud Marries a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Jennifer Lee Proud, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Proud of Berkeley Heights, N.J., to Geoffrey Simonson Mearns, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Mearns of Shaker Heights, Ohio, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J. Msgr. John F. Corr performed the ceremony.

title: The Long and the Short of Museum Loans
description: Woven into the fabric of every major museum there are two kinds of thread. Both are important. Both are invisible to the casual eye. One is the thread of the long loan - the work of art that is by now so much at home in the museum that we forget that it belongs to someone else and can be withdrawn at any time. One such is the very beautiful early Rembrandt of the ''Rape of Europa'' that has been on loan for years - and much coveted by others - in the Metropolitan Museum's Dutch 17th-century galleries.

title: Victoria English Becomes a Bride
description: Victoria English, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore English of Grafton, Mass., was married in London yesterday to William David Turner Ellington 3d, a son of Mrs. James G. Downward of Hilton Head Island, S.C., and the late Jesse T. Ellington. The Rev. David Usher performed the ceremony at the Rosslyn Hill Unitarian Chapel.

title: A Family Defends Its Dynasty
description: IT is one of the great family dynasties in corporate America. McGraw-Hill Inc., the publishing giant founded in 1909, has had a McGraw at the helm through two world wars, the Depression and into the electronic era.

title: Boston Judge Fighting Homelessness From Bench
description: When her husband left last year, Mattie E. Johnson found she could not single-handedly support her four children. Bills went unpaid and before long, the family was evicted for failing to meet the rent.

title:
INVESTING;
Pearls From a Former Shell?
description: LEAD: ONE rarely finds a company that has $650 million of annual revenues in the ''pink sheets,''a printed listing of mostly obscure securities. But that is where the stock of Schick Companies Inc. is listed, at about $4 a share.

title: Sports of The Times; The Johnson-Cashen-Piniella Triangle
description: Dave Johnson's tenure as the Mets' manager beyond this season has been uncertain now for nearly a year. But with his winning record, it had been unthinkable that the Mets' front office would consider changing managers until after the season. Then the Mets lost 8 of 12 games before returning to Shea Stadium against the Atlanta Braves this weekend.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE CORMORANT. By Stephen Gregory. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) It would be very easy and very wrong to simplify the horror Stephen Gregory creates in this strong first novel. ''The Cormorant'' has a relentless focus that would make Edgar Allan Poe proud: the terrible effect an inheritance has on a sweet young English family.

title: Julian Webber Weds Lucy Sexton in Ireland
description: The marriage of Lucy Sexton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Sexton of Brooklyn and Corofin, County Clare, Ireland, to Julian M. C. Webber, a son of Pamela Kyne of Stowmarket, Suffolk, England, and Dr. Brian P. Webber of Guernsey, took place yesterday at St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church in Corofin. The Rev. Patrick Walsh performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
Where the Fragrant Plants Grow
description: LEAD: ONE whiff of the heavy scent of gardenias transports me back 20 years to my grandmother's garden in Florida. Her large gardenia plant was always covered with velvety white blooms that perfumed the air. At age 5 I had discovered an ancient pleasure.

title: Talk of Women, Parties and Wives
description: JUST as the New Jersey Democratic Party chairman, Raymond M. Durkin, was about to speak on party unity Monday morning to his state's delegates at the Democratic National Convention, loud cries came from the back of the room.

title:
MUSIC;
Organetto, Sackbut and All
description: LEAD: THE ensemble called Music for a While, which specializes in medieval and Renaissance music, will perform the final program in the Professional Artist Series on Thursday night, sponsored by the Arts Foundation of New Jersey as part of the Leonardo Teacher Institute. The program will begin at 7:30 in the Blumberg Auditorium of Lucy Stone Hall, at Livingston

title: Reviews/Music; The Accordion as Star, in 'The Big Squeeze'
description: Under the title ''The Big Squeeze,'' the Serious Fun festival at Alice Tully Hall assembled a diverse passel of accordionists Friday night. The accordion has its ins and outs, and this concert had its ups and downs. The idea was sweet, and with better editing and technical support it might have been outstanding. But ambivalence of intentions laid it low.

title: Groovy '60's Is Charity Party Theme
description: LEAD: AS sensitive as some may be to the term ''Yuppie,'' it does not offend Ruth Ann McSpadden. Unless, of course, being a Yuppie involves ''a total commitment to materialism,'' said the mother of three young children.

title: A Kingdom Of Wildlife In a Great Lake
description: IT is a forest island, rising like a green castle from the blue lake, its beaches the color of sunshine. The evergreen woods, sand dunes, inland lakes and wetlands are rich in small wildflowers and fruit - buttercups and blackberries, pink bean peas and waterlilies, tiny woodland orchids, blueberries, primroses, strawberries and creeping snowberries, jewel weed and yarrow. The island also hides wildlife, especially deer, rabbits, grouse and ducks, with fox, beaver, raccoons, even an occasional shy coyote in the forest. On its roads there are more butterflies than cars, and on the beaches more sandpipers than sunbathers.

title: Pipeline Idea Alive But Quiet
description: TWO summers ago, word of a proposal to run a natural gas pipeline through the peaceful hills of northwestern Connecticut galvanized the region. Word spread quickly, meetings attracted hundreds of angry residents, and protest was sounded up and down the proposed pipeline route.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MOSES IN THE PROMISED LAND. By R. Howard Bloch. (Gibbs Smith/Peregrine Smith, Paper, $10.95.) The author of this satire of contemporary remnants of the 1960's counterculture is a professor of French literature at the University of California, Berkeley, which leads one to look for French influences and to wonder if the setting, a town called Beacon, is actually Berkeley.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Salem, N.H.;
'Last Straw' Lights a Fire
description: LEAD: THE Massachusetts Legislature's passage of a health-care law in April that provides coverage to those not covered by private plans has been a cause for celebration in this border town.

title: Read All About Shakespeare!
description: To the Editor:

title: Fear Takes the Sting Out of High Prices
description: COSMETICS companies have long invested heavily in developing products that promise to moisturize, preserve and otherwise enhance the beauty of your skin. But until only about a decade ago, the industry largely avoided the sun-care market. Now, analysts say, sun-care products represent about 10 to 15 percent of sales for major cosmetics companies, at least twice the level of five years ago.

title: Man's Efforts Lead to 7,000 More Trees in Queens
description: Because of Paul Kerzner, 7,000 more trees are cooling the streets of western Queens in the humid summer, brightening them in the autumn, and diminishing air pollution year-round.

title: Dr. Bernard Meyer, Psychiatrist, Dies at 78
description: Dr. Bernard C. Meyer, a Manhattan psychiatrist and psychoanalyst whose affiliation with Mount Sinai Hospital spanned more than 40 years, died Friday night at his home after a lengthy illness. He was 78 years old and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: GOLDEN OLDIES Nostalgia is strictly in the eyes and or ears of the beholders. And this is the week on Long Island for those who remember what popular music was like before they had to roll with the rock to venture into their past. For example, today Cab Calloway, the legendary inventor of ''Hi-De-Ho,'' comes to Hempstead Town Park in Point Lookout at 7:30 P.M. to help people recall his ''Minnie the Moocher'' and ''Caledonia.''
