title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WHY IS THERE SALT IN THE SEA? By Brigitte Schwaiger. Translated by Sieglinde Lug. (University of Nebraska, $15.95.) Originally published in Vienna in 1977, Brigitte Schwaiger's first novel was widely acclaimed in both Austria and Germany, and subsequently throughout Europe. It is now available for the first time in a smooth, although at times too literal, English translation by Sieglinde Lug.

title: Get Thee Behind Me, Podium
description: A few weeks ago, the composer Andrzej Panufnik conducted a program of his music at the 92d Street Y, courtesy of the First New York International Festival of the Arts. It was an excellent concert, with Mr. Panufnik's outwardly conservative, accessible yet still searching and original music expertly rendered by the New York Chamber Symphony. I reported on the concert at the time, but there was something about the occasion that set my mind spinning off in another direction that seemed inappropriate for a review.

title: Patent Remedies
description: To the Editor:

title: For Sun Lovers, Tan Is Worth the Risk
description: AS beauty experts and dermatologists extol the virtues of pallor, a large number of the nation's sunbathers are sending a different message: The popularity of tanning will never fade.

title: Preaching to the Unconverted
description: To hear David Zinman tell it, turning 50 a couple of years ago wasn't all that bad. For one thing, it gave him the courage of some still-unorthodox Beethovenian convictions - like observing the composer's metronome markings, phrasing in a style closer to Mozart than to Mahler, even adding Baroque-style ornaments in the earlier symphonies.

title: Austria Weighs Joining European Community
description: After years of resisting the idea of joining the European Community, neutral Austria is seriously considering full membership as the organization's 12 members move toward the goal of a single market by 1992, according to Austrian officials and politicians.

title: Shore Pollution Driving Away Summer Tourists
description: The medical waste that has fouled beaches in the New York region at the peak of the summer season has taken its toll on business all along the shore, driving vacationers away both from beaches that have been closed and from those that have remained open.

title: WESTERN CIV AND ITS CHILDREN
description: There is great controversy today about the character and quality of American education. A longstanding concern with the nation's schools, elementary and secondary, has in recent years been made even more dramatic by reports of decline at the highest level in America's colleges and universities. In our late-20th-century throwaway culture, where every idea has its season, it has become fashionable to find fault with American higher education, to imagine that both professors and students are engaged in some sort of illicit conspiracy to make over a system that was once perfect, that used to involve students and their professors in close textual study of the ''great books'' of the ages. Although no one in the United States would seriously argue that we ought to return to the medicine and health care system that existed in the 1940's - and while no one sees this as a golden age, now lost - such a proposition for higher education would not seem at all preposterous to many who complain vociferously about what they perceive to be the fall in standards in America's colleges and universities.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: The New Priorities; Wiring and Power Now Dominate Office Concerns
description: BEFORE Thomson McKinnon Securities, the brokerage firm, moved its headquarters into a new downtown tower, workers had to route more than 28,000 miles of wire to a multitude of computers, lights, telephones and other office equipment.

title: Fancies Flow in a Quiet Garden As Californians Experiment With Outdoor Chairs
description: What does the word ''chair'' suggest? Lots of different things, no doubt: anything from a folding chair to a fauteuil, from Chippendale to Charles Eames. As for ''the chair,'' it can equally well conjure up a symbol of authority - the chair that a chairman takes - and the electric chair.

title: ALL DECKED OUT
description: ONCE THERE'S A GLOSS OF SUN, A hint of warmth or an extended patch of blue sky in Seattle, the city moves outside. This passion for the outdoors may account for the profusion of decks that appear just about anywhere with enough space to set the posts. By the time summer rolls around, daylight extends until 10 P.M., and decks citywide have become adjuncts to the dining room.

title:
cONNECTICUT q&a;: ALLEN BEAVERS;
'Day Camp Is Not Day Care'
description: LEAD: CAMPING trends are changing, according to Allen Beavers, the executive director of the Connecticut Campground Owners Association. Computer camps are out. Parents today want an old-fashioned summer camp for their children with nature programs, arts and crafts and swimming. Above all, he said, they want a wholesome environment.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Are You Following The Leadup To the Olympics?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: What Taxpayers and Their Teams Do for Each Other
description: Two generous suitors and an inamorata who likes money have been providing melodrama here for months. It has been a long-distance, very public, often extravagant affair that begs the question: What won't a state do to get - or keep - a major league team?

title: Officials Who See Only Until Elections
description: IT could be a proposed home for the mentally retarded or a school for the physically disabled, or it could even be a housing project for low-income senior citizens. Elected officials, at first, respond with a degree of support, and some may even go so far as to express understanding of the need to be addressed by the proposal.

title: Review/Jazz; Ellington Tunes, Familiar and Rare
description: A night of Duke Ellington's music at the ''Jazz in July'' festival at the 92d Street Y on Thursday evening balanced polished treatments of familiar Ellington tunes with an assortment of fascinating, rarely heard Ellingtonia, highlighted by the emergence of two stellar performers.

title: Mandela Receives Prison Visit From Family
description: The imprisoned black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela today accepted an offer from the South African Government and received a visit from his wife and family.

title: State Presses for Orderly Growth
description: ALREADY the most densely populated state with 7.6 million people living in its 8,204 square miles, New Jersey is facing increasing pressures from haphazard growth as it nears the end of the century.

title: Courts' Message On the N.F.L.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jessica Spohn, Teacher, Weds Clifford Kayhart
description: Jessica Anne Spohn and Clifford Scott Kayhart were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by Judge Richard B. Lowe 3d of New York City Criminal Court.

title: Practical Traveler; Precautions to Take When Children Fly Alone
description: THE Department of Transportation cannot guess how many unaccompanied children are traveling by air on United States airlines these days. But as a general indication, two years ago United Airlines said it carried 500,000 over the summer. Piedmont said it carried 212,293 last year and expected 230,000 this year. Trans World Airlines said 300 to 350 unaccompanied children made connections every day through St. Louis.

title: Parking Lot Worker Is Killed; Another Is Shot, in Harlem
description: An attendant at a Harlem Hospital parking lot was shot in the face and killed early yesterday morning, and another attendant critically wounded, when they stopped a car that had been stolen from the lot several hours earlier, the police said.

title: A LEAP TOWARD CLOSING THE BASIC GAP BETWEEN CHRISTIANS AND JEWS
description: Neither fanfare nor controversy surrounded the Episcopal Church's endorsement earlier this month of a document called ''Guidelines for Christian-Jewish Relations.'' But the action was enough to start some Jewish and Christian leaders talking about a whole new era in relations between their faiths.

title: Minister Who Helped Jackson In Rights Movement Is Slain
description: A minister who was associated with the Rev. Jesse Jackson's civil rights efforts was found beaten to death in his church Friday, not long after he had returned from the Democratic National Convention. The police charged a nearby resident with the slaying.

title: Staci M. Berman, Lawyer, Engaged
description: Karen Berger of New York and Quogue, L.I., and William H. Berman of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Staci M. Berman to John Robert Barber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Barber of New York. The couple plan to marry Sept. 10.

title: Anne Ackerley to Wed David Lewis in August
description: Anne Frances Ackerley, an associate in investment banking at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, and David Lawrence Lewis, a staff writer in Yonkers for Gannett Westchester Newspapers, plan to marry Aug. 28.

title: Preventing The 'Brain Drain'
description: Dr. Norma Foreman Glasgow, the State Commissioner of Higher Education, has called attention to a problem which has begun to worry employers and government and community leaders - the migration of Connecticut college-bound youth. [ For College Students, the Grass May Be Greener at Home, June19 ] Statewide the figure is 53 percent; however, Fairfield County loses over 60 percent of its students to outofstate institutions of higher learning. Once these students leave the state, they may not return, thereby causing a ''brain drain.'' At a time when Connecticut is short of nurses, engineers and other trained professionals, the departure of its youth may represent a threat to the economy and well-being of the state.

title: Swedish Rookie Leads Open by 2
description: Continuing to be unintimidated by the pressures of leading the world's most prestigious women's golf championship, Liselotte Neumann of Sweden today equaled the 54-hole record score to take a two-stroke lead into Sunday's final round of the 43d United States Women's Open.

title: THE MOST AMAZING CHILD
description: LEAD: RIMBAUD By Pierre Petitfils. Translated by Alan Sheridan. Illustrated. 388 pp. Charlottesville: University Press of Virginia. $34.95.

title: 'La Cage' Staged in New Fairfield
description: AFTER the critical drubbing and commercial defeat suffered by the recent musical ''Beetle Bailey,'' Candlewood Playhouse audiences are ready for the reassurance of a proven hit, and in ''La Cage aux Folles,'' they have just the one: a guaranteed good time.

title: Oil: Putting the Pieces Together
description: WILL the price of oil rise in the next few months or fall? Probably both, sharply, and several times, if the recent past is any guide.

title: 'Side bySide' Offers Vintage Sondheim
description: ''SIDE BY SIDE BY SONDHEIM'' is a collage of music and lyrics by the American musical theater master Stephen Sondheim. Devised by the English actor-director Ned Sherrin, it had its premiere in London in 1976 and transferred to Broadway the following year. Now, this celebration of the work of Stephen Sondheim is the highlight of the Arena Players Repertory Theater summer season.

title: Colleen Campbell to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold L. Windman of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Hilton Head, S.C., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Windman's daughter Colleen Campbell to Peter Terrence Yanni, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Yanni of Briarcliff Manor. Ms. Campbell, a daughter also of the late Joseph P. Campbell, is a media planner at McCann-Erickson Advertising in New York. Mr. Yanni is a national account executive for Wang Laboratories in New York. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: Ambivalence in the Face of Helplessness
description: A BENT-OVER man with gray hair is mopping the once-elegant lobby floor as if he were sowing seeds of ammonia. The fumes rise to our eyes as we walk by him. My Aunt Bertie has lived in this place for 50 years. At one time, the elite of Brooklyn would announce the name of this building with a sense of aristocratic snobbery, as if they were giving a Park Avenue address.

title: SOME KIND WORDS IN ASIA DO NOT DISPEL A SENSE OF WANING U.S. INFLUENCE
description: In a parting toast at a banquet in Beijing, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen of China told Secretary of State George P. Shultz that ''the door of China is forever open to you.'' President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines said goodbye by lauding him as ''our true and trusted friend, a friend to me and our people.'' And after Mr. Shultz's luncheon address in Jakarta, one of his Indonesian hosts invited him to come back next year, either as a professor or a businessman.

title: Display of Figures by de Staebler
description: A PRESS release emblazoned with the artist's letterhead; a hefty catalogue with most of the reproductions in color; a nationwide tour - all this plus a splendid installation at the Neuberger Museum here. It is the kind of treatment normally reserved for old masters or contemporary superstars but it has nevertheless been accorded Stephen de Staebler, a sculptor who has yet to achieve the status of either.

title: Mary Ellen Rampino Weds
description: The marriage of Mary Ellen Rampino, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Rampino of Kendall Park, N.J., to Dr. Kenneth William Martin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth H. Martin of Kissimmee, Fla., took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. James Horner performed the ceremony. The bride is an executive secretary at The New York Times Company. The bridegroom is a chiropractor in Brooklyn.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Dark Eyes Starring Marcello Mastroianni, Silvana Mangano, Marthe Keller, Elena Sofonova, Pina Cei. Directed by Nikita Mikhalkov. 1987. CBS/Fox Video. 116 minutes. $89.98. In Italian, with English subtitles. Not rated.

title: Question Of the Week; What Should Righetti's Role Be?
description: Dave Righetti's role with the Yanks should be selling hot dogs on rolls in the stands. DAVID KAUFMAN Brooklyn

title: Budget Debate: Annual vs. Biennial
description: In the Connecticut Q&A, which appeared on May 22, Leo V. Donohue, the Democratic State Auditor, discussed the budget process and annual versus biennial budgets. Both he and the Republican State Auditor Henry J. Becker have been recommending a return to biennial budgets for over 10 years and the rationale put forth appears to have merit.

title: Michael Gunnison Wed To Frances M. Lynam
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Aidan in Williston Park, L.I., Frances McManus Lynam, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Lester Lynam of East Williston, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Joseph Gunnison, the son of Winifred Gunnison of Southold, L.I., and the late Joseph B. Gunnison Jr. The Rev. Michael Deacy, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Russian Village Seeks Landmark Status
description: LEAD: WHEN Kronid Elin was much younger, he used to spend his summers surrounded by figures like Count Ilya Tolstoy, Sergei Rachmaninoff and other Russian artists, writers and dancers. But Mr. Elin paid little mind to the talent, choosing instead to go fishing in the Pomperaug River below Russian Village in Southbury.

title: How to Clean Up Needle Beach
description: Investigators have not yet found the specific sources of hypodermic needles, blood vials and other medical waste rolling in with the tides on Northeast beaches. But controlling the problem poses no mystery at all.

title: Back to the Nest: Savings at a Price
description: To anyone planning to move back to his parents' house after being on his own, I've got one thing to say: Are you crazy?

title: Yale Cabaret Thrives on New Risks
description: AT the Ensemble Company for the Performing Arts, which sponsors the Summer Cabaret at Yale University in New Haven, the administrators take pride in taking risks.

title: Judge Under Fire For a Speech
description: OFFHAND it did not appear to be a very judicious statement for a judge to make.

title: THE WORLD: Iraq's Next Move; ISRAEL FEARS THAT PEACE IN THE PERSIAN GULF WILL UNLEASH A BITTER FOE
description: While the rest of the world breathed a sigh of relief as Iran and Iraq began talking about a cease-fire, in Israel the reaction was something close to anguish.

title: Reviews/Music; Blanchard Harrison's Young Jazz
description: The Blanchard-Harrison band, which played at Mikell's Thursday night, has had the luxury of major record-company support, allowing it to perform regularly. The results show: they're now one of the best young bands playing jazz today.

title: GLORY DAYS AT NASA
description: LIFTOFF The Story of America's Adventure in Space. By Michael Collins. Illustrated by James Dean. 288 pp. New York: Grove Press. $25.

title: The Fine Points Of Suit Combinations
description: MOST players think of suit combinations as kids' stuff. They are indeed the basic building blocks of play. Some of them, however, are quite deceptive and difficult to analyze.

title: A Hard Sell for Audi
description: NEXT month, Audi of America will introduce the Audi 100 and 200, two new models whose success or failure will reach far beyond industry sales charts. If the cars are a hit, the beleaguered luxury division of Volkswagen of America may be able to restore its image as a producer of refined luxury-performance cars. If they flop, Audi of America may be forced to pull out of the American market.

title: Revised Plan for Airport Gains Support
description: LEAD: A scaled-down airport-modernization plan, which reduces the proposed new terminal's size to 41,000 square feet from 51,500 and cuts parking-garage spaces to 1,200 from 2,000, received stepped-up support from some key county officials who reviewed it last week.

title: LIFE IS BORED WITH MERRIL
description: THE CRYPTO-AMNESIA CLUB By Michael Bracewell. 111 pp. New York: Serpent's Tail/Carcanet. Paper, $8.95.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transcription error, a quotation in a review of Gerald Clarke's biography ''Capote'' June 12 was incorrect. The passage, from Harper Lee's novel ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' describes a character whose ''hair was snow white and stuck to his head like duck fluff.''

title: Waquoit Outruns 4-5 Personal Flag
description: Waquoit, the pride of Boston, won the 100th running of the Brooklyn Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park, using the same front-running tactics that won him the 99th edition last year.

title:
The View From: Arrowwood Golf Course;
Fervent Devottion On the Greens
description: LEAD: THERE they were, a dozen grown men and women sitting around an L-shaped table at Arrowwood of Westchester taking notes, just like schoolchildren. Outside, the sun beat down brutally on the object of all their attention - a golf course. Inside, an air-conditioner hummed and a high priest of sorts - a golf pro - lectured in a style befitting a television evangelist.

title: New Look in Lobbies: Glitzy Eclectic
description: >GLITZ has overtaken tradition as the decor of choice in the lobbies of Manhattan's new higher-income residential buildings. Entrances are awash in the riches of the material world, with majestic works of art, modern statuary and glistening fountains set off by decorations faced with marble and detailed with gold leaf.

title: Article 249788 -- No Title
description: A proposed novel about Christopher Columbus's discovery of America, to be written within the next 18 months by Louise Erdrich and Michael Dorris, has been bought by Harper & Row for $1.5 million.

title: Susan Scott Stowell Plans to Marry Peter Romer Chapman Next Month
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel C. Stowell of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Scott Stowell to Peter Romer Chapman, a son of Mrs. William L. Chapman Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Chapman. The couple plan to marry Aug. 27.

title: POSTINGS: Yonkers Co-ops for $72,000; Hospital Reborn
description: To offer $72,000 co-ops from a total rehabilitation in Yonkers, Kurt Wittek said, it helps to start with an inexpensive shell. But to find bargains, you have to consider offbeat properties. Mr. Wittek bought Yonkers Professional Hospital for $1,175,000 in 1986 and is converting the 140-room institution at 27 Ludlow Street into 70 studios and one- and two-bedroom apartments priced at up to $225,000. Mr. Wittek said similarly priced co-ops were available in the city, but were the product of ''superficial rehabs,'' unlike his $6 million job. Rob Francour, the marketing director, added that with rehabs of old apartment buildings, ''you're going to be the 25th family to live in that apartment.''

title: Sealing Leaks in Walls
description: BASEMENT leaks are cured most effectively by making repairs on the exterior side of the foundation walls. Unfortunately, this is usually a major undertaking, not because of the patching procedure (which in most cases is simple), but because of excavation to expose the areas requiring treatment.

title: Shopper's World; The Glitter and Glow Of Polish Crystal
description: MANY first-time visitors to Warsaw limit their souvenir shopping to a bottle of vodka or a Polish ham. Others, with more time and money, may venture into one of the state-run, hard-currency shops such as Pewex (for liquor, tobacco and packaged foodstuffs) or Cepelia (for folk crafts and amber).

title: Guatemalan History
description: To the Editor:

title: Griffith Joyner Takes The 200
description: The United States Olympic track and field trials ended today as Florence Griffith Joyner turned in another outstanding performance and a few surprise athletes made the team along with a bunch of familiar faces.

title: SOME ARE WEAK, ALL ARE GREEDY
description: WOMEN IN A RIVER LANDSCAPE A Novel in Dialogues and Soliloquies. By Heinrich Boll. Translated by David McLintock. 208 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Study Finds Cost of $1 Billion For New York Welfare Raise
description: A cost-of-living study has concluded that welfare benefits would have to rise by 30 percent to meet the minimum needs of the 1.3 million welfare recipients in New York State, state officials and welfare advocates said.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: PRIVILEGED LIVES. By Edward Stewart. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The melding of fact and fiction gives this large, glitzy novel an auspicious start. In fact, the place names, familiar events and hints of real people in the luxurious surroundings in Manhattan give Edward Stewart's 10th book an immediacy that is, at least at first, irresistible.

title: Read All About Shakespeare!
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Tourists Are Taking Rice Home to Tokyo
description: LEAD: KIYOSHI MINAGAWA has an American dream. In it, the estimated two million Japanese tourists in the United States this year make a favorite-souvenir list that looks something like this:

title: Verbatim: A Schoolgirl's Life
description: 'We often listen to the radio as times are very exciting, having a frontier with Germany and being a small country we never feel safe.' Margot Frank Anne Frank's sister, in one of two letters the Jewish girls sent to two pen pals in Iowa in April 1940, the month before the German invasion of the Netherlands. The letters have just come to light.

title: FOCUS: Toronto; Growth Foreseen Into 1990's
description: WITH its reputation as a center of manufacturing and finance as well as its proximity to major United States cities, Toronto has emerged as one of Canada's economic bright spots. Last year there was record demand for office space, and as a trade agreeement with the United States nears approval, the business community is geared up for continued economic growth in the 1990's.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Of Medals, Notes and Books
description: LEAD: A new silver medal celebrates the millennium of Christianity in the Soviet Union. It was struck by the Leningrad Mint, according to Gene Czaplinsky, the California coin dealer who arranged for its issuance.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Businesswomen Celebrate
description: LEAD: When the Westchester Association of Women Business Owners was founded, the majority of its 32 members were ''homemakers, divorced women in cottage industries,'' according to Christine McCabe, a past president of the organization and owner of Future Benefit Consulting, which advises individuals and businesses on insurance planning.

title: Challengers in the Rutgers Tradition
description: RUTGERS-NEW BRUNSWICK is in the throes of its 1988 Summerfest, which means that at the university's arts center, on George Street at Route 18, there are concerts most days through the month of July and an occasional theatrical performance by students. Though music has the upper hand, the visual arts are not neglected, for in the Walters Hall Gallery is ''Art After Silence,'' a show organized by Francis Morelli of the university's Mason Gross School.

title: Suffolk's Program To Save Farmland
description: Laura Herbst [ ''Farmers Adapt to Keep Their Land,'' June 12 ] has shown quite clearly the things farmers have been up against on the East End of Long Island and how they are coping, but a very important factor was not emphasized. That is Suffolk County's program of buying the development rights of agricultural land.

title: Two Film Makers Tape Their Recent Past
description: THIS summer, while some youngsters work on their backstrokes and others on building sand castles, a dozen Connecticut youths are making a feature film called ''Fields of Their Youth.''

title: TALKING: Conversions; Rules for Switching Apartments
description: A MODIFIED form of musical chairs is being played more and more often in and around New York City whenever a rental building is converted to a co-op or condominium. The goal is for tenants to buy the apartments they want to own, rather than those they occupy.

title: ASTROCHICKEN AND ENERGY TREES
description: INFINITE IN ALL DIRECTIONS By Freeman J. Dyson. 321 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Collecting Your Wisdom in a System
description: ''YOU can drive yourself crazy reading through all these annual reports unless you learn a few tricks,'' one of my first bosses cautioned. ''The first thing I do is glance at the accountant's message at the back. If it's one or two paragraphs long, everything is on the up and up. If it goes to three paragraphs there may be some hanky-panky going on, so then you turn to the president's picture to see if he's smiling. Four grafs and you should block out a day or two to track down the story ahead of the indictment.''

title: Robert Wilson's Stunning Images: Do They Add Up?
description: Paradise is a portly angel, completely and vibrantly red, moving against the total whiteness of a celestial garden populated by white bears, herons and monkeys. This image, so striking that it is still being discussed by those who saw it in New York, was created by Robert Wilson and closed his recent and visionary staging of ''Le Martyre de Saint Sebastien.''

title: Founding Fathers Would Object
description: SINCE the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the United States Postal Service, with more than 800,000 employees and $33 billion in annual sales, has been the largest business enterprise in America. The framers of the Constitution realized that few freedoms are as fundamental to democracy as guaranteeing the universal exchange of information and ideas through the mail service. The Constitution gives Congress the power to establish post offices in the same section that it gives Congress the power to declare war, raise armies and coin money. But the Reagan Administration, through its budget cuts, has made it a priority of its last months in office to undermine the Postal Service to the detriment of the American public.

title: Karl Bays Makes Over IC Industries
description: FOR Karl D. Bays, figuring out what he wanted to do with his life was never much of a problem. There was really just one career that interested him. ''All I ever wanted to be was a manager,'' said Mr. Bays, a husky, cigar-smoking Kentuckian.

title: What Have We Got to Lose?
description: A ''PUBLIC be damned'' monopolist of the last century would scarcely have dared as much: to charge more for less. Yet that is exactly what the United States Postal Service did earlier this year when it followed up a major cut in service with a 13.6 percent increase in the price of a first-class stamp.

title: A Summer Dessert of Berries
description: DESSERTS are easy in the summer. As berries become cheaper they can be made into tarts and pies - and summer pudding, my favorite of all. This English dessert, made with raspberries, blackberries and red currants, is a beautiful ruby-red dome that tastes as wonderful as it looks. I rarely let a summer go by without making it.

title: Travel Advisory; Italy Acts To Reduce Air Congestion
description: In a move to ease summer congestion, the Italian Transport Ministry has opened five former military air spaces to commercial flights, allowing more air traffic from northern Europe. It has also limited the number of flights at Linate International Airport in Milan to 32 an hour, giving preference to commercial flights and moving charter and private flights to Malpensa Airport and Orio al Serio Bergamo Airport, both twice as far (more than an hour's drive) from the city center.

title: Let the Electoral College Die Like the Dinosaur; Tilt Toward Sunbelt
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA UPDATE: July 24, 1988
It's All Greek
description: What's distinctive about the following paragraph?

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. When we decided to close our house for the winter while we were away, we got conflicting advice. One school of thought recommended leaving the heat on at a low setting because otherwise the woodwork, furniture and even the latex paint could be damaged by cold and dampness inside the house. The other school of thought said that dmage, if any, would be negligible, and the worst would be offset by the savings in fuel bills. What do yo think we should do next winter?

title: Lynn M. Carroll Marries in Jersey
description: The marriage of Lynn Marie Carroll, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Carroll of Spring Lake, N.J., to John Chauncy Williams 3d, a son of Carroll G. Williams of Middleburg, Va., and Mr. Williams Jr. of Warrenton, Va., took place yesterday at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake. The Rev. Robert J. Patterson, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Anne Williamson Wed to a Lawyer
description: The Community Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Anne Campbell Williamson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Geiger Williamson of Short Hills, to Thomas Alan Holman, a son of Sandow Holman of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Vivian Barnett Holman. The Rev. Gregory Schmidt performed the ceremony.

title: 44 Hurt in Jersey Bus Crash; Driver Is Charged
description: Forty-four people were injured yesterday when a tour bus traveling to Atlantic City ran off the Garden State Parkway near Bass River, N.J., and struck some trees. The driver was arrested and charged with possession of drug paraphernalia and driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, the New Jersey state police said.

title: Mets Bow as Braves Pitcher Makes His Debut
description: At the end of each inning, John Smoltz would walk slowly back to the Atlanta dugout and, just before stepping down, steal a look into the box seats. There, without fail, he would spot the small knot of family and friends who had traveled halfway across the country to watch his debut in the major leagues.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: The Democrats and Grandbaby Lily
description: Michael Dukakis's speech accepting the Democratic nomination Thursday conveyed no strong organizing theme - yet the whole convention did and it was a startling theme indeed: children.

title: SUBDIVIDING THE SINGLE-FAMILY HOUSE
description: For many years, the symbol of suburban life has been that oasis of privacy and refuge from urban crowding, the single-family home. But in the New York City suburbs, more and more of these snug houses harbor more than one family, almost always illegally.

title: Question Of the Week; What Should Righetti's Role Be?
description: Color commentator. BOB HOFFMAN Larchmont, N.Y.

title: A CHASTENED AYATOLLAH CALLS OFF HIS HOLY WAR
description: By almost any standard, it was a remarkable statement. In the equivalent of a fireside chat except that it was read for him by a radio announcer, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in effect told the Iranian nation last week that it had lost the war with Iraq and must now turn its attention to salvaging what is left of the decade-old revolution he brought about.

title: Cuban Political Prisoners Slowly Come to U.S.
description: At 8:30 P.M. on May 5, a guard came to the cell of Pablo Prieto Castillo at the Combinado del Este jail outside Havana and took him to the administration compound where he was given new clothes and led outside to a small, windowless van.

title: Ellen J. Remsen Marries Banker
description: At St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., Ellen Jebb Remsen, a daughter of Mrs. Charles G. Miller Jr. Greenwich and Frederick D. Remsen of Mount Kisco, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Lorne Waxlax, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lorne R. Waxlax of Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Richard F. Van Wely performed the ceremony.

title: Horse Show to Be Olympic Test
description: LEAD: WITH its $190,000 in prize money, including the $50,000 Grand Prix, and a reputation for elegance, the Hampton Classic Horse Show is considered a leading event on the national horse show circuit.

title: Reviews/Dance; New Cast in 'La Ronde' By the Canadian Ballet
description: The National Ballet of Canada has come a long way since it first performed at the Metropolitan Opera House in 1973, serving mostly, it was said, as a backdrop for Rudolf Nureyev.

title: Lisa M. Nenner Plans A Bridal for November
description: Dr. and Mrs. Raphael P. Nenner of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter Lisa Marilyn Nenner to Dr. Arnold Goldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Goldman of New York. The wedding is planned for November.

title:
ART;
50 Years of Works by an Enigmatic Painter in Madison
description: LEAD: THE painter Ben Benn (1884-1983) is an enigma. If one thinks of an enigma as something shadowy or mysterious, they will wonder how the term applies to Benn, who is nothing if not relentless and iron-fisted.

title: The View From: The National Theater for the Deaf; Bringing Change, One Play at a Time
description: AS a young Chinese man sat on a sunny deck and described his plan to continue his father's effort to form a theater troupe of deaf performers in China, a dozen American actors - most of them deaf - climbed and swung over a section of metal scaffolding in a shady yard nearby, exercising before a rehearsal.

title: INSIDE

title: Faces in the Shadows: What Do They Mean?
description: The 1876 ''Portrait of Madame Charpentier and Her Children'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is one of Renoir's most familiar paintings. Its Japanese setting is the Parisian town house of Georges and Marguerite Charpentier, patrons of Renoir and influential supporters of the arts. Mme. Charpentier is sitting on a sofa, her feathery right arm soft and protective, her dark dress settling on the floor like a huge wing. Beside her on the sofa is her 3-year-old son, Paul, dressed as a girl, looking sweetly at his 6-year-old sister, Georgette, who is staring dreamily into space as she sits sidesaddle on their Newfoundland dog, a resigned but not altogether willing chariot. What appears to be a conventional portrait is very much like a fairy tale. The mood of fantasy and enchantment is reinforced by secondary images knitted into or rearing up within the fabric of the painting. One is in the curtain at the far right. It is a face suggesting a monstrous outsider grimacing at this scene of grand bourgeois bliss. Another is in the arm of the sofa to the immediate right of the woman. It is feline, and it seems to be resting on the lap of Mme. Charpentier and looking at her: indeed there is an amusing sense that this apparition may be the real subject of the dog's discontent. There are also intimations of nastier images - like skulls - in Mme. Charpentier's dress, which is a world unto itself. Renoir's painting has the gentleness and foreboding of a children's morality tale, and the secondary images help explain why.

title: That Old Sweet Song Lives On
description: Of all the pop styles that flourished in the 60's and early 70's, none seems quainter today than the romantic psychedelia tapped by the Beatles, Beach Boys, the Bee Gees, the Moody Blues and Donovan. Although the sticky, sugar-frosted sound that characterized songs like ''Strawberry Fields'' and ''Wouldn't It Be Nice'' eventually lost its cachet, pop fans still have a soft spot for the music's heady romanticism. Earlier this year, George Harrison's amiably nostalgic album, ''Cloud Nine,'' which cleverly resurrected late-60's utopian mush, sold more than a million copies.

title: Public Enemy: Rap With a Fist in the Air
description: In the last decade, rap has become as much a symbol as a musical style. For those who revel in it as well as for those who can't stand it, rap holds all the tensions of urban life - tensions between sexes, generations, races and classes. Its electronic crunch and sonic collages, its jolts and shouts, echo an urban streetscape that some city dwellers want to flaunt or exorcise, others to escape. Beyond an occasional novelty hit, rap is virtually ignored by radio stations because, the programmers maintain, rap alienates older listeners as it draws teen-agers; even stations that call themselves ''urban'' or ''black'' are likely to segregate rap in separate programs, away from the pop songs it often outsells. The teen-ager blasting a rap song from a boom box and the businessman who hears it as an assault on sanity might agree that rap can never be background music; whether it's brandished as virtuosic self-assertion or shunned as rude noise, it makes itself heard.

RIC FENTON Greenwich, Conn.

title: Gypsy Fusion Sounds

Though the Kings incorporate two percussionists, a bassist and a keyboardist and use rhythms from all over the world, their raw and driving music is immediately identifiable as the music made by Europe's own permanent underclass, the gypsies.

title: MEESE: IMPROPRIETY APPEARS BUT IT'S OPEN TO INTERPRETATION

McKay, concluded that Mr. Meese had probably violated some income tax and conflict-of-interest laws, he decided not to prosecute. ''It all came down really to the question: 'If this were an ordinary person, would he be prosecuted?' '' Mr. McKay said at a press conference. ''And we concluded that he probably would not be.''

Will the phone companies be allowed into cable? Gordon Crawford Senior vice president and cable specialist, Capital Research Company.

title: Yech! It's Jason, Dripping Soap

I was off to ''Friday the 13th, Part VII - The New Blood.'' I saw ''The Suicide Club,'' ''Slaughterhouse Rock,'' ''American Gothic'' and ''Maniac Cop.'' Stabbings and stranglings were so common to me that I only perked up for truly inventive murders - one by telekinesis, another by overgrown children using a jump rope. And each time I stepped out of another sleazy theater, I thought: It was just like a soap opera.

Until Jesse Jackson, playing the part of a spell-binding Baptist preacher, electrified the audience with a 50-minute monologue, only 32 percent of television sets were tuned in. Even the extras, playing delegates, were absent from the floor or dozing in their seats.

title: Headliners; Telling Secrets?
description: A United States Navy veteran who worked for naval intelligence and mysteriously disappeared over two years ago has surfaced in the Soviet Union, where he has been granted political asylum. Glenn Michael Souther, a former petty officer in his 30's, was under investigation for espionage by the Federal Bureau of Investigation when he disappeared from Old Dominion University in Norfolk, Va., in May 1986. Mr. Souther, who was honorably discharged from the Navy in 1982, had access to satellite photo data when he was stationed with the Sixth Fleet in Italy in the early 1980's. The Soviet newspaper Izvestia said that Mr. Souther wished to ''hide from U.S. secret services which unfoundedly persecuted him,'' and that the decision to grant asylum was ''guided by humane considerations.''

description: There was a disheartening incongruity between what was seen and what was heard at Friday evening's Mostly Mozart concert, at Avery Fisher Hall. In the opening work, Mozart's Symphony No.25 in G minor, Raymond Leppard's conducting gestures were full of detail: phrases and their components were drawn vividly in the air, and the signals for entries and cutoffs were crisp and unequivocal. Yet all this balletic energy was expended in the service of a reading so lethargic that the work's normally striking contours melted away. Things got livelier later, but it was a long evening.

He made clear that the era of unrestricted access to American markets was over, and acknowledged that the decade-long strategy for dealing with refugees is not working. Here are some other issues that came up along the way. Japan Although Mr. Shultz praised Japan for stimulating economic growth - thus raising demand for American and other foreign products - there is a realization that the United States and Japan may never have a balanced trade relationship. South Korea The United States is concerned about South Korea's fragile democracy and rising anti-Americanism. Mr. Shultz voiced qualified support for a series of recent proposals by President Roh Tae Woo for interim steps toward reunification with North Korea. China Mr. Shultz failed to win assurances that the Chinese would stop selling long-range ballistic missiles to the Middle East. But the U.S.-China relationship is delicate -each depends on the other as a counterweight to Soviet influence in Asia - and China's cooperation is needed on Cambodia, so Washington is not going to push. Cambodia The United States is encouraged by China's willingness to help reach a settlement that would lead to the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia. Hanoi officials and representatives of the four Cambodian factions plan to meet for the first time this week in Jakarta. Philippines The United States hopes that negotiations for an interim agreement for two American military bases can be concluded soon. At issue: the Filipinos want more money. There are no predictions as to the bases' fate after the contract expires in 1991.

title: NEW MODELS OFFER MORE FOR LESS
description: Partly it is the setting that gives the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago a distinctly festive air. Unique among American cities - and comparable to the famed waterside esplanades of Geneva and Montreux - Chicago has developed much of its lakefront as a vast park dotted with beaches, fountains and statuary. It is as if the city had decided to give itself a treat.

title: KEEPING THE LID ON By Ruth La Ferla
description: AN OLD-TIME COWBOY AND his hat seldom parted company.

title: LISBON STRUGGLES TO UNDO CHARTER
description: Ever since their revolution in 1974, the Portuguese have been trying to undo their complicated, leftist-oriented Constitution.

title:
GARDENING;
Controlling Pests Without Pesticides
description: LEAD: CONCERN has been building over the use of chemical pesticides in and around the garden, even those relatively safe materials available over the counter.

title: BREAKING ALL THE RULES
description: For some time now, a suspicion has been growing in the minds of many people that the architectural profession may be somewhat out of touch with social reality (''Breaking All the Rules,'' by Joseph Giovannini, June 12). Mr. Giovannini's account of the new deconstructivist movement stands as resounding proof that this is not the case. It speaks to the real needs of the age to at last have a design theory derived from abstract speculation.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Three Share Hartford Lead: Ronnie Black shot a 65 and Mark Calcavecchia had a 67 yesterday to tie Mark Brooks for a share of the lead after three rounds of the $700,000 Sammy Davis Jr.-Greater Hartford Open in Cromwell, Conn. Black, 30 years old, of Scottsdale, Ariz., made six birdie putts to pull into a tie with Calcavecchia and Brooks at 13-under-par 200. Brett Upper and Fulton Allem were two strokes off the pace and five other players were three strokes behind the leaders after 54 holes at the par-71, 6,786-yard Tournament Players Club of Connecticut course. Brooks, 27, from Fort Worth, shot a 65 on Friday to take the lead but didn't get off to a good start yesterday and finished with a 69. Allem shot a 67 and Upper had a 69 yesterday.(AP) Zembriski Charging: Walt Zembriski one-putted eight greens on the way to a seven-under-par 65 and the second-round lead at the Newport Cup Seniors Golf Tournament in Newport, R.I. Zembriski, 53, from Mahwah, N.J., is bidding for his first victory in four seasons on the PGA Senior Tour. He was at 12-under 132 after 36 holes, two shots better than the former Masters champion Charles Coody, who shot his second successive 67.(AP) Player in Front: Gary Player of South Africa held a one-stroke lead over Neil Coles of England after the third round of the British Seniors Open in Turnberry, Scotland. Coles, the defending champion, narrowed the gap with a third-round 69 for a five-under-par 204. Player shot a 72 for 203.(AP) Tennis Connors Gains Semifinal: Andres Gomez overcame a dismal start yesterday to move into the finals of the rain-plagued $232,050 D.C. Tennis Classic in Washington with a 1-6, 7-5, 6-3 victory over Derrick Rostagno. Gomez, seeded third, lost the final six games of the first set. But he held serve the rest of the way to end Rostagno's bid to enter the finals of a Grand Prix event for the first time in his professional career. Gomez will next face the winner of today's Jimmy Connors-Aaron Krickstein semifinal.

title:
ART;
Surrounded By Water
description: LEAD: SURROUNDED as it is by water, Long Island is the ideal venue for art exhibitions on aquatic themes. Coincidentally, two galleries are now presenting shows organized around that very subject: ''Waterworks,'' a show by 11 painters, sculptors and printmakers at the Smithtown Township Arts Council's gallery at Mills Pond House in St.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Briarcliff Manor
description: LEAD: WHEN Edward T. Dorsey was growing up in Yonkers during the 1950's, he had a dream of one day moving farther up the Hudson River, away from the big city to the tranquil Westchester village of Briarcliff Manor.

title: Foreign Policy Is the Last Refuge of a Lame-Duck Team
description: Foreign affairs presents a singular opportunity for a lame-duck Administration. The time has passed for new domestic initiatives, and White House nominees for judgeships are languishing on Capitol Hill, while the political world has shifted much of its focus to the campaign trail.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE ELIZABETH STORIES, by Isabel Huggan. (King Penguin, $6.95.) Elizabeth is forced to play the only male role in a ballet recital and discovers that her father really wanted her to be a boy. Last year, our reviewer, Ellen Currie, said that in these stories about a Canadian girl's troubled adolescence ''Isabel Huggan is superb at establishing that helpless awareness of capture and duress that is the character of our experience when we are young and have no power because we have no information. [ She ] re-creates for us that sense of outraged acquiescence, the astonished stoicism of the child, the disenfranchised, the mute.'' ANOTHER DAY OF LIFE, by Ryszard Kapuscinski. Translated by William R. Brand and Katarzyna Mroczkowska-Brand. (Penguin, $6.95.) During the mid-1970's the Polish journalist Ryszard Kapuscinski lived in Angola, trying to fathom the civil war that led to the country's still uneasy independence. Last year, William Boyd said here that he liked the book's idiosyncratic touches, such as the account of an open-air cinema, abandoned by its owner, where the pornographic film ''Emmanuelle'' plays over and over, its audience seemingly oblivious to the surrounding war. ''Throughout the book, in the decaying surreal city or the tense journeys through the bush, one senses just how fragile is our sense of order, our idea of a comprehensible world.'' WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Dell, $4.95.) An actress suspects that her Oscar-winning sister was killed by her rich fiance. Last year, our reviewer, Kiki Olson, called this novel ''the ideal book for the beach bag, picnic hamper or carry-on luggage.'' SPYCATCHER: The Candid Autobiography of a Senior Intelligence Officer, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Dell, $4.95.) Banned in Britain by the Official Secrets Act, the memoirs of Peter Wright, a former British intelligence agent, tell of his efforts to smoke out Soviet moles. Last year, Christopher Andrew said here that Paul Greengrass's writing helped make this ''revealing'' book readable but that he feared Mr. Wright was suffering from a bad case of ''conspiracy theory,'' seeing infiltrators where none exist. THE GIRLS: A Story of Village Life, by John Bowen. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) When Janet has a baby named Butch, her enraged lesbian lover accidentally kills the father. ''If it were not for its humor, ironic tone and eccentric characters, this well-crafted novel of murder and mystery could be mistaken for an example of feminist-separatist literature,'' Regina Weinreich said in The Book Review last year. GARDENING FOR LOVE: The Market Bulletins, by Elizabeth Lawrence. Edited by Allen Lacy. (Duke University, $9.95.) Elizabeth Lawrence, the celebrated garden writer, died in 1985, leaving behind the chaotic manuscript of what she once had intended as her masterwork. It was edited by Allen Lacy, a professor of philosophy who writes about gardening for The Times, and the result is ''an enchanting work, unlike any other gardening book in existence,'' our reviewer, Stanley Kunitz, said in 1987. A WARMER SEASON, by Joseph Olshan. (Ballantine, $3.95.) After befriending a blue-collar family of Italians, a middle-class Jewish boy learns that it is not always possible to transcend the walls that divide us. Last year, Albert Mobilio said here that the novel is ''well designed and engagingly told. . . . By placing the economic and ethnic tensions in high relief, 'A Warmer Season' becomes a novel about teen-agers of compelling interest to adults.'' WITH LOUIS AND THE DUKE: The Autobiography of a Jazz Clarinetist, by Barney Bigard. Edited by Barry Martyn. (Oxford University, $8.95.) In a series of conversations, the clarinetist Barney Bigard told Barry Martyn, a New Orleans jazz writer, about his years with the bands of Duke Ellington and Louis Armstrong. ''Mr. Bigard talks more of the genius of Mr. Ellington and Louis Armstrong, or the drinking habits of Ben Webster and Jack Teagarden, than he does of his own style,'' Don Palmer said here in 1986. ''He is jocular, critical, cantankerous and mildly irreverent.'' The same publisher has reissued A LIFE IN JAZZ ($9.95), an oral history in which the guitarist Danny Barker tells the critic and musician Alyn Shipton about New York and New Orleans jazz. Last year, one reviewer said this ''anecdotal and chatty'' book would be ''more appreciated by jazz fans than scholars.'' THE NEON RAIN, by James Lee Burke. (Pocket Books, $3.95.) While trying to solve a murder, a New Orleans police lieutenant and jazz buff is framed by the mob and becomes so dispirited that he reverts to alcoholism. James Lee Burke ''writes exceptionally clean, unforced prose that has a pronounced streak of poetry in it,'' Newgate Callendar said here in 1987. ''He obviously knows people and has experienced life.'' BERNSTEIN: A Biography, by Joan Peyser. (Ballantine, $5.95.) This psychobiography of the composer, conductor and pianist Leonard Bernstein is gossipy and disorganized, Leon Botstein said here last year. But he called it ''the first attempt at a critical account of Mr. Bernstein's life and work. . . . [ Joan ] Peyser has managed to convey the magnitude and range of Mr. Bernstein's talent and achievements.'' DEAD BABIES, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $8.95.) When Martin Amis's novel about a group of rich kids and their violent weekend party was reviewed in 1975, one critic called it ''a remarkable fantasy'' but said the book is ''not for the squeamish.'' The characters are described ''with a total ferocity which is nevertheless frequently comic.''

title:
THE NATION;
ON SOME PAROLES, EVERYBODY WANTS A VOTE
description: LEAD: One night in 1963, Gregory Ulas Powell was stopped for a minor traffic violation. He and an accomplice kidnapped two Los Angeles police officers and drove them to an onion field near Bakersfield, where Mr. Powell shot and killed one of the officers. Sentenced to death, Mr. Powell was spared the gas chamber when the United States Supreme Court held the death penalty unconstitutional.

title: A 'Tanless Society' by the Year 2000?
description: IN the wake of warnings that sun exposure damages skin, many beachgoers have suddenly turned sun-shy. A survey last year by the American Academy of Dermatology found that 96 percent of all adults could name at least one negative effect of the sun - and 54 percent singled out skin cancer, the most serious danger.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on May 29 with an article about Florence misstated some telephone numbers and a closing day. The numbers are, for Harry's Bar, 296700; the Sabatini restaurant, 282802 and the Excelsior Italia Hotel, 264201. Harry's Bar is closed Sunday.

title: Barbecue
description: To the Editor: The articles about the debate over barbecue (Travel, July 3) certainly hit home - in fact, two homes. My North Carolinian husband, after a dozen years in New Jersey, still refuses to call a cookout a barbecue. It is certainly true that we Jerseyans call the act of cooking any meat on a grill, with or without sauce, a barbecue.

title: Panel Finds Excesses In Drug and Alcohol Care
description: LEAD: A REPORT by a Cabinet advisory panel has found that an excessive number of health-insured drug and alcohol abusers who seek treatment in New Jersey are placed in overpriced, unnecessarily intrusive inpatient settings.

title: Another Salinger Heard From
description: LEAD: Over croissants and orange juice in his Manhattan studio apartment, Matt Salinger explains how it came to pass that his father, J.D. Salinger - whose book, ''The Catcher in the Rye,'' made him a cult literary hero of the 50's and 60's, but who has completely withdrawn from public life - could possibly have a son who has chosen to be an actor, a profession that subjects him to continuous public scrutiny.

FICTION

This collection of stories is the work of a German-born poet of Polish descent who, as a 4-year-old refugee, immigrated with his parents to Australia after the end of World War II.

title: Getting on the Track of Efficiency
description: COMMUTER rail fares on N. .J. Transit went up again in May, this time between 6 and 20 percent. In the public hearings dealing with its perennial budget gap, N.J. Transit argued yet again that all options necessarily included a major fare increase.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 5 about the Middle West misidentified the architect of the New Harmony Inn in New Harmony, Ind. It was Evans Woollen of Indianapolis.

description: WHEN James E. Carnicelli, a civil engineer, began a part-time business 16 years ago, he said he had his friends to thank for it.

description: On a warm July night in the rolling hills of western Connecticut, the sound of children splashing in a swimming pool and the smell of hamburgers and hot dogs roasting on the grill danced across Cheri Wilhelm's back yard.

title: Martyrs' Tales, Angels of Gold In Montreal
description: WERE Mark Twain to return to Montreal he would still find appropriate the oft-quoted observation he made on his first visit, that a person could stand on any street corner in Montreal, throw a stone and it would hit a church.

title: Battery Park City Looks Inward For Innovation
description: It is no secret among those who live at Battery Park City, the much-acclaimed complex of condominiums, office towers and commercial space in lower Manhattan, that the quality of the apartments themselves is less than stellar. Indeed, except for the spectacular views some of the units have, there is little to distinguish the interiors of most Battery Park City apartments from the insides of the ordinary, developer-built boxes of Second Avenue. Battery Park City has made a great architectural contribution to New York, but it is almost all in terms of urban design. It is the exteriors of these buildings, their arrangement on streets, and the extraordinary system of parks and riverfront esplanades far more than the apartments themselves that makes this a wonderful place to live.

description: ONLY TWO CAN PLAY Starring Peter Sellers (in photo), Mai Zetterling, Richard Attenborough, Kenneth Griffiths, Virginia Maskell. Directed by Sidney Gilliat. RCA Columbia Pictures Home Video. 1962. 100 minutes. $69.95.

title: Tapes Link Genovese Group To Murder of a Union Chief
description: New evidence from secretly recorded conversations has linked members of the Genovese organized crime family to the unsolved 1987 murder of Daniel F. Conlin, the head of the New York City school custodians union, according to court papers.

IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;

description: LEAD: THE Nynex Corporation, better known for phones than for floor space, plans to become a significant force in Westchester's commercial real estate market.

title: On Eve of Cambodia Talks, Indonesian Is Upbeat
description: Both China and the Soviet Union have given assurances that they are willing to help resolve the war in Cambodia, the Indonesian Foreign Minister said today.

title: TOUR de FRANCE; Dutch Rider Happy As 'Proper' Second
description: For a brief moment, it looked as if Steven Rooks would be the man in the yellow jersey, the overall leader of the Tour de France. But his lead was short-lived, and as a question of a fellow rider's drug use was resolved this week, it became clear that Rooks could finish no better than second when the three-week bicycle race ended in Paris Sunday. Ironically, he was thrilled. ''I can't say how happy I am,'' Rooks exclaimed after he heard that Pedro Delgado would not be penalized 10 minutes for testing positive for use of a drug that is banned by the International Olympic Committee, but not under current international cycling rules. ''It was wonderful news.''

title: Force Disbanded
description: In another move that could mark the end for the Major Indoor Soccer League, the league's most successful team, the Cleveland Force, has disbanded, the victim, according to its owners, of its own success. ''Maybe we grew too fast for the other kids in the class,'' said Scott Wolstein, the club's executive vice president and son of the principal owner, Bert L. Wolstein. ''It's unfortunate that when we got to the apex, there was nobody there.''(AP)

title: Here, Let Me Clean You Out . . .er, Off!
description: Pickpockets armed with squeeze bottles of mustard have been spraying foreign tourists at Kennedy International Airport for the last six weeks, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: Eating Fish From Troubled Waters
description: Ever since the discovery of medical waste on New York and New Jersey beaches and in New England, officials of state health and environmental conservation departments have been getting calls from anglers asking if fish caught in the region's waters are dangerous to eat. The answer is no, or, to be more precise, no more so than before the dumping took place.

title: Free Orchestral Concert In the Pops Tradition
description: Summertime living is easy, said the Gershwins, and sometimes it doesn't cost much either. Our Connecticut week is bracketed by free orchestral concerts, and a number of other free programs beckon as well.

title: And Then the Grass Grows Some More
description: ''NO, I won't be needing the gardener this year,'' I declared in December, full of resolve. I pushed up the sleeves of my sweater and anticipated the coming of summer. Snow covered the ground outside my window as I wrote a note explaining my change of plans to the landscape gardener.

title: Cool is for Democrats
description: All political parties, even in one-party states, have conventions, and the main purpose is the same. It is to gather and energize the faithful, give them the message and send them out to mobilize the masses.

description: No wonder mainstream Americans shrug off warnings about the nation's decline, if even sages can't tell. Daniel Patrick Moynihan and James R. Schlesinger assure us all is well - as if economic and military might were all that counts.

Can the geography of one area of the world influence attitudes toward people in another area? And how might the accumulation of wealth in one region determine underdevelopment in another?
