title: Big Glick Plan in East 60's Set for Review
description: A $500 million mixed-use project proposed by the Glick Organization for the Upper East Side has passed its first regulatory hurdle and is scheduled for a public hearing in September.

title: Smaller Than Ruth or Dempsey
description: To the Editor:

title: Christine Walter Wed To Joseph McGrath Jr.
description: Christine J. Walter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolf Walter of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Joseph P. McGrath Jr., a son of Kathleen McGrath of Summit, N.J., and the late Mr. McGrath. Msgr. John Breheny performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church.

title: Lake Runs Low, and People Wonder Why
description: FROM Sue Gleason's view from the docks at Smitty's Marina here in Woodport on a recent sultry afternoon, Lake Hopatcong, New Jersey's largest lake, resembled a silent and ominous mural. Ms. Gleason, a Woodport native and co-manager of Smitty's Marina Restaurant, said that as a result of the lake's low water level - two feet below normal - many boat owners had hauled their boats to shore.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: IT'S ANYBODY'S BALLGAME. By Joe Garagiola. (Contemporary, $17.95.) Haven't we heard all this before? Surely Joe Garagiola has told these tales on more NBC telecasts than most of us would care to admit having watched over the years - his days growing up with Yogi and the guys in St. Louis, his exploits as a mediocre ballplayer with the champion Cardinals of 1946 and the pathetic Pirates of 1952, his stories about the funniest darned things that happen on the banquet circuit.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: SEOUL
description: The residents of Seoul don't just walk the streets. They attack them, barreling along with elbows and chins out, almost defying anyone to get in the way. There is nothing hostile in this. Restraint is simply not a conspicuous element in the city's character.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE HOLLYWOOD STUDIOS: House Style in the Golden Age of the Movies. By Ethan Mordden. (Knopf, $24.95.) You switch on the television at 1 A.M. and while you don't know the name of the classic Hollywood film that's on, it looks familiar. If the movie has snappy editing and rat-a-tat-tat dialogue, you can bet it's from Warners.

title: THE WORLD: A Voice from South Africa; 'COLOREDS': CAUGHT BETWEEN BLACK AND WHITE
description: In the small Eastern Cape town of Grahamstown, Constable David Patrick Goosen of the South African police was sentenced in May to death for the murder of a black teen-ager, whom he killed while on duty in July 1986. A month or so earlier on Durban's Golden Mile, the country's most popular beach strip, a university dropout named Robert McBride had planted a bomb that killed three young women.

title: Cuts by Eastern Shaking Miami In Many Ways
description: When Phil Bakes, the president of Eastern Airlines, announced plans Friday to lay off 4,000 employees and eliminate or sharply cut service in several Western cities, he said the carrier was going back ''to our roots'' on the East Coast.

title: Ashley King Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Ashley Windisch King to Preston Lane Goddard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanhope S. Goddard Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., has been made known by her parents, Mrs. Howard E. C. Hall of Greenwich and Charles H. King Jr. of Wilton, Conn. The couple plan to marry Sept. 10.

title: Italy to Take Back Waste
description: Two Italian ships will be sent to retrieve several tons of unspecified toxic waste left in Koko, a Nigerian port that has been the site of a controversy over the dumping of toxic waste in West Africa, Civil Defense Minister Vito Lattanzio said Friday. The announcement was expected to ease tensions between Italy and Nigeria and lead to the release of the Italian freighter Piave, which was seized by Nigeria pending a resolution of the waste issue. Nigeria said hundreds of drums of toxic waste have been illegally shipped from Italy to Koko. The Italian company that shipped the waste said the delivery was authorized.

title: Pay for Jury Duty To Rise in 5 Areas
description: LEAD: JURORS in five judicial districts in the state will be paid more under a new system of compensation beginning in September.

title: With Friends
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article reminded me of a technique I've used with groups even as small as two. Each of the possible companions prepares for the others two short lists: Things I Can't Do Without and Things I Can't Stand. If one party refuses to miss the glories of sunrise and another can't bear to get up before 10, best to know it early on.

title: Hunts Propose a $663 Million Bankruptcy Settlement for Placid Oil
description: The Hunt brothers of Texas have proposed a formula that calls for their Placid Oil Company to repay $663.5 million in cash to a group of 17 banks in an effort to bring their company out of bankruptcy.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Explosive Past Of Beach Revealed

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Santa Fe, N.M.;
Old Technique In New Homes
description: LEAD: DEVELOPERS here are keeping pace with a recent demand for authentic adobe housing that comes despite a near standstill of commercial building and the city's less than 1 percent population growth. Although this Southwestern cultural center of 50,000 has been suffering from an overbuilt market, new subdivision sales of the $200,000 to $1 million adobe homes are booming.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Clean Dads Are Best Amid all the high jinks and inspired gossip of Truman Capote's life, there are some quiet moments in which you see how real he also was. Here's a scene in Taormina, Italy, with Capote's companion Jack Dunphy and Pearl Kazin, who was visiting them. It's in ''Capote'' by Gerald Clarke (Simon & Schuster).

title: The Odyssey of a Young Playwright
description: ONE day in a Baton Rouge, La., high school, David Biele had to contend with a common assignment in freshman-composition classes: putting his thoughts, whatever they were, freely on paper.

title: Perry Is Dieting
description: It will come as no surprise to those who have followed his career, but according to one medical specialist, William Perry suffers from an eating disorder.

title: Question Of the Week; What Should Righetti's Role Be?
description: Righetti's role should be that of a starter. He is still a young man.

title: A Love Affair With Life and Baseball
description: WHERE do the memories go? I try to tidy up, but how do you prune away the past?

title: STREETSCAPES: Bronx Borough Courthouse; For an Abandoned Civic Landmark, a Second Life?
description: IT is now not much more than a huge pigeon coop - abandoned and windowless. But the grandeur of the Bronx Borough Courthouse still comes as a surprise as a motorist rounds the bend of Third Avenue heading toward 161st Street in the Melrose section.

title: POSTINGS: At 78th and Lexington; An Eye-Catcher
description: Nikos S. Kafelidis plans to make an impression with his corner of Manhattan. ''We want people to see and say, 'That is the 78th and Lexington corner,''' Mr. Kafelidis said after returning from a vacation in Greece to supervise the final stages of work at 1117-23 Lexington Avenue and 146 East 78th Street. Along with John Linehan, Mr. Kafelidis is restoring the four-story tenements, in which the upper three floors have been empty and sealed up for over 20 years.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: NEW JERSEY officials who bought a lake for $3.1 million were chagrined to learn later that the lake's dam was in danger of collapsing and that it would cost $15 million to repair it. On top of that, the 800-acre site -Union Lake, near Millville, 13 miles above Delaware Bay - was contaminated with arsenic from a chemical company upstream.

title: Rusison Choral Festival For Sarah Lawrence
description: OF the dozen or more concerts I attended during an International Music Festival in Leningrad last May, the most remarkable by far was a choral program with Vladimir Minin conducting the Moscow Chamber Choir. The nuances and color shadings the conductor coaxed from his singers were nothing short of astonishing, and I was delighted to learn that he would soon be visiting the United States.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Officials Seek Timeout From Litigation and Abuse
description: LEAD: Officials in today's economy-conscious sports environment face complex new problems. Be it at the professional, college, high school or youth league level, the men and women of the striped-shirt profession now have concerns that take them beyond their traditional roles as enforcers and interpreters of sports rules.

title: Iraq's Forces Push Into Iranian Territory
description: Iran said Iraqi troops backed by tanks, warplanes and chemical weapons pushed nearly 40 miles across the border today, and it called on all able-bodied fighters to rush to the front.

title: GARDENING MEANS WAR
description: Michael Pollan's article ''Gardening Means War'' (June 19) was a direct hit. I sat reading it, and laughed until I nearly cried, while, outside, a mother woodchuck was training her three youngsters in guerrilla tactics in my garden. We have put the garden in a new spot this year. Last year, after we jammed boulders into the gaping holes surrounding our vegetable patch, the resident woodchuck set up new underground quarters - with its main entrance in the middle of the snap beans.

title: Democrats Seeking Amicable Primary
description: THE unity that Democrats sought last week in their National Convention in Atlanta is being pursued locally in the primary contest being waged by three Democrats for the seat held by United States Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi.

title: Puzzle on Maine Island: Treasurer's Disappearance
description: When Dan Blaszczuk moved to Frenchboro eight years ago, he fit in easily among its residents, a close-knit group of about 50 people, most of whom have spent all their lives on the small island 10 miles at sea.

title: Marye E. Buckley Weds J.P. Moran
description: The marriage of Marye Esther Buckley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick O. Buckley of Marblehead Neck, Mass., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to John Patrick Moran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Moran of Massapequa Park, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., took place yesterday in Marblehead, Mass. Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Newark performed the ceremony at Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
Fond Memories of Eleanor Roosevelt
description: LEAD: ''You are invited to come in costume with a mask. Prizes will be awarded for the three costumes judged best by a committee. Those winning prizes will be called upon to perform upon a stage in any way they wish. Singly or in a group of their own choosing.''

title: Reviews/Music; Reshuffle In Romberg 'New Moon'
description: Watching the New York City Opera's handsome production of Sigmund Romberg's ''New Moon'' on Wednesday, it was easy to see how the 1928 operetta came to enjoy two film incarnations within 12 years of its premiere. Set in New Orleans around the time of the French Revolution, it has everything M-G-M's moguls wanted in a musical: a lightly baked plot, generous doses of romance and idealism (offset by both swashbuckling and comedy) and a frothy, lyrical score packed with hit tunes (''Stouthearted Men,'' ''Lover, Come Back to Me'' and ''One Kiss'' among them).

title: AIDS Count: Is the Quest for Precision on the Right Track?
description: A series of seemingly contradictory forecasts and drastically revised estimates of the AIDS crisis in New York City has bewildered and upset even some experts. All sides agree that AIDS will continue to inflict a rising toll of suffering and death for at least the next several years, but there is less agreement as to the potential extent of the problem - and a continuing dispute over the methodology that should be used in estimating it.

title: Reviews/Dance; Leads Change in 'Onegin'
description: The National Ballet of Canada gave a polished account of John Cranko's ''Onegin'' on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. The dancing was smooth and clear, and the performance revealed that this is a very carefully trained company. But it also revealed how great an artistic distance there can be between studio and stage, for despite their technical competence, several leading dancers failed to be dramatically convincing.

title: Demand For Hotels Lures More Developers
description: LEAD: ACROSS Long Island a small army of local and national developers stand at the ready, poised to add to the Island's stock of hotel rooms. They face a Byzantine maze of restrictive town and county codes, sophisticated campaigns of community opposition and, typically, years of delays while awaiting approval, but they appear willing to stay the course.

title: Who Is the Enemy in Mexico Drug War?
description: Most of the people of the vast desert state of Sonora have always regarded the Mexican Government's war against the drug trade as something that has little to do with them and their daily lives. But not any more, not after what happened here just after dawn one spring morning.

title: Fittipaldi Wins Pole Spot
description: Emerson Fittipaldi, a 41-year-old Brazilian driver, captured the pole position today in qualifying trials at the Meadowlands and will start in the No. 1 position Sunday in the $700,000 Marlboro Grand Prix auto race.

title:
GARDENING;
Controlling Pests Without Pesticides
description: LEAD: CONCERN has been building over the use of chemical pesticides in and around the garden, even those relatively safe materials available over the counter.

title: Disposal Limited by Closings
description: LEAD: WHEN a West Haven landfill was closed on May 31, the only automobile shredding operation in the state was left with no place to dispose of the residue of junk cars. Because the company, Michael Schiavone & Sons of West Haven, could no longer dump the residue, known as fluff, it suspended operations.

title: Poignant, Daft 'Miss Firecracker'
description: FOR the first play of its first full-scale summer season, which includes concerts and variety shows, the McCarter Theater has come up with an uneven production of a real winner: ''The Miss Firecracker Contest'' by Beth Henley, the playwright from Jackson, Miss., whose best work transforms eccentricity into extraordinariness, and punctuates oddball comedy with bursts of all-embracing compassion.

title: Linda Susan Burns Marries N. J. Colmenares, Engineer
description: Linda Susan Burns, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold I. Burns of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married last night to Narses Jose Colmenares, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jose Colmenares Azuaje of Caracas, Venezuela. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel in New York.

title: 'THIS ALMOST CHOSEN PEOPLE'
description: GOD LAND Reflections on Religion and Nationalism. By Conor Cruise O'Brien. 97 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $15.95.

title: D'Orsay Displays Design's Elite
description: Decorative arts of the early Industrial Age - rich in stylistic contrasts, abundant in technological innovation and stunning in materials - fill dozens of galleries and two towers of the Musee d'Orsay. The 1,200 works displayed, produced between 1848 and 1914 and assembled over the last decade, represent one of the most comprehensive international surveys of design of the period.

title: Sharpton Says Brawley Will Return in 2 Weeks
description: As law-enforcement officials continued to assert that Glenda Brawley would be arrested when she returned to New York State, her advisers said yesterday that Mrs. Brawley was ''somewhere south of Canada'' and would come back within two weeks in a ''challenge'' to the authorities.

title:
INVESTING;
Oil Stock Choices After a Cease-Fire
description: LEAD: THE possibility that the eight-year war between Iran and Iraq is ending has left oil-industry analysts and investors scrambling to reassess their positions. The proposed cease-fire has sparked a spirited debate over the direction of oil prices and oil stocks.

title: Pascale Sauleman To Wed a Lawyer
description: Dr. Pascale Sauleman and Joel R. Reidenberg plan to marry in September, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. David Sauleman of Vincennes, France, have announced. Mr. Reidenberg is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Marcus Reidenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Cori Daggett Marries
description: Cori Elizabeth Daggett, a second-year law student at Fordham University, and Christopher Hadley Stephens, an associate at the Manhattan law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan, were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Albany by the Rev. Richard Cockrell. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clark B. Daggett of Albany. The bridegroom is a son of Thomas J. Stephens of Armonk, N.Y., and Joan Stephens of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Simpler Views From Islands Off Wisconsin
description: BAYFIELD PENINSULA is a forest-covered finger of Wisconsin that juts into the awesome, chilly drink of Lake Superior. Its easterly shore helps to shelter and embrace Chequamegon Bay, and clustered around the tip of this digit are the lovely, low-lying Apostle Islands. There are 22 of them, of odd shapes and varying sizes, and they lie hunkering about the peninsula like the bushy pates of a submerged race of giants.

title: Donald Verrilli Jr. and Gail W. Laster, Washington Lawyers, to Wed Aug. 27
description: Gail Winnifer Laster and Donald Beaton Verrilli Jr., lawyers and 1979 graduates of Yale University, are planning to be married Aug. 27.

title: Laura Siegel to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Tess Siegel of Teaneck, N.J., of the engagement of her daughter, Laura Jane Siegel, to Stephen David Stern, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Stern, also of Teaneck. Ms. Siegel, who is also the daughter of the late Seymour Kelly Siegel, is an associate at the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell. Her fiance is the manager of business operations for Grolier Book Clubs in New York.

title: 'Last Temptation' Dwells on Humanity of Jesus
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Justice's Remarks About His Colleagues
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun discussed each of his eight colleagues in a July 15 speech at a conference of Federal judges and lawyers in St. Louis. Following are excerpts based on a tape recording: On William H. Rehnquist

title: 'Happy Ending' Is Seen For Hostages in Beirut
description: The spiritual leader of pro-Iranian Moslem Shiite fundamentalists here said today that the time has come for a ''happy ending'' to the plight of foreign hostages in Lebanon.

title: Major Robinson, Journalist, 70
description: Major Robinson, a journalist and public relations figure who helped originate Jet magazine, the Johnson Publishing Company's pocket-sized weekly, died Tuesday at Veterans Hospital in Manhattan. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Article 509988 -- No Title
description: Vice President Bush sought to reach out today to women by proposing a tax refund of at least $1,000 to help parents with child care needs.

title: Members of Coalition Win 58% in Thai Vote
description: Parties that formed Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda's coalition Government won 58 percent of the votes in Sunday's parliamentary elections, paving the way for General Prem's return to power, official results showed today.

title: What They Meant by Judicial Restraing; Judge-Made Law
description: To the Editor:

title: The Latest Tennis Racquet
description: Tennis racquet design has become an engineering quest that pits technology against last year's models. The latest design is Prince's Constant Taper System (CTS), due on the market by September. There are two models: the CTS Approach, a 100 percent graphite racquet with maximum firmness, and the CTS Graduate, a graphite composite that is less stiff.

title: Havana Cocktail Party Upsets U.S.-Cuba Ties
description: About a week ago, the small United States diplomatic mission here invited about 20 Cuban human rights advocates and a few foreign diplomats to a cocktail party at the apartment of one of the Americans.

title: U.S. Women's Open; Neumann Hangs On to Win
description: Like a runner who stumbles and falls only to pick herself up and win the race, Liselotte Neumann of Sweden bounced back from a potentially disasterous four-putt double bogey today to win the 43d United States Women's Open championship with a record score of 277.

title: Washington Stood Here. Here's Why
description: Federal Hall National Memorial, the Greek Revival temple that marks the site of the nation's first Capitol, is to emerge from lower Manhattan's shadows in the coming year and become home to a Museum of American Constitutional Government.

title: New Jets Look to New Season
description: In a collegiate rah-rah atmosphere so different from the one surrounding the group that played out the final games of last season, the new Jets assembled today for the first time.

title: Former Apollo Officer Joins Honeywell Bull
description: Roland D. Pampel, who resigned a week ago as president and chief operating officer of Apollo Computer Inc., has been named president of Honeywell Bull Inc.

title: Jesuits Try New Kind of Recruiting
description: JUST what is it that Jim Pierce, Bill O'Malley, Dean Brackley and Henry Schwalbenberg have in common? Three are bearded. One is black. But all are Jesuits - three priests and a brother - and they all star in a sophisticated print advertising campaign intended to attract other men to their ranks.

title: Status of East River Not Easily Changed
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks on Illinois Bank Sale
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is holding talks with various parties concerning a sale of its 67.5 percent stake in the Continental Illinois Corporation.

title: Mystery of Fouled Beaches: Clues, but No 'Smoking Gun'
description: It began, unnoticed, on the crystalline morning of Sunday, July 3: Sometime around 10:30, the wind imperceptibly turned, blowing in from the southwest, targeting the beaches of Long Island.

title: Runway Accident in India
description: An Air France Boeing 747 jet carrying 275 people swerved off a runway at New Delhi's airport and crashed into a field today after the pilot aborted takeoff because he thought an engine was on fire, airport officials said. No one was seriously injured in the accident, the Airport Authority said. Indian news agencies said several passengers on the flight, which had been bound for Paris, were treated for minor cuts and bruises after evacuating the plane through emergency chutes.

title: Increase in Sugar Quota Will Benefit 39 Nations
description: A 40 percent increase in the United States' sugar quota will benefit the Dominican Republic, the Philippines, Brazil and 36 other countries and is bringing praise from large United States sugar users.

title: Helen Link Wed To Daniel Egger
description: Helen Burleigh Link, a daughter of Dr. Deborah S. Link of New Canaan, Conn., and Gordon L. Link of New York, was married at her mother's home yesterday to Louis Daniel Egger, a son of Dr. M. David Egger of Princeton, N.J., and the late Ellen Maytag Egger. Judge Paul D. Shapero of the Probate Court in Stamford, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: Top Studios Support 'Christ' Film
description: Hollywood's major studios are backing Universal Pictures in its battle with evangelical Protestants who want to ban Martin Scorsese's new movie, ''The Last Temptation of Christ.''

title: Still No Answers to Giants' Questions
description: Bill Parcells may remember this as one of the more forgettable training camps in his six seasons as the Giants' head coach. Downpours, illnesses and holdouts dashed the Giants' hopes for a quick start.

title: Bringing Madison Ave. to Pennsylvania Ave.
description: In two short years, the New York advertising agency Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey has built a business promoting vacuum cleaners, shopping malls, ice cream and magazines. Now, defying an unwritten precept that ad agencies can afford neither the time nor the risk of alienating clients by working in politics, three of the agency's principals are making commercials for Vice President Bush.

title: New Mission At Riverside Is Money
description: Riverside Church, an institution born of wealth whose programs to fight poverty and injustice are models for churches around the nation, is desperately trying to cut costs and raise money to avert what its interim senior minister calls financial ''disaster.''

title: N.A.S.D. Attacks Plans To Halt Volatile Trading
description: A new report by a committee of the National Association of Securities Dealers strongly criticizes proposals to halt trading in volatile markets. The report comes when a consensus is growing among major exchanges and market experts that such a plan should be adopted.

title: Hmong Refugees Find Adjustment to U.S. Painful
description: Under the tutelage of her American cousins, 8-year-old Kia Lor is learning about soap operas, baseball, hair styles and even this odd custom, she confided, of painting one's fingernails.

title: Broker Gets 3 Months
description: A former E. F. Hutton broker was sentenced Friday to three months in prison and fined $3,000 for his part in a money-laundering scheme at the firm's Providence office. Brian J. Lareau, 46 years old, could have been sentenced to six years in prison and fined $6,000, but under a plea bargain prosecutors had recommended no more than six months in prison.

title: Tour de France; Delgado Wins Amid Cheers, Criticism
description: Finishing a Tour de France shaken by a dispute over his drug use, Pedro Delgado cruised across the finish line in Paris victorious this afternoon.

title: Market Place; The Price Boom In Collector Cars
description: A FEW years ago, a 1959 Cadillac Eldorado convertible with low mileage and in good condition could be bought for under $10,000. Earlier this year, one brought $67,000 at an auction and dealers in collector cars say $100,000 is in sight.

title: The Fat Cats Are Back
description: Ceaseless fund-raising events at the Democratic Convention produced a slew of $100,000 checks for the Dukakis campaign. The process and the money make clear that fat-cat donors, limited after Watergate by Federal restrictions and new laws on public financing, are once again a major factor.

title: TV Notes
description: Mystery on Channel 13

title: 5 Chemical Bank Offices Add Full-Service Broker
description: Chemical Bank customers at five branches found their banker and a full-service broker under one roof last week. It was the latest step in the trend toward one-stop shopping for financial services and in the banking industry's drive to compete head-on.

title: New-Directors Series Planning Double Bills
description: ''New Directors/Newer Films,'' a two-week series of film screenings, many featuring works that have had their premieres at the New Directors/New Films series at Lincoln Center, is to begin Aug. 12 at 6:15 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Each program is to feature an early film by a particular director, followed by a later work. More than 45 films, made from 1972 to 1987, are to be shown.

title: Health Journal Expands Its H.M.O. Circulation
description: To prove that a magazine person is a magazine person, at home with a print publication on any subject, Terrence Driscoll and Kevin M. Barry, who were publisher and associate publisher of Horticulture magazine when it was owned by The New Yorker, are today president and publisher of Health Journal, a national quarterly magazine for members of health maintenance organizations.

title: Courageous New Policies in Seoul
description: South Korea's new President, Roh Tae Woo, has wisely and boldly scrapped the substance and liturgy of South Korea's longstanding policy of totally shunning the Communist North. Earlier this month, he called for massive exchange of visits between the Koreas and for open trade frontiers, as within a single nation. Already, he has drawn an interesting response from North Korea.

title: One- and Two-Year Treasuries This Week
description: Treasury offerings this week include a two-year note sale and a one-year bill auction in addition to the regular sale of three-month and six-month bills.

title: For Burma Now, It's All Speculation
description: U Ne Win's decision to step down after 26 years as Burma's leader and his call for a referendum on the country's one-party system has produced political uncertainty in a nation that traditionally favors harmony and stability, experts said yesterday.

title: Vichy Journal; Fading of a Spa: Incurable? Or Will a Face Lift Do?
description: Despite the gallons and gallons of mineral water consumed, the daily showers in warm spring water, and the occasional mud bath or two, the Queen is showing her age. The Queen of Spas, that is.

title: Review/Television; Julie Christie in German Mini-Series
description: We have been treated recently to a rash of stories about how Julie Christie is making a television movie. The implication is that television should be grateful for snaring a film star of such established magnitude. Perhaps, but don't hold your breath. As it happens, Miss Christie can be seen on Showtime, the pay-cable service, in a German mini-series made in 1986 for television. Furthermore, her co-star is Burt Lancaster. Alas, ''Sins of the Fathers,'' running on for four excruciating hours, only proves that film stars do not necessarily translate into good television. The first half can be seen on Showtime tonight at 10; the rest tomorrow at 10.

title: F.T.C. Favors Mark IV Plan
description: The Federal Trade Commission approved the application of Mark IV Industries to acquire up to 15 percent of the common stock of the Armtek Corporation, Armtek announced yesterday. On July 4, Mark IV, based in

title: Lacroix Mutes His Palette, but Not His Exuberant Spirits
description: Christian Lacroix, who propelled poufs and brief skirts into the mainstream of fashion with his first couture collection a year ago, proved today that there are more strings to his lyre. He got the week of fall and winter couture shows off to a strong start with clothes that are cheerful, amusing and amazingly diversified. They were presented in three back-to-back showings at the Hotel Intercontinental, each before an audience of around 400 people.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf

title: Cards Open Camp As Arizona Cheers
description: UNLIKE most communities in the desert states of the Sun Belt, the summmer is kind to the economy of this mountain city. Interstate 40 slices through the southern tip of the main business district, bringing tourists in search of one of the Seven Wonders of the World.

title: A Couple Share a Life on the Road
description: Richard D. Hueltje sat at a small truck stop here just after 6 A.M., dividing his attention between his hearty breakfast of toast, eggs and home fries and the log book that he is required to keep by the United States Department of Transportation.

title: Mansion of Spielberg Badly Damaged in Fire
description: Steven Spielberg's multimillion-dollar home was damaged today in a fire that spread to another oceanfront estate, the authorities said.

title: Rising Repairs Are Straining Ambulances
description: As an investigation continued yesterday into the death of a Brooklyn man who waited nearly an hour for an Emergency Medical Service ambulance to arrive, the New York City agency's executive director said the percentage of ambulances out of service for repairs in recent weeks has been ''absolutely too high.''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 24, 1988: MONDAY Archer-Daniels-Midland Howell Corp Armstrong World Indus Johnson & Johnson Arvin Industries Kennametal Inc Atlantic Richfield Kentucky Utilities Bank New England Lubrizol Corp Consolidated Freight NWA Inc Crane Co Newmont Mining Corp Detroit Edison Phila Elec Co Georgia Pacific Rohm & Haas Co TUESDAY HF Ahmanson & Co Kaufman & Broad Inc Amax Gold Inc Loral Corp Amoco McDonald & Co Invstmts Ball Corp Norwest Corp Bausch & Lomb Owens & Minor Bay State Gas Polaroid Corp Becton, Dickinson Primerica Corp Black Hills Corp Public Serv New Mex Boise Cascade Rockaway Corp Borden Inc Rollins Inc Brush Wellman Santa Fe So Pacific Cilcorp Inc Southwestern Public Serv Conn Natural Gas Tribune Co Enserch Corp USX Corp Fedders Corp Union Camp Corp Glenfed Inc Warner-Lambert Great Western Financial WICOR Inc Kansas G&E Zemex Corp WEDNESDAY AMP Inc McGraw-Hill American Elec Power McKesson Corp Anheuser-Busch NCNB Corp AH Belo Corp Natl Medical Enterprises Chevron Panhandle Eastern Corp Coast Savings & Loan Philips Indus Donaldson Co Pilgrims Pride Downey Savings & Loan Shaw Indus Du Pont SmithKline Beckman Energen Corp Squibb Corp Hercules Inc TW Services Inc Houghton Mifflin Union Carbide Inland Steel Indus West Point-Pepperell Lukens Inc THURSDAY Acme-Cleveland Lawter Intl American Gen Corp Legg Mason Inc Amer Home Products Mead Corp Anadarko Pete NCH Corp Avemco Corp Norton Co Avery Intl Olin Corp Crs Sirrine Inc Potlatch Corp Delta Air Lines Potomac Elec Power Dynamics Corp America Quaker State Eastern Gas & Fuel Quantum Chemical Emhart Corp RLC Corp Empire Elec Rollins Environmental Ethyl Corp Sonat Inc Gerbers Union Pacific Corp Golden West Financial UST Inc Iowa-Ill G&E Veeco Instruments FRIDAY Beverly Properties Mobil Dean Foods Oakite Products Dennison Mfg Phelps Dodge Corp Equifax Inc OH Progressive Corp Florida Steel Sizeler Property McDonnell Douglas Twin Disc

title: Swimming Down Hudson River
description: SKIP STORCH renewed an intriguing relationship 14 months ago. It began accidentally in college, broke off without reason for a decade, and resumed after Storch turned 30.

title: Sports World Specials; And It Never Balks
description: Anyone who has ever watched a group of 8- , 9- and 10-year-olds try to play organized baseball has a good idea of the meaning of eternity. Even with the shortened distance of 45 feet 6 inches from the pitching mound to home, few 10-year-olds are able to get the ball over the plate with any consistency. And when a young pitcher does manage to get one over, the young batter who, likely as not, has been ducking wild pitches all afternoon, is generally too surprised and too paralyzed with fear to do anything about it. The result is games that go on and on and on.

title: Brett Singman Is Married To Bo-Goron Borg on L.I.
description: The marriage of Brett Singman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry S. Singman of New York and Miller Place, L.I., to Bo-Goron Borg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nils Borg of Laholm, Sweden, took place last night at the Fox Hill Country Club in Baiting Hollow, L.I. Rabbi Richard Rosenberg and the Rev. James Genzel, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title: Greenhouse Effect Culprit May Be Family Car
description: To the Editor:

title: 2,875 Pages and Growing: A Publisher's Dilemma
description: Its plot is one-dimensional, none of its characters are fully developed, and the 5-pound, 11-ounce book seems big enough to crush any careless reader who cuddles up with it. Nevertheless, ''The Baseball Encyclopedia,'' published by Macmillan, has been a major success story. More than 360,000 copies of the $45 book, first published in 1969 and updated every few years, have been sold.

title: Pillsbury Expected to Name New Chief Executive Soon
description: With takeover prospects dimming, the Pillsbury Company's choice of a new chief executive has become the crucial factor affecting the stock price of the $6.2 billion food and restaurant concern.

title: The Editorial Notebook; When Lightning Strikes
description: Where is the safest place to be in an electrical storm? One must be the Empire State Building. It has been struck as many as eight times in a single storm yet no one inside gets hurt.

title: Bernstein in Moscow
description: Leonard Bernstein is to conduct three concerts in Moscow this week, tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday. He will lead the Schleswig-Holstein Music Festival Orchestra, which is made up of 119 young musicians from 18 countries. The concerts are to be televised in the Soviet Union in observance of Mr. Bernstein's 70th birthday, which is Aug. 25.

title: IRAQIS PULL BACK FROM IRAN AS WAR AGAIN QUIETS DOWN
description: Iraqi troops started pulling back today from Iranian territory that they had occupied, according to information from both warring Persian Gulf neighbors, as the fierce fighting that flared between them last week appeared to subside.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; For Dining 'Comet,' a Sky's-the-Limit Plan
description: Joseph H. Baum thinks the serpent in the Garden of Eden may have been the first restaurant consultant. ''He was suggesting a menu,'' Mr. Baum pointed out.

title: OLD FRIENDS, NEW SONGS AND DRAMA
description: Few younger pop singers have devoted themselves more assiduously to discovering worthy new material by contemporary songwriters than Marti Jones, a vocalist from Cleveland who has yet to achieve the commercial success that her talents merit. Ms. Jones recently released her third album, ''Used Guitars,'' which includes songs by more than half a dozen talented writers of varied stylistic hue. And at the Bottom Line on Monday, more than half a dozen composers and lyricists whose songs Ms. Jones has recorded joined her in a concert that focused as much attention on the writers as on Ms. Jones herself.

title: The Nixon Cover-Up Goes On
description: Fourteen years after he resigned in disgrace from the Presidency, Richard Nixon has emerged as a senior statesman and American oracle on important foreign policy issues. While the American disease of historical amnesia figures prominently in this remarkable rehabilitation, we should not slight Richard Nixon's own resourcefulness. For nearly a decade and a half, the former President has orchestrated a brilliant campaign of time-consuming lawsuits and hard-nosed political lobbying to delay the release of important historical records from his Administration. In short, the cover-up goes on. Just over a month ago, for example, I checked into the ''Nixon Presidential Papers Project,'' outside Washington, to continue my work on a biography of the former Alabama Governor, George Wallace. I had scarcely unpacked my word processor in the spartan, warehouse-like facilities before a veteran researcher sidled over to my desk, glanced around and quietly offered me some advice.

title: Atlanta's Message: A Brawl in the Fall
description: Governor Dukakis talked a lot about ''unity'' and ''issues'' at the Democratic convention, but this campaign promises to be about as intellectual as a prize fight. Dukakis praised President Reagan's nuclear reduction policy, but was not so gentle on Vice President Bush. And Dukakis clearly is going to make a personal issue between his own shirtsleeves background and the silver foot in George's mouth.

title: Minnesota Man Charged in Killing Of Second Honeywell Co-Worker
description: A man who was rehired by Honeywell Inc. after serving four years in prison for strangling a co-worker has been charged with killing another co-worker, a woman he allegedly stalked and threatened for weeks, the police said.

title: Auto Racing; Unser Jr. Outdrives Fittipaldi
description: Al Unser Jr. cut Emerson Fittipaldi off at the pass today and went on to win the Marlboro Grand Prix at the Meadowlands.

title: For British Tories, a Private Feud Goes Public
description: One of the most intense personal and political feuds in Britain in the 1980's turned into a public uproar this weekend after former Prime Minister Edward Heath attacked his successor as Conservative Party leader, Margaret Thatcher.

title: Curbs on Tuition for Doctors Raising Fear for Care of Poor
description: In medically needy inner cities and rural areas around the country, people like Delina Barrera are worried.

title: Sports of the Times; Number 41 Is Home
description: TOM SEAVER was late and Jay Horwitz, the Mets' director of media galvanization, was concerned on this gray Sunday morning. He peered out the door of the Diamond Club on the ground level of Shea Stadium with a troubled arch to his pensive brow.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We certainly have an affliction.'' - Dave Johnson, manager of the Mets, after second straight loss to last-place Braves. [ C3:5. ]

title: Shoreham Chickens, Home to Roost
description: Do Long Islanders oppose the opening of the completed Shoreham nuclear plant because they think it is dangerous or because they don't want to pay for it?

title: A Triumphant Showing for ESPN
description: Advertiser-supported cable services are coming into their own. Nowhere is that clearer than at ESPN Inc., the sports service that is 80 percent owned by Capital Cities/ABC Inc. and 20 percent owned by RJR Nabisco Inc.

title: Greenhouse Effect Culprit May Be Family Car; New Ice Age by 1995?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fitness; Retirees Make Exercise Video for People Over 50
description: TWO retired women from the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn recently were discussing the exercise video they had produced. ''I think we made the video because we were retired and wanted something to do,'' said Belle Joseph, who is 72 and proud of it. ''We were feeling guilty about not doing anything.''

title: Steel Industry Woos Makers of Cans
description: The steel industry is battling to win a bigger piece of the beverage can market it once dominated. Steel makers say that higher aluminum prices and better technology have made their product competitive again.

title: BIG HOLLYWOOD SALARIES A MAGNET FOR THE STARS (AND THE PUBLIC)
description: When 20th Century-Fox gave Bruce Willis $5 million to star in ''Die Hard,'' the studio was gambling that, in return, the actor would entice customers into 1,258 theaters when the movie opened on July 15.

title: GOLF AND TENNIS PACKAGES TAKE TO THE HILLS
description: ALL-INCLUSIVE package plans at ski resorts have been around a long time. Even nonskiers usually know of ski weeks or weekend vacations that include lodging, meals, skiing and ski instruction. It's only logical that this kind of package plan would sooner or later be available for summer activities at ski resorts. This time of year, the focus is on tennis and golf instruction programs, but at least one resort - Mount Snow in Vermont - has started a mountain biking package as well.

title: Newborn Boy Is Found Tied In a Plastic Bag in Brooklyn
description: A newborn boy was found yesterday tied inside a plastic bag in the lobby of a Brooklyn apartment house.

title: Blackmun Provides a Peek at the People Under Those Robes
description: The members of the Supreme Court were assembled in conference one day not long ago, in the inner sanctum where they cast their votes on the claims of Presidents and paupers alike. Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall had the floor.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, a bank holding company, elected as a director Frederick P. Stratton Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Milwaukee-based Briggs & Stratton Corp., a producer of air-cooled gas engines for outdoor power equipment.

title: Clothes Make the Man
description: Interagency rivalry took on a sartorial note last week during the dedication of a portrait of William H. Webster commemorating his tenure as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Outdoors: Clamming
description: IF you relish seafood and have had a series of boring days uselessly flogging ocean or bay for striped bass or bluefish, try clamming. Clams stay put. Once you have located them, they are yours, and the same is true of mussels.

title: National League; Rookie Shuts Down Pirates
description: Steve Sax had three hits and drove in both of the Dodgers' runs, and the rookie Shawn Hillegas limited Pittsburgh to one run over six innings as the Dodgers beat the Pirates, 2-1.

title: J. T. Hompe Wed To Ms. Hodgson
description: At St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church in Port Washington, L.I., Amanda Elissa Hodgson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. S. Hodgson of Port Washington, was married yesterday to John Thomas Hompe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Harold Hompe of Stanley, Wis. The Rev. Joseph C. Coschignano performed the ceremony.

title: Tool Orders Jumped 17.8% Last Month
description: New orders for American-made machine tools jumped 17.8 percent in June from the previous month, a report to be released today by the industry's trade association says.

title: Karen Weiner Married To Douglas Allen Rich
description: The marriage of Karen Audrey Weiner, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Joel Weiner of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Douglas Allen Rich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rich of Wilton, Conn., took place yesterday at the Inn at Longshore in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Stephen Parker, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated.

title: New World Unhappily Seeks A Buyer for Marvel Comics
description: Comic-book readers know Marvel for its gripping tales of Spiderman, Captain America and other heroes. Now, the Marvel Entertainment Group itself is the star of a saga.

title: Fighting Label, Dukakis Offers Traditional Message
description: It was Sunday morning and Michael S. Dukakis was occupied in the same way as much of middle America. He was in church, with his wife, listening to a sermon about loving one's neighbor and God.

title: Drexel Sees Shift by S.E.C.
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. told its employees Friday that it could no longer be certain that it would receive 24 hours' notice before the Securities and Exchange Commission brought charges against it.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many members of the Pittsburgh Pirates, the team challenging the Mets for the National League Eastern Division lead, were acquired in trades?

title: Cuomo Shares Optimism of His Area's Democrats
description: ''Dukakis is good for the country,'' Governor Cuomo proclaimed yesterday on national television. ''Competence for a change.''

title: Knight-Ridder Profit Rises
description: Knight-Ridder Inc.'s net earnings rose 4.4 percent, to $44.9 million in the second quarter, from $43 million a year earlier, despite weakness in newspaper advertising, the big media company reported Friday. The company's pretax profit, however, declined to $74.8 million from $78.9 million. Revenues rose 3.3 percent to $544.6 million from $526.9 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Writers and Producers Meet for 13 Hours
description: A meeting of nearly 13 hours between Producers and striking scriptwriters ended early this morning with a news blackout the only announced agreement, but another meeting was planned.

title: Ambush in Bangladesh
description: Buddhist rebels shot and killed five Moslem settlers and wounded three others in an ambush Saturday on a ferry in southern Bangladesh, the police said today. The rebels opposed a Government program resettling Moslems from the plains to hilly land. They attacked a boat ferrying 50 settlers near the hill town of Rangamati, about 120 miles southeast of Dhaka, a police officer said.

title: Issue for SSC Holdings
description: The SSC Holdings Corporation is issuing $500 million of debt in three tranches through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The first tranche of 13 percent senior subordinated extendible notes is priced at par and due in 1998. Due in 2000 will be $125 million of 12 1/2 percent notes and $175 million of 13 1/4 percent notes. The rates will be reset in 1990, and annually after that. Rated CCC+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation and B-2 by Moody's Investor Service, the notes are callable on any reset date. The gross spread of the issue is $35, with a selling concession of $2.50 and a reallowance of $1.25.

title: Pay Offers to College Graduates Rise
description: This year's college graduates received higher salary offers than last year's graduates, especially in business fields, but the number of offers declined slightly, according to a survey made public today.

title: U.S. Team A Blend Of New And Old
description: Many of them are experienced and familiar. The United States Olympic track and field team is in good hands with reliables like Carl Lewis and Edwin Moses, Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Evelyn Ashford, Willie Banks and Henry Marsh, Valerie Brisco and Francie Larrieu Smith, Steve Scott and Sydney Maree.

title: Horse Racing; Bone-Chip Surgery Is Set for Lost Code
description: Lost Code, the leading handicap horse in the East, will undergo surgery Monday to remove a bone chip from his left knee and will be sidelined for at least two months, his trainer, Bill Donovan, said today.

title: Shoreham: A Deal Faulted Because It's 'Too Good'
description: Late last month, as the approval process for Governor Cuomo's agreement with the Long Island Lighting Company to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant began to gather momentum, Wall Street reviewed the settlement and declared it highly favorable to Lilco.

title: 2 Arabs Dead in Holiday Clashes With Israeli Troops in West Bank
description: Two Palestinians were killed in clashes with soldiers in the occupied West Bank today as widespread violence marred the first day of the Moslem holiday Eid al-Adha and the Jewish holiday of Tisha b'Ab.

title: In Much of Canarsie, That Sinking Feeling Is All Too Real
description: Parts of southeast Brooklyn are sinking. They have been for years, and now, even as the city begins to repair the damage, the neighborhoods continue to sink.

title: Soviet Foray Into Capitalism Begins to Show a Seamy Side
description: Where does a Soviet mobster launder his drug money?

title: Account
description: * Showtime/The Movie Channel to Kirshenbaum & Bond for its Viewer's Choice, a pay-per-view service.

title: Former Judge Petitions Court to Practice Law
description: Two years after the House of Representatives voted to remove him from the bench, an impeached Federal district judge who served 17 months in prison for tax evasion sought Friday to resume practicing law in Federal court.

title: Fashion Channel Filing
description: The Fashion Channel Network Inc., which sells clothes through cable television, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company said Friday that it had ''severe liquidity problems'' but supplied no financial data. The Fashion Channel said it intended to keep distributing the program through its present cable systems. According to information from the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau Inc., the Fashion Channel is carried on cable systems that have 7.7 million subscribers.

title: Schools Are Preparing Children for Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * In Germany, the Economics Ministry's state secretary, Otto Schlecht, said the European Community must insure that different withholding tax rates within the community are harmonized before 1992 to stop capital flight and to help create a unified financial market. Bonn's tax reform, passed in July, will impose a 10 percent withholding tax beginning next year. Ministers have called for banks to refrain from encouraging capital flight to countries where no withholding taxes exist, such as Luxembourg.

title: Yvonne S. Burgess Weds
description: Yvonne Scott Burgess and Barrington Neville Wright were married yesterday at Alder Manor at Elizabeth Seton College in Yonkers. Justice Daniel W. Joy of State Supreme Court officiated. He was assisted by the bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. George Wilson of the Seventh Day Adventist Church.

title: Longo Captures 2d Tour
description: Jeannie Longo of France won her second consecutive women's Tour de France today.

title: Susan Schwartz, a Producer, Is Married
description: Susan Louis Schwartz and Andrew Schuyler Lynn were married yesterday in Mystic, Conn., at the Inn at Mystic. Judge Angelo Santaniello of the Connecticut Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Midas Touch a Hallmark Of Buyer of Texas Banks
description: LEAD: Under its previous owners, the Minnesota Twins baseball team had never won a World Series - not one in 26 years of existence. But it took Carl R. Pohlad only two seasons. After buying the team in 1984, the Twins overcame 150-to-1 odds to give Mr. Pohlad the championship last year.

title: After 3 Months, Davis Trial Will Hear First Arguments
description: After three tortuous months of jury selection, the longest in the memory of Bronx court officials, opening arguments will begin tomorrow in the latest trial of Larry Davis in the Bronx County Courthouse.

title: 4-Party Angola Talks Held in Secret Session
description: Angola, South Africa, Cuba and the United States held secret talks last week in Cape Verde on ending the war in Angola, Cape Verdian Government officials said today.

title: Martha Patterson Wed To Laurence I. Barrett
description: At the Women's National Democratic Club in Washington, Martha Priddy Patterson was married yesterday to Laurence I. Barrett. Judge Abner Mikva of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit officiated.

title: Wistful Koch Offers to Stump for Dukakis
description: A reflective, even melancholy Mayor Koch expressed some wistfulness today that Michael S. Dukakis had failed to select him as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention and expressed hope that Dukakis forces in New York would seek to use him in the Presidential campaign.

title: Contra Hopes for Peace Talks in August
description: The senior contra guerrilla leader says he hopes a new round of negotiation with the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua can be held next month.

title: Sports World Specials; The Sporting Life
description: Michel Dion knew he had two strikes on him, so to speak, when Gary Carter joined the West Palm Beach Expos of the Florida State League in June 1972. Dion was the backup catcher with the Class AA team, and as soon as he saw Carter in action, he realized he did not have any future with the Montreal Expos.

title: Trucking's New Labor Problem
description: Larry A. Myers's aim as the director of recruiting for the Jones Motor Group is to find enough new truck drivers to support the company's ambitious growth plans. But his real problem is simply keeping up with the turnover in Jones's current pool of 350 drivers.

title: 'Cosby' Reruns Give Stations An Intimidating Weapon
description: IN the last four years, one program, ''The Cosby Show,'' has essentially rearranged the network television business. The show brought NBC from last to first, its enormous popularity cannily exploited to build an empire of hits and to ruin the strategies of the opposition. Producers lucky enough to have shows proximate to ''Cosby'' on the NBC schedule are now Hollywood moguls. As programming weapons go, ''Cosby'' is the hydrogen bomb.

title: Bridge
description: For 60 years, since the dawn of contract bridge, the most difficult events to win in New York City have been the knockout team championships, scheduled two or three times a year at regional tournaments. The best performance ever on such an occasion by an all-woman team was achieved on July 17. Kathie Wei, Judi Radin, Karen McCallum and Kitty Bethe, all of Manhattan; Carol Simon, of Summit, N.J., and Susan Green, of Alexandria, Va., won their semifinal match with some help from the diagramed deal.

title: Japan Workers' Sacrifice
description: Workers at seven semiconductor plants owned by Japan's largest electrical machinery manufacturer will give up summer vacations because of a worldwide shortage of computer chips, a news report said Saturday. The Kyodo News Service, quoting unidentified industry sources, said workers at seven Hitachi Ltd. semiconductor plants had agreed Friday to a management proposal that they skip their vacations, usually lasting about a week in mid-August. No details were given on the agreement. Officials were not available for comment because of the weekend holiday. Kyodo said two other large Japanese chip makers, Fujitsu Ltd. and the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, were negotiating with their unions over a similar cancellation of summer holidays.

title: Tribute to Norway
description: The Washington Square Music Festival will offer a salute to Norway in its free chamber-orchestra concert tomorrow at 8 P.M. The concertmaster of the Royal Norwegian Opera Orchestra, Ole Bohn, will be the soloist for Niels Wilhelm Gade's Violin Concerto in D minor, under the direction of Henry Schuman. The orchestra will also play Beethoven's Symphony No. 1. Some 500 chairs will be available near the Garibaldi statue in Washington Square Park, on a first-come, first-served basis; blankets and beach chairs are permitted. In case of rain, the concert will take place at Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: Copper Price Forecast
description: Higher world copper output next year is likely to end a run of price increases that began about a year ago, Shearson Lehman Hutton predicted Friday in its quarterly report. Shearson said copper prices, which earlier hit spot highs of $1.50 a pound, had not regained these levels. Shearson said the current year's surplus would be 65,000 metric tons, against a previous estimate of 130,000 metric tons.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Orders for machine tools rose 17.8 percent in June. The amount of total orders, $382.5 million, was up 88.6 percent from a year earlier. Experts said the increase reflected strong capital spending as businesses gained confidence in the economy. [ Page D1. ] Trucking companies are struggling to recruit drivers. Experts attribute the high turnover to discontent with wages and working conditions, long hours and stricter enforcement of traffic laws. The shortage may eventually raise shipping prices. [ D1. ] An N.A.S.D. committee has criticized ''circuit breaker'' plans endorsed by the directors of the Big Board and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. [ D6. ] More than half of the states made tax changes this year, with 13 states raising taxes and 14 lowering them. [ D5. ] Steel makers want a bigger share of the beverage can market. They say higher aluminum prices and better technology have made their product competitive again. [ D4. ] COMPANIES Pillsbury may have chosen a new chief executive at a special board meeting on Friday, with an announcement coming as early as this week. Several of the candidates said to be under consideration have not inspired enthusiasm on Wall Street, where Pillsbury's stock has fallen 25 percent since March. title: Oil Pipeline Ruptures
description: River currents have ruptured the main petroleum pipeline in eastern Colombia, spilling thousands of barrels of oil and halting operations at a pumping station, the state-owned oil company Ecopetrol said today. An Ecopetrol spokesman said the Cobaria River, swollen by heavy rains, broke off a section of the pipeline Saturday near the pumping station in Arauca province, about 210 miles northeast from Bogota. The spokesman said he did not know when pumping would resume.

title: Sports People; Twin Wrestlers
description: Two of the 10 freestyle wrestlers who will represent the United States in the Olympic Games at Seoul, South Korea, began competing at age 9 on the living room floor of their parents' home in Mobridge, S.D. Jim and Bill Scherr, identical twins, eventually moved their ragtag grappling on the rug to more orderly matches downstairs in the basement where their father served as referee and their grandfather as timer. The twins went on to became national collegiate champions at the University of Nebraska in 1984, Jim at 177 pounds and Bill at 190. The Scherrs, who will celebrate their 27th birthdays tomorrow, were alternate selections to the United States team in 1984. After winning their national collegiate titles as seniors, they watched from the sidelines as the American men won 7 of 10 freestyle events and 2 more in the 10-division Greco-Roman competition. ''It was disappointing that we didn't get chances to compete, but we wanted Olympic gold medals so much that we decided to stick with wrestling for four more years,'' Bill said yesterday at an informal gathering with the news media in Manhattan. ''Olympic medals are something we've been working toward for six or seven years. It's been a long grind, but we're ready, emotionally and mentally.'' Jim, who will wrestle at 198 pounds, is an assistant coach at Northwestern University. Bill, an assistant at Indiana University under Jim Humphrey, the head coach of the Olympic freestyle wrestlers, will compete at 220 pounds. Bill won the world championship at 198 pounds in 1985, but moved up to the heavier weight class to open the way for Jim to land an Olymic berth.(AP)

title: Fashion Isn't All Diapers, You Know
description: IT'S a hard life, being toted around in Mom's or Dad's arms, trying to look cool and stylish among the fashionable crowd at a charity event. Still, someone has to do it. Take the young guests seen recently at an auction in Bellport Village, L.I., that benefited AIDS research. With bonnets and bows at the ready, these youngsters proved that the diaper set could stay dapper in the heat for a good cause. The outfit of choice - a T-shirt, plain or emblazoned with designs. Some young ones came in their Sunday best - butterfly white dresses, playsuits or short-pants overalls. But these clothes were meant to be lived in, not just looked at, as befits children born to working mothers who bring them to the office. No babes in the woods, these. Some 700 grown-ups paid $50 to gather at the Jonathan and Deanna Annis estate and bid for fashion items, including a shirt of Mick Jagger's, boots belonging to Eddie Murphy and a guitar donated by Sting, along with photographs and a 1930 portrait of Greta Garbo. The auction raised $160,000.

title: Poland Debt Postponed
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to postpone for 10 years the repayment of $1.5 billion in hard-currency debts owed by Poland, a Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said today. The announcement follows an agreement reached on July 20 under which Western banks also rescheduled the repayment of $9 billion in debt. Moscow had also offered Poland new credits worth 400 million rubles, or about $640 million, to balance payments and agreed on terms to sell the country Soviet crude oil, gas, iron ore and other raw materials for five years, he said.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Lendl and Agassi Advance: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl and second-seeded Andre Agassi both advanced yesterday to the second round of the Volvo International tennis tournament at Stratton Mountain, Vt. Lendl defeated Christian Saceanu, 6-4, 6-4, and Agassi, the top-ranked American men's player, struggled past Paul Wekesa of Kenya, 6-4, 3-6, 6-3. Agassi was ahead by 5-2 in the third set when rain suspended play for one hour. The 18-year-old, ranked fifth in the world, won the match two games later when Wekesa hit a ball long. Lendl, the world's No. 1-ranked player, applied his strong forehand to down Saceanu, a hard-hitting Rumanian playing out of West Germany. Saceanu is ranked No. 70 in the world. Playing his solid, methodical game, Lendl broke Saceanu midway through the first set and early in the second to win the match. In another match yesterday, unseeded Malivai Washington of Swartz Creek, Mich., downed 11th-seeded Christo van Rensburg, 6-2, 7-5.(AP) Yachting Chicago Boats Big Winners: Two vessels from the Columbia Yacht Club in Chicago emerged as the big winners yesterday in the 81st annual Chicago-to-Mackinac Island, Mich., yacht race. The 35-foot Aces Wild, owned by Jack Levy, was ranked first over all in the 292-vessel fleet, according to Don Clements of Data General, which handled the statistics for the 333-mile race, which began last Saturday. Aces Wild finished with a corrected time of 32 hours 57 minutes 56 seconds. Finishing first over all in the International Offshore Rules category was the 35-foot Jeannine, with a corrected time of 39:48:24. Like last year, first across the finish line was Pied Piper of the Bayview Yacht Club in Detroit, but with a much smaller handicap than other boats, its official time was 46:28:11.(AP) Golf Davis Leads Senior Qualifiers: Joe Davis, an amateur from the Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., qualified for the United States Golf Association Senior Open championship by shooting a 33, 38-71 yesterday in the sectional qualifying at the St. Andrews Golf Club, Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Five other golfers from the field of 113 advanced to the finals Aug. 4-7 in Metinah, Ill.: Paul Moran of Scotch Plains, N.J., and Curtis Thatcher of Westchester, Pa., who had 75's; and Ron Nicol of the Scarsdale Golf Club, Don McDougall of Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Southampton, L.I., and Dick Hendrickson of West Chester, Pa., all with 76's. N.B.A. Knicks, 117, 76ers 106: Eddie Lee Wilkins scored 31 points and grabbed 10 rebounds to lead the Knicks past the Philadelphia 76ers in a rookie game last night at Princeton, N.J. Wilkins, a veteran who is trying to win a spot on the Knicks, played in the Continental Basketball Association last season while working his way into shape after knee surgery. Delray Brooks of Providence scored 16 for New York and Bill Jones of Iowa and the veteran Ken Bannister scored 13 each.(AP)

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Tony Casillas of Atlanta, a nose tackle and the second player taken in the 1986 draft, left the Falcons' training complex yesterday after Coach Marion Campbell gave him a few days off to ponder his future. Casillas suffered a stress fracture of the left fibula Nov. 29 that put him out for the 1987 season. He has also suffered thumb, hand, toe and knee injuries during his career. . . . The Indianapolis Colts signed Dean Biasucci, a Pro Bowl place-kicker, to a new contract yesterday and released six other players, including the veteran wide receivers Billy (White Shoes) Johnson and Charlie Brown. . . . Mike Jones, a wide receiver, signed a two-year contract with the New Orleans Saints. . . . Coach Joe Gibbs of the Washington Redskins, fearful that a decision on the status of Dexter Manley would not come for several days, has moved Markus Koch back from linebacker into the starting defensive end slot. Manley, a starter at right defensive end since 1981, has been excused from attending training camp pending a ruling by Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League. Manley met with Rozelle last Friday to discuss the veteran's failure to comply with guidelines regarding his behavior, as established by the league.(AP)

title: The Multiple Epiphanies of a New-Age Composer
description: ''We have an immense musical vocabulary available to us,'' the electric guitarist and composer Rhys Chatham said. ''Since the turn of the century, we've been looking for different directions. Arnold Schoenberg suggested one. John Cage suggested another. We've seen that anything from random noise to a conversation can be regarded as a piece of music. The question is no longer 'Can we do it?' It's 'Now that we can do anything we want, what do we want to do?' This is the post-modernist dilemma.'' The 35-year-old Mr. Chatham began his composing career as a Serialist and has also written electronic and chance works. But the style that brought him to prominence a decade ago involves Minimalist compositional techniques and rock instrumentation - electric guitars, bass and drums. More recently, he began writing drum and trumpet works; and in his latest piece, ''Minerva,'' he has blended elements of both styles in a score for seven guitars, bass, drums and two trumpets.

It's not a matter of thinking while looking (in summer, that's beyond the call of duty on television), but those who take the trouble to ponder may find their own perspectives on things being challenged.

But in his Tuesday evening concert, which included the Fifth and Sixth Symphonies, Mr. Zinman delivered on his promise of interpretive novelty, and he did so in a way that focused on the music's details without losing sight of its broader sweep.

title: Yukon Dust Revives Gold Dreams
description: Nearly a century after the Yukon gold rush, the family of Len and Rona Millar spends 10 hours every summer day down on Gold Bottom Creek, participating in the biggest gold-mining revival here since World War I. From a wooden home that is all that remains of a thriving gold rush town 20 miles east of Dawson, the Millars run what has become a typical Yukon mining operation. Working with two sons and a daughter, they use a bulldozer, a backhoe and a pump to sluice gold from the creek that was first mined during the gold rush of 1897-98. Their operation is one of about 200 scattered along the creeks of the Yukon, two-thirds of them within 50 miles of Dawson.

title: Review/Art; Views of Jewishness In Museum Video Show
description: This summer, the Jewish Museum has made its debut in the domain of video art. ''Time and Memory: Video Art and Identity'' is the general title of the show. Visitors to the museum will hear and see live canaries as a counterpoint to antiphonal readings from the diaries of Anne Frank and the confessions of a Chilean torturer. Schubert's early masterpiece ''The Erl King'' is sung and played fortissimo on tape while visitors are given the chance to summon at will a wide range of related images on the screen. This visitor had to miss Bart Friedman's ''Harold's Bar Mitzvah'' (1977), which has been giving great pleasure. (I also missed part of Beryl Korot's ''Dachau 1974'' (1975), which I had seen more than once when it first came out.) But Fred Riedel, the guest curator in charge of the show, rings any number of changes during its somewhat erratic course, and some of them have much to teach us.

title: Cartoonish Couples Are Cuddling Up On Movie Screens
description: KEVIN COSTNER and Susan Sarandon, John Cleese and Jamie Lee Curtis, Bob Hoskins and Roger Rabbit - all over movie screens real people are meeting cartoons, falling in love with them or tugging on their ears. When Roger plants a grateful kiss on Eddie Valiant, the grumpy detective who reluctantly befriends him, it is only the most conspicuous instance of a two-dimensional figure co-starring with a human. It took years of work, hundreds of people, and up-to-the minute technology to create so convincing a blend of live action and animated art in ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' But in many of this summer's most intriguing films, from the witty romance of ''Bull Durham'' to the comic-adventure ''Midnight Run,'' real-life actors and actresses have simply taken on cartoon roles. Sometimes they have filled in their characters' outlines with enormous charm; sometimes their awful pretensions to humanity have smashed them as flat as Wile E. Coyote, never to bounce back.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on June 29 about a Soviet newspaper's publication of a plea for legal vindication of Trotsky briefly described Trotsky's politics. The article said Trotsky opposed Lenin's New Economic Policy. As some scholars have written to point out, Trotsky did not oppose the policy when it was introduced in 1921, but in later years he differed sharply with other Soviet leaders over its management. Scholars differ over whether he should be portrayed as an opponent.

Review/Film; Identity Crisis: My Monkey, My Self
description: George A. Romero's ''Monkey Shines: An Experiment in Fear'' has more coincidences than a Sidney Sheldon mini-series, more cliches than a Jackie Collins potboiler, and one thing they don't have - Ella, the killer monkey. A cute little organ-grinder's monkey, Ella dusts furniture, does windows, and has been injected with an experimental serum made from freeze-dried human brain cells. Trained to help the handicapped, she belongs to a quadriplegic named Allan - he was, of course, a star athlete until he was hit by that truck - and when Ella is not helping Allan with his law-school homework, they are trading telepathic messages. Either the man or the monkey is very angry, as Allan's former girlfriend, careless nurse and nagging mother eventually learn the hard way.

description: Few would dispute that fast reliable ambulances are among the most essential of New York City's essential services. title: Reviews/Music; Lively Music of Cambodia

The New York Open Center offered one such reminder last Saturday evening with a program called ''Traditional Music of Cambodia,'' performed by a quintet led by Sam-Ang Sam, a young doctoral candidate at Wesleyan University whose specialty is the music of the Khmer civilization. The ensemble included Mr. Sam on the khloy (a recorder); Pok Van on the tro (a two-stringed fiddle with a sound like an oboe or a bagpipe); Ngek Chum on khim (a hammered dulcimer) and on roneat (a wooden xylophone); Ra Khlay on a variety of drums, and Yan Van, a vocalist who also played hand cymbals.

title: Guidepost: Phones With Flexibility
description: Cordless telephones - many are now on sale - are a convenience when the backyard or terrace becomes your summer living room. Models and features vary widely depending on price. Some contain answering machines, intercom systems and automatic dialers capable of storing up to 20 numbers. Some can be used in a swimming pool and some allow both the base and the handset to be used as individual phones. The base of a cordless phone, which houses a transmitter, must be plugged into a modular telephone jack and an electric outlet. The portable element is the handset. During recharging, which takes three to six hours, the handset must be cradled in the base. Most current models have ranges of up to 1,000 feet, the legal limit set by the Federal Communications Commission. Because of the limited number of frequencies allotted by the F.C.C., users often experience interference; newer models will search automatically for the clearest line. PRICE FEATURES $59-69 Pulse and tone dialing, volume control. $100-150 ntercom system, paging, memory dialing, frequency selection. $200 and up Built-in answering machines, extensive memory dialing, wider frequency selection. Handset and base can be used as phones. Source: Consumer Electronics Magazine
