description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN FEMINISM FAILED
description: As a professional woman and (formerly) the first national coordinator for women's health of the National Organization for Women, I have to agree, sadly though, with Mary Anne Dolan's observations of women today in the marketplace. But as a sociologist, I disagree strongly with what I see as her conclusion that the increased presence of women in the work place is the causal factor for the American romance with power and greed. Those causes are better understood by examining the messages of Main Street, Wall Street and Pennsylvania Avenue. JOAN VALENTINE GOLDSTEIN Princeton, N.J.

title: After Stock Plunge, a Brokerage Is Born
description: Barely six weeks after the Oct. 19 stock-market plunge, a new investment brokerage firm here opened its doors for business.

title: The Rocky Road to Economic Unity
description: 1957: Treaty of Rome signed, creating European Community, then called Common Market, with six members: France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. 1963: President de Gaulle blocks attempts by Britain, Denmark, Norway and Ireland to join. 1967: Britain reapplies, followed by Ireland, Denmark and Norway. 1970: Community reaches an agreement to have voluntary but limited coordination of foreign policy. 1970: Community officials, through the Werner Plan, call for monetary union and coordination of economic policies by 1980. 1972: Heads of government call for European unity by 1980, endorsing a report promoting economic and monetary union, a common foreign policy and common regional and social policies. 1973: Britain, Ireland and Denmark finally join but Norwegians vote against membership. 1974: The campaign for monetary and economic union is shunted aside as community members are preoccupied with the oil crisis and sluggish growth. 1979: Eight of the nine members (all except Britain) form the European Monetary System, pegging their currencies to one another's to help prevent inflation and wild currency swings. 1981: Greece becomes 10th member. 1985: National leaders approve plan to create single market by 1992. 1986: Spain and Portugal become 11th and 12th members. 1987: Turkey applies for membership. 1988: Agreement reached in February on crucial question of reining in agricultural subsidies. 1992: Community's deadline for removing all internal economic barriers and customs posts.

title: Gail A. Mealey To Wed Sept. 17
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carroll J. Mealey of Albany have announced the engagement of Mr. Mealey's daughter, Gail Anne Mealey, to Brian Dalmar Quinn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Brian O'M. Quinn of Delmar, N.Y. A Sept. 17 wedding is planned.

title: Hospitals to Share Costly Equipment
description: HOSPITALS around the state, which alone cannot handle the expense of buying some of the most modern, and expensive, health-care equipment, are forming partnerships to buy or lease the material jointly. Purchasing such advanced equipment can cost about $2 million an item. A pact has been announced for the first lithotripter in the state. The machine uses sound waves to break up stones in the kidney and urinary tract without surgery.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SAY GOODNIGHT, GRACIE By Julie Reece Deaver. 214 pp. New York: A Charlotte Zolotow Book/ Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: America Is Taking Comic Books Seriously
description: TOMORROW, Warner Books, one of the biggest commercial publishers in the United States, marks the official publication date of ''Batman: Year One,'' a 96-page color comic book about a neurotic superhero who is a successor to the original caped crusader. This event follows the success of the 1986 Batman book, ''The Dark Knight Returns,'' which has sold 85,000 copies. And this fall, Warner has high hopes for ''Brought to Light,'' a 72-page comic it is issuing about the Iran-contra affair, no less.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Morristown
description: LEAD: AS the noon hour fell on the business district of Morristown one recent summer day, executives spilled out of modern office complexes and hurried by tall maple trees on the central green, which was framed with historic churches and buildings that serve as testaments to this New Jersey community's past.

title: 1 Dead and 56 Hurt In Bombing at Stores Near Johannesburg
description: A bomb exploded at a crowded shopping center in a white suburb of Johannesburg today, killing a woman and wounding at least 56 other people, the police said. The authorities said most of the victims were white, including the woman who died.

title: For Standing Out in a Crowd, Designers Create Art to be Worn
description: LEAD: ALONG with the crafts renaissance of the 1980's and a greater interest in handmade objects is a new popularity in wearable art.

title: The Fight Against Prejudice Must Continue on All Fronts
description: Bias crimes, those having an racial, ethnic or religious component, continue to be the focus of law-enforcement agencies, educational decision makers and other community forces. Race and racial issues continue to be of concern as well.

title: WHERE TIME IS OUT OF JOINT, JUST AS IT SHOULD BE
description: SCORES of people gathered around a small potted evergreen and a much-larger, eight-foot-tall cedar tree last Saturday outside the summer home of Dick and Janet Miller to celebrate ''Christmas in July'' on Cedar Island off Clinton.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Despite Space Surplus, Office Park Grows
description: LEAD: BANKING on a strong location and architectural design to attract corporate tenants, a Connecticut developer has begun work on the second half of a speculative office park in East Hanover, despite a surplus of commercial space in Morris County.

title: Yugoslavia Threatens Tough Moves on Unrest
description: The Communist leadership ended a meeting today with a threat to take tougher action against unrest in the southern province of Kosovo, where ethnic Albanians are demanding greater autonomy.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CELINE: Remembering Louisiana, 1850-1871. By Celine Fremaux Garcia. Edited by Patrick J. Geary. (University of Georgia, $25.) At the turn of the century, when she was in her 50's, Celine Fremaux Garcia recorded the events of her girlhood and her coming-of-age in this vivid memoir, now published for the first time.

title: Slayer of Youth Sentenced
description: A professor convicted of killing and dismembering a teen-age male prostitute with a chain saw was sentenced Friday to 25 years to life in prison. The 58-year-old defendant, Max Bernard Franc, taught political science at Fresno State University until his arrest last August. His secret life as a homosexual voyeur was disclosed at his trial for the killing of Tracy Leroy Nute, 18.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I had thought freedom was more important to people than rice, but it isn't. Rice is more important. These people just want to survive, survive, survive.'' - Dansing Narido, a Manila slum dweller. [ 12:6. ]

title: Resolutions Speed Pace Of Gorbachev Changes
description: The Communist Party has set deadlines for overhauling the party, Government and judiciary to quicken Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of change in the Soviet system, according to resolutions made public today by the official press agency Tass.

title: African Tableaux
description: MANDELA Starring Danny Glover, Alfre Woodard (in photo), Warren Clarke, John Indi, John Matshikizia, Nathan Dambuza Mdledle. Directed by Philip Saville. 1987. HBO Video. 135 minutes. $79.99. Not Rated.

title: Ethics and Fetal Research: Government Begins to Move
description: FOR years, scientists who wanted to do research involving human embryos and fetuses have found themselves in a Catch-22 situation. They could do their work with impunity, and receive Federal funds for it, so long as an ethics advisory board approved their proposals. The catch is that the board does not exist, and has not for nearly a decade.

title:
GARDENING;
Maintenance to Help Plants Survive
description: LEAD: By August, summer has begun to take its toll in our gardens. Heat, drought and often just plain neglect will have resulted in an advancing appearance of shabbiness. Prompt action acn still rejuvenate plantings so that they will remain presentable until the end of the season.

title: Going From Music-Lovers to Mass Market
description: IF there is a silvery glint in the eyes of music sellers and listeners, it is the reflection of millions of compact disks being popped into compact disk players. About seven million compact disk players have been sold since 1983, the year they were introduced. Over the past five years they have been selling better than video cassette recorders, of which 1.1 million were sold from 1983 through 1987, according to Link Resources, a New York-based market research group. Last year alone, 102 million compact disks were sold for a total of about $1.6 billion, according to the Recording Industry of America, a trade association.

title: U.S. Industry Flooded by Faulty Bolts, Panel Says
description: Millions of substandard nuts and bolts have been used in everything from military equipment and weapons to the space shuttle and commercial trucks, a Congressional committee said in a report issued today.

title: CIVIC ENVOY: Toshio Nagamura; A Japanese Banker's Bid to Cement U.S.-Japanese Ties
description: IN his dark blue suit, slicked-back black hair and quiet formal manner, Toshio Nagamura might seem at first like the typical Japanese businessman in America, astute but essentially detached from the American environment.

title: Schayes Stays
description: He could have gotten more by jumping to another club, but Danny Schayes, the Nuggets' free-agent center, wanted to stay in Denver, so he had to settle for less. As a result, Schayes will get $9 million over the next six years.

title: The Allure of Mapplethorpe's Photographs
description: If style and its permutations, fashionability and taste, are major topics of late 80s art, then Robert Mapplethorpe is perhaps the most topical artist of the moment. Less than 20 years since he first decided to make art with a camera, his elegant but often provocative photographs are being heralded as exemplars of the new stylish sensibility. Certainly they are popular. I am told that to see the exhibition of his work held recently at the National Portrait Gallery in London, one had to wait in line.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Camden, Me.; New Ways to Use an Old Mill
description: IN this seaside resort, the last of five textile mills closed earlier this year, and the century-old wooden structure will soon be converted to an inn, retail shops and offices.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''In New York the distinction between hostile and friendly takeovers has been very much blurred.'' - Yoshiji Fukushima, executive vice president, Nomura Securities.

title:
DINING OUT;
Traditional Menu in Cold Spring
description: LEAD: Bravos to the renovators who have transformed a dark and outdated space into an airy, multi-level, high-tech, black and white expanse. Walls have been pushed out and filled with windows washing the room with the lingering summer sun. Plants line the window shelf - coleus, sage, tarragon - and enliven other areas of the dining room as well.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
They Shall Not Go Nameless
description: LEAD: Cindy Ruskin, a reporter, Matt Herron, a photojournalist, and Deborah Zemke, a designer, have put together THE QUILT: Stories From the Names Project (Pocket, $22.95), an assemblage of life stories and photographs of a memorial - a huge quilt of quilts, now numbering some 2,000 3-by-6-foot panels in the names of people AIDS has killed.

title: Britain, Citing Rebel Threat, Plans Kabul Staff Reduction
description: Britain plans to evacuate 10 embassy workers and their dependents from Afghanistan next week because of fears of increased guerrilla attacks on Kabul, the Foreign Office said today.

title: CONSTRUCTION SLOWS TRAFFIC ON HUTCHINSON
description: LEAD: As dismayed motorists caught in traffic jams are discovering, the State Department of Transportation has resumed work on a 7.4-mile stretch of the 14.5-mile-long Hutchinson River Parkway, making the heavily traveled road safer to drive and alleviating chronic flooding.

title: Kimberly Castor Is Wed
description: Kimberly Susan Castor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Castor of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Timothy James Kristof, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Kristof of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Robert Childs officiated at the Stanwich Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn. Mrs. Kristof is a marketing development manager for the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting and consulting firm in New York.

title: J. R. Ward Weds Elizabeth Daley
description: Elizabeth Ann Daley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Daley 3d of New Haven and Rye Beach, N.H., was married yesterday in Rye Beach to John Richard Ward, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ward of Darwen, Lancashire, England. The Revs. Thomas R. Hennigan and Gordon R. Allen performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Andrew's-by-the-Sea.

title:
FOCUS: Ventura, Calif.;
Companies Move as Housing Costs Rise
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to mountains and cold weather, this beach town 60 miles northwest of Los Angeles cannot compete with Bozeman, Mont.

title: THE WORLD: Visit From Grosz; Hungary and the U.S., Finally Face to Face
description: IN international relations, as in marriage, it sometimes takes a long time to achieve reconciliation. The United States and Hungary have needed more than four decades to reach the state of comity that made it possible for Prime Minister Karoly Grosz to journey from Budapest to Washington last week.

title: Temporarily Unchilled
description: South Africa has wisely suspended temporarily a proposal that would require some journalists to register or face heavy fines or jail. But the proposal is only suspended, not shelved, and it's hardly reassuring that Home Minister Stoffel Botha cites ''practical considerations'' as grounds for his decision.

title: Suppliers Balking at Pentagon Certification Policy
description: A number of military contractors are contending that a new Pentagon policy requiring them to certify that they have not received inside information in the bidding process is overly restrictive and could leave them in a legally untenable position.

title: No More Identity Crisis In Canada
description: What is the National Ballet of Canada? For nearly three decades it seemed to model itself after Britain's Royal Ballet; then suddenly, a few years ago, it began to resemble American Ballet Theater. Nowadays, it looks, believe it or not, like the National Ballet of Canada - a company that has finally found its true identity.

title: How the Spell Was Broken for Bolcom's 'Etudes'
description: William Bolcom began his ''Twelve New Etudes'' for piano - the works that won him this year's Pulitzer Prize for music - in 1977, and almost didn't complete them. ''I was composing them for Paul Jacobs,'' he explained in a telephone interview the day the Pulitzer was announced, ''but by the time I had completed the first nine of the 12, Paul had become ill and could no longer play them. When he died, in 1983, I just stopped working on them. I felt blocked. I played No. 9 at the concert we gave in his memory at Symphony Space, the following year, and I thought that would be the end of them.''

title: Talks to End Scriptwriters Strike Collapse
description: Contract talks between scriptwriters and movie and television producers collapsed today, erasing earlier optimism that weekend negotiations might end the 21-week strike.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: U.S.-U.S.S.R MINGLING

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AL FRESCO SHAKESPEARE According to the Performance Studio of New Haven, even small children enjoy a taste of Shakespeare as presented by the six-year-old troupe in al fresco settings for an audience of picnickers.

title: Teheran Reports Successes Along the Battlefront
description: Iran said today that its troops drove Iraqi soldiers occupying four towns back to the border and blunted a new Iraqi offensive elsewhere. Iraq said it withdrew from occupied areas.

title: American Express Goes High-Tech
description: IN recent months, holders of the American Express card have seen a change in their billing statements. In the past, the bills came with a bulky packet of paper receipts of purchases. Today those slips have been supplanted by neat laser-printed sheets containing as many as eight reduced images of the original receipts on a single page.

title: Home Market
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Agassi to Face Annacone: Second-seeded Andre Agassi advanced to the final of the Volvo International tournament in Stratton Mountain, Vt., yesterday, using his powerful forehand and a looping topspin to beat 12th-seeded Dan Goldie, 6-3, 6-3. Agassi's opponent today will be 13th-seeded Paul Annacone, who returned to his chip-and-charge game to defeat ninth-seeded Darren Cahill, 6-4, 6-3. It will be the first final for Cahill since 1985.(AP) Graf Breezes Into Final: Steffi Graf advanced to the final of the Virginia Slims tournament in Hamburg, West Germany, with a 6-2, 6-3 victory over Bettina Fulco of Argentina yesterday. Graf, a West German, will meet Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria in the final today. Maleeva defeated Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia, 2-6, 6-1, 6-1.(AP) Sanchez and Perez-Roldan Advance: Top-seeded Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina and second-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain advanced to the final of a Grand Prix tournament yesterday at Hilversum, the Netherlands. Perez-Roldan defeated Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden, 7-6, 2-6, 6-3; Sanchez downed Mark Woodforde of Australia, 6-4, 6-3.(AP) Noah Defeated in Semifinal: Ronald Agenor of Haiti defeated Yannick Noah of France, 4-6, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday to gain the final of the Grand Prix tournament Bordeaux, France, for the second consecutive year. Agenor, who lives in Bordeaux, will play Thomas Muster of Austria in the final today.(AP) Golf 3 Share Lead: Howard Twitty bogeyed the final hole yesterday and dropped into a three-way tie with Steve Elkington and Scott Verplank after three rounds of the Buick Open in Grand Blanc, Mich. Elkington, a 26-year-old Australian who started the day three strokes behind Verplank and one in back of Twitty, shot a five-under-par 67. He was tied at 14-under-par 202 with Twitty, who had a 68, and Verplank, who shot a 70. (AP) Seeking to End Drought: Connie Chillemi, bidding for her first victory in 12 years on the Ladies Professional Golfers Association Tour, shot a seven-under-par 64 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Jan Stephenson and Beth Daniel after two rounds of the Greater Washington Open in Bethesda, Md. Chillemi, who started the day five strokes behind Judy Dickinson, birdied six of the final nine holes. She was at six-under-par 136 after two trips over the 6,250-yard Bethesda Country Club course. Stephenson had three birdies and a bogey en route to a 69.(AP) Rodriguez in Front: Chi Chi Rodriguez birdied four of the last five holes yesterday for a three-stroke lead after two rounds of the Digital Senior tournament in Concord, Mass. Rodriguez, who won the tournament the past two years, finished with a seven-under-par 65 for a 36-hole score of 133. Bob Charles of New Zealand was second at 136.(AP) Horse Racing Anka Germania Wins: Anka Germania caught the leaders entering the stretch yesterday and edged away through the final furlong on her way to a 1 1/2-length victory in the Sword Dancer Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Belmont Park. The favorite in the Grade I race, Sunshine Forever, rallied to finish second in the field of seven, 1 3/4 lengths ahead of Carotene. The victory was the fourth in six starts this year for the 6-year-old daughter of Malinowski-Affaire d'Amour. She carried Craig Perret and highweight of 117 pounds over the mile and a half in 2:32 1/5 and earned $141,120 for Fernwood Stables. She was part of an entry that paid $9.40 for $2 to win. Wrestling Going to the Olympics: John Morgan of Minneapolis qualified for the United States Olympic wrestling team's 180 1/2-pound slot yesterday by twice beating Jeff Steubing of San Luis Obispo, Calif., 1-0. The matches were in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The team selected its other 19 wrestlers during trials in Pensacola, Fla., in June. But trials for the 180 1/2-pound class were interrupted when Morgan suffered a neck injury in a loss to Stuebing.(AP) Boxing Jackson Keeps Title: Julian Jackson retained his World Boxing Association junior-middleweight title by stopping Buster Drayton in the third round of a scheduled 12-round bout yesterday in Atlantic City. The 27-year-old Jackson, from St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands, improved to 34-1 with 31 knockouts. Drayton, 34, of Philadelphia, is 36-11-1 with 28 knockouts.(AP) Indoor Football Title to Detroit: Rich Ingold ran for a touchdown and threw for 121 yards, and Steve Griffin had 6 receptions and 2 interceptions to lead the Detroit Drive to a 24-13 victory over the Chicago Bruisers in ArenaBowl '88, the championship game of the Arena Indoor Football League.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Minneapolis;
A Big Addition To the Skyline
description: LEAD: A NEW skyscraper will soon join the Minneapolis skyline. The International Business Machines Corporation and the Opus Corporation plan to build two office towers, one of 58 stories and the other of 18, that will flank and rise above a circular 14-story atrium.

title: Change of Venue?
description: After holding the National Horse Show in one Madison Square Garden or another for 104 years, show officials have decided that it has become too expensive. The horse show officials have approached officials of the Meadowlands about the possibility of moving to Byrne Meadowlands Arena for the 1989 show. Michael Rowe, the arena's general manager, said he plans to meet this week with Henry L. Collins 3d, the chairman of the horse show committee.

title: Teacher Traces Ebb and Flow of Education Over 6 Decades
description: Since entering first grade in 1930 until my recent retirement as a professor of English, I have twirled about in six decades of education fads. Some of these hoola hoops were productive, some regrettable, some destructive - but all were well-intentioned. And in each decade the educators were absolutely certain that they at last had the correct philosophy.

title: FICTION
description: WHAT SHOULD WE DO ABOUT DAVEY? By Julius Fast. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) Oh, the trials of Davey Quinn, that good-looking, sexually obsessed, socially inept 16-year-old. Older women invite him in for cake and cookies -and seduce him. Big brother Sam is forever telling him he's a slouch. Even Dad, hoping for the best for his son, is heartbroken as Davey bungles another after-school job (caught sleeping with the librarian this time). Julius Fast's sixth book is a first-person account of a pivotal summer in the life of this youngster, told in what strives to be an ingenuous style. To be sure, Davey's voice, at times, is infectiously energetic and his descriptions vivid, particularly when he's describing the Jewish boys camp in the Catskills of the 1930's where he works as a waiter for the summer, and where most of the novel takes place. Davey recounts camp life in intimate detail, reveling in boyish pranks from the kitchen to the sleeping bag. But Mr. Fast, who is the author of an Edgar-award-winning mystery, ultimately fails to lift this book beyond the level of a teen-ager's randy account of an adventurous summer.

title: Gasoline Prices Up In Summer Trend
description: LEAD: THE price of gasoline on Long Island is inching higher and is likely to continue increasing through the summer, industry spokesmen say, but exactly why remains unclear.

title: Sept. 10 Wedding For Sarah Burke
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Burke of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Spencer Burke, to Michael Joseph McNamara, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. McNamara of Waltham, Mass. Miss Burke and her fiance, graduates of Middlebury College, plan to marry Sept. 10.

title: House Gifts, Welcome and Unwelcome
description: A CROQUET set, Lorna R. Cameron thought. Yes, a croquet set would be an inspired house gift for the weekend she was invited to her friends' new place in the Poconos. There, she was led to believe, she would find a lovely green ''English-type rolling lawn'' in front of the house.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Office Costs Around the World; In Tokyo, Rents Are High and Waiting Lists Long
description: AS recently as four years ago, New York City stood as the most expensive office center in the world. But the sagging fortunes of the dollar and the growth of other cities as money-market rivals make Manhattan look like an international bargain today.

title: Sally Hohman Marries Charles Butler Thomas
description: Sally Ann Hohman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Hohman of North Arlington, Va., and Charles Butler Thomas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Thomas of Old Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday in Washington. The Rev. Christopher Johnson performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church.

title:
MUSIC;
On the Farm, Culture Now Grows
description: LEAD: Appel Farm, once a small chicken farm, is now in the process of becoming an important arts center in southern New Jersey.

title: Dispute Over Oil Shale Is Fueled by Old Claims
description: Frank Cooley's law office in the center of Meeker, Colo., faces a sandstone bluff on the edge of the Piceance Creek Basin, an area geologists say contains the richest oil-shale deposit in the world.

title: Question Of the Week: Next Week; Are Red Sox Fans in For Another Fall?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Not Moving
description: THE owner of the Seattle Mariners announced that he would not take immediate advantage of an escape clause in his lease with the Kingdome that would allow him to move the team to another city next season. The statement by George Argyros came after considerable speculation in Seattle that he would invoke a provision of the lease that allows him to seek a new site for the team if attendance fails to average 1.4 million for two consecutive seasons, an average the Mariners failed to acheive. (AP)

title: Mets Shut Out Pirates Again
description: The banner, made up of individual placards and subject to change with each batter, hangs above the loge seats in right field. Last night, it read: SSSSSSSSSSSSSID, with each of the first dozen letters designating a strikeout. For Sid Fernandez, it is not the standard spelling of his name. It is, though, an increasingly common way of summarizing his game.

title: Reviews/Music; Troyanos and Valente in Handel and Mozart Arias
description: Reconciling 18th-century style to modern ears is an endless puzzle, and all of the consonances and discords between old and new seemed to converge at Avery Fisher Hall Wednesday night. Raymond Leppard conducted the Mostly Mozart Orchestra; Tatiana Troyanos and Benita Valente sang arias and duets from operas by Handel and Mozart.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: In Seoul, a Grim March for Gold
description: In a nation where soldiers are everywhere, the South Korean Olympic team is going to boot camp.

title: CLASIC bLACK
description: In the contemporary design world, black conjures up images of sleek, high-tech objects and stark spaces. But countless old-fashioned decorative accessories are black, too. Indeed, black can be as romantic and alluring as it can be gloomy, perhaps because it is an earth pigment that in the color spectrum expresses violet. ''It is a terribly underrated and misunderstood color,'' says Donald Kaufman, the color specialist. ''Most people think black simply absorbs color, but when an object is black, it becomes a silhouette - one that makes all the other colors around it glow.'' -

title: Advice on Fixing a Food Giant
description: EVER since February, when the Pillsbury Company's board forced chief executive John M. Stafford to resign, Pillsbury-watchers on and off Wall Street have been debating who the next chief of the floundering Minneapolis-based food and restaurant giant would be. Several logical contenders are said to have turned down the job. Last week, one accepted. Starting tomorrow, Philip L. Smith, chairman of the General Foods Corporation, will be chairman, president and chief executive of Pillsbury.

title: S. S. Murray Wed To Sarah Aldrich
description: The marriage of Sarah Elizabeth Aldrich, a daughter of Mrs. Charles D. Aldrich of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Aldrich, to Stephen Sheals Murray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan J. Murray of Morristown, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., took place yesterday at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Cambridge. The Rev. William J. Galvin, assisted by the Rev. John P. Boles, performed the ceremony.

title: Phoenix Stages 'Boy Meets Girl'
description: ''Listen, I've been writing stories for 11 years: Boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy gets girl,'' the Hollywood screenwriter, J. Carlyle Benson, says with finality. ''Or girl meets boy, girl loses boy, girl gets boy; love will find a way - love never loses; put your money on love; you can't lose - I'm getting hungry,'' his partner, Robert Law, snaps back.

title: Olympic Athlete Jackie Joyner-Kersee
description: TOWARD THE end of a steamy afternoon at the United States Olympic track and field trials in Indianapolis two weeks ago, Jackie Joyner-Kersee listened intently as her coach and husband, Bob Kersee, talked about the 200-meter sprint, her next task in the seven-event, two-day heptathlon. Run the curve as if it were the straightaway, her coach told her, and the straightaway will take care of itself. A few minutes later, Jackie asked her family and hometown friends, who'd come from East St. Louis, Ill., to sit in the stands along the curve; that's where she would need them to cheer her on.

title: In Botswana, A Democracy In Full Voice
description: The dissonance of democracy echoes loudly through this country of seemingly endless desert and bush.

title: POSTING: In the Shadow of the Trade Center; At Home in TriBeCa
description: Near the modest 10-story brick apartment house at 311 Greenwich Street is a park and gazebo, an elementary school and a community college. But over this homey setting the two towers of the World Trade Center loom so large that they seem sure to ward off the rain. Such are the curiosities found in of TriBeCa, one of Manhattan's newest residential locations in one of its oldest districts.

title: What'd They Say? A-Wop-Bop A-Loo-Bop
description: The other night at the Cat Club, David Thomas of Pere Ubu was introducing ''Final Solution,'' a song about a teen-age wallflower the band recorded a decade ago and had disdained until other groups revived it. ''They all pronounce the words so that they can be understood,'' he said, and paused, deadpan. ''We don't make that mistake.'' The rendition that followed was noisy, impassioned, thoroughly unintelligible and probably definitive.

title: What Jazz Is - and Isn't
description: My generation finds itself wedged between two opposing traditions. One is the tradition we know in such wonderful detail from the enormous recorded legacy that tells anyone who will listen that jazz broke the rules of European conventions and created rules of its own that were so specific, so thorough and so demanding that a great art resulted. This art has had such universal appeal and application to the expression of modern life that it has changed the conventions of American music as well as those of the world at large.

title: Miss Persico Is Married
description: Vanya Maria Persico and Lawrence Jeffrey Perez, members of the staff of the New York State Assembly, were married yesterday at the Church of St. Patrick in Watervliet, N.Y. The Rev. Erwin Schweigardt performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: CD'S OFFER REVITALIZED SOUND
description: It was W. H. Auden who pointed to a special meaning of ''new.'' ''For many of us,'' he observed, ''our most important 'new' experiences are discoveries about the hitherto unknown past.''

title: Experts See a Time Bomb in the Rapidly Exploding Philippine Population
description: When evening falls, Dansing Narido's oldest two sons take the top bunk bed, her twin daughters take the bottom bed and the other 12 members of the family arrange themselves in a crowded row on the floor.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We used our charcoal barbecue grill on the porch and as a result some of the painted siding on the house is blackened. Can you suggest how I can remove this eyesore?

title: Mystic is Breeder of Fur Seals
description: THE Mystic Marinelife Aquarium has become the world's foremost breeder of northern fur seals, a species termed depleted under the Federal Marine Mammal Protection Act.

title: AWAITING THE CALL
description: THOSE WISHING TO find His Majesty Mohammad Zahir Shah must negotiate a series of country lanes in a wedge of suburban Rome that is still mostly pasture and forest. Since he was overthrown in 1973, the former King of Afghanistan has accepted the genteel irrelevance of a deposed monarch - living quietly in Rome, confining his plotting to the bright red display of his electronic chess game. But recently envoys and messengers have been appearing at the King's door, interrupting his retirement with news of war and plans for peace.

title: The World Watches Europe, the Power That Will Be By STEVEN GREENHOUSE
description: THE European Community's rapid march toward removing its maze of internal economic barriers began with fears that it was falling hopelessly behind the United States and Japan. But as the movement picks up speed, leaders in the rest of the world are beginning to wonder what life will be like - politically as well as economically - if Western Europe indeed emerges as a united superpower.

title:
GARDENING;
Maintenance to Help Plants Survive
description: LEAD: By August, summer has begun to take its toll in our gardens. Heat, drought and often just plain neglect will have resulted in an advancing appearance of shabbiness. Prompt action acn still rejuvenate plantings so that they will remain presentable until the end of the season.

While no other citizens are afforded similar privileges, journalists have often seen themselves as unelected public servants, members of a special Fourth Estate.

Richard Alvin Burnett, the son of Dr. A. W. Burnett of Los Angeles and Mary Elizabeth Bitzer of Chevy Chase, Md. Canon Joel A. Gibson of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York performed the ceremony.

description: CARING for a vacation home when you cannot be there is the classical quandary of anyone who has ever owned a hideaway cottage in the country or by the shore.

IN SHORT;
FICTION

description: THE ECONOMIC CHALLENGE OF PERESTROIKA By Abel Aganbegyan. Edited by Michael Barratt Brown. Translated by Pauline M. Tiffen. Tables. 248 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $18.95.

title: POSTING: N.J. Conversions; Union City Blooms
description: Not so long ago, Union City, N.J., was the only community between the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels that had not seen a great deal of residential construction and conversion. While nearby cities like Weehawken and Hoboken have sprouted new condominiums and cooperatives whose marketing is directed at New York City across the harbor, landlocked Union City seemed to remain insular, concentrating on its own commercial districts along Bergenline Avenue and Kennedy Boulevard.

title: Bookshelf
description: TOPSY TURVY. Written and illustrated by Monika Beisner. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. (All ages) The rich and witty illustrations that accompany this collection of short verses, adapted from the German by Daniel Huws, are full of topsy-turvy incongruities. A little girl sits on the lap of her wooden doll, kites dance on the ground while children fly in the sky, a cuckoo hatches kittens from her eggs.

title: The Phantom Of the Boxcar
description: KIDS who grow up straining to hit past manhole covers are lucky.

title: THE NATION: Pro & Con; Is Congress Up to Its Constitutional Job Of Judging Judges?
description: WITH its vote last week to recommend the impeachment of Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings, the House Judiciary Committee brought the full House and Senate to the verge of confronting one of their least welcome Constitutional tasks: deciding whether a high official, in this case a life-tenured Federal judge, should be impeached and removed from office.

title: 'Commissar' Director Is Upset by U.S. Distributor's Cuts
description: Aleksandr Askoldov, the Soviet director of ''Commissar,'' was able to endure Moscow's 21-year suppression of his film by refusing to give up hope for its eventual success, only to find at its screening at the Library of Congress that it had been cut by its American distributor.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SKULLDUGGERY, by Peter Marks. (Carroll & Graf, $4.50.) For years amateur historians have tried to discover who perpetrated the hoax of the Piltdown man by planting the bones that tricked anthropologists into believing they had found the missing link. Last year, our reviewer, Patrick McGrath, said the imaginary solution offered in this novel was unconvincing but that Peter Marks ''displays a masterly grasp of the scientific subtleties [ and ] an extensive familiarity with the lives and works of the famous men who grace his pages.'' THE GREAT SCHOOL WARS: A History of the New York City Public Schools, by Diane Ravitch. (Basic, $14.95.) Decentralization was an untried idea when Diane Ravitch completed her history of New York City's troubled school system 15 years ago. The result of this effort to wrest control from administrative headquarters in downtown Brooklyn has been ''thirty-two bureaucratic outposts in the districts plus the old, familiar bureaucracy,'' she writes in a new introduction, while the underlying problems remain the same. In 1974, our reviewer, George Levine, said the book's criticisms were ''mild and judicious'' and that one of its ''great virtues'' was that it might ''move us toward less blandly optimistic views of public education. . . . For her strenuous carefulness we can only be grateful.'' OH!, by Mary Robison. (Nonpareil/Godine, $9.95.) When this deadpan novel about a bizarre Midwestern family run by a soft-drink and miniature-golf entrepreneur was published in 1981, The Times's Anatole Broyard said Mary Robison's prose ''is like the sawdust that termites leave. . . . She's something of a gourmet of various kinds of collapse.'' THE CHILDREN AT SANTA CLARA, by Elizabeth Marek (Penguin, $6.95.) The lessons she was learning at Harvard began to seem beside the point, so Elizabeth Marek moved to the Southwest, where she worked at a home for emotionally disturbed children. Last year our reviewer, Rosellen Brown, called the book a ''celebration, by a gentle and unworldly young woman, of the terror and the head-clearing shock of standing close to the uncontrolled flame of the real world.'' PALOMINO, by Elizabeth Jolley. (Stanley Moss/Persea, $8.95.) On a cruise, Laura, a gynecologist and murderer, falls in love with the daughter of an earlier lesbian lover. ''Laura's character, blending tragic knowledge and absurd hopes, is an achievement of tragicomic art,'' Josephine Hendin said here last year. LILLIAN HELLMAN: The Image, the Woman, by William Wright. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Many details of Lillian Hellman's memoirs may have been fiction, William Wright confirmed, but even without embellishment she led a creative, adventurous life. ''This worldly biography, unlike anything else written by or about Hellman, has no hidden agenda,'' Frank Rich said here in 1986. ''Mr. Wright isn't interested in refighting the political wars of the past half century from the perspective of one camp or another. His main concern is facts, which he has diligently collected, documented and analyzed.'' SIGHTINGS, by Susan Trott. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) When Sunny returns to California from England, where she is having an affair with a philosopher, she finds that her father has run off with her best friend. ''Although she has created an unlikely troupe here and her plot is wildly baroque, [ Susan ] Trott displays a sensitivity to human quirkiness and longings that make this a splendid entertainment,'' Valerie Gladstone said in The Book Review last year. THE IRISH AMERICANS: The Rise to Money and Power, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner, $8.95.) The novelist, priest and sociologist uses a mix of opinion polls, historical profiles and reminiscence to attack the cultural stereotypes that surround Irish-Americans. Father Greeley ''vents a good deal of spleen,'' Frances Taliaferro said here in 1981. But she found the author ''well equipped to . . . argue that Irish-Catholic Americans 'have become the most successful educational, occupational, and economic gentile ethnic group in America while at the same time maintaining (traditional) cultural patterns.' In other words, 'the Irish are wealthy, powerful, and still Irish.' '' MAN'S WORK, by John Connelly. (Penguin, $7.95.) Short stories about disaffected Americans trapped by their ennui and inarticulate nature are becoming so numerous that they almost constitute a genre. Last year our reviewer, Susan Mernit, said some of the pieces in this collection are too understated but she admired John Connelly's ''vigorous prose.'' ''There are enough signs of talent in 'Man's Work' to suggest that Mr. Connelly is a writer worth our attention,'' she said. HANDEL, by Christopher Hogwood. (Thames and Hudson, $14.95.) The founder of the Academy of Ancient Music wrote a book on Handel that is ''the clear biography of choice for anyone interested in one of the great figures of music,'' John Rockwell said here in 1985. BODIES, by Robert Barnard. (Dell, $3.50.) A quadruple murder in a photography studio in London's Soho district leads to the uncovering of a conspiracy involving body building and pornography. ''Robert Barnard brings a fine satirical touch to his account of the iron-pumping cult,'' John Gross said in The Times in 1986. THE NEXT LEFT: The History of a Future, by Michael Harrington. (Owl/Holt, $8.95.) One of America's most articulate socialists argues that the left may be ready to rise again. The book is ''full of fascinating insights and provocative judgments,'' George P. Brockway said here last year.

title: Sara French Married to Laurence Margolin
description: Sara R. French, a daughter of Naomi French of Brooklyn and the late Emanuel French, and Laurence S. Margolin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Margolin of Great Neck, L.I., were married last evening. Rabbi Myron Fenster officiated at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Reclaiming Fields on Fire Island
description: ALTHOUGH most people think of national parks as places where trees are protected at all costs, a new program now under way at Fire Island National Seashore's William Floyd Estate in Mastic is aimed at tearing up several acres of trees and turning them into wood chips.

title: Role for Shoreham: Nuclear Waste Museum
description: The agreement by New York State with Lilco to take over the abandoned plant at Shoreham can have a more hopeful resolution than the dismantling of this $5.3 billion white elephant. This notorious plant can have an unscheduled use: it can become the Museum of Nuclear Waste.

title: Question Of the Week; Are You Following The Leadup To the Olympics?
description: Yes, but only with some difficulty. Trying to keep abreast of the selection of this year's United States Olympic team (much less other countries) through the media is strictly a hit-or-miss affair. The parochial nature of United States sports means that domestic sports such as baseball overshadow international competitions such as track and field.

title: Cycling in Beijing
description: To the Editor: The article by Nicholas D. Kristof on bicycling in Beijing (Travel, June19) omitted mention of my way of riding a bicycle there. Some people own bicycles, some rent them as he did, but I hitched a ride on one.

title: Britain, Not Exactly a Joiner, Still Favors a Few Barriers
description: HOW European is Britain anyway? Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had head-shaking continentals asking that question last week after she launched a sizzling attack on one of her favorite whipping boys, Jacques Delors, president of the European Community's commission.

title: A Man Recalls the Boy He Played in 'Commissar'
description: It has been 20 years since an impish-looking boy with dark eyes, curly hair and an infectious grin was chosen from hundreds of Soviet children by the director Alexander Askoldov to play the leading child in his 1967 film, ''Commissar.'' No sooner was the film finished than it was banned by the authorities for its frank treatment of Soviet anti-Semitism.

title: Shouts and Whispers About Sex
description: America may pride itself as socially advanced, but to read two recent studies from the Alan Guttmacher Institute is to conclude that when it comes to sex and its consequences, this country is downright backward.

title: Alice Chasan, Editor, Wed To Jeffrey Charles Kanige
description: Alice Chasan, a daughter of the late Harriet and Raymond Chasan of Jersey City, and Jeffrey Charles Kanige, the son of Mr. and Mrs. and Charles Kanige of Center Moriches, L.I., were married yesterday in Princeton, N.J. Mayor Barbara Boggs Sigmund of Princeton Borough performed the ceremony in her office at Borough Hall.

title: DATA BANK: July 31, 1988
PUSHING CIGARETTES OVERSEAS
description: The thrust of Peter Schmeisser's article on American cigarette exports was predictable from its title, ''Pushing Cigarettes Overseas'' (July 10). However, whether one likes or dislikes a product is a matter quite apart from whether or not it should be treated equitably in world trade. Some people think we would be better off without televisions and motorcycles, but the existence of those products worldwide is a matter of everyday reality. It is the same with cigarettes, except that, as a product, American cigarettes are highly competitive abroad and many other American products are not.

title: D. J. Sandor Wed To Miss Troeger
description: Elizabeth Ann Troeger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis R. Troeger of New Canaan, Conn., and Woodland Valley, N.Y., and Donald J. Sandor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph J. Sandor of New Canaan, were married yesterday. The Rev. Peter Dora performed the ceremony at St. Benedict's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford, Conn.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MAGPIE RISING: Sketches From the Great Plains. By Merrill Gilfillan. (Pruett, $14.95.) ''There comes a morning every spring,'' writes Merrill Gilfillan in ''Magpie Rising,'' ''a morning whose light is just so - when the first solid thought to enter the mind is drive. It's as predictable as lilacs and the return of the big flocks.

title: Hamptons Festivals Strike Chord
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH they suspected that the Hamptons, fabled for visual arts, but lacking in sustained musical activity, would be ripe for summer programming, the founders of two festivals are surprised at just how well they have done.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Parkinson's Research
description: LEAD: Volunteers are being sought for two research projects supervised by Dr. Jesse Cedarbaum, director of the Parkinson's Disease and Movement Disorders Clinic at the Burke Rehabilitation Center in White Plains.

title: Bizarre '30's Trellis Is Being Rescued
description: LEAD: A CATHEDRAL-LIKE garden trellis of basketweave teak that soars to meet the tree tops on the grounds of the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts in Roslyn has experts divided over its attractiveness.

title: Reviews/Music; Icelandic Sugar Cubes Rock the World
description: The Sugar Cubes, who had been kept from playing here in June by visa problems, finally made it to New York and played their debut performance to a packed audience at the World on Thursday night. The group, from Iceland, has a good idea: it mixes a touch of punk noise and anarchism with a new-wave, near-folk melodicism.

title: MAKING WHAT PASSES FOR LOVE
description: LEAD: LETOURNEAU'S USED AUTO PARTS By Carolyn Chute. 244 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $16.95.

title: American League; CLEMENS AND BARRETT KEEP RED SOX ON A ROLL
description: Even when the Boston Red Sox do wrong, they can do no wrong.

title: At the Kouros in ridgefield, Art Complements Nature
description: THE Kouros Sculpture Center in Ridgefield, is still a work in progress and at 14, the number of artists is pretty much the same as it was when the reviewer visited two years ago. Three of the names are new, though, and thecollection, seemingly larger, has settled into the hundred rolling acres at its disposal. Or is it that nature is closing in on the art, garnishing it with a few spiderwebs and a touch of bird lime?

title: Question Of the Week; Are You Following The Leadup To the Olympics?
description: With the Mets allowing the Pirates to be in a pennant race, how can I find the time to follow the Olympics leadup? Hopefully by the time the Olympics take place in September, the Mets will have clinched the National League East, and I'll be able to concentrate on Carl Lewis, et al, for a few weeks. JIM KEATING Brooklyn

title: Giants' Old Pro Is Mellow
description: This is his 13th National Football League season, and he will be 35 years old before it ends. He has been voted to the Pro Bowl nine times in the last 10 years. His skills may have diminished somewhat and he may no longer be the game's best inside linebacker, but he is certainly among the wisest and the best.

title: How Our Presidential Candidates Are Tested; Short Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Pool Plan Divides Glen Cove Residents
description: LEAD: AN Olympic-size pool in Glen Cove is making political waves for the officials searching for a place to put it.

title: The Playwright as Prosecutor
description: The theater, Federico Garcia Lorca said, is a public tribunal in which mankind ''submits as evidence old or mistaken lessons and explains with living examples the eternal norms of the heart and of human sentiment.'' All over Latin America in recent years, the heirs of the great Spanish playwright and poet have been busy applying his dictum, and it is that spirit that animates the works they bring to the monthlong 12th Festival Latino in New York, which begins this week.

title: In London This Summer, Masses of Old Masters
description: Old master paintings have been at home in London for close on 400 years, but right now there is what might be called a new nonchalance in the way in which they come into view. It is not that they are taken for granted - how could they be, when so many of them have been made new for us by recent cleaning? - but that this summer has given them, one after another, the freedom of the city in ways not often paralleled.

title: Amy C. Shull to Marry J. G. Finnerty 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Henderson Shull Jr. of Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Caroline Shull to Joseph Gregory Finnerty 3d, a son of Alice Ann Finnerty of Baltimore and Mr. Finnerty Jr. of Glen Rock, Pa. The couple plan to marry in November.

title: Amanda Tidwell Weds
description: The marriage of Amanda Kay Tidwell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elton Tidwell of Indianapolis, to Dr. Jeffrey Alan Rapaport, a son of Mrs. Joseph Samuelson of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Willi Rapaport, took place last evening at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Robert Widom performed the ceremony.

description: Beyond the competitive rush of the crowded city center, creativity flourishes in a place of quiet, tree-shaded harmony.

title:
ART;
'Marketplace' Joins Artists, Seminars At Bronx Museum
description: LEAD: The annual program, ''Artist in the Marketplace,'' at the Bronx Museum for the Arts is designed to acquaint young artists from a variety of economic and ethnic backgrounds with the contemporary art world. A series of seminars is given by professionals - ranging from tax accountants to critics - and the 32 artists in the program each year are given a show in the spacious lower gallery of the museum.

description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Pollis of North Attleboro and West Falmouth, Mass., have announced that their daughter Ann Margaret Pollis and Jonathan O'Herron Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Herron of Darien, Conn., and Woods Hole, Mass., plan to marry Sept. 24.

title: Susan Melville Hunt, Ph.D. Candidate, Weds the Rev. Mark Hollingsworth Jr.

Mark Hollingsworth Jr., the son of Caroline J. Hollingsworth of Concord, Mass., and the late Mr. Hollingsworth. Bishop Charles F. Hall, who is retired from the Episcopal Diocese of New Hampshire, and the Rev. Peter Gomes, minister of the nondenominational church, performed the ceremony.

title: India Bogged Down in Sri Lanka's Ethnic Conflict
description: One year after sponsoring an accord to end the conflict in Sri Lanka, India remains mired in its island neighbor's bloody civil war with little prospect of ending the violence, imposing a settlement or bringing home its 50,000 troops.

title: Rockaway Reopens, but a Residue Of Mistrust Is Now Found Ashore
description: The sky was clear, the sun shimmered invitingly on the water and temperatures were in the 90's, but most beachgoers did not go swimming yesterday at Rockaway Beach.

title: Hurrying to Find Housing in Jersey
description: Like 500 other welfare families who have exhausted their emergency shelter benefits, Sheila Gonzalez and her two sons have begun to pack their belongings and prepare to leave the Brookside Motel on Monday.

title: Fulfilled
description: GREAT EXPECTATIONS Directed by David Lean. Produced by Ronald Neame. Starring Alec Guinness and John Mills (in photo), Valerie Hobson, Jean Simmons, Martita Hunt, Francis L. Sullivan, Torin Thatcher. 1946. 118 minutes. Paramount Home Video. $19.95

title: Victory for the Weary

And if a cease-fire can be achieved, followed by peace negotiations, the fighting could stop on the one basis practically everybody except the combatants required - victory for neither side.

He worried aloud about Charles Hudson and Ron Guidry, who were both hurting, and announced that Richard Dotson was being sent to the bullpen and that Steve Shields would start in six days against Minnesota.

Catlett Jr., also of Richmond, and the late Marion Buckey Catlett of Union Bridge, Md. The couple plan to marry Oct. 8.

title: Shelby LaMotte Marries
description: Shelby LaMotte, a landscape designer, and James Michael Giannone, a landscape foreman, both at Leisure Life Gardens in Essex Junction, Vt., were married yesterday at the Pound Ridge (N.Y.) Community Church by the Rev. Richard Monkman. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. LaMotte of Bedford, N.Y. Her father is president of Prime Office Systems in White Plains. Mr. Giannone is the son of Jack Giannone of Milton, Vt., a law and finance teacher at the Essex (Vt.) Educational Center, and Margaret Carpenter of Crown Point, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A table last week with an article about McGraw-Hill Inc. mislabeled the company's second-quarter results for 1988 and 1987. For the 1988 quarter, revenues were $443.8 million, net income was $44.8 million and earnings per share were 92 cents. For the 1987 quarter, revenues were $425.9 million, net income was $40 million and earnings per share were 79 cents.

title: Reviews/Music; Tosh and Mowatt in Reggae Feats
description: Jamaican Rastafarian culture, represented by Andrew Tosh and Judy Mowatt, made its way to New York on Wednesday night. At S.O.B.'s, both Mr. Tosh and Ms. Mowatt mixed Rastafarian songs with pop tunes; the contradictions between the asceticism of the religious compositions and the unabashed desire to entertain bothered neither the musicians nor the packed audience.

title: A NEW KIND OF REVOLUTION
description: THE TURBAN FOR THE CROWN The Islamic Revolution in Iran. By Said Amir Arjomand. 283 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $21.95.

description: LEAD: BELIEVE THEM By Mary Robison. 146 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: With a sigh, Dan O'Connor, board member and chairman, glanced at his watch. The gesture was imitated all around the table. Yes, hard as it was to believe, the minute hand was stalking midnight. This evening's meeting of the New Jersey Audubon Society's Conservation Committee had been a lengthy one.

title: HUSSEIN REDUCES TIES TO WEST BANK AND PALESTINIANS
description: King Hussein signed a decree today dissolving the lower house of Jordan's Parliament, which represents the interest of Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, the official Jordanian press agency announced this afternoon.

title: Britain
description: To the Editor: Having spent several days in late May at Ardsheal House, my wife and I agree with Phyllis Lee Levin's glowing assessment of this unique guesthouse (''A Scottish Inn, Sturdy and Grand,'' Travel, June 5). Our subsequent two-week, 1,600 mile auto tour of the Highlands and Grampians made it clear to us that the hospitality and cuisine offered by the Taylors at Ardsheal set a difficult standard to equal.

title: Far From the San Marco Crowd
description: Henry James, who on another occasion admitted to a perpetual love affair with Venice, once described the city as a vast museum where the little wicket that admits you is perpetually turning and creaking, a place you march through with a herd of fellow gazers.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, some copies of the Travel section last Sunday included page 19 from the previous week in place of the current version; the correct page carried the opening section of the article on Montreal churches. Readers wishing copies of the correct page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: The Dream That Fell to Earth
description: AT night I dreamed of flying. Not on one particular night, but every night. One night I was chasing the Red Baron above the trenches of the Western Front, the next I was an owl soaring from tree to tree.

title: Maine Coast
description: As you drive up the coast from Portland to Bar Harbor, rocky, evergreen-lined bluffs taper into sandy shores. Spartan fishing villages give way to towns with boutiques, restaurants and galleries. Simplicity and sophistication coexist along this 161-mile stretch that is Maine's midcoast region. The best way to get a feel for the terrain is by car, a trip that can take a few hours or a few days, preferably accompanied by DeLorme's Maine Atlas.

title: STREETSCAPES: 116 John Street; Deja Vu in Zoning Dispute
description: THE argument over the height of 116 John Street, which was built 58 years ago, sounds just like the current zoning dispute case at 108 East 96th Street, a dispute that has caught the public's attention because it is so unusual.

title: Pariahs Abroad, Mozambique Rebels Fight On
description: In Gorongosa District, Mozambique, July 28 - In the heart of Mozambique, a beleaguered group of anti-government rebels facing almost total regional and international isolation continues to plot the destruction of this country's ailing transport and electricity network from the seclusion of their shifting forest headquarters.

title: Evert and Mill Wed Walker Hospitalized
description: In a civil ceremony attended by 100 family members and friends, Chris Evert and the former United States Olympic skier Andy Mill were married yesterday in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: THE EVERLASTING CONSTRUCTION SITE
description: Offering his own suggestion as to why the third President remained wholly preoccupied with building himself a house for nearly all of his long life, Jack McLaughlin says that the creation of Monticello might have been a form of adult play. In the light of his entrancing study of the bricks-and-mortar Thomas Jefferson, this is not at all a farfetched conclusion. The fact is that Monticello absorbed him more than human relationships, more than the great offices he held, more than anything. It was the kind of total absorption children have when they are making something.

title: Airport Repairs Alter Flight Paths
description: LEAD: MAJOR renovations at Kennedy International Airport are causing the intermittent shutdown of two of its four runways. As a result some sections of southwest Nassau County are seeing, and hearing, many more flights in and out of the airport.

title: Is 'New' The Same As Phony?
description: Reviews arouse resentment. The most common kind is anger at what is perceived as excessive or misguided negativism: an artist or his admirers protests (to the critic directly but more commonly among themselves) about the critic's ignorance or intemperance or penchant for personal vendetta.

title: JUDGE SAND MAKES A CHOICE: CONTEMPT CHARGES
description: For the better part of an hour last Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Judge Leonard B. Sand seemed to be weighing alternative sanctions in his two-year effort to force Yonkers to comply with a housing-desegregation plan.

title: Arrests of Burmese Dissidents Reported
description: The new Burmese Government arrested a major opposition figure, at least 10 other critics and an Associated Press reporter, Western diplomats said today.

title: The Positional Advantage Is Exploited
description: WHEN one thinks of hammer blows, the image that comes to mind is that of a mating attack sweeping through all resistance, yet positional play in which the safety of the enemy king is not an issue can also evince extraordinary force.

title: Housing Violations Pressed
description: MOUNT KISCO

title: Upper Maine Youths Go South to New Horizons
description: For the last six weeks, Kerry Pelletier, a high school student from a tiny Maine town on the Canadian border, has seen how the other half lives.

title: Propaganda: Third Reich Issues
description: WEBSTER'S defines propaganda as deception or distortion. Usually it is gross and unsubtle. The propaganda stamps printed by both the Axis and the Allies in World War II were among the most gross.

title: A Medical Success: The Children's Fund
description: ''Y's Turning to Younger Donors'' [ June 19 ] focuses a well-deserved spotlight on a vital segment of Long Island's community. Unfortunately, the reporter committed an error of omission when she neglected to mention one of this region's largest, longstanding and extremely effective philanthropic organizations, with a majority of its members 40 years of age or younger: the Children's Medical Fund of New York.

title: INSIDE
description: Optimism for Hostages The families of nine Americans held hostage by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon are expressing optimism about their release with Iran's acceptance of a U.N. resolution aimed at ending the war with Iraq. Page 22. Texas Rivalry Deepens With Texas climbing out of recession, an old rivalry between Houston and Dallas is intensifying. Page 18.

title: Arms, Not Principles
description: 'Saudi Arabia is not tied to anyone. . . . If we find what we need among friendly nations and if they give us what we ask, they do so for money. We are not getting anything for free. So, if things become complicated with a certain country we will find other countries, regardless of whether they are Eastern or Western. We are buying weapons, not principles.' - King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, discussing his country's decision to buy British and Chinese weapons after decades of almost exclusive reliance on American-made arms.

title: On Martha's Vineyard, A Drive Against Mopeds
description: Several times this year a group of residents here on Martha's Vineyard have been driven through town on a flatbed truck, some of them dressed in bandages made to look bloody. It is not a pretty sight. But then, some residents said, neither is the plethora of accidents on motor-driven bicycles, or mopeds, that prompted the display and a campaign to ban moped rentals.

title: Trying to Abolish Need for Glasses
description: IF RESEARCH by Dr. Francis A. L'Esperance Jr. succeeds, people with bad eyesight will be able to see clearly without glasses.

title: Couch Potatoes Arise; It's Time to Interact
description: THE next phase in the development of the compact disk is interactive compact disks or CD-I. These disks, which are still in the developmental stages, allow the user to, in essence, ''talk back'' to a television set to get information. Philips and Sony are among the companies working on making CD-I available for the mass-market; they hope to have their products in stores as early as next summer.

title: A Dangerous Poison
description: Anti-Semitism in the political life of a great American city: the idea is shocking and it is not to be brushed aside as a local oddity. Attention must be paid to what is happening in Chicago. Jesse Jackson has to face it. So does Michael Dukakis.

title: 3 Museums That Tell Venice's Story
description: Venice offers such extraordinary works of art in diverse settings that even the most ambitious sightseer must make choices. For those who appreciate viewing art in the context of history, three museums will provide insight into the development of this island city. These are the Correr Museum in the Piazza San Marco, the Museum of the Venetian 18th Century in Ca' Rezzonico on the Grand Canal, and the Naval Museum near the Arsenal, at the eastern end of the city. Admission to each museum is about $2.40. Correr Museum

title: Forty Niner Wins Haskell by a Nose
description: Forty Niner and Seeking the Gold race for different stables but seem to have gone through their careers as an entry. Sons of the same stallion, Mr. Prospector, they were born in the same barn at Claiborne Farm in Paris, Ky., grew up together in the fields there, went to New York as 2-year-olds and spent last winter in Florida.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Kingsland, Ga.;
description: CONSTRUCTION has begun on a $40 million residential and commercial development adjacent to the Kings Bay Naval Submarine Base in anticipation of rapid growth in the coastal area of southern Georgia and northern Florida.

title: Headliners; Back to the 60's
description: Linda Joyce Grinage by any other name and 19 years later was still a hijacker, Federal authorities said last week as they arrested a 39-year-old woman using the name Haziine Eytina in Albany. No statute of limitations applied, they explained, as she already had been indicted in the hijacking of an Eastern Airlines jet that was forced to land in Havana in 1969. The suspect, said to have used at least a dozen aliases, had been working as a teacher's aide in the Federal Head Start program since 1983. Her husband, Mylo Eytina, a lawyer, called it a case of mistaken identity; a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which acted on a tip, said that indeed she had seemed ''quite surprised.'' She pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn Thursday.

title: Inflation Redux?
description: Last quarter, the gross national product grew by 3.1 percent, down from recent quarters but still fairly healthy. Strong growth combined with high levels of capacity utilization and low unemployment is the classic formula for inflation. But commodity prices have recently begun to fall due to a stronger dollar and the return of rain to the Middle West. What will happen to inflation? Lawrence Chimerine Chairman, WEFA Group.

title: Rules on Handling Medical Waste Come Under Scrutiny
description: LEAD: The used syringes and vials of blood that have fouled New York and New Jersey beaches this summer, coupled with fears about AIDS transmission, have focused intense public attention on the debris generated by the care of the sick and wounded.

title: Land Bill's Sponsor Describes 'Larger Design'
description: Legislation recently approved by both houses would require Rutgers University to hold a public hearing and obtain the Governor's approval in order to proceed with any plan to sell or lease undeveloped land. I sponsored this bill in response to a specific project, which involved arrangements of a contract by Rutgers officials to build 1,200 apartment units on 335 acres of its Busch and Kilmer campuses.

title: CRIME
description: When Robert B. Parker came out with ''The Godwulf Manuscript'' in 1974, it was immediately apparent that an important contributor to the private-eye genre had appeared. Mr. Parker's hero, Spenser, a Boston detective, was big and tough, yet literate - and a gourmet cook to boot. Some splendid books ensued.

title: Naval Chief Sees Technology Advancing Fleet
description: In the Navy of the 21st century, submerged submarines will be able to shoot at airplanes, stealth fighters that evade radar will be flown from aircraft carriers and laser beams will protect warships, according to the chief of naval operations, Adm. Carlisle A. H. Trost.

title: Texas Bank's New Parent to Hold Foreclosed Assets
description: A pledge to manage rather than quickly sell more than $1 billion in foreclosed real estate held by the First Republicbank Corporation was key to the regulators' decision to allow the NCNB Corporation to acquire the ailing Texas banking company, the chairman of NCNB said today.

title: A Chicago Showcase for Chicago Architecture
description: One architect's presence hovers over all of the sprawling exhibition, ''Chicago Architecture 1872-1922: Birth of a Metropolis'' that has just opened at the Art Institute of Chicago. It is not Louis Sullivan or Daniel Burnham or even Frank Lloyd Wright, prominent though they all are in this show. None of these great men of history holds a position here quite equal to that of Stanley Tigerman, the Chicago architect who designed this exhibition in a personal, highly idiosyncratic, and often brilliant manner.

title: When Networking is Play
description: NEARLY everyone knows about networking. There are old-boy networks and professional women's networks, all devoted to helping their members achieve success in the get-ahead, stay ahead world of business. Less publicized - but just as critical - is the network that exists amonth mothers who are home full time raising their children. Surprisingly, it often exists in the innocuous form of play groups. For the uninitiated, a play group is nothing more than a loose organization of women and their pre-school children who gather periodically so the children can play together and the mothers can attempts to talk.

title: Taking a Team Approach to Soviet Trade
description: ROBERT J. CARBONELL remembers it all too well. About 12 years ago, Standard Brands Inc. (now a part of RJR Nabisco Inc.) was talking to a since-disbanded branch of the Soviet Union's agricultural ministry about producing high-fructose corn syrup in Russia. Soviet officials broached the idea, so presumably they did all they could to ease the company's path.

description: LEAD: Behind the weathered paint and well-worn doorway of the General Store on the corner of Main and King Streets in this Hunterdon County village is a bustling delicatessen-restaurant.

title: Chamber Festival Has Student Stars
description: THE Norfolk Chamber Music Festival, which wraps up its 48th season this weekend, has emerged as so important an adjunct of summer music in Connecticut that we tend to forget that its original raison d'etre was to provide a home and a focus for the Yale Summer School of Music.

title: Question Of the Week; Are You Following The Leadup To the Olympics?
description: Yes. But for objective media coverage I have to turn to sources other than the home press and television. The domestic media continue to report on the Olympics with a parochial fervor that borders on arrogance.

description: To the Editor:

NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;

title: Q And A
description: Stratford, Ontario Question: My travel agent was unable to find any tours to the festival at Stratford, Ontario, from New York, although a friend went on a weekend tour, with two plays, from Lewiston, N.Y. How can you account for this? -L. B. H., Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. Answer: It looks as though lack of demand has forestalled attempts to run group tours to the Stratford Festival from New York. Some travelers go in private groups that make their own arrangements. There are tours from western New York because of the relatively short distance. Lewiston, north of Buffalo, is about 100 miles east of Stratford. On the other hand, another travel agent might be able to discover tour organizations that plan a visit. One such company is Dailey-Thorp Travel, which specializes in opera and music tours. Dailey-Thorp is based in New York, but it is running its Canadian Cultural Salute program, with Stratford included, from Oct. 7 to 10, on the basis of independent arrivals in Toronto. The tour is being organized for members of the Metropolitan Opera Guild; basic annual membership of the guild can be had for $40. (Metropolitan Opera Guild, 1865 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10023; 212-582-7500.) The Canadian tour includes attendance at Shakespeare's ''Taming of the Shrew'' at the Festival Theater in Stratford and dinner at the city's Church Restaurant. In Toronto, where guild members will spend three nights at the Four Seasons Hotel, they will see Verdi's ''Don Carlos'' and Tchaikovsky's ''Queen of Spades'' performed on successive nights by the Canadian Opera Company at the O'Keefe Center. The cost of the tour is $987 a person, double occupancy. Air fare not included. (Dailey-Thorp Travel, 315 West 57th Street, New York, N.Y. 10019; 212-307-1555.) Travelers planning an independent visit may obtain information on accommodations and the theater program - there are three theaters -from Stratford Festival, Post Office Box 520, Stratford, Ontario, Canada N5A 6V2 (519-271-4040). The box office number is 519-273-1600. The festival season continues until Oct. 29. Visiting Yemen Question: Another woman and I would like to visit North Yemen. Are there limitations for length of stay? Where can we get information on hotels, currency and tours? Is spring the best season? - M. A. T., Brooklyn Answer: A tourist visa for the Yemen Arab Republic, which costs $10, is valid for 30 days, and Yemeni officials say travelers can obtain a one-week extension while in Yemen. Visas may be obtained from the Yemen Mission to the United Nations (866 United Nations Plaza, New York, N.Y 10017; 212-355-1730) or the Embassy of Yemen (600 New Hampshire Avenue N.W., Washington, D.C. 20037; 202-965-4760). A spokesman at the mission said tourist visas are generally granted in a day or two, but they are not issued to holders of passports bearing an Israeli or South African stamp.

title: Wordperfect Leaps Closer to Desktop Publishing
description: THE gulf between word processing programs and desktop publishing systems has been getting narrower in recent months, and the recent introduction of Wordperfect version 5.0 brings the two classes of software even closer together.

title: BRITISH CAN'T RACE, BUT THEY'LL WATCH
description: When Dennis Conner's twin-hulled catamaran and Michael Fay's elongated sloop meet in the America's Cup match Sept. 7, they are likely to encounter an uninvited guest.
