DINING OUT;
Elaborate Cuisine in Short Hills
description: LEAD: For months, shoppers finding their way around the maze of cloverleaf turns by the Short Hills Mall watched the fortress-like structure rise across the road. Finally opened in the spring, the Hilton at Short Hills turns out to have a spacious, elegant interior with two restaurants - the airy, casual Terrace

title: Headliners; Back to Earth
description: Elegant in the clinging draperies of her period, but looking sturdy enough to have pulled a plow back home on Mount Olympus, a 2,400-year-old goddess believed to be Aphrodite has been causing a stir in the world of classical art. The J. Paul Getty Museum announced last week that it had acquired the marble-and-limestone statue of the goddess, seven and a half feet tall, for an undisclosed price. Little is known about its origins except that it may have been made in southern Italy, but it is the only known cult figure from the late fifth century B.C. to have survived nearly intact. Prof. Angelos Delivorrias, the director of the Benaki Museum in Athens, describing the statue, was moved to lyricism: ''It is as if the goddess had just arrived on earth - from her world to our world,'' he said.

title: Reagan Appeals for Passage Of New U.S. Aid to Contras
description: President Reagan renewed his plea for Congressional support of rebels in Nicaragua today and linked a top official of the country's Government with the illicit drug trade.

title: Sharpton Is Released After One Night in Jail
description: After spending just one night in the Albany County Jail, the Rev. Al Sharpton was released on bail yesterday pending appeal of his 15-day sentence for disorderly conduct during a demonstration on behalf of Tawana Brawley in April.

title: Again, Families of Mideast Captives Dare to Hope
description: For the first time in more than 18 months, the families of Americans held hostage by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon say they have allowed themselves to be optimistic that their loved ones will be released.

title: IN THE WHIRL AND MUDDLE OF WAR
description: Sometime in the late 1920's, Horace Pippin, a black American veteran of World War I, began to write his memories of his war. It must have been difficult: Pippin was not a writer and was not very well educated. Even the physical act of writing was hard for him, for his right hand and arm had been crippled by a sniper's bullet and he could scarcely hold a pen. Yet he tried several drafts of a war narrative before he gave the writing up and turned to drawing and finally to painting. That, too, was a struggle; he had to hold the brush in his crippled right hand and guide its movements with his left. He worked at one painting for three years, giving it, he reckoned, a hundred coats of paint. It was called ''The End of the War: Starting Home,'' and it hangs now in the Philadelphia Museum of Art - a strange and powerful image of the violence that he remembered.

title: Bear Feats
description: WHATEVER CLAIMS TO MODESTY he is making in the photograph above, this is a talented bear; for instance, he can juggle with his feet. He and 11 ursine cohorts, all similarly gifted, are performers with the Moscow Circus, a collection of virtuoso acrobats, jugglers and clowns (as well as trained animals) set for a 15-stop North American tour that begins in Toronto on Aug. 17. Representing Soyuzgoscirk, the Soviet state circus, which employs 3,500 performers in a variety of venues throughout the Soviet Union, the 12 acts were selected by Steven E. Leber and Scott Sanders, producers of the tour for Radio City Music Hall Productions in New York. (The circus stops in Radio City from Sept. 14 to Oct. 9.) Since last November, the producers have made three excursions to the Soviet Union, visiting 10 cities, to select talent. ''We were looking for acts with unique appeal,'' Leber says; eight of the acts have never before been seen in North America. They include the Flying Cranes, aerialists capable of quadruple somersaults, whose performance, balletlike, conveys a narrative; Nikolai Pavlenko and his 17 Sumatran tigers, and Tamerlan Nugzarov, horses and horsemen from the Caucasus region. ''They're amazing,'' Leber says. ''Riders are dragged at full speed along the ground. Then this horse jumps through a hoop that has knives sticking out of it.'' The juggling bear act is known as the Zolkins, named for the trainers Vyacheslav Zolkin and Svetlana Mikityuk, who are husband and wife. Lifetime circus performers, they've been doing this particular routine for a decade, since Vyacheslav, once a tightrope walker, broke his back and needed something else to do. Antipod, or leg juggling, is a family thing; Svetlana's father, apparently, was the first human to master it. -

title:
ABOUT CARS;
Cadillac's Image Is Sputtering
description: LEAD: I've just spent a couple of days playing cars, fooling around with my semi-matched set of old Cadillacs.

title: Spoonbread, Virginia's Choice
description: In the South, as in many parts of the United States, regional cooking has given way to Chinese, Japanese and Mexican takeout, nouvelle French or what passes for it, and almost anything but what transplanted Virginians and Carolinians will tell you was standard fare in their childhood kitchens or the dining room of the local hotel. title: The Defense Speaks for Mark Belanger
description: IT may well be that nothing funny happened to Willie Stargell on his way to induction today into the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, but something passing strange seems to have affected at least a few of the people whose votes helped put him there. I should know. I was one of them.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: Odessa and Yalta, both Urkranian cities, were identified as Soviet cities. This is a similar to saying that Paris or Rome are in Europe without bothering to indicate the countries in which they are found.

title: A Drug Problem for All the Americas
description: AS soon as drugs emerged as a big issue in this year's American election campaign, nervous Latin American governments braced themselves for more accusations, aware that vote-seeking politicians in the United States would once again blame the supply of cocaine, heroin and marijuana from the south for the devastating impact of drugs in the north.

title: Stirrings of Peace
description: Suddenly, a season of peace seems to be warming the world. The last few months have seen five bitter and protracted conflicts brought suddenly closer to peaceful resolution. In the Middle East, Asia, Africa and Central America, populations stunned and bleeding by endless regional war look up and hope.

description: A table on July 10 with an article about Savoy Hotel P.L.C. gave incorrect figures for the company's second-quarter earnings per share for 1988 and 1987. For the 1988 quarter, the earnings were 57 cents; for the 1987 quarter, they were 51 cents.

title: NONFICTION
description: IMPROVISATION: Music From the Inside Out. By Mildred Portney Chase. (Creative Arts, Paper, $7.95.) Improvisation, as we are often reminded, is concert music's lost art. Two hundred years ago, cadenzas in concerto movements served to launch the individual performer's flights of fancy; cadenzas today are simply repetitions of what someone else has already written out. Few current virtuosos dare to exploit their spur-of-the-moment inspirations or would know how if asked. Are we more inhibited? Yes, but largely because we know less. Like most good jazz performers, 18th-century virtuosos were more complete musicians than their technique-mad classical counterparts today. They had the fund of knowledge that liberates the fantasy. This brief set of essays on the improviser's art by a musician and the author of ''Just Being at the Piano'' encourages the modern musician to go beyond inhibition with many helpful suggestions for all ages. Yet it skirts the major problem of an art that demands both a free-flying spirit and the heavy weight of discipline: namely, that the freedom to imagine and the capacity for imagination do not necessarily go hand in hand. Mildred Portney Chase's eloquent cheerleading won't do much good if her readers are the young pianists who typically can play the hell out of Chopin's G minor Ballade, but when asked to transpose a simple chorale a third downward, stare back in dumb silence. The Book of Common Prayer said it best: there is no ''perfect freedom'' without ''service.''

CHOOSING FROM LISTS AT LOCAL RESTAURANTS
description: LEAD: Thankfully, most area restaurants have shown remarkable resistance to the big city trend toward sprawling, encyclopedic wine lists.

title: FICTION
description: LONG RIDE BACK. By John Jacob. (Thunder's Mouth, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $9.95.) If you want to know what it felt like in the Vietnam War to itch and to sweat, to fear and to kill, the poet John Jacob's first novel will give it to you straight - too straight, perhaps. ''Long Ride Back'' provides a lot of action, but not much reflection. It is not an antiwar novel; in fact, you can love or hate war and still read the book with interest. Once in a while, Mr. Jacob's extremely detached hero, Travis Jones, lets a feeling slip out, but he never succumbs to self-pity. Jones and his cohorts were elite commandos sent on bizarre intelligence missions far from the usual battle areas. In describing their experiences, Mr. Jacob's writing is terse and vivid, but his novel's structure demands patience. The war scenes, told in past-tense flashbacks, are frequently, sometimes annoyingly, interspersed with present-tense scenes set in Chicago after the war, where Travis Jones is still suffering from malaria, going through life on the slant, with an emotional limp from his obsessive memories. The great strength of the book is its even narrative pitch: it describes and does not moralize. The Chicago sections are episodic, virtually plotless. But the part of the story that is set in Vietnam finishes like a thriller, in sweaty jungle fear, in betrayal - and in a final dramatically satisfying knife duel in which, Travis Jones recalls, ''Our eyes locked in patterns of the darkest fear, hate, anger, resentment. It was the most depraved moment of my war.''

title: Leveraged Buyouts Suffer a Casualty
description: Revco sought bankruptcy protection, burdened by the huge debt load that management took on when it bought the drugstore chain in a $1.3 billion leveraged buyout 19 months ago. Revco's chairman, Boake A. Sells, said most of the 2,000 stores were profitable but the company could not generate enough cash to cover both operating expenses and $150 million a year in interest payments. The buyout plan had forecast sales of $3.37 billion in the latest fiscal year, but eight months into the year, and past the Christmas season, the total was only $1.66 billion. Leveraged buyouts, in which management joins with outside investors, have absorbed billions of dollars of ''junk bond'' financing in recent years. Revco is the largest such buyout to fail.

The clinic will treat all aspects of Lyme disease, but will concentrate on its later manifestations, which can occur months or even years after its onset.

title: NONFICTION
description: SALAMANDER: The Story of the Mormon Forgery Murders. By Linda Sillitoe and Allen D. Roberts with a forensic analysis by George J. Throckmorton. (Signature, $17.95.) Mark Hofmann, a premed student, decided at age 25 to become a professional forger of old documents. For several years in the early 1980's he had outstanding success as he turned the Mormon world upside down while he picked its pockets and cast doubt on some of its fundamental beliefs. His Mormon upbringing and his diligent research into the history of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints enabled Mr. Hofmann to forge papers that seemed to show the prophet Joseph Smith Jr. was a fraud. Mr. Hofmann produced the so-called Salamander Letter, which raised questions about the very foundation of Mormonism, the story of how an angel had led Smith to the gold plates he translated into the Book of Mormon. Highly placed Mormons scrambled to buy and control Mr. Hofmann's forgeries. When he found himself facing exposure, he coldly selected two men who were innocently involved in his fraudulent transactions and left pipe bombs to kill them. One died, and the wife of the other man was killed when she picked up the package. A third bomb, intended for someone else, exploded accidentally in Mr. Hofmann's car, wounding him. Linda Sillitoe and Allen D. Roberts, both Mormon journalists, trace the lives of the major players as the forger and murderer is unmasked. Their research is impressive, but their presentation of it seems to be aimed at a Salt Lake City audience. The effect, frequently, creates a desire to see fewer trees and more forest.

A small crowd is gathered at the perimeter of the field watching the six riders of the green and yellow teams clash on the dusty terrain. The aroma of horses and saddle leather hangs in the air.

title: NONFICTION
description: A DAY AT THE RACES: The Education of a Racetracker. By Barry Gifford. (Atlantic Monthly, $17.95.) The novelist and poet Barry Gifford has devoted his 18th book to what he calls ''a portrait of Thoroughbred horse racing as it exists in the present time on any particular day at any track in the United States.'' He attempts to accomplish this by providing, with no comment, 73 monologues transcribed from interviews with 34 ''racetrackers'' - trainers, owners, grooms, clockers, etc. The result is a narrow collection of raw material that falls far short of the author's goal. Mr. Gifford says he did his research at seven far-flung tracks, but the vast majority of the interviews are from Golden Gate Fields, a second-rate track near his home in northern California. Also, 35 of the book's 73 passages come from only three of the interview subjects, and their voices wear thin. But the book's major problem is the lack of an expert voice that can sift through the interviews and comment on their truth or relevance. For example, a gambler claims to lose money only once in every 300 trips to the track. He does not disclose his secret and any real horseplayer knows his statement is absurd, but Mr. Gifford gives the reader no choice but to believe it. He writes in a brief and irrelevant epilogue about a day spent at the Longchamps track in Paris: ''The race was 2,000 meters on the grass, as, of course, all European races are.'' Actually, European races are run at many different distances and most but not all are on grass. Perhaps it is best that Mr. Gifford did not attempt to provide his own voice as that of an expert.

title: Venice Inside and Out
description: Inside Venice, for us, was located only two brisk turns behind San Marco, ''the central building of the world,'' in the city that in certain moods looks as if it might still, for coherent beauty, rank as the central city of the world. In 1987, when we were looking for a pied-a-terre in Venice, we were unexpectedly offered one, gratis, by a learned and charming Bolognese doctor, at that time unknown to us, who happens to agree with Ruskin about San Marco and the esthetic perfections of La Serenissima - the most Serene, an old name for Venezia. For several weeks we set up housekeeping in his 16th-century flat on Calle Larga San Marco. Inside the center of the center. ''Saint Mark's Wide Street,'' the street we came back to footsore several times a day for meals and sleep, may have been considered a wide street 300 years ago, but if four tourists wanted to walk abreast in it, the fourth would have to be halved, like the viscount in Italo Calvino's angry postwar fable, ''Il Visconte Dimezzato.'' Calle Larga San Marco is a busy, noisy street, a prime trinket street where you can also find international couture, but our refuge - of four (or five) low-ceilinged rooms - is so secretively buried within the edifice that our serenity was never disturbed. One of our two courtyards was a well, surrounded on three sides by our windows and on the fourth by the never-opened windows of the circumambient hotel, defended against our gaze by metal shields that the Italians call saracens. Where we were exactly in the indistinct complex, or who owns what part of the building, remains perplexing. Our remarkable host put in the plumbing himself, and doing the pipe work must have been a nightmare, what with the seven-inch beams and the property confusions combined. For the first time I understand how a family could be hidden in a space whose location would be hard to imagine, let alone detect - as happened with Anne Frank's family in Amsterdam or Art Spiegelman's parents in Poland. In fact, our apartment, too, has a secret room behind a closet door, scarcely more than a bed wide, fitted up with bunk beds and books.

description: The marriage of Natalie Anne Branchini, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Caesar Branchini of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., to David Joseph Kirby 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kirby 2d of the Bronx and Miami Beach, took place yesterday at the Holy Name of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Croton-on-Hudson. The Rev. Gennaro L. Gentile performed the ceremony. The couple are fourth-year students at the New York Law School.

title: U.S. VIEW IS MIXED ON JORDAN MOVES
description: The moves by King Hussein of Jordan to reduce his role in the West Bank will complicate American efforts to arrange Arab-Israeli peace negotiations, but do not necessarily kill the American peace plan, according to American officials and foreign diplomats.

title: 'WHO WANTS TO SAVE THAT OLD THING?'
description: JOHN W. SHANNAHAN, the executive director of the Connecticut Historic Commission, oversees the state's programs to preserve its cultural heritage, including its historic buildings. He is also the state's historic preservation officer and is responsible for historic preservation programs of the National Park Service, such as nominating buildings to the National Register of Historic Places.

title: High Tide, Fat Fish: Story for a Sunday Afternoon
description: IT was high tide on a Sunday afternoon and the fishermen were lined up along Bayville's beach. The swimming season had not yet begun, and out-of-towners were still welcome. There is something reassuring about a group of men standing or sitting quietly at the waterfront, attending to their fishing rods with calm, deliberate motions, ignoring the passage of time.

title: SOVIET CHIC
description: SLAVA ZAITSEV stares dolefully at the chalky walls of his office in the Dom Modi, one of Moscow's premier fashion houses.

description: While King John prepares for a summer stint in Central Park, the City University of New York is planning some Shakespeare of its own.

title: America's Cup: On to the Future
description: THE long-awaited decision by the Supreme Court of New York came last week and so we are going to see in September perhaps the strangest race ever staged on land, sea or air between humans, animals or machines.

title: BUSINESS FORUM: EMPLOYEE BENEFITS FOR THE 1990's; Business Needs a Family Policy
description: EFFECTIVE July 1, all permanent Connecticut state employees are entitled to 24 weeks of family leave within any two-year period, upon the birth or adoption of a child or the serious illness of a child, spouse or parent of the employee. A medical leave of absence of 24 weeks is also permissible if the employee should become seriously ill. Upon expiration of the leave, the employee is entitled to her or his original job. If that position is not available, an equivalent position with equivalent pay must be offered.

title: Gaps and Surprises on Museum Tour
description: ''Meet me at Stop No. 6,'' urges the friendly voice on the Metropolitan Museum's audio-cassette tour. ''It's Edouard Manet's 'Boating.' You'll find it by walking past Manet's 'Woman With a Parrot' to the other side of the gallery.'' Museum visitors who arrive at the rendezvous wonder if they've been stood up. Manet's ''Boating'' isn't there.

title: Reviews/Music; Roy Orbison Mines Some Old Gold
description: Roy Orbison, who played at Pier 84 Wednesday night, got right to the point: he opened his show with his hit ''Only the Lonely,'' setting the open spaces in the tune's arrangement ringing with his quivering, over-ripe falsetto.

title: BUSINESS FORUM: EMPLOYEE BENEFITS FOR THE 1990's; Long Leaves Hurt Small Companies
description: Legislation is pending in Congress that would mandate 10 weeks of leave without pay for parents, after which workers would have a right to reclaim their jobs. William C. Dunkelberg, dean of the School of Business at Temple University and chief economist of the National Federation of Independent Business, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman about the economic impact of extended periods of parental leave.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: During a recent visit to Moscow and Leningrad to present a film about the Broadway theater to Soviet high school students, I was eager to experience as much Russian theater as possible. I found that the Intourist sevice desk at my hotel posted lists of over 30 state-supported theaters presenting musical and dramatic attractions on a daily basis. Unfortunately, the hotel ticket agents offered only tickets to the Circuis or the Ice Show.

description: MAYOR KOCH returned home from abroad last week to find a city - his city - where ambulances were breaking down at a fearsome clip, where hypodermic needles and other debris were rolling in with the tides. But still his homecoming with reporters in the foyer of City Hall turned to a discussion of Irish politics.

description: The United States has been rebuffed in an effort to win a strong denunciation of Nicaragua from Central American Foreign Ministers, senior Costa Rican and Guatemalan officials say.

description: More than a century after they were discovered in a mansion here, three colonial-era murals have been restored and put on public display.

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: Ray Warners's letter (Travel, May 29) expressing disappointment due to unfufilled promises from Intourist during a Soviet tour is no surprise to anyone who has been there. The Intourist attitude is arrogant and often misleading.

title: A Devoted New York City Fireman in Every Way, Save One
description: When the end of World War I was announced, 10-year-old Louis Albert Taube climbed into the driver's seat of a horse-drawn fire engine, pulled the steam whistle and decided he was going to be a fireman.

title: From the '50's, 'Summer Cooking' Remains Fresh
description: A NEW edition of ''Summer Cooking'' by Elizabeth David has just been published by Penguin ($8.95, paper). First published in 1955, it remains as fresh as ever. ''A grilled chicken is perhaps one of the nicest foods at any time,'' is a statement that could be written today.

title:
ART;
Allegories With Hispanic Roots
description: LEAD: ''AMERICANOS,'' at the East Hampton Center for Contemporary Art, comes at a time of increasing recognition for the contributions of ethnic groups as a major creative force.

title: View From Sidelines Of the Fast Lane
description: Even at practice, the Indy-style cars whirled around the track sounding more like a swarm of enraged hornets than precision-engineered race cars. Ten-year-old Russell Decker of Clifton covered his ears, his grin a partial grimace. ''Wow, Dad! Did you see that! How fast are they going, how fast?'' Michael Decker, 42, a machinist in Little Falls, shook his head. ''I don't know, but pretty fast, that's for sure,'' he said. Like thousands of other curious spectators and racing enthusiasts who came to the Meadowland sports complex recently to view qualifying runs for the Marlboro Grand Prix, the Deckers wanted a chance to ''watch fast cars close up and not on TV.''

title: Arts Council Announces $22.6 Million in Grants
description: LEAD: The State Council on the Arts has announced fiscal 1989 awards totaling $22.6 million to 562 organizations and 85 individual artists.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Yankee Interns
description: LEAD: As job titles go, ''Yankee Intern'' has a nice ring to it. At least Eric Weinberger thinks so. Mr. Weinberger, who begins his senior year at Yale this fall, is a Yankee Intern at Lyndhurst this summer. His job is to organize several thousand letters, documents and photographs into an orderly record of the last 100 years of the mansion's history.

title: Walker Hospitalized
description: Greg Walker, the Chicago White Sox first baseman, suffered an apparent seizure and collapsed on the field yesterday before a game against the California Angels in Chicago.

title: Seduced by 'Les Liaisons Dangereuses'
description: Dianne Wiest intended but didn't get a chance to see Christopher Hampton's ''Liaisons Dangereuses,'' which closed rather abruptly when the Royal Shakespeare Company vacated Broadway's Music Box Theater after four months in 1987. Now, as she undertakes the role of the Marquise de Merteuil in the first major American production of the play - opening Tuesday at the Williamstown Theater Festival - she especially regrets not having seen Lindsay Duncan in the part. (The New York-based Mirror Repertory Company opened a production of the play in Belfast, Me., last week.) ''I'm not one of those purists who doesn't want to see any other interpretation,'' explains Ms. Wiest. ''There are always things you can learn. In fact, there are always things you can feel, and that always put you far ahead of the game,'' she says, laughing appreciatively at her own candor.

title: Pam McGinley Plans to Wed in October
description: The engagement of Patricia Ann McGinley to Scott Murray Quackenbush, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert G. Quackenbush of Orlando, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald H. McGinley of Short Hills, N.J., and Hobe Sound, Fla. An October wedding is planned.

title: 'Die Hard' Calls to the Kidult
description: ''Die Hard,'' which sounds like a dozen other movies anyone might name, is for that reason, as well as a couple of others, a nearly perfect movie for our time. Bear with me, plot synopsis and all. ''Die Hard'' is about a New York cop, John McClane (Bruce Willis), who faces down a gang of European terrorists on the top floors of a brand-new, computer-controlled, high-rise office building in Los Angeles's Century City.

title: What Once Was Under Is Now Over
description: THEIR mothers and grandmothers - according to the famous advertisements that ran from the late 1940's into the 60's - dreamed of showing up at the poshest of places clad in their Maidenform bras. Last Thursday night at a disco party at the Copacabana nightclub, a hundred or so avant-garde denizens of the city's fashion subculture made mom's and grannie's dream come true.

title: Question Of the Week; Are You Following The Leadup To the Olympics?
description: The concept of the Olympics celebrating the promotion of peace and understanding through international amateur-athletic competition, has disappeared. During the past five Olympics, including 1988, the Olympics have been reduced to a forum for politics, professionalism, nationalism and terrorism, all elements contrary to the spirit of the Games.

title: Possessing Dukakis
description: WE CAN ALL agree: the 1988 Democratic National Convention was Michael S. Dukakis's.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: Outbreaks of respiratory problems on hot summer afternoons at the Shore may be caused by smog, according to scientists who have examined the problem.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WAY-PAVER. By Anne Devlin. (Faber & Faber, Cloth, $14.95; Paper, $4.95.) Most of the nine tales in this collection of short stories by the Irish playwright Anne Devlin do not dwell on the ''troubles'' that plague Northern Ireland. They are about ordinary subjects - possessive lovers, unrequited passion, unfaithful husbands - and they are often uninspiring.
